2025 Supreme Court Environmental Decisions Recap: Limiting EPA’s Use of “End-Result” Provisions in NPDES Permits,12/31/2025,"<p>As we look forward to 2026, we wanted to share with you a series of blogs to recap of some of the worst U.S. Supreme Court decisions that will shape our ability to protect our environment for decades to come. (Blog 4/4)&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Supreme Court Limits EPA&rsquo;s Use of &ldquo;End-Result&rdquo; Provisions in NPDES Permits&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>In <a href=""https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/24pdf/23-753_f2bh.pdf"">City &amp; Cty. of S.F. v. EPA, 145 S. Ct. 704 (2025)</a>, the Supreme Court struck down certain narrative (as opposed to numeric) standards that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) had included in San Francisco&rsquo;s National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit under the Clean Water Act (CWA).&nbsp;</p>

<p>NPDES permits are required for discharges of pollution from a point source into waters of the United States. In this case, the San Francisco&rsquo;s wastewater treatment plant had a permit issued by EPA.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Typically, an NPDES permit specifies discharge limits or treatment requirements, whether they be numeric (e.g., pH) or narrative (e.g., &ldquo;no visible sheen&rdquo;) limits. If the permit holder complies with those requirements, the &ldquo;permit shield&rdquo; provision in the CWA deems them in compliance with the Act. This approach provides regulatory certainty: following the permit&rsquo;s explicit terms should protect the permittee from additional liability.&nbsp;</p>

<p>However, in 2019 the EPA added two provisions to San Francisco&rsquo;s wastewater treatment permit that imposed liability if the water receiving the discharge failed to meet certain quality standards, regardless of whether the City had met all other permit conditions. One provision prohibited any discharge that &ldquo;contributes to&rdquo; a violation of applicable water quality standards. The other prohibited any discharge that &ldquo;creates pollution, contamination, or nuisance&rdquo; under California law. These types of limits are quite comment in NPDES permits, and can allow the permittee the flexibility on how to create the most cost-effective way to comply with these requirements.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Court, in overturning the permit, created a new term &ldquo;end-result provision&rdquo; and held that the CWA authorizes the EPA to impose limitations that are within the permittee&rsquo;s control, such as limits on the facility&rsquo;s own discharges, not broad results that depend on downstream conditions influenced by many other factors (e.g., the end result). By requiring San Francisco to ensure downstream water quality regardless of other pollution sources, the Supreme Court held that EPA exceeded its statutory authority. This decision unnecessarily removed a tool from the EPA&rsquo;s regulatory belt, one that will likely make it harder to keep our waters clean.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>This case illustrates how <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PA-and-a-Post-Chevron-World"">Loper Bright Enterprises v. Raimondo</a> continues to shape judicial review of agency actions. In <em>Loper Bright</em>, the Court ended the <em>Chevron</em> doctrine, meaning courts no longer defer to an agency&rsquo;s reasonable interpretation of ambiguous statutes. Instead, judges independently interpret the law&rsquo;s meaning. Here, the Court analyzed the Clean Water Act and concluded that Congress only empowered the EPA to regulate a permittee&rsquo;s own discharges not to hold it responsible for the condition of the water body as a whole. Under <em>Chevron</em>, the Court would have analyzed whether the EPA&rsquo;s interpretation of the Clean Water Act was reasonable, and if it was, they would give their interpretation deference, most likely siding with them over these provisions. Now under <em>Loper Bright</em>, the Court is given the final say in how the EPA, and other agencies, are allowed to fulfill their statutory charges. In this case, determining that the EPA&rsquo;s long-used &ldquo;end-result provisions&rdquo; are not authorized.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s attorneys are working hard to protect our environment and the rule of law. Support our efforts by donating to our <a href=""https://secure.everyaction.com/qR5o_vCadkOYejqXlMyN6Q2"">Legal Environmental Advocacy Fund (LEAF)</a> today!</p>

2025 Supreme Court Environmental Decisions Recap: Agencies Don’t Have to Chase Every “What If”,12/31/2025,"<p>As we look forward to 2026, we wanted to share with you a series of blogs to recap of some of the worst U.S. Supreme Court decisions that will shape our ability to protect our environment for decades to come. (Blog 3/4)&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Supreme Court Says Agencies Don&rsquo;t Have to Chase Every &ldquo;What If&rdquo; in Environmental Reviews&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>When the federal government wants to build or permit something big, like a railroad, pipeline, or highway, it has to follow the National Environmental Policy Act, or NEPA. NEPA&rsquo;s main rule is simple: before starting, the agency has to study how the project could affect the environment and determine whether that impact is &ldquo;significant.&rdquo; If so, it must write up an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS), looking at those impacts and mitigation that could lessen them. But NEPA doesn&rsquo;t tell them what decision to make. It just makes sure they have&nbsp;&ldquo;taken a hard look&rdquo; before moving forward.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In this case, <a href=""https://www.justice.gov/d9/2024-06/23975sevencountyfinal.pdf"">Seven Cty. Infrastructure Coal. v. Eagle Cty., 145 S. Ct. 1497, 1507 (2025)</a>, seven Utah counties wanted to build an 88-mile railroad in the Uinta Basin. The agency in charge, the U.S. Surface Transportation Board, put together a huge 3,600-page EIS. It looked at everything from wildlife to air quality. They also mentioned other possible mining and refining projects nearby, but since those were just ideas and not actual plans, they didn&rsquo;t go into detail.&nbsp;</p>

<p>A federal appeals court in D.C. said that wasn&rsquo;t good enough they wanted a deeper dive into all those &ldquo;what if&rdquo; future projects. But the Supreme Court stepped in and said: hold on. NEPA doesn&rsquo;t require agencies to analyze every hypothetical project that might someday exist. They just need to focus on the project they&rsquo;re actually reviewing and its reasonably foreseeable effects.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As a result, it&rsquo;s harder for opponents to argue that an EIS is incomplete. A challenger will need to prove that the EIS didn&rsquo;t include reasonably foreseeable effects. This bar is incredibly high as the Court emphasized;&nbsp;the agency gets a fair amount of discretion in constructing its EIS, and its length or level of detail are up to the Agency&rsquo;s discretion.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This ruling sheds light on an area where <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PA-and-a-Post-Chevron-World"">Loper Bright</a>&rsquo;s power shift does not reach. In <em>Loper Bright</em>, the Supreme Court said judges, not agencies, get the final say on how federal laws are interpreted. That means courts can now take a closer look at the legal framework behind an agency&rsquo;s decisions. But here, the Court still made it clear: when it comes to the nitty-gritty details of something like an EIS, agencies get a lot of discretion. In other words, <em>Loper Bright</em> may have shifted power toward judges on what powers a statute grants, but where the statute is clear as to what it requires of an agency, the technical contents are still up to the agency experts. Even if that deference allows agencies to severely limit the allowable scope of impacts under NEPA review, as they did in <em>Seven County</em>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But like the definition of &ldquo;waters of the United States&rdquo; post-<em>Sackett</em>, NEPA is also being eroded by Presidential and executive agency actions. Earlier in 2025, the Council for Environmental Quality, the agency tasked with implementing NEPA, revoked its NEPA regulations, allowing agencies to rescind and weaken their own NEPA regulations, including by replacing regulations with non-binding guidance. And just like the protection of our nation&rsquo;s wetlands, environmental impact review is now going to fall under the states, many of which do not have the laws set up to allow for this kind of review.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s attorneys are working hard to protect our environment and the rule of law. Support our efforts by donating to our <a href=""https://secure.everyaction.com/qR5o_vCadkOYejqXlMyN6Q2"">Legal Environmental Advocacy Fund (LEAF)</a> today!</p>

2025 Supreme Court Environmental Decisions Recap: Sackett v. EPA and the Clean Water Act,12/30/2025,"<p>As we look forward to 2026, we wanted to share with you a series of blogs to recap of some of the worst U.S. Supreme Court decisions that will shape our ability to protect our environment for decades to come. (Blog 2/4)&nbsp;</p>

<h2><strong>Where the Water Flows: Sackett v. EPA and the Clean Water Act&nbsp;</strong></h2>

<p>In 2023, the Supreme Court of the United States issued a major decision in <a href=""https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/22pdf/21-454_4g15.pdf"">Sackett v. EPA, 598 U.S. 651, 143 S. Ct. 1322 (2023)</a>, redefining the scope of the Clean Water Act (CWA) and reshaping how federal jurisdiction over wetlands is determined. While not as headline-grabbing as some other recent cases, <em>Sackett</em> has quietly redrawn the map of environmental protection in the United States.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The case began when Michael and Chantell Sackett purchased a plot of land in Idaho to build a home. Part of their property contained wetlands, which they backfilled during construction. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) claimed this action violated the CWA, which prohibits &ldquo;the discharge of any pollutant&rdquo; into &ldquo;navigable waters.&rdquo; 33 U.S.C. &sect;&sect; 1311(a), 1362(12)(A). This prohibition applies to &ldquo;the waters of the United States&rdquo; (WOTUS) a term that sounds straightforward, but, as Justice Alito asked in his opinion, what exactly does that mean?&nbsp;</p>

<p>Before <em>Sackett</em>, the EPA interpreted WOTUS broadly. In addition to traditionally navigable waters, it claimed jurisdiction over waters with a &ldquo;significant nexus&rdquo; to navigable waters, a standard that allowed regulation of wetlands and other features connected to navigable waters in ways not always obvious to the naked eye.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Court rejected this &ldquo;significant nexus&rdquo; test as inconsistent with the CWA&rsquo;s text and as granting the EPA jurisdiction far beyond what Congress intended. In its place, the Court adopted a narrower two-part test: First, the party asserting jurisdiction over an adjacent wetland must prove that the adjacent body of water constitutes a &ldquo;water of the United States.&rdquo; Second, the party must show that the wetland has a continuous surface connection with that water, making it difficult to distinguish where the water ends and the wetland begins. This holding significantly restricts the reach of the CWA, limiting jurisdiction to wetlands that are physically and visibly connected on the surface to covered waters. Wetlands that are nearby but separated by barriers such as roads, even if hydrologically connected underground, are now outside the EPA&rsquo;s regulatory reach.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The decision has two immediate effects. First, it narrows the federal government&rsquo;s authority under <a href=""https://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?req=code+of+federal+regulations&amp;f=treesort&amp;num=4317"">33 U.S.C. &sect; 1344(g)(1)</a> and <a href=""https://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?req=granuleid:USC-2007-title33-section1362&amp;num=0&amp;edition=2007"">&sect; 1362(7)</a>, redefining &ldquo;waters of the United States&rdquo; in a way that excludes many wetlands previously covered. Second, it shifts regulatory responsibility for those excluded wetlands to individual states, creating the possibility of a patchwork of protections that vary widely across the country&mdash;the very thing the CWA was developed to protect against.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Unfortunately, <em>Sackett</em> was just the beginning. This November, EPA released its new definition of &ldquo;waters of the United States&rdquo; that is even more restrictive than the Supreme Court directed in <em>Sackett</em>.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>According to <a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/sites/default/files/2025-03/Wetlands_Report_R_25-03-B_05_locked.pdf"">recent calculations by our friends at NRDC</a>, this rule could remove federal protections from a majority of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s wetlands. Wetlands not only ensure cleaner water flowing downstream, they also:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Reduce flooding &nbsp;</li>
	<li>Filter harmful pollution &nbsp;</li>
	<li>Provide essential fish and wildlife habitat&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Store carbon&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>Without streams and wetlands to serve as natural buffers, floodwaters rise faster and hit harder, leaving homeowners, businesses, and taxpayers with massive bills for damage, cleanup, and emergency response. Communities across Pennsylvania&ndash;both big and small&ndash; will face increased infrastructure and water treatment costs if protections are removed.&nbsp;</p>

<p>And while Pennsylvania is lucky to have strong state-level water quality protections, we are not immune from the impact of the &ldquo;Polluted Water Rule.&rdquo; We must <a href=""https://secure.everyaction.com/DySHjxuLw0ivAE9lyrxzbw2?emci=1a89d85c-90df-f011-8194-000d3a1ec8c6&amp;emdi=4c09cddc-20e0-f011-8195-000d3a1d58aa&amp;ceid=6532780"">act now and speak up</a> against the gutting of the Clean Water Act! Comments are due January 5, 2026.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s attorneys are working hard to protect our environment and the rule of law. Support our efforts by donating to our <a href=""https://secure.everyaction.com/qR5o_vCadkOYejqXlMyN6Q2"">Legal Environmental Advocacy Fund (LEAF)</a> today!&nbsp;</p>

2025 Supreme Court Environmental Decisions Recap: Loper Bright in Action: NRC v. Texas,12/29/2025,"<p>As we look forward to 2026, we wanted to share with you a series of blogs to recap of some of the worst U.S. Supreme Court decisions that will shape our ability to protect our environment for decades to come. (Blog 1/4)&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Loper Bright in Action: NRC v. Texas (June 2025)&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>The Supreme Court&rsquo;s recent decisions have fundamentally reshaped the way federal law is interpreted and applied. In our earlier post, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PA-and-a-Post-Chevron-World"">PA and a Post &ldquo;Chevron&rdquo; World</a>, we discussed the landmark case <a href=""https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/23pdf/22-451_7m58.pdf"">Loper Bright Enters. v. Raimondo, 603 U.S. 369 (2024)</a>, which overturned the 1984 precedent of <a href=""https://www.loc.gov/resource/usrep.usrep467837/"">Chevron U.S.A. Inc. v. Natural Resources Defense Council, 467 U.S. 837 (1984)</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Under <em>Chevron</em>, when Congress left gaps or used vague language in a statute, courts would defer to an agency&rsquo;s reasonable interpretation&mdash;trusting the &ldquo;masters of the subject&rdquo; to apply their technical expertise. This approach recognized that Congress cannot predict every future development. For example, in the Clean Air Act, Congress avoided creating a closed list of pollutants, leaving room for agencies to address newly discovered threats to public health and the environment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But in <em>Loper Bright</em>, the Court shifted that responsibility to the judiciary. Now, judges, not agencies with knowledge and expertise, decide the meaning of ambiguous statutory terms. While agencies can still offer expert perspectives, their interpretations no longer receive automatic deference.&nbsp;</p>

<p>On June 18, 2025, the Supreme Court applied this post-Loper approach in <a href=""https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/24pdf/23-1300_b97c.pdf"">NRC v. Texas, 145 S. Ct. 1762 (2025)</a>. The Court held that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) lacked authority under the Atomic Energy Act to license private interim storage facilities for spent nuclear fuel. Reading the statute closely, the Court found that Congress assigned responsibility for long-term nuclear waste storage to the Department of Energy, not private licensees, and that, absent clear congressional authorization, the NRC could not grant such licenses.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The decision has sweeping implications for the nuclear energy sector. It removes a key tool, the ability of private entities to store spent fuel, and shifts the entire burden of storage to the federal government, even though federal capacity is already stretched thin.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Supporters of the Court&rsquo;s shift may welcome the move as a check on agency overreach and a reaffirmation of Congress&rsquo;s role in lawmaking. Critics, however, warn that it could undermine long-standing regulations that protect public health, safety, and the environment. Without agency deference, well-established rules could be challenged, and potentially dismantled, by parties seeking to avoid compliance.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In theory, Congress could respond by updating laws to meet evolving challenges. In practice, a politically divided legislature may lack the capacity or will to act quickly. For decades, expert-driven agency interpretations have helped bridge that gap, freeing Congress to address other pressing national needs. Time will only tell just how far <em>Loper Bright</em> will go in eroding federal protections, and this case was just one of the first examples.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s attorneys are working hard to protect our environment and the rule of law. Support our efforts by donating to our <a href=""https://secure.everyaction.com/qR5o_vCadkOYejqXlMyN6Q2"">Legal Environmental Advocacy Fund (LEAF)</a> today!</p>

Introducing PennFuture's Fall 2025 Interns,11/10/2025,"<p>Since its inception in 1998, PennFuture has emphasized the importance of using the law to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment and &ldquo;create a just future where nature, communities, and the economy thrive.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Over the past two decades, we have achieved significant legal and policy victories that reduce pollution and protect the environment and our communities. We have provided millions of dollars in pro bono legal services while setting critical precedents and enforcing environmental laws across the Commonwealth.&nbsp;</p>

<p><br />
But as PennFuture looks forward to the next 20 years, we recognize that we need to be more involved with cultivating the people that will continue to support our mission. Our staff have a long history of mentoring interns, externs, and fellows, and we wanted to create a more formal program to inspire the next generation. &nbsp;<br />
With the generous support of the George and Miriam Martin Foundation and the Otto Haas Charitable Trust, PennFuture created a paid legal internship program to inspire and mentor students interested in making a difference for our environment. &nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Ultimately, the goal of this program is to provide the organization a cadre of young legal and policy minds interested in taking on the myriad challenges impacting Pennsylvania as well as to further their potential environmental careers. We&rsquo;ve seen success on this front as many of our legal interns have found work in the Pennsylvania environmental legal space. We also hope that providing for a funded internship will help to bring more diversity and inclusivity into the non-profit environmental advocacy sphere. &nbsp;</p>

<p><br />
Over the past five years, our interns have made it possible for PennFuture&rsquo;s legal team to do more, faster, and better! They have supported our litigation efforts against water polluters and fracked-gas facilities, they have drafted comments in support of stronger regulatory protections across the Commonwealth, and they have helped our attorneys strategize and execute impactful legal actions. We are grateful for all of the hard work, passion, and dedication of our legal interns. &nbsp;</p>

<h3>&nbsp;<br />
This fall, we have two fantastic students, including a returning intern, joining us who bring their unique backgrounds and experiences to our mission. We&rsquo;ve asked our interns to explain, in their own words, what environmental law and PennFuture&rsquo;s mission means to them:&nbsp;</h3>

PennFuture Commends Pocono Municipalities for Preparing for Data Centers,8/28/2025,"<p>This summer has brought a flurry of activity from municipalities across the Poconos as they adopt new zoning ordinances to prepare for potential data center development. You can learn more about data centers <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/datacenters"">here</a>.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Poconos&rsquo; recent experience with rapid warehouse/distribution center growth has taught the region the importance of getting zoning ordinances on the books to address this next wave of highly-impactful development. Ordinances give municipalities the power to control where data center development occurs and under what conditions. Without them, municipalities lose this control. That is especially true in Pennsylvania because our Supreme Court has held that the Pennsylvania constitution requires every municipality to allow for every legitimate land use somewhere within its borders. This means municipalities do not have the option of saying &ldquo;no thank you&rdquo; to data centers, and a municipality that fails to address data centers in its zoning ordinance runs the risk of a data center developer bringing a legal challenge against the ordinance. If the developer wins that challenge, they must be allowed to develop wherever they please. Municipalities whose ordinances do not allow for data centers remain vulnerable to these challenges up to the moment they formally announce their intention to adopt an ordinance to &ldquo;cure&rdquo; the exclusion.&nbsp;</p>

<p>One township that learned this the hard way is Clifton Township, Lackawanna County. This spring, the township learned of a developer&rsquo;s desire to build a 17-building data center campus on approximately 500 acres in the township, along with another 500 acres in neighboring Covington Township. Much of this property is located in a residential zoning district, and nearly all of it contains uncut forest and Exceptional Value streams and wetlands. Clifton Township&rsquo;s existing zoning ordinance did not address data centers, so the township quickly drafted an amendment that would limit data centers to its Industrial District and impose commonsense restrictions on them. However, mere hours before the township publicly announced its intention to adopt this ordinance, the data center developer submitted a legal challenge to the existing ordinance. By doing so, the developer &ldquo;beat the clock,&rdquo; and Clifton Township now must defend against the challenge. If it loses, it must allow the data center developer to build in the residential zone, regardless of what the new ordinance says.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Clifton Township&rsquo;s experience can serve as a warning to all Pennsylvania municipalities&mdash;do not wait until a developer is at your door to update your zoning ordinance. Decide NOW how your municipality should regulate these uses if and when they come knocking. PennFuture commends the municipalities in the Poconos that have done just that, including Coolbaugh, Jackson, Chestnuthill, Polk, Clifton, and Covington Townships, and other townships like Kidder, Tobyhanna, and Smithfield that are quickly working toward doing the same.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>As several of these municipalities have acknowledged, their first efforts at data center regulation may not be perfect. Data centers are new uses for most Pennsylvania municipalities, and technological innovations are occurring at a rapid pace. It is very likely that the ordinances adopted this summer will need to be revised and amended in the future as we learn more about how this development will take shape in Pennsylvania. But, municipalities should not let the perfect become the enemy of the good. An imperfect ordinance is better than no ordinance at all!&nbsp;</p>

<p>And municipalities do not have to go at it alone! PennFuture is here to help! Our <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Model%2DData%2DCenter%2DOrdinance%281%29.pdf"">model data center ordinance</a> and<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gdnx39zyNTg""> video series</a> can help municipalities get up to speed and take action quickly to ensure data center growth is appropriately regulated. We&rsquo;ve done the leg work necessary to produce a thorough and considerate ordinance, reviewing ordinances from PA and other states, considering the impacts of this type of land use, and ensuring sufficient local authority over where this new land use should go. Check them out today!&nbsp;</p>
",Community; Energy,"Brigitte Meyer, Staff Attorney"
Here Comes the Sun: PennFuture’s Guide to Planning for Grid-Scale Solar Development,7/9/2025,"<p>Grid-scale solar (large, ground-mounted solar arrays, often referred to as solar farms) is the fastest-growing and least expensive form electric generation in the United States. Pennsylvania has increased its solar power generation by 370% over the past decade, and the future undoubtedly holds even more of this clean, renewable power source. In fact, nearly all of the energy generation projects awaiting approval from PJM, the organization that controls which energy generators can connect to the grid, are grid-scale solar projects.</p>

<p>As the level of government tasked with the job of choosing good locations for all types of land development, municipalities have an important role in ushering in Pennsylvania&rsquo;s bright new energy future. However, many municipalities are considering grid-scale solar for the first time and are in need of information about this type of development in order to make good siting decisions.</p>

<p>That&rsquo;s why PennFuture created <em>Here Comes the Sun: A Municipal Guide to Grid-Scale Solar Siting</em>. This isn&rsquo;t another model ordinance. Many model ordinances for solar already exist. Instead, this publication aims to give municipalities the background and tools they need to evaluate potential ordinance provisions, learn the truth behind common objections to solar, and appropriately plan for grid-scale solar development.</p>

<p><em>Here Comes the Sun</em> is a comprehensive guide that covers a number of topics of interest to municipalities planning for solar.&nbsp;<br />
These include:</p>

<ul>
	<li>What is grid-scale solar?</li>
	<li>Parts of a grid-scale solar system</li>
	<li>What makes a good site for grid-scale solar</li>
	<li>Tips for improving the legal landscape for grid-scale solar, including analysis of common solar ordinance provisions</li>
	<li>The reality of solar on brownfields, warehouse roofs, and parking lots</li>
	<li>Objections based on grid-scale solar&rsquo;s lack of direct connection to local energy consumers</li>
	<li>The truth behind common myths about grid-scale solar.</li>
</ul>

<p>PennFuture is excited to provide this resource to help municipalities across the Commonwealth effectively prepare for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s clean energy future! Download a copy here:&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Publication-Here-Comes-The-Sun-A-Municipal-Guide-to-Grid-Scale-Solar-Siting"">https://www.pennfuture.org/Publication-Here-Comes-The-Sun-A-Municipal-Guide-to-Grid-Scale-Solar-Siting</a></p>
",Community; Energy,"Brigitte Meyer, Staff Attorney"
Introducing PennFuture's Summer Term Legal Interns!,7/8/2025,"<p>Since its inception in 1998, PennFuture has emphasized the importance of using the law to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment and &ldquo;create a just future where nature, communities, and the economy thrive.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Over the past two decades, we have achieved significant legal and policy victories that reduce pollution and protect the environment and our communities. We have provided millions of dollars in pro bono legal services while setting critical precedents and enforcing environmental laws across the Commonwealth.<br />
But as PennFuture looks forward to the next 20 years, we recognize that we need to be more involved with cultivating the people that will continue to support our mission. Our staff have a long history of mentoring interns, externs, and fellows, and we wanted to create a more formal program to inspire the next generation.&nbsp;<br />
With the generous support of the George and Miriam Martin Foundation and the Otto Haas Charitable Trust, PennFuture created a paid legal internship program to inspire and mentor students interested in making a difference for our environment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Ultimately, the goal of this program is to provide the organization a cadre of young legal and policy minds interested in taking on the myriad challenges impacting Pennsylvania as well as to further their potential environmental careers. We&rsquo;ve seen success on this front as many of our legal interns have found work in the Pennsylvania environmental legal space. We also hope that providing for a funded internship will help to bring more diversity and inclusivity into the non-profit environmental advocacy sphere.&nbsp;<br />
Over the past five years, our interns have made it possible for PennFuture&rsquo;s legal team to do more, faster, and better! They have supported our litigation efforts against water polluters and fracked-gas facilities, they have drafted comments in support of stronger regulatory protections across the Commonwealth, and they have helped our attorneys strategize and execute impactful legal actions. We are grateful for all of the hard work, passion, and dedication of our legal interns.&nbsp;<br />
This summer, we have three fantastic students joining us who bring their unique backgrounds and experiences to our mission. We&rsquo;ve asked our new interns to explain, in their own words, what environmental law and PennFuture&rsquo;s mission means to them:</p>

Empowering Voices: The Vital Role of Civic Engagement in Protecting Our Environment,10/29/2024,"<p>Democracy is the cornerstone of our country and the basis of how decisions are made, including those that directly affect our environment. Our own state constitution defines our right to things like clean air, pure water, and preserved natural places.&nbsp;</p>

<p>All of what we do functions within our system of democracy which we as voters have a say in! The people we vote for are the people who vow to uphold that constitutional right of ours.&nbsp;</p>

<p>That&rsquo;s why a civically engaged population is critical to our mission. Our vote is our power, and our Civic Engagement team works every year <a href=""https://secure.everyaction.com/awns8aE-WEmcsPQkttDljw2"">to ensure that everyone is ready to cast their ballot</a>. A functioning, strong democracy and a representative government will lead to stronger, safer environmental protections for us all. But that starts with all of us voting. After so many fought for our right to vote and make our voices heard &ndash; it is important that we exercise and protect that right.&nbsp;</p>

<p>With Election Day coming up on <strong>Tuesday, November 5</strong>, the importance of engaging with our democracy is top of our minds now more than ever. Our Civic Engagement team is ready to help our advocates, members, and subscribers get prepared for this election &ndash; we want to make sure you are all set and ready to vote!&nbsp;</p>

<p>In just a few simple steps, you can make sure you are ready to cast your ballot and make your voice heard:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Make a plan!&nbsp;
	<ul>

		<li>Already requested a mail-in ballot? Drop it in the mail ASAP or drop it off at a local dropbox or your County&rsquo;s Board of Elections office.&nbsp;</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Find out who is on your ballot:
	<ul>
		<li>Your vote is your choice. Every seat on your ballot matters. Check out who&rsquo;s on your ballot and their positions by heading to<a href=""http://www.vote411.org/ballot""> www.vote411.org/ballot</a>.</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Having an issue or need assistance casting your ballot?
	<ul>
		<li>Head to <a href=""http://vote.pa/help"">vote.pa/help</a> to call the Voter Protection Hotline or get personalized assistance from a member of the Vote Navigator team.&nbsp;</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
</ul>
