Because a majority of the Supreme Court had not conclusively rejected the Payne test, the Commonwealth Court continued to apply it for several more years, until the Supreme Court definitively rejected it in a case known as PEDF II.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>PEDF II</h2>

<p style=""text-align: center;""><strong>Pa. Envtl. Def. Found. v. Commonwealth, 161 A.3d 911 (Pa. 2017) (PEDF II)</strong>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The next significant ERA decision by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court came in 2017. In this case, the Pennsylvania Environmental Defense Fund (PEDF) challenged the leasing of state-owned land for oil and natural gas development and the budgetary scheme that dispersed the revenue from those leases. This scheme redirected over $330 million that would have been used for conservation purposes under prior law to the General Fund, where it was appropriated for a variety of state government purposes unrelated to maintaining and protecting public natural resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Court began its analysis by decisively rejecting the Payne test, stating that it was unrelated to the text of the ERA and stripped the ERA of its meaning. This time, four Supreme Court justices agreed with this holding, finally spelling the end of the Payne test. The four-justice majority also affirmed Robinson Township&rsquo;s statement of basic ERA principles, thus solidifying those principles into binding precedent. The Court went on to elaborate on the Commonwealth&rsquo;s trustee duties, firmly grounding these in private trust law. These duties include the duty of loyalty, which imposes an obligation to manage the corpus of the trust so as to accomplish the trust&rsquo;s purposes for the benefit of the trust&rsquo;s beneficiaries, and the duty of impartiality to treat all beneficiaries equitably in light of the purposes of the trust. The Commonwealth&rsquo;s discretion as to how to handle Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources is limited by these trustee duties and the purpose of the trust.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Court also held that the proceeds from the sale of public natural resources, including the sale of oil and gas from public lands, are to be considered part of the corpus of the trust and must be dealt with in the same way as other public natural resources. Therefore, the Commonwealth is not entitled to spend that revenue on general budgetary items in any way it sees fit; those funds must be directed toward the purpose of the trust&mdash;conserving and maintaining Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources. Accordingly, the Court held that the budgetary provisions that took revenue generated from the sale of oil and gas on state lands and placed them in the General Fund without requiring the Commonwealth to put them toward conserving and maintaining public natural resources violated the ERA.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The remainder of the Court&rsquo;s decision, as well as several subsequent decisions, dealt primarily with characterizing the precise nature of the revenue generated by oil and gas leases and the precise scope of the activities that could be funded with that revenue. For example, in a later case, <strong>Pennsylvania Environmental Defense Foundation v. Commonwealth, 279 A.3d 1194 (Pa. 2022)</strong>, the Supreme Court held that a trustee is entitled to incur reasonable costs in administering the trust, and, therefore, oil and gas revenues could be used to fund general operating expenses of the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources such as salaries, wages, and travel expenses for its employees.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Recent Cases&nbsp;</h2>

<p>In the years since Robinson Township and the PEDF cases, Courts have tended to focus on language in those two seminal cases stating that the ERA protects only against unreasonable degradation of natural resources and &ldquo;does not call for a stagnant landscape&rdquo; or &ldquo;require a freeze of the existing natural resource stock.&rdquo; Although Payne&rsquo;s explicit balancing test has gone by the wayside, courts have continued to view the Commonwealth&rsquo;s ERA obligations in terms of a balance between the duty to maintain and conserve natural resources for the benefit of all the people and other legitimate government interests. The effect has been that, when specific government actions have been challenged, courts have focused on whether the challenged action represents an appropriate balance between environmental interests and other concerns or is instead an unreasonable degradation of the environment. In nearly all cases, courts have decided that the appropriate balance has been struck and no unreasonable degradation has or will occur. Often, these decisions have resulted from what courts or local decision-making bodies have found to be inadequate evidence of alleged environmental harms.&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>One such case is <strong>Frederick v. Allegheny Twp. Zoning Hearing Bd., 196 A.3d 677 (Pa. Cmwlth. 2018)</strong>. In this case, residents of Allegheny Township challenged a zoning ordinance that permitted fracking by right in all zoning districts, subject to various restrictions. The Commonwealth Court held that the challengers had not produced sufficient evidence that fracking was harmful to the environment or public health and, even if they had, Township had appropriately balanced those concerns against the economic benefits of fracking.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Courts have also doubled down on the principle, first articulated in <strong>Community College of Delaware County v. Fox</strong> in 1975, that the ERA does not give executive branch agencies like the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) additional powers or authority beyond what the General Assembly has given them by statute. On multiple occasions, courts have held that DEP and other agencies like it cannot create regulations, make decisions, issue or deny permits, or take any other actions based on ERA concerns if there is no state statute allowing them to do so. For example, the Commonwealth Court in <strong>Marcellus Shale Coalition v. Department of Environmental Protection, 193 A.3d 447 (Pa. Cmwlth. 2018)</strong>, invalidated a regulation that required DEP to consider impacts to species of special concern when issuing permits for oil and gas development because the statute that created the permitting scheme only authorized DEP to consider impacts to endangered and threatened species.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The same applies to municipalities, who cannot act beyond the powers given to them by the General Assembly. For example, in <strong>Frederick v. Allegheny Township</strong>, the Court held that municipalities lack the power to replicate the environmental oversight that the General Assembly has conferred upon DEP and other state agencies.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Conclusion</h2>

<p>Courts continue to wrestle with the ERA and the implications of Robinson Township and PEDF II. Courts have never directly addressed what preservation of the &ldquo;scenic&rdquo; and &ldquo;esthetic&rdquo; values of the environment means. The scope of what constitutes &ldquo;public natural resources&rdquo; also remains largely unexplored. Questions remain as to the nature of the Commonwealth&rsquo;s duty to act affirmatively to protect the environment by passing laws. Few cases have delved deeply into the question of what &ldquo;prudence, loyalty, and impartiality&rdquo; look like in the context of preserving and maintaining public natural resources. The Pennsylvania Supreme Court has not elaborated on the proper approach to balancing the rights guaranteed by the ERA with other legitimate government interests like promoting economic development, and it is unknown whether it will approve of the two-part test created by the Commonwealth Court in Frederick Township.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As these questions percolate through the courts, PennFuture&rsquo;s legal team is dedicated to protecting and defending our fundamental constitutional right to a healthy environment through litigation and regulatory commenting. To learn more about PennFuture&rsquo;s legal efforts on the ERA, visit our webpage on the ERA. To view the PennFuture ERA Policy Brief, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/ERA%2DPolicy%2DBr.pdf"">click here</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Brigitte Meyer, Staff Attorney"
"The Delaware River has a pollution problem, and PWD can’t scare it into going away",2/23/2024,"<p>Philadelphians received a troubling email from the water department over Presidents&#39; Day weekend, threatening higher water rates. Proposed new water quality standards will require the Philadelphia Water Department (PWD) to reduce the pollution it discharges into the Delaware River in order to help improve water quality and save the endangered Atlantic Sturgeon. Instead of explaining this, PWD attempted to scare its customers and policymakers by tying a cleaner Delaware River to high rates. This is unconscionably false, and the PWD&rsquo;s missive failed to mention the pollution problem in the Delaware River it helped create, and used misinformed data to rile up ratepayers. If you got this email, you may have asked yourself, &quot;Why is my water department telling me that the benefits of clean water don&#39;t outweigh the costs?&quot;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Excuse Me, How Much?</strong></h3>

<p>PWD operates three wastewater treatment plants on the River:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Northeast Water Pollution Control Plant</li>
	<li>Southeast Water Pollution Control Plant</li>
	<li>Southwest Water Pollution Control Plant</li>
</ul>

<p>It needs to upgrade these plants to comply with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)&rsquo;s proposed new water quality standards. In its recent communications to ratepayers, PWD alleged that these upgrades would cost $3 billion and that PWD would raise rates by $265 per year to pay for them. These amounts are outdated, based on false assumptions, and designed to make Philadelphians afraid.&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>What Happened: The EPA&#39;s Involvement in the Delaware River</strong></h3>

<p>In December 2022, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-and-Partners-Convince-EPA-to-Upgrade-Delaware-River-Water-Quality-Standards"">EPA granted PennFuture&rsquo;s and our partners&#39; petition</a> for a rulemaking to establish new water quality standards under the Clean Water Act for dissolved oxygen in the urban Delaware River. In layman&rsquo;s terms, the wastewater treatment plants along the Delaware River are old and using outdated technology. As a result, they fail to capture all of the pollution that enters it and instead dump that pollution into the river, including dangerous substances like ammonia, which dramatically lowers the amount of oxygen in the river through a process called &ldquo;nitrification.&rdquo; This ensures that the river is not suitable for most wildlife to live&mdash;including the endangered Atlantic Sturgeon&mdash;as well as people to use the river for recreation. In other words, this pollution leads to the Delaware River being a deadzone in and around Philadelphia.</p>

<p>Then, in December 2023, <a href=""https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2023/12/21/2023-27758/water-quality-standards-to-protect-aquatic-life-in-the-delaware-river"">EPA released a draft of revised standards for public comment</a>. With barely 48 hours remaining in the comment period, PWD chose to push out misleading information to its ratepayers, attacking the science behind the new standards, and claiming that it would enact exorbitant rate increases.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>This is misinformation. PWD&#39;s scare tactics, financial threats, and &quot;either/or&quot; mindset do a disservice to Philadelphians who deserve a clean and healthy river. Philadelphians should not have to worry about whether their water provider is trying to fight against clean water.&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>The Science is Clear!&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>The major government agencies&mdash;EPA and the Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC)&mdash; that watch over the Delaware River agree. Wildlife, including the endangered Atlantic Sturgeon, live in the urban reaches of the Delaware River, and they need higher <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/national-aquatic-resource-surveys/indicators-dissolved-oxygen"">dissolved oxygen</a> regularly to thrive. Stronger water quality standards that reduce pollution in the river and increase dissolved oxygen levels are essential to restore these majestic creatures to full population health, protect other fish vital to the river ecosystem, and support recreational and commercial fishing. You can read more about this in <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/2024.2.20%2DFinal%2DJoint%2DEPA%2DProposed%2DWQS%2DComments.pdf"">PennFuture&rsquo;s comments</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Of course, getting the water to hold higher dissolved oxygen levels does not happen overnight. The dissolved oxygen levels in the Delaware River are low because of discharges from wastewater treatment plants.</p>

<p>To prevent this nitrification process from happening in the Delaware River, PWD needs to upgrade their wastewater treatment plants. The plants need to reduce the amount of ammonia they discharge, or nitrify it, before discharging it so it won&#39;t pull dissolved oxygen out of the Delaware River.</p>

<h3><strong>PWD&#39;s Eye-Popping $3 Billion Cost Estimate Is Too Bad To Be True</strong></h3>

<p>PWD&rsquo;s email to ratepayers told them that it would cost $3 billion to upgrade its three facilities. That number sounds shocking. PWD <a href=""https://delawarecurrents.org/2021/03/24/delaware-river-dissolved-oxygen/"">linked to some sources</a> connecting to a report that the <a href=""https://www.nj.gov/drbc/library/documents/NitrogenReductionCostEstimates_KleinfelderJan2021.pdf"">DRBC commissioned in 2021</a> to estimate conservative upgrade costs for PWD&rsquo;s plants, under four possible scenarios&ndash;and PWD&rsquo;s number only looks at the most expensive one. Again, this number is not based on the cost of the actual proposed regulation. A more realistic estimate would look at the specific requirements of the proposed regulation. What PWD has done here is like getting a single quote for a home-improvement project where you include every possible upgrade, just to see how much it&rsquo;d all cost.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Importantly, EPA provided a different estimate for the costs of upgrading. <a href=""https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2023/12/21/2023-27758/water-quality-standards-to-protect-aquatic-life-in-the-delaware-river"">EPA&#39;s estimate</a> for upgrading all of the impacted wastewater treatment plants&mdash;only three of which are PWD&rsquo;s&mdash;is $137 million per year. Let&rsquo;s repeat that: That is $137 million for all the plants along this stretch of the Delaware. EPA estimates that PWD&rsquo;s three plants will require approximately $78 million per year. But PWD told ratepayers it needs $3 billion for just its three plants and didn&rsquo;t provide ratepayers any sense of what that could mean per year. The math doesn&rsquo;t add up!</p>

<p>PWD didn&rsquo;t tell ratepayers, but later in the week wrote in its official comments to EPA, that it commissioned its own studies to get its own cost estimates. However, PWD hasn&rsquo;t made it clear what the basis is for its estimates. Without understanding how PWD got to the numbers it did, it is hard for anyone else to evaluate what the costs are and how to pay for them.&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Why Water Rates Don&#39;t Need To Increase</strong></h3>

<p>Here&rsquo;s the kicker: PWD does not have to raise rates to pay for all of these upgrades. It can take advantage of significant state and federal infrastructure funding. Funds are available through several federal programs&mdash;the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA), the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL), and other sources&mdash;to make the necessary improvements to its wastewater treatment plants.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Municipalities and utilities like PWD have the opportunity to access federal funds for system upgrades. On February 20, 2024, <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/biden-harris-administration-announces-58-billion-president-bidens-investing-america"">the Biden administration announced over $5.8 billion</a> for states, Tribes, and territories to invest in drinking water and clean water infrastructure upgrades. The funding focuses on essential water infrastructure that protects public health and treasured water bodies nationwide. Almost half of this funding will be available as grants or principal forgiveness loans, ensuring funds reach underserved communities most in need of investments in water infrastructure.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In total, the Biden administration has invested $50 billion in the nation&#39;s water infrastructure through the BIL. Pennsylvania&#39;s water infrastructure has already benefited&mdash;<a href=""https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/biden-harris-administration-announces-more-200-million-pennsylvania-drinking-water"">receiving $782,982,000 in investments from the BIL since 2022</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The ARPA is another source of federal funds. Philadelphia received $1.4 billion from the federal government via ARPA to assist with relief efforts related to the COVID-19 pandemic and recession, and to invest in its water infrastructure. <strong>Philadelphia</strong> <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/2022-11-03-what-the-american-rescue-plan-means-for-philadelphia/""><strong>must allocate $449 million by the end of this year</strong></a>. <strong>To date, it has not done so</strong>.</p>

<p>Philadelphia can use the ARPA funding to invest in long-term upgrades to our aging water infrastructure system and reduce the need to fund these projects through debt service or rate increases. It can do all this without negatively impacting PWD&rsquo;s ability to borrow money at the most favorable rates.</p>

<p>Indeed, PWD has already planned to do at least a portion of this work. PWD intends to <a href=""https://water.phila.gov/drops/virtual-presentation-for-planned-deammonification/"">build a sidestream treatment facility</a> to reduce the ammonia load moving through the Southwest Water Pollution Control Plant. PWD&#39;s own estimates are that this sidestream plant will solve 10% of the ammonia problem by itself. PWD plans to pay for this through a grant from Pennsylvania&#39;s PENNVEST fund, not through an increase in water rates.&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Philadelphia Can&mdash;And Should&mdash;Have Both a Healthy Delaware AND Affordable Water Rates</strong></h3>

<p>PWD&rsquo;s actions to set up a false narrative is a loss for us all and greatly reduces our confidence in its ability to manage Philadelphia&rsquo;s aging water system. To start rebuilding trust, PWD should publicly rescind its e-mail and update its information to reflect the truth&mdash;upgrading its three wastewater treatment plants is necessary and can be done without raising water rates.</p>

<p>We all want the same thing&mdash;a healthy Delaware and affordable water rates. Instead of fear-mongering, PWD should figure out how to make the river cleaner and healthier and what resources are available to help fund that work. PennFuture will continue to hold PWD accountable for equitable rates and a healthy and productive Delaware River. Millions of people use the river for recreation, food, and work. Our goal is to ensure they can do so for years to come.</p>
",Environment,"Emma Bast, Staff Attorney; Jessica O'Neill, Senior Attorney"
"Zoning, Not Popular Vote, Should Determine 'Warehouse' Development",2/8/2024,"<div><span style=""white-space: normal;"">A recently-proposed bill in the Pennsylvania legislature has attracted the attention of residents concerned about the proliferation of logistics facilities such as warehouses and distribution centers. This bill (HB 1960), proposed by Rep. Emrick of Lower Nazareth, Northampton County, would subject local land development approval of certain warehouses and distribution centers to a public referendum, effectively giving the public standardless veto power over this type of development. While this bill reflects an admirable response to community outcry and a desire for more control over a form of development that can cause significant traffic, aesthetic, health, and environmental impacts, the mechanism it offers misses the mark.&nbsp;</span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>To see why this is the case, consider an illustration: You are driving through an unfamiliar town and see that the posted speed limit is 45 mph. You are cruising along at 40 mph and obeying all known traffic laws, so you are surprised when a police officer pulls you over and writes you a ticket. &ldquo;What&rsquo;s the problem, officer?&rdquo; you ask, &ldquo;The sign says the speed limit is 45 mph. I was only going 40 and haven&rsquo;t done anything else illegal that I know of.&rdquo;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&ldquo;I know,&rdquo; says the police officer, &ldquo;but, we have a law that says that a driver can be ticketed if local residents don&rsquo;t approve of the way they are driving, even if they are following the traffic laws. Some of the folks who live on this street called the station and said they didn&rsquo;t like how fast you were going, so I have to write you a ticket.&rdquo;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&ldquo;That&rsquo;s not fair!&rdquo; you exclaim. &ldquo;You&rsquo;re telling me I can get a ticket just because local residents &lsquo;don&rsquo;t like&rsquo; how I&rsquo;m driving?! How am I supposed to know what kind of driving they&rsquo;ll approve of? What keeps me from getting a ticket just because they don&rsquo;t like my car or the way I look?! How do I know they won&rsquo;t change their mind about what they approve of next time I drive through here?! If they wanted the speed limit to be lower, they should have gotten the law changed and put up new signs!&rdquo;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&ldquo;Maybe,&rdquo; says the police officer with a shrug, &ldquo;but they&rsquo;re the ones who live here and they agreed they don&rsquo;t like the way you&rsquo;re driving today, so that&rsquo;s the way it is. Have a nice day.&rdquo;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <span style=""white-space:pre""> </span></div>

<div>If you were this driver, you would be right to think this was unfair. Most of us understand that we have a right to know ahead of time whether our actions are lawful and what specific standards we must follow to comply with the law. We have a right not to be subject to the whims of our neighbors on a case-by-case basis. In fact, this right is so fundamental to our understanding of how society works that it is enshrined in a constitutional amendment that prohibits deprivation of life, liberty, or property without due process of law. In the context of land development, due process means that a person&rsquo;s right to use and develop their property cannot be subject to arbitrary, standardless, case-by-case decision making, even if the decision makers are neighbors and community members.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><span style=""white-space: pre; white-space: normal;""> </span></div>

<div>This is why the type of public referendum put forth by HB 1960 cannot be the mechanism used to control logistics development. Neither landowners nor the community would know ahead of time what type of development would be permitted, and voters could reject or approve a proposed development for any number of reasons, including unfair and unlawful ones. Voters could reject a proposed development simply because they don&rsquo;t think the developer is the &ldquo;right&rdquo; kind of person, because they think their brother-in-law should get to develop the property instead, or because they think a different type of development would be more attractive or personally beneficial to them. Public referendums would also invite unsavory politicking by developers, who may try to influence voting with bribes or other unlawful incentives. All of this would amount to a deprivation of property rights in violation of due process.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><span style=""white-space: pre; white-space: normal;""> </span></div>

<div>But neighbors and community members do have a say in how our communities are developed. Communities&rsquo; ability to guide and control logistics development resides not in public veto power over individual projects, but, as it always has, in municipalities&rsquo; power to adopt zoning and land development ordinances. These ordinances set forth the standards governing land use and development so that everyone&ndash;land developers, decision-makers, and community members alike&ndash;know the rules ahead of time and apply them fairly to all comers. Clear standards, set forth in ordinances and applied by local decision-making bodies in public proceedings, prevent the kind of &ldquo;arbitrary and capricious&rdquo; decision-making that results from standardless public referendums. Landowners can consult ordinances and know with confidence what will and will not be permitted on their land, and neighboring community members can consult them to see what kind of land use and development they can reasonably expect on nearby properties.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><span style=""white-space: pre; white-space: normal;""> </span></div>

<div>Although ordinances may not seem as &ldquo;sexy&rdquo; as a direct public vote on individual logistics development projects, they can accomplish the same goals while keeping the appropriate constitutional safeguards in place. Through ordinances, municipalities can dictate where within a municipality logistics uses may be constructed and impose restrictions to ensure that the significant impacts caused by these facilities are appropriately minimized and mitigated. Pennsylvania residents who are concerned about the impacts of logistics development on their communities should encourage their local officials to review their land use ordinances and determine whether updates are necessary to appropriately control this development. PennFuture has drafted a <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Publications/PennFuture_Ordinance_Manual_7.pdf"">model ordinance and guidebook</a> as well as a community toolkit for just this purpose.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><span style=""white-space: pre; white-space: normal;""> </span></div>

<div>PennFuture applauds state and local officials like Rep. Emrick who have engaged with the issue of logistics development and listened to community members who desire more control over this highly impactful form of land use. While public referendums may not be the solution, Pennsylvania municipalities and residents still have the power to guide and control this development while protecting their communities and the environment from harm. We will continue to work with community members and state and local elected officials to see that this is accomplished.&nbsp;</div>
",Community,"Brigitte Meyer, Staff Attorney"
Mapping Climate Change By Viewing USDA's Plant Hardiness Zones,12/1/2023,"<div>This month, the USDA released the first update to its <a href=""https://planthardiness.ars.usda.gov/"">Plant Hardiness Zone Map</a> in more than a decade, providing a stark, full-color depiction of the progress of climate change.</div>

<div><span style=""white-space: pre; white-space: normal;""> </span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The USDA Plant Hardiness Zone Map divides the country into thirteen hardiness zones based on the annual extreme minimum winter temperature at each location. The extreme minimum winter temperature reflects the average of the coldest temperature reached in a location for each year over a specified time period and provides a reasonable estimate of the lowest temperature one can expect at that location each year. Each hardiness zone covers ten degrees Fahrenheit and is broken into two five-degree half-zones (e.g. zone 5 is divided it half-zones 5a and 5b). <strong>Gardeners and growers use this information to determine which perennial plants are likely to thrive at a location, and the USDA Risk Management Agency uses it to set crop insurance standards. Scientists also use this data to model the spread of exotic weeds and insects.</strong></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The 2023 map is based on the average lowest annual winter temperature for the 30-year period from 1991 to 2020 and incorporates data from more than 13,412 weather stations nationwide. Compared to earlier versions of the map, the 2023 map shows that many hardiness zones have shifted significantly over time. In fact, between 2012 and 2023, about half the country, including much of Pennsylvania, has shifted a half-zone warmer. For example, the 2012 map, based on data from 1976 to 2005, places nearly all of Lancaster County in Zone 6b, with an average extreme minimum winter temperature between -5 &deg;F and 0 &deg;F . <strong>The new 2023 map shows that the average extreme minimum winter temperature in Lancaster County is now five degrees warmer, placing the county in Zone 7a. Harrisburg, Erie, Scranton, Reading, the Poconos, and much of southwest PA similarly have shifted a half-zone warmer from their 2012 zones.&nbsp;</strong></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Plant1.jpg"" style=""width: 940px; height: 788px;"" /></div>

<div><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Plant3.jpg"" style=""width: 940px; height: 788px;"" /></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Comparing the 2023 map to the 1990 map, which is based on data from 1974 to 1986, (link here: <a href=""https://www.plantmaps.com/interactive-pennsylvania-usda-plant-zone-hardiness-map.php"">Pennsylvania Interactive 1990 USDA Plant Hardiness Zone Map</a>)&nbsp;shows an even more dramatic shift. In 1990, approximately half the Commonwealth fell into Zones 4b or 5, with average extreme minimum temperature ranging from -25 &deg;F to -10 &deg;F. Now, only a small portion of the northernmost counties remains in Zone 5b, and no part of the Commonwealth remains in Zone 5a or 4b. This means not only that the coldest temperature one can expect to experience anywhere in Pennsylvania is now ten degrees warmer than it was in 1990, but that the portion of the Commonwealth that will experience these cold temperatures is severely reduced.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>While home gardeners may welcome the extended growing season that comes with warmer weather,<strong> this data signals trouble for some native plants. </strong>A number of native plant species such as balsam fir, and bog laurel and creeping snowberry are already at the far southern fringe of their remaining habitat in Pennsylvania. Research by the Pennsylvania Natural Heritage Program has designated these and more than a dozen other native plant species as &ldquo;extremely vulnerable&rdquo; to warming temperatures. Many of these species, including the white-fringed orchid, the leafy bog aster, bog rosemary, and Labrador tea grow only in bog or wetland habitats that are highly vulnerable to loss or reduction with climate changes..&nbsp; &nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Warmer temperatures also allow invasive insect species that prey on native plants to thrive. For example, the emerald ash borer is an invasive insect that poses a serious threat to the 308 million ash trees in Pennsylvania forests. Cold temperatures help reduce the number of emerald ash borer larvae that survive the winter, but significant larvae die off does not occur until temperatures fall to -10 &deg;F. The 2023 Plant Hardiness Zones Map indicates that the portion of Pennsylvania that can expect to experience temperatures this low has shrunk dramatically since 2012.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Similarly, low winter temperature has a dynamic role in impacting the range and population of the hemlock woolly adelgid, an invasive insect that has infected, weakened, and killed an enormous number of the Pennsylvania state tree, the eastern hemlock. The destruction of hemlocks by this pest has greatly affected Pennsylvania&rsquo;s forest habitats and streams by reducing shelter for wildlife and warming unshaded streams. This, in turn, threatens aquatic species that depend on cooler water such as brook trout, rainbow trout, and the eastern hellbender. Like the emerald ash borer, hemlock woolly adelgids can survive subfreezing temperatures, but their survival rate drops off significantly once temperatures dip below zero, and most will die when temperatures reach -10 &deg;F. As the map below illustrates, as fewer locations experience the extreme cold necessary to keep the population in check, the woolly adelgid&rsquo;s range creeps ever northward, threatening more of these beautiful emblems of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s natural beauty and diversity.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Plant2.jpg"" style=""width: 940px; height: 788px;"" /></div>

<div>The threat posed to our native plant species and the ecosystems they support is just one of the reasons that PennFuture is committed to combating and mitigating the impacts of the climate crisis by reducing greenhouse gas emissions, building resilient communities, and forging a just and equitable clean energy economy in Pennsylvania. Support our work by becoming a PennFuture member today!&nbsp;</div>
",Climate,"Brigitte Meyer, Staff Attorney"
Climate Disruption on Trial: A Major Victory for Environmental Rights in Montana,11/15/2023,"<p>On August 14, 2023, a Montana state trial court decided that the legislature violated the people&#39;s constitutional right to a &quot;clean and healthful environment&quot; by exempting climate change from the standard environmental review to which major projects are subject. It did so after a week-long trial in which the state made no serious effort to challenge the scientific validity of human-caused climate disruption.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>While many climate cases are pending, Held v. Montana is the first constitutional climate decision in the U.S. based on a trial&mdash;and climate disruption lost.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The story is not over because Montana&#39;s attorney general has appealed the decision to the state&#39;s supreme court. But that court has already held that two other legislative exemptions to environmental laws violate the right to a &ldquo;clean and healthful environment.&rdquo;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Background On Held v. Montana</strong></h3>

<p>The case began in March 2020 when 16 Montana youth filed suit. Since 1971, the Montana Environmental Policy Act has required the state to assess the environmental impact of proposed major state actions that may significantly affect the environment. More recently, the legislature adopted an exemption to that act. As the trial court explained, the exemption &quot;bars agencies from considering [greenhouse gas] emissions and climate impacts for any project or proposal, even to assess whether the project complies with the Montana Constitution.&quot;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
In its decision, the trial court made detailed findings of fact about:</p>

<ul>
	<li>The impact of climate change on Montana&#39;s environment</li>
	<li>The harm climate change is causing plaintiffs</li>
	<li>How defendants&#39; actions contribute to both climate change and harm to the plaintiffs</li>
	<li>How the MEPA exemption contributes to that harm and prevents full review of technologically and economically available alternatives to fossil fuels in Montana&nbsp; &nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>A Constitutional Right to a &ldquo;Clean and Healthful Environment&rdquo;</strong></h3>

<p>The court held that the plaintiffs &quot;have a fundamental constitutional right to a clean and healthful environment, which includes climate as part of the environmental life-support system.&quot;&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>The exemption infringes on that right, the court held, and thus is subject to strict scrutiny. Under Montana constitutional law, a law (like this exemption) that infringes on a fundamental right can still be constitutional if it survives strict scrutiny review. To do so, the law must be narrowly tailored to serve a compelling government interest.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The state did not provide any evidence on this issue. Therefore, the trial court held the exemption to be unconstitutional and enjoined the state from acting in accordance with it.&nbsp;</p>

<p><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Montana%2D%281%29.jpg"" style=""width: 640px; height: 640px;"" /></p>

<h3><strong>Previous Cases</strong></h3>

<p>On the merits, the attorney general&#39;s appeal must address prior Montana Supreme Court decisions that appear to weigh strongly against the state.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In Montana Environmental Information Center v. Department of Environmental Quality (1999), the state legislature exempted arsenic discharges from groundwater pumping tests from review under the state&#39;s water quality nondegradation statute. The plaintiffs claimed the exemption violated their right to a &quot;clean and healthful environment.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>They demonstrated that the tests would increase the concentration of arsenic in the receiving water above the concentration that would have required review under the nondegradation statute. The exemption, the state&#39;s Supreme Court held, thus intrudes on the plaintiffs&#39; right to a &quot;clean and healthful environment.&quot;&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>In a later case, Park County Environmental Council v. Montana Department of Environmental Quality (2020), the Montana Supreme Court held that a legislative exemption to MEPA violated the right to a&quot; clean and healthful environment.&quot; The amendment barred courts from issuing injunctions to prevent violations of MEPA.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In this case, the Department of Environmental Quality approved an exploration permit for mining in the Yellowstone River watershed 15 miles from Yellowstone National Park. However, its MEPA analysis did not adequately analyze wildlife and water quality effects. Under the statutory amendment, the company would have been able to continue conducting exploration activities while the MEPA defects were being corrected.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The court held the amendment unconstitutional on its face, using strict scrutiny analysis, because it removed &quot;the Plaintiffs&#39; only available remedy adequate to prevent potential constitutionally-proscribed environmental harms.&quot;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>A Supreme Court Victory Won&#39;t Stop Fossil Fuel Project Approvals</strong></h3>

<p>MEPA requires environmental impacts to be considered before a decision.&nbsp; But if the state considers these impacts, MEPA does not stop the state from approving a fossil fuel project that will be environmentally damaging. So even if the plaintiffs win on appeal, coal mines, gas wells, and oil and gas pipelines may continue to be approved.&nbsp;</p>

<p>However, the state would be required to provide public information about the climate change impacts of these projects and alternatives to them.&nbsp; This information is likely to have some negative effect on these projects.&nbsp; Otherwise, the legislature would not likely have passed the exemption.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<h3><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Montana%2D%282%29.jpg"" style=""width: 640px; height: 640px;"" /><br />
&nbsp;</h3>

<h3><strong>How the Montana Case Relates to Pennsylvania&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s constitution (Article I, Section 27) recognizes that the people have a right to &ldquo;clean air, pure water,&rdquo; and the preservation of certain environmental values.&nbsp; This is similar to the right to a &ldquo;clean and healthful environment&rdquo; in Montana.&nbsp; Article I, Section 27 also requires the Commonwealth to &ldquo;conserve and maintain&rdquo; public natural resources for the benefit of present and future generations. There is nothing like that in Montana&rsquo;s constitution.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania has no statute like MEPA. Still, Article I, Section 27 could be an effective tool to address climate change.&nbsp; Robert McKinstry, an environmental attorney, and I have argued that in an article.&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
In a recent case, petitioners challenged a PA Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) regulation that would reduce carbon dioxide emissions from major power plants. They allege that this regulation, which would enable Pennsylvania to join the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI), was not authorized by the state&#39;s Air Pollution Control Act. The Commonwealth Court agreed with them and issued a preliminary injunction against the regulation in 2022.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>On appeal to the Pennsylvania Supreme court, the Widener Commonwealth Environmental Law and Sustainability Center and Robert McKinstry, as well as PennFuture, supported the regulation.&nbsp; In separate friend-of-the-court briefs, we argued that DEP has statutory authority and that Article I, Section 27 supports the state&#39;s authority to adopt this regulation. A decision on that appeal is pending.</p>

<p>On November 1, the Commonwealth Court issued a permanent injunction against the RGGI regulation. Governor Josh Shapiro has 30 days to appeal that decision to the PA Supreme Court.</p>

<p>Constitutional provisions like those in Montana and Pennsylvania are not silver bullets for fighting climate change. But they can play an essential role in the effort.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"John Dernbach, Board member"
PennFuture Appeals Zoning Approval of Commercial Development in EV Watershed,10/27/2023,"<p>Yesterday, PennFuture <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/2023.10.26---Notice-of-Land-Use-Appeal.pdf"">filed a notice of land use appeal </a>in the Monroe County Court of Common Pleas challenging the decision of the Paradise Township Board of Supervisors granting conditional use approval for a&nbsp; resort and shopping center on the banks of two Exceptional Value (EV) streams.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In short, while we support the development of a resort that actually considers and attempts to minimize its impacts on the surrounding environment, community, and EV waters, we filed this appeal to hold the Township accountable to its own zoning ordinances and the law. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Logistics-Facilities-are-Coming-Is-Your-Municipality-Ready-PennFuture-Releases-Model-Logistics-Use-Ordinance-and-Guidebook"">Having proactive and thoughtful zoning on the books</a> is one of the most important things municipalities can do to protect us from unreasonable impacts, but those zoning ordinances are only useful if the municipality actually applies them and holds developers accountable to the requirements therein.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Background &ndash; Paradise Township&rsquo;s Resort Development Overlay District&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>In August 2022, New York-based developer JSPA Realty, LLC submitted a zoning application to Paradise Township, Monroe County. The developer seeks to build a resort and shopping center on a 240-acre parcel along the banks of Indian Run and Swiftwater Creek, two of the Poconos&rsquo; Exceptional Value streams. The property is located in Paradise Township&rsquo;s Resort Development Area Overlay District, a special zoning district that permits resorts to be combined with a variety of other types of uses such as shopping centers to create integrated developments called &ldquo;Master Developments.&rdquo;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The overlay district is a well-crafted ordinance that facilitates development that diversifies the Township&rsquo;s economy and enhances the tourism industry that has attracted people to the Poconos for over 100 years while also conserving existing stream water quality and other natural features. To accomplish this balance between economic development and protection of the environment and the surrounding community, the zoning ordinance requires the various uses within Master Developments to be &ldquo;integrated&rdquo; with one another and to meet a variety of other requirements.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Master Developments like the one proposed by the developer are conditional uses in the Resort Development Overlay District. This means that the Township Board of Supervisors must hold a hearing to decide if the development can be approved. This is an important stage of the land use approval process where the developer must &ldquo;show its work&rdquo; and demonstrate how its proposal satisfies all the applicable requirements of the zoning ordinance. A developer who does not demonstrate at the hearing how they will go about satisfying the zoning ordinance requirements is not entitled to approval.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Township Approved the Proposal Despite Lack of Integration Between Resort and Shopping Center&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>PennFuture participated in nine hearings on the proposed development. Based on the evidence presented at these hearings, we concluded that the resort is the type of thoughtful, well-designed development that PennFuture supports in the Poconos. The developer&rsquo;s plans and testimony show a project that respects the natural landscape and the exceptional value waterways by minimizing impervious coverage and shaping development around the existing contours of the land. The developer also proposes stormwater and wastewater treatment facilities that will return water to the ground without discharging it into the nearby streams. While we will continue to watchdog the DEP permitting of the project to ensure protection of the EV streams, we believe the resort as proposed will allow visitors to experience the natural beauty of the area, as visitors to the Poconos have for decades, without unduly harming it.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>The shopping center is another story. In order to be allowed in the district, the shopping center must be integrated with the resort as one &ldquo;Master Development.&rdquo; After hearing all the evidence, we concluded that the resort and shopping center were not &ldquo;integrated&rdquo; as required. The Paradise Township Board of Supervisors agreed and found that the developer failed to show how it would comply with this and various other requirements of the zoning ordinance.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>This should have been the end of the story, and the conditional use application should have been denied for these reasons. However, the Board approved the application anyway, believing that the developer could make up for the shortcomings later by complying with certain conditions the Board placed on the approval.&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Municipalities Must Require Developers to Show Their Work Before Development is Approved&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>This is why PennFuture appealed the decision. Pennsylvania law is clear: A developer must show how its proposal will comply with the zoning ordinance at the time the application is submitted. This is why conditional use hearings exist&mdash;for a developer to demonstrate to the municipality and the public precisely how it will meet the ordinance requirements. A township cannot approve an application based on a developer&rsquo;s promise to &ldquo;work things out&rdquo; in the future.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>It is vital that municipalities follow the rules that govern the land use approval process, especially in our special protection watersheds and other sensitive environmental areas. Paradise Township has taken an important first step by enacting an ordinance that appropriately balances protection of the natural environment and the economic needs of the community. However, good ordinances are ineffective if municipalities do not take the next step and ensure that developers follow them. We know that protecting our Exceptional Value waters means municipalities must require developers to &ldquo;show their work&rdquo; before those municipalities approve development, and we will do our best to watchdog local municipalities and hold them accountable should they compromise the health of our environment and communities by failing to follow their own local zoning.&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Support our work protecting local streams and communities by becoming a <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">PennFuture member</a> today!&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Brigitte Meyer, Staff Attorney"
How RGGI Can Help PA Meet EPA’s New Carbon Emission Reduction Standards,10/24/2023,"<p>The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) solicited comments on a proposed rule that will limit the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions that can be released by new and modified fossil-fuel power plants.&nbsp;When the comment period closed on August 8, 2023, over 1.1 million comments had been submitted. According to the EPA, power plants account for at least 25 percent of the greenhouse gas emissions released into the atmosphere, which is nearly twice as much as homes and small business contributions combined.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>In its proposed rule, the EPA found that a technology called carbon capture and storage (CCS) could be used to achieve a 90 percent capture of GHG emissions.&nbsp;CCS involves the capture of carbon emissions from power plants and storing them underground or in the ocean.&nbsp;There are many concerns involved in the use of CCS.&nbsp;The technology is not widely used and will be more expensive for power plants to install than clean energy alternatives such as solar generation.&nbsp;More information about carbon capture and the EPA&rsquo;s proposed carbon rule can be found here.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Although the EPA has designated CCS as the best system of emission reduction (BSER), this does not mean it is the only method states can use to achieve 90 percent emission reduction.&nbsp; States are not required to &ldquo;compel regulated sources to adopt the particular components of the BSER itself,&rdquo; which means states are not required to use CCS to achieve the EPA&rsquo;s emission guidelines.&nbsp;The Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative is one potential cost-effective method of reaching the EPA&rsquo;s target.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>What is RGGI?&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>Thirteen regional states currently use RGGI to reduce GHG emissions and control the amount of pollution released by power plants.&nbsp;RGGI&nbsp;is a cap-and-trade program that limits the amount of GHG emissions power plants can release.&nbsp;The program was started in 2005 with seven member states: Connecticut, Delaware, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, and Vermont.&nbsp;Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Maryland joined two years later in 2007 and Virginia joined RGGI in 2020.&nbsp;RGGI has successfully reduced GHG emissions in these states by more than 50 percent.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>How does RGGI work?&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>RGGI allows participating states to establish a regional cap on carbon dioxide emissions and each state creates allowances based on its share of the regional cap.&nbsp;Power plants with at least one generator with a capacity of 25 MW are required to purchase allowances to cover their carbon dioxide emissions at quarterly auctions.&nbsp;Each allowance enables the power plant to emit one ton of carbon dioxide.&nbsp;These auctions also allow states to track emission levels from individual power plants and ensure that they are paying for the emissions they create.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>RGGI allows the competitive market to standardize the cost of each allowance power plants purchase.&nbsp;Allowances are distributed to power plants from the highest bidder to the lowest bidder.&nbsp;Once all the allowances are allocated, each power plant pays the same amount for their allowances which is based on the lowest bid from the auction.&nbsp;RGGI rules include safeguards at these auctions to ensure that allowance prices fall within a designated price range to provide market stability.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>RGGI operates in three-year cycles.&nbsp;To remain compliant under RGGI, power plants must purchase enough allowances to cover fifty percent of their emissions for the first two years in a cycle.&nbsp; Additional allowances are purchased during quarterly auctions or in limited cases from the secondary market.&nbsp;Power plants can roll over any unused allowances and use them during a three-year cycle.&nbsp;In the third year, known as the control period, power plants must surrender all their remaining allowances, including any unused allowances from years one and two.&nbsp;The control period in RGGI creates an incentive for power plants to purchase fewer allowances to prevent surrendering them at the end of the three-year period, and in turn, encourages them to reduce their carbon emissions.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>RGGI creates benefits beyond carbon dioxide reduction.&nbsp;The revenue generated from quarterly auctions is invested back into the community through &ldquo;energy efficiency, renewable energy, direct energy bill assistance, and other greenhouse gas reduction programs.&rdquo;&nbsp;RGGI generated $374 million in 2021 alone, with 51 percent of the investment focused on energy efficiency.&nbsp; States that participate in RGGI are experiencing a double benefit from the program; a reduction in GHG emissions and a revenue source to fund programs to improve their energy sectors.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>What About Pennsylvania?&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>On April 23, 2022, Pennsylvania published its CO2 Budget Trading Program allowing the State to participate in the RGGI market.&nbsp;This signaled a commitment from Pennsylvania that it was taking ownership of its responsibility to reduce GHG emissions and address its contribution to climate change.&nbsp;Unfortunately, the polluters from the coal industry and their allies in the legislature challenged the rule and brought an action in State court requesting that the law be declared unconstitutional.&nbsp;As a result of a last-minute injunction, Pennsylvania was forced to pull its allowances from the September 2022 auction and cannot participate in the RGGI auctions until the injunction is lifted or the case is resolved.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s withdrawal from RGGI has been a blow to the State&rsquo;s commitment to fight climate change but has also had financial repercussions.&nbsp;Over a billion dollars in energy investment funds may have been lost while Pennsylvania awaits a court decision on the constitutionality of RGGI.&nbsp;Participating RGGI states have prevented the release of 4.4 million tons of carbon dioxide, which also creates a reduction in other pollutants such as nitrogen oxide, sulfur oxide, and particulate matter.&nbsp;Citizens of these states have directly benefited from the $1.2 billion in lifetime energy bill savings.&nbsp;While other states are reaping the rewards of RGGI participation, Pennsylvania is being left behind.&nbsp;The absence of state regulation allows power plants in Pennsylvania to continue to pollute the air we breathe without any accountability and without paying a cent.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>RGGI is Right for Pennsylvania?&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>Citizens across the State of Pennsylvania are feeling the effects of power plant pollution and paying the price with their health.&nbsp;The Shenango Coke Plant was closed on Neville Island near Pittsburgh in 2016.&nbsp;Coking plants are fueled by coke derived from coal and emit similar pollutants to power plants.&nbsp;A recent study conducted by New York University has shown that the plant&rsquo;s closure created a 90 percent decrease in sulfur pollution and local residents experienced an immediate 42 percent reduction in emergency room visits.&nbsp;Those visits further declined by 62 percent after the plant was closed for three years.&nbsp;It&rsquo;s anticipated that additional health benefits including a decrease in asthma cases and cardiovascular disease, will be realized as more time passes since the plant&rsquo;s closure.&nbsp;With both coking and power plants scattered across the State, even a reduction in pollution emissions from these plants could vastly improve the health of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s citizens.&nbsp;RGGI could create these reductions with the added benefit of generating investment funds for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s clean energy infrastructure.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In just a few short weeks, the September RGGI auction will take place without Pennsylvania&rsquo;s participation. Power plants in Pennsylvania will continue to emit harmful pollutants into our air and advance the climate change disaster that is being felt across the world.&nbsp;RGGI could not only provide a solution to this problem but would make it possible for Pennsylvania to comply with the 90 percent carbon emission reduction included in the EPA&rsquo;s proposed carbon rule.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>We can only hope the Pennsylvania Supreme Court will uphold RGGI and the State can participate in the December 2023 auction, although it is unlikely the case will be resolved in time.&nbsp; Pennsylvanians deserve to reap the benefits enjoyed by other participating RGGI states in our region.&nbsp;Power plants need to be held responsible for the harmful emissions they release into the air we breathe.&nbsp;The State could utilize RGGI to create accountability and force power plants to reduce their GHG emissions, which would improve the health and quality of life for all Pennsylvanians.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Energy,Lindsay Williamson
"Riparian Buffers: a Natural, Inexpensive, and Crucial Way to Protect and Improve Water Quality",10/18/2023,"<h3><strong>What are riparian buffers?</strong></h3>

<p><br />
Riparian buffers are the areas of undeveloped land surrounding bodies of water that contain trees, shrubs, and other plants. Riparian buffers protect water quality and create wildlife habitat along creeks, streams, rivers, and wetlands. They offer valuable ecosystem services to nearby human communities, and they act as both an economic driver and financial saver for these communities.<br />
Riparian buffers serve many roles. They provide habitat for wildlife and maintain cool water temperatures to support aquatic life, like trout. They act as sponges, soaking up stormwater runoff, which reduces the occurrence and impact of flooding. They also act as filters by purifying that stormwater, removing contaminants like road salt and vehicle fluids that can get carried into waterways during heavy rainfall events.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Benefits of riparian buffers to PA&rsquo;s waters and communities</strong></h3>

<p><br />
Pennsylvania&#39;s waterways are under threat. <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/Business/Water/CleanWater/WaterQuality/IntegratedWatersReport/Pages/2022-Integrated-Water-Quality-Report.aspx"">More than 30% of Pennsylvania&#39;s 86,000 stream miles are so polluted that the DEP considers them &quot;impaired&rdquo;</a> - meaning that they are too polluted to meet the standards set for them. This includes rivers like the Lehigh, which was named one of the nation&rsquo;s &ldquo;Most Endangered Rivers&rdquo; in April 2023. What&#39;s more, only 2% of Pennsylvania&#39;s stream miles are clean enough to be designated as Exceptional Value, having the best and most protected water quality in the state.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Stormwater runoff is the major source of water pollution across the state. Stormwater carries with it pollution such as sediment, nutrients, and even toxic chemicals. This is especially true where chemicals such as fertilizers or manure are inappropriately applied to the land. Moreover, large areas of impervious surfaces - like parking lots and roofs of industrial buildings - shed stormwater quickly, increasing the likelihood of flooding. If not properly managed, stormwater harms our waters by increasing both the type and amount of pollutants that enter the Commonwealth&rsquo;s waters.</p>

<p>In addition to the environmental and ecological benefits described above, riparian buffers provide a wide range of ecosystem services, which benefit surrounding human communities. These services include:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Capturing and storing carbon in vegetation and soils, which helps regulate the climate and clean the air.</li>
	<li>Mitigating the negative effects of land use, including commercial or industrial development.</li>
	<li>Reducing the cost of and stress on water treatment infrastructure by trapping sediment and pollutants before they reach the water.</li>
	<li>Decreasing soil erosion - the roots of vegetation hold soil in place, even during extreme weather events and flooding.</li>
</ul>

<p>These ecosystem services translate into real monetary value. Riparian buffers in the Delaware River Basin, alone, provide about $11,000 per acre in services each year. The social cost of carbon is approximately $50 per metric ton, so Pennsylvania&rsquo;s 219 million metric tons of CO2 of annual emissions contribute to $10.95 billion in damages every year. However, one million acres of riparian buffer around the state could offset around 70% of that figure, even without considering the other ecosystem service benefits. Case in point, riparian buffers provide up to $9,409 of carbon storage benefits per acre per year in the Delaware River Basin. Additionally, according to regional case studies, watershed conservation in New York was at least $6.5 billion cheaper than a new filtration plant; and, in the Chesapeake Bay, each pound of nitrogen abatement was nearly one-third cheaper when done by forest buffers instead of treatment plants.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>We need to do more to protect riparian buffers from destruction and development.&nbsp;</strong></h3>

<p>And we know that Pennsylvanians support this. Last spring, the Our Pocono Waters campaign commissioned <a href=""https://ourpoconowaters.wordpress.com/2022/05/11/pocono-residents-support-more-action-to-protect-exceptional-value-streams-new-poll-finds/"">a survey</a> of community members in the headwaters of the Delaware and Lehigh Rivers. The results were overwhelming -&nbsp; 94% of residents in the Poconos want their state and local officials to do more to protect and preserve their waterways. And we see similar sentiments from communities throughout the Commonwealth, especially in relation to increased flooding and other climate impacts.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We know that downstream communities experience the cumulative impacts of upstream land uses, including increased, large-scale development. Protecting riparian buffers across watersheds can help mitigate some of those impacts, like flooding and degraded water quality, and can help some of our most sensitive communities from bearing the brunt of this pollution.</p>

<p>Over the years, PennFuture has prioritized stormwater management and has championed riparian buffers and other ways to protect our waters from stormwater pollution and our communities from flooding. In 2017, we drafted a <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PennFuture_StormwaterManual_web_3.20.17.pdf"">Stormwater Ordinance Manual</a> which guides communities to better safeguard water sources. In 2022, PennFuture was <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-Protects-Major-River-Basins-Across-Pennsylvania-in-Stormwater-Settlement"">successful in its litigation</a> against PA DEP, Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission, resulting in stronger protections from stormwater runoff in our major river basins. More recently, PennFuture successfully nominated the Lehigh River for <a href=""https://mostendangeredrivers.org/river/lehigh-river/"">American Rivers&#39; Most Endangered Rivers List of 2023</a>, and supported the publication of Our Pocono Waters&#39; <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/OurPoconoWaters_Report_FINAL_WEB-PDF_8.8.22-%28reduced%29.pdf"">&quot;Economic Effects of Special Protection Stream Designations in the Pocono Mountains Region&quot;.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>Currently, we are actively supporting the passage of the Riparian Buffer Protection Act <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billInfo/billInfo.cfm?sYear=2023&amp;sInd=0&amp;body=H&amp;type=B&amp;bn=1275"">(HB 1275)</a>. This piece of legislation aims to safeguard Pennsylvania&#39;s pristine waterways and to invest in the health of the impaired streams impacting our communities by establishing riparian buffers for all the Commonwealths&rsquo; waterways. Laws like this help Pennsylvania &ldquo;protect the pristine and invest in the impaired.&rdquo;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Riparian buffers and property rights</strong></h3>

<p>In response to bills like the Riparian Buffer Protection Act or local ordinances that establish riparian buffers, opponents of these natural and cost effective solutions to pollution argue that creating or increasing riparian buffers will be a &ldquo;takings.&rdquo; This argument, however, is without merit.</p>

<p>Takings are an exercise of governmental authority in restricting a property owner&rsquo;s use of his property. Taking of private property for public use is allowed by the government, but if it goes too far, then the property owner must receive &ldquo;just compensation&rdquo; for his loss of property. There is much case law and legal standards that apply to help determine when a restriction on the use of property through regulatory actions is a taking. In short, it&rsquo;s a balancing act and, on balance, riparian buffers statutes and ordinances are not a takings.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Regulations that prevent harm to the public or protect a public interest in quality of life and the environment, such as riparian ordinances, are traditionally considered legitimate exercises of the police power that do not constitute a taking. Additionally, many of these regulations, including the Riparian Buffer Protection Act, include exceptions for much of the work that small landowners and even developers may do on their property that could impact the riparian buffer area.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Riparian buffers are an essential way for Pennsylvania to protect and improve water quality and protect landowners and communities from increased flooding across the state while also respecting the rights of property owners. This is why PennFuture supports actions, conservation measures, and legislation that establishes and protects riparian buffers in Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>How can you help protect water quality and riparian buffers</strong></h3>

<p>Check out PennFuture&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/policy-briefs"">Riparian Buffer Policy Brief</a>.</p>

<p>Learn more about how irresponsible development threatens riparian buffers and water quality in the Lehigh River watershed by watching this <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QOg9C_ybIp0"">short video</a>.</p>

<p><a href=""https://act.americanrivers.org/page/50773/action/1?ea.tracking.id=MERms"">Sign and share this petition</a> telling state lawmakers to support HB1275 - the Riparian Buffer Protection Act.</p>

<p>Support PennFuture&rsquo;s efforts to protect the quality of our waters and protect our communities from pollution and flooding by<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate""> becoming a member today</a>!</p>
",Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy; Donna Kohut, Policy Manager for Sustainable Economics"
Renaming Erie’s “Summer of Soot and Sewage” to the Summer of Community Climate Solutions,9/22/2023,"<p>Last week, an article in the Erie Times-News aptly referred to Erie&#39;s summer as the &ldquo;Summer of Soot and Sewage&rdquo;.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Citing poor air quality resulting from widespread Canadian wildfires and numerous beach closures linked to elevated E. coli levels, reporter David Bruce described a &ldquo;double whammy of pollution.&rdquo; More research is forthcoming to understand the record E. coli-related beach closures because some, uncharacteristically, did not follow periods of intense rainfall. However, research shows us an overarching tie between elevated exposure to E. coli bacteria and increased Canadian wildlife burn acreage to a changing climate.&nbsp; With Erie being named the 7th fastest-warming city in the US and July 2023 becoming the hottest month on record globally, we can see clearly that Erie is not immune from climate impacts.</p>

<p>We are facing significant environmental challenges, and research shows we need to take action at all levels and across all sectors to prevent the worst harm. At PennFuture, we advocate to those in positions of power for policy change. However,l to succeed in this role, we rely on the efforts and stories of hardworking scientists, government employees, and social justice, environment, and labor activists, among others on the ground.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Reflecting on Erie&rsquo;s summer, I want to highlight four community activist-led efforts that provide hope and inspiration about our ability to affect change. Based on the examples set by these community advocates, I propose we rename this recent season to the &ldquo;Summer of Community Climate Solutions.&rdquo;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>UE Wabtec Strike &amp; the Green Locomotive Project</strong></h3>

<p>At the beginning of summer, the University of Massachusetts - Amherst Political Economy and Research Institute released a report concluding that if Wabtec committed to producing 1,000 green locomotives per year at its Lawrence Park plant, up to 5,100 well-paying jobs would be created in Erie County alone. Our partner, ReImagine Appalachia, elevated the report from the United Electrical, Radio, and Machine Workers of America (UE) and their Green Locomotive Project. UE&rsquo;s Green Locomotive Project aims to create &ldquo;good union jobs, address climate change, and clean up pollution in the low-income communities and communities of color which bear the brunt of pollution from rail yards.&rdquo;</p>

<p>The Green Locomotive Project was a focal point of contention between UE and Wabtec during a two-month strike of UE&rsquo;s 1,400-member workforce. PennFuture stood in solidarity with UE Locals 506 and 618 in Pittsburgh and Erie, speaking in support of the Green Locomotive Project at two Erie rallies.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I hope the efforts of UE in Erie this summer will be a catalyst for more conversations about Erie&rsquo;s position in the rapidly expanding green manufacturing sector and a more sustainable local standard for development.</p>

<h3>&nbsp;</h3>

<h3>&nbsp;</h3>

<h3><strong>Grow Erie Groundbreaking at Savocchio Opportunity Park</strong></h3>

<p>Right around the corner from Wabtec, the persistence of East Erie residents is setting another example for climate action. On June 15th, Grow Erie, an initiative spearheaded by the Minority Community Investment Corporation (MCIC), broke ground at Savocchio Opportunity Park after 20 years of planning and persistence.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Grow Erie site, a remediated brownfield, will include a new urban agriculture facility made possible by a public-private partnership of MCIC, the Erie County Redevelopment Authority, and Integrated Agriculture Systems. Planned for the site is a commercial aquaponics facility and a community greenhouse. MCIC leader Gary Horton shared his vision for Grow Erie to &ldquo;invest in our neighborhoods, provide employment opportunities, and bring locally-grown food to a food desert.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Lisa Thompson Sayers of the Erie Times-News summarized the potential for Grow Erie to serve as a model by concluding a recent column with, &ldquo;The nation knows Erie well as a political bellwether. When it comes to resolving some of its most damnable and intractable social, economic and environmental ills, let it be a bellwether of change.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Fairview, Girard Resident Opposition Leads to Defeat of Proposed Agricultural Conversion for Business Park</p>

<p>Rural Erie County advocates also claimed victory over the status quo this summer. Erie&rsquo;s history of unencumbered urban sprawl and consequent population decline from its dense community centers bore great economic, social, and economic costs. Habitat loss, increased automobile travel and emissions, and greater inequity between area school districts and communities are just some of the impacts.</p>

<p>While many in Erie understand that reinvestment in Erie County&rsquo;s community cores will bring greater benefits and return-on-investment, polarized politics can get in the way.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The West County Citizens Coalition advocacy shows that the situation is more nuanced at the ground level. A dozen Girard and Fairview Township residents rallied the support of over 1,500 people to fight against converting agricultural land to a business park. Their advocacy, citing concerns of insufficient public transparency and resident engagement, increased stormwater runoff, new traffic emissions, and more, led Erie County Council to rescind approval of the necessary property transfer on August 29th. Less than two months after their initial vote, this unanimous decision effectively ended the business park proposal.</p>

<p>I applaud the concerned citizens of Girard and Fairview Townships for standing up against outdated land use decisions.</p>

<h3>&nbsp;</h3>

<h3><strong>Hold Erie Coke Accountable Calls for Transparency, Community Working Group</strong></h3>

<p><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Untitled-design-%289%29.jpg"" style=""width: 800px; height: 480px; float: left;"" />The work of Hold Erie Coke Accountable (HECA), another group of concerned residents, began in 2019 in response to persistent air and wastewater pollution violations by Erie Coke Corporation. Rather than bringing the plant into environmental compliance, as HECA advocated, Erie Coke chose to dodge responsibility and shutter the plant without alerting employees.</p>

<p>HECA&rsquo;s advocacy continues. HECA became increasingly concerned about the lack of effort by area leaders to ensure opportunities for community engagement regarding the future of the site. As a result, the group sent a letter outlining their concerns to almost 150 Erie regional stakeholders in mid-August.&nbsp;</p>

<p>One of HECA&rsquo;s critical calls to action is the formation of a Community Working Group, mirroring the precedent set for Tonawanda Coke in Western NY. HECA continues to meet with stakeholders and leaders to advocate for the Community Working Group.</p>

<p>HECA remains committed to its principles for site reuse aimed at preventing another EPA Title V Air Permit holder from occupying the site. I appreciate HECA serving as a watchdog advocating for a future for the site, informed by the community and without another emission-belching, bad actor moving in.</p>

<p>A more equitable future for Erie that recognizes the importance of balanced economic prosperity and environmental stewardship will require lessons learned from near and far. This summer has shown that the list of local examples is growing rapidly, and we must build support for leaders who can connect the dots. Thank you again to the community advocates named above and others fighting for a better future for the PA Lake Erie Watershed and its residents.</p>

PennFuture’s Fall 2023 Legal Interns,9/21/2023,"<p>Since its inception in 1998, PennFuture has emphasized the importance of using the law to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment and &ldquo;create a just future where nature, communities, and the economy thrive.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Over the past two decades, we have achieved significant legal and policy victories that reduce pollution and protect the environment and our communities. We have provided millions of dollars in pro bono legal services while setting critical precedents and enforcing environmental laws across the Commonwealth.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But as PennFuture looks forward to the next 20 years, we recognize that we need to be more involved with cultivating the people that will continue to support our mission. Our staff have a long history of mentoring interns, externs, and fellows, and we wanted to create a more formal program to inspire the next generation. &nbsp;</p>

We also hope that providing for a funded internship will help to bring more diversity and inclusivity into the non-profit environmental advocacy sphere.&nbsp;</p>

After moving away and seeing that these sentiments did not permeate in other parts of the world, it became clear that work was needed to help integrate the ideas and policies that I had seen work so effectively in my own home into other places. &nbsp;</p>

The State of Solar Development in PA: Solar Energy Benefits Remain Unrealized,8/10/2023,"<p>According to the <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/Citizens/solar/Pages/default.aspx"">PA Department of Environmental Protection</a>, solar energy currently contributes less than 1 percent of the state&rsquo;s total electricity generation. Despite overall <a href=""https://www.seia.org/state-solar-policy/pennsylvania-solar"">increases across the state</a>, slow solar growth in PA does not align with the rapidly declining costs of installation, <a href=""https://www.energy.gov/eere/solar/homeowners-guide-federal-tax-credit-solar-photovoltaics"">available tax credits</a>, and myriad health benefits of prioritizing solar over fossil fuels. There are more reasons than ever to act quickly to secure Pennsylvanians&rsquo; economic, environmental, and social wellbeing, all of which would be augmented by increased deployment of solar energy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To clarify why Pennsylvania decision-makers must take urgent action to invest in, expand access to, and amplify the co-benefits of solar energy, PennFuture recently released a <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Publication-White-Paper-Solar-Energy"">new report on solar energy</a>. This paper sets the record straight on commonly held myths about solar and recommendations to overcome the largest obstacles to solar energy adoption.&nbsp;</p>

<p><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/White-Paper-Solar-Energy-%282%29.jpg"" style=""width: 400px; height: 400px;"" /></p>

<h3><span style=""color:#696969;"">Solar Myths &amp; Misconceptions</span></h3>

<p>Several&nbsp;myths and misconceptions have led to confusion and worry about the construction of both utility-scale and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Why-Go-Solar"">residential solar</a>.</p>

<p><strong>A few key points correcting common misinformation include the following:</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Pennsylvania receives ample sunshine to make solar generation effective.</li>
	<li>Solar arrays can <a href=""https://www.reuters.com/business/sustainable-business/with-agrivoltaics-we-dont-have-choose-between-solar-power-producing-food-2023-03-20/"">coexist with working farms</a>, providing farmers with a sustainable source of income and the opportunity to maximize profit through agrivoltaics &mdash; the co-location of solar panels and agriculture. Unlike permanent housing developments, solar development and agricultural land use are not mutually exclusive.</li>
	<li>Well-designed modern solar systems are designed to mitigate concerns about erosion, groundwater contamination, and glare.</li>
	<li>The reuse, recycling and decommissioning of solar panels is feasible and sustainable.
