Many panels will continue to generate electricity long after a system is decommissioned and can be used in other applications. When it is time to retire the panels, <a href=""https://www.energy.gov/sites/default/files/2022-02/Solar%20Energy%20Supply%20Chain%20Report%20-%20Final.pdf"">90% of their&nbsp; components are recyclable</a> with current technology, which is continually improving.</li>
</ul>

<p>In addition to the threats posed by solar myths, solar development in PA also faces more concrete legislative obstacles. Bills currently awaiting action in the PA legislature could further solidify the state&rsquo;s dependence on fossil fuels, prevent local efforts to incentivize solar, and burden solar development with greater bonding requirements than dirtier industries. Pennsylvania also lacks bills that strengthen solar access; to combat this issue, lawmakers should enable community solar and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Misguided-Homeowner-Association-Restrictions-Block-Pennsylvanias-Solar-Potential"">curtail HOA solar restrictions</a>.</p>

<h3><span style=""color:#696969;"">Moving&nbsp;Forward from Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Legacy of Dirty Energy and Polluted Air</span></h3>

<p>Solar energy offers a key opportunity to <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-What-We-Learned-from-the-December-2022-Deep-Freeze-Dont-Rely-on-Natural-Gas-When-Its-Fracking-Cold-Part-1."">enhance the security of our energy grid</a>, create <a href=""https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy22osti/82213.pdf"">thousands of jobs</a>, improve <a href=""https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy07osti/41998.pdf"">air quality, and reduce health impacts</a> caused by fossil fuel emissions.</p>

<p><br />
<strong>Policy Recommendations:</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Pennsylvania should increase its solar energy goals through higher Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards (AEPS) targets. The previous AEPS solar goal (0.5% of the 8% renewable energy goal) was attained in 2021, and a more ambitious target is needed. PennFuture supports <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us//cfdocs/Legis/CSM/showMemoPublic.cfm?chamber=S&amp;SPick=20230&amp;cosponId=40010"">PA Senate Bill 230</a>, which would increase the renewable energy goal to 30% by 2030 and permit community solar.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Pennsylvania must encourage solar power development on brownfields and through use of agrivoltaics. The state has plenty of space for solar, especially since solar is a more preferable investment for farms than permanent-conversation developments. Additionally, the Eastern Pennsylvania Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation has found that there are more than <a href=""http://epcamr.org/storage/Abandoned_Mine_Land_Pgm_Fact_Sheet.pdf"">200,000 acres of abandoned mine land in PA</a>, which could potentially host solar farms.</li>
	<li>Pennsylvania needs to implement legislation supporting residential solar access, community solar, and more equitable bonding requirements. Rather than perpetuating the dominance of polluting fossil fuels, PA lawmakers must instead focus on pro-solar policies that will yield greater long-term advantages for their constituents.</li>
</ul>

<p>PennFuture continues its work promoting clean energy and a sustainable future for all Pennsylvanians. Solar energy is undoubtedly a crucial climate solution that is more affordable than ever. Continued solar restrictions, limited funding for renewable infrastructure, and subsidies for dirty energy are simply illogical and are doing a disservice to future generations.</p>
",Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
How Humans are Breaking the Jet Stream and Changing the Weather,7/19/2023,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-624a2864-7fff-bca5-ce8f-0b73f99ad4bd""></span></p>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s weather in 2023 has been strange at best and deadly at worst. Extreme drought in May gave way to historically dangerous air quality in June, with a dash of severe storms and tornadoes for good measure. Forecasters point to wind patterns to describe why the weather has been so extreme. But a deeper dive into what&rsquo;s causing these unusual events points to something more insidious: humans are breaking the Earth&rsquo;s jet streams.</p>

<p>Let&rsquo;s back up and start with the basics before this becomes a sequel to Day After Tomorrow.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong><span style=""color:#696969;"">What is a jet stream?&nbsp;</span></strong></h3>

<p><br />
Jet streams are like twelve-lane highways in the atmosphere. Fast-moving jets of air that circle the globe and are usually found at the height that commercial airlines fly. Jet streams exist because of temperature differences. The sun warms the Earth unevenly because our planet has an orbit and its axis is tilted, so regions around the equator get more solar warmth than regions around the poles. The temperature difference between the colder north and south poles with the equator causes the wind to blow in fast currents.&nbsp;</p>

<p>These jet streams play a huge role in our daily lives. For example, Pennsylvania has faced numerous energy crises because of the polar vortex, where the northern polar jet dips down really far south, bringing with it arctic cold air.&nbsp;</p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-d3dce9d8-7fff-ff8b-694c-15ab453d861b""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(33, 33, 33); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;""></span></span></div>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(33, 33, 33); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;""></span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-624a2864-7fff-bca5-ce8f-0b73f99ad4bd""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(33, 33, 33); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;""></span></span></p>

<p><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Screen-Shot-2023-07-19-at-2.17.20-PM.png"" style=""width: 1198px; height: 736px;"" /></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-0783cf7b-7fff-e4d3-a7d7-7787389525c5""></span></p>

<p>This image above shows the jet streams on June 29, 2023. Notice the faster moving lines closer to the very top and bottom of the map. Also note that in the northern hemisphere, there is the so-called subtropical jet cutting across the United States and through the northern Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.</p>

<p>For months, forecasters talked about how the United States weather has been driven by what is called an <a href=""https://weather.com/forecast/national/news/2023-06-05-omega-block-weather-pattern-united-states-forecast-early-june"">Omega Block</a>, a pesky phenomenon where the jet stream stops moving predominantly west to east across the country and instead moves in big, blocky waves.</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Screen-Shot-2023-07-19-at-2.17.50-PM.png"" style=""width: 1308px; height: 873px;"" /></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b973b055-7fff-ae8c-050a-3e439dcc7516""></span></p>

<p>The second map zooms in on the United States during the same time period and highlights this wavy, omega-like jet stream pattern, which existed for all of May and into July. This blockiness locked in profound weather changes, including extreme heat in Texas, numerous tornado outbreaks across the plain states and deep south, as well as providing a pathway for wildfire smoke to travel from Canada to our airspace in Pennsylvania.</p>

<h3><br />
<strong><span style=""color:#696969;"">Changing Patterns</span></strong></h3>

<h2>&nbsp;</h2>

<p>Omega Blocks are not uncommon, but what is unusual is how stuck and blocky the whole global jet stream pattern has become. Dr. Michael Mann, an esteemed climate scientist in Pennsylvania, <a href=""https://www.sciencealert.com/earths-jet-streams-look-as-chaotic-as-a-van-gogh-right-now-and-thats-a-big-problem"">noted that</a> he&rsquo;s &ldquo;...honestly at a loss to even characterize the current large-scale planetary wave pattern. Frankly it looks like a Van Gogh.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Look more closely at the first map of global jet streams, and you may pick up what Dr. Mann sees&mdash;the subtropical jet in the northern hemisphere has become fragmented, discontinuous, and very slow compared to the jet streams elsewhere on the planet. For example, the jet stream lines over the US, India, China, and Northern Africa are colored light green (slower speed), and it&rsquo;s difficult to connect a continuous line across the globe. It&rsquo;s subtle but important.</p>

<h3><br />
<strong><span style=""color:#696969;"">Why does this matter, and what&rsquo;s causing it?</span></strong></h3>

<h2>&nbsp;</h2>

<p>Climate change research <a href=""https://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2018/10/climate-change-and-extreme-summer-weather-events-the-future-is-still-in-our-hands/"">gives us a good clue</a> about what is going on. Man-made global warming is rapidly heating the planet and much of that heat is being recorded as big temperature spikes at the poles. For instance, the North Atlantic is <a href=""https://www.cnn.com/2023/06/20/europe/marine-heatwave-north-atlantic-climate-scn-intl/index.html"">in the midst</a> of a never before seen increase in ocean temperatures of 5 to 10 degrees Fahrenheit. Arctic Sea ice has plummeted so much recently that scientists expect it to be <a href=""https://www.cnn.com/2023/06/06/world/arctic-sea-ice-free-climate-change/index.html"">ice-free</a> in the summer by the end of this decade. And <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2023/06/13/climate/global-warming-heat-june.html"">global average temperatures</a> in June are currently running close to a degree warmer than any month in recorded history.</p>

<p>Rapid warming in the Arctic fundamentally changes the temperature difference between the poles and the equator. Without a steep temperature difference, wind currents slow. <strong>In other words, global warming&mdash;and thus human activity&mdash;slows, and even breaks the global jet streams.</strong> As the jet stream slows, the blocky wave patterns like the Omega Block, get bigger and tend to get stuck.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Sound familiar to what we&rsquo;ve been experiencing for over two months in Pennsylvania?&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the short-term, extreme weather is only going to get worse. Natural cycles in global climate patterns are also changing. They will enhance the human-induced changes we just discussed, including a rapid warming of the east Pacific Ocean called an El Nino pattern that also causes significant changes to the jet stream and US weather patterns.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Humans burning fossil fuels and warming the planet are having far-reaching impacts, going so far as to now change the fundamental dynamics of the planet&#39;s jet streams and adding to the long and growing list of extreme weather harming the Commonwealth. The question has long been: can and should we do anything about global warming in Pennsylvania? Yet, as we more deeply change the climate, the question shifts&nbsp; to how fast can we do everything to stop this madness?</p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b973b055-7fff-ae8c-050a-3e439dcc7516""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(33, 33, 33); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;""></span></span></div>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-0783cf7b-7fff-e4d3-a7d7-7787389525c5""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(33, 33, 33); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;""></span></span></div>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-624a2864-7fff-bca5-ce8f-0b73f99ad4bd""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(33, 33, 33); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;""></span></span></div>
",Climate,"Matthew Stepp, Vice President and Chief of Staff, PennFuture"
Logistics Facilities are Coming. Is Your Municipality Ready?: PennFuture Releases Model Logistics Use Ordinance and Guidebook,7/11/2023,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">Pennsylvania municipalities *should* update their zoning ordinances to reflect societal changes. In the United States, one of the most significant societal changes of recent years is the rise of e-commerce and the expansion of the logistics industry (the part of the supply chain that includes acquiring, storing, and shipping goods to their final destination).&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 700; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">How to Manage Big Commercial Development</span></p>

<p><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Distrib-Centers-%282%29.jpg"" style=""width: 500px; height: 419px; float: left;"" /><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">As online shopping has become a major source of retail goods in the 21st century, logistics industry practices have changed, and so has the industry&rsquo;s demand for land. Even though they are commonly called &ldquo;warehouses,&rdquo; today&rsquo;s logistics facilities are not the long-term-storage-based warehouses of the past &mdash; </span><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">they are massive distribution and fulfillment centers with the potential to generate far-reaching traffic, noise, aesthetic, and environmental impacts</span><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;""> unanticipated by zoning ordinances drafted long before this development pattern was even a remote possibility.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">Municipalities cannot ignore this new pattern of development and cannot simply ban distribution and fulfillment centers from within their borders (this would be unconstitutional). They must proactively plan for the day when distribution and fulfillment centers come to town by adopting ordinances that reflect the reality that these land uses differ significantly from traditional warehouses.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 700; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">A Powerful Tool for Local Governments</span></p>

<p><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Distrib-Centers-%281%29.jpg"" style=""width: 500px; height: 450px; float: left;"" /><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">These are the reasons why PennFuture has created a <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Publication-Living-With-Logistics-A-Model-Logistics-Use-Zoning-Ordinance-for-Pennsylvania-Municipalities"">Model Logistics Zoning Ordinance</a>. Zoning ordinances are the most powerful tool municipalities have to control how land is used and to ensure that community growth is orderly and reasonable and does not outpace a community&rsquo;s ability to provide adequate water, sewer, school, recreational, and public safety services and employment opportunities. Zoning is also a way for municipalities to preserve valuable natural resources such as forests, waterways, wetlands, aquifers, and floodplains by directing development away from these areas and/or imposing restrictions on development that may impact these resources. Zoning also provides a predictable regulatory environment for developers and the public.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">PennFuture&rsquo;s Model Ordinance gives municipalities a template for updating their zoning ordinances to address the modern reality of the logistics industry and its impact on communities and the environment. The Model Ordinance provides updated definitions for logistics uses and divides them into three categories based on their size and ability to generate traffic. It also imposes restrictions based on these characteristics. For example, under the Model Ordinance, logistics facilities that generate significant truck traffic must be located within a half-mile of an expressway, install signage to direct truck drivers away from local roads, and provide overnight truck parking and amenities for drivers. Large facilities (over 25,000 sq. ft.) must have buffer yards to separate them from neighboring properties and must plant trees and shrubs to lessen their visual and noise impact.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">All logistics facilities, regardless of size, must incorporate certain environmental protections such as a minimum 100-foot wide buffer zone around all waterways, lakes, and ponds and a limitation on woodland disturbance. All facilities are also eligible for impervious pavement credits to mitigate the negative impact of the vast impervious surfaces they generate. Finally, PennFuture recommends that all but the smallest, least impactful logistics facilities be designated as conditional uses or special exception uses, regardless of which zoning district they are in. This provides municipalities and the public the opportunity to review and comment on proposed facilities during a public hearing to determine whether they are appropriate for the proposed location.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<h3 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; text-align: justify; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</h3>

<h3 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; text-align: justify; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">Designed for Any Municipality in Pennsylvania</span></span></h3>

<h3 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; text-align: justify; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Distrib-Centers.jpg"" style=""width: 500px; height: 419px; float: left;"" /><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">The Model Logistics Use Zoning Ordinance is based on the information and experience that PennFuture&rsquo;s staff has gained through our engagement with community members and municipalities in the Lehigh Valley and Northeastern Pennsylvania, the logistics hub of the East Coast. The Model Ordinance draws on our participation in several local land use hearings and appeals, research into how the e-commerce logistics industry works, and review of existing and proposed zoning ordinances that attempt to address the growing and changing logistics industry in Pennsylvania and elsewhere. Along with the accompanying guidebook, which provides additional guidance for adopting the Model Ordinance and tailoring it to the needs of each individual community, as well as factual support for the proposed provisions, the Model Ordinance provides an excellent starting point for municipalities across Pennsylvania as they bring their zoning ordinances into the twenty-first century.</span></span></h3>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">PennFuture urges municipalities across Pennsylvania to review their existing zoning ordinances to determine whether they adequately address the modern logistics uses and the significant impacts that these massive facilities generate. If they do not, PennFuture urges municipalities to adopt its Model Logistics Use Ordinance before it&rsquo;s too late.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; text-align: justify; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">Are you interested in learning more?&nbsp;</span></span></h3>

<h3><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Distrib-Centers-%283%29.jpg"" style=""width: 500px; height: 419px; float: left;"" /><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">PennFuture will have an upcoming webinar where you can learn more about our Model Ordinance. Municipalities, concerned citizens, and conservation groups are also encouraged to organize a model ordinance workshop. If interested, please email Brigitte Meyer at </span><a href=""mailto:meyer@pennfuture.org"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">meyer@pennfuture.org</span></a><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">.</span></span></h3>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;text-align: justify;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">Our work protecting our waters and our communities couldn&rsquo;t happen without the support of our members. Please consider </span><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(74, 110, 224); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">becoming a member </span></a><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">of PennFuture today to support our efforts to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment.</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8ec39218-7fff-24de-7b40-672e3fcdc73a""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;""></span></span></div>
",Community; Environment,"Brigitte Meyer, Staff Attorney"
The Carbon Rule,7/5/2023,"<div background-color:="""" class=""OutlineElement Ltr SCXW228638989 BCX0"" font-size:="""" segoe="""" style=""margin: 0px; padding: 0px; user-select: text; -webkit-user-drag: none; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent; overflow: visible; cursor: text; clear: both; position: relative; direction: ltr; font-family: "" ui="""">
<p class=""Paragraph SCXW228638989 BCX0"" paraeid=""{8b08935a-f01f-4196-b044-c6aa240d0a45}{164}"" paraid=""1419466682"" style=""margin: 0px; padding: 0px; user-select: text; -webkit-user-drag: none; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent; overflow-wrap: break-word; white-space-collapse: preserve; vertical-align: baseline; font-kerning: none; background-color: transparent; color: windowtext;""><span class=""TextRun SCXW228638989 BCX0"" data-contrast=""auto"" lang=""EN-US"" style=""margin: 0px; padding: 0px; user-select: text; -webkit-user-drag: none; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent; font-variant-ligatures: none !important; line-height: 20.5042px; font-family: Calibri, Calibri_EmbeddedFont, Calibri_MSFontService, sans-serif;"" xml:lang=""EN-US""><span class=""NormalTextRun SCXW228638989 BCX0"" style=""margin: 0px; padding: 0px; user-select: text; -webkit-user-drag: none; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;""><span></span></span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/psac.jpg"" style=""width: 640px; height: 504px;"" /></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">When the Soviet Union launched the Sputnik satellite, President Dwight D. Eisenhower created a committee of notable scientists with the purpose of advising the President on scientific matters. Eight years later, the panel of scientists on the President&rsquo;s Science Advisory Committee issued a dire warning about something else...&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">The scientists wrote in a 1965</span><a href=""https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/3227654-PSAC-1965-Restoring-the-Quality-of-Our-Environment#document/p9/a329921"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(5, 99, 193); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">report</span></a><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> that by dumping carbon pollution in the air from burning fossil fuels, we were &ldquo;unwittingly conducting a vast geophysical experiment.&rdquo; It predicted we would cause a 25 percent increase in atmospheric CO2 compared to the 19</span><span style=""font-size: 16pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> century by the year 2000 and would &ldquo;almost certainly cause significant changes in the temperature.&rdquo;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">The predictions were correct, and by 1988, NASA&rsquo;s Dr. James Hansen testified before Congress on global warming, saying &ldquo;It is already happening now.&rdquo;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">When the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator determines that air pollution from a category of sources &ldquo;contributes significantly to air pollution&rdquo; and &ldquo;endangers public health or welfare,&rdquo; the Clean Air Act requires action. But, at least in this case, meaningful action has been very slow coming.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">By 1999, organizations were petitioning the EPA to make an &ldquo;endangerment finding&rdquo; for greenhouse gasses (GHGs), and there was little question from the scientific community that public health was at risk. By then, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) had</span><a href=""https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2018/05/2nd-assessment-en-1.pdf"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(5, 99, 193); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">warned</span></a><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> about climate change having &ldquo;wide-ranging and mostly adverse impacts on human health, with significant loss of life.&rdquo; Still, it took until December 2009 for the EPA Administrator to make an endangerment finding.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">Even then, it was more than four years before the EPA proposed a plan of action for the pollution from large fossil-fuel-powered electric generators. Known as the Clean Power Plan, it would have reduced carbon pollution from those sources by 32 percent while providing between $25 and $45 billion in net climate and health benefits.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">The Trump Administration killed the program, which attempted to replace it with a far less effective (and far less cost-effective) plan they called the Affordable Clean Energy (ACE) rule.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">By 2021, courts had determined the ACE rule violated the Clean Air Act and, in a separate case, the US Supreme Court used its recently invented &ldquo;major questions doctrine&rdquo; to tie the EPA&rsquo;s hands</span><a href=""https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/21pdf/20-1530_new_l537.pdf"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(5, 99, 193); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">declaring</span></a><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> that Congress didn&rsquo;t give the agency the authority to set emissions caps in the way the Clean Power Plan attempted.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Power-Plants-%282%29.jpg"" style=""width: 600px; height: 530px; float: left;"" /></p>

<h3 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><strong><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">Moving forward to set standards</span></span></strong></h3>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">However, the Supreme Court did not say the EPA couldn&rsquo;t regulate carbon pollution&mdash;it had already</span><a href=""https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/549/497/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(5, 99, 193); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">decided</span></a><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> in 2007 that GHGs &ldquo;fit well within the CAA&#39;s capacious definition of air pollutant.&rdquo; The debate was over what comprises the &ldquo;best system of emissions reductions&rdquo; (BSER) as required by the CAA (Clean Air Act).&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">In the Clean Power Plan, the EPA looked beyond the fence line of individual facilities to say the best emissions reduction system involved shifting generation to cleaner sources. While the Supreme Court did not say BSER &ldquo;refers </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">exclusively </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">to measures that improve the pollution performance of individual sources,&rdquo; it nevertheless ruled against the EPA </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 120, 212); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">on this issue </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">and left it to the Biden Administration to craft a new plan.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">The EPA proposed its new rule on May 23, 2023.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">This time, the EPA based their emissions standards for most of the larger fossil-fuel facilities on implementing 90% carbon capture or co-firing some percentage &ldquo;low-GHG&rdquo; hydrogen along with the existing fossil fuels.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">Both methods look much more like the traditional technology-based emissions controls the EPA has used for decades, but this does not mean that any facility needs to install carbon capture technology or burn any hydrogen. The EPA&rsquo;s plan only sets standards of performance&mdash;states, like Pennsylvania, are then given the flexibility to decide how facilities must meet that target and, for existing facilities, can take into consideration the remaining useful life of the plant along with other factors (RULOF).&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<h3 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Power-Plants-%283%29.jpg"" style=""width: 600px; height: 530px; float: left;"" /><strong><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">State action to cut carbon</span></span></strong></h3>

<h3 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></h3>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">While we probably won&rsquo;t know exactly what is in our state&rsquo;s plan before the summer of 2026, we can envision some possibilities.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">First, this rule will not impact Pennsylvania&rsquo;s large conventional coal-fired power plants. The four remaining facilities are all scheduled to retire or convert to gas-fired generation by 2028, and this new rule won&rsquo;t go into effect until 2030.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">Pennsylvania&rsquo;s waste-coal-fired power plants may largely avoid significant impacts as well. BSER for such plants that retire by 2032 or that will run with limited capacity as late as 2035 consists of &ldquo;routine methods of operation and maintenance&rdquo;&mdash;that is, business as usual. We don&rsquo;t know precisely when the existing plants will retire, but most of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s waste coal facilities came online in the early 1990s and wouldn&rsquo;t be running today without huge subsidies</span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 120, 212); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;""> funded by state taxpayers</span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> and electric ratepayers. Market forces could quickly drive most of them offline before more stringent emissions standards are required.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">The 2026 State Plan will, therefore, likely focus on existing fracked-gas-fired power plants, a&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">few newer fracked-gas-fired power plants, and whatever remaining waste-coal facilities are still in operation. For each of these, the state will calculate a target emissions level that meets BSER according to the EPA rules by the applicable compliance deadline. Then, the DEP (Department of Environmental Protection) will need to craft a plan that will &ldquo;ultimately provide for equivalent stringency as would be achieved if each affected source was achieving the applicable presumptive standard of performance, after accounting for any application of RULOF.&rdquo;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">It&#39;s unclear how much RULOF will have an impact on the eventual state targets. While states have a right to consider this, the EPA already made allowances for plants nearing retirement or running at low capacities when it set BSER. It would make sense for EPA to limit any further weakening of the performance standards to special cases it hasn&rsquo;t already considered.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">With the final numbers in hand, designing a plan with &ldquo;equivalent stringency&rdquo; raises the prospect of what the EPA calls &ldquo;compliance flexibilities.&rdquo;&nbsp; While that could include plants using newly invented control technologies the EPA had yet to specifically consider, the EPA clearly has something else in mind. It specifically proposes to allow states to use &ldquo;averaging and market-based mechanisms&rdquo; in their plans.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">In Pennsylvania, that raises the prospect of participation in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) being a creditable measure. There are certainly details to be worked out</span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> and </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">in fact, EPA is specifically asking for comments on how to make interstate emissions trading work in this context among other issues. But one can foresee RGGI emissions reductions being subtracted from an aggregate statewide target and that credit, in turn, being apportioned to individual facilities in some manner. As the EPA notes, such trading programs tend to be highly cost-effective because they allow owners to &ldquo;prioritize emission reduction actions where they are the quickest or cheapest.&rdquo;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">Along with trading, the EPA is also considering using banking programs. </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(209, 52, 56); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: line-through; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">Essentially, that means allowing facilities that meet their targets earlier than required to carry over credit for those reductions to a later control period. The good part of banking is that it encourages emission reductions to happen faster than they otherwise would, still unless the program is well designed, a surplus of banked credits could undermine the program&rsquo;s effectiveness in later years. </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(209, 52, 56); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: line-through; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">If this appears in the state plan, we&rsquo;ll need to carefully consider the details.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/AP_051019024812.jpg"" style=""width: 580px; height: 392px; float: left;"" />&nbsp;</span></span><strong><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">Concerns, and the need to act </span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;"">now</span></span></strong></p>

<h3 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></h3>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">While meaningful federal action to address the growing climate crisis is long overdue, it&rsquo;s also critical that whatever path we take, we do things right.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">While co-firing low-GHG hydrogen in a fossil fuel plant likely fits the Clean Air Act&rsquo;s definition of &ldquo;Best System of Emissions Reduction,&rdquo; that does not mean it is the best choice for getting us to net zero.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">While the EPA&rsquo;s definition of &ldquo;low-GHG&rdquo; hydrogen doesn&rsquo;t exclude clean hydrogen made from renewable energy, it&rsquo;s doubtful anyone will co-fire clean hydrogen to any significant degree. It makes little sense to start with clean electricity, make hydrogen, then burn the hydrogen to generate less electricity than you started with. In practice, the hydrogen that gets used will likely come from steam reformed methane, which will drive more fracking.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">The EPA attempted to address the pollution from fracking and other upstream sources by defining low-GHG hydrogen based on &ldquo;well to gate&rdquo; emissions. Still, the resulting expansion of the petrochemical industry presents an incredibly significant problem.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">There are better choices than using carbon capture and storage (CCS). Aside from the technical challenges of achieving 90% carbon capture and the outstanding questions of whether we can reliably store the carbon underground in Pennsylvania, we know that doing so will not be cheap.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">The EPA projects their plan will return $85 billion in net climate and public health benefits over the next two decades, which certainly isn&rsquo;t bad, but we can still do better. The US Supreme Court might not allow EPA to consider much more cost-effective investments in clean renewable generation and energy efficiency as part of the BSER, but that does not mean Pennsylvania can&rsquo;t make better choices for itself.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); "">No matter what path we take, we cannot wait until 2030 and beyond to act. As PennFuture said back in 2015, we can grow our economy while protecting our health and the environment, but we need to make responsible choices</span><span style=""font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); ""> and we need to act now. You can act by sending a direct email to the EPA in support of the strong standards in the new rule &mdash; <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/71723epacarbonrule"">you can use this template</a> to submit public comment.</span></span></p>

<p class=""Paragraph SCXW228638989 BCX0"" paraeid=""{8b08935a-f01f-4196-b044-c6aa240d0a45}{164}"" paraid=""1419466682"" style=""margin: 0px; padding: 0px; user-select: text; -webkit-user-drag: none; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent; overflow-wrap: break-word; white-space-collapse: preserve; vertical-align: baseline; font-kerning: none; background-color: transparent; color: windowtext;""><br />
<span class=""TextRun SCXW228638989 BCX0"" data-contrast=""auto"" lang=""EN-US"" style=""margin: 0px; padding: 0px; user-select: text; -webkit-user-drag: none; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent; font-variant-ligatures: none !important; line-height: 20.5042px; font-family: Calibri, Calibri_EmbeddedFont, Calibri_MSFontService, sans-serif;"" xml:lang=""EN-US""><span class=""NormalTextRun SCXW228638989 BCX0"" style=""margin: 0px; padding: 0px; user-select: text; -webkit-user-drag: none; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;""></span></span><span class=""EOP SCXW228638989 BCX0"" data-ccp-props=""{}"" style=""color: windowtext; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; user-select: text; -webkit-user-drag: none; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent; line-height: 20.5042px; font-family: Calibri, Calibri_EmbeddedFont, Calibri_MSFontService, sans-serif;""></span></p>
</div>
",Climate; Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
PennFuture’s New Legal Interns Summer 2023,6/26/2023,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-eaaf46f2-7fff-19d2-6de0-e01c8d1c6d65""><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Legal-Interns.png"" style=""width: 900px; height: 451px;"" /></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-eaaf46f2-7fff-19d2-6de0-e01c8d1c6d65""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Since its inception in 1998, PennFuture has emphasized the importance of using the law to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment and &ldquo;create a just future where nature, communities, and the economy thrive.&rdquo;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-eaaf46f2-7fff-19d2-6de0-e01c8d1c6d65""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Over the past two decades, we have achieved significant legal and policy victories that reduce pollution and protect the environment and our communities. We have provided millions of dollars in pro bono legal services while setting critical precedents and enforcing environmental laws across the Commonwealth.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-eaaf46f2-7fff-19d2-6de0-e01c8d1c6d65""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">But as PennFuture looks forward to the next 20 years, we recognize that we need to be more involved with cultivating the people that will continue to support our mission. Our staff have a long history of mentoring interns, externs, and fellows, and we wanted to create a more formal program to inspire the next generation.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-eaaf46f2-7fff-19d2-6de0-e01c8d1c6d65""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">With the generous support of the George and Miriam Martin Foundation and the Otto Haas Charitable Trust, PennFuture created a paid legal internship program to inspire and mentor students interested in making a difference for our environment.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-eaaf46f2-7fff-19d2-6de0-e01c8d1c6d65""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Ultimately, the goal of this program is to provide the organization a cadre of young legal and policy minds interested in taking on the myriad challenges impacting Pennsylvania as well as to further their potential environmental careers. We also hope that providing for a funded internship will help to bring more diversity and inclusivity into the non-profit environmental advocacy sphere.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-eaaf46f2-7fff-19d2-6de0-e01c8d1c6d65""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">This summer, we have three fantastic students for our internship, representing a range of backgrounds and experiences. We&rsquo;ve asked our new interns to explain, in their own words, what environmental law and PennFuture&rsquo;s mission means to them:</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-eaaf46f2-7fff-19d2-6de0-e01c8d1c6d65""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-917ee38c-7fff-476a-446a-cf51a296f33c""></span>

<div dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 12pt;""><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-917ee38c-7fff-476a-446a-cf51a296f33c""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Jackie Jaques, rising Third Year student at Temple University Beasley School of Law</span></span></strong></div>

<div dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 12pt;""><strong><span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></strong><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-917ee38c-7fff-476a-446a-cf51a296f33c""></span></strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-323a6da2-7fff-05d0-4dbc-478bc683b44d""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/jackie.png"" style=""width: 250px; height: 280px; float: left;"" />I am going into my third year at Temple after spending my spring semester at Temple&rsquo;s Tokyo campus. I am the vice president of Temple Law&rsquo;s Name Change Project.</span></span></div>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-323a6da2-7fff-05d0-4dbc-478bc683b44d""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">I am from Boston originally, and I attended Bowdoin College in Maine. I majored in both Sociology and Government &amp; Legal Studies, and played rugby for the college&rsquo;s varsity team. I took a class at Bowdoin called Ecology and Society that taught, among other things, about federal administrative environmental management and the roles of the EPA, USDA, and Department of the Interior. I would think back to that class during my Constitutional Law class and my Environmental Law class.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-323a6da2-7fff-05d0-4dbc-478bc683b44d""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">I&rsquo;m very happy to be working at PennFuture because I am interested in the legal logistics of environmental protection and development of sustainable infrastructure. I want to use my legal career to participate in work to make these systems more stable and equitable. During my semester in Japan I was able to see how widespread and reliable transportation and food infrastructure can sustain a large, dense population, and it inspired me to think about how changes in infrastructure can better support&nbsp; marginalized communities in Pennsylvania.</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-257e650d-7fff-690a-d4bb-c5fa747a7e11""></span><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-257e650d-7fff-690a-d4bb-c5fa747a7e11""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></strong><strong><span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></strong><strong><span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></strong></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 12pt;""><br />
<span id=""docs-internal-guid-8d8aa68e-7fff-b5fa-be9c-3d7810f3865f""></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:12pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><u><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8d8aa68e-7fff-b5fa-be9c-3d7810f3865f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Kaleb Wilson, rising Third Year student at PennState Dickinson Law</span></span></strong></u></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Kaleb_Wilson_12_4x6-%281%29.jpg"" style=""width: 200px; height: 300px; float: left;"" />I have always had a passion and interest in the environment since I was introduced to birdwatching when I was young. I come from a tiny town in rural Southwest PA, so issues of clean air and water are near and dear to my heart. In high school I was captain of the Envirothon team, which ingrained in me a love of nature and conservation. My experience with Envirothon has helped define my career dreams and served as my introduction to environmental law.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8d8aa68e-7fff-b5fa-be9c-3d7810f3865f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">I did not plan to attend law school when graduating high school, but my plans changed while earning my BA in Politics and History from Saint Vincent College. After falling in love with my political science courses freshman year, I decided that law school would be the best path for me to pursue both my love of conservation and public service. <span id=""docs-internal-guid-50f55a45-7fff-5355-a17d-f403eae3522d""></span></span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-50f55a45-7fff-5355-a17d-f403eae3522d""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">I am thrilled to get experience with environmental law and policy this summer with PennFuture and hope to use this experience to continue my pursuit of conservation.</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-50f55a45-7fff-5355-a17d-f403eae3522d""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b53521ee-7fff-a33b-24c0-aec5a33963ad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Lindsay Williamson, rising Fourth Year student at Widener University Commonwealth Law School</span></span></strong></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><strong><span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-7ed501d2-7fff-f74e-2b1e-890f748e1b66""></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-7ed501d2-7fff-f74e-2b1e-890f748e1b66""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Headshot--Lindsay-Williamson.png"" style=""width: 200px; height: 300px; float: left;"" />I have wanted to go to law school since elementary school and have always had an interest in nature, particularly animals.&nbsp; Growing up, I always enjoyed researching and writing and law school seemed like the best path to develop a career where I could utilize those skills to help people.&nbsp; Before attending law school, I worked in local government and transcribed for the Connecticut Legislature.&nbsp; My undergraduate degree is in political science, and I had the opportunity to intern with the United States Army War College after my 1L year.&nbsp; My legal studies have been focused on learning about environmental issues and I am pursuing the Environmental Law Certificate along with certificates in legislation and administrative law.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-7ed501d2-7fff-f74e-2b1e-890f748e1b66""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">I have been very active in extracurricular activities during my time at Widener Commonwealth.&nbsp; I am currently the President of the Environmental Law and Policy Society, President of the Law and Government Student Society, President of the Appellate Advocacy Honor Society, and the Colloquium Coordinator for the Trial Advocacy Honor Society.&nbsp; I also serve as a Research Assistant for Environmental Law and an Academic Success Fellow for Criminal Law.&nbsp; In addition, I write for Widener Commonwealth&rsquo;s Law Review, where my comment on recycling practices in the United States was chosen for publication.&nbsp; I will also be writing for the Pennsylvania Bar Association&rsquo;s Environmental Law and Energy section beginning this fall.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-7ed501d2-7fff-f74e-2b1e-890f748e1b66""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Prior to my internship with PennFuture, I completed a Human Rights course in Ghana.&nbsp; The experience taught me how important it is to ensure that everyone has access to necessities like clean air and water; a luxury many of us take for granted and still others go without.&nbsp; I&rsquo;m very excited to intern with PennFuture where I can utilize both my government background and environmental law education and gain firsthand experience in affecting policy to improve environmental conditions in Pennsylvania.&nbsp; PennFuture is doing very important work and I&rsquo;m honored to be working with them this summer. </span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-7ed501d2-7fff-f74e-2b1e-890f748e1b66""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><strong><span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></strong></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-323a6da2-7fff-05d0-4dbc-478bc683b44d""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<h3><strong><span><span style=""border:none;display:inline-block;overflow:hidden;width:161px;height:179px;""></span></span></strong></h3>
</div>
",Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
