Swiftwater Solar Settlement: A win for all in the Poconos,6/6/2023,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-9a543e8e-7fff-643f-cb04-4db772038663""></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-9a543e8e-7fff-643f-cb04-4db772038663""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">PennFuture and Brodhead Watershed Association (BWA) are pleased to announce that we have reached a settlement with the developer of the Swiftwater Solar project and the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) that protects the water quality of Exceptional Value Swiftwater Creek, while allowing the Swiftwater Solar project to go forward and increase the supply of renewable energy in Pennsylvania, creating green jobs and growing the green economy.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-9a543e8e-7fff-643f-cb04-4db772038663""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<h2 style=""text-align: center;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b81a2b00-7fff-a641-6077-8cd6b1216c22""></span></h2>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b81a2b00-7fff-a641-6077-8cd6b1216c22""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" font-weight:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Why this outcome protects the environment:</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">&nbsp;</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b81a2b00-7fff-a641-6077-8cd6b1216c22""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></strong></h2>

<p dir=""ltr"">&nbsp;</p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""></span>

<ul dir=""ltr"">
	<li style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">The settlement creates a true &ldquo;meadow condition,&rdquo; using a warm-weather meadow seed mix, which will maintain the water conditions that flow to Swiftwater Creek, Scot Run, and Dry Sawmill Run.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Swiftwater Solar will not only use low-impact construction practices, but will also do multiple decompactions of the soil throughout the construction. This will allow for stormwater infiltration across the whole site, mimicking the forest conditions that are there now.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Testing requirements are in place to ensure that the target conditions are being met.&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Swiftwater Solar has improved the design of its stormwater basins and integrated environmentally sensitive design principles, to ensure that the basins will continue to function into the future.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Solar field development can be a lower-impact use, in terms of permanent impact to natural lands and resources, than other types of development that require roads, parking lots, and installation of other permanent impervious surfaces.&nbsp;</span></span></li>
</ul>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Untitled-design-%287%29.jpg"" style=""width: 450px; height: 450px; float: left;"" /><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" font-weight:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Previously:</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">&nbsp;</span></span></strong></p>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</h2>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">As we explained in a previous</span><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Renewable-Energy-Projects-Have-Our-Support-but-Not-At-Any-Cost"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> </span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" text-decoration-line:="""" text-decoration-skip-ink:="""" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">post</span></a><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">, the proposed</span><a href=""https://www.swiftwatersolar.com/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> </span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" text-decoration-line:="""" text-decoration-skip-ink:="""" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Swiftwater Solar project in the Poconos</span></a><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">, is an 80-megawatt solar field that will generate &ldquo;grid-scale&rdquo; renewable energy, meaning that rather than go directly to a particular user (as a rooftop solar project might), this energy will be drawn on as part of the larger electric grid.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">In July 2022, DEP issued water quality permits to developer Swiftwater Solar for its proposed solar facility sited at the top of Bear Mountain in Pocono Township. The project requires the clearing and regrading of approximately 500 acres of woodlands, which drain into Exceptional Value Swiftwater Creek and High Quality streams Dry Sawmill Run and Scot Run. In August 2022, PennFuture and BWA filed a lawsuit against DEP and developer Swiftwater Solar, because the permits issued did not ensure that the water quality of these special protection waters would be protected from the degrading impacts of the project. The settlement resolves these issues and closes out the case.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">It is important to remember that Swiftwater Solar was determined to be a &ldquo;Major Essential Service&rdquo; under the local zoning ordinance by the local Planning Commission. As a result, the solar field is a permissible use for this property and would be built. However, a permissible use is not a blank check to develop without any regard for the surroundings. PennFuture, BWA, Swiftwater Solar, and DEP worked together to reach a plan that would balance the water quality protections with the solar development itself.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" font-weight:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Fluffy soil is key:</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">&nbsp;</span></span></strong></h2>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</h2>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">A critical factor in this case was ensuring that the &ldquo;hydrological condition&rdquo;&mdash;basically, the way that rain and snow infiltrate into the ground, and then filter into the surrounding streams&mdash;of the site would be maintained. A key principle is to have soil that is not compacted, but is soft, with lots of space between the bits of dirt in the ground (the technical term is &ldquo;pore space&rdquo;). Think of it like a loaf of bread: wonderbread is even and smooth, while an English muffin has those nooks and crannies. In uncompacted soils, when it rains or when snow melts, the water has lots of places to go and filters into the ground before eventually making its way into a nearby stream, pond, or other waterbody. When soil gets really compacted, water just runs straight off the surface, bringing sediment and other pollutants along that can harm pristine waters like Swiftwater Creek. To maintain the hydrological condition, we needed the site to maintain (where possible) and restore (where necessary) that soft nooks-and-crannies type of soil.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Clearing forests is concerning because forests are recognized for being great natural filters and protectors of streams, and this is because they create conditions that slow down rainwater and reduce surface runoff in a couple ways. First, the trees, shrubs, and groundcover all help physically slow down the rainwater as it reaches the ground. Then, the root systems of all these plants, which can run very deep, help to keep the soil in a relatively &ldquo;fluffy&rdquo; state, with the &ldquo;nooks and crannies&rdquo; mentioned above.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">However, forests are not the only thing that can do this well. A true meadow, one seeded with native plants that vary in height and have high resiliency, can also be a great filter for stormwater in the same ways that forests are. Now, the term &ldquo;meadow&rdquo; can be tricky because it is a word that has both a technical use but is also is often used casually in a number of different ways. A farmer might think of a hay pasture meadow, seeded with grasses for yield and nutrition. A biologist might think of a grassland meadow where plants are allowed to flower, grow, and self-seed without grazing. And most average people might simply think of a lush field of grass and maybe flowers, without worrying about what kind of grasses or flowers they are. But the composition is important to the performance, and the plants that grow above ground also affect what is happening below ground, and what happens when it rains and storms. Consider the average lawn: a uniform, non-native grass that is kept at a consistent short height does not do a great job of creating space for water to infiltrate.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">So here, where the goal is to create the kind of meadow that protects the soil and natural resources, we needed to be sure that what was being installed was the kind of true meadow.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">In the end, Swiftwater Solar agreed to a number of changes in its construction practices and its restoration practices that will achieve this. First, they will use low-impact construction equipment wherever possible and work to minimize the amount of compaction of soil. Second, the site will have multiple levels of decompaction, to ensure that the soil is restored to a fluffy state that allows infiltration across the whole area. Swiftwater and DEP agreed to testing protocols, to ensure that there are some simple metrics for accountability. Swiftwater Solar will also use specialized seed mixes that balance the need to use the right plant species for the area with the height requirements of the solar panels themselves.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" font-weight:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Environmentally sensitive designs are a win-win:</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">&nbsp;</span></span></strong></h2>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</h2>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">PennFuture and BWA also fought to incorporate environmentally sensitive design principles, to ensure that the final design would be long lasting and resilient. Swiftwater Solar and DEP agreed to some modifications of the site design of the infiltration/stormwater management basins that were planned to ensure this would happen. It was crucial for us that this project&rsquo;s stormwater management be designed with an eye for the generations to come, not only the short term.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">The result of integrating these principles is that the development&rsquo;s stormwater basins will have better water flow management, improved plant selection for the landscaping, and maximize use of bio-friendly building materials. This means that the seeds for the final planting are chosen with the long-term use in mind, whether it is the wetland-like conditions at the bottom of the basins, or the dryer, steeper sides of the basins. The basins will be planted with willows, which will improve infiltration and discourage invasive plants. And these modifications are win-win, because they also lower the maintenance burden for Swiftwater Solar and DEP.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" font-weight:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Final thoughts:</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">&nbsp;</span></span></strong></h2>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</h2>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">While PennFuture is firmly in the business of advocating for clean energy and Pennsylvania&rsquo;s transition to a clean and just energy economy, we also strongly believe that transition cannot come at the expense of other natural resources. So often, the environment is just a small slice of the pie, and we are asked to divide it into smaller and smaller slivers between us. It is a bad approach. We shouldn&rsquo;t take natural resources away from each other; what should be stopped is reckless development and things that deplete the environment altogether, like spec warehouses that are paving over the state, fossil fuel buildout that wreaks our air and water, or urban sprawl that introduces traffic and buildings to the places that most need protection.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">The settlement is an example of how clean energy can be developed in harmony with consideration to the natural resources. While PennFuture hopes that future grid-scale solar can be sited with more consideration to low-impact solar siting considerations, such as</span><a href=""https://elibrary.dcnr.pa.gov/PDFProvider.ashx?action=PDFStream&amp;docID=4659215&amp;chksum=&amp;revision=0&amp;docName=Conservation_Considerations_for_Grid-Scale_Solar_Systems_Pennsylvania_Sept2022&amp;nativeExt=pdf&amp;PromptToSave=False&amp;Size=3890968&amp;ViewerMode=2&amp;overlay=0"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> </span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" text-decoration-line:="""" text-decoration-skip-ink:="""" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">DCNR&rsquo;s 2022 recommendations</span></a><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">, we also hope that this can be an example of how grid-scale solar can also be responsibly built to protect natural resources.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1fefbb6-7fff-f0eb-5fee-fa1fca2f243f""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></div>
</div>

<p class=""Paragraph SCXW29216152 BCX0"" paraeid=""{e6898a34-8851-45df-92af-96c7af276c34}{234}"" paraid=""1375767219"" style=""margin: 0px; padding: 0px; user-select: text; -webkit-user-drag: none; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent; overflow-wrap: break-word; white-space: pre-wrap; vertical-align: baseline; font-kerning: none; background-color: transparent; color: windowtext; text-align: justify; text-indent: 48px;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p><span><span>Like any law, zoning ordinances should be updated to reflect changes in society. One of the most significant changes impacting land use in Pennsylvania today is the rise of e-commerce and the massive logistics facilities that support it. As online shopping has become a major source of retail goods, industry practices have changed, and land development patterns have changed along with them. No longer the long-term-storage-based &ldquo;warehouse&rdquo; uses of the past, 21st century logistics facilities like distribution centers, fulfillment centers, and truck terminals are substantially larger, with an emphasis on rapid turnover of massive quantities of goods and materials.&nbsp;</span></span></p>
&nbsp;

<p><span><span>Previous PennFuture blog,</span><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-The-True-Cost-of-Convenience-The-Impacts-of-Never-Ending-Warehouse-Development"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> The True Cost of Convenience: The Impacts of Never-Ending Warehouse Development</span></a><span>, discusses the driving forces behind this new pattern of development and the detrimental impacts that result.</span><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Distribution-Centers-Bring-into-Focus-Limitations-of-Local-Zoning-Laws"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> Distribution Centers Bring into Focus Limitations of Local Zoning Laws</span></a><span> explores how Coolbaugh Township in Monroe County discovered the importance of well-crafted zoning ordinances in controlling the proliferation of logistics facilities in the Poconos and beyond. In this blog, we will look at a recently proposed zoning amendment in another Monroe County municipality that is hoping to get ahead of the massive influx of logistics facilities that threaten the health of our communities and our special protection waters.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<div><span><span></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<h3 style=""text-align: center;""><span></span></h3>

<p><span><span>Case Study &ndash; Jackson Township, Monroe County</span></span></p>

<div><span><span></span></span></div>

<div style=""text-align: center;""><span></span>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span><span>Updated Definitions</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>Jackson Township has taken steps to update its zoning ordinance to address logistics uses. Its proposed ordinance, to be considered for approval at a public meeting on June 7, 2023, builds on lessons learned in Coolbaugh Township.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>To begin, Jackson Township&rsquo;s proposed ordinance includes clearer definitions of Warehouse and Distribution Center/Logistics Center. Where the existing ordinance defines a warehouse as &ldquo;a building or group of buildings primarily used for the indoor storage, transfer and distribution of products and materials,&rdquo; the proposed ordinance clarifies that a warehouse shall only consist of indoor storage of products and materials and cannot include &ldquo;value-added&rdquo; activities typical of distribution and fulfillment centers such as breaking down large orders into smaller orders, packaging, and order fulfillment. With this new definition, the proposed ordinance makes clear that any facility that goes beyond mere storage is not a warehouse.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;""><span><span>In addition, where the existing ordinance treats all warehouses the same, regardless of size, the proposed ordinance recognizes that today&rsquo;s warehouses are no longer exclusively small- to medium-sized facilities that can blend easily into a typical industrial or commercial area.&nbsp; Therefore, the proposed ordinance divides warehouses into two categories: Small Warehouses (up to 25,000 sq. ft.) and Large Warehouses (25,000 sq. ft. and above). Large Warehouses are subject to greater restrictions than Small Warehouses.&nbsp;</span></span><span><span></span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;""><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Dead_Wholesale_store_in_Pittsburgh-_Pennsylvania_(9311821912).jpg"" target=""_parent""><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Dead_Wholesale_store_in_Pittsburgh-_Pennsylvania_%289311821912%29.jpg"" style=""width: 450px; height: 380px; float: left;"" /></a><img alt=""Walmart Distribution Center in Tomah, Wisconsin"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Walmart_distribution_center_in_Tomah-_Wisconsin_9_pano.jpg"" style=""width: 580px; height: 320px;"" /></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>Jackson Township&rsquo;s proposed ordinance also updates the definition of Distribution Center/Truck Terminal by strengthening the distinction between Distribution Centers/Truck Terminals and Warehouses. The proposed definition makes clear that value-added services, which are explicitly excluded from the definition of Warehouse, are one of the defining characteristics of a Distribution Center/Truck Terminal. The proposed ordinance also eliminates potentially-confusing language in the existing ordinance that allows a Warehouse to be &ldquo;part of the operation&rdquo; of a Distribution Center/Truck Terminal. In the proposed ordinance, these two uses are clearly distinct from one another.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;""><br />
<span><span>Most significantly, the proposed ordinance treats any Large Warehouse that will generate more than 50 tractor-trailer trips in any 24-hour period as a Distribution Center/Truck Terminal. This is especially important because third-party developers often construct logistics facilities on speculation or &ldquo;on spec.&rdquo; This means the developer does not know who will occupy the facility when it is completed</span><span><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">1. </span></span><span>Developers can take advantage of this uncertainty by simply declaring that their facility is a storage-only Warehouse, not a Distribution Center/Truck Terminal offering value-added services. Without knowing who will ultimately occupy the building, municipalities and residents are forced to take developers at their word. Jackson Township&rsquo;s 50-vehicle-trip trigger closes this loophole by linking regulation of the facility to an objective measurement that a developer must provide when applying for zoning approval.&nbsp; </span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;""><span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Large Warehouses and Distribution Centers to Require Conditional Use Approval</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""text-align: left;""><span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>Jackson Township&rsquo;s new, more precise definitions allow the Township to craft additional zoning restrictions suited to the different types of uses.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>For example, under the existing ordinance, Warehouses of any size are permitted as of right in the Township&rsquo;s I-Industrial district. This means that any facility that meets the definition of a warehouse and complies with building size and setbacks requirements, even a 1 million square foot facility, could be built anywhere in the I-Industrial district without review or approval by the Board of Supervisors or public input as to whether the use is appropriate in that location.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>The proposed ordinance changes this. Both Large and Small Warehouses are still limited to the I-Industrial district, but only Small Warehouses can be built without additional zoning review. Under the proposed ordinance, Large Warehouses are conditional uses, meaning that the Township Supervisors must review each proposed Large Warehouse to make sure it satisfies the specific requirements in the zoning ordinance. The Board of Supervisors must hold a public hearing and allow the public to weigh in on the proposal. This process also gives the Board of Supervisors an opportunity to impose conditions on approval, which is not possible with uses permitted by right.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>The proposed ordinance also adds new, specific requirements that Large Warehouses must meet to obtain zoning approval from the Board of Supervisors. These requirements are related to the impacts generated by these massive facilities and include:&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<ul dir=""ltr"">
	<li><span><span>A description of the nature and scale of on-site activities;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>A detailed description of potential environmental impacts;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>Evidence that the number of truck parking spaces will be adequate to accommodate expected demand; and&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>A traffic study.&nbsp;</span></span></li>
</ul>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>Under both the existing ordinance and the proposed ordinance, Distribution Centers/Truck Terminals are conditional uses in the I-Industrial district and are subject to the same review process. However, the proposed ordinance enhances the Township&rsquo;s power to control Distribution Center/Truck Terminal by adding new requirements a developer must satisfy to obtain approval.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>Under the existing ordinance, the only requirements for zoning approval of a Distribution Center/Truck Terminal are a 5-acre minimum lot size, a 100-foot setback from residential areas and a 50-foot setback from commercial areas. The proposed ordinance adds new requirements aimed at mitigating the impacts of these facilities, particularly traffic impacts.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>These include:&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<ul dir=""ltr"">
	<li><span><span>A 10-acre minimum lot size;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>A 150-foot setback between the facility and residential property lines;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>On-site stacking area for tractor-trailers;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>Prohibition against parking, loading and unloading on any public road;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>Amenities for the comfort, convenience and safety of truck drivers;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>A traffic study; and&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>An environmental impact assessment.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
</ul>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>PennFuture is pleased to see Jackson Township taking these steps toward a more comprehensive and effective ordinance that will enhance the Township&rsquo;s ability to regulate logistics uses, and we support their amendment.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span>Possible Improvements to Better Protect High Quality Streams</span></span></h2>

<h2>&nbsp;</h2>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>Although Jackson Township&rsquo;s proposed ordinance is a substantial improvement over its existing ordinance, there is some room to improve the ordinance to provide greater protection for special protection waters.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>Several streams</span><a href=""https://www.goamplify.com/blog/business/spec-construction-loans/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> designated</span></a><span> as High Quality waters by the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection flow through Jackson Township&rsquo;s I-Industrial zone. These waters are threatened by the vast amount of impervious surface that accompanies these uses. (See</span><a href=""https://news.climate.columbia.edu/2010/07/13/no-more-pavement-the-problem-of-impervious-surfaces/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> No More Pavement! The Problem of Impervious Surfaces</span></a><span> for more information about the impacts of impervious coverage).&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>Municipalities should incorporate provisions into zoning ordinances to mitigate the detrimental impact of the impervious surfaces that come along with logistics uses. Possible options for Jackson Township include:&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<ul dir=""ltr"">
	<li><span><span>Reduction in the amount of impervious surface permitted on a site.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>Incentives for use of impervious pavement.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>A requirement to minimize woodland disturbance. For more information about the role trees play in reducing stream degradation, see Penn State Extension&rsquo;s article,</span><a href=""https://extension.psu.edu/the-role-of-trees-and-forests-in-healthy-watersheds"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> The Role of Trees and Forests in Healthy Watersheds</span></a><span>.&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span><span>150-foot riparian buffers. For more information about the importance of riparian buffers, see the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection&rsquo;s</span><a href=""https://www.dep.state.pa.us/dep/subject/advcoun/ag/2009/june2009/Riparian%20Forest%20Buffer%20Guidance.pdf"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> Riparian Forest Buffer Guidance</span></a><span>&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></li>
</ul>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>These requirements would be appropriate for both Large Warehouses and Distribution Centers/Truck Terminals, as both have the potential to generate large amounts of impervious surface that triggers water quality concerns.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><strong><span><span>PennFuture Model Ordinance and Guidebook&nbsp;</span></span></strong></h2>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>PennFuture has taken the lessons from Coolbaugh Township, Jackson Township and other municipalities and distilled them into two forthcoming documents to assist municipalities in their efforts to better control and regulate logistics development. A Model Logistics Ordinance will provide municipalities with suggested definitions for logistics uses and other provisions aimed at mitigating the detrimental impacts of these uses. The accompanying Municipal Logistics Guidebook will explain PennFuture&rsquo;s reasons for suggesting the Model Ordinance provisions and provide a road map to guide municipalities through the zoning and land development approval processes for these uses. Look for these resources from PennFuture later this summer!&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style=""text-align: left;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span>Please support our efforts to protect our waters in the Poconos by</span><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> becoming a member today</span></a><span>!&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<div><span><span></span></span></div>

",Community,"Brigitte Meyer, Staff Attorney"
"The End Game is Clean Water: PennFuture, partners lead 7th Annual Pennsylvania Clean Water Education Week",5/12/2023,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">In Pennsylvania, 2023 has been marked by several notable transitions. Governor Josh Shapiro began his first term in office, along with a large group of members in the General Assembly, including 50 representatives and six senators. The Commonwealth started a new two-year legislative session, with a Democratic majority in the state House for the first time in twelve years.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">In the face of so much change, environmental groups must highlight much-needed investment and policy change, especially during this time of year as budget negotiations ramp up. At PennFuture, advocating to protect and restore Pennsylvania&rsquo;s diverse and beautiful creeks, rivers, and lakes is a large part of our work. Building upon the successes of last year&#39;s </span><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-Applauds-Historic-Environmental-Investments-Included-in-New-State-Budget"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">historic state budget</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">, which included major victories such as the Clean Streams Fund &mdash; an initiative that targets the major sources of water pollution in Pennsylvania &mdash; it is crucial that we continue to prioritize state investments towards immediate needs in order to make the promise of clean water for all real, not empty words.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">In the first week of May, PennFuture Campaign Managers, acting as state leads for the </span><a href=""https://www.delriverwatershed.org/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Coalition for the Delaware River Watershed</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> and the </span><a href=""https://www.choosecleanwater.org/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Choose Clean Water Coalition (Chesapeake Bay Watershed)</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> and based on </span><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/erie"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">policy leadership in the Lake Erie Watershed</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">, organized our 7th annual </span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-weight: 700; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Clean Water Education Week</span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">. Shifting power dynamics and the presence of many new members within the state legislature created valuable opportunities for these Coalitions and partners to educate lawmakers about Pennsylvania&rsquo;s precious waterways, reminding them of the importance of investing in clean water.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Specifically, we asked Governor Shapiro and members of the General Assembly to:</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" role=""presentation"" style=""list-style-type: decimal; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<ol dir=""ltr"">
	<li role=""presentation"" style=""list-style-type: decimal; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre; line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Support full &ldquo;fair share&rdquo; funding for the Interstate Basin Commissions responsible for protecting and monitoring our waterways. These commissions include the Delaware River Basin Commission, Susquehanna River Basin Commission, Interstate Commission for the Potomac River Basin, Ohio River Valley Sanitation Commission, and Great Lakes Commission.&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li role=""presentation"" style=""list-style-type: decimal; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre; line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Support increasing funding for state agencies, including the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP), the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR), and the Department of Agriculture (PDA).</span></span></li>
	<li role=""presentation"" style=""list-style-type: decimal; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre; line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Support sustainable annual funding for the Clean Streams Fund, the first Pennsylvania fund dedicated to water protection and restoration, created in last year&rsquo;s budget.</span></span></li>
	<li role=""presentation"" style=""list-style-type: decimal; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre; line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Support legislation that bolsters the PA DEP Office of Environmental Justice (SB 158/HB 742).</span></span></li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">More detailed information about each of these requests </span><a href=""https://docs.google.com/document/d/1rFrb5iZQavJ-YLWEB5c63fIFuBsZqhfrDqluKKeWDrY/edit?usp=sharing"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">can be found here</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Clean Water Education Week is more than holding meetings with lawmakers to discuss deficiencies in funding for resource agencies and modernizing conservation practices. It involves a number of tools and events in order to successfully champion clean water funding for all. Here&#39;s how we did it:</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<ul dir=""ltr"">
	<li role=""presentation"" style=""list-style-type: disc; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre; line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Joint Sign-On Letter</span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> - We are thankful for the support of</span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> 29 partner organizations</span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> that </span><a href=""https://docs.google.com/document/d/1mTp56bYhmy_fa3dLApKSwoh9flr3iQYKzU3GZS3E9ak/edit?usp=sharing"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">signed on to a letter to Governor Shapiro and all members of the General Assembly</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> outlining our Clean Water Education Week requests.</span></span></li>
</ul>

<p style=""list-style-type: disc; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre; line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<ul dir=""ltr"">
	<li role=""presentation"" style=""list-style-type: disc; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre; line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Legislative Meetings </span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">- We held </span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">23 meetings</span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> with legislators representing portions of all of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s major watersheds. We met with freshman legislators and shared our insights with those in leadership positions. Each legislator received educational materials with summary talking points for each of our requests. We also saw a welcomed return to some in-person meetings in Harrisburg.</span></span></li>
</ul>

<ul dir=""ltr"">
	<li role=""presentation"" style=""list-style-type: disc; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre; line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Rotunda Press Conference</span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> - On Wednesday, May 3rd, we held a press conference in the main Rotunda of the Capitol Building. </span><a href=""https://www.facebook.com/PennFuture/videos/773998994428232"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">The recording can be watched on our Facebook page.&nbsp;</span></a></span></li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-left: 36pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">We want to thank our participating speakers, including:</span></span></p>

<ul dir=""ltr"">
	<li role=""presentation"" style=""list-style-type: circle; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre; margin-left: 36pt; line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Patrick McDonnell, President &amp; CEO, PennFuture</span></span></li>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Clean Water Education Week is an important part of our statewide efforts to champion Pennsylvania&rsquo;s rivers, streams, and waterways. Now, more than ever, we need to protect and preserve these natural resources for generations.</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-48c08ef5-7fff-387a-9150-e56cecfed02f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>
",Environment,"Donna Kohut, Policy Manager for Sustainable Economics; Jenny Tompkins, Campaign Manager for Clean Water Advocacy; Michael Mehrazar, Advocacy Manager"
2023 State of the Air: Pennsylvania Cities Rank Among Most Polluted,5/2/2023,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-af3787ce-7fff-58fd-7bea-9a18e1e8a346""></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-af3787ce-7fff-58fd-7bea-9a18e1e8a346""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">A new report ranks Pennsylvania cities among the worst in the nation for particle pollution, with at least one Pennsylvania metropolitan area making the lists of the 25 most polluted cities for short-term and annual particle pollution.&nbsp;The lists are otherwise largely dominated by cities in western states that are impacted from particle pollution caused by devastating wildfires, highlighting the magnitude of the damaging industrial pollution experienced by Pennsylvanians.</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-af3787ce-7fff-58fd-7bea-9a18e1e8a346""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></p>

<p><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">On April 19, 2023, the American Lung Association released its 24</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> annual &ldquo;State of the Air&rdquo; report, which grades Americans&rsquo; exposure to unhealthy levels of ozone air pollution, and both annual and short-term spikes in fine particulate pollution over the three-year period of 2019 to 2021.&nbsp;The &ldquo;State of the Air&rdquo; report evaluates daily and annual measures of particle pollution and daily measures of ozone, two of the most dangerous and widespread pollutants.&nbsp;The report uses air quality data to calculate values reflecting the air pollution problem which it uses to rank metropolitan areas and assign grades to counties, allowing the public to easily compare air pollution exposure between communities and to track air quality changes over time.</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-af3787ce-7fff-58fd-7bea-9a18e1e8a346""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<h2><span id=""docs-internal-guid-23e33db7-7fff-c011-b53f-65456a80dc7d""></span></h2>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.2; margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-23e33db7-7fff-c011-b53f-65456a80dc7d""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" font-weight:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Pennsylvania Cities Among Worst for Particle Pollution in Eastern U.S.</span></span></strong></h2>

<p dir=""ltr""><img alt=""Downtown Pittsburgh from Federal Street, Lafayette Hilltop, North Side  Source: Cbaile19"" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Downtown_Pittsburgh_from_Federal_Street-_North_Side-_2022-12-07-1.jpg"" style=""width: 450px; height: 338px; float: left;"" /><span id=""docs-internal-guid-a1e10d51-7fff-2d84-4ca3-829cc95cf5a9""></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-a1e10d51-7fff-2d84-4ca3-829cc95cf5a9""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">The report showed that the cities most impacted by high levels of particle pollution were those cities in the western U.S. where they are affected by wildfires.&nbsp;Because western wildfires are a major contributing factor for the increasing unhealthy levels of particulate pollution, it is not surprising that all but two of the 25 worst metro areas for short-term particle pollution are in western states.&nbsp;Pennsylvania has the unfortunate distinction of being home to the only two eastern cities to make that top 25 list, Pittsburgh and Lancaster, ranked 20</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> and 24</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> respectively.&nbsp;Both of which posted more days in high fine particle pollution in this years&rsquo; report.&nbsp;Pittsburgh&rsquo;s short-term particle pollution was ranked the worst in the nation east of Denver, Colorado.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-a1e10d51-7fff-2d84-4ca3-829cc95cf5a9""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">While the worst 25 cities for annual particle pollution were somewhat more geographically dispersed than the short-term particle pollution list, cities most affected by western droughts and wildfires still accounted for much of the list.&nbsp; Pittsburgh ranked 14</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> worst for annual particle pollution overall and ranked the third worst among those cities located east of Phoenix, with only Indianapolis and Detroit ranking higher.&nbsp;</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-a1e10d51-7fff-2d84-4ca3-829cc95cf5a9""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Ranking on the list of cities with the worst particle pollution in the country, without the direct impacts of wildfires, demonstrates just how much Pennsylvania communities are being damaged by air pollution from industrial sources.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.2;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.2; margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-84209c21-7fff-810a-438e-b7a24955bbb3""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" font-weight:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Pittsburgh Metro Area Particle Pollution Worsening, Among Worst in U.S., and Ozone Pollution Improves</span></span></strong></h2>

<p dir=""ltr""><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Back_slopes_of_Mount_Washington-_2022-11-29-_01.jpg"" style=""width: 450px; height: 337px; float: left;"" /><span id=""docs-internal-guid-12f1718a-7fff-e384-2132-7894ddbac752""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">The 12-county Pittsburgh-New Castle-Weirton, PA-OH-WV metro area continued to rank among the worst polluted cities in the country for both annual and 24-hour particle pollution.&nbsp;The Pittsburgh metro area experienced more short-term spikes in particle pollution in comparison with last year&rsquo;s report.&nbsp;This means that residents of the Pittsburgh metro area experienced an average of more unhealthy days during the three years covered by this year&rsquo;s report than in the time period of last year&rsquo;s report, with an annual weighted average of 8.2 high particle days in the 2023 report in comparison with 7.7 days in the 2022 report.&nbsp;There was also a small increase in the annual particulate matter pollution in the Pittsburgh area.</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-12f1718a-7fff-e384-2132-7894ddbac752""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">As a result, the Pittsburgh metro area rose two slots to 20</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> on the list of cities with the worst short-term particle pollution out of 223 metro areas, up from 22</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">nd</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> place last year.&nbsp;It maintained last year&rsquo;s ranking of 14</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> worst city for annual particle pollution out of 200 metro areas.&nbsp;The worsening particle pollution in the Pittsburgh area is a troubling trend that shows much more needs to be done to curb harmful air pollution from industrial sources.</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-12f1718a-7fff-e384-2132-7894ddbac752""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">The Pittsburgh metro area did show improvement in the number of high ozone days, with its rank improving to 54</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> most polluted in the country out of 227 metro areas, down from 46</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> in the last report.&nbsp;Allegheny County also received its first passing grade for ozone, however it still experienced an annual weighted average of 2.0 unhealthy air days for ozone smog, earning it a C grade.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-12f1718a-7fff-e384-2132-7894ddbac752""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<h2><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8114bfbb-7fff-33a9-ceaf-44b114b3280e""></span></h2>

<h2 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.2; margin-top: 12pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8114bfbb-7fff-33a9-ceaf-44b114b3280e""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" font-weight:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Philadelphia Area Air Shows Improvement, Maintains Failing Grade for Ozone</span></span></strong></h2>
