<p dir=""ltr""><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Philadelphia_Skyline_from_the_Air_2.jpg"" style=""width: 450px; height: 338px; float: left;"" /><span id=""docs-internal-guid-03ca394a-7fff-a685-a8e6-acba06ac0e33""></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-03ca394a-7fff-a685-a8e6-acba06ac0e33""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">The 16-county Philadelphia-Reading-Camden, PA-NJ-DE-MD metro area experienced less unhealthy air days of high ozone, but with a ranking this year of 28</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> it still only managed to narrowly avoid inclusion in the list of the country&rsquo;s top 25 worst cities for ozone pollution.&nbsp; Both Philadelphia and Bucks counties still received failing grades for ozone, experiencing an annual weighted average of 6.5 and 5.7 unhealthy ozone days respectively.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-03ca394a-7fff-a685-a8e6-acba06ac0e33""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">The Philadelphia area&rsquo;s short-term particle pollution stayed the same from last year&rsquo;s report, with Delaware County still receiving a D grade with an unchanged number of unhealthy days of particle pollution.&nbsp; The Philadelphia area&rsquo;s national rank did improve to 55</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> worst city for short-term particle pollution, up from 48</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> in last year&rsquo;s report.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-03ca394a-7fff-a685-a8e6-acba06ac0e33""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">In welcome news, the report found that the Philadelphia area experienced lower year-round particle pollution levels than in last year&rsquo;s report.&nbsp; The Philadelphia area dropped off the list of the 25 most polluted cities for annual particle pollution.&nbsp; The area was tied for 18</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> most polluted in last year&rsquo;s report, and this year leapt down to 46</span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span style=""font-size:0.6em;vertical-align:super;"">th</span></span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""> most polluted for year-round particle pollution.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"">&nbsp;</p>

<h2 dir=""ltr""><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-866997c2-7fff-0568-f1a5-653cf603ebe5""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" font-weight:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">Many Pennsylvania Counties Receive Failing or Poor Grades for High Ozone Days and Short-Term Particle Pollution</span></span></strong></h2>

<p dir=""ltr""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-c94ebb74-7fff-7e16-06f9-a1cea9ffb9cf""></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-c94ebb74-7fff-7e16-06f9-a1cea9ffb9cf""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">The report paints a worrying overall picture of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s air quality.&nbsp; Based on the air quality data available, the report was able to assign grades for 40 out of the 67 counties in Pennsylvania for at least one measure of air quality.&nbsp; Bucks and Philadelphia counties both received a failing grade for high ozone days, with six other Pennsylvania counties receiving a C grade for high ozone days (Allegheny, Armstrong, Berks, Delaware, Montgomery, and Northampton).&nbsp; For short-term particle pollution, Allegheny and Lancaster counties each received a failing grade.&nbsp; Berks, Cumberland, Dauphin, and Delaware counties received a D grade for short-term particle pollution, and six other Pennsylvania counties received a C grade (Beaver, Chester, Lebanon, Lehigh, Northampton, and Philadelphia).&nbsp; Overall, 15 counties in Pennsylvania received a C grade or lower for at least one pollutant measure.</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-c94ebb74-7fff-7e16-06f9-a1cea9ffb9cf""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">The 2023 &ldquo;State of the Air&rdquo; shows that Pennsylvanians continue to be exposed to harmful levels of air pollution, and much more work needs to be done to fight air pollution from industrial sources and to ensure communities across Pennsylvania can breathe clean air.</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-c94ebb74-7fff-7e16-06f9-a1cea9ffb9cf""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:="""">PennFuture is dedicated to protecting and improving air quality for all of Pennsylvania.&nbsp; If you are interested in supporting our work, please become a member today!&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-c94ebb74-7fff-7e16-06f9-a1cea9ffb9cf""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></div>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8114bfbb-7fff-33a9-ceaf-44b114b3280e""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" font-weight:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></div>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-a1e10d51-7fff-2d84-4ca3-829cc95cf5a9""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></div>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-23e33db7-7fff-c011-b53f-65456a80dc7d""><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" font-weight:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></div>
",Environment; Keep Philly Green & Water Clean,"Angela Kilbert, Staff Attorney"
Why Go Solar?,4/24/2023,"<p></p>

<p><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""><span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Across Pennsylvania, interest is growing in rooftop solar panels for environmental and economic reasons. Despite early adoption, </span><a href=""https://www.seia.org/state-solar-policy/pennsylvania-solar"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">PA ranks 26th</span></a><span> in the nation for solar installations; </span><a href=""https://www.seia.org/state-solar-policy/texas-solar"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Texas</span></a><span>, on the other hand, ranks 2nd, with 10,346 solar jobs and more than 4 GW of solar expected to be installed by 2027 to replace retiring fossil fuel generators. With increasing heatwaves and extreme weather events, the growth of renewables in Texas will be crucial for </span><a href=""https://www.cnn.com/2022/06/14/us/texas-energy-record-solar-wind-climate/index.html"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">maintaining grid reliability and keeping prices low</span></a><span>.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span><span>According to a </span><a href=""https://votesolar.org/poll-finds-overwhelming-support-for-solar-power-in-pennsylvania/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">2022 Embold Research poll</span></a><span>, solar has strong support across PA: 65% of respondents, across all demographic groups, want to see increased solar production, restoring Pennsylvania&rsquo;s prior status as a national solar leader. Neighboring states, such as Maryland, New York, and New Jersey, all have higher renewable energy targets (50% by 2030) compared to PA&rsquo;s current goal of 8% renewable energy (with half a percent from solar). Scaling up solar, both residential and utility-scale, will create abundant jobs and cost savings, improve residents&rsquo; health, and help PA lower its carbon footprint. Otherwise, Pennsylvania will continue missing out on solar benefits.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<div><span><span></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Installation_of_solar_PV_panels_-_panels_in_place_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2624288.jpg"" style=""width: 600px; height: 241px; float: left;"" /><span id=""docs-internal-guid-63016621-7fff-b78a-53a3-82aa797aedff""></span><strong><span style=""color:#808080;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-63016621-7fff-b78a-53a3-82aa797aedff""><span></span></span></span></strong></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong><span style=""color:#808080;""><span><span>Cost Predictability:&nbsp;</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-63016621-7fff-b78a-53a3-82aa797aedff""><span></span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-375d74f0-7fff-dc10-e9c8-555d4d0c28e7""></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-375d74f0-7fff-dc10-e9c8-555d4d0c28e7""><span></span></span></span></strong></div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span><span>For one, solar energy offers homeowners reliable power with predictable costs: a benefit that cannot be derived from fossil fuels.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<div>
<ul>
	<li><span id=""docs-internal-guid-375d74f0-7fff-dc10-e9c8-555d4d0c28e7""><span style=""font-size: 11pt;"">During </span><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-What-We-Learned-from-the-December-2022-Deep-Freeze-Dont-Rely-on-Natural-Gas-When-Its-Fracking-Cold-Part-1"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">December 2022 Winter Storm Elliott</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt;"">, wholesale energy prices (from failing fracked gas plants) soared, leaving many homeowners questioning whether continued dependence on fracked gas is good for their wallets.</span></span></li>
	<li><span id=""docs-internal-guid-375d74f0-7fff-dc10-e9c8-555d4d0c28e7""><span style=""font-size: 11pt;"">Fracked gas must be purchased constantly at an average of </span><a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/24/business/energy-environment/solar-and-wind-energy-start-to-win-on-price-vs-conventional-fuels.html#:~:text=According%20to%20a%20study%20by,and%20coal%20at%206.6%20cents."" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">$0.061 per kilowatt-hour and coal at $0.066</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt;"">, whereas rooftop solar power is free once the system cost is covered&mdash;and there is not much room for fossil fuels prices to decrease.&nbsp;</span></span></li>
	<li><span id=""docs-internal-guid-375d74f0-7fff-dc10-e9c8-555d4d0c28e7""><span style=""font-size: 11pt;"">Costs of home heating oil are also rising: according to the </span><a href=""https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=54699#:~:text=Residential%20heating%20oil%20prices%20rose,imports%2C%20and%20limited%20production%20capacity."" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt;"">, U.S. heating oil prices were 65% higher in October 2022 than the previous year, reaching a high of $5.90 per gallon on November 7, 2022.</span></span></li>
</ul>
</div>

<p style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></p>

<h3>&nbsp;</h3>

<h3><strong><span style=""color:#808080;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5d6a373d-7fff-22ea-0039-3e0edf264146""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5d6a373d-7fff-22ea-0039-3e0edf264146""><span>Healthier Energy Source:&nbsp;</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5d6a373d-7fff-22ea-0039-3e0edf264146""><span></span></span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-a57c7a84-7fff-6471-ff41-8de5ec2f4ffb""></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-a57c7a84-7fff-6471-ff41-8de5ec2f4ffb""><span></span></span><span></span></span></strong><span><span></span></span></h3>

<p><span><span>Not only are fossil fuels increasingly expensive, but they are also </span><a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/sites/default/files/climate-change-health-impacts-pennsylvania-ib.pdf"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">detrimental to our health</span></a><span> and environment. Fossil fuel pollution is linked to adverse health problems such as asthma, heart issues, heat-related illnesses, and greater exposure to infectious diseases. Related emissions and spills have polluted our air and water as well as caused toxic contamination of our food supply, extreme weather, and environmental disasters.&nbsp;</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-a57c7a84-7fff-6471-ff41-8de5ec2f4ffb""><span></span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-962f1fab-7fff-aca5-b614-15e08e3a4895""></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong><span style=""color:#808080;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-962f1fab-7fff-aca5-b614-15e08e3a4895""><span>Long-term cost savings and reduced carbon footprint:&nbsp;</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-962f1fab-7fff-aca5-b614-15e08e3a4895""><span></span></span></span></strong></h3>

<h3><strong><span style=""color:#808080;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b47fdf0f-7fff-d29f-1b5e-dc323d31f38c""></span></span></strong></h3>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b47fdf0f-7fff-d29f-1b5e-dc323d31f38c""><span>Rooftop solar panels offer clean energy at a more affordable cost than ever, thanks to the Inflation Reduction Act. Solar panels also will increase home value, and provide energy savings of approximately </span><a href=""https://www.ecowatch.com/solar/worth-it/pa"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">$23,634 after the payback period</span></a><span>. Through net metering, homeowners can receive credit for the energy that they add to the grid, effectively removing their electricity bills.</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b47fdf0f-7fff-d29f-1b5e-dc323d31f38c""><span></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Back_of_Visitor_Center_with_solar_panels_%286347776413%29%281%29.jpg"" style=""width: 640px; height: 480px;"" /></div>

<h2><span id=""docs-internal-guid-c695874a-7fff-3526-1cc5-bc8b9540bd3a""></span></h2>

<h2><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-c695874a-7fff-3526-1cc5-bc8b9540bd3a""><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">What&rsquo;s a solar co-op?</span></span></strong><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-c695874a-7fff-3526-1cc5-bc8b9540bd3a""><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-d76b349c-7fff-601d-e307-d689e033df7e""></span></span></span></strong></h2>

<div>
<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-d76b349c-7fff-601d-e307-d689e033df7e""><span>A </span><a href=""https://www.energy.gov/eere/solar/articles/purchasing-power-going-solar-through-cooperatives#:~:text=A%20solar%20co%2Dop%20is,and%20typically%20receiving%20bulk%20discounts."" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">solar co-op</span></a><span> consists of individual homeowners and/or businesses who join together to learn about going solar, provide mutual support, and benefit from bulk discounts&mdash;as a group, co-ops are able to obtain competitive bids from solar installers. Solar co-ops are free to join, flexible (members are not required to go solar), and focused on meeting members&rsquo; needs and priorities.</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-d76b349c-7fff-601d-e307-d689e033df7e""><span></span></span></div>
<span><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<h3><strong><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></strong><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></h3>

<h3><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1f35504-7fff-49f5-b192-0d2e101f8ef5""></span></h3>

<h3><strong><span style=""color:#808080;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1f35504-7fff-49f5-b192-0d2e101f8ef5""><span>Local Case:</span></span></span></strong></h3>

<p><strong><span style=""color:#808080;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-040c9e5e-7fff-9389-d061-0f52e22a51f0""></span></span></strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-040c9e5e-7fff-9389-d061-0f52e22a51f0""><span>Residents of Lancaster, PA currently have the opportunity to join Solar United Neighbor (SUN)&rsquo;s </span><a href=""https://www.solarunitedneighbors.org/co-ops/pennsylvania/lancaster-county-2023-solar-and-ev-charger-co-op/#coop"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Lancaster Solar Co-op</span></a><span>, which aims to reach 100 members by July 31, 2023 and have solar installations completed in spring 2024. This group is facilitated by SUN and nine community partners, who are offering educational sessions and support, advice on financing, and a solar installation discount. SUN plans to continue expanding their co-ops to reach more PA counties in the future.</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-040c9e5e-7fff-9389-d061-0f52e22a51f0""><span></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<h3><span id=""docs-internal-guid-776ea349-7fff-b833-6620-348a261d77d1""></span><strong><span style=""color:#808080;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-776ea349-7fff-b833-6620-348a261d77d1""><span>Equitable Energy:</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-776ea349-7fff-b833-6620-348a261d77d1""><span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-481cfcfe-7fff-fdeb-883d-ab10391b55ee""></span></span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-481cfcfe-7fff-fdeb-883d-ab10391b55ee""><span></span></span></span></strong><span><span></span></span><span><span></span></span></h3>

<p><span><span>Solar co-ops can also offer a way to advance energy equity and lower the energy burdens for lower and middle income (LMI) homeowners through providing free rooftop solar panels. Low-income households are more likely to spend a larger portion of their income on energy than wealthier homeowners, but installing solar panels is often unaffordable. SUN is also planning an upcoming solar co-op in Allegheny County, following the success of their </span><a href=""https://www.wesa.fm/environment-energy/2023-03-31/putting-equity-in-energy-local-partners-celebrate-solar-program-for-low-income-homeowners"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">LMI pilot program</span></a><span> there. With programs such as SUN&rsquo;s that augment solar access and equity in LMI communities, resulting lower energy bills can significantly improve quality of life.</span></span></p>

<div>
<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-481cfcfe-7fff-fdeb-883d-ab10391b55ee""><span></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2><span id=""docs-internal-guid-7adf01a9-7fff-5a23-f9a3-618e3a45d366""></span></h2>

<h2><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-7adf01a9-7fff-5a23-f9a3-618e3a45d366""><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">What is community solar?</span></span></strong><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-7adf01a9-7fff-5a23-f9a3-618e3a45d366""><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></strong><strong><span><span></span></span></strong><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-b1f35504-7fff-49f5-b192-0d2e101f8ef5""><span></span></span></strong></h2>
</div>

<h2 dir=""ltr""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-f3e6fe69-7fff-6d17-4bc4-ecbc2df4c311""></span></h2>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-f3e6fe69-7fff-6d17-4bc4-ecbc2df4c311""><span>If you cannot install solar panels (renters and those with unsuitable roofs), there is still a way to go solar through a community solar program. </span><a href=""https://www.energy.gov/eere/solar/articles/purchasing-power-going-solar-through-cooperatives"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Community solar</span></a><span> is defined by the U.S. Department of Energy as &ldquo;&hellip;any solar project or purchasing program in which the benefits of a single solar array or project flow to multiple customers.&rdquo; In community solar programs, a solar array provides energy directly to the electric grid and subscribers receive a credit lowering the cost of their energy bills. </span><a href=""https://www.ecowatch.com/community-solar-vs-solar-co-op.html"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Subscribers benefit</span></a><span> from electricity savings and a lower carbon footprint without having to install or maintain their own solar panels.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3><span style=""color:#808080;""><strong><span id=""docs-internal-guid-f3e6fe69-7fff-6d17-4bc4-ecbc2df4c311""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Economic advantage for Pennsylvania:</span></span></strong></span></h3>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-f3e6fe69-7fff-6d17-4bc4-ecbc2df4c311""><span>According to the </span><a href=""https://www.pa4communitysolar.com/_files/ugd/928c94_f03059a17fdc45e38808b379d4903230.pdf"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">PA Community Solar Economic Alliance</span></a><span>, 235 planned community solar projects across 48 counties await the passage of this legislation. These projects would provide a $1.8 billion economic stimulus and $83 million in local revenue.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-00dcdd3b-7fff-d103-941e-7fa77c76ed93""></span></p>

<p><strong><span style=""color:#808080;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-00dcdd3b-7fff-d103-941e-7fa77c76ed93""><span>Not available in Pennsylvania yet:</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-e7db2904-7fff-2135-d5b8-16f5705bad71""></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-e7db2904-7fff-2135-d5b8-16f5705bad71""><span></span></span></span></strong></p>

<p><span><span>Unfortunately, Pennsylvania is not one of the </span><a href=""https://www.epa.gov/green-power-markets/shared-renewables#:~:text=Shared%20renewables%20legislation%E2%80%94specifically%2C%20community,%2C%20Rhode%20Island%2C%20South%20Carolina%2C"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">22 states</span></a><span> that have policies allowing for community solar. Although community solar bills are expected to be re-introduced, prior bills have not moved from committee. Despite huge support in Pennsylvania &mdash;&nbsp; </span><a href=""https://www.pa4communitysolar.com/_files/ugd/928c94_f03059a17fdc45e38808b379d4903230.pdf"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">77% of voters</span></a><span> &mdash; Pennsylvania has still not passed this economic and environmentally advantageous legislation.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span></span></p>

<h2><span><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">What can you do?</span></span></h2>

<p></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-4820a08d-7fff-2ef7-b339-27de0c59c0cc""><span>Solar is a wise investment for homeowners concerned about rising energy prices and negative health impacts of fossil fuels, as well as those wanting to shift to sustainable energy. There are options for individuals to learn more about solar, especially if you&rsquo;re unsure of where to start:&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<ul dir=""ltr"">
	<li><a href=""https://www.solarunitedneighbors.org/go-solar/want-to-install-solar/go-solar-in-a-coop/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">SUN Solar Co-Ops</span></a></span></li>
	<li><a href=""https://pasolarcenter.org/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">PA Solar Center</span></a></span></li>
	<li><a href=""https://votesolar.org/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Vote Solar</span></a></span></li>
	<li><a href=""https://www.sierraclub.org/pennsylvania/clean-energy-team"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">PA Sierra Club</span></a></span></li>
	<li><a href=""https://www.nrel.gov/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">National Renewable Energy Laboratory</span></a></span></li>
	<li><a href=""https://center4ee.org/how-solar-energy-works/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Center for Energy Education</span></a></span></li>
	<li><a href=""https://www.phillysolar.org/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Philadelphia Solar Energy Association</span></a></span></li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span></span></p>

<h2><span><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Our Position:&nbsp;</span></span></h2>

<p dir=""ltr""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8d57ea60-7fff-3b91-0afe-ecd049b62123""></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8d57ea60-7fff-3b91-0afe-ecd049b62123""><span>PennFuture advocates for community solar programs and clean energy access for all Pennsylvanians, and provides research to lawmakers on the benefits of solar. We support the following proposed solar policies:</span></span></p>

<ul dir=""ltr"">
	<li><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8d57ea60-7fff-3b91-0afe-ecd049b62123""><a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billinfo/billinfo.cfm?syear=2023&amp;sind=0&amp;body=S&amp;type=B&amp;bn=230"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">SB 230: Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards Act</span></a></span></li>
	<li><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8d57ea60-7fff-3b91-0afe-ecd049b62123""><a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billinfo/bill_history.cfm?syear=2023&amp;sind=0&amp;body=H&amp;type=B&amp;bn=137"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">HB 550: Solar for Schools Act</span></a></span></li>
	<li><a href=""http://https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billinfo/billinfo.cfm?sYear=2023&amp;sInd=0&amp;body=S&amp;type=B&amp;bn=550.""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8d57ea60-7fff-3b91-0afe-ecd049b62123""><span style=""font-size: 11pt;"">New Community Solar Bill (SB 550)</span></span></a></li>
	<li><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8d57ea60-7fff-3b91-0afe-ecd049b62123""><span style=""font-size: 11pt;"">Solar access legislation: not yet proposed</span></span></li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8d57ea60-7fff-3b91-0afe-ecd049b62123""><span>To get involved in this important fight, become a PennFuture member, consider installing solar or your home or join a solar co-op, and tell your legislator you want community solar and other pro-solar policies.</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-8d57ea60-7fff-3b91-0afe-ecd049b62123""><span></span></span></div>

<div><span><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<div><span><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-e7db2904-7fff-2135-d5b8-16f5705bad71""><span></span></span></div>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-00dcdd3b-7fff-d103-941e-7fa77c76ed93""><span></span></span></div>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-f3e6fe69-7fff-6d17-4bc4-ecbc2df4c311""><span></span></span></div>

<p><span><a href=""https://www.phillysolar.org/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></a></span><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></p>

<div><span><span background-color:="""" color:="""" font-variant-alternates:="""" font-variant-east-asian:="""" font-variant-numeric:="""" new="""" style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: "" times="""" vertical-align:="""" white-space:=""""></span></span></div>
",Climate,"Caroline Weiss, Legal intern"
West Chester stormwater case: how ordinance language can harm PA’s pollution control,4/12/2023,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-f09577c4-7fff-7701-368b-ef82a8e614d8""></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-f09577c4-7fff-7701-368b-ef82a8e614d8""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">The Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania recently published an opinion holding that West Chester Borough&#39;s (&quot;West Chester&quot;) stormwater charge constituted a tax from which the Pennsylvania State System of Higher Education (the &quot;Universities&quot;) was immune from payment. </span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Borough of W. Chester v. Pennsylvania State Sys. of Higher Educ.</span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">, No. 260 M.D. 2018, 2023 WL 27942 (Pa. Commw. Ct. Jan. 4, 2023).</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-f09577c4-7fff-7701-368b-ef82a8e614d8""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">West Chester operates a Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System (MS4) and imposes a stormwater charge on owners of developed properties that benefit from the system.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-f09577c4-7fff-7701-368b-ef82a8e614d8""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">The Universities were assessed charges but refused to pay, arguing that the stormwater charge constituted a tax from which they were immune because state entities are immune from local taxation. West Chester argued that the charges were service fees and filed a petition in the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania to determine the rights and obligations of the Universities regarding the stormwater charges. The court held that the stormwater charge was a tax, not a fee.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-f09577c4-7fff-7701-368b-ef82a8e614d8""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">West Chester filed an appeal to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, but the ruling already generated controversy among other municipalities with similar stormwater ordinances and tax-exempted entities.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-f09577c4-7fff-7701-368b-ef82a8e614d8""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<div><img alt="""" class=""align-left"" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Stormwater-%281%29.jpg"" style=""width: 480px; float: left; height: 480px;"" /><span style=""background-color: transparent; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-weight: 700; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Stormwater Fees Help Manage Pollution from Stormwater Runoff&nbsp;</span></div>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-d385dd52-7fff-0291-1cfc-5fd29b8c91b6""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-d122ced3-7fff-882b-fa2a-b2aae9f7bbc3""></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-d122ced3-7fff-882b-fa2a-b2aae9f7bbc3""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Under the Clean Water Act, state and local governments must implement stormwater management to minimize environmental and economic harm to cities and local communities. In 2008, the National Research Council and the Environmental Protection Agency released a report identifying unmanaged stormwater from rain or snow events as a significant source of water pollution. As precipitation runs down rooftops and over dirty streets and sidewalks, the stormwater collects pollutants such as oil, fertilizer, litter, and pet waste. Stormwater runoff carries pollutants into nearby rivers, streams, and lakes.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-d122ced3-7fff-882b-fa2a-b2aae9f7bbc3""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Municipalities typically serve on the frontlines of stormwater management, but operating and maintaining stormwater infrastructure is a significant expense. Although various funding mechanisms are used around the country to build and improve stormwater management systems, a standard tool is implementing a fee on user-landowners who contribute to stormwater runoff.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-d122ced3-7fff-882b-fa2a-b2aae9f7bbc3""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Like many other municipalities, West Chester charges a stormwater fee to raise revenue that is redirected back into the system for specific stormwater projects. Municipalities will charge property owners a stormwater fee proportionate to the amount of impervious cover (ex., concrete) their property contains. In plain language, this means that the more impervious surface area on a property, which causes more stormwater runoff, the fee will increase.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-d122ced3-7fff-882b-fa2a-b2aae9f7bbc3""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Commercial properties, which often contain paved parking lots, service roads, large buildings, and sidewalks, burden a town&#39;s stormwater system more than a single-family home and are, therefore, likely to pay higher stormwater fees.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-d122ced3-7fff-882b-fa2a-b2aae9f7bbc3""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<h3><span id=""docs-internal-guid-ccecf97d-7fff-f2ca-5c6d-11794bfb9a27""></span></h3>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-ccecf97d-7fff-f2ca-5c6d-11794bfb9a27""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Ruling Hurts Municipalities&rsquo; Ability to Manage Stormwater Pollution</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-ccecf97d-7fff-f2ca-5c6d-11794bfb9a27""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-bab89cba-7fff-4110-966a-47b2db274280""></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-bab89cba-7fff-4110-966a-47b2db274280""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">The Commonwealth Court&#39;s ruling disrupts West Chester&#39;s ability to assess fees against tax-exempted entities designed to defray the cost associated with implementing environmental regulatory requirements&mdash;shifting the cost now onto taxpayers and other members of the community.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-bab89cba-7fff-4110-966a-47b2db274280""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Under the court&#39;s ruling, tax-exempted entities such as universities and churches that disproportionately burden stormwater systems no longer have to pay their fair share of the cost of stormwater management.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-bab89cba-7fff-4110-966a-47b2db274280""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Despite the Commonwealth Court&#39;s holding that West Chester&#39;s stormwater charge constitutes a tax, the decision does not hold that all stormwater fees are taxes. The particular facts pertaining to West Chester&#39;s Stormwater Ordinance, the testimony, and the factual record developed in the proceeding tipped the scale towards West Chester&#39;s stormwater charge constituting a tax rather than a fee.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-bab89cba-7fff-4110-966a-47b2db274280""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">The court discussed the differences between a tax and a fee for service, noting that while a tax is imposed on many or all citizens, it contributes to a general fund. Municipalities use the collected revenue to benefit the entire community. Fees, however, provide a discrete benefit not shared by the community and are paid voluntarily.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-bab89cba-7fff-4110-966a-47b2db274280""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">The court found that West Chester failed to &quot;point to any evidence that [the Universities] receive[d] discrete benefits through payment of the stormwater charge.&quot;</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-bab89cba-7fff-4110-966a-47b2db274280""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<h3><span id=""docs-internal-guid-3164dbcd-7fff-8325-9fa9-f4d30b2b28f9""></span></h3>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-3164dbcd-7fff-8325-9fa9-f4d30b2b28f9""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">A Similar Case in Virginia, But With a Different Outcome</span></span></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-3164dbcd-7fff-8325-9fa9-f4d30b2b28f9""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-82616659-7fff-bcda-073e-077aa3f4067c""></span>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-82616659-7fff-bcda-073e-077aa3f4067c""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">In a contrasting analysis, the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals held that a similar stormwater charge imposed by the City of Roanoke was a fee, not a tax. Norfolk S. Ry. Co. v. City of Roanoke, 916 F.3d 315 (4th Cir. 2019). The City of Roanoke enacted a stormwater fee to fund its stormwater management system, similar to West Chester&#39;s program. Roanoke assessed a stormwater charge for Norfolk Southern Railway, but Norfolk Southern refused to pay and sued the city, alleging that the charge was a discriminatory tax against railways. The Fourth Circuit applied a multi-factor analysis to determine whether the charge was a tax or a fee. Unlike the Commonwealth Court, the Fourth Circuit found that the properties charged did receive a discrete benefit from the funded stormwater system by controlling and treating polluted stormwater contributed by developed properties.&nbsp;</span></span></p>
&nbsp;

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-82616659-7fff-bcda-073e-077aa3f4067c""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Furthermore, the Fourth Circuit determined that the primary purpose of the stormwater charge serves a regulatory function to manage stormwater runoff to comply with state and federal requirements, constituting a fee rather than a tax.</span></span></p>
&nbsp;

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-82616659-7fff-bcda-073e-077aa3f4067c""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">As West Chester awaits an appeal to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, the lower court&#39;s ruling has widespread implications for the validity of stormwater fees. Carefully drafted stormwater ordinances must delineate that stormwater fees are tied to city services as an alternative to property owners dealing with stormwater discharge on an individual basis and that the purpose of revenue collected will fund specific stormwater projects. These considerations in structuring stormwater ordinances help stormwater charges to bear the characteristic of a service fee rather than a tax.</span></span></p>
&nbsp;

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-82616659-7fff-bcda-073e-077aa3f4067c""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">PennFuture has long championed the use of stormwater fees in PA and has even drafted a </span><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PennFuture_StormwaterManual_web_3.20.17.pdf"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">model fees ordinance</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">. We are currently figuring out how best to support West Chester Borough and other municipalities and how to protect the use of stormwater fees in light of this ruling.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">UPDATE: <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/2023.7.13-PF-West-Chester-Amicus-TIME-STAMPED.pdf"">view the amicus brief here</a></p>

<div><span id=""docs-internal-guid-82616659-7fff-bcda-073e-077aa3f4067c""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></div>
</div>
",Environment,"Malisa Dang, Legal Intern"
Philly Spill Scare: This Is Why We Fight,4/4/2023,"<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">Last week, Philadelphians dealt with the fallout of a chemical spill into the Delaware River, their drinking water source. By mid-week, the Philadelphia Water Department (PWD) and the city announced that the chemical plume&mdash;and thus the immediate danger&mdash;had passed and that the city&rsquo;s drinking water had tested safe. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-In-Drinking-Water-Scare-Philly-Should-Stay-Mad-at-its-Complacent-Leaders"">PennFuture</a> and others have rightly and roundly criticized the response of City officials as a case study of what not to do in a potential environmental crisis, so today, I&rsquo;m here to talk about something else.</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">Now that the initial emergency has passed, I cannot help but think: &ldquo;This is&nbsp;</span><em style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">exactly</em><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;why we fight for the environmental protections we have and fight to make them stronger.&rdquo;&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; </span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">We have many unanswered questions about the spill&mdash;Why did the city wait so long to tell folks? How sensitive is the testing that PWD is doing? How will they do better next time?&mdash;but one of the things that seems true is that the city, at least, found out about the spill in time to shut off the water intakes from the Delaware. This wasn&rsquo;t the result of corporate benevolence or some happy accident but of some (largely invisible) protections:</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">Folks should know first that this report happened because it was required to do so: Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Clean Streams Law, 25 Pa. Code &sect; 91.33(a), requires&nbsp;</span><em style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">any</em><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;polluter who spills a substance that could endanger downstream users to report the spill to DEP immediately.&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">What kind of substance counts? The adage that &ldquo;the dose makes the poison&rdquo; applies here: DEP has issued&nbsp;</span><a class=""editor-rtfLink"" href=""http://www.depgreenport.state.pa.us/elibrary/GetDocument?docId=3963581&amp;DocName=GUIDANCE%20ON%20NOTIFICATION%20REQS.%20FOR%20SPILLS%2C%20DISCHARGES%2C%20%26amp%3B%20OTHER%20INCIDENTS%20OF%20A%20SUBSTANCE%20CAUSING%20OR%20THREATENING%20POLLUTION%20TO%20WATERS%20OF%20THE%20COMMONWEALTH%20UNDER%20PA%26%2339%3BS%20CLEAN%20STREAMS%20LAW.PDF%20%20%3Cspan%20style%3D%22color%3Agreen%3B%22%3ECOMMENTS%20DUE%20DECEMBER%2015%2C%202021%3C%2Fspan%3E"" style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;; color: #4a6ee0;"" target=""_blank""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">guidance</span></a><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;explaining that even substances that might generally be non-toxic (milk, for example) should be reported if it is spilled in large enough quantity.&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">So if your toddler spills a cup of milk in the Schuylkill, that&rsquo;s fine. If a truck tanker of milk tips over into the Wiss, that&rsquo;s another matter entirely! If I went to walk through the Wiss and the water was white and opaque, I&rsquo;d want to know what was going on and whether my family was safe. Under our current rules, I could find out.&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">Folks should know next that state Senator Gene Yaw (R Dist. 23) has re-upped efforts from last year to weaken these reporting rules that keep us safe. The &ldquo;Let Them Spill&rdquo; bills from the 2021-22 session (</span><a class=""editor-rtfLink"" href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billInfo/billInfo.cfm?sYear=2021&amp;sInd=0&amp;body=H&amp;type=B&amp;bn=1842"" style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;; color: #4a6ee0;"" target=""_blank""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">HB 1842</span></a><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;and</span><a class=""editor-rtfLink"" href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billinfo/billinfo.cfm?syear=2021&amp;sind=0&amp;body=S&amp;type=B&amp;bn=545"" style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;; color: #4a6ee0;"" target=""_blank""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;SB 545</span></a><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">) have reared their heads again for the 2022-23 session as</span><a class=""editor-rtfLink"" href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billinfo/billinfo.cfm?syear=2023&amp;sind=0&amp;body=S&amp;type=B&amp;bn=286"" style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;; color: #4a6ee0;"" target=""_blank""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;SB 286</span></a><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">. The bill&rsquo;s sponsor claims they are making the reporting requirements more straightforward. The reality is that the legislation would serve only to make life easier for polluters by letting the polluters themselves decide when and how much of a chemical is a problem.&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">The bill does this by hiding behind the &ldquo;numeric water quality criteria&rdquo; established by the state while conveniently ignoring that (as the Inquirer</span><a class=""editor-rtfLink"" href=""https://www.inquirer.com/health/philadelphia-drinking-water-epa-acrylate-trinseo-20230331.html"" style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;; color: #4a6ee0;"" target=""_blank""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;reported</span></a><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">) the industry has been resisting any new chemicals added to water quality criteria for decades.</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">Let&rsquo;s play out how Philly&rsquo;s water scare could have gone under this new scheme:&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">The chemicals released into the Delaware&mdash;ethyl acrylate, methyl methacrylate, butyl acrylate, and Styrene&mdash;aren&rsquo;t currently in the state&rsquo;s water quality criteria. Moreover, the new wording would allow polluters to &ldquo;take into account any control and remedial measures.&rdquo;&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">The result?&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">The Bristol plant operators could decide that they had shut the leak down early enough that &ldquo;only&rdquo; 8,000 gallons of the chemical had spilled and that these chemicals don&rsquo;t have a reportable requirement anyway. And then, they simply could choose not to report it, and none of the thousands of people in multiple states who use the water would have known.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">Clean, clear, safe water requires clean, clear information sharing. Because of the reporting requirements that protect us right now, the system in the back of the house appears to have worked, letting the various authorities act in time to save Philly&rsquo;s drinking water from the worst harm. It isn&rsquo;t hard to imagine a different outcome.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; </span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">The best way to keep us safe is to keep these environmental problems from happening in the first place. But to the extent that accidents happen, the next best thing is ensuring that citizens and authorities know about them and have all of the information they need.&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">We dodged the worst this time, but this could happen again. Industry and other polluters will not</span><a class=""editor-rtfLink"" href=""https://www.inquirer.com/news/delaware-river-pollution-toxic-chemical-companies-philadelphia-drinking-water-20230331.html"" style=""color: rgb(14, 16, 26); background: transparent; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt;; color: #4a6ee0;"" target=""_blank""><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;keep us safe</span></a><span data-preserver-spaces=""true"" style=""background: transparent; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"">&nbsp;simply out of the goodness of their hearts. Accidents happen. I fight so that when the next spill comes, we will know, we will better understand what the threats are to our community, and we will be able to stay safe.</span></p>
",Environment,"Emma Bast, Staff Attorney"
"Why PennFuture, Partners Petitioned EPA to Object to U.S. Steel’s Clairton Coke Works Title V Operating Permit",3/29/2023,"<h2><span id=""docs-internal-guid-08e7dbe4-7fff-9826-3328-2bad9ab7006b""></span></h2>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: right;"">(Image:&nbsp;U.S. Steel&#39;s Clairton Coke Works, Clairton, PA. Photo credit: Reid R. Frazier / StateImpact Pennsylvania)</p>

<p dir=""ltr""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">The renewed air permit for U.S. Steel&rsquo;s Clairton Coke Works, issued last year by the Allegheny County Health Department (ACHD), fails to include the monitoring and testing requirements needed to ensure the facility actually complies with its permit limits.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">That&rsquo;s why PennFuture, along with our partner groups&mdash; Environmental Integrity Project and Clean Air Council&mdash;</span><a href=""https://www.epa.gov/system/files/documents/2023-03/EIP%20CAC%20PennFuture%20Clairton%20Coke%20Petition_3-06-23.pdf"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> formally petitioned</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> the Administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to object to the Title V Operating Permit issued by ACHD on November 21, 2022, to the U.S. Steel Mon Valley Works Clairton Plant.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><strong><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial; font-size: 14.6667px; font-weight: 700; white-space: pre-wrap;"">The Problems with this Title V Permit</span></strong></h3>

<p dir=""ltr"">&nbsp;</p>
