<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">PennFuture and partners are urging EPA to object to the Title V Renewal Permit because it does not include testing, monitoring, reporting, and recordkeeping requirements sufficient to ensure compliance with multiple air quality emissions limitations for multiple emissions sources. For the Clairton Coke Works facility, this includes requirements for coke oven battery combustion stacks, flares, boilers, and quench towers.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p><br />
<span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Pollutants of concern emitted by the facility include particulate matter (PM), carbon monoxide (CO), volatile organic compounds (VOCs), nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur dioxide (SO2), and several hazardous air pollutants, including benzene.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">This Title V Renewal Permit does not include monitoring and testing requirements sufficient to ensure compliance with necessary air quality protections or adequate measures to reduce the community&rsquo;s exposure to harmful emissions. Sufficiently monitoring the emissions of PM, CO, VOCs, NOx,&nbsp; SO2, and hazardous air pollutants from Clairton Coke Works is critical to protecting the community from harmful exceedances.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&nbsp;</span></span><strong><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial; font-size: 14.6667px; font-weight: 700; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></strong></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><strong><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial; font-size: 14.6667px; font-weight: 700; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Clairton Coke Works&rsquo; History of Air Pollution</span></strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">The U.S. Steel&rsquo;s Clairton Coke Works is the largest coke plant in North America and a significant source of air pollution in Allegheny County. It also has a history of noncompliance with environmental requirements.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">In 2022 alone, ACHD issued over </span><a href=""https://www.wesa.fm/environment-energy/2022-12-03/u-s-steel-fined-458k-by-allegheny-county-for-air-violations"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">$9 million in fines</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> to U.S. Steel for emissions-related violations. The latest </span><a href=""https://www.alleghenycounty.us/uploadedFiles/Allegheny_Home/Health_Department/Programs/Air_Quality/Enforcement/USS-0052sao2023-03-15ref190604-Demand-for-Stipulated-Penalties.pdf"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></a><a href=""https://www.alleghenycounty.us/uploadedFiles/Allegheny_Home/Health_Department/Programs/Air_Quality/Enforcement/USS-0052sao2023-03-15ref190604-Demand-for-Stipulated-Penalties.pdf""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">fines came down on Thursday, March 16 for $307,800</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""><a href=""https://www.alleghenycounty.us/uploadedFiles/Allegheny_Home/Health_Department/Programs/Air_Quality/Enforcement/USS-0052sao2023-03-15ref190604-Demand-for-Stipulated-Penalties.pdf""> </a>for air permit violations during the second quarter of 2022.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Air quality issues have been an ongoing public health concern in Allegheny County. The county </span><a href=""https://www.lung.org/media/press-releases/sota-pittsburgh-metro-area-2022"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">received a failing grade in the American Lung Association&rsquo;s 2022 State of the Air Report</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> <span id=""docs-internal-guid-7148b5bf-7fff-fdc0-d4fe-331dcfcd0132""></span></span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-7148b5bf-7fff-fdc0-d4fe-331dcfcd0132""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">for both daily fine particle and ozone pollution, and continued to rank in the worst 25 metro areas in the country for both annual and daily fine particle pollution. A recent University of Pittsburgh Medical Center study examining&nbsp; the Air Quality Index in Allegheny County from 2010 to 2018 found that </span><a href=""https://inside.upmc.com/alleghenycountypoorairquality/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">even moderate levels of air pollution increased ER visits for kids with asthma.</span></a></span></p>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></p>

<p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial; font-size: 14.6667px; font-weight: 700; white-space: pre-wrap;"">How Did We Get Here</span></strong></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">The Clean Air Act requires all significant sources of air pollution operate under what is known as&nbsp;</span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">a &ldquo;Title V&rdquo; permit. These permits are the primary method of enforcing and ensuring compliance with air pollution control.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Under the Clean Air Act, Title V permits must include all applicable limits and requirements for a facility, as well as monitoring, testing, reporting, and recordkeeping requirements sufficient to ensure compliance with all terms and conditions in the permit.</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Clairton Coke Works&rsquo; last Title V operating permit was issued in 2012 and expired in 2017. U.S. Steel applied for a renewal in 2016, however, according to the County, the renewal process has been delayed by regulatory and operational changes, including the 2018 Christmas Eve fire at the Clairton facility.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">PennFuture and partners submitted detailed comments on the draft Title V renewal permit issued by ACHD during the public comment period in early 2022, and ACHD sent the final Title V renewal permit to EPA for review in November 2022. A Title V petition allows anyone to raise concerns to EPA and to ask them to object to the issuance of the permit for a specific facility if those concerns were raised to the permitting authority during the appropriate notice and comment period.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Because ACHD&rsquo;s final Title V renewal permit fails to include sufficient monitoring and testing requirements for PM, CO, VOCs, NOx, SO2, and hazardous air pollutants, the final renewal permit fails to comply with the Clean Air Act.&nbsp; Accordingly, PennFuture and partners petitioned EPA to object to the permit.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">If EPA grants the petition and objects to the permit, ACHD must revise and resubmit the renewal permit in compliance with the Clean Air Act requirements and standards.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h3 dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;""><strong><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial; font-size: 14.6667px; font-weight: 700; white-space: pre-wrap;"">PennFuture&rsquo;s Air Quality Advocacy in Allegheny County</span></strong></h3>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">As part of its goal to protect and improve air quality in Allegheny County, PennFuture has worked over the years to curb harmful emissions from Clairton Coke Works by advocating for stronger regulations and permit terms and making it the target of PennFuture&rsquo;s Toxic Neighbor Campaign which advocated for the retirement of Clairton&rsquo;s oldest and dirtiest coke oven batteries, modernization of the facility, and greater transparency. Our Toxic Neighbor campaign resulted in the </span><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-delivers-Toxic-Neighbor-petition-to-US-Steel"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">collective voices of more than 5,300 people</span></a><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> demanding clean air, healthy communities, and a commitment to public safety by U.S. Steel.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">This request for EPA to object to this inadequate Title V Renewal Permit is another critical step in PennFuture&rsquo;s fight against harmful emissions from major polluters in Allegheny County.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-81767ddb-7fff-22e8-9cba-973fd52f21f0""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

"Environmental Disaster from East Palestine, OH Train Derailment",2/23/2023,"<p>The East Palestine, Ohio train derailment disaster is shocking in its scale and potential effects. Unfortunately, we may not know this disaster&#39;s long-term health and environmental impacts for months or even years.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The gradual release and burn of these chemicals increased the risk that they spread beyond the crash site. With butyl acrylate found in local surface water, testing the groundwater supply and subsoil is crucial. We encourage anyone concerned about pollution and the safety of their community to document their observations and request soil and well water testing from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).&nbsp;</p>

<p>The residents of East Palestine and neighboring communities deserve transparency around the EPA&#39;s plan for continued air quality monitoring and the data of air tests.</p>

<p>Regardless of location and as a regular practice, residents should report any unusual odor or changes in environmental conditions to the appropriate state environmental agency. We encourage residents to do their best to document the changes they&#39;ve observed so environmental threats can be tracked and mitigated.</p>

<p>PennFuture continues to closely track developments and information coming from both locals and government agencies.</p>

<h3 style=""color:#aaa;font-style:italic;""><strong>What We Know of the Accident</strong></h3>

<p>On Friday, February 3, at 8:54 p.m. ET, a Norfolk Southern freight train heading to Conway, Pennsylvania, derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, approximately 1.2 miles from the Pennsylvania state line. Thirty-eight rail cars went off the tracks and caught fire.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://www.ntsb.gov/news/press-releases/Pages/NR20230214.aspx"">According to the National Transportation and Safety Board (NTSB)</a>, the investigating agency, a resident&#39;s home surveillance video showed what appears to be a wheel bearing in the final stage of overheating failure moments before the derailment.</p>

<p>The fear of a possible explosion forced the evacuation of 1,500 to 2,000 residents in a town of only 4,900.&nbsp;</p>

<h3 style=""color:#aaa;font-style:italic;""><strong>An Explanation of the Environmental Disaster</strong></h3>

<p><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Images/Smoke_from_the_fire_on_the_night_of_the_accident_%28v0wn4mB%29.jpg"" style=""width: 400px; height: 301px;"" /></p>

<p>The train towed 20 cars with hazardous material&mdash;11 of which derailed. Five overturned cars contained vinyl chloride, a chemical used to make PVC plastic and vinyl products. According to the National Cancer Institute, it is a flammable gas and cancer-causing.</p>

<p>Norfolk Southern said some cars carrying vinyl chloride were at risk of exploding. Ohio Governor Mike DeWine authorized a controlled burn of the chemicals on Monday, February 6. This burn resulted in a massive smoke plume.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Vinyl Chloride</strong></p>

<p>When burned, vinyl chloride breaks down into two chemicals: hydrogen chloride and phosgene. Phosgene is highly poisonous&mdash;used in chemical warfare during World War I and responsible for many deaths, <a href=""https://emergency.cdc.gov/agent/phosgene/basics/facts.asp"">according to the CDC</a>. While long-term exposure to higher concentrations of the gas can be deadly, the gas released by Norfolk did not result in reports of injuries or fatalities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Hydrogen chloride can cause eye, skin, and respiratory irritation and pain.</p>

<p><strong>Other Chemicals Onboard</strong></p>

<p>In addition to vinyl chloride, the EPA listed the following chemicals as also on the train:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Butyl acrylate &mdash; a liquid used for making paint, adhesives, and sealants</li>
	<li>Ethylhexyl acrylate &mdash; a liquid used for making paint, printing inks, and plastics, is toxic to the lungs and nervous system</li>
	<li>Ethylene glycol monobutyl ether &mdash; an industrial solvent that can be absorbed through the skin and is toxic to the liver and kidneys</li>
	<li>Isobutylene &mdash; &#8203;&#8203;a gas used in antioxidants, packaging, plastics, and high-octane plane fuel</li>
</ul>

<p>It&#39;s currently known that the derailment caused the release of butyl acrylate and ethylhexyl acrylate, which leaked into the ground, nearby streams, and storm drains.</p>

<p>Another major cause for alarm is the areas of contaminated soil and free liquids that, according to the EPA, <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/system/files/documents/2023-02/Norfolk%20Southern%20East%20Palestine%20Train%20Derailment%20General%20Notice%20Letter%202.10.2023%20%281%29.pdf"">&quot;were observed and potentially covered and/or filled during reconstruction of the rail line including portions of the trench /burn pit that was used for the open burn off of vinyl chloride.&quot;</a></p>

<p>Having multiple chemicals released adds to the complexity of the situation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>On Tuesday, February 21, EPA&nbsp;Administrator Michael Regan ordered Norfolk Southern Railway to pay for the contaminated soil and water cleanup and reimburse the EPA for the private cleanup of residential homes and businesses. This order enables the EPA to force Norfolk Southern to adhere to a plan set and managed by the EPA.&nbsp;</p>

<h3 style=""color:#aaa;font-style:italic;""><strong>Health Impacts</strong></h3>

<p>The EPA monitored the air quality and tested East Palestine&#39;s municipal drinking water well. Private well water testing is ongoing and residents with wells are told to still use bottled water. The EPA did not yet release the data from air monitor testing.</p>

<p><strong>Drinking Water</strong></p>

<p>Ohio Gov. DeWine said on Wednesday, February 16, that the water in East Palestine&#39;s municipal system is <a href=""https://www.axios.com/2023/02/15/ohio-train-derailment-water-safe"">safe to drink</a> based on the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency&#39;s results, however:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>The Ohio EPA recommends people using private wells for drinking water schedule an appointment for well water testing.</li>
	<li>The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) will conduct independent water sampling to monitor water contamination risks related to the train derailment closely.&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Air Monitoring</strong></p>

<p>Air quality monitors are a tool to measure exposure to air contaminants, but the technology has limitations. While the EPA has come out to say the air quality in and around East Palestine is safe for residents to return home, officials have not provided any data from the air tests.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Depending on which types of air monitors the EPA is utilizing, they may not be providing the exact chemical breakdown and measurements in the air.&nbsp;</p>

<p>How a healthy first responder reacts to a particular air quality measurement differs from an older adult or a child.</p>

<p>The EPA needs to be transparent with community members on the technology used to test air quality, the limitations of the equipment, the chemical specificity found, and the measurements.&nbsp;</p>

<h3 style=""color:#aaa;font-style:italic;""><strong>Environmental Impacts</strong></h3>

<p>The Norfolk Southern train carried 20 cars with hazardous materials. After the spill, chemicals&mdash;including an entire load of butyl acrylates&mdash;were seen running into storm drains and water sources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As of Tuesday, February 21&mdash;two weeks after the train derailment&mdash;Norfolk Southern reported the chemical spill contaminated at least 15,000 pounds of soil and 1.1 million gallons of water.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Locals documented images of dead fish and an oily sheen along Ohio River tributaries days after the spill. Those streams are reintroduction sites for the hellbender salamander.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Water pollution puts endangered amphibian species at risk. An official with the<a href=""https://www.wkbn.com/news/local-news/east-palestine-train-derailment/officials-speak-on-dead-fish-following-train-derailment/""> Ohio Department of Natural Resources told WKBN</a> that it would take time to know the effects on the hellbender.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The federal government&#39;s Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry opened an investigation tracking the chemical exposure.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Water Contamination</strong></p>

<p>According to the <a href=""https://epa.ohio.gov/monitor-pollution/pollution-issues/east-palestine"">Ohio EPA</a>, the Sulphur Run stream was the body of water most impacted by the derailment because of an &quot;impoundment&quot; on February 8 when officials rerouted the water with the damming and pumps.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Environmental teams dammed a portion of Sulphur Run and rerouted it to protect water downstream. Teams will treat contaminated water with booms, aeration, and carbon filtration units.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>What Are Dioxins?</strong></p>

<p>Dioxins are highly toxic, persistent organic pollutants that take a long time to break down once in the environment. They are a contaminant formed during the production of some chlorinated organic compounds, released through waste incineration or burning fuels. Dioxins can travel long distances in the air or water; when they settle into the soil, it will take several years to break down.</p>

<p>Once in the environment, they can accumulate in the food chain&mdash;primarily in animal fat, fish, and shellfish.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Dioxins can cause cancer, disrupt hormones, lead to reproductive and developmental problems, and damage the immune system. <a href=""https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6221983/"" target=""_blank"">In July 1976, a chemical plant explosion near Seveso, Italy exposed locals to the highest known levels of dioxin.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>Ohio&#39;s senators Sherrod Brown (D) and J.D. Vance (R) sent a <a href=""https://www.brown.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/letter_to_epa_about_dioxins_and_east_palestine_final.pdf"">joint letter </a>requesting the state and federal EPAs to test the air for dioxins.</p>

<p><a href=""https://response.epa.gov/site/site_profile.aspx?site_id=15933"">Follow EPA&nbsp;updates on the environmental impact of the Norfolk Southern train derailment disaster&nbsp;</a></p>

<h3 style=""color:#aaa;font-style:italic;""><strong>What Pennsylvania Leaders Say</strong></h3>

<p><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Images/image_32148362561677013983515_1677013983780.jpg"" style=""width: 400px; height: 267px;"" /></p>

<p>On Tuesday, February 21, Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro said his office made a criminal referral against Norfolk Southern to the acting Pennsylvania attorney general for review. At a press conference with Ohio Governor Mike DeWine, Shapiro said:&nbsp;</p>

<p>&quot;The combination of Norfolk Southern&#39;s corporate greed, incompetence, and lack of care for our residents is absolutely unacceptable.&quot;</p>

<p>Shapiro previously said publicly and in a letter to Norfolk Southern&#39;s CEO:&nbsp;</p>

<p>&quot;You can be assured that Pennsylvania will hold Norfolk Southern accountable for any and all impacts to our Commonwealth.&quot;&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/2023.2.14-Norfolk-Southern-Letter.pdf"">Shapiro listed three critical things Norfolk Southern did wrong after the derailment</a>:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Norfolk Southern made its own plan and did not implement a unified command which confused first responders and emergency management. As a result, state and local agencies had to react versus work in tandem.</li>
	<li>Norfolk Southern gave inaccurate information and conflicting modeling about the impact of the controlled release of chemicals.</li>
	<li>Norfolk Southern was unwilling to explore an alternative to burning chemicals and released and burned the chemicals without warning government agencies.&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>Pennsylvania&#39;s senators Bob Casey (D) and John Fetterman (D) <a href=""https://www.casey.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/letter_to_epa_about_ns_derailment.pdf"">sent a joint letter with the Ohio senators</a> requesting the EPA continue its monitoring of the land, air, and water in East Palestine, Darlington Township in Beaver County, and other impacted communities &quot;until the long-term effects of the exposure are fully understood.&quot;</p>

<h3 style=""color:#aaa;font-style:italic;""><strong>Questions and Actions Post-Emergency Operations</strong></h3>

<p>PennFuture believes environmental disasters are long-term public health disasters.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We should ask the following questions of Norfolk Southern Railway Company and Pennsylvania and Ohio leaders:</p>

<ol>
	<li>What is the current plan for continued community engagement? How frequently will residents in East Palestine and the surrounding areas receive updates? Are there opportunities to comment on cleanup plans?</li>
	<li>How is ambient air being monitored? What are those measurements?</li>
	<li>Where are air samples being collected?</li>
	<li>How frequently is the air quality being tested?&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Do experts know how far the toxic plume traveled?&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Which bodies of water are scientists sampling, and for which chemical constituents?</li>
	<li>Are officials advising children and dogs not to play in streams?</li>
	<li>Were surface wipes used on residents&#39; homes and vehicles? If so, what were the results?</li>
	<li>Where are soil samples being collected, and how deep are those samples?</li>
	<li>What is the plan for dioxin testing?&nbsp;</li>
	<li>What is the plan to notify the community of dioxin contamination?</li>
	<li>Was the controlled release and burn the best way to control the chemicals?</li>
	<li>What are the reasoning and safety around transporting various chemicals near one another?&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Was the train adequately inspected? Are there plans to improve the inspections in the future?</li>
	<li>How can the community engage with testing and ongoing monitoring?</li>
	<li>Are we investing enough in environmental agencies&#39; personnel and equipment to ensure the fastest and best response to the next disaster?</li>
</ol>

<h3 style=""color:#aaa;font-style:italic;""><strong>Notable Environmental Organizations to Follow</strong></h3>

<p><a href=""https://theoec.org/ohiotrainderailment/"">Ohio Environmental Council</a></p>

<p><a href=""https://cleanaircouncil.salsalabs.org/eastpalestine"" target=""_blank"">Clean Air Council</a></p>

<p>The longer people go without answers and action, anxiety and fear grow in the community. We need to limit pollution&#39;s impact on the ecosystem and mental health. East Palestine and Beaver County residents deserve transparency in testing and cleanup and a clear plan for long-term environmental monitoring.&nbsp;</p>

Misguided Homeowner Association Restrictions Block Pennsylvania’s Solar Potential,2/5/2023,"<p><strong>By Caroline Weiss, Legal Intern</strong></p>

<p>Lately, homeowners are coming across unlikely opponents to their solar ambitions. In states without solar access legislation, new restrictions are being implemented by homeowners associations.&nbsp;</p>

<p>For &ldquo;aesthetic&rdquo; reasons, HOAs all too often prohibit installation of solar panels on homeowners&rsquo; rooftops. Even when they lack solar bylaws, HOAs can be reluctant to have conversations with their members about the possibility of solar in their neighborhood.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Restrictions can sometimes be quite unfair or illogical: solar panels may only be allowed on the side of the roof that is not visible from the street&mdash; thus often disregarding the fact that solar panels are more effective on south-facing roofs. Preventing homeowners from installing solar on their own properties also limits potential benefits such as higher property values, lower electricity costs, and non-polluting renewable energy. In fact, homes with installed solar can, on average, sell for 4 percent more than properties without solar systems, according to&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.zillow.com/research/solar-panels-house-sell-more-23798/"">Zillow</a>. These reasons are why many are calling for changes to solar-restricting practices.</p>

<p>Ohio recently addressed these concerns with legislation that grants extra protections for individuals who install solar panels on their own property. Ohio&rsquo;s&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.legislature.ohio.gov/legislation/134/sb61"">Senate Bill 61</a>, passed June 14, 2022 and in effect since September 13, 2022, specifically applies to homeowners in condominiums and planned communities, who are subject to HOA regulations. Under this&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.dickinson-wright.com/news-alerts/-ohio-legislature-adopts-new-protections-for-solar-access"">bipartisan bill</a>, homeowners are permitted to install solar panels unless explicitly prohibited by the HOA declaration, as long as one of the<a href=""https://search-prod.lis.state.oh.us/solarapi/v1/general_assembly_134/bills/sb61/EN/05/sb61_05_EN?format=pdf"">&nbsp;following conditions&nbsp;</a>apply:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>The condominium unit includes the roof (as defined in the declaration), thus the owner is responsible for costs related to the roof, or&nbsp;</li>
	<li>The declaration expressly permits solar panels and &ldquo;establishes responsibility for the cost to insure, maintain, repair, and replace such devices.&rdquo;&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>HOAs can still retain the ability to establish &ldquo;reasonable restrictions&rdquo; on solar panel size and placement, which may differ for each community. While this law clearly does not grant full rights to homeowners to install solar as desired without restrictions, SB 61 is&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.natlawreview.com/article/ohio-sb-61-adds-protections-solar-panels-condominium-and-planned-community-homes"">a&nbsp;positive change</a>&nbsp;from prior Ohio law, which allowed HOAs to prohibit solar entirely.</p>

<p>Ohio State Senator Nickie Antonio&nbsp;<a href=""https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__solarunitedneighbors-2Dorg.zoom.us_rec_share_yf-2DAUSILu4EmeDDd5lJfWsN9sj0CICLX6qbxzX7wLzTADRHyoclFNEEVpP5qyPck.LDX3PC6c9qQjYBqM-3FstartTime-3D1674486151000&amp;d=DwMFAw&amp;c=euGZstcaTDllvimEN8b7jXrwqOf-v5A_CdpgnVfiiMM&amp;r=FWlGgRActI0u6Isyl7Nzu50dSmcEuzpnuGVzmbjyYL8&amp;m=_7uswVlUwfgRz-9zt_BLnYhjoKptxIFy8u5_pir7Dhs&amp;s=QV2NHQ85b3S0wsQ5zbGNplUBtE6pIBW9IkEDettPBbQ&amp;e="">spoke last month</a>&nbsp;about her reasons for supporting SB 61. Sen. Antonio had seen firsthand the benefits of solar in her own neighborhood and had heard stories from frustrated homeowners who were subjected to solar restrictions. Leader Antonio said that the bill&rsquo;s success in Ohio was derived from luck, timing, and relationships, as well as the time in which it was considered: over the course of two general assemblies, there was ample time to educate members to garner support.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This type of education is especially important as we see more and more anti-solar sentiment being promoted, sometimes perpetuated by the oil and gas industry.&nbsp;For example,&nbsp;<a href=""http://www.paenvironmentdigest.com/newsletter/default.asp?NewsletterArticleID=52705&amp;SubjectID="">misconceptions of solar</a>&nbsp;have been expressed by Pennsylvania leadership, resulting in stalled pro-solar legislation and the introduction of anti-solar bills&mdash;such as Senate Bills&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billinfo/billinfo.cfm?syear=2021&amp;sind=0&amp;body=S&amp;type=B&amp;bn=275"">275</a>,&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billInfo/billinfo.cfm?syear=2021&amp;sind=0&amp;body=S&amp;type=B&amp;bn=284"">284</a>, and&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billinfo/billinfo.cfm?syear=2021&amp;sind=0&amp;body=S&amp;type=B&amp;bn=792"">792</a>. Each piece of legislation is a clear attempt to manufacture concerns to raise fear, uncertainty, and doubt about solar. In Pennsylvania, local cities, townships and boroughs have the ability to regulate solar through&nbsp;<a href=""https://kleinmanenergy.upenn.edu/research/publications/regulating-utility-scale-solar-projects-on-agricultural-land/"">municipal zoning ordinances</a>.&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.farmanddairy.com/news/majority-of-local-zoning-codes-in-pa-lack-guidance-on-solar/666604.html"">A Penn State Dickinson Law review</a>&nbsp;of 2,500 local ordinances revealed, however, that only 13 percent of municipalities addressed solar of any kind in these codes. Some municipal ordinances make it harder for solar to be sited than, say, a gas-fired power plant.</p>

<p>Lack of solar access is a problem in Pennsylvania as well. Tony Ranieri, founder and president of Ohio solar installation company&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.solarisfreedom.com/"">Solar is Freedom</a>, also spoke to the benefits of solar for the energy economy in his state. Ranieri said that his business and that of other solar installers increases substantially with solar access legislation. As more homeowners are granted the opportunity to go solar, their choice to do so reduces grid pressure and overall cost per kilowatt-hour of energy.</p>

<p>Ohio&#39;s neighboring success highlights Pennsylvania&rsquo;s lack of solar access legislation.&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us//cfdocs/Legis/CSM/showMemoPublic.cfm?chamber=S&amp;SPick=20210&amp;cosponId=35408"">Senate Bill 826</a>, introduced by Senator Katie Muth in July 2021, would ensure that HOAs permit solar panel installations. This bill is still awaiting a vote, unfortunately. With every session that our legislators fail to take action to protect homeowners&rsquo; property rights, our state falls even further behind on advancing home rooftop solar&rsquo;s potential. HOAs&rsquo; solar restrictions should be curtailed all across the Commonwealth. Doing so would advance equity in property rights and allow homeowners the ability to enjoy greater environmental and economic benefits.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy,
Introducing PennFuture’s New Legal & Policy Interns!,1/30/2023,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-645d8449-7fff-fb39-19c3-30766dccae8c""></span></p>

<p>Since its inception in 1998, PennFuture has emphasized the importance of using the law to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment and &ldquo;create a just future where nature, communities, and the economy thrive.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Over the past two decades, we have achieved significant legal and policy victories that reduce pollution and protect the environment and our communities. We have provided millions of dollars in pro bono legal services while setting critical precedents and enforcing environmental laws across the Commonwealth.</p>

<p>But as PennFuture looks forward to the next 20 years, we recognize that we need to be more involved with cultivating the people that will continue to support our mission. Our staff have a long history of mentoring interns, externs, and fellows, and we wanted to create a more formal program to inspire the next generation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>With the generous support of the George and Miriam Martin Foundation and the Otto Haas Charitable Trust, PennFuture created a paid legal and policy internship program to inspire and mentor students interested in making a difference for our environment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Ultimately, the goal of this program is to provide the organization a cadre of young legal and policy minds interested in taking on the myriad challenges impacting Pennsylvania as well as to further their potential environmental careers. We also hope that providing for a funded internship will help to bring more diversity and inclusivity into the non-profit environmental advocacy sphere.</p>

<p>This spring, we have two fantastic students for our internship, representing a range of backgrounds and experiences. We&rsquo;ve asked our new interns to explain, in their own words, what environmental law and PennFuture&rsquo;s mission means to them:</p>

<p><strong>Lisa Dang, Third Year Student at Penn State Dickinson Law</strong></p>

<p>I have always had a penchant for environmental issues. During my undergraduate studies at William and Mary, I participated in a semester-long study abroad program in Cambodia and Vietnam, exploring environmental and climate change impacts on local communities located along the Mekong River. Immediately after undergrad, I worked at Environment Virginia, coordinating and implementing grassroots activities to advocate for environmental justice and renewable energy. Additionally, I interned at the Pennsylvania Utility Law Project (PULP), serving at-risk communities affected by utility and energy-related matters.</p>

<p>As a 3L at Penn State Dickinson Law, I have continued to pursue environmental policy and law classes, further driving my passion and commitment to help foster a more sustainable future. I spent significant time researching the feasibility of deploying solar technology in K-12 public school systems in Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>I am thrilled to be a part of the PennFuture team, working with passionate, diverse environmental law attorneys to tackle a wide range of environmental issues. I relish the opportunity to learn and help protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s right to clean air, water, and environment.</p>

<p>Beyond work and school, I enjoy playing competitive ultimate frisbee. Currently, I play for DC Shadow and Scandal based in Washington, DC.</p>

<p><strong>Caroline Weiss, graduate student at the University of Iceland in Environment and Natural Resources, with a specialization in environmental policy</strong></p>

<p>I am currently pursuing my Master&rsquo;s in Environment and Natural Resources at the University of Iceland, where I am specializing in environmental policy and management. Beginning my undergraduate study at the University of Pittsburgh, I had never envisioned myself double majoring in Environmental Studies and Political Science. Yet my introductory Environmental Science course, sustainability-focused extracurriculars, and childhood influence converged as I recognized my passion for environmental issues. I had grown up hiking most weekends, learning the importance of recycling and conserving at home, and volunteering at Heritage Creek Farm Camp, which ignited my appreciation for the natural world.</p>

<p>&nbsp;Throughout my studies, I have been drawn to the social sciences and policy as tools to drive environmental change. From my participation in Pitt&rsquo;s environmental honors fraternity, internships at the Sierra Club and Pittsburgh Parks Conservancy, and study abroad experience in Iceland, I gained an even deeper understanding of the value of policy and education to advance environmental solutions. I am eager to learn from PennFuture&rsquo;s talented team of environmental advocates this spring, especially regarding renewable energy policy issues in our state.</p>

<hr />
<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s legal and policy team is dedicated to restoring and protecting our environment and communities, to protecting our right to clean air and pure water, and to moving Pennsylvania toward a clean energy future. I thank our amazing staff and interns for their great work, and also our members for your continued support. We can&rsquo;t do this without you!&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">Please consider joining PennFuture today</a> to support all of the great work we do to protect our environment and hold polluters and our government accountable.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
What We Learned from the December 2022 Deep Freeze: Don’t Rely on Natural Gas When It’s Fracking Cold (Part 2),1/27/2023,"<p><b><i>In our previous article, we explained how Pennsylvania&rsquo;s energy grid became perilously close to a brownout event during last month&rsquo;s winter storm. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-What-We-Learned-from-the-December-2022-Deep-Freeze-Dont-Rely-on-Natural-Gas-When-Its-Fracking-Cold-Part-1"">Read part one for a day-by-day breakdown of the chain of events.</a></i></b></p>

<p>In December, fracked gas and coal plants across the Pennsylvania energy grid failed at rates of significantly higher than the grid operator had anticipated.</p>

<p>While PJM collects more detailed information on the cause of the 2022 holiday weekend outages, their preliminary data aggregates the causes into a few categories. Most of the outages are reported to have been caused by failed plant equipment, low fuel supply, or start failure and unit trips. Outages in the last category are often a consequence of equipment or fuel issues.</p>

<p>Fuel supply for gas plants is an <a href=""http://www.nerc.com/pa/RAPA/ra/Reliability%20Assessments%20DL/NERC_SPOD_11142017_Final.pdf"">on-going concern</a>. An operator must not only purchase sufficient fuel, but they must also have sufficient pipeline capacity for that fuel to be delivered when and where it is needed.</p>

<p>Gas generators can arrange for sales and delivery with either &ldquo;firm&rdquo; contracts (where the customer is a high priority) or cheaper &ldquo;interruptible&rdquo; contracts, where an order can be canceled if someone else is willing to pay more. Preliminary data shows that more than 17 percent of the gas in Pennsylvania <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/electricity/data/eia923/"">was acquired</a> through interruptible contracts, meaning many gas power plants would lose their supply when other consumers needed it most.</p>

<p>Even firm contracts don&rsquo;t insure delivery. Unexpected conditions&mdash;like severe winter storms&mdash;can result in local gas utilities and gas-fired generation competing for the same supply and pipeline capacity. In those situations, the local utilities normally take priority. That&rsquo;s because, if they lose gas, millions of households will have no other option for heat, not to mention the danger of re-lighting massive numbers of pilot lights. As a result, gas-fired power plants with firm contracts can have the tap turned off. It looks like this may have happened as well.</p>

<p><i>Fracked Gas is Rightfully Nervous and is Looking to Cast Blame Elsewhere<o:p></o:p></i></p>

<p>High on the list of industry talking points is the tired claim that environmental protections get in the way of their operations, and, with less oversight and fewer regulations, they could do better&mdash;we just need to trust them. Unfortunately for them, there is no evidence this is true.</p>

<p>Preliminary reports show that only a very small percentage of facilities reached their emissions limits and had to shut down That isn&rsquo;t surprising since section 202(c) of the Federal Power Act already addresses this problem&mdash;the Department of Energy allows generators to temporarily exceed their emissions limits or operate contrary to any environmental law or regulation when needed to respond to an emergency. In fact, 202(c) was invoked on the evening of December 24, and PJM reports that several plants were able to operate for a few additional hours because of that order.</p>

<p>Blaming PJM itself appears to be another popular approach. The fracked gas industry is arguing that the problem was PJM making bad energy forecasts, or PJM notified plants too late to secure the fuel they need.</p>

<p>PJM admits that, while they historically overestimate demand on holiday weekends, this time they underestimated demand by 10 percent. But, to their credit, they also realized they lacked confidence in the forecast and went into the event with a reserve capacity almost ten times higher than they normally would want. That would have been sufficient but for the shockingly high forced outage rate.</p>

<p>The lack of timely notification makes even less sense. PJM reported that in 92 percent of cases, generators gave them one hour or less of notice of outages.<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span>If these facilities had fuel concerns, they should have reported that to PJM back on December 21 when PJM issued a cold weather alert, and certainly by the time a second alert was issued on December 23.</p>

<p>After years of claiming the mantle as a &ldquo;reliable&rdquo; source of energy, it shouldn&rsquo;t be a surprise that the gas industry is quick to point fingers. Rather than hold themselves accountable for failing Pennsylvanians, they&rsquo;re trying to bend reality so that they don&rsquo;t have to pay for their mistakes. But a cold, hard look at the situation proves that the (fracked gas) emperor has no clothes.</p>

<p><i>What does this mean for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Energy Future?</i><i style=""mso-bidi-font-style:normal""><o:p></o:p></i></p>

<p>Not only does someone need to pay to the energy industries failures during December 2022, but policymakers, grid operators, advocates, and industry need to take a critical look at Pennsylvania&rsquo;s energy grid with an eye to reform.</p>

<p>But first we must get past the industry hyperbole. The fracked gas industry is already claiming that the solution is more fracking and more pipelines to create even more oversupply. That simply doesn&rsquo;t make any sense. In addition to the obvious environmental and public health consequences of fracking, the economics just don&rsquo;t work. We would need to spend billions of dollars to over-build vast amounts of infrastructure to guard against shortages, likely causing an unsustainable glut in the market outside of these events. Consumers would ultimately pay far higher energy prices to over-frack the Commonwealth with little benefit.</p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">The real solution is not putting all our eggs in one energy source basket in the first place. If we diversify our generation&mdash;particularly away from resource-constrained fossil fuels and towards non-resource constrained clean, renewable energy&mdash;we will be less exposed to supply chain risks and mechanical failures. If we also invest in energy efficiency, we can mitigate peak demand so there is less need to over-supply the grid in times of crisis. And, if we expand our capacity for energy storage, we will have more flexibility&mdash;and more options&mdash;to manage the grid when we need it most.</p>

<p>Doing all these things requires thoughtful planning and policy, but they are the stalwarts of a modern-day energy system. What the December 2022 energy crisis is teaching us is that Pennsylvania needs to move away from an energy grid steeped in the philosophies of the last century and reflect the needs and technological innovations of today.</p>

<p><i>Conclusions and Next Steps</i><o:p></o:p></p>

<p>Each year, billions of dollars of ratepayer money goes to the fracked gas industry in the form of capacity payments in return for their guarantee that they will be available to power the grid when needed. More than 37 percent of our fracked gas plants couldn&rsquo;t run when needed them most. That raises serious concerns as to the reliability of the energy sources we&rsquo;re paying to underpin the grid. A broader rethink of this energy policy is needed immediately.</p>

<p>But most insidious is how unfair Pennsylvania&rsquo;s energy system has become. It&rsquo;s now dominated by a fracked gas industry propped up by taxpayer subsidies and lax regulations that struggled to keep our lights on. Their failure to live up to their commitments caused energy prices to skyrocket to historic levels. Over time, those costs of these bills&mdash;and even the penalties gas generators incurred&mdash;will be borne by small businesses, households, and other energy users.</p>

<p>In other words, we&rsquo;ve built a Pennsylvania energy grid where taxpayers are paying for the fracking, the pipelines, and the power plants up front through subsidies, but also paying for the cost of their grid, without mentioning the monumental health and environmental costs throughout the fracking process. It&rsquo;s high time that Pennsylvania rolls up its sleeves and re-thinks its energy policies that have created this unfair grid before the next storm causes real blackouts.<o:p></o:p></p>
",Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
What We Learned from the December 2022 Deep Freeze: Don’t Rely on Natural Gas When It’s Fracking Cold (Part 1),1/24/2023,"<p><em>This&nbsp;article is the first in a two-part series. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-What-We-Learned-from-the-December-2022-Deep-Freeze-Dont-Rely-on-Natural-Gas-When-Its-Fracking-Cold-Part-2"">Read Part 2: How Fracked Gas Failed Pennsylvania</a>.</em></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">As the 2022 holiday weekend approached, a developing winter storm promised to bring severe cold weather to Pennsylvania. It&rsquo;s in these moments that our infrastructure&mdash;particularly our energy grid&mdash;is needed most and is stress tested. Unfortunately, our grid staggered, nearly leaving our homes in the cold and dark.</p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">The 2022 winter storm is an event that should bring a critical eye to Pennsylvania&rsquo;s increasingly gas-reliant energy mix. Otherwise, we will continue the slide towards becoming an expensive energy state, consistently threatened with energy instability wile energy generators are unfairly enriched.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal""><o:p></o:p><strong><u>December 21</u></strong></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">With forecasts looking ominous, PJM Interconnection LLC (PJM)&mdash;the regional energy grid operator that manages Pennsylvania&mdash;issued a Cold Weather Alert.<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span>At that time, gas generators should have been alerting PJM if they foresaw problems buying gas on the spot market to support increased consumer demand.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">PJM&rsquo;s plan to ensure we have the power we need is to purchase &ldquo;capacity&rdquo; in addition to energy.<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span>The way the system works, generators who clear the capacity auction get paid to be available, whether they are called on to run and sell energy or not. For the 2022<span class=""MsoCommentReference""><span style=""font-size:8.0pt""><span style=""mso-special-character:comment"">&nbsp;</span></span></span>delivery year, those payments totaled about $4 billion. Generators who take this money face steep penalties if they are unable to deliver energy when called so, in theory, companies have an incentive to invest in preventative maintenance, winterization, and other measures to improve reliability and be ready when we need them the most&mdash;at least, that is the plan.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal""><u><b>December 23</b></u></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">PJM&rsquo;s models forecast a need for 127 gigawatts (GW), but there was a lot of uncertainty. Power plants are complicated and, even in normal times, they are unavailable when called upon about 5 percent of the time. This forced outage rate&mdash;in other words, the number of power plants not running when they were supposed to&mdash;gets higher in extreme weather, climbing to around 10 percent. In addition to worries about forced outages, there is uncertainty predicting the weather and, in this case, uncertainty how demand might change on a holiday weekend. Rather than the 3GW of reserve, back-up capacity that PJM normally considers adequate, the grid operator planned for 29 GW.<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">Temperatures plummeted, dropping 29 degrees over a 12-hour period&mdash;a steeper decline than the historic 2014 polar vortex.<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span>With those crashing temperatures, the demand for energy soared, peaking about 10 percent higher than the forecast of 139 GW. <span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp;</span>The 29 GW of reserve capacity should have been more than enough to cover the demand&mdash;if the planned capacity could deliver. Unfortunately, the forced outage rate started to rise.<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">Early in the morning on Friday, December 23, there were about 12 GW of forced outages. By late Friday night, that climbed to 34 GW. <o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal""><u><b>December 24</b></u></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">Forced outages peaked at 46 GW. Failures not only included the &ldquo;expected&rdquo; 10 percent of generators that PJM called to run; over 23 percent of PJM&rsquo;s total capacity was unavailable. Worse yet, PJM had little or no notice these plants couldn&rsquo;t run&mdash;in 92 percent of cases, they had less than one-hours&rsquo; notice and, in some cases, no notice at all.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">PJM resorted to a suite of emergency procedures. Most glaring to the average Pennsylvanian were the reports on the news that households were asked to &ldquo;voluntarily&rdquo; reduce electricity on Christmas Day. PJM was also calling up idling synchronized reserve generators, issuing voltage reduction warnings, and obtaining permission for plants to exceed their emissions limitations, if they had to. PJM even became a net importer of power for a period, relying on neighboring grids to fill in supply gaps. By and large, the lights stayed on, if just barely, but it came at a staggering cost.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">With demand outstripping supply, the costs to consumers soared. Wholesale prices for energy vary, but they are generally under $50 a megawatt-hour (MWh) and often under $30/MWh.<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span><span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp;</span>For comparison, average retail electric prices (which includes local utility charges) were about $100/MWh in PA in 2021.<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span>During this event, PJM saw wholesale prices for energy peak at $4,300/MWh&mdash;essentially as high as the system is designed to go.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p>What this means is that energy purchased by utility companies during the holiday weekend were paying up to 1,000 percent more for that energy than normal&mdash;a cost that will certainly be borne by consumers in some way.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal""><strong>What went wrong?</strong><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">PJM is expected to issue a full report in mid-April, but preliminary data shows that about 70 percent of the forced outages came from fracked gas plants not operating like they should have . Gas makes up about 50 percent of PJM&rsquo;s generation with over 86 GW installed. At the peak of the crisis on December 24, its forced outage rate was over 37 percent with over 32 GW offline.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">Coal was having problems, too, with a forced outage rate of about 16 percent (7.5GW).<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span>While the industry touts itself as &ldquo;fuel-secure&rdquo; because piles of coal often sit at the plant and they don&rsquo;t rely on pipelines, they still contend with frozen coal piles, supply-chain issues, and maintenance problems at decades-old plants that cause more than their share of outages.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">PJM&rsquo;s &ldquo;other&rdquo; category, which includes nuclear power and renewables, performed largely as expected with a forced outage rate of about 10 percent.<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span>In fact, when the data is in, we expect it to show that wind generation performed far better than what PJM had planned.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">Claims that fracked gas is a reliable energy source have been circulating for years and, even as recently as 2017, PJM itself <a href=""http://www.pjm.com/~/media/library/reports-notices/special-reports/20170330-pjms-evolving-resource-mix-and-system-reliability.ashx"" target=""_blank"">suggested</a> that as much as 86 percent gas-fired generation on our grid could maintain reliability.<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span>Hypotheticals aside, in December 2022 fracked gas wasn&rsquo;t reliable when we needed it, and consumers ended up paying steep costs&nbsp;for that failure.<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp; </span>The key question is why.</p>

<p class=""MsoNormal""><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-What-We-Learned-from-the-December-2022-Deep-Freeze-Dont-Rely-on-Natural-Gas-When-Its-Fracking-Cold-Part-2""><i>Read Part 2: How Fracked Gas Failed Pennsylvania.</i></a><i><o:p></o:p></i></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal""><o:p></o:p><o:p></o:p></p>

PennFuture and Partners Pave the Way for Erie Environmental Advisory Council,1/6/2023,"<p>After more than a year of advocacy by PennFuture and our partners, Erie City Council this week passed an ordinance creating an <a href=""https://weconservepa.org/eac/eac-basics/"" target=""_blank"">Environmental Advisory Council (EAC)</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The second municipality to develop an active EAC in Northwest Pennsylvania, Erie&rsquo;s EAC will build capacity and support community outreach efforts at a time of growing environmental ambitions.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>What is an EAC?</strong></p>

<p>EACs are extensions of municipal governments that focus on environmental conservation and improvement. They provide increased capacity for municipalities to protect their natural resources, communicate with the public, and meet their environmental goals.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania Act 148 of 1973 authorized municipalities to create EACs via ordinance and the model has proven successful. In fact, Erie is now home to the <a href=""https://weconservepa.org/groups/"" target=""_blank"">161<sup>st</sup> EAC in the Commonwealth</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>EACs do not make regulatory decisions nor are they independent environmental advisory organizations. They function most effectively when working cooperatively with elected officials, staff, and other authorities and boards.</p>

<p>EACs are comprised of seven voting members that must be municipal residents. Members must have expertise in environmental matters, and they serve three-year terms with staggered initial appointments.</p>

<p><strong>Why is an EAC important for the City of Erie?</strong></p>

<p>The City of Erie is working to reinvent itself by attracting 21st century businesses and bringing people, especially young people, to work, live, and play in the city. Many in the city are also working to address racial inequities and high poverty rates. Today&rsquo;s young adults seek sustainable and socially aware cities where they feel their voices can be heard.</p>

<p>Recent efforts by Mayor Joseph Schember to achieve this future include<a href=""https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/consultant-recommends-city-of-erie-hire-full-time-dei-coordinator-create-diversity-team/ar-AA14fiFw"" target=""_blank""> hiring a diversity, equity, inclusion, and justice consultant</a>; <a href=""https://www.yourerie.com/news/local-news/solar-panels-added-to-erie-central-fire-station/"" target=""_blank"">installing solar panels on the city&rsquo;s fire station</a>; and committing to the city&rsquo;s first <a href=""https://pennwatch.org/dep-and-local-officials-kick-off-2022-23-local-climate-action-program/"" target=""_blank"">climate </a>and <a href=""https://www.fundersnetwork.org/nine-communities-receive-partners-for-places-mini-grants/"" target=""_blank"">environmental justice</a> planning processes.</p>

<p>However, Erie will need more capacity and resources to meet its goals of becoming a more sustainable city. A well-functioning EAC that works with government is a low-cost way to expand the city&rsquo;s capacity to reach this goal. In addition to advising city departments on environmental matters, an EAC can expand outreach to Erie residents, especially when planning and decision-making will impact them. This increased public involvement will go far to bring residents to the table and to elevate their voices - two important aspects for addressing injustice.</p>

<p>Mayor Schember stated a desire to create a body to advise him on climate and environmental matters in his first term. Environmental groups supported this but recognized an opportunity to implement a model that could transcend any one administration. In alignment with <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/ErieCommonAgenda_6.pdf""><em>Our Water, Our Future: A Common Agenda for Protecting Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Lake Erie Watershed</em></a>, a codified EAC was recommended that would be much more difficult for a future administration to dismantle.</p>

<p><strong>What actions led to EAC ordinance passage?</strong></p>

<p>Mayor Schember and City Sustainability Coordinator Sarah Peelman welcomed the input of PennFuture and our partners, based on the Common Agenda. As a result, the following individuals embarked on a campaign to create a City of Erie EAC:</p>

<p><img alt="""" src=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Images/EAC-List-Test-2.PNG"" style=""width: 800px; height: 180px;"" /></p>

<p>The team researched best practices and met with several existing EACs before providing a proposal to the Mayor and City Council President. This proposal included a 12-step &ldquo;roadmap&rdquo; for Erie EAC creation. Recommended action included interagency and community outreach. The group then drafted an EAC ordinance based on examples from other cities and submitted this to the Mayor, City Council, and the City Solicitor for review.</p>

<p>PennFuture is thankful for the support of the mayor and City Council. Still, passing the EAC ordinance was not without its challenges.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The final ordinance included language that requires the EAC only research and focus on those initiatives dictated by the mayor and City Council. However, the first power EACs hold, as outlined in the state governing legislation, is to &ldquo;identify environmental problems and recommend plans and programs&hellip;&rdquo;.&nbsp;</p>

<p>If the EAC is unable to study additional issues, the council would be left vulnerable to individual interests of elected officials, rather than be accountable to needs of the community.&nbsp;</p>

<p>EACs that our partnership consulted maintain a cooperative working relationship with elected officials, but the council leaders are trusted as experts, left to conduct public outreach, identify issues, and make recommendations accordingly. Leaders can then choose whether to act upon those recommendations.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture and our partners chose to support the final ordinance language because we believe qualified EAC appointees will gain the trust of leaders. However, if political threats arise, we will defend the rightful duties of the EAC.</p>

<p><strong>What are the next steps for the Erie EAC?</strong></p>

<p>It is vitally important that the city receive diverse, passionate, and qualified applicants to serve on the EAC. Four appointments will be made by Council and three by the mayor.&nbsp;</p>

<p>If you are a qualified resident of the City of Erie, apply to serve! Encourage friends and colleagues to apply too! <a href=""mailto:tompkins@pennfuture.org"">Please reach out to Erie Campaign Manager Jenny Tompkins</a> if you would like additional information.</p>

<p>Passage of the EAC ordinance was made possible by months of collaborative educational and outreach efforts. It is the hope that this initial work of the advocacy team will provide a foundation for new EAC members to build from. The EAC framework, now implemented by 160 communities, has the potential to provide great benefit to the City of Erie and its residents. Erie&rsquo;s leaders must give it space to do so.</p>

<p><em>Photo courtesy Doug Kerr</em></p>
",Community; Environment,"Jenny Tompkins, Campaign Manager for Clean Water Advocacy"
Delaware River Basin Commission’s New Fracking Regulations Mark Incremental Progress,12/27/2022,"<p>This month, the Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC) finalized regulations banning the discharge of fracking wastewater within the basin. Additional&nbsp;regulations regard&nbsp;the import and export of water for fracking purposes outside of the Delaware watershed.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>DRBC seems to have at last heeded&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/2022-02-28-PennFuture-Comments-DRBC-Fracking-Wastewater-Ban.pdf"">calls from PennFuture</a>&nbsp;and others that&nbsp;final regulations needed to be tightened,&nbsp;closing&nbsp;loopholes that had allowed fracking wastewater and byproducts to potentially harm the basin.&nbsp;</p>

<p>DRBC&rsquo;s regulations clearly recognize that fracking wastewater is so toxic that it poses &ldquo;significant, immediate and long-term risks&rdquo; to water resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Here&rsquo;s a rundown on what this all means for the Delaware River Basin&rsquo;s environment and for the communities that rely upon its water supplies.</p>

<p><strong>Where does fracking stand in the Delaware River Basin?</strong></p>

<p>Fracking is banned! Following on the heels of a decade-long de facto moratorium on fracking and all fracking-related activities, the <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fracking-Banned-in-Delaware-River-Basin"">DRBC banned fracking in the Delaware River Basin in 2021</a>. This ban protects our water resources and our communities from the known dangers from the physical act of fracking!</p>

<p><strong>But what about fracking wastewater?&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>Well, that depends. The DRBC&rsquo;s final regulations prohibiting the &ldquo;discharge&rdquo; of fracking wastewater is great news. The final regulations add clarity to the&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-DRBC-Proposed-Regulations-Ban-Discharge-of-Fracking-Wastewater-Discourages-Fracking-Related-Interbasin-Water-Transfers"">October 2021 draft regulations </a>that ban fracking wastewater and byproducts such as:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Road spreading of fracking wastewater</li>
	<li>Injection of fracking wastewater into deep well for storage/disposal</li>
	<li>Disposal of fracking wastewater in landfills</li>
	<li>Discharge of leachate from landfills that accept fracking waste, including after treatment&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>Furthermore, the DRBC clarified that &ldquo;wastewater&rdquo; includes wastewater, brine, and sludge that contains fracking contaminates, even if that wastewater was treated. The Commission also made explicit that the discharge ban includes any type of discharge, whether on land or directly into the waters, and whether intentional or unintentional.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>What about risks from transporting fracking wastewater?</strong></p>

<p>The DRBC&rsquo;s final regulations still allow for the transport, storage, transfer, process, and reuse of fracking wastewater within the basin, which carry with them the possibility of spills and leakage that could irreparably damage the Delaware&rsquo;s water resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The DRBC anticipates &ldquo;only low volumes&rdquo; of fracking wastewater to be transported to or through the Basin, arguing that this reduces the &ldquo;number of probable spills.&rdquo; <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-New-Report-Details-the-Use-of-Forever-Chemicals-in-Fracking-Operations-Despite-Serious-Concerns-to-Public-Health"">Fracking wastewater is highly toxic</a>. DRBC&rsquo;s regulations, therefore, do not seem to be stringent enough to protect the heath of our communities or our environment. Despite our knowledge of how harmful this wastewater is, there are still many potentially toxic components which we still don&rsquo;t know about.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As a way to alleviate these concerns, the DRBC has argued that there is a &ldquo;high bar&rdquo; for approval of any importation of wastewater into the basin. To that end, PennFuture will be diligent in monitoring any applications to the DRBC regarding the importation of fracking wastewater into the basin to ensure that the Commission adheres to its duty to protect the Delaware from harm.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>What about the use of Delaware River Basin water for fracking outside of the basin?</strong></p>

<p>The DRBC refused to ban or limit the use of basin water for fracking activities elsewhere. Instead, the Commission argued that its current regulations of the expiration of water should be stringent enough to protect the watershed from over-extraction of water.&nbsp;</p>

<p>DRBC has argued that an application for water exportation by a fracking company is highly unlikely to meet the standards and requirements to merit a permit. The Commission&rsquo;s duty through this review is to ensure, by evaluating a series of factors, that there is &ldquo;no harm&rdquo; to the basin&rsquo;s water resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We are hopeful that the DRBC will adhere strictly to its duty and regulations and reject any water exportation request that does not meet these stringent standards&mdash;regardless of whether it&rsquo;s for fracking or any other activity outside the Basin.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In conclusion, these final fracking wastewater regulations are very much an improvement over the&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Public-Comment-Closes-on-DRBC-Fracking-Regulations"">regulations originally drafted in 2018</a>. PennFuture fully supports the clear prohibition of discharges of fracking wastewater within the Delaware River Basin, as well as DRBC&rsquo;s efforts to clarify and strengthen that prohibition following recent public comment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While we are unhappy that there still remain opportunities for fracking wastewater to be brought into the Basin&mdash;and with it the potential to irreparably harm our waters and communities&mdash;we are hopeful that the DRBC will do everything in its power to minimize those potential harms.</p>
