",Energy; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
PennFuture and Partners Convince EPA to Upgrade Delaware River Water Quality Standards,12/20/2022,"<p>Back in April, PennFuture and our partners filed a petition to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), requesting a new water quality standard for dissolved oxygen for the urban stretch of the Delaware River. On December 1, the EPA took the rare step and granted our petition!&nbsp;</p>

<p>While it might sound like a technical issue, this is a major development for our continued efforts to upgrade and protect the Delaware River estuary&mdash;the 38-mile stretch of the river from Trenton to the top of the Delaware Bay.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The petition raised critical questions surrounding what defines &ldquo;existing use&rdquo; of this stretch of the river and how data-driven evidence demonstrates that existing use.&nbsp; The problem here is that there is solid evidence that fish propagation is occurring in this section of the river. This evidence of an &ldquo;existing use&rdquo; formed the basis for our petition to EPA to upgrade the designated use to include propagation of fish.</p>

<p>As we explain below, PennFuture and our partners had petitioned the Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC) years ago to recognize the propagation of fish and set appropriate standards to protect it. However, DRBC, the intergovernmental agency responsible for water quality protections in the Delaware River watershed, has failed to act on our petition in a timely manner. And so the time had come for us to petition EPA to step in and take control to protect the river under their overarching authority under the federal Clean Water Act.</p>

<p><strong>The law.</strong>&nbsp;The federal Clean Water Act requires that regulators determine the &ldquo;existing use&rdquo; of a waterbody and establish a &ldquo;designated use&rdquo; that matches or goes beyond the existing use. At the moment, the designated use&mdash;with regard to aquatic life&mdash;is defined as &ldquo;maintenance of resident fish and other aquatic life&rdquo; and &ldquo;passage for migratory fish.&rdquo;&nbsp; The currently applicable standards, in these zones of the River, do not include protections to provide for the &ldquo;propagation of fish.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>The science.</strong> Based on the &ldquo;maintenance&rdquo; designated use, the DRBC set a dissolved oxygen standard of 3.5 mg/L. Dissolved oxygen is required to support aquatic life. Yet pollution from industry, insufficiently treated sewage from wastewater plants, and the pollution carried to the river from our streets during rain events can have dramatic impacts on the ecosystem. High levels of pollution adversely affect aquatic habitats, potentially causing harmful algal blooms, which deprive the river of oxygen and create dead zones for other life. And the more sensitive juvenile fish populations that are present in areas where propagation of fish occur need a higher level of dissolved oxygen than those areas where only maintenance of adult populations is needed. Upgrading the designated use of this section of the river should result in the creation of higher dissolved oxygen standards necessary to protect all live stages of fish.</p>

<p><strong>The evidence</strong>. Federally-protected Atlantic Sturgeon can be found in this stretch of the river&mdash;living and spawning, not just migrating through&mdash;and therefore need a higher dissolved oxygen standard in order to survive. The argument is simple. The fish are existing there, and this &ldquo;existing use&rdquo; by the sturgeon needs to be recognized by law.</p>

<p>This issue has been brewing for years. In 2013, Delaware Riverkeeper Network (DRN) and other organizations submitted an initial petition to the DRBC, urging it to recognize the emerging data that fish are now spawning in all zones of the Delaware Estuary. In 2021, DRN, PennFuture and others filed a supplemental petition with the DRBC, pointing to additional evidence of fish propagation and urging DRBC to move faster.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture and our partners remain frustrated with the DRBC&rsquo;s delay and inaction. PennFuture, DRN, and others filed a petition to the EPA in April, requesting:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>EPA issue a rule that revises the designated uses for these urban zones to include a) maintenance and propagation of resident fish and other aquatic life, and b) spawning and nursery habitat for anadromous fish</li>
	<li>EPA upgrade the dissolved oxygen standard from 3.5 mg/L to 6/3 mg/L</li>
</ul>

<p>On December 1, EPA granted the petition for rulemaking and set out a 12-month timeline for establishing new water quality standards for dissolved oxygen in this part of the Delaware. In making this determination, EPA found that &ldquo;&lsquo;propagation of fish&rsquo;&rdquo; is &ldquo;attainable&rdquo; and that the &ldquo;currently applicable dissolved oxygen criterion for these zones is not sufficient to protect propagation.&rdquo; EPA determined, in other words, that the dissolved oxygen standard needs to be higher.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Still to be determined is exactly what that higher standard will be. EPA expects to release draft regulations by 2024, which will be addressed in the years thereafter by the DRBC and the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP), as well as the environmental agencies of New Jersey and Delaware. The higher water quality standards will then be implemented by upgrading wastewater treatment plants along the estuary as well as by creating more stringent permits for polluters along the river. Fortunately, significant increases in state and federal infrastructure funding could, in part, be used for these wastewater treatment plant upgrades.</p>

<p>PennFuture is committed to ensure the Delaware River&rsquo;s new standards will protect the survival of the sturgeon as well as the health of other aquatic life in the basin.&nbsp; Millions of residents use the Delaware River for recreation, food, and work. Our goal is to make sure that they will be able to do so for years to come.</p>

<p><em>Photo courtesy James Loesch/Flickr</em></p>
",Environment,"Jessica O'Neill, Senior Attorney"
Distribution Centers Bring into Focus Limitations of Local Zoning Laws,11/2/2022,"<p>Northeast Pennsylvania&rsquo;s growing proliferation of large-scale distribution centers is threatening the high-quality waterways of the Pocono Mountains. This region is home to a high concentration of special protection streams &ndash; some of the healthiest waters in the state &ndash; and serves as the headwaters of the Delaware River. While High Quality and Exceptional Value waters do receive legal protection, irresponsible and poorly sited development projects can still cause degradation when local land use policies fail to uphold these protections.</p>

<p>The approval process for land use projects can be cumbersome and difficult to follow, but a recent decision made by local officials in Monroe County provides an excellent example of why paying close attention to zoning ordinances can be advantageous. On October 26, the Coolbaugh Township Zoning Hearing Board voted unanimously to deny a special exception for a 426,000-square-foot distribution center. The project was pitched as a &quot;warehouse&quot; and proposed for a 48-acre tract of land located in a commercial district. While warehouses are a permitted use in this district as a special exception, &ldquo;distribution centers&rdquo; are not, and the developer did not demonstrate that it adhered to the definition of a warehouse. The township had thoughtful zoning on the books. Applying these zoning ordinances ensured that the proposed use was appropriately sited.&nbsp;</p>

<p>First, some background on zoning practices. While municipalities in Pennsylvania must legally allow for every &quot;use&quot; within its borders, zoning districts determine where those uses are located. Districts include but are not limited to commercial, industrial, residential, and open space. Within those districts, municipal officials can list which uses are automatically allowed, which are not allowed, and which require a special exemption that will need to meet conditions placed on the project by officials.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Initial zoning ordinances did not anticipate the large-scale industrial nature of distribution centers, which are vastly different from what was considered a &quot;warehouse&quot; 10, 20, 50 years ago. This means that warehouses and distribution centers are likely no longer appropriate uses in commercial or village districts, as they were previously considered.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It is critical to note the distinction made in the zoning ordinance between warehouses and distribution centers. Essentially, a warehouse is designed for the indoor storage, transfer, and distribution of goods, but crucially, it does not include a truck terminal. Meanwhile, a distribution center receives, stores, and distributes goods. This definition includes the redistribution and consolidation of orders, as well as the storage, parking, and servicing of trucks. The distinction is clear. While the township did not decide that the proposed project was a distribution center, they did determine that the applicant failed to show that it was a warehouse.</p>

<p>In short, the Coolbaugh Township Zoning Hearing Board&rsquo;s decision last month utilized the tools it had under its zoning ordinance to ensure that this type of large-scale industrial development was appropriately sited in the township.</p>

<p>This is a critical victory for special protection streams in the Poconos. Had the Coolbaugh project moved forward, stormwater on the property would have naturally flowed into the Tobyhanna, a High Quality creek, increasing the likelihood of degradation. Thermal impacts and contamination from salt and chemicals carried by stormwater runoff can create a potentially toxic environment for wildlife. Additionally, the paved surface of parking lots also generally increases and speeds up the flow of runoff into streams, leading to more frequent and severe flooding events.</p>

<p>Unless municipalities take a watershed-wide approach to land use, industrial development risks causing &quot;death by a thousand cuts&quot; to local waterways. Long-lasting and devastating impacts are magnified when one distribution center turns into many. Just a single 300,000-square-foot distribution center can cause long-lasting negative impacts on the environment through stormwater pollution. But consider the massive impact of several of these projects in a condensed area.&nbsp;</p>

<p>For example, in Pocono and Jackson Township, there are upwards of four warehouses being proposed, totalling over 1.5 million square feet, all within a few miles of each other and some projects proposed on adjacent properties. Our streams will not be all that suffers from this onslaught as neighboring homes and businesses will have to contend with air pollution, noise pollution, light pollution, and traffic impacts. While one distribution center may make sense in a properly sited industrial zone, it is less sensible to develop several all within a commercial zone bordering homes or special protection streams. When municipalities review their zoning ordinances, the cumulative impacts of multiple large-scale projects must be considered because the harm caused to the environment and surrounding communities becomes exponential.&nbsp;</p>

<p>County-wide or multi-municipality planning and zoning could provide for just this type of holistic approach to warehouse and distribution center development. If the zoning issues in the Poconos are not addressed, this region known for clean water, clean air, open space, and outdoor recreation will be unrecognizable as it evolves into a busy industrial zone with poor air quality, degraded streams, and traffic congestion.</p>

<p>Coolbaugh Township was lucky to have &ndash; and apply &ndash; zoning that recognized these issues. Similarly, Pocono Township is attempting to be responsive to the threat by beginning the curative amendment process to fix problems with its zoning related to distribution centers and warehouses.&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://ourpoconowaters.wordpress.com/2022/05/11/pocono-residents-support-more-action-to-protect-exceptional-value-streams-new-poll-finds/"">More than 98 percent of Pocono residents </a>believe that more must be done to protect local waterways from large-scale commercial and industrial development.</p>

<p>As the saying goes, &quot;we all live downstream.&quot; It is not just the immediate community and ecosystem that will experience the consequences of development-fueled degradation. Neighboring communities and even those that live miles downstream will feel the impact. Our pristine Pocono streams protect the quality of drinking water for 13 million people that live downstream, and they also contribute to the health of the region&#39;s outdoor recreation economy. These outstanding waters must be considered when making consequential land use decisions.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The proliferation of distribution centers provides municipal officials reason to take a more holistic approach toward their&nbsp;zoning ordinances. They have widespread support among residents, who have been showing up to meetings in droves, demanding action. Our local leaders have the tools at their fingertips. Now is the time to act before it&#39;s too late.</p>

<p><em>Photo courtesy Nicholas_T/Flickr</em></p>
",Environment,"Donna Kohut, Policy Manager for Sustainable Economics"
Erie’s Stormwater Fee Program Becomes Reality,10/19/2022,"<p>Today&nbsp;Erie City Council passed a much-anticipated stormwater user fee. The fee creates a dedicated fund for long-overdue stormwater maintenance and, more importantly, for stormwater-management improvements that bring environmental, economic, and human health benefits.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Six major streams wind their way through the City of Erie. All are deemed &ldquo;impaired&rdquo; under the Clean Water Act due to excessive sediment pollution caused by runoff. The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection requires the city to reduce these sediments by 10 percent over five years by implementing a <a href=""https://cityof.erie.pa.us/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/Erie-PRP-2022-Final-Draft-updated-5-11-22-rev1.pdf"" target=""_blank"">Pollutant Reduction Plan (PRP).</a> A stormwater engineer was recently hired by the city, with plans to fund the position over the long term using revenue from the stormwater fee.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Stormwater funding aimed at capital improvements will promote public safety and ultimately save money. Over the past 70 years, Erie experienced <a href=""https://glisa.umich.edu/climate-change-in-the-great-lakes-region-references/"" target=""_blank"">a more than 10-percent increase in total annual precipitation</a> and a 35-percent increase in the amount of precipitation during heavy storms. Recently, the City experienced significant flooding after more than <a href=""https://www.goerie.com/story/news/local/2022/09/28/erie-pa-sets-rainfall-record-for-sept-27-reports-flooded-roads-creeks/69523245007/"" target=""_blank"">2.5 rapid inches of rainfall</a> fell on the region. Past massive storms led to the <a href=""https://www.cbsnews.com/pittsburgh/news/flooded-erie-home-2-dead/"" target=""_blank"">drowning of two people in 2017 </a>and emergency infrastructure failures, such as the East Fifth Street storm sewer failure in 2021, which <a href=""https://www.goerie.com/story/news/local/2021/09/01/garrison-run-east-erie-storm-sewer-failure-cost-least-1-2-m-infrastructure-stormwater/5654320001/"" target=""_blank"">cost the city over $1.2 million for repairs</a>. With over 500 miles of stormwater infrastructure, a significant portion of which is over a century old, the city needs this dedicated fee funding to protect all residents and businesses.</p>

<p>Creation of the fee program also directly aligns with recommendations in <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/ErieCommonAgenda_6.pdf""><em>Our Water, Our Future: A Common Agenda for Protecting Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Lake Erie Watershed</em></a>. In collaboration with other area environmental organizations, PennFuture determined pollution caused by surface runoff, including urban stormwater runoff, to be the largest direct threat to our regional water quality. Recommended strategies to mitigate this threat at the local level include creation of a multi-municipal stormwater authority and a county-wide stormwater fee. Though scaled down from the <em>Common Agenda</em>&rsquo;s proposal, we support Mayor Joseph Schember&rsquo;s decision to advocate for a fee.</p>

<p>Collaboration across state, county, and local entities was critical to advance the stormwater fee. In 2019, the City&rsquo;s consultants recommended adoption of a stormwater fee as one strategy to combat the city&rsquo;s financial vulnerability. The DEP&rsquo;s Office of the Great Lakes, Erie County Department of Planning and Community Development, City of Erie, and Millcreek Township then worked together to obtain funding for a 2021 feasibility study of stormwater fees for the county&rsquo;s two largest municipalities. An expert stormwater program consultancy, Wood Consulting, who notably assisted in the development of nearby Meadville&rsquo;s fee in 2012, was contracted to complete the study. Though Millcreek Township elected to not yet enact a fee after the conclusion of the feasibility study, the city opted to move forward with a fee ordinance.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The resulting proposed fee structure is built upon the same foundation outlined in PennFuture&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PennFuture_StormwaterManual_web_3.20.17.pdf"">Model Stormwater Management Fee Ordinance (2017)</a>. Both ordinances charge a stormwater user fee to all property owners, regardless of taxable status, based on their property&rsquo;s amount of impervious surface area. The fee structure relies on the concept of an &ldquo;equivalent residential unit&rdquo; representing the average impervious surface area of a residential tax parcel. Once the ERU is calculated, the desired revenue from the annual fee is divided by the estimated total count of ERUs across the City to determine the fee per ERU. For non-residential properties, ERUs are totaled and billed accordingly. In many other municipalities, residential property owners are all charged a fee of one ERU, regardless of how much impervious surface they have. However, the city sought to make costs more equitable for residential payers by creating three payment tiers based on housing footprints. As a result, residential payers will only pay between $12 and $36 per year. In a comparison of other fees across Pennsylvania, the <a href=""https://cityof.erie.pa.us/stormwater/"" target=""_blank"">City of Erie&rsquo;s low residential costs stand out.</a> The city has pledged to not raise fees for five years.</p>

<p><a href=""https://www.goerie.com/story/news/local/2021/12/01/no-erie-pa-stormwater-fee-now-city-council-rejects-proposal/8808404002/"" target=""_blank"">Council rejected a fee ordinance with a 4-3 vote in late 2021</a>, citing a lack of sufficient detail. Stormwater fee programs often allow utility payers to reduce their annual fee (i.e. obtain &ldquo;credits&rdquo;) by implementing best management practices to mitigate volume and/or rate of runoff from their properties. In response, Wood Consulting and the city administration have since crafted a fee credit policy with input from a 12-member Stormwater Credit Advisory Committee. The resulting credit policy, presented to Council ahead of a second attempt to enact a fee, allows for a generous 45 percent maximum credit for commercial and institutional fee payers. PennFuture and our partners support this new credit policy and are glad that it ultimately received the support of Council.</p>

<p>Erie now joins <a href=""https://digitalcommons.wku.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1000&amp;context=seas_faculty_pubs"" target=""_blank"">over three dozen Pennsylvania municipalities collecting stormwater fees,</a> including counterparts in Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, Allentown, Lancaster, Bethlehem, and nearby Meadville. As outlined in the Our Water, Our Future Campaign, stormwater fees provide capacity to tackle a primary source of pollution in our watershed: urban stormwater runoff. We applaud City Council for its decision to approve the stormwater fee ordinance, following through on the recommendations and efforts of so many stakeholders, including PennFuture and our partners.</p>

<p><em>Photo courtesy Paul Comstock</em></p>
",Environment,"Jenny Tompkins, Campaign Manager for Clean Water Advocacy"
The Clean Water Act’s 50-Year Impact on Pennsylvania,10/18/2022,"<p>As we<a href=""https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2022/10/17/a-proclamation-on-the-50th-anniversary-of-the-clean-water-act/"" target=""_blank""> celebrate 50 years</a> of the groundbreaking Clean Water Act, I&rsquo;d like to take this opportunity to reflect on what it means to PennFuture, Pennsylvanians, and our over 86,000 miles of streams.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania has a long history of polluted waterways, due in major part to our economy&rsquo;s historical reliance on extractive industries. In particular, coal mining&rsquo;s&nbsp;toxic legacy remains the leading cause for the on-going&nbsp;impairment of the Commonwealth&rsquo;s waters. More than <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/OurCommonWealth/Pages/Article.aspx?post=92"" target=""_blank"">5,550 miles of streams</a> are still impacted by acid mine drainage from abandoned coal mines.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Extractive industries continue to damage Pennsylvania&rsquo;s waterways. In particular, the fracking industry has <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/tag/dimock/"" target=""_blank"">recklessly polluted</a> streams and groundwater across the state &ndash; through the<a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/news/pennsylvania/pennsylvania-fracking-gas-drilling-tainted-water-dimock-criminal-case-20220218.html"" target=""_blank""> fracking process itself</a> or through construction of <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/mariner-east-builder-sunoco-agrees-to-4m-settlement-over-marsh-creek-lake-spill/"" target=""_blank"">pipeline infrastructure</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As far back as 1905, the Purity of Waters Act set limits on how much sewage could be added to the Commonwealth&rsquo;s waters. And yet, even from the beginning, some of the largest water polluters - namely coal mines and tanneries - were specifically exempted from this law. As water pollution continued to worsen, Pennsylvania enacted the Clean Streams Law in 1937 to strengthen discharge limits and to increase coverage and penalties. And yet still, coal mines were exempted from this law. Nor did the Clean Streams Law require restoration of degraded waterways. In fact, it wasn&rsquo;t until significant amendments in 1945 that the Clean Streams Law included discharges from coal mines and required the industry to develop and implement a plan for reducing these toxic discharges from fouling our waters.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Unfortunately, despite these rules, enforcement remained lackluster. The number of polluted streams continued to increase as industrial activity overtook our waters. This led the Clean Streams Law to be amended again in 1965, significantly strengthening the regulation of water pollution discharges &ndash; specifically for coal mines &ndash; while requiring that polluters restore degraded waters and attempt to prevent their degradation in the first place. And yet our waterways still suffered.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Eventually, the federal government recognized that states were ill equipped to prevent water pollution. Rather than rely on a patchwork quilt of water protection laws at the state level, on October 18, 1972, the Clean Water Act (officially the Water Pollution Control Act of 1972) was signed into law (over President Richard Nixon&rsquo;s veto).&nbsp;</p>

<p>This groundbreaking law set forth the goal to &ldquo;restore and maintain the chemical, physical, and biological integrity of the Nation&rsquo;s waters.&rdquo; Focused on discharges of pollution from point sources into waters of the United States, the Clean Water Act (CWA) aimed to prevent, reduce, and eliminate water pollution through the development of water quality standards and limitations set forth in permits. Critically, the CWA imposes the concept of &ldquo;antidegradation&rdquo; into the regulatory scheme, meaning that once a waterway reaches a level of water quality,<a href=""https://files.dep.state.pa.us/AboutDEP/Testimony/Pennsylvania%20Joint%20Letter%20on%20WOTUS.pdf"" target=""_blank""> that level cannot be degraded</a>. The federal backstop created by the CWA is especially important for states like Pennsylvania where some of our most ecologically sensitive and economically important streams and creeks are all too often polluted with no regard to the value &ndash; or &ldquo;use&rdquo; &ndash; of those waters.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Although the CWA was hopeful that we would meet these laudable goals by 1985, we are still struggling to protect and restore our waters today. That is not to say that the CWA has not been successful; it most certainly has. We no longer have <a href=""https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/cuyahoga-river-caught-fire-least-dozen-times-no-one-cared-until-1969-180972444/"" target=""_blank"">burning rivers </a>and many of our rivers have seen a resurgence in aquatic life once struggling on the brink of extinction. People no longer turn their backs to the rivers and creeks that once provided so much recreational and economic opportunities for our communities. The CWA has significantly reduced raw sewage from being directly dumped into our waters. We have more &ldquo;fishable and swimmable&rdquo; waters than we did 50 years ago!&nbsp;</p>

<p>But the problem is clearly bigger than anticipated, and with the CWA failing to regulate most non-point source discharges (e.g., stormwater runoff) and groundwater, there are regulatory holes that allow for water pollution and degradation to continue. (Good news: the Clean Streams Law covers groundwater!) With developers and industry continuing to challenge the applicability of the CWA (<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Reasons-to-Remain-Hopeful-as-Supreme-Court-Rules-on-Clean-Water-Acts-Future"">here&#39;s the latest example</a>), the constantly uphill battle can often seem overwhelming for environmentalists and conservationists.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Perhaps one of the most important components of the CWA is how the law allowed the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to set a Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) for the Chesapeake Bay in 2010. Imposition of a TMDL (think of it as a &ldquo;pollution diet&rdquo;) was necessary to prevent pollution and clean up the Bay after decades of sediment and nutrient pollution took it to the brink. These pollutants are primarily from wastewater and non-point source runoff, resulting in murky waters and harmful algae blooms that threaten aquatic vegetation and organisms, while lowering the dissolved oxygen levels that are critical for the survival of aquatic life.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In Pennsylvania, the Chesapeake Bay Watershed TMDL means that pollution inputs on the Susquehanna River &ndash; the main tributary to the Bay &ndash; must be significantly cut, improving water quality for Pennsylvanians as well as downstream communities. Recognizing this benefit to the water quality of one of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s largest river systems, PennFuture has worked to support efforts to reduce pollution to the Susquehanna River. When agricultural interests initially challenged the Bay TMDL in federal court, <a href=""https://www.courthousenews.com/epa-prevails-in-fight-over-chesapeake-bay/"" target=""_blank"">PennFuture successfully intervened to support EPA</a>. And yet, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/chesapeakebay"">Pennsylvania is failing to meet these TMDL goals</a>. And so we lobby in Harrisburg for <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Final-Chesapeake-report.pdf"">funding for pollution reduction programs</a> and press for robust water quality protections in permits and agency programs.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Today, PennFuture continues to wrestle with protecting and restoring the Commonwealth&rsquo;s waters, and we are grateful that the CWA is there along the way, supporting our efforts. CWA has allowed for Pennsylvania to enact stronger state laws that protect water quality, protecting those state laws from legislative rollbacks. Our attorneys rely on the CWA in defending our waters and enforcing against polluters. And when the jurisdiction of the CWA has been threatened over the years, <a href=""https://files.dep.state.pa.us/AboutDEP/Testimony/Pennsylvania%20Joint%20Letter%20on%20WOTUS.pdf"" target=""_blank"">Pennsylvania has stepped up</a> in calling for robust protections at the federal level.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania is lucky to have both tens of thousands of miles of streams and robust water protection laws. However, without enactment of the CWA 50 years ago, our history of allowing industries to pollute those waters could have undermined the overall health of the Commonwealth&rsquo;s waters. PennFuture celebrates the enactment of the Clean Water Act and will continue to fight to protect our waters under it.</p>
",Environment; Keep Philly Green & Water Clean,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Upholding the True Meaning of Pennsylvania’s Environmental Rights Amendment,10/12/2022,"<p>The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit recently handed down a decision upholding the ban on fracking in the Delaware River basin.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The decision is the latest in a series of legal disputes over the state&rsquo;s constitutional protections for the Delaware River &mdash; and all waterways throughout the Commonwealth.</p>

<p>Back in February 2021, after a lengthy de facto moratorium, the Delaware River Basin Commission officially issued regulations <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fracking-Banned-in-Delaware-River-Basin"">banning fracking </a>in the basin in February 2021. (Some parts of this regulation relating to wastewater and water transfers remain to be finalized.)&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Some members of our Pennsylvania legislature, acting as individual legislators and not on behalf of the whole legislature, brought a challenge in federal court, asserting that they were legally harmed by the fracking ban and asking the court to overturn it. PennFuture and a number of our partner organizations are particularly concerned about the legislators&rsquo; argument that they are trustees of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources under our Environmental Rights Amendment, and that they have a duty to increase the value of the trust by fracking. We strongly disagree and, earlier this year, filed a brief with the federal district court explaining that the ERA in no way supports the legislators&rsquo; arguments.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Fortunately the district court <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Federal-Court-Dismissed-Lawsuit-Challenging-DRBCs-Ban-on-Fracking"">agreed </a>and dismissed the legislators&rsquo; case for lack of standing, finding that the legislators did not have an actual legal injury upon which to make a claim.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The legislators appealed to the Third Circuit, and again PennFuture and our partners filed an amicus brief to set the record straight on the ERA. We explained that the individual legislators were not trustees under the ERA, and even if they were, trustees would not be under a duty to frack. Instead, we explained, the ERA requires that trustees conserve and maintain trust assets, including the water resources of the Delaware River basin.</p>

<p>The Third Circuit agreed, issuing an <a href=""https://www2.ca3.uscourts.gov/opinarch/212315p.pdf"" target=""_blank"">opinion </a>that affirmed the district court&rsquo;s dismissal of the legislators&rsquo; claims. First the Court found that the individual legislators lacked standing to assert institutional injuries belonging to the legislature as a whole. The Court wrote that the legislators&rsquo; claims are &ldquo;classic examples of institutional injuries because they sound in a general loss of legislative power.&rdquo; Moreover, the legislators, as individuals, were not authorized to represent the interests of those institutions in court. If the legislature or the Commonwealth as a whole were injured, the Attorney General would be the party for representing the Commonwealth, not individual legislators.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Court also addressed the argument that the legislators had standing to challenge the ban as trustees of the Commonwealth&rsquo;s natural resources under the ERA. The court found this &ldquo;legally creative&rdquo; but that it &ldquo;falls short.&rdquo; The Court, referring to our brief, agreed with us that the legislators&rsquo; view of the ERA would &ldquo;turn it upside down.&rdquo; The ERA trust is not a &ldquo;run-of-the-mill financial trust in which the trustees have a duty to maximize profits.&rdquo; Instead, the trust must &ldquo;conserve and maintain&rdquo; our public natural resources. The Court engaged in an analysis of trust responsibilities and concluded that &ldquo;the ban promotes the purposes of the trust and protects its corpus&rdquo; by preventing our public natural resources from being depleted.</p>

<p>The ERA is one of the most important tools that Pennsylvanians have to defend against exploitation of our natural resources and ensure that future generations will be able to breathe pure air and enjoy clean water. We will continue to fight - even against our own legislators when we need to - to defend the rights that the ERA guarantees to the people of the Commonwealth.</p>

<p><a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/donate/index.html"">Please consider becoming a member of PennFuture today</a> and help support our fight for cleaner water and against the fracking and petrochemical industry&rsquo;s destructive practices.</p>

<p><em>Photo courtesy Jim Lukach</em></p>
",Environment,"Jessica O'Neill, Senior Attorney"
Reasons to Remain Hopeful as Supreme Court Rules on Clean Water Act’s Future,10/4/2022,"<p>On the eve of the 50th anniversary of the federal Clean Water Act, the U.S. Supreme Court heard argument on the case of <i>Sackett v. EPA</i>, which has the very likely potential to severely curtail the types of waters that are automatically protected by the Act.</p>

<p>The Clean Water Act (CWA or the Act) &ldquo;restore[s] and maintain[s] the chemical, physical, and biological integrity of the Nations&rsquo; waters&rdquo; by asserting jurisdiction over &ldquo;waters of the United States&rdquo; (often referred to as WOTUS). At issue before the Supreme Court is what is included in the definition of WOTUS&mdash;which waters are &ldquo;jurisdictional&rdquo; and therefore protected by the CWA. In particular the Court was focused on when and whether wetlands are covered by the Act.</p>

<p>WOTUS could perhaps be the most hotly contested CWA issue over the past 50 years. This issue has been a battle before the Supreme Court <a href=""https://eelp.law.harvard.edu/2022/06/sackett-v-epa-and-the-definition-of-waters-of-the-united-states/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; color: rgb(5, 99, 193); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">three times</span></a><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> already and each of the past three presidential administrations have come out with </span><a href=""https://eelp.law.harvard.edu/2017/09/defining-waters-of-the-united-states-clean-water-rule/"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; color: rgb(5, 99, 193); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">multiple rules</span></a><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> defining WOTUS. Yet we still don&rsquo;t have a clear rule.</span></p>

<p>This is mostly because there was a 4-1-4 split at the Supreme Court in the 2006 case of <span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Rapanos v. EPA</span><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">. This means that there were two competing tests for jurisdiction: Justice Scalia&rsquo;s &ldquo;continuous surface connection&rdquo; test, which would restrict jurisdiction to only those wetlands that that have a physical surface connection to waters; and Justice Kennedy&rsquo;s &ldquo;significant nexus&rdquo; test which recognized that wetlands impact water quality of hydrologically connected waters, even if that connection is below the surface.&nbsp; With no clear rule set forth by the Supreme Court, subsequent lower court decisions disagreed on how to apply the law, with most courts agreeing that Justice Kennedy&rsquo;s significant nexus test is a minimum for jurisdiction, but no court holding that a water is jurisdictional only if it meets Justice Scalia&rsquo;s &ldquo;continuous surface connection&rdquo; test.</span></p>

<p>The Sackett&nbsp;family have already been in front of the Supreme Court on just this issue. In 2004, Michael and Chantell Sackett bought a piece of property near Priest Lake in Idaho that was previously defined by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as a jurisdictional wetland. Because of that, the couple was prevented from filling in the wetland without a CWA permit to build a house. The couple sued EPA, arguing that the CWA didn&rsquo;t apply to their property because it wasn&rsquo;t a WOTUS; the case made its way to the Supreme Court on procedural issues and was remanded to the District Court, which in 2019 upheld EPA&rsquo;s determination that the wetland was jurisdictional under the &ldquo;significant nexus&rdquo; test (the wetlands were adjacent to and had a subsurface connection to a navigable body of water).&nbsp;</p>

<p>The case presently before the Supreme Court asks &ldquo;whether the [federal Court of Appeals] set forth the proper test for determining whether wetlands are &lsquo;waters of the United States&rsquo; under the Clean Water Act.&rdquo; Essentially, the Sacketts are asking the court to reject the significant nexus test in favor of the more limiting &ldquo;continuous surface connection&rdquo; test offered by Justice Scalia. In fact, they are asking the Court to apply an even-more stringent two-part test that would go further than even Justice Scalia in <span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Rapanos.</span></p>

<p>Over the past decade, EPA, state agencies, and many of the federal courts across the country have been applying the significant nexus test as the appropriate and scientifically-supported method for determining CWA jurisdiction. There has been much litigation over the agencies&rsquo; proposed WOTUS rules in that time, something that we don&rsquo;t have to time to go into in this blog post (but see <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-New-Definition-of-Waters-of-the-United-States-Threatens-Clean-Water-Act-Protections"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; color: rgb(5, 99, 193); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">here</span></a><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> if you&rsquo;re curious). Suffice it to say, no administration and no agency has ever thought a test as limiting as the one presently offered by the Sacketts was an appropriate test &ndash; not even the previous administration&rsquo;s </span><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-New-Definition-of-Waters-of-the-United-States-Threatens-Clean-Water-Act-Protections"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; color: rgb(5, 99, 193); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">proposed rule</span></a><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> that so severely curtailed the jurisdiction of the CWA that it was labeled the &ldquo;Dirty Water Rule.&rdquo;</span></p>

<p>Although I&rsquo;m not one to read tea leaves of the Supreme Court, overall, the justices seemed disinclined to wholesale reject that &ldquo;wetlands&rdquo; are clearly within the jurisdiction of the Clean Water Act. The focus of the questioning was around the term &ldquo;adjacent&rdquo; as it applied to wetlands, both as it is read in Section 404(g) of the Act (for those wetlands adjacent to traditionally navigable waters) as well as the &ldquo;significant nexus&rdquo; test (for those wetlands adjacent to other WOTUS, such as tributaries). Questions from multiple justices recognized that &ldquo;adjacent&rdquo; does not always require physical touching, nor have the federal agencies ever applied so stringent a limitation in making jurisdictional determinations. Many justices focused on the core purpose of the Clean Water Act - to protect and maintain the water quality of our Nations&rsquo; waters - as perhaps requiring a more inclusive definition than that being proposed by the Sacketts. These lines of questions bode well for the significant nexus test and recognition that physical surface barriers may not cut off CWA jurisdiction for adjacent wetlands.</p>

<p>Where some justices did seem a bit concerned, however, was on the practical implications of applying a jurisdictional test that requires analysis (such as the significant nexus test) and potential impacts to landowners. Worried about whether a landowner might know whether they had a jurisdictional wetland on their property, one line of questioning revolved around the cost of determining jurisdiction that the landowner might have to bear. In response, counsel for the federal government responded that a landowner could ask EPA to make that jurisdictional determination and that they will do it at no cost to the landowner. Counsel went on to explain that, should the landowner wish to challenge that determination, only in the most extreme large-scale development projects &ndash; i.e., not mom-and-pop building their single-family home &ndash; do we see costs for supporting studies reach into the hundreds of thousands of dollars.</p>

<p>Another line of questioning tried to imply that since all waters are connected, it would be nearly impossible to know when an impact can be cut off. But again, the response was quick that, as the government has been applying the test since 2006, there must be a &ldquo;significant&rdquo; connection to establish jurisdiction. Yes, sometimes there may be disputes about that but it is not an unworkable standard that must be rejected by the court.</p>

<p>There were many great lines of questions both supporting and questioning the government&rsquo;s position in this case. Yet the reality of how agencies have applied the significant nexus test since 2006 has not borne these concerns out much. So, in light of the seeming support for the federal government&rsquo;s position in this case, I question what impact, if any, might these types of questions have.</p>

<p>There will be much analysis over the next few days on this case, and we won&rsquo;t really know what the justices are thinking until we see the final opinion. But I came away from today&rsquo;s oral arguments (knock on wood) more positive than I thought I would.</p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-27468b99-7fff-eee6-3be8-94fdc32b4a4f""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">WOTUS has been a major issue under the Clean Water Act for my entire legal career (I started law school a few months after </span><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Rapanos</span><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""> was decided). Pennsylvania has fairly strong water quality protections with our Clean Streams Law. Still, there are places where a weakened CWA would impact our streams, lakes, and wetlands. I believe in the need &ndash; and the inherent right &ndash; for clean water, and I was encouraged today by the Court&rsquo;s acknowledgment and perhaps even support of the Clean Water Act&rsquo;s stated purpose. After 50 years of the Clean Water Act, I still remain hopeful that we will meet that goal.&nbsp; </span></span></p>
",Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
"Solar-Powered PennFuture Walks the Walk, Doubles PV Capacity",9/14/2022,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-cc64d2fa-7fff-43f4-af8c-0b94e590b18a""></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-cc64d2fa-7fff-43f4-af8c-0b94e590b18a""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""></span></span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">In June 2003, PennFuture installed our first set of solar panels. The 3.84-kW system was made up of 32 panels, each rated at 120 watts. Our rooftop system generated about 65 megawatt hours of clean electricity since installation, helping us to avoid about 35 tons of carbon pollution since it was installed.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">As solar PV technology continues to improve, more modern panels provide greater output. We wanted to do even better&mdash;and we did.</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">This month, PennFuture replaced our system with a modern 6.56-kW installation. Our new panels are about twice the size of the old ones, generating 410 watts of power each&mdash;almost 4 times more power. That means that, on the same racks that held the old panels, we now have 16 new ones generating almost twice as much energy and lowering our electricity bill by more than $1,000 per year.</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Better yet, the 32 panels removed from our roof are not headed to a landfill. Even after 19 years of service, they remain in great condition and will continue generating clean energy in other applications. They may still be in service many years from now&mdash;most solar panels are guaranteed to operate for 25 years, and even &ldquo;worn out&rdquo; panels can generate 80% or more of the electricity they did when they were new.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Our work on solar</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""><img alt="""" src=""https://twitter.com/RobAltenburg/status/1564970488585240579/photo/1"" style=""margin: 1px;"" />Solar panels today typically cost less than $3 per watt&mdash;less than half of what they did when our first system was installed 19 years ago&mdash;and other programs can make them even more affordable.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Since PennFuture&rsquo;s founding in 1998, we have been an outpost in Pennsylvania, fighting for programs to make solar more affordable and more accessible to all our citizens.</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">In 2004, we helped pass the Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards Act that required utilities and electric generation companies to ensure a certain percentage of the power they sell comes from solar and other clean renewable energy. To do so, these companies buy &ldquo;credits&rdquo; from clean energy generators&mdash;with each credit representing a megawatt-hour of clean energy.</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">A few years later, we successfully defended <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Net-Metering-Works-for-Pennsylvania"">Pennsylvania&rsquo;s net metering rules </a>from plans to weaken the program. Under net metering, utilities are required to purchase excess electricity from homes and businesses with small solar generation systems and pay the full retail value for that energy.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">We also supported programs like the recent extension of the federal Investment Tax Credit (ITC), which gives families and businesses a 30% tax credit for installing solar panels and otherwise improving efficiency.</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">There is more work to do</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">But, the fight isn&rsquo;t over. The next challenge is to bring solar access to the 40&ndash;75% of Pennsylvanians that can&rsquo;t readily buy solar panels on their own. Maybe they rent, live in multi-family housing, or simply have more immediate priorities for investing money. </span></span></p>

<p><span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">For these homes and businesses, the answer might be Community Solar.&nbsp;Rather than build solar on their property, people can buy or lease a share of a larger centralized system. Energy produced by their share would appear as a credit on their electricity bill, much like it would if the panels were on their roof. Many other states already have this program. To get it in Pennsylvania, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Looking-Ahead-to-the-Best-and-Worst-of-2022s-Legislative-Proposals"">our Legislature needs to pass a new law such as HB 1555</a>, currently before our legislature.</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-5fcb5661-7fff-670e-c139-e5a12d5b8dff""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">We couldn&rsquo;t do any of this without your support! <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">Please consider becoming a PennFuture member today.</a></span></span></p>

",Climate; Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
Growing Greener Lives On – with Bipartisan Support,8/29/2022,"<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Growing Greener program has a long history of bipartisan support. Now known as the State Parks and Outdoor Recreation Program, Growing Greener reflects the importance of clean streams, open space protections, and robust environmental infrastructure to members of both parties. We are proud to be among the state lawmakers who continue to support this crucial program.</p>

<p>The program&rsquo;s history goes back to 1999. Governor Tom Ridge signed into law legislation creating the first Growing Greener program to benefit various environmental initiatives including parks and recreation, clean water, agricultural improvements and sewer and water projects.&nbsp; This program received large bipartisan support.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Under Governor Ed Rendell, Growing Greener II became law in 2005. Funded with a bond issuance, Growing Greener II continued many of the same funding streams to benefit watersheds, outdoor recreation and the environment around our Commonwealth. It also received broad bipartisan support.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Since that time, there has been pent-up demand to enact a Growing Greener III program to provide new funding to these initiatives and to add to environmental investments in our state.&nbsp; The challenge has been finding funding while the Commonwealth has operated under strained budgets over the past decade.&nbsp;</p>

<p>However, with the coronavirus pandemic, there has been a significant stream of federal monies coming to states to address important issues during these challenging times. We introduced Growing Greener III bills in the Senate and the House this session that directed some of the American Rescue Plan (ARP) federal monies to be used to fund this latest update to this successful legacy program.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>At the same time, other legislation was introduced in the Senate to provide millions of dollars of ARP funds for a Clean Streams Fund to address agricultural runoff and acid mine drainage.&nbsp; Once again, these bills had broad bipartisan support. The challenge was getting this legislation to the &ldquo;finish line&rdquo; when there were dozens of competing plans to use the limited amount of federal ARP monies.</p>

<p>Soon after introducing Senate Bill 525, we began working with the diverse Growing Greener coalition that had been formed years ago. Among the partners in this group are WeConservePA, Natural Lands, PennFuture, Lancaster Farmland Trust, Sierra Club, Trout Unlimited, and the Foundation for PA Watersheds.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Also, we worked with, and communicated on a regular basis with, DCNR Secretary Cindy Dunn who has been a vocal advocate for new investment.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In addition, we must acknowledge that the PA Farm Bureau listed these two bills as their top priority when they engaged with all legislators during their advocacy day in Harrisburg in late March.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>With the assistance of all of these groups and Secretary Dunn, we were able to spread the word to their membership and from their membership to legislators and legislative leaders. As we headed into the serious budget negotiations in June, we could feel the momentum increasing.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The end result of July&rsquo;s comprehensive budget package &ndash; passed with broad bipartisan support &ndash; was a monumental investment in programs and initiatives to benefit the environment across our Commonwealth:</p>

<ul>
	<li>$100 million in ARP monies for parks and recreation along with $56 million additional from the oil and gas lease funds.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>$220 million for the Clean Streams Fund to address agricultural run-off and mine drainage, especially in how it affects the Chesapeake Bay.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>$320 million for sewer and water projects to ensure that our communities have access to safe and clean water and that our streams and rivers aren&rsquo;t infected with faulty or outdated systems.&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>Thanks to a concerted and united effort, this entire package was adopted.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We look forward to working with all of the coalition groups and supporters of this effort to ensure that these monies are well spent and that our Commonwealth and environment will benefit for generations to come.&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,Senator John Gordner (R-27) and Representative Lynda Schlegel Culver (R-108)
"How we helped create ""A Shared Vision for Pennsylvania’s Environment and Communities"" and where we go next",8/3/2022,"<p>Our mission at PennFuture is to protect the air, water, and land for the benefit of all Pennsylvanians. We act on this goal every day, from <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-Protects-Major-River-Basins-Across-Pennsylvania-in-Stormwater-Settlement"">winning meaningful legal settlements</a>, advocating for - <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-Applauds-Historic-Environmental-Investments-Included-in-New-State-Budget"">and then winning</a> - historic increases in clean water funding, and being on the forefront of <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Terrible-Excuses-to-Mine-Bitcoin"">identifying new (and sometimes esoteric) threats to our environment.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>However, we recognize that we are but one voice among many in the overall environmental, conservation, and environmental justice movements in Pennsylvania. To seek the change that we so desperately require, we recognize the need to join with a diverse group of partners and come together to speak with one clear voice. That is why this year, we were proud to work together with 29 other organizations across the state on the development of <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/sharedvision"">A Shared Vision for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Environment and Communities</a>&cedil; a document directed towards all state level candidates, both gubernatorial and legislative, that lists the most pressing environmental issues facing the Commonwealth along with the policy proposals that will fix them.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture served on the Steering Committee, alongside the <a href=""https://centerforcoalfieldjustice.org/"">Center for Coalfield Justice</a>, <a href=""https://www.conservationpa.org/"">Conservation Voters of Pennsylvania (CVPA)</a>, <a href=""https://pittsburghunited.org/"">Pittsburgh United</a>, and <a href=""https://www.sierraclub.org/pennsylvania"">Sierra Club&rsquo;s Pennsylvania Chapter</a>. I, along with my wonderful colleague Michelle Giles from CVPA, were honored to be selected to be the co-coordinators helping guide along the process from inception to completion.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our Shared Vision builds upon the great work of the <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Publication-PennFuture-Launches-Green-in-18-Campaign-to-Back-PA-Common-Conservation-Agenda-Developed-by-Statewide-Coalition-of-Environmental-Groups"">&ldquo;Green in &rsquo;18 Common Agenda&rdquo;</a>, a groundbreaking document that represented the first time that the Pennsylvania environmental community came together to list the top environmental issues facing the Commonwealth. This year, we wanted to build upon that great effort and expand it to be more even comprehensive.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>First and foremost, while the 2018 Common Agenda had an environmental justice section, we purposely decided early on that environmental justice principles and policy solutions should be interwoven throughout the entire document. In order to hold the Steering Committee accountable to this lofty goal, we held meetings with environmental justice groups before, during, and after the drafting of the document to ensure that their concerns and desires were being heard and adequately addressed. We then added two environmental justice members to the Steering Committee, <a href=""https://www.maketheroadpa.org/"">Make the Road PA</a> and <a href=""https://onepa.org/vote/"">OnePA</a>, to ensure that our commitment remained steadfast. These meetings proved to be extremely valuable and helped shape our Shared Vision.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Their input directly leads to two more concrete changes from the 2018 Common Agenda: expansion on the number of sections and inclusion of personal profiles.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our Shared Vision includes seven intertwining sections: Air, Water, Energy, Housing and Land Use, Labor, Democracy, and Education. We recognized that without protecting labor rights a transition to a green energy future is impossible. That without empowering and protecting our democratic institutions it will be impossible to protect our air &amp; water. And that it is only with quality environmental education for all students, that we can build an understanding and appreciation for how our natural world impacts us among future generations.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>To ensure that these efforts are not mere abstracts, for each of these sections we selected a cross-selection of everyday citizens from throughout the four corners of Pennsylvania to talk about the immediate impact of the policies discussed. We believe that this adds a human touch to the Shared Vision, which reinforces the real-life benefits of our policies.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We recognize that drafting the document is only the first step, and we are now working diligently to see it implemented. We officially launched the Shared Vision this week with a press conference at the Harrisburg Capitol Rotunda. And for the rest of August throughout the state there are events posted that will be open to the public they are:&nbsp;</p>

PennFuture and the other co-signers intend to build off our momentum this month, by using use the Shared Vision as a mechanism to educate the candidates seeking an elected position on the state level. After the elections, we intend to use this document as an education tool for incoming lawmakers and for the next gubernatorial administration.
