PennFuture Celebrates Lake Erie and Introduces New Erie Campaign Manager During PA Clean Water Education Week,4/13/2022,"<p>PennFuture is celebrating its sixth annual PA Clean Water Education Week, dedicated to showcasing the Commonwealth&rsquo;s unique waterways and advocating for their health by ensuring sufficient state funding for protection and restoration initiatives. Throughout the week, we highlight each of PA&rsquo;s six major watersheds. Today we celebrate the Lake Erie Watershed!</p>

<p>There is much to appreciate about Lake Erie. The 11th largest lake in the world by surface area, Erie provides drinking water to over 11 million people basin-wide. Erie is the warmest and shallowest of the five Great Lakes and, subsequently, the most biologically productive and diverse. Lake Erie also presents a success story for clean water funding. Efforts of the 1970s, including the passage of the Clean Water Act and the multi-national <a href=""https://ijc.org/en/great-lakes-water-quality-agreement-turns-50#:~:text=There%20is%20much%20to%20reflect%20on%20as%20the,social%2C%20cultural%20and%20spiritual%20activities%20of%20Indigenous%20peoples."">Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement</a>, addressed unabated industrial pollution, agricultural runoff, and poor wastewater treatment that plagued Lake Erie. More recent funding from the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative provided extra assistance for priority cleanup locations known as Areas of Concern, including Presque Isle Bay, which was deemed safe again and delisted in 2013. Consistent support from decisionmakers and dedicated clean water funding have allowed Lake Erie and Presque Isle Bay to become the thriving recreational, commercial, and cultural assets we know today.</p>

<p>In my first weeks with PennFuture in Erie, it became clear that many Erieites are proud of the improvements made to their lake and bay. However, we cannot take this progress for granted and must remain unified in our resolve for protection of these resources. Today, our lake faces complex challenges linked to climate change, surface runoff, invasive species, legacy and emergent industrial toxins, and pollution from the fossil fuel and plastics industries. Watershed residents in historically burdened communities, particularly communities of color, face compounding and disproportionate impacts from legacy contamination and other threats. For these reasons, we continue to advocate for the funding necessary to limit the impacts of our built and agricultural resources on water quality, to improve ecosystem and community resilience, and to foster an appreciation of these resources among all Pennsylvanians by ensuring everyone has access to outdoor amenities, including our lake.</p>

<p>Sufficient funding is essential for protecting Lake Erie and our watershed residents but is only one piece of a comprehensive approach requiring policy change and involvement from decision makers at all levels, businesses, academic institutions, and a diverse array of citizen advocates. I am thankful for the foundational work of our staff and community partners as outlined in <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/ErieCommonAgenda_6.pdf"">Our Water, Our Future: A Common Agenda for Protecting Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Lake Erie Watershed</a>. In collaboration with twelve area environmental organizations, several resident scientists, and a cohort of social justice reviewers, PennFuture outlined this comprehensive framework needed to address water quality concerns.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Clean water funding remains a priority for the state budget season, but we must advance other aspects of the Common Agenda. Stimulus funds under the American Rescue Plan and Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Acts create opportunities to fund many of our budget recommendations. These relate to stormwater management, renewable energy and electric vehicle infrastructure, orphaned and abandoned oil / gas well plugging, brownfield reclamation, and other commercial and neighborhood development efforts. We will advocate for watershed communities getting their fair share of these funds and for the prioritization of water quality and environment concerns in project implementation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Recognizing the disproportionate impact of environmental issues and the COVID-19 pandemic on disadvantaged communities and people of color, we seek to ensure stimulus investments and other decision-making processes equitably benefit all communities and promote inclusive decision-making. This includes ongoing involvement in <a href=""https://blavity.com/how-a-pennsylvania-towns-community-revitalization-project-is-hurting-its-low-income-poc?category1=opinion"">litigation with PennDOT</a> and the US Highway Administration regarding the Bayfront Parkway reconstruction plans that lacked of proper environmental consideration in project design phases and will harm environmental justice communities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>New and improved policy at local and state levels will be essential to placing Lake Erie Watershed communities on a sustainable, long-term trajectory, particularly once stimulus funds are spent. PennFuture and our partners continue to focus on landuse policies that benefit water quality and human health, and legislative safeguards against industrial, fossil fuel, and plastic pollution. With collaboration and shared goals, the Erie region can set itself on a new path, recognizing environmental and human health need not be framed in opposition to economic prosperity. I welcome the input of diverse partners across all sectors as we work toward this vision for our watershed communities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To remain up to date on our work in the Lake Erie Watershed, please like and follow the recently launched PennFuture &ndash; Erie <a href=""https://www.facebook.com/PennFutureErie"">Facebook</a>, <a href=""https://twitter.com/PennFutureErie"">Twitter</a>, and <a href=""https://www.instagram.com/pennfutureerie/"">Instagram</a> pages! These pages will cover water quality education, local environmental news and events, and provide local context for our other state and regional work. Be sure to check out our Clean Water Education Week and Lake Erie Watershed celebration posts from this week.</p>

<p>Water is central to the identity of many in Northwest Pennsylvania, and we must work together to protect our most precious resource. Thank you for celebrating Clean Water Education Week and the Lake Erie Watershed with PennFuture. Please consider getting involved in our other efforts to protect Lake Erie and our local communities.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jenny Tompkins, Campaign Manager for Clean Water Advocacy"
Chasing the Rainbow: Carbon Capture is Magic Thinking,4/13/2022,"<p>There&rsquo;s been a lot of discussion and excitement <a href=""https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/carbon-capture-climate-change-iowa-rcna19572"">about the idea of carbon capture and storage technology.</a>&nbsp; Unfortunately, the excitement about the potential far outstrips the reality of the technology.</p>

<p>There is no doubt that we are living <a href=""https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg2/"">through climate change</a>. It isn&rsquo;t a question of whether it&rsquo;s coming, it&rsquo;s a question of&mdash;pardon the pun&mdash;degree. We all see and experience the changing weather patterns, the increasing storms. Our parents&rsquo; stories of skiing and sledding throughout the winter in Philadelphia when they were children is nearly unimaginable now. The future is uncertain and often scary. In these dramatic circumstances, it&rsquo;s natural for us to reach for hope and to reach for dramatic solutions.</p>

<p>Carbon capture, also known more formally as &ldquo;carbon capture utilization and storage&rdquo; (and it&rsquo;s accompanying acronym &ldquo;CCUS&rdquo;), looks on its surface like exactly the hero we need. The idea behind it is tantalizingly simple: develop technology and systems that takes the carbon we&rsquo;re putting into the air with fossil fuels and simply puts it back into the ground where it came from. In theory, there are different ways to do this, ranging from startups that could develop bold new technologies, to simply identifying and accelerating natural processes that already happen, like planting trees. Carbon capture holds universal appeal: environmentalists see it as a way to restore the planet to sustainable CO2 levels, fossil fuel proponents see it as a way to continue their business without major disruption, and even non-experts can get behind the idea of something that gives us the best of all worlds.</p>

<p>Sadly, this is all magical thinking. Magical thinking is dangerous, because it lets us avoid the real, immediate challenges we are facing in favor of a solution that may never materialize. As a global society, we absolutely need to develop new technologies to mitigate the effects of climate change. However, not only is carbon capture not a silver bullet, it is distracting us from the technology we already have.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We already have proven technology that is competitive on the free market: For instance, we know that solar, wind, and other renewable energy sources <a href=""https://ieefa.org/milestone-u-s-wind-power-second-highest-electrical-source-last-week/"">can work wonderfully</a> as part of a portfolio of energy sources. Battery technology has improved almost beyond imagination in a short time, with energy storage costs <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/analysis/studies/electricity/batterystorage/"">declining 72% between 2015 and 2019</a>, and energy storage systems <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/analysis/studies/electricity/batterystorage/"">increasing 27% from 2018 to 2019 alone</a>. These are real tools that we are already successfully using worldwide and that the USA is playing an important part in expanding.</p>

<p>By contrast, carbon capture is a technology that overpromises and underdelivers. Despite <a href=""https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/31/carbon-capture-technology.html"">decades of development efforts</a>, carbon capture remains both extremely expensive, unproven to be able to work <a href=""https://www.newscientist.com/article/2287551-inside-the-race-to-scale-up-co2-capture-technology-and-hit-net-zero/"">at the necessary scale</a>, and largely unable to meet its own projections of success. For one example, we could look at hydrogen as &ldquo;clean&rdquo; energy. What we really know is that hydrogen as a fuel source is really just a rebranding of an old frenemy, the oil and gas industry. So-called &ldquo;green&rdquo; or &ldquo;blue&rdquo; hydrogen is advertised as a new energy solution, better for the climate. In reality, the carbon capture systems at hydrogen plants have been shown to fall dramatically short, with terrible consequences. First of all, it&rsquo;s critical to know that hydrogen must have highly successful carbon capture&mdash;90% or more!&mdash;to be &ldquo;clean.&rdquo; However, <a href=""https://ieefa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/Blue-Hydrogen-Presentation_February-2022.pdf"">recent studies</a> have found that hydrogen plants that utilize carbon capture only have a success rate ranging from 48% to 77%.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Even if (and it is a big &ldquo;if&rdquo;) carbon capture has a breakthrough, the better use for that technology would be to reduce our global carbon levels back down to more sustainable levels. The global temperature is rising: this technology should be used to mitigate the problems, not to try and put a band-aid over a bullet hole. But until that time, we have the ability to start work using the tools that are already at hand: strengthening our environmental protections, working with other states in the country and region to fundamentally reduce greenhouse gas release (such as through joining RGGI), and accelerating our use of renewable power.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Emma Bast, Staff Attorney"
Pennsylvania House Asks: Could We Live Without Fossil Fuels? We Say: We Must.,3/31/2022,"<p>The only thing more destructive than the fumes from fossil fuels extracted in PA is the fumes of the trillions of taxpayer dollars up in flames by the constant shilling to fossil fuel boosters in the form of disinformation-laden hearings in our State Capitol.&nbsp;</p>

<p>On March 28, 2022, the Pennsylvania House Environmental Resources &amp; Energy Committee held an industry-friendly hearing titled &ldquo;Could We Live Without Fossil Fuels?&rdquo; Phrases such as &ldquo;natural gas and oil are essential to life&rdquo; uttered by Rep. Mike Armanini and &ldquo;we cannot go back to living like the colonials and Native Americans&rdquo; stated by both Chairman Daryl Metcalfe and panelist David Taylor polluted the air of the meeting room. Metcalfe asks in the title of this hearing &ldquo;could we live without fossil fuels?&rdquo; and the answer is not &ldquo;we could,&rdquo; &ldquo;we couldn&rsquo;t,&rdquo; or even &ldquo;we should;&rdquo; but instead: we must.</p>

<p>The panelists, which were all (and only) representatives of the fossil fuel industry including the American Petroleum lnstitute (API), Marcellus Shale Coalition, Pennsylvania Independent Oil and Gas Association (PIOGA), American Refining Group, and Pennsylvania Chemical lndustry Council. These panelists were aided throughout the hearing by the majority chairman and his caucus.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This hearing repeated tired, frequently-debunked talking points about the &ldquo;necessity&rdquo; of fossil fuel-based products in the American consumer&rsquo;s daily life. However, as Minority Chair Greg Vitali correctly pointed out, <a href=""https://theconversation.com/oil-companies-are-going-all-in-on-petrochemicals-and-green-chemistry-needs-help-to-compete-153598"">roughly 80 percent&nbsp;of each barrel of oil extracted</a> is used for gasoline or other fuel, while the rest goes to other petrochemical products such as those used in household items. Rep. Danielle Friel Otten and Rep. Joe Hohenstein also pushed back on the &ldquo;necessity&rdquo; of these products and assertions by the panelists that &ldquo;no viable alternative&rdquo; exists. With increased research and development, environmentally sustainable household products are increasing in availability and lowering in price. In regards to baby products, an area of much discussion at this hearing, there is no shortage of products that are <a href=""https://www.mother.ly/baby/baby-shopping-guide/eco-friendly-baby-care-items/"">both sustainable</a> and <a href=""https://www.poison.org/articles/dangerous-household-hydrocarbons"">actually safer</a> for mothers and their newborns than petrochemical based products.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Another heavy focus of the hearing was medical devices, and the current reliance on petrochemicals in their production. The panelists, aided by majority representatives, argued that &ldquo;viable alternatives&rdquo; do not exist to the current medical products. This is largely false, as <a href=""https://www.greenbook.org/mr/market-research-news/environmental-sustainability-healthcare-and-medical-devices/"">roadmaps and suggestions to manufacturing</a> more sustainable medical devices and products have existed for years.</p>

<p>However, what is lacking is larger-scale investment, development, and research which would lead to such products becoming less expensive and more widely available.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Rep. Bud Cook, a member of the majority, raised an interesting question &ndash; whether the panelists could speak to the perspectives of employees in the fossil fuel industry and how their work impacts the environment in which they live. Metcalfe quickly interrupted Cook, rephrasing the question to whether the panelists could speak to the &ldquo;necessary&rdquo; petrochemical based products used in fishing and outdoorsman equipment. PennFuture has long researched and written about the impacts of fossil fuel extraction on vulnerable, front-line communities including, but not limited to, rural and working-class populations largely served by members of the majority in Harrisburg.</p>

<p>In Rep. Cook&rsquo;s Washington and Fayette County constituencies, residents fall victim to <a href=""https://www.coalfieldjustice.org/blog/2019/8/5/statement-on-columbia-gas-explosion-in-washington-pa"">pipeline explosions</a>, <a href=""https://www.wpxi.com/news/top-stories/thousands-gallons-gas-spill-into-washington-county-creek-neighbors-report-feeling-sick/DTFEFKNXANFGHLRPYUTYLG5C3M/"">gas leaks</a>, <a href=""https://www.alleghenyfront.org/cnx-pleads-to-criminal-charges-for-misreporting-air-pollution-in-washington-county/"">air pollution</a>, and <a href=""https://www.publicsource.org/rural-pennsylvanians-with-contaminated-water-potentially-from-fracking-feel-abandoned-by-state-regulators/"">water contamination</a> due to continued fossil fuel extraction. PennFuture also maintains the position that fossil fuels and petrochemicals are not the key to revitalizing regions that both Rep. Metcalfe and Rep. Cook serve. Alternative, <a href=""https://exclusive.multibriefs.com/content/green-collar-jobs-in-the-spotlight/facilities-grounds"">&ldquo;green-collar&rdquo; job opportunities</a> are growing worldwide and present <a href=""https://rmi.org/rmi-reality-check-appalachia-poised-to-become-clean-energy-country/"">enormous economic opportunities</a> for Appalachia, and instead of chasing a dying industry, Pennsylvania would be best served <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/greenstimulus"">leading the path into the new, green economy.</a>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This hearing, at its basis, presents a false dichotomy: invest in fossil fuels or live like those in the colonial era. As Minority Chair Vitali aptly noted, &ldquo;that is ridiculous.&rdquo; As for the remark about Native Americans made by Metcalfe and some in the panel, Rep. Hohenstein made a noteworthy retort. Hohenstein cited the <a href=""https://www.ictinc.ca/blog/seventh-generation-principle"">Seventh Generation Principle</a>, based on an ancient Haudenosaunee (Iroquois) philosophy. This Principle states that the decisions we make today should result in a sustainable world seven generations into the future.</p>

<p>While we seek cheap and quick solutions to our energy needs today, we are leaving a dead planet for our children tomorrow unless we make swift investments in the emerging green economy. As the representative from API said in this hearing: &ldquo;we all breathe the same air, we all drink the same water, and we want a clean environment&rdquo; &ndash; and it is time we put our money where our mouth is and act like we believe this while we still can.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"John Ukenye, Policy Analyst"
Philadelphia’s 2023 Budget Must Prioritize Clean Water for All,3/29/2022,"<p><a href=""https://c.tenor.com/QZNVDaVse9sAAAAC/looney-tunes-bugs-bunny.gif"">Duck season! Rabbit season!</a></p>

<p>No, it&rsquo;s budget season!&nbsp;</p>

<p>We are only days away from Mayor Jim Kenney&rsquo;s penultimate budget address to City Council and the annual push to fund numerous priorities. The good news? Philadelphia continues to recover from the economic turmoil brought on by the coronavirus pandemic. The bad news? Philadelphia <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/news/philadelphia-budget-pandemic-revenue-down-mayor-jim-kenney-20220215.html"">continues to lag behind other major cities</a> in America in its recovery from the pandemic.</p>

<p>In a January <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hTd5wWNrAM8"">town hall</a>, Mayor Kenney said: &ldquo;The budget is not just about numbers and spending. It&rsquo;s the representation of the priorities of our city&hellip;The budget takes our values and turns them into investments. And, turns our hopes and goals into plans.&rdquo;</p>

<p>A video presentation went further: &ldquo;The budget represents the City of Philadelphia&rsquo;s commitment to tackling its biggest challenges, including providing a safe and just city, health equity for all, and quality education for all Philadelphians. Amid all the charts and numbers of the budget is a core goal: to increase equity and opportunity so that you can reach your full potential regardless of what corner of the city you live in.&rdquo;</p>

<p>So, what are our values for the 2023 fiscal year? A survey helps shed some light on the city&rsquo;s priorities and preferences. These were the options to choose from:</p>

<p>Anti-violence;<br />
Neighborhood Services;<br />
Education;<br />
Business and Workforce Development;<br />
Arts and Culture;<br />
Infrastructure (Roads and Bridges);<br />
Support for Vulnerable People;<br />
Public Health;<br />
Public Safety; and<br />
Other: ______.</p>

<p>Attendees were encouraged to choose three priorities and provide their priorities in the chat if they selected &ldquo;Other.&rdquo; Not surprisingly, education was the top priority among attendees, followed by neighborhood services.</p>

<p>At first glance, the list of potential options encapsulates many, if not most, of the broad categories that require further investment. But if we take another look, there are issues. The list above makes no mention of climate or the environment. In fact, climate was not mentioned once during the virtual town hall that spanned approximately sixty minutes. The environment was not mentioned either. Unfortunately, <a href=""https://www.thegreencities.com/news/mayor-kenney-leaves-out-climate-change-out-of-his-budget-address/"">we&rsquo;ve seen this movie before</a> in Philadelphia as issues related to climate change and the environment are set aside during one of the most crucial periods of the fiscal year.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To start, infrastructure isn&rsquo;t just roads and bridges &ndash; as one attendee astutely pointed out during the January town hall. In fact, Philadelphia <a href=""https://e360.yale.edu/features/with-a-green-makeover-philadelphia-tackles-its-stormwater-problem#:~:text=In%20a%20major%20initiative%2C%20Philadelphia,green%20America's%20fifth%2Dlargest%20city."">remains a leader</a> through its incorporation of green infrastructure like trees, rain gardens, and other natural elements to improve the local environment and increase public health.</p>

<p>We have also seen the annual reminder of the impact our aging water infrastructure can have on all of us <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/busted-water-mains-flood-philly-streets-as-city-fails-to-hit-pipe-replacement-goals/"">with another round of water main breaks</a> as the city&rsquo;s efforts to replace old pipes continue to fall short. As I&rsquo;ve written previously, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Its-Time-to-Reimagine-Americas-Infrastructure"">Philadelphia&#39;s water pipes are ancient</a>. The average age is approximately 73 years, and more than 800 miles of the city&rsquo;s mains are older than 100 years.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Massive water main breaks can be devastating for any community, particularly underserved communities that cannot afford to shoulder the cost of repairs to their homes and neighborhoods that can stem from a massive water main break, <a href=""https://6abc.com/south-philadelphia-water-main-break-queen-village-july-2021-6th-and-bainbridge/11658288/"">nor bear the delays</a> in restoring basic services to the impacted area. Part of Kingsessing <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/news/water-main-break-west-philly-kingsessing-56th-and-springfield-avenue-20220209.html"">recently experienced</a> a 48-inch break to a water main that was 100 years old. The main broke in early February and neighbors <a href=""https://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/local/one-month-after-massive-water-main-break-residents-still-feeling-impact/3171770/"">are still suffering from the effects</a> more than a month later. One family said that it took several weeks to restore heat to their home, forcing family members to use a space heater to provide some warmth during cold winter months.</p>

<p>Councilmember Jamie Gauthier represents the neighborhood and <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/news/water-main-break-kingsessing-heat-electricity-20220218.html"">summed up the situation</a> in a written statement: &ldquo;Our most vulnerable residents should not have to shoulder the burden of the long-term failure of all levels of government to adequately fund the maintenance of Philadelphia&rsquo;s water infrastructure.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Mayor Kenney&rsquo;s budget address and the subsequent hearings in City Council present an opportunity for the city to clarify how it will do its part to properly fund efforts to update its creaking, groaning water infrastructure. PennFuture will be listening for spending proposals that will capitalize on the important work of the city&rsquo;s Green City, Clean Waters plan to utilize green stormwater infrastructure and green space to relieve some of the pressure on the city&rsquo;s water mains. We are also very interested to hear from the city how it plans to take advantage of new funding sources provided by the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act to help it fund this critical work and avoid millions of dollars in damages to communities that can least afford it.</p>

<p>Green City, Clean Waters has also provided opportunities for the city to create opportunities for workforce development through organizations like <a href=""https://powercorpsphl.org/"">PowerCorpsPHL</a>. Founded in 2013, PowerCorpsPHL <a href=""https://thephiladelphiacitizen.org/powercorpsphl-philadelphia/"">has helped hundreds of young people</a> gain access to career opportunities that were not previously available to them. Participants can earn an hourly wage while developing skills in areas that will help them succeed in the jobs of tomorrow through rebuilding and protecting our natural infrastructure. Green City, Clean Waters allows participants to receive training in the installation, repair, and maintenance of green stormwater infrastructure, which remains an industry <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Report-highlights-success-of-Philadelphias-Green-City-Clean-Waters-Program"">with enormous growth potential</a> and economic benefit across Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>Unfortunately, PowerCorpsPHL has seen its city funding <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/news/philadelphia-gun-violence-programs-funding-20211227.html"">cut severely over the past several years</a> despite its strong record of providing employment opportunities to disconnected youth, reducing violence, and improving Philadelphia&rsquo;s natural environment. In fact, the city has cut its funding to PowerCorpsPHL from almost $1.5 million per year to less than $400,000 since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic.</p>

<p>PowerCorpsPHL remains a national model that reminds us of what is possible when we prioritize workforce development and training in 21st-century career paths with efforts to improve the urban environment. Prior to the pandemic, the program <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/news/power-corps-mural-arts-guild-philadelphia-youth-gun-violence-20201202.html"">was able to secure family-sustaining jobs</a> for 90 percent of its participants. It also provided an opportunity for youth and returning citizens to chart a path for themselves that would be free of the immediate threat of crime and violence.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The city recognized the program&rsquo;s success in helping to combat the rising tide of violence in Philadelphia when it awarded PowerCorpsPHL with a $550,000 grant because of last year&rsquo;s budget negotiations. This, however, must be used for the specific grant proposal and will not help sustain the program in doing the work that it has done so successfully since its inception. The city should use this budget season as an opportunity to restore its funding to PowerCorpsPHL to pre-pandemic levels.</p>

<p>It is a clich&eacute;, but budgets are about our values. PennFuture&rsquo;s values during this budget season are simple:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Protect our most vulnerable neighborhoods from the impact of warmer, wetter weather, and an aging infrastructure through sustained investment in green infrastructure and green space;</li>
	<li>Ensure that the least fortunate among us do not have to bear the burden of preventable disasters like water main breaks; and</li>
	<li>Provide access to job opportunities for disconnected youth and returning citizens so that they can have access to careers that will provide for themselves and their families.</li>
</ol>

<p>We hope that Mayor Kenney&rsquo;s budget address and the subsequent City Council hearings will reaffirm the city&rsquo;s commitment to these values and demonstrate the city&rsquo;s ability to put its money where its mouth is.</p>

"PennFuture, Partners Halt Construction of Proposed Liquefied Natural Gas Plant in Bradford County",3/28/2022,"<p>PennFuture, representing our partners Clean Air Council and Sierra Club, secured a big legal victory on March 18 by obtaining a settlement that&nbsp; halts the construction of a proposed Bradford County Real Estate Partners (&ldquo;BCREP&rdquo;) Liquified Natural Gas (&ldquo;LNG&rdquo;) facility near the Susquehanna River in Wyalusing Township, Bradford County, in Northeastern Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In August, PennFuture and our partners appealed a second extension of the air pollution permit for the proposed facility issued by the Department of Environmental Protection (&ldquo;DEP&rdquo;) to the Environmental Hearing Board (&ldquo;EHB&rdquo;).&nbsp;In this challenge, we objected to the second extension on several grounds, including that DEP erred in granting the extension because BCREP had not commenced construction at the Wyalusing facility, as required by the regulations.&nbsp;Further, the second extension relied on outdated and inappropriate pollution control technology.&nbsp;We also objected to the second extension because the DEP relied on flawed analysis resulting in insufficient and erroneous air emission limits, and several other significant deficiencies as detailed in our <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/2021-8-26-Notice-of-Appeal-without-exhibits.pdf"">Notice of Appeal,</a> which may be found here.</p>

<p>The parties agreed that BCREP will not move forward with construction of the facility under its current air pollution permit and will allow the permit to expire on July 22, 2022.&nbsp;In return, PennFuture and our partners ended our appeal of the second extension of the air pollution permit.&nbsp;If BCREP wants to build this facility, the settlement requires them to go through the process of applying for and obtaining an entirely new air pollution permit from DEP.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The proposed Wyalusing facility would have processed fracked natural gas into highly explosive LNG for shipment by truck or train through Pennsylvania communities to a proposed LNG export facility in Gibbstown, New Jersey for transport to overseas markets. This proposed LNG export scheme would endanger the health of our communities and environment, increase fracking in Pennsylvania, and lead to the further entrenchment of the fossil fuel industry.&nbsp;If constructed under the current air permit, the Wyalusing facility would have been permitted to emit over a million tons of greenhouse gasses and hundreds of tons of other harmful air pollutants annually, contributing to both climate change and dangerous air pollution.&nbsp;To learn more about LNG and its dangers, please check out our LNG Blog Series:&nbsp; <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-Series-1-What-is-Liquefied-Natural-Gas"">LNG Blog #1</a>, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-2-Bomb-Trains-Through-Pennsylvania"">LNG Blog #2</a>, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-3-Protect-Northern-PA"">LNG Blog #3</a>, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-4-Liquified-Natural-Gas-Should-Not-Become-the-New-Bomb-Trains-to-Threaten-Our-Communities"">LNG Blog #4</a>, and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-5-Public-opposition-grows-to-proposed-LNG-shipping-terminals"">LNG Blog #5.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>PennFuture is working hard to protect our waters, our air, and our communities from the dangers of the petrochemical buildout across Pennsylvania.&nbsp;Halting the construction of this LNG facility is an important step of that work and our fight for a clean energy future.&nbsp;</p>

<p>If you are interested in supporting our work, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">please become a member today!</a></p>
",,"Angela Kilbert, Staff Attorney"
"Fallacy, Fiction, and Falsehoods: Debunking the Fossil Fuel Industry’s Stance on Russia’s War in Ukraine",3/25/2022,"<p>On Feb. 24, Russia commenced its unprovoked and atrocious invasion of its neighbor Ukraine. It didn&rsquo;t take long for fossil fuel interests in the United States to exploit this geopolitical and humanitarian crisis for their own benefit, using the war to call for increased fracking, fast-tracked permitting, new subsidies, and relaxed environmental regulations here in America.</p>

<p>Unfortunately, the industry didn&rsquo;t stop there. Nearly every day, there are&nbsp;news articles, social media content and opinion pieces from industry boosters who spread false narratives, myths and other fallacies, all in an effort to further pad the pockets of corporate polluters.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This is a running list of some of the most egregious bad-faith arguments being put forth by the fossil fuel industry and their legislative champions in media outlets, accompanied by fact-checking of those arguments. Please continue to check back frequently, as we will add to this list as we come across new content.&nbsp;</p>

<hr />
<p><u><strong>Myth</strong></u>: In a recent Op Ed piece, state Sen. Camera Bartolotta made <a href=""https://observer-reporter.com/opinion/op-eds/op-ed-time-to-wake-up-to-consequences-of-energy-reliance/article_1133b352-9e2e-11ec-b123-1b698af81a81.html?utm_medium=social&amp;utm_source=twitter&amp;utm_campaign=user-share"">many false and disingenuous statements</a> about Pennsylvania&rsquo;s role in combating Russian aggression. Notably, Bartolotta said Gov. Tom Wolf &ldquo;banned natural gas development in the eastern third of the state&rdquo; and &ldquo;banned development of the state&rsquo;s own natural gas rights underlying publicly owned property.&rdquo; Finally, the state senator bluntly said &ldquo;the U.S. needs Putin&rsquo;s oil.&rdquo;</p>

<p><u><strong>Fact:</strong></u> There is a lot to unpack here. First, the Delaware River Basin Commission - which is composed of Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey, Delaware, and a representative from the federal government - <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2021/02/25/delaware-river-basin-commission-votes-to-ban-fracking-in-the-watershed/"">voted to ban fracking</a> in Pennsylvania&rsquo;s portion of the basin last year. Gov. Wolf is but one of many voting members of the DRBC, and did not act unilaterally when the agency banned fracking in the basin.</p>

<p>Secondly, Gov. Wolf&nbsp;did not ban fracked gas development on public lands in Pennsylvania. He <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2015/01/29/gov-wolf-bans-new-drilling-in-state-parks-and-forests/"">placed a moratorium on new drilling</a>, which is a huge difference. Prior to that moratorium, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Department of Conservation and Natural Resources leased more than 250,000 acres of state forest lands in the Marcellus play, 65% of which hasn&rsquo;t been drilled (163,089 acres). The problem isn&#39;t availability of locations, it&rsquo;s the economics. The companies drill only when it makes economic sense, which it currently does not. Saying that Gov. Wolf &ldquo;banned&rdquo; drilling on our public lands is an outright lie.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Thirdly, the United States does not need Russian oil, as evidenced by President Biden&rsquo;s ban on Russian imports. Even before that ban, <a href=""https://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory/explainer-happen-us-banned-russian-oil-83314181"">roughly 8% of U.S. imports of oil and petroleum products</a> came from Russia - a modest amount by any measure.&nbsp;</p>

<hr />
<p><u><strong>Myth</strong></u><strong>:</strong>&nbsp;In <a href=""https://www.wnep.com/article/news/local/bradford-county/800-million-project-bradford-county-in-jeopardy-new-fortress-energy-group-liquefied-natural-gas-plant/523-ef8e3933-a8a8-4d51-a377-27199fb5fd0c"">a March 23 news story</a> concerning PennFuture and other groups <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-Environmental-Groups-Shut-Down-Construction-of-Proposed-Liquefied-Natural-Gas-Plant-in-Wyalusing-Township-Bradford-County"">shutting down a liquefied natural gas plant</a> in Bradford County, the president of the Marcellus Shale Coalition said &ldquo;the worldwide need for U.S. natural gas exports has never been more critical.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Fact:</strong></u> Europe, which is directly threatened by Putin&rsquo;s turn to war, has already come to the conclusion that an economy tethered to fossil fuels is highly unpredictable, costly, and dangerous&mdash;particularly when we factor in the <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/28/climate/climate-change-ipcc-report.html"">impacts of climate change.</a>&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s not like Europe is clamoring for our energy exports. Germany recently announced it is <a href=""https://www.reuters.com/business/sustainable-business/germany-aims-get-100-energy-renewable-sources-by-2035-2022-02-28/"">accelerating its timeline to achieve 100 percent renewable energy</a>. The European Union is <a href=""https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/02/23/russia-ukraine-eu-nordstream-strategy-energy/"">readying an initiative</a> to fast-track renewable energy projects and cut the continent&#39;s use of fossil fuels in half in eight years. And most EU countries are ahead of schedule in their renewable energy goals and are not slowing down. Clearly, fracked gas is not the answer.</p>

<hr />
<p><u><strong>Myth:</strong></u> In a March 8th <a href=""https://triblive.com/opinion/sen-gene-yaw-american-energy-key-to-undermining-putins-war/"">editorial in the Pittsburgh Tribune-Review</a>, Pennsylvania state Sen.&nbsp;Gene Yaw said that &ldquo;renewable energy accounts for less than one third of global energy supply and remains notoriously unreliable.&rdquo;</p>

<p><u><strong>Fact:</strong></u> This is wrong on two counts. First, renewable energy &ndash; which encompasses a huge range of sources, including wind, solar, and hydroelectric &ndash; is in fact equally reliable to other energy sources. No kind of power plant <a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/experts/rachel-fakhry/myth-247365-power-plant"">runs 24/7, 365 days a year</a>, and operating America&rsquo;s electric grid always involves managing variability of supply and demand at all times.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Second, it&rsquo;s contradictory for Yaw to claim renewables are unreliable when he&rsquo;s talking about a fossil fuel supply that has proven to be - you guessed it - highly unreliable when it&rsquo;s controlled by a despot like Vladimir Putin. Fossil fuels have always been controlled by whichever country or political entity sits atop them, which leads to a great deal of volatility and weaponization of these products. Nobody owns the sun and wind. They cannot be manipulated or controlled for political or other gain.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<hr />
<p><u><strong>Myth:</strong></u> In a letter <a href=""https://www.energy.senate.gov/services/files/6902686E-7AEC-47F8-8C38-5010A3A352D4"">sent to President Biden on March 2</a>, the Senate Natural Resources Committee claimed that President Biden is responsible for soaring gas prices because of his hostile attitude toward the oil and gas industry, including a moratorium on drilling on public lands.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Fact:</strong></u> President Biden is <a href=""https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/01/27/oil-gas-leasing-biden-climate/"">currently outpacing</a> his predecessor when it comes to issuing drilling permits on public lands. According to <a href=""https://biologicaldiversity.org/w/news/press-releases/new-data-biden-slays-trumps-first-year-drilling-permitting-by-34-2022-01-21/#:~:text=New%20Data%3A%20Biden's%20First%20Year,34%25%20%2D%20Center%20for%20Biological%20Diversity&amp;text=WASHINGTON%E2%80%94%20New%20federal%20data%20shows,first%2Dyear%20total%20of%202%2C658."">the Center for Biological Diversity</a>: &ldquo;the Biden administration approved 3,557 permits for oil and gas drilling on public lands in its first year, far outpacing the Trump administration&rsquo;s first-year total of 2,658.&rdquo; That&rsquo;s not to mention that oil and gas companies <a href=""https://news.bloomberglaw.com/environment-and-energy/oil-gas-industry-stockpiled-drilling-leases-before-biden-pause"">have thousands of leases on public lands</a> that are unused and inactive, which has nothing to do with President Biden, and everything to do with energy companies&rsquo; own business choices.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<hr />
<p><u><strong>Myth:</strong></u> In a recent Op Ed piece, U.S. Rep. Gus Bilirakis alleged that scaling up domestic oil and gas is <a href=""https://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/energy-environment/596804-the-real-way-to-support-ukraine-is-to-flip-the-switch"">as easy as &ldquo;flipping the switch.&rdquo;</a></p>

<p><u><strong>Fact:</strong></u> Domestic crude oil production in the U.S. is at <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=PET&amp;s=MCRFPUS1&amp;f=A"">historically high levels</a> with 2019, 2020, and 2021 exceeding production in all other years.&nbsp;Production of natural gas in 2021 also reached an <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/dnav/ng/ng_prod_sum_a_EPG0_FGW_mmcf_a.htm"">all-time high</a> both nationally and in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;Even if companies had the ability and desire to increase production&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/02/energy/us-oil-production/index.html"">it could take years before we see significant changes.</a> That&rsquo;s not likely given the fact investors <a href=""https://www.npr.org/2021/03/06/973649045/hold-that-drill-why-wall-street-wants-energy-companies-to-pump-less-oil-not-more"">are hesitant to pour more money</a> into companies that have underperformed in recent years.</p>

<hr />
<p><u><strong>Myth:</strong></u> Industry boosters are claiming that Pennsylvania is in a position to increase LNG production and exports to Europe, and say that <a href=""https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/energy/fracking-is-a-powerful-weapon-against-russia/2022/02/24/8bd49c56-95b5-11ec-bb31-74fc06c0a3a5_story.html"">&ldquo;fracking may be America&rsquo;s most powerful weapon against Russian aggression.&rdquo;</a></p>

<p><u><strong>Fact:</strong></u> Liquified Natural Gas&nbsp;exports reached peak levels in 2021 at just over 3.5 trillion cubic feet.&nbsp;Many European nations, including the United Kingdom, France, Netherlands, Turkey, Spain, Portugal, Lithuania, and Poland imported record high levels of American LNG. Because our infrastructure is already operating near capacity, meeting the demand in Europe required diverting production that would normally be sold into Asian markets. At this point, increasing exports to Europe will require major investments in infrastructure on both sides of the Atlantic.&nbsp;Accomplishing this will take years and cost, potentially, billions of dollars. Furthermore, this assumes that Europe is looking to buy, but in fact, they are responding to this crisis <a href=""https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-02-28/germany-brings-forward-goal-of-100-renewable-energy-to-2035"">by accelerating their plans to move to renewable energy.</a></p>

<hr />
<p><u><strong>Myth:</strong></u> In his &ldquo;End Russian Aggression Act,&rdquo; state Rep. Seth Grove <a href=""http://www.repgrove.com/News/26413/Latest-News/Grove-Calls-for-Increased-Distribution-of-Pennsylvania-Natural-Gas-to-Reduce-Reliance-on-Russia-"">has suggested that Pennsylvania&rsquo;s participation</a> in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) is somehow connected to or impacted by Russia&rsquo;s war and oil and gas exports.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Fact:</strong></u>&nbsp;Under the RGGI program, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s electric generators burning fossil fuels will pay market-based emission fees for each ton of carbon pollution they emit.&nbsp;The proceeds from this program will be invested in cost-effective programs to reduce energy consumption and air pollution.&nbsp;The net result will be to help diversify our generation mix and lower both our dependence on fossil fuels and our exposure to a fossil fuel market Putin and others can manipulate. Simply put, RGGI has absolutely nothing to do with Russia or its oil and gas exports.</p>

<hr />
<p><u><strong>Myth:</strong></u> In <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/10/climate/climate-oil-crisis-global.html?smtyp=cur&amp;smid=tw-nytclimate"">a March 10 article in the New York Times</a>, a fossil fuel executive&nbsp;acknowledges &ldquo;the need to tackle climate change,&rdquo; but said &ldquo;that effort should take a back seat to the more urgent need to increase fossil fuel production.&rdquo;</p>

<p><u><strong>Fact:</strong></u><strong>&nbsp;</strong>Action on climate change has been taking a back seat for decades, and this current moment is definitely not the time to backslide any further. The science backs up that claim:&nbsp;many of the impacts of global warming are now simply &quot;irreversible,&quot; <a href=""https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-60525591"">according to the UN&#39;s latest assessment</a>, and humans and nature are being pushed beyond their abilities to adapt. It&rsquo;s already well past time for humanity to break its addiction to fossil fuels, and the industry will always be looking for ways to stay relevant in a world that is increasingly climate-conscious.&nbsp;</p>

<hr />
<p><strong><u>Myth:</u>&nbsp;</strong>Weakening environmental protections will allow us to increase production and become independent of foreign oil.</p>

<p><u><strong>Fact:</strong></u> The US is already operating very near its all-time peak level of crude oil production, with over <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&amp;s=mcrfpus1&amp;f=a"">4 billion barrels produced last year</a>.&nbsp;In spite of this near-record production, the US still imported more than 3 billion barrels of oil in 2021 with more than <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/pet_move_impcus_a2_nus_ep00_im0_mbbl_a.htm"">245 million barrels coming from Russia.&nbsp;&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>Pennsylvania is also operating near its peak levels of oil production, but that represents a fraction of a percent of the national total <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&amp;s=mcrfppa1&amp;f=a"">with less than 7 million barrels produced in 2021</a>. The true path to energy independence lies in strengthening and securing our grid and reducing reliance on oil in the first place, not in rolling back the environmental protections that let us breathe, drink clean water, and enjoy the natural resources of our incredible state and country.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations; Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
"This year, Pennsylvania must properly fund efforts to clean up our waterways",3/22/2022,"<p>On Feb. 8, Gov. Tom Wolf delivered his eighth and final budget address in which he spelled out the top priorities and programs that need to be funded in the coming fiscal year. The speech marks the official kickoff of a budget process that will culminate with a new state spending plan by the end of June.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It is absolutely imperative that this new budget includes the necessary funding needed to get Pennsylvania closer to our clean water goals, both here at home and in the Chesapeake Bay. Wolf&rsquo;s speech, after all, came only a few weeks after a new report that shows at least one-third of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s waterways are so impaired and polluted that they are unsafe for wildlife, recreation and drinking water. Locally, over half of York County&rsquo;s waterways are impaired.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Simply put, our dirty water problem is getting worse in Pennsylvania, not better, and elected officials in Harrisburg have shown little appetite to properly fund the programs and initiatives that are needed to clean our waterways.</p>

<p>We can&rsquo;t continue to lose ground in the ongoing fight for clean water. That&rsquo;s why PennFuture <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/cleanwaterpetition/index.html?fbclid=IwAR33vmbJNrwO1i8CZYpdfHb-Lulev3e4IZ0NqCCwe4VqZivpwk84-AJxi5g"">started a new petition calling on our elected officials to take seriously</a> their duty and responsibility to bring about clean water, both for current and future generations of Pennsylvanians. The time is now for lawmakers to hear our concerns and to finally understand that properly funding clean water initiatives isn&rsquo;t just the right thing to do, it&rsquo;s the smart thing to do right now and for the future.</p>

<p>We all benefit from clean water in our waterways. The issue of polluted water in Pennsylvania is significant. But that doesn&rsquo;t mean it&rsquo;s insurmountable.</p>

<p>In 2010, Pennsylvania, along with five other states and the District of Columbia, voluntarily entered an agreement to clean up local waters and the Chesapeake Bay by the end of 2025. This commitment was reaffirmed in 2014 when the parties signed another agreement upholding their intent to meet the goals on time.&nbsp;</p>

<p>What does that mean for Pennsylvania? In the Susquehanna and Potomac River watersheds alone, which account for roughly half of the state, the funding gap to clean up our polluted creeks and rivers will cost additional $325 million annually from what is already being spent.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Excess nutrients and sediment pollute our streams here in Pennsylvania and ultimately flow down to the Chesapeake Bay where they have a detrimental impact on aquatic life, including oysters and blue crabs. In Pennsylvania&rsquo;s portion of the watershed, 15,000 miles of streams are polluted. In York County, there are 868 miles of polluted streams, roughly the same number of miles it would take to reach Daytona Beach, Florida. Key sources of this water pollution are runoff coming from farms, cities, and towns.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania has a long way to go to meet its goals. Since entering this agreement, the state has severely lagged behind in making progress, so much so that two lawsuits were filed in 2020 against the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s failures, including one by the states of Maryland, Virginia, Delaware, and the District of Columbia.&nbsp;</p>

<p>There is hope. The state just released an updated plan on how it will meet its goals by 2025. Almost every county in the watershed has a plan developed locally by community leaders and members. There are thirty County Action Plans that identify what needs to be done and the resources needed to accomplish the local goals. The estimated annual cost in York County is $26 million.It&#39;s now up to the General Assembly to do their part. Despite forward momentum to improve local waterways, time and time again our legislators fail to fully invest in our water resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This year our elected officials are out of excuses to kick the can further down the road. The state&rsquo;s coffers are projected to have over $1.6 billion in surplus plus a large infusion of billions of dollars from the federal government through the American Rescue Plan and the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, both passed last year by Congress.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The clock is ticking. There are less than four years remaining for Pennsylvania to meet its goals. In a recent letter to Pennsylvania, the EPA was clear that it is willing to take action if the state does not meet the federal government and increase funding.</p>

<p>We know that Pennsylvanians value their constitutional right to clean water and a healthy environment. Poll after poll demonstrates wide, bipartisan support for increases in state investments for clean water.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our elected officials need to hear from you. That is why we are calling on Pennsylvanians to show lawmakers you care about clean water funding.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Renee Reber, Campaign Manager, Watershed Advocacy"
"Russia-Ukraine Crisis: War, Fossil Fuels, and What it Means for Pennsylvanians",3/1/2022,"<p>Russia&rsquo;s war with Ukraine is underlining the economic and national security costs of relying on fossil fuels. Global reliance on limited, place-based fossil fuel resources, such as Russia&rsquo;s gas reserves, has become a tool of authoritarian leaders, like Russian President Vladimir Putin, to exert their global influence, regardless of its human and economic costs. How the world&mdash;including states like Pennsylvania&mdash;reacts to this global security crisis may dictate our energy future for years to come.</p>

<p>Russia bases its leverage on the world stage on its fossil fuel production and Western reliance on their supply, and is using this leverage to engage in military operations in Ukraine. The European Union <a href=""https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/cache/infographs/energy/bloc-2c.html"">relies on Russia for around 40 percent</a> of its fossil fuel supply. Global recourse against Russian aggression in Ukraine, such as military action or economic sanctions, could result in immediate energy consequences in Europe, potentially by Russia limiting supply, as well as global implications because fossil fuel prices will be (and already are) skyrocketing.</p>

<p>The sanctions recently announced by President Biden and other world leaders will begin testing Russia&rsquo;s fossil fuel leverage over the world. For its part, the United States has temporarily worked behind the scenes to ameliorate these energy concerns in the short-term by working with partner countries to increase liquefied natural gas (LNG) exports to the European Union. In fact, the United States is now the largest exporter of LNG to the European Union. As a result, Germany, Russia&rsquo;s largest trading partner in Europe, was comfortable <a href=""https://www.cnbc.com/2022/02/22/germany-halts-certification-of-nord-stream-2-amid-russia-ukraine-crisis.html"">halting operation of the massive Nord Stream 2 fracked gas pipeline project</a>, an $11 billion pipeline designed to double the amount of gas flowing from Russia to Germany. However, as Russia&rsquo;s war with Ukraine continues, prices will continue to rise worldwide and our energy security problems will only deepen.</p>

<p>In response to Russia&rsquo;s war and western economic sanctions, what happens next will be telling. Russia may respond to harsher sanctions by suspending sales of fracked gas to the West. <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/14/business/oil-markets-prices.html"">Outside of Europe</a>, Russia produces 10 percent of the world&rsquo;s supply, and 3 percent of the US&rsquo;s daily consumption of fracked gas. U.S. consumers have already begun feeling the effects of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, with nationwide gas prices <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/14/business/oil-markets-prices.html"">rising 20 cents on average</a> in the last month alone. <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2022/02/18/Pittsburgh-gasoline-price-rise-Russia-Ukraine-international-oil-markets-risk-premium-natural-gas/stories/202202170126"">In Pennsylvania</a>, as well, consumers have been facing rising prices due in part to the crisis.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We are also starting to see the fossil fuel industry <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/23/business/economy/russia-ukraine-energy-security-climate-change.html"">try and take advantage</a> of this global crisis. Gene Barr, President of the Pennsylvania Chamber of Commerce, is calling for <a href=""https://triblive.com/opinion/gene-barr-its-time-us-energy-policy-stops-empowering-russia/"">state and federal policy changes</a> to allow for building more pipelines and export facilities&mdash;going so far as calling out advocates as well as environmental and safety regulations as being the equivalent of &ldquo;enriching Russia.&rdquo; Three Pennsylvania State Senators <a href=""https://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2022/02/24/pennsylvania-lawmakers-urge-restart-construction-keystone-xl-pipeline/"">are advancing a resolution</a> calling on President Biden to restart the Keystone XL Pipeline&mdash;a pipeline that was canceled in 2020, which would have increased the capacity of transporting tar sands crude oil from Alberta, Canada, into the United States. And State Representative Seth Grove <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/legis/CSM/showMemoPublic.cfm?chamber=H&amp;SPick=20210&amp;cosponId=36931"">is proposing</a> the End Russian Aggression Act to de-regulate fracking, expedite pipeline permits, provide new subsidies for pipeline construction, and end Pennsylvania&rsquo;s alignment with the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative.</p>

<p>In Pennsylvania, the recent completion of the Mariner East 2 pipeline to the Marcus Hook refinery and export facilities is now poised to increase LNG exports to Europe from the frack fields in Pennsylvania, creating an opportunity for the fossil fuel industry to argue for state policies that allow for more drilling with efforts to counter Russian aggressions.</p>

<p>The United States&mdash;and Pennsylvania&mdash;has a long-term choice to make. We could follow the playbook of the fracked gas industry, Rep. Grove, and other policymakers and drill, baby, drill to potentially send more LNG to market for overseas export (not for national markets) and raise energy prices further because of increased competition abroad. Or it could chart another path that doesn&rsquo;t rely on drilling, pipelines, and the whims of global energy markets by pushing for renewable energy sources.</p>

<p>The pro-climate change policies enacted at the state and federal level in recent months cannot be thrown off-course by fracking enthusiasts that are singularly driven by their profit margin. We certainly believe doubling down on the long-term reliance on fossil fuels in Pennsylvania in reaction to a global energy crisis caused by the Russian government cannot be further from the solution or the truth. Our energy policies must continue to have long-term, future generations in mind.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Furthermore, reliance on fossil fuels is not energy independence. In fact, we&rsquo;re not the only ones that think so&mdash;the European Union is paving a far different path forward than drill, baby, drill <a href=""https://www.eenews.net/articles/will-russia-spur-or-deter-europes-shift-to-green-energy/"">by hitting the gas pedal</a> on renewable energy.</p>

<p>The crisis in Ukraine has forced Germany, and the European Union as a whole, to reevaluate their complex relationship with the Kremlin and the dirty energy the EU consumes from them. The EU <a href=""https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/02/23/russia-ukraine-eu-nordstream-strategy-energy/"">plans to unveil an initiative</a> in the next week that would fast-track the permitting process for renewable energy projects. European policymakers acknowledge they would be in a better spot if they had started more concerted work on building robust energy independence years ago, but they say that in some ways skeptics have needed this crisis to be kicked into action. In December, Germany approved $68 billion to accelerate its climate and green infrastructure spending.</p>

<p>It is past time that the United States, and our Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Its-Past-Time-for-Pennsylvania-to-Invest-in-Renewable-Energy"">embraces a renewable energy future</a>. A renewable energy future, in addition to being great for American workers, jobs, and our climate, would prove to be a better investment of America&rsquo;s resources and national security and serve as a robust alternative to further reliance on authoritarian dirty energy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The world looks different today to many&mdash;the post-World War II global alignment is threatening to be shattered by Russia&rsquo;s aggressions in Ukraine. But for many still, the world has also looked different because of the global insecurity and economic threat that is climate change. An energy crisis caused by Russian military action and weaponizing fracking is not an anomalous event&mdash;it&rsquo;s the latest in a constant drumbeat of natural disasters, fossil fuel infrastructure crises, and geopolitical threats sparked by a reliance on fossil fuels.</p>

<p>The United States&mdash;and Pennsylvanians&mdash;have a choice: continue the energy policies of fossil fuels&mdash; those causing public health and natural disasters&mdash;or charter a renewable energy path that breaks us from this cycle once and for all.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The chorus of voices from the fossil fuel industry will only grow louder in the coming weeks, all seeking the same handouts and weakened regulations. We should reject this chorus and not double down on the policies that have exacerbated this crisis in the first place. Europe is publically wishing it moved faster toward renewables. We shouldn&rsquo;t make the same mistake.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"John Ukenye, Policy Analyst; Matthew Stepp, Vice President and Chief of Staff, PennFuture"
Philadelphia Will Not Meet Climate Goals Without a Reconstituted Philadelphia Gas Works,2/23/2022,"<p>The future of energy in Philadelphia took center stage in mid-February during Philadelphia City Council&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wLkEy4H-msY"">joint committee hearing on the Philadelphia Gas Works (PGW)</a> Business Diversification Study. Members of the Committees on Finance and Transportation and Public Utilities heard from city administration officials, PGW President and Chief Executive Officer Seth Shapiro, and advocates and stakeholders <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/media/20211207134817/PGW-Business-Diversification-Study-2021-12.pdf"">on the recommendations contained in the study</a> and how best to transition PGW away from its reliance on fracked gas.</p>

<p>Released in December 2021, the Diversification Study makes clear PGW&rsquo;s position as a gas utility and its desire to remain a gas utility. PGW has maintained that it believes gas will continue to play a central role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions in Philadelphia, as it did throughout the past two years while the study was ongoing. In fact, a straight line can be drawn from PGW&rsquo;s 2019 testimony during <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6rgxvRKWbMk"">an earlier City Council hearing on this topic</a> to much of the findings and recommendations in the Diversification Study.</p>

<p>The study&rsquo;s third recommendation calls for a local decarbonized gas program where PGW partners with other City departments to convert waste into biomethane or renewable natural gas (RNG). Despite <a href=""https://www.vice.com/en/article/qjbwwv/big-oil-has-a-plan-to-turn-appalachia-into-hydrogen-country"">big oil&rsquo;s big efforts</a> to ensure that RNG becomes the latest great hope to reduce carbon emissions while simultaneously continuing to promote an economy of extraction, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Renewable-Natural-Gas-Hope-or-Hype"">the future of RNG is more complicated</a>. As the study makes clear, RNG cannot play a significant role in reducing emissions in Philadelphia because it is more expensive to produce, does not contribute to air quality improvements, and it is limited in terms of commercialization or total availability. This recommendation should be shelved as RNG will not provide substantial aid in Philadelphia&rsquo;s climate pledges.</p>

<p>The study&rsquo;s second recommendation surrounding the use of geothermal energy carries the most promise. PennFuture strongly supports the pursuit of networked geothermal district systems to fully transition PGW from fracked gas. The conversation surrounding a potential geothermal energy future provided some of the most illuminating testimony during the joint hearing and could represent Philadelphia&rsquo;s best chance to significantly reduce PGW&rsquo;s emissions, provide protection for ratepayers from increasing costs as more households move away from fracked gas, and provide opportunities to PGW&rsquo;s workforce to maintain similar positions and even expand into new areas. But, we must move forward with all possible speed to complete any feasibility study and identify opportunities to quickly implement a pilot program.</p>

<p>Philadelphia will not achieve its climate pledges without a reimagined and reconstituted PGW. The joint hearing <a href=""https://www.audacy.com/kywnewsradio/news/local/philadelphia-gas-works-zero-carbon-goal-city-council"">further revealed PGW&rsquo;s ongoing reluctance</a> to do more than pay lip service <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/city-council-hears-options-for-decarbonizing-philadelphia-gas-works-divergent-visions-of-the-future-emerge/"">to this important conversation</a> while continuing to rely on oil and gas industry talking points. While PGW CEO Seth Shapiro does deserve some credit for stating his support for the idea of geothermal heat, this encouraging moment does not outweigh the balance of his testimony regarding the Diversification Study and PGW&rsquo;s role in supporting gas preemption legislation in Harrisburg.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Here are two points worth focusing on from Shapiro&rsquo;s testimony:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Shapiro stated that it is irrefutable &ldquo;that natural gas is perhaps the most significant tool in greenhouse gas reductions.&rdquo; <a href=""https://www.vox.com/energy-and-environment/2019/5/30/18643819/climate-change-natural-gas-middle-ground"">Wrong.</a> In fact, this statement is directly contradicted by the Diversification Study, which says: &ldquo;Reaching the City&rsquo;s climate goals requires Philadelphia homes and commercial buildings to transition from natural gas to alternative sources of heating.&rdquo;</li>
	<li>Shapiro pointed out that Pennsylvania currently produces a large portion of its electricity (40 percent) from fracked gas. While this may be accurate, it ignores <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PF_FossilFuel_Report_final_2.12.21.pdf"">the various ways that fracked gas is subsidized</a> in Pennsylvania and how far public officials are willing to go to further deepen our reliance on fossil fuels like fracked gas.</li>
</ul>

<p>The Pennsylvania General Assembly has consistently sought to change the rules of the free-market economy to advance the interests of the oil and gas industry. The joint committee hearing <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/emails-about-pgws-role-in-energy-choice-bill-pit-councilmember-gym-against-utilitys-ceo/"">raised the latest method that lawmakers are seeking</a> to advance in Harrisburg: gas preemption <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billinfo/billinfo.cfm?sYear=2021&amp;sInd=0&amp;body=S&amp;type=B&amp;bn=275"">through Senate Bill 275</a> and <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billinfo/billinfo.cfm?sYear=2021&amp;sInd=0&amp;body=H&amp;type=B&amp;bn=1947"">House Bill 1947</a>. These bills would ban municipalities across Pennsylvania from restricting or prohibiting utility services based on the types of energy they provide. It is being <a href=""https://www.vox.com/22691755/gas-utilities-fight-electrification-preemption"">pushed nationally by oil and gas industry groups</a> like the American Gas Association, which includes PGW as a member.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Why would state legislation be raised in a local government hearing on a seemingly unrelated topic? Because PGW <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/pgw-emails-show-involvement-in-drafting-bill-that-runs-counter-to-climate-goals/"">has worked to support and strengthen</a> this dangerous legislation. Shapiro raised several points under questioning from Councilmember Helen Gym that require attention:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Shapiro stated that PGW is very concerned with the &ldquo;catastrophic impact of limiting energy choice.&rdquo; To be clear, this legislation only seeks to limit real energy choice by changing the rules of the game to counter market forces that are seen as a threat to the fossil fuel industry.</li>
	<li>He maintained that PGW is neutral on the bill. It is not. Former PGW executive Gregory Stunder provided substantive feedback on the bill and provided additional language to strengthen definitions contained in the bill.</li>
	<li>He denied that PGW provided line edits to the legislation. <a href=""https://media4.giphy.com/media/UVkisudp4aRFWA2ReE/giphy.gif?cid=790b76114a6e02f7bea9bd155ef54c827aa4694292bf08fc&amp;rid=giphy.gif&amp;ct=g"">It did.</a></li>
	<li>He repeated several times that PGW staff are subject matter experts and are obligated to provide feedback on legislation. This is nothing more than an attempt to ignore the real issue at hand: PGW contradicted the city&rsquo;s own stance on this legislation and worked to undermine the city&rsquo;s ability to achieve its climate pledges.</li>
</ul>

<p>As Councilmember Gym pointed out to Shapiro, definitions matter. The feedback matters. Shapiro mentioned several times throughout this testimony that we must look at facts and repercussions even though he used half-truths, obfuscations, and fossil fuel industry falsehoods in his defense of PGW&rsquo;s involvement with gas preemption legislation and its defense of the continued reliance on fracked gas.&nbsp;</p>

<p>There is good news, though! Gas preemption legislation recently hit a roadblock in the General Assembly despite the best efforts of organizations like the American Gas Association.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The state House of Representatives passed HB 1947 but was not able to garner enough support to override a veto from Governor Tom Wolf. This was a critical vote because it demonstrated that oil and gas champions within the General Assembly will likely be unable to pass this unnecessary legislation through regular order.</p>

<p>This would not have been possible without the hard work and advocacy from those who took time to reach out to their state legislators and voice their opposition to gas preemption and the disastrous consequences it will have on Pennsylvanians across the Commonwealth.</p>

<p>There is more work to do, though, as the General Assembly will likely continue to seek out potential avenues to enact this legislation. As we saw most recently <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-The-Plastics-Problem-More-False-Strategies-Statewide-Preemption"">with preemption efforts</a> to prevent municipalities from banning single-use plastic bags, gas preemption legislation could make its way into a fiscal code bill during state budget negotiations. Our work continues to ensure that this legislation is not enacted because those who support the legislation remain determined.</p>

<p>The oil and gas industry will continue to use all the power at its disposal to delay or deny Pennsylvanians the opportunity to have energy that is both clean and affordable. Fossil fuel insiders will continue to argue that they can drill and refine our way out of the worst impacts from man-made climate change, but natural disasters generated <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/joewalsh/2022/01/10/us-natural-disasters-cost-145-billion-in-2021---3rd-costliest-year-on-record/?sh=288bcb5d4606"">approximately $145 billion in economic damage</a> throughout the United States in 2021. Pennsylvania suffered effects from the costliest natural disaster: Hurricane Ida.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We are consistently confronted <a href=""https://www.vox.com/22912760/natural-gas-methane-rename"">with the language of denial</a>, deflection, and delay. There is time to act, but we must do so with speed and clarity. It will require the kind of innovation that so many called for during the joint hearing on the Diversification Study. Continued reliance on fracked gas &ndash; or its derivatives &ndash; will not help us.</p>

<p>We cannot afford to continue operating as usual as the toll from climate change grows ever higher. These are the facts and the repercussions, and we must face them.&nbsp;</p>
