"During Press Conference, State Senators Openly Choose Profits Over Pennsylvanians, Our Environment",11/8/2021,"<p>They&rsquo;re getting nervous.&nbsp;</p>

<p>On October 20, 2021, State Senators Camera Bartolotta, Gene Yaw, and Independent John Yudichak held a press conference at the Main Capitol Rotunda filled to the brim with falsehoods wrapped in package of clearly unscripted and unplanned maunders about a &ldquo;radical energy agenda,&rdquo; &ldquo;radical environmentalists,&rdquo; &ldquo;socialists&rdquo; (as a pejorative), and other immature nicknames aimed to conjure a boogeyman-type image of their opponents. It is clear that these Senators see the writing on the wall: <a href=""https://cleanair.org/rggi-poll/"">60% of voters approve</a> of Pennsylvania&#39;s efforts to join the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI); <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2021/06/22/poll-shows-pennsylvanians-support-climate-action-amid-pandemic/"">by a 51-31 margin</a>, Pennsylvanians believe the state should &ldquo;pursue policies that prioritize the availability of renewable energy such as solar and wind&rdquo; over fossil fuels.</p>

<p>Instead of doing the right thing on behalf of their hard-working constituents, these Senators are aiming to pit urban and suburban workers against rural workers, all while doing the bidding of the big dirty energy industry who line their campaign coffers.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Debunking the New &ldquo;Rising Energy Bills&rdquo; Myth</u></p>

<p>A recently repeated talking point by these Senators revolves around rising energy prices, especially as we head towards the winter season and blaming the rise to &ldquo;environmentalists driving out fossil fuels.&rdquo; As with most of their points raised, this particular point is easily refuted with a simple Google search.&nbsp; <a href=""https://www.iea.org/commentaries/what-is-behind-soaring-energy-prices-and-what-happens-next"">According to the International Energy Agency (IEA)</a>, COVID-19 brought with it a historic plunge in global energy consumption which drove the prices of many fuels to their lowest levels in decades. As the pandemic&rsquo;s impact has declined, fuel prices have rebounded strongly, mainly as a result of an exceptionally rapid global economic recovery (this year is on track for the <a href=""https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2021/06/08/world-bank-global-economic-prospects-2021"">fastest post-recession growth in 80 years</a>), longer winter seasons in the Northern Hemisphere <a href=""https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-58425526"">due to increased climate change</a>, and a low supply due to the lockdowns earlier in the pandemic that have slowed down maintenance and necessary operational work.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As I have stated in previous posts, building new renewable energy <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2018/12/03/plunging-prices-mean-building-new-renewable-energy-is-cheaper-than-running-existing-coal/"">is cheaper than running existing coal plants</a> and prices get cheaper every year. By 2025, almost every existing coal plant in the United States <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2019/03/26/the-coal-cost-crossover-74-of-us-coal-plants-now-more-expensive-than-new-renewables-86-by-2025/#7f5abb5322d9"">will cost more to operate</a> than building replacement wind and solar within 35 miles of each plant. The (short term) <a href=""https://www.npr.org/2015/06/23/414926833/how-fracking-is-changing-the-nation-s-electrical-grid"">rise of the fracked gas industry</a> in Pennsylvania <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2018/jan/29/natural-gas-killed-coal-now-renewables-and-batteries-are-taking-over"">has accelerated the death of the coal industry</a>. As we are already seeing, the costs of both economically unsustainable sources of energy are being shouldered onto the consumer.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Debunking the &ldquo;RGGI Will Kill Jobs&rdquo; Myth</u></p>

<p>Senator Yaw got one thing right in this press conference: &ldquo;The environment and the economy are not mutually exclusive.&rdquo; Among RGGI&rsquo;s 11 current member states, RGGI <a href=""https://www.analysisgroup.com/globalassets/uploadedfiles/content/insights/publishing/analysis_group_rggi_report_april_2018.pdf"">has also created 45,000 jobs</a> across the region since the program&rsquo;s launch and <a href=""https://www.analysisgroup.com/globalassets/uploadedfiles/content/insights/publishing/analysis_group_rggi_report_april_2018.pdf"">added around $4 billion in economic value</a> to the region. Meanwhile, RGGI state economies <a href=""https://acadiacenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Acadia-Center_RGGI_10-Years-in-Review_2019-09-17.pdf"">have grown 31 percent faster</a> than non-RGGI states, even as the RGGI states have cut power plant carbon pollution nearly twice as fast as the rest of the nation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I have written <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-What-You-Wont-Hear-During-the-Aug-17-Public-Hearing-on-Pipelines-in-Pennsylvania"">not once</a>, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Its-Past-Time-for-Pennsylvania-to-Invest-in-Renewable-Energy"">but twice</a> since August of this year about the rise of alternative energy jobs in the U.S., including the ever-increasing competitiveness in terms of pay for workers in various green energy sectors. The renewable energy industry has become a major U.S. employer. E2&rsquo;s Clean Jobs America 2019 report found nearly 3.3 million Americans working in clean energy&mdash;<a href=""https://e2.org/reports/clean-jobs-america-2019/"">outnumbering fossil fuel workers by 3-to-1.</a> E2 reported <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2019/03/04/if-u-s-emissions-rose-in-2018-despite-clean-energy-growth-how-can-we-meet-climate-goals/?sh=5c372bdc11d9"">the fastest-growing jobs across 12 states</a> were in renewable energy during 2018, and renewable energy <a href=""https://www.bls.gov/ooh/fastest-growing.htm"">is already the fastest-growing source</a> of new U.S. electricity generation, leading the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics to forecast America&rsquo;s two fastest-growing jobs through 2026 will be solar installer (105% growth) and wind technician (96% growth).</p>

<p>A recent study <a href=""https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/green/reports/2021/07/07/501280/clean-economy-revolution-will-unionized/"">published by the Sierra Club</a>, in partnership with the Political Economy Research Institute at the University of Massachusetts-Amherst, estimated that upgrading U.S. infrastructure, expanding renewable energy, and increasing energy efficiency could create 9.3 million jobs over the next 10 years.</p>

<p>Moreover, further supporting the unionization of alternative energy workers would be good for all workers across sectors and the overall U.S. economy. <a href=""https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/green/reports/2021/07/07/501280/clean-economy-revolution-will-unionized/"">Unionization raises total compensation</a>&mdash;both wages and benefits&mdash;of union workers by an average of about 28 percent, according to the Economic Policy Institute. Just as &ldquo;the environment and the economy are not mutually exclusive,&rdquo; unionized labor, the environment, and economic prosperity can co-exist in harmony.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Debunking the &ldquo;We Need Fossil Fuels to Create Everyday Products&rdquo; Myth</u></p>

<p>Senator Yaw often repeats the fallacy that fossil fuels are a necessary part of the creation of televisions, windmills, solar panels, our food production, and other everyday items like make-up. However, sustainable ways to manufacture everyday items <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/smm-electronics/basic-information-about-electronics-stewardship"">have been outlined for years</a>. The major issue facing further sustainable practices in electronics manufacturing has come from <a href=""https://www.vttresearch.com/en/news-and-ideas/five-ways-towards-sustainable-electronics"">a lack of investment</a> in research, development, and implementation of new biodegradable materials and energy-efficient and material-efficient manufacturing techniques This is something <a href=""https://www.sierraclub.org/trade/what-green-new-deal"">a Green New Deal </a>(which these Senators and others relentlessly attack as &ldquo;socialist&rdquo;) would solve.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Leaving their Own Behind</u></p>

<p>Rocky Mountain Institute (RMI) has not only detailed the benefits of renewable energy on the nation&rsquo;s economy, but they <a href=""https://rmi.org/renewables-offer-rural-america-the-economic-development-opportunity-of-a-generation/"">have repeatedly highlighted</a> how Appalachia, and Pennsylvania specifically, can stand the most to gain from a Clean Energy Economy. By 2030, US wind and solar is on track to generate more than $60 billion in annual revenue&mdash;on par with the three leading US agricultural commodities: corn ($58 billion), soy ($44 billion), and beef production ($70 billion). Analysis conducted for RMI&rsquo;s Seeds of Opportunity report indicates that the projected 600 GW of new wind and solar projects built between 2020 and 2030 <a href=""https://rmi.org/insight/seeds-of-opportunity/"">would generate $220 billion in direct, lifetime economic benefits</a>. This is a gamechanger for Rural America, of which much of Pennsylvania falls into.</p>

<p>These Senators spent the entire press conference adopting populist language while offering citizen-harming solutions and empty, fake promises. If these Senators really care about the worker, they would be actively working to secure their whole personhood -- promoting the proliferation of high-earning long term jobs, protecting their air, their water, and their land. It is past time they stop making excuses on behalf of a dirty energy past, and stand up for a clean, green Pennsylvania energy future.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"John Ukenye, Policy Analyst"
The Basics of Hydrogen,11/4/2021,"<p>Back in the 1970s and 1980s, the comedian Don Novello performed in character as Father Guido Sarducci.&nbsp;One of his famous bits was the Five Minute University where, in just five minutes, he would teach you everything the average college student remembers five years after graduation.&nbsp;For his Spanish class you would only learn the phrases &quot;&iquest;Como est&aacute; usted?&quot; and &ldquo;Muy bien&rdquo; figuring that you&rsquo;d probably forget the rest anyway. For economics, you would just learn &ldquo;supply and demand.&rdquo; <a href=""http://standupeconomist.com/"">Physics isn&rsquo;t as funny as economics</a>, but if that were included you&rsquo;d probably just need to remember &ldquo;conservation of energy.&rdquo;</p>

<p>If that is the only thing anyone remembers from their science classes, it would be enough to understand why many of us are skeptical about hydrogen &ldquo;solving&rdquo; the climate crisis.</p>

<p><u>The challenge with hydrogen</u></p>

<p>Most of the hydrogen we use industrially today is made from methane (CH4)&mdash;the major component in fracked gas.&nbsp;Often called &ldquo;gray hydrogen&rdquo; this, not surprisingly, has significant environmental problems.&nbsp;Aside from all the energy used and pollution released in drilling and fracking for the methane, extracting the hydrogen creates carbon pollution as a waste product.&nbsp;Although people claim that carbon capture could reduce these emissions, that presents huge technical problems.&nbsp;Also, it should be clear that carbon capture is only going to make the resulting gas more expensive.</p>

<p>There is a cleaner alternative, known as &ldquo;green hydrogen,&rdquo; that is mostly produced by electrolysis&mdash;running electricity through water to split the H20 molecule into hydrogen and oxygen.&nbsp;Unlike gray hydrogen, if the electricity is obtained from a clean renewable source there are no dangerous emissions.&nbsp;The chemical formula for the process looks like this:&nbsp;</p>

<p><em>2H20 + energy &rarr; 2H2 + O2&nbsp;</em></p>

<p>To get useful energy out of the resulting hydrogen fuel, we generally need to burn it.&nbsp;What we call &ldquo;burning&rdquo; is just something reacting quickly with oxygen and releasing a lot of heat. In the case of Hydrogen, that is <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RudCaJB_Xx4"">a very energetic reaction</a> and the chemical formula should look very familiar.&nbsp;It&rsquo;s the opposite of electrolysis:</p>

<p><em>2H2 + O2 &rarr; 2H20 + energy</em></p>

<p>Conservation of energy tells us that the energy that comes out of that chemical reaction must come from somewhere.&nbsp;It did&mdash;it&rsquo;s the energy we had to add to split water into hydrogen and oxygen in the first place.&nbsp;It shouldn&rsquo;t be a surprise that we can&#39;t get more energy out of the reaction than we put in.&nbsp;&nbsp;As the Nobel prize winning <a href=""https://openlibrary.org/books/OL7246691M/Treatise_on_thermodynamics."">physicist Max Planck once wrote</a>, &ldquo;It is in no way possible, either by mechanical, thermal, chemical, or other devices, to obtain perpetual motion, i.e. it is impossible to construct an engine which will work in a cycle and produce continuous work, or kinetic energy, from nothing.&rdquo;</p>

<p><u>We need action, not delay</u></p>

<p>This doesn&rsquo;t mean green hydrogen is useless&mdash;we just need to think of it more like a battery than a fuel, and this has some implications for our policy planning. We also need to be skeptical about some of the messaging we hear about hydrogen&mdash;particularly the claim that we are just using fracked gas or dirty hydrogen now, but sometime in the future when technology improves we will move to cleaner green hydrogen.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>It should be obvious that if we can use clean energy directly, it doesn&#39;t make sense to turn it into green hydrogen first, and that isn&rsquo;t going to make sense in the future either.&nbsp;Planning to use fracked gas or dirty hydrogen on projects that we can electrify&mdash;even if we claim we are only doing it &ldquo;for now&rdquo;&mdash;just makes things worse.</p>

<p>It should also be obvious that doing essentially nothing while hoping a miracle technology will be developed that will fix the problem for us is irresponsible, unethical, and bad policy.&nbsp;Unfortunately, this is exactly the approach the fossil fuel industry is pushing to protect their profits for a few more years.&nbsp;It would be great if some new technology comes along to make decarbonization easier and cheaper, but after decades of inaction, we&rsquo;ve already wasted more time waiting and hoping than we had to spare.&nbsp;We have the tools and the technology to make significant progress in the fight against climate change right now&mdash;we just need the will to act.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Potential uses for hydrogen by sector</u></p>

<p>If we are going to reduce carbon pollution, we need to pay attention to where those emissions are coming from in the first place.&nbsp;Then, we can think about the role a green hydrogen &ldquo;battery&rdquo; might play in reducing those emissions.&nbsp;The chart below shows emissions reported by the DEP in their <a href=""http://www.depgreenport.state.pa.us/elibrary/GetDocument?docId=3925177&amp;DocName=2021%20PENNSYLVANIA%20CLIMATE%20ACTION%20PLAN.PDF%20%20%3cspan%20style%3D%22color:green%3b%22%3e%3c/span%3e%20%3cspan%20style%3D%22color:blue%3b%22%3e%28NEW%29%3c/span%3e%209/21/2023"">2021 Climate Action Plan</a> broken down into sectors.</p>

<p>It shouldn&rsquo;t surprise anyone that hydrogen projects have been proposed in all of these areas, but if we are going to prioritize resources and effort, we need to consider more than whether a particular use is technically possible.&nbsp;Ideally we want strategies that are economical compared to other zero-carbon alternatives and can scale sufficiently to make a significant difference.</p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-1eac4fc5-7fff-3417-5b0a-ae153c9d93ef""><a href=""http://www.depgreenport.state.pa.us/elibrary/GetDocument?docId=3925177&amp;DocName=2021%20PENNSYLVANIA%20CLIMATE%20ACTION%20PLAN.PDF%20%20%3cspan%20style%3D%22color:green%3b%22%3e%3c/span%3e%20%3cspan%20style%3D%22color:blue%3b%22%3e%28NEW%29%3c/span%3e%209/21/2023"" style=""text-decoration-line: none;""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(17, 85, 204); font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""><span style=""border:none;display:inline-block;overflow:hidden;width:624px;height:357px;""><img height=""357"" src=""https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/eIjhyuB9Sl9auxBXG_fKYhxVE4n9zKmIxXKCi-_yamtEQWX7MCSrJN959CsX2GuVllFWnLcSAerg-K_A8on8XR1HO_NCRbfIk0lNK8Ku4TE_v3nsVvFHNhNaqewHcAPlxDeGwiXs"" style=""margin-left:0px;margin-top:0px;"" width=""624"" /></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>The maxim that, if we can use clean energy directly, it doesn&#39;t make sense to turn it into hydrogen rules out a lot of uses in the electric generation sector.&nbsp;Hydrogen generation may come in handy getting electricity to locations where we can&rsquo;t run powerlines, and it may become an effective way to store surplus clean generation for when we need it, but it&rsquo;s not going to lessen the need for significantly more clean generation on our grid.</p>

<p>The residential sector isn&rsquo;t likely to be a key hydrogen market either.&nbsp;While it&rsquo;s technically possible to use hydrogen instead of gas for heating, cooking, and other applications, it&rsquo;s simpler and cheaper to electrify. Because hydrogen is a very tiny and light molecule it leaks at any opportunity, it&rsquo;s also incompatible with a lot of existing infrastructure. Large scale use of hydrogen would require we either retrofit or build out entirely new distribution networks both under our city streets and in many thousands of existing homes. That would be prohibitively expensive.</p>

<p>Transportation has more potential, although probably not for most light duty cars and trucks.&nbsp;Transportation always presents a chicken-and-egg problem where no one wants to buy a car without convenient refueling/recharging infrastructure and no one wants to invest in the infrastructure unless there are the cars around to use it.&nbsp;This is one of the reasons why natural gas vehicles, despite years of design and production, are rarely seen outside of centrally-fueled fleets.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Hydrogen vehicles, particularly fuel-cell electric vehicles (FCEVs), have some distinct advantages over battery electric vehicles (BEVs) in terms of weight, range, and recharging times, so it&rsquo;s possible they could gain a foothold in the market.&nbsp;BEVs on the other hand are generally cheaper to operate, they can take advantage of a lot of existing infrastructure, and for many of us they are good enough in terms of range and other factors.&nbsp;Given their cost effectiveness and head start in the market, it seems likely BEVs will continue to oupace FCEVs, at least in the near term.</p>

<p>Outside of light duty vehicles, the case for hydrogen is stronger.&nbsp;Commercial applications that have centrally-fueled fleets and need rapid turn-around after refueling, such as transit vehicles and some trucking are promising areas for hydrogen.&nbsp;Also, while battery operated aircraft exist they are very limited in endurance and hydrogen might prove useful there too if the weight of storage tanks can be kept low enough.&nbsp;Similar applications may exist in the shipping and rail industries as well.&nbsp;To be sure, cutting all of these emissions are important, but cars and light trucks are the largest contributors to transportation emissions.</p>

<p>The commercial and industrial sectors also have significant potential.&nbsp;Most sources cite industries like cement making, steel manufacturing, and ammonia production as areas where hydrogen should be considered.&nbsp;There are likely many other applications as well but, while we shouldn&rsquo;t discount where hydrogen can be used to decarbonize commercial applications, we don&rsquo;t want to over-sell hydrogen as a solution either.</p>

<p>Like in transportation, generation, and other sectors hydrogen is most likely to be used in specific industrial applications that can&rsquo;t be plugged into the grid or, for some other reason, can&rsquo;t be readily electrified.&nbsp;While there could be thousands of different processes in the industrial sector that fit this bill, any one technology might only apply to a small handful of facilities. The big players like steel, cement, and ammonia may be on everyone&rsquo;s radar, but to really decarbonize the industry we are going need to dig a lot deeper.</p>

<p><u>How we move forward</u></p>

<p>Step number one is to stop making the problem worse.&nbsp;This means not subsidizing fossil fuels and new petrochemical projects&mdash;even if the backers promise that someday the fracked gas will be replaced by hydrogen.&nbsp;Every ton of carbon pollution we add is a ton we&rsquo;re going to need to remove later, and every piece of infrastructure we build is a potential stranded asset that tends to lock us into future fossil fuel use.</p>

<p>Step number two is to invest more in the technologies that are available today.&nbsp;This means building more wind and solar, adopting cost-effective energy efficiency measures, improving our grid and distribution network to support electrification, and replacing gas and diesel vehicles with EVs.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Step number three is where we invest some limited resources in basic research and development of new technology.&nbsp;This is not because we are counting on a panacea that will solve the crisis&mdash;although that would be welcome.&nbsp;Research will be needed to find solutions for the hundreds of small issues we are sure to encounter along the way.</p>

<p>Like many things, controlling emissions often follows something like an 80/20 rule where that last 20% on the way to net zero emissions is likely going to be the most difficult.&nbsp;New approaches such as producing hydrogen from algae, waste, or other methods may find a niche in these cases.&nbsp;Similarly, new ways to store and transport hydrogen such as using liquid organic hydrogen carriers or other methods may find a role in our energy economy.&nbsp;It&rsquo;s prudent to keep the research and development in these areas going, but the important part now is not to get so hung up on the &ldquo;20% problems&rdquo; that we stop trying to deal with the 80% of emissions we can control today.</p>

<p>The topic of hydrogen can seem heavy and hard to digest. To help explain the issue more clearly, PennFuture partnered with the Ohio River Valley Institute on Nov. 28 to present an educational webinar to Pennsylvania advocates and leaders. If you&rsquo;d like to watch a recording of this webinar, <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LmNZveWOSCM&amp;t=795s"">please click here.&nbsp;</a></p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
Connecting Pennsylvania with COP26,11/3/2021,"<p>The eyes of the world are turned to my adopted home away from home, Glasgow, now the beating heart of the planet for the next two weeks because of the United Nations Climate Change Conference, COP26.&nbsp;The imperative for bold action on climate has never been greater.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania needs a good outcome from COP26, for a lot of exquisitely good reasons, but we live in a state very much dominated by fossil fuels, for centuries, so it&rsquo;s getting more and more complicated to extract climate leadership from one body you&rsquo;d typically expect leadership from &ndash; our state elected officials.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Despite the science and the climate emergency and its links to the burning of coal, gas and oil, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s fossil fuels interests have shown no sign of letting up &ndash; keeping up a steady drumbeat of climate denialism, and maintaining a good flow of contributions to politicians. They have lots of help from friendly state elected officials, mostly anti-environmental Republicans with very loud voices and influence in Harrisburg.&nbsp;Together these chums have revived the stereotype&nbsp;of branding as extreme those environmentalists promoting the expansion of renewable energy.&nbsp;They&rsquo;ve framed our ideas as a radical agenda that will destroy the state&rsquo;s energy industry.&nbsp;They&rsquo;ve successfully championed billions in tax credits and subsidies that deepen the state&rsquo;s reliance on the sector at taxpayer expense.</p>

<p>The fossil fuel industry, and their friends in labor and government have doubled down on fracking, petrochemicals and plastics.&nbsp;They view Pennsylvania&rsquo;s energy industry through the singular lens of fossil fuels, ignoring the myriad other sources, including a growing renewables portfolio, that make up our energy industry. And they never talk about the fact that the greener energy sector employs more people here than does the dirty energy sector.</p>

<p>Here&rsquo;s the current state of affairs in that sector according to this most recent (Oct. 21, 2021) Energy Profile offered by the US Energy Information Administration (the emphases are mine):&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li><em>Pennsylvania&#39;s marketed natural gas production, primarily from the Marcellus Shale, reached a <strong>record</strong> 7.1 trillion cubic feet in 2020, and the <strong>state is the nation&#39;s second-largest natural gas producer</strong> after Texas.</em></li>
	<li><em>Pennsylvania is the <strong>third-largest coal-producing</strong> state in the nation after Wyoming and West Virginia, and it is the <strong>second-largest coal exporter</strong> to foreign markets after West Virginia.</em></li>
	<li><em>In 2020, Pennsylvania ranked second in the nation after Illinois in electricity generation from nuclear power. However, natural gas generation surpassed nuclear generation in 2019 to provide the largest share of in-state electricity generation.</em></li>
	<li><em>Over half of Pennsylvania households use natural gas as their primary home heating fuel, and the state&#39;s <strong>49 underground gas storage sites--the most for any state</strong>--help meet regional heating demand in winter.</em></li>
	<li><em>Pennsylvania is the third-largest net supplier of total energy to other states, after Wyoming and Texas.</em></li>
</ul>

<p>Those are some impressive rankings for our state, and I can understand the appeal of ongoing economic exploitation of Pennsylvania&#39;s fossil fuels.&nbsp;But the toll has become too great on our communities that boom and bust, blossom and shrivel depending on market manipulations.&nbsp;And, these fuels harm our bodies, our air, our children and our water, and desecrate our land.</p>

<p>But, all is not lost. Pennsylvania voices are breaking through in climate leadership, and some voices have been around for a long time.&nbsp;These individuals have embraced life-long personal missions toward climate action:&nbsp;Former PennFuture CEO Larry Schweiger of western Pennsylvania, former PennFuture board chair Char Magaro of Enola, and former board member Dr. Jim Jones of Mechanicsburg.&nbsp;No other scientist has been able to slice through industry lies that muddle the utter seriousness of the emergency than Dr. Michael Mann, climatologist, geophysicist, and director of PennState&rsquo;s Earth System Science Center, and PennFuture Board member.&nbsp;PennFuture board member Steve McCarter founded the House Climate Caucus while a member of the State House Legislature.&nbsp;U.S. Congressman Brendan Boyle will travel to Glasgow as part of Speaker Nancy Peolsi&rsquo;s delegation.&nbsp;And Pittsburgh Mayor Bill Peduto has distinguished himself as an American climate leader standing up to Donald Trump and fossil fuel interests that targeted his city.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We are happy to report that several of these individuals will be joining us at noon on Tuesday, November 16 for a webinar to offer their reflections on COP26. This will be a chance for PennFuture&rsquo;s members to hear directly from those on the frontlines of climate action in Glasgow, and a chance for participants like Congressman Boyle and Mayor Peduto and others to offer their hopes and opinions on what comes next after COP26.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The stakes couldn&rsquo;t be higher at COP26. Here&rsquo;s to hoping leaders like Boyle and Peduto have a front-row seat at COP26 to real, meaningful, and ambitious climate action, and that our world finally starts to take seriously the enormous task of combating the climate crisis.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
"DRBC Proposed Regulations Ban Discharge of Fracking Wastewater, Discourages Fracking-Related Interbasin Water Transfers",11/2/2021,"<p>Earlier this year, the Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC) released final regulations <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fracking-Banned-in-Delaware-River-Basin"">that banned fracking in the watershed</a>, citing decades of scientific and technical studies, reports, and findings. This is a monumental step in the protection of our waters and health throughout the Delaware basin. Although litigation on DRBC&rsquo;s fracking ban <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Federal-Court-Dismissed-Lawsuit-Challenging-DRBCs-Ban-on-Fracking"">is ongoing</a>, PennFuture remains confident that these strong and necessary protections will withstand any legal challenge.&nbsp;</p>

<p>At the time the fracking ban was announced, the DRBC also rescinded its previous draft regulations regarding fracking wastewater and interbasin water transfers. In our <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Public-Comment-Closes-on-DRBC-Fracking-Regulations"">2018 comments</a> on the original draft regulations, PennFuture said that if these regulations couldn&rsquo;t be strengthened to ensure that the water resources of the basin would be protected, then DRBC has a duty to ban these activities within the watershed.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Well, it appears that the DRBC was listening as these new proposed regulations prohibit the discharge of fracking wastewater, including co-products and byproducts, within the Delaware River watershed, whether on land or directly into the water. This ban includes the use of fracked wastewater &ldquo;brine&rdquo; spreading on dirt and gravel roads.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This is critical for the health of the waters, wildlife, ecosystems, and humans since fracked wastewater contains thousands of chemicals, many of which we don&rsquo;t even know about and some that can be <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-New-Report-Details-the-Use-of-Forever-Chemicals-in-Fracking-Operations-Despite-Serious-Concerns-to-Public-Health"">harmful</a>, toxic, or even <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Toxic-Fracking-Waste-Becomes-Mounting-Problem-for-Downstream-Communities"">radioactive</a>. This is also especially important for the upper Delaware basin where approximately <a href=""https://ourpoconowaters.wordpress.com/"">80% of the commonwealth&rsquo;s Exceptional Value waters</a> and wetlands are located. A recent <a href=""http://www.paenvironmentdigest.com/newsletter/default.asp?NewsletterArticleID=53454&amp;SubjectID=58"">study by Penn State University</a> found that road spreading of oil and gas drilling wastewater is significantly less effective than commercial alternatives and increases the potential harm to aquatic systems, human health, and agriculture.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In addition, the new draft regulations continue the DRBC&rsquo;s position to &ldquo;discourage&rdquo; importation and exportation of waters to and from the basin (e.g., interbasin water transfers), and set out specific criteria that must be met in each case to be allowed by the DRBC.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture is still reviewing these draft regulations, but at first glance it appears that the DRBC is taking seriously its authority &ndash; and duty &ndash; to protect the Delaware watershed from the inherent harms of fracking. We will be submitting written comments and participating in the proposed public hearings on these proposed regulations, and we encourage all of you to do the same.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The DRBC is seeking comments on the effects the proposed rules may have within the Delaware River Basin on the following:</p>

<ul>
	<li>water availability;</li>
	<li>the control and abatement of water pollution;</li>
	<li>economic development;</li>
	<li>the conservation and protection of drinking water supplies;</li>
	<li>the conservation and protection of aquatic life;</li>
	<li>the conservation and protection of water quality in Special Protection Waters; and</li>
	<li>the protection, maintenance and improvement of water quantity and quality basinwide.</li>
</ul>

<p>The DRBC will also consider any other comments that concern the potential effects of the draft rules on the conservation, utilization, development, management and control of the water and related resources of the basin.</p>

<p>Written comments are due to the DRBC by 5:00pm on Friday, January 28, 2022, and must be submitted via the DRBC&rsquo;s online public comment collection system. More information and details on submission may be found <a href=""https://www.nj.gov/drbc/meetings/proposed/notice_import-export-rules.html"">at the DRBC&rsquo;s website.</a></p>

<p>Virtual public hearings will be held on the following Wednesdays in December:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>December 8, 2021, 2:30-4:30pm</li>
	<li>December 8, 2021, 6:30-8:30pm</li>
	<li>December 15, 2021, 1:00-3:00pm</li>
	<li>December 15, 2021, 4:00-6:00pm</li>
</ul>

<p>Please visit the DRBC&rsquo;s website for more information and to register to speak.&nbsp;</p>
