",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Planting Trees and Fighting for Funding in the Keystone State,10/29/2021,"<p>It might be the best way to clean our water. Planting trees along rivers and streams provides multiple benefits in the work to protect and restore our rivers and streams. Known as riparian buffers, they prevent pollution from entering waterways, stabilize stream banks, and provide critical habitat, shade, and food for critters. What&#39;s more, it&#39;s also one of the most cost-effective ways to improve water quality.</p>

<p>For all these reasons, PennFuture was thrilled to partner with the Choose Clean Water Coalition and&nbsp;the Alliance for the Chesapeake Bay&nbsp;to host its first on-the-ground restoration event. Gathering on a Plain Sect dairy farm in Lancaster County on October 13, a group of 20 volunteers planted approximately 600 trees as part of a two-acre buffer on a direct tributary to the Conestoga River.</p>

<p>Buffers like this are an important part of Pennsylvania&#39;s Phase 3 Watershed Implementation Plan (WIP) and are effective in both rural and suburban areas. According to the Phase 3 WIP, Pennsylvania has committed to plant more than 85,000 acres of buffers at a cost of $28 million annually. This would greatly improve local water quality by preventing 16 percent of nitrogen and 41 percent of phosphorous pollution from reaching our waterways. According to the 2021 numeric milestones, Pennsylvania has planted only 42 percent of its forest buffer goal.</p>

<p>But buffers are just one of many practices Pennsylvania has agreed to implement by 2025. Other necessary projects, such as manure storage, are much more expensive. Fortunately, in the Pennsylvania General Assembly there are two proposed pieces of legislation with broad bipartisan support that would invest a combined $750 million dollars of the American Rescue Plan Act funding in clean water programs.</p>

<p><u><strong>Growing Greener III</strong></u></p>

<p>First passed in 1999 with bipartisan support, Growing Greener continues to receive overwhelming public support today. In 2020, a poll commissioned by Conservation Voters of PA and the Growing Greener Coalition showed that nearly 90 percent of voters support funding for Pennsylvania&#39;s land, water, and wildlife, even during the economic downturn of the COVID-19 pandemic. Growing Greener funding provides critical support to community-driven work in our communities through grant programs at the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, the Department of Environmental Protection, and the PA Department of Agriculture. A boost of $500 million, as proposed in Senate Bill 525, from American Rescue Plan funding is much needed for this program.</p>

<p><u><strong>Clean Streams Fund</strong></u></p>

<p>But to reach its clean water goals, Pennsylvania must also invest state funds into clean water programs. A piece of legislation currently moving through the Pennsylvania state legislature would provide another source of crucial support to improve the Keystone State&#39;s waterways. The Clean Streams Fund (SB 832 and HB 1901) proposes $250 million in dedicated funding from the American Rescue Plan to create new clean water programs, including the Agricultural Conservation Assistance Program. This program would provide farmers funding to implement conservation practices on their land. Of Pennsylvania&#39;s 50,000+ farms, 98 percent of them are family-owned with an average net cash farm income of $42,020. With agriculture as the number one source of water pollution in Pennsylvania, the state must help farmers effectively steward their land by investing in conservation practices.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>A Worthwhile Investment&nbsp;</strong></u></p>

<p>The dairy farm where we planted the riparian buffer on October 13 is part of the Sustainable Dairy Pennsylvania project, a collaboration between The Hershey Company, Land O&#39; Lakes, and the Alliance for the Chesapeake Bay focused on supporting a more sustainable and climate-friendly dairy supply chain in Pennsylvania for Hershey&#39;s Milk Chocolate.&nbsp;But getting conservation practices on-the-ground isn&#39;t free. Using American Rescue Plan funding through the Growing Greener III and passing the Clean Streams Fund will provide much needed assistance to our farmers. As many farmers have shared with us, by planting buffers and implementing other conservation practices, they are doing their part to ensure clean water for now and future generations.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We look forward to getting our hands dirty again at another planting, but until then, we will keep up the fight to ensure all Pennsylvanian farmers have the necessary resources to effectively steward their land and leave a legacy of clean water.</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,"Renee Reber, Campaign Manager, Watershed Advocacy"
"Plastics Could Soon Overtake Coal as a Climate Killer, and Pennsylvania is Right in the Middle of It",10/26/2021,"<p>A report released on Oct. 21 by Beyond Plastics <a href=""https://www.beyondplastics.org/plastics-and-climate"">predicted dire consequences</a> as a result of our inability to stop consuming plastics. Specifically, the report&rsquo;s authors claim that the domestic plastics industry&rsquo;s contribution to climate change is on track to exceed that of coal-fired power in this country by 2030.</p>

<p>We&rsquo;ve known for years that our oceans and other water bodies <a href=""https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trash-removed-from-great-pacific-garbage-patch/"">are choked with unfathomable amounts of plastics pollution</a>, and that the process to create those plastics is dependent on fossil fuels, namely fracked gas. Even in an increasingly climate-conscious world, more than 300 million tons of plastic are produced each year,&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/stories/single-use-plastics-101"">half of which is consumed as single-use</a>&mdash;products used once and tossed away (i.e. plastic bags), often finding their way to sidewalks, waterways, and green spaces.</p>

<p>This isn&rsquo;t some far-away problem. The Keystone State is, after all, about to be home to the world&rsquo;s newest plastics factory once Shell Chemical&rsquo;s ethane cracker plant in Beaver County comes online sometime next year, a plant that is predicted to <a href=""https://www.reuters.com/article/shell-ethane-cracker-pennsylvania/shell-says-pennsylvania-ethane-cracker-about-70-complete-idUKL1N2H00V3"">churn out 1.6 million tons of plastic annually.</a> The plant won&rsquo;t just be responsible for introducing <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/oct/11/plastics-appalachia-next-cancer-alley-fracking-public-health-ethane"">massive amounts of single-use plastic into the world</a>, but it will also pump <a href=""https://www.environmentalhealthproject.org/blog/the-health-behind-plastics-cracker-plants"">more than 30 tons of hazardous air pollutants</a>, 323 tons of fine particles, and 522 tons of volatile organic compounds into our air each year.&nbsp;</p>

<p>According to the Beyond Plastics report, therein lies the problem: the U.S. plastics industry already emits at least 232 million tons of greenhouse gases annually, which is equal to the emissions of 116 average-sized coal-fired power plants. Those numbers will increase significantly in the coming years&mdash;Shell&rsquo;s ethane cracker plant is only one of five cracker projects under construction or in the planning phases in the United States.</p>

<p>In total, at least 42 plastics facilities have opened, are under construction, or are in the permitting phase since 2019. If all of them <a href=""https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5eda91260bbb7e7a4bf528d8/t/616ef29221985319611a64e0/1634661022294/REPORT_The_New-Coal_Plastics_and_Climate-Change_10-21-2021.pdf"">become fully operational</a>, they could cumulatively have the impact of 27 500-megawatt coal-fired power plants coming online by 2025.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The bottom line is that the petrochemical industry is slated to surpass coal in terms of climate-killing emissions by 2030 and Pennsylvania&rsquo;s dreams of becoming a petrochemical and plastics &ldquo;hub&rdquo; is part of the problem. We&rsquo;re building on our longer history of polluting and destructive industries&mdash;timber, oil, coal, and fracked gas&mdash;with plastics.</p>

<p>Massive ethane cracker facilities aren&rsquo;t the only culprits. The report specifically called out another sector of the plastics industry that Pennsylvanians should be familiar with: chemical recycling, sometimes referred to as &ldquo;advanced recycling,&rdquo; a complex process that involves turning plastic waste into fuel.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To be clear, despite the name, this is not true recycling of plastics in which plastics are turned into other plastics. Instead, it would take plastic waste, break it down to its chemical constituents, and burn it as a source of fuel (with associated air quality emissions).&nbsp;</p>

<p>Though there are only a few chemical recycling facilities operational across the country, one is being proposed right here in Pennsylvania, in Erie. It&rsquo;s not currently clear what kinds of pollution could result from the Erie facility&mdash;all of the plastic sent to this facility will be turned into tiny flakes, half of which will be shipped or trucked to Canada and burned in steel mills. At this time, it is also unclear where the other half of the flaked plastic trash will go.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We do know, however, that it&rsquo;s estimated that the facility will require <a href=""https://www.eenews.net/articles/a-rust-belt-city-debates-a-growing-plastic-future/"">about 400 truckloads of plastic per day</a> to stay profitable. We also know that chemical recycling facilities in the United States are predicted to be responsible for releasing 18 million tons of greenhouse gases annually, equivalent to nine coal-fired power plants.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The report paints a very dim picture of our ongoing relationship with plastics, and though Pennsylvania plays a significant role in this crisis, work is underway to fight back.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture is one of several groups that&rsquo;s been <a href=""https://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/environmentalists-critical-of-natural-gas-storage-hub-in-southwest-pa-regional-plan/Content?oid=15288269"">working for years</a> to beat back attempts to turn Appalachia into a plastics hub. The Shell plant may be online soon, but other similar facilities planned for the region <a href=""https://businessjournaldaily.com/pttgc-delays-decision-on-belmont-cracker-plant/"">have been put on hold indefinitely</a> because of pushback from communities, and because of unfavorable market conditions as the world slowly becomes more climate-conscious.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Progress can be seen in other nearby states, too. People in the state of New York <a href=""https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/plastic-pollution-climate-change-1245402/"">once used 23 billion single-use plastic bags</a> annually, a number that is in steep decline because of a ban on plastic bags. PennFuture is supporting <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/phillys-plastic-bag-ban-is-finally-here-with-enforcement-still-to-come/"">a similar effort underway</a> in Philadelphia, and the hope is that the entire state could soon follow in banning plastic bags.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Finally, community members in Erie <a href=""https://www.eriereader.com/article/questions-surround-the-plasticity-of-our-city"">are questioning the viability</a> of the chemical recycling plant planned there, and many voices of civic society have fought&nbsp;back against <a href=""https://www.penncapital-star.com/energy-environment/report-pa-s-fossil-fuel-industry-received-3-7-billion-in-tax-breaks-in-2019/"">any new subsidies for plastics and fossil fuels.</a>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our world might be trending in the wrong direction in terms of our plastics addiction, but we&rsquo;re still fighting. If you want to fight alongside us, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">please consider becoming a member today.&nbsp;</a></p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
DEP Should Revoke Permits for Troubled Mariner East Pipeline,10/19/2021,"<p>On October 5, Pennsylvania Attorney General Josh Shapiro announced 48 criminal charges related to construction of the Mariner East pipeline project, including one felony count of failing to report pollution. Yes, you read correctly, a corporation is facing criminal charges for its behavior. So how did we get here, and what does that mean for Mariner East, its parent company Energy Transfer, and Pennsylvania? Read on.</p>

<p>Energy Transfer Partners, the Texas-based pipeline company building the Mariner East pipeline, has been plagued by a litany of problems. The pipeline project <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-The-Problem-with-Pipelines"">has been rife with issues for years</a>, and this most recent evidence has shown that despite the numerous fines and temporary shutdowns Energy Transfer has faced from the Department of Environmental Protection, these issues have continued unabated, reaching a level where the Pennsylvania Attorney General himself took notice.</p>

<p>After a years-long investigation, a grand jury released its findings. The report details the numerous serious environmental harms that took place at specific locations across Pennsylvania, including Raystown Lake, Loyalhanna Lake, and Marsh Creek Lake. Highlights <a href=""https://www.attorneygeneral.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/2021-10-05-Mariner-East-Presentment.pdf"">of the 64 page document include</a>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>In its rush to begin construction, &ldquo;Sunoco and its prime contractors hired HDD subcontractors from across the country who were unfamiliar with Pennsylvania geology and water features as well as the regulatory landscape that existed in the state. The subcontractors applied their standard practices to an unusual environment, which resulted in environmental impacts.&rdquo; And that &ldquo;In addition to the problematic geology, this former Sunoco employee indicated that the people hired to do the work were young and with limited actual experience. Leaks and spills of drilling fluid began to occur almost immediately.&rdquo;</li>
	<li>Elsewhere, in Indiana County, drilling was stopped after the DEP issued a Notice of Violation due to another spill. The day after work resumed, there was another spill, which was not reported. This exact story was replayed later in the report at a site in Cambria County: a large spill, contaminated wetlands, work stoppage after a DEP Notice, with the only result that &ldquo;the same thing happened again the next day.&rdquo;</li>
	<li>The scale of the leaks is difficult to wrap one&rsquo;s head around: these were not small and minor leaks of only a few gallons of toxic drilling fluid. At one site, near the William Penn Highway, a loss of 65,000 gallons of drilling fluid went unreported. Imagine nine yellow school buses lined up next to each other. This was not a small amount of water by any stretch, and it happened again and again.</li>
	<li>The report details testimony from a number of homeowners that Energy Transfer threatened to take their homes if they didn&rsquo;t give Energy Transfer the right to build the pipeline across their land, sometimes promising they wouldn&rsquo;t feel the effects of construction. Later, Energy Transfer threatened to take their houses when those whose water had been ruined tried to assert their rights.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>On top of leaking drilling fluid across the state, Energy Transfer used unapproved chemicals in that drilling fluid, meaning that not only did they leak chemicals into people&rsquo;s wells and lakes, they did not even have permission to use those chemicals in the first place.&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>All of these massive, systemic, and ongoing problems were carefully recorded by inspectors and geologists on site. These records were simply unreported to the DEP.</p>

<p>Further, and even more offensive, is that Energy Transfer straight-up lied to the DEP about the incidents: In an April 24, 2019 letter to DEP, Sunoco claimed that, due to inadvertent miscommunication, its management never learned of the losses of fluid. However, the evidence before the Grand Jury clearly indicated that this claim was &ldquo;false.&rdquo; In fact, a project manager for one drilling subcontractor told the Grand Jury that if something was not reported, it was not because people were not there to see it. Another Construction Manager testified that it was &ldquo;preposterous&rdquo; for someone to imply that Energy Transfer&rsquo;s environmental team was unaware. Despite the citizen complaints, the obvious spills, and its own records, Energy Transfer tried to claim they somehow went unaware.</p>

<p>As the infamous saying goes, &ldquo;Who&rsquo;re you gonna believe: me, or your own lying eyes?&rdquo;</p>

<p>The numerous, severe, repeated violations noted by the Grand Jury report&mdash;the details span over 50 pages&mdash;only encompass a mere 16% of the total number of horizontal drilling sites of the project. One wonders how long the Grand Jury report would be if even half of the sites were investigated.</p>

<p>So what does all this mean? First, we applaud the Attorney General for taking action against Energy Transfer, to try and bring some greater consequence to Energy Transfer, and to shine a brighter light onto their multitude of transgressions. It isn&rsquo;t often that corporations themselves are held accountable for their actions, and we believe this to be a good step in the right direction here. Ultimately, we need to strengthen the laws themselves so that when the Attorney General needs to prosecute, they have a stronger sword with which to do so.</p>

<p>Second, one of the other crucial takeaways from the Grand Jury Report is that the Department of Environmental Protection was entirely too under-resourced to be able to effectively administer and oversee the level of violations here. This shows something that matches our common sense: it isn&rsquo;t enough to simply pass regulations, but the agencies charged with carrying out laws and regulations must be provided with enough resources to effectively oversee them.&nbsp;</p>

<p>However, the Department of Environmental Protection can still take swift and decisive action here to prevent even more harm. A number of advocates have called for the DEP to terminate Energy Transfer&rsquo;s environmental permit, which allows them to do the work that is leaving a trail of environmental ruin and carnage in its wake.</p>

<p>The legal standard for the Department of Environmental Protection to terminate a permit is simple: When a permittee either has been shown to be in noncompliance with any condition of their permit, or the permittee misrepresents &ldquo;any relevant facts at any time,&rdquo; a permit can be terminated. How does this process start? That is also simple: either a person submits a written request that the permit be terminated, or information showing that there has been noncompliance is brought to the DEP&rsquo;s attention, and they can take action of their own accord. The DEP can then begin the process of terminating the permit. It is clear that this simple legal standard has been met.</p>

<p>The Department of Environmental Protection should terminate the permits associated with the Mariner East pipeline immediately.</p>

<p>So what can you do today? <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/marinereast2permits/index.html"">Write to your representatives</a>, and ask them to increase funding for long term oversight of environmental permits, and ask them what they are doing to make sure that Energy Transfer is not allowed to further poison the water and resources of hard working Pennsylvanians.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Emma Bast, Staff Attorney"
Pittsburgh Embraces Stormwater Fee,10/15/2021,,Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Adam Nagel, Campaign Manager"
It's Past Time for Pennsylvania to Invest in Renewable Energy,10/5/2021,"<p>On October 4, 2021, the Pennsylvania State Senate Environmental Resources &amp; Energy Committee and the Senate Community, Economic &amp; Recreational Development Committee held a joint-committee hearing titled &ldquo;Consumer &amp; Economic Impacts of Failing to Invest in PA&#39;s Natural Gas Infrastructure.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Instead of highlighting the billions in subsidies given to the fossil fuel industry over the past few decades, how it has led to the degradation of our shared environment, and the subsequent harmful effects on our health, the Majority Chairs quickly began dismissing these issues, pointing fingers at the &ldquo;radical environmental left,&rdquo; and scapegoating other countries.</p>

<p>Experts have stated repeatedly that merely pointing out that other, industrialized countries are also sources of high carbon pollution does not absolve the US of responsibility or somehow make any attempts by the US to reduce their carbon emissions meaningless. Also, many scapegoaters, including those leading the hearing yesterday afternoon, leave out key facts about these aforementioned countries.&nbsp;</p>

<p>China plans to increase their share of non-fossil fuel energy consumption <a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/experts/han-chen/trump-admin-scapegoats-china-india-satisfy-polluters"">to 20 percent by 2030</a>. China is already the world leader in new installations <a href=""http://www.cnbc.com/2017/02/13/china-and-us-lead-way-with-wind-power-installations-says-global-energy-report.html"">of wind</a> and <a href=""http://energydesk.greenpeace.org/2017/01/06/china-five-year-plan-energy-solar-record-2016/"">solar power</a>. India is increasing their share of non-fossil fuel energy consumption to 40 percent by 2030. India plans to add <a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/experts/sameer-kwatra/india-joins-paris-agreement-climate-change"">175 gigawatts of renewable energy</a> by 2022. Also, India plans to reduce emissions intensity 33 to 35 percent by 2030 based on 2005 levels. The US must do its part to reduce its carbon footprint because the average emissions for every American <a href=""http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/overview.php?v=CO2ts_pc1990-2015"">is eight times that of the average Indian citizen</a>. Similarly, the emissions per person in China <a href=""http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/overview.php?v=CO2ts_pc1990-2015"">is only half that</a>&nbsp;of the average American, and a bit more than residents of the EU. Overall, the average emissions per American <a href=""http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/overview.php?v=CO2ts_pc1990-2015"">are three times higher</a> than the global average.</p>

<p>However, as is the position of PennFuture, the burden to curb carbon emissions is not on the average individual, but on producers and polluters -- namely the fossil fuel industry.</p>

<p>In February 2021, PennFuture released the third edition of our <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Publications/PF_FossilFuel_Report_final_2.12.21.pdf"">Fossil Fuel Subsidy Report</a>. In this report, we uncovered that Pennsylvania provided $3.8 billion in fossil fuel subsidies in Fiscal Year 2019 by systematically disabling many of its standard tools for collecting tax revenues, allowing the industry to extract public resources at little to no charge, and awarding the industry grants and tax credits. Meanwhile, in the same time period, the industry imposed $11.1 billion worth external costs to the state and its residents. These facts alone plainly show the nonsensical nature of the premise of the hearing itself; it was a waste of taxpayer money that is better served being invested in our workers, our environment, and our future. It is more than clear to us that Pennsylvania&rsquo;s continued investment in the fracked gas industry is harmful to workers, businesses, and the general public.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We recognize the need to secure the livelihood of Pennsylvanians, especially in this volatile time as the country as a whole begins the long road of recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. However, we also recognize that this recovery period is a source of opportunity. Pennsylvania, as many other states and nations already have, can leap to the forefront of the new, clean energy economy and provide hundreds of thousands of high paying jobs in a diverse number of sectors for the people across this great Commonwealth.</p>

<p>A better path forward doesn&rsquo;t lie in some far-off future, it is already here, and it is time for our great Commonwealth to seize this opportunity through heavily and seriously investing in the New Clean Economy.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Transitioning to the New Clean Economy is Good for the Overall Economic Development in Pennsylvania</u></p>

<p>A major point made by the leaders of yesterday&rsquo;s hearing was how going after the fossil fuel industry would result in higher costs to the consumer and a loss of jobs for the workers in the industry. However, these leaders conveniently leave out, time and time again, that carbon-polluting jobs <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikescott/2020/06/05/pandemic-accelerates-decline-and-fall-of-fossil-fuel-producers/?sh=6689dc97f639"">have been on the decline</a> as the industry itself continues to give way to the new, clean energy economy. They also fail to mention how clean energy is, in many cases, cheaper to produce (and thus cheaper to the consumer) than fossil fuel-based energy. It would be in the best interests of labor unions and their workers alike to embrace the new economy, which offers <a href=""https://yaleclimateconnections.org/2021/09/how-much-do-energy-industry-jobs-pay-a-look-at-the-data/"">better job security</a>, increasing wages, and is overall beneficial to the environment and general public.</p>

<p>In a blog post from August <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-What-You-Wont-Hear-During-the-Aug-17-Public-Hearing-on-Pipelines-in-Pennsylvania"">about a similar hearing held in the State House</a>, I discussed how greener, more environmentally friendly energy alternatives are already proving to not only be both <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2020/01/21/renewable-energy-prices-hit-record-lows-how-can-utilities-benefit-from-unstoppable-solar-and-wind/?sh=5128549c2c84"">cost effective for producers and consumers</a>, but also offer <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimmagill/2020/10/26/oil-gas-vs-clean-energy-which-will-have-best-jobs-in-the-future/?sh=51d9704c5738"">higher-paying wages</a> for those in the green energy job sector. I pointed out how wind energy prices have fallen 70% and solar photovoltaics have fallen 89% on average, <a href=""https://www.lazard.com/perspective/lcoe2019"">according to a 2019 report</a>. Utility-scale renewable energy prices <a href=""https://energyinnovation.org/2018/01/22/renewable-energy-levelized-cost-of-energy-already-cheaper-than-fossil-fuels-and-prices-keep-plunging/"">are now significantly below</a> those for coal and gas generation.</p>

<p>Experts and analysts <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2020/06/09/plunging-renewable-energy-prices-mean-us-can-hit-90-clean-electricity-by-2035at-no-extra-cost/?sh=54f12a7d2f9b"">have claimed that</a>, with wind, solar, and storage prices <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2020/01/21/renewable-energy-prices-hit-record-lows-how-can-utilities-benefit-from-unstoppable-solar-and-wind/#7cbce6f2c84e"">falling at such a fast rate</a>, the United States can reach 90% clean electricity by 2035 without raising customer costs at all from today&rsquo;s levels, and actually decreasing wholesale power costs 10%. Jobs in solar and wind <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimmagill/2020/10/26/oil-gas-vs-clean-energy-which-will-have-best-jobs-in-the-future/?sh=51d9704c5738"">pay about 50 cents more</a>. Specifically, wind and solar electricians (HVAC technicians, mechanics, welders and assemblers) <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimmagill/2020/10/26/oil-gas-vs-clean-energy-which-will-have-best-jobs-in-the-future/?sh=51d9704c5738"">get paid $2.50 more than their counterparts</a> in the dirty energy space. Clean energy jobs are more likely to be union jobs than jobs across the economy as a whole &ndash; <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimmagill/2020/10/26/oil-gas-vs-clean-energy-which-will-have-best-jobs-in-the-future/?sh=51d9704c5738"">9 percent versus 6 percent</a> &ndash; which correlates to higher pay and better benefits.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Building new renewable energy <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2018/12/03/plunging-prices-mean-building-new-renewable-energy-is-cheaper-than-running-existing-coal/"">is cheaper than running existing coal plants</a> and prices get cheaper every year. By 2025, almost every existing coal plant in the United States <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2019/03/26/the-coal-cost-crossover-74-of-us-coal-plants-now-more-expensive-than-new-renewables-86-by-2025/#7f5abb5322d9"">will cost more to operate</a> than building replacement wind and solar within 35 miles of each plant.</p>

<p>The renewable energy industry has become a major U.S. employer. E2&rsquo;s Clean Jobs America 2019 report found nearly 3.3 million Americans working in clean energy&mdash;<a href=""https://e2.org/reports/clean-jobs-america-2019/"">outnumbering fossil fuel workers by 3-to-1</a>. E2 reported the <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2019/03/04/if-u-s-emissions-rose-in-2018-despite-clean-energy-growth-how-can-we-meet-climate-goals/?sh=5c372bdc11d9"">fastest-growing jobs across 12 states</a> were in renewable energy during 2018, and renewable energy is already <a href=""https://www.bls.gov/ooh/fastest-growing.htm"">the fastest-growing source of new U.S. electricity generation</a>, leading the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics to forecast America&rsquo;s two fastest-growing jobs through 2026 will be solar installer (105% growth) and wind technician (96% growth).</p>

<p>U.S. coal consumption <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=37692"">fell 4% in 2018 to its lowest point</a> in 39 years due to accelerating coal plant closures and reduced coal plant utilization. The electric power sector <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=38632"">represented 93% of total U.S. coal consumption</a> from 2007 to 2018, but over that period 68 GW of coal-fired generation (out of 313 GW in 2007) retired, capped by 13 GW of retirements in 2018.</p>

<p>Rocky Mountain Institute (RMI) has not only detailed the benefits of renewable energy on the nation&rsquo;s economy, <a href=""https://rmi.org/renewables-offer-rural-america-the-economic-development-opportunity-of-a-generation/"">but they have repeatedly highlighted</a> how Appalachia, and Pennsylvania specifically, can stand the most to gain from a Clean Energy Economy. By 2030, US wind and solar is on track to generate more than $60 billion in annual revenue&mdash;on par with the three leading US agricultural commodities: corn ($58 billion), soy ($44 billion), and beef production ($70 billion). Analysis conducted for RMI&rsquo;s Seeds of Opportunity report indicates that the projected 600 GW of new wind and solar projects built between 2020 and 2030 <a href=""https://rmi.org/insight/seeds-of-opportunity/"">would generate $220 billion in direct, lifetime economic benefits</a>. This is a gamechanger for Rural America, of which much of Pennsylvania falls into.</p>

<p>Specifically, onshore wind and utility-scale solar projects can result in $2.7 billion in tax revenues collected by local governments annually; $2.2 billion collected in land lease payments to rural landowners hosting turbines or panels on their property; $2.3 billion in construction jobs and wages; and $3.7 billion in operations and maintenance jobs and wages, <a href=""https://rmi.org/renewables-offer-rural-america-the-economic-development-opportunity-of-a-generation/"">all occurring annually by 2030</a>.<br />
As America faces an economy post-COVID 19, the green energy sector presents an avenue to create jobs on a massive, interstate scale <a href=""https://www.brookings.edu/blog/the-avenue/2020/09/10/how-clean-energy-jobs-can-power-an-equitable-covid-19-recovery/"">that includes a diverse workforce of people</a> with varying levels of education and skill set.</p>

<p>In July 2020, PennFuture released a report titled <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Green-Stimulus-FINAL.pdf"">A Green Stimulus and Recovery Platform for Pennsylvania</a> which detailed how transitioning to a green energy future would preserve or create 389,000 good paying and environmentally sustainable jobs in a variety of sectors and types such as tourism, blue-collar, and white-collar jobs&mdash;including detailed steps our legislature can take to make this a reality.&nbsp; Such a new economy cannot be realized without proper investment, and Pennsylvania, facing the brunt of the dying fossil fuel industry, is the perfect place to rise to the moment and invest.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania has a legacy of environmental damage from extractive industries including timber, oil, coal, and gas. In response, we passed a Constitutional amendment, Pa. Const. Art. I &sect; 27, acknowledging our fundamental right to clean air and pure water and requiring that the government act as a trustee with the duty to conserve and maintain our environment and our shared public natural resources. The threats associated with climate change only add to the urgency of this duty.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Instead of doubling down on an unsustainable and dirty fracked gas industry, Pennsylvania must work to reduce dependence on fossil fuels and promote alternatives such as energy efficiency and clean renewable energy. To do so, we must align our investments with our goals and avoid unintended side effects that promote pollution and poison our communities and our workers. This is a significant undertaking, but as a start PennFuture recommends the following:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Regular and ongoing evaluation of the costs and benefits of the fracked gas and fossil fuel subsidies: As time and technology changes, subsidies that were once justified may no longer make sense. Regular reconsideration of existing subsidies is needed to ensure we are spending money wisely and working towards our goals.</li>
	<li>Engaging in discussions with statewide, national, and international leaders in the renewable energy space: As renewable energy companies continue to establish themselves as leaders in the ever-growing clean energy economy, it would be wise for Pennsylvania economic development leaders to engage in job-creation centered dialogue in order to foster a robust and diverse clean energy sector in this great Commonwealth.</li>
</ul>

<p>We believe Pennsylvania can build a vibrant and growing economy on clean and renewable energy. We ask our lawmakers to take the needs of all Pennsylvanians seriously, do the right thing, and lead us to that New Clean Economic future by investing in renewable energy industries and jobs.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"John Ukenye, Policy Analyst"
PennEast Pipeline is Cancelled!,9/30/2021,"<p>Earlier this week it was announced that the PennEast Pipeline company <a href=""https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/penneast-end-development-pennsylvania-new-jersey-natgas-pipe-2021-09-27/"">will cease development of its proposed fracked gas pipeline</a> determining that &ldquo;further development of the project no longer is supported.&rdquo; The 120-mile, 36-inch diameter pipeline, which was slated to run from Luzerne County in northeast Pennsylvania through the Delaware River watershed to New Jersey, was unable to get all necessary environmental permits.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture responded to this announcement <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-Responds-to-PennEast-Pipeline-Cancelation"">with relief for our environment and communities</a> and thanks for everyone who fought against this pipeline!&nbsp;</p>

<p>The decision to cease development of the PennEast pipeline came as a welcome surprise, especially since the company <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Supreme-Court-Ruled-Natural-Gas-Companies-Can-Condemn-State-Owned-Land"">just won a big case</a> with the U.S. Supreme Court that allowed the company to use eminent domain on state-owned or controlled lands in New Jersey. We knew something was going on when, despite that win, PennEast decided to <a href=""https://www.mcall.com/news/pennsylvania/mc-nws-pa-penneast-pipeline-eminent-domain-halted-20210810-q3ub2gijazgxthvetqd4sqn2qa-story.html"">stop condemnation proceedings</a> in both New Jersey and Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Condemnation occurs when the private property is taken for public use and the landowner is given &ldquo;fair market value&rdquo; for that property. In 2017, we joined with Save Carbon County and others to <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Environmental-Impacts-and-the-PennEast-Pipeline"">highlight the unfair practices</a> in which pipeline companies may condemn private lands for pipeline right-of-ways even before the pipeline route is finalized. Once condemned, the pipeline company may access the property to do surveys and <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2020/07/03/family-lost-hundreds-of-trees-to-failed-pipeline-project-settles-with-company-gets-land-back/"">may even destroy some of the natural resources</a> on the land, like by clearcutting trees along the proposed right-of-way.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In addition, PennFuture has been concerned with the PennEast pipeline&rsquo;s environmental impacts since its inception in 2014. Impacts from the PennEast pipeline would have included degradation of streams, including special protection waters; loss of high functioning wetlands; destruction of forest habitat and increased invasive species; and increased greenhouse gas emissions, among other things. PennFuture - both individually as well as with others, including our key partners Delaware Riverkeeper Network (DRN) and Clean Air Council - have submitted numerous public comments opposing the various federal and state approvals the PennEast pipeline needed.&nbsp; Additionally, among other actions taken, PennFuture intervened in proceedings before the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, and our ally DRN has brought numerous legal challenges against PennEast.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Many other local, regional, state, and federal groups fought against the destructive PennEast pipeline. As result of this strong opposition, New Jersey had recently denied critical environmental permits for the pipeline. This caused PennEast to propose to bifurcate its process and build the PA-only portion of the pipeline in phases to allow for construction to move forward, despite it being a <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PennEast-Chs.-102---105-Comments-Jan.-2021-.pdf"">pipeline to nowhere</a>, as PennFuture pointed out in our comments on the &ldquo;Phase One Amendment&rdquo; proposal. And while PennEast <a href=""https://www.lehighvalleylive.com/allentown/2021/09/penneast-pipeline-co-halts-its-natural-gas-transmission-line-crossing-lehigh-valley.html"">has stated</a> that it is &ldquo;examining the proper next steps in the regulatory process as it pertains to the Phase One Amendment pending at FERC,&rdquo; we believe that the PennEast pipeline is dead in PA.&nbsp;</p>

<p>No doubt that the sustained legal, regulatory, and outreach efforts of PennFuture and our partners resulted in the necessary delay of construction of this project. And New Jersey&rsquo;s forceful recognition of the environmental harms of this pipeline and their denial of key permits was critical to PennEast inability to quickly push this pipeline through. But I don&rsquo;t think we can overlook the fact that this decision came from PennEast - and not the courts. This appears to be a business decision rather than a conclusive legal holding that the pipeline cannot be built. Because we are now at a time when market forces show that investment in fracked gas <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fracked-Gas-Petrochemical-Industries-Continue-to-Overpromise-and-Underdeliver-for-Pennsylvanians&#8203;"">is no longer as profitable as it once was</a>, such fierce and coordinated opposition seems to be working to halt the fracked gas industry from proposing facilities that may be operating on the margins.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But Pennsylvanians cannot rely on market forces, private business decisions, or other states to protect us from harmful fracked gas and petrochemical facilities. Our Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) must do everything it can to live up to its name and protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment. The DEP is a trustee under <a href=""https://blogs.law.widener.edu/envirolawcenter/files/2010/03/PA_Citizens_Guide_to_Art_I_Sect_27.pdf"">PA&rsquo;s Environmental Rights Amendment</a> (ERA), Article I, Section 27 of our state constitution. The ERA puts our right to &ldquo;clean air, pure water, and to the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic and esthetic values of the environment&rdquo; on par with other First Amendment rights like free speech. Thus, DEP must take seriously its fiduciary obligation to &ldquo;conserve and maintain [Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources] for the benefit of all the people.&rdquo;</p>

<p>To continue to issue approvals to an industry that we have seen <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/tag/mariner-east-2/"">time</a> and <a href=""https://www.fractracker.org/2021/03/shells-falcon-pipeline-under-investigation-for-serious-public-safety-threats/"">time</a> and <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2018/09/10/natural-gas-pipeline-blast-in-beaver-county-prompts-evacuation/"">time again</a> destroy our environment and threaten the health and safety of our communities violates that fiduciary duty of the trustee. Rather, DEP must look critically at applications and promises made and must use its permitting process to ensure that construction and operation of pipelines will not harm our environment. DEP must continue to issue strong enforcement actions against these companies when - and in PA it appears to be when, not if - they destroy our waters, our lands, our communities.</p>

<p>To end on a positive note, PennFuture is very happy that the PennEast pipeline no longer seems to be a threat in Pennsylvania. This news is a huge relief for PennFuture and the impacted communities across the Delaware River watershed who have been tirelessly working to defeat this terrible pipeline. We couldn&rsquo;t have gotten here without the support of our partners, supporters, and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">members.</a> And we will continue to fight to protect our communities from the harmful impacts of the fracked gas and petrochemical industries.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
When Profits are on the Line: The Fight Over Energy Markets,9/29/2021,"<p>Having energy available when we flip on a light switch is a complicated business and making the wrong choices can have serious consequences. In Pennsylvania, these choices are often made by our Regional Transmission Organization (RTO)&mdash;a nonprofit organization known as <a href=""https://www.pjm.com/"">PJM Interconnection</a>.&nbsp;They manage a large marketplace providing services in an area touching 13 states and the District of Columbia.</p>

<p>In the short term, many key decisions are made through auctions.&nbsp;PJM forecasts how much energy we will need tomorrow, and generators bid to see who can provide that energy at the lowest cost.&nbsp; The cheapest generators clear the auction and everyone receives the market clearing price.&nbsp;If additional energy is needed over the course of a day, PJM also has a spot market that runs a similar auction every five minutes.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
While this system works very well and most generators make the bulk of their revenue from these markets, it doesn&rsquo;t provide any long-term price signals to ensure the capacity we need is built and maintained.&nbsp;Relying only on short-term markets to influence long-term behavior is a bad idea&mdash;this was one of the primary causes of the <a href=""https://apnews.com/article/why-texas-power-grid-failed-2eaa659d2ac29ff87eb9220875f23b34"">high-profile and catastrophic failures</a> the Texas grid experienced in recent months.&nbsp;Fortunately, PJM doesn&rsquo;t follow the Texas plan.</p>

<p>PJM has what is known as a Capacity Market in addition to the energy markets.&nbsp;Under the Capacity Market, generators who clear the market commit to be available, if needed, three years in the future in exchange for set payments.&nbsp;They receive the capacity payments whether or not they actually are called upon to deliver energy, but they are also liable for penalties if they are not able to run when called.&nbsp;This gives them both time to plan and incentives to be reliable.</p>

<p>Prior to December 2019, PJM was concerned that some market participants with buyer-side market power could manipulate the market.&nbsp;For example, a load-serving entity that built new power plants could dump new generation into the capacity market at artificially low prices. They might lose money on those plants, but if it drove the market clearing price low enough, they could more than make up for those losses buying the capacity they need at cheaper prices.&nbsp;To prevent this sort of manipulation, PJM set a price floor for certain new generation.&nbsp;They called this the Minimum Offer Price Rule or &ldquo;MOPR.&rdquo; (pronounced m&#333;p-er)</p>

<p><u>Overreaches of authority</u></p>

<p>Since 2019, another type of possible market influence arose.&nbsp;Maryland wanted to encourage new in-state generation so it created a program where a company would bid into the PJM capacity market but, in addition to its capacity revenue, it would also receive out-of-market payments to make up the difference between the market clearing price and a pre-arrange contract price.&nbsp;The Supreme Court <a href=""https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/15pdf/14-614_k5fm.pdf"">rejected this program</a>, holding that Maryland&rsquo;s plan disregarded an interstate wholesale rate required by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC).</p>

<p>This decision was very limited.&nbsp;Although it rejected a type of market influence by the state, the Court explicitly said that &ldquo;Nothing in this opinion should be read to foreclose...states from encouraging&nbsp; production of new or clean generation...so long as a state does not condition payment of funds on capacity clearing the auction.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Unfortunately, then President Trump&rsquo;s FERC ignored this clarification and claimed that practically any effort by the state to make policy decisions about their resource mix &ldquo;threaten[s] the competitiveness of the capacity market.&rdquo;&nbsp; As a result of this new FERC decision, PJM was ordered to expand the MOPR well beyond the initial purpose of limiting buyer-side market power.&nbsp;The expanded MOPR would include practically any &ldquo;state-subsidized&rdquo; resource, whether or not the subsidy was conditioned on a generator clearing the capacity market.&nbsp;These targeted subsidies would have a disproportionate impact on new clean renewable generation like those sources benefiting from Pennsylvania&rsquo;s alternative energy portfolio standards (AEPS), forcing new clean resources to bid into the capacity market at uncompetitively high prices.</p>

<p>Rather than supporting an efficient market, this created a fiction where PJM would effectively pretend that these clean resources didn&rsquo;t exist.&nbsp;Not only would that raise the capacity prices across the board, it also meant ratepayers would be forced to pay for more capacity than was actually needed.&nbsp;Or, as PJM put it &ldquo;attempting to &lsquo;hermetically seal&rsquo; the capacity market from the reality of state policies...effects an over-correction that itself works against the determination of just and reasonable rates.&rdquo;&nbsp;By 2030, this could mean $2 billion per year in excess payments that would largely flow into the coffers of polluting generators and extend the life of uncompetitive and unneeded fossil fuel plants.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;But prices didn&rsquo;t increase in our last capacity auction!&rdquo; comes the cry from the polluters.&nbsp;In reality, that is a distraction rather than a vindication for the expanded MOPR.&nbsp;First, because of the various changes, PJM delayed the last auction for two years allowing for a much more accurate forecast of needed capacity and the need for less reserves, as a result, they bought 2.5GW less capacity saving ratepayers <a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/experts/tom-rutigliano/how-save-four-billion-without-really-trying"">over $4 billion</a>. Second, the vast majority of existing resources were grandfathered, so no one seriously expected the MOPR to show large effects in the first few auctions anyway. While ratepayers did get a huge break, the MOPR system was still broken.</p>

<p>While all four of the current FERC commissioners were appointed by the former President, it is a very different body than it was in 2019.&nbsp;Right now, there is an even split with two Democrats and two Republicans, and a fifth commissioner&mdash;a third Democrat&mdash;has been nominated by President Biden and is expected to be confirmed by the Senate later this year.&nbsp;President Biden also named Commissioner Richard Glick, who dissented in the prior opinion, as the new Chairman replacing Niel Chatterjee.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>With the expanded MOPR deeply unpopular and support at FERC for that approach waning, PJM saw the handwriting on the wall and, earlier this year, held a series of workshops to discuss alternatives.&nbsp;This ended with the consideration of nine different proposals to reform the MOPR.&nbsp;After putting the options to various stakeholder groups, PJM&rsquo;s own plan was clearly the most popular.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This would only apply the MOPR to facilities that actually exercised buyer side market power or those receiving &ldquo;conditioned state support&rdquo;&mdash;the narrow category specifically identified by the Supreme Court.&nbsp; PJM proposed to adopt this plan in July and, with the FERC commissioners split two against two on the change, FERC took no action.&nbsp;The revisions <a href=""https://elibrary.ferc.gov/eLibrary/filelist?accession_num=20210929-3009"">became effective by operation of law</a> on September 29, 2021.</p>

<p><u>Panic from the fossil fuel industry</u></p>

<p>PJM revising a fairly obscure rule in a way that would save ratepayers billions of dollars doesn&rsquo;t seem controversial, but shortly before the new rule took effect, the PA House Environmental Resources and Energy (ERE) Committee, led by the irascible Rep. Daryl Metcalfe, held an entire hearing to rail against this new plan and the danger of &ldquo;subsidies&rdquo;.&nbsp;He seemed to be under the impression that this was somehow orchestrated by President Biden even though Trump appointed all of the current FERC commissioners. (Richard Glick, who Daryl kept referring to as &ldquo;Biden&rsquo;s appointee,&rdquo; was the Trump appointee who Biden named as Chairman.)&nbsp;</p>

<p>The following day the PA State Senate ERE committee held a meeting on the same topic, with largely the same speakers.&nbsp;Many Senators also took the opportunity to object to other states investing in new renewable generation even though doing so would actually lower electricity costs for their constituents.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Why would two legislative committees feel the need to go on record advocating for a plan to raise their constituent&rsquo;s electric bills right before an election year? If you suspect the fossil fuel industry has a hand in this, you would be right.</p>

<p>While it&rsquo;s a good thing we don&rsquo;t follow the Texas model and rely on short-term markets to drive investments, our Capacity Market has its own problems, perhaps the biggest of which is systematic over-procurement.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Take for example the Cheswick coal-fired power plant in Allegheny County.&nbsp;In 2020 it was only called upon to run at less than 10% of its rated capacity.&nbsp;That is like a restaurant only opening its doors for just over a month each year&mdash;not a sustainable business.&nbsp;With such poor sales, capacity payments may have accounted for most of its revenue and, if it didn&rsquo;t clear the capacity auction and lost those guaranteed payments, it wouldn&rsquo;t make sense to stay open. It&rsquo;s not surprising then that just days after the 2022/23 Capacity Auction results were published, it was announced Cheswick would retire.</p>

<p>An analysis by PJM concluded that its <a href=""https://pjm.com/planning/services-requests/gen-deactivations.aspx"">retirement won&rsquo;t create any reliability issues</a>, but that raises a bigger question.&nbsp;Why did we pay around $20 million to keep a plant in service that barely generated any electricity and wasn&rsquo;t actually needed anyway?&nbsp;The simple answer is systematic over-procurement.</p>

<p>While PJM says <a href=""https://www.sierraclub.org/sites/www.sierraclub.org/files/blog/Wilson%20Overprocurement%20of%20Capacity%20in%20PJM.PDF"">reserve margins in the range of 16% of their forecasted peak load</a> are adequate, their actual reserve margins are often over 20%, that alone results in about 15GW of unneeded capacity being bought each year.&nbsp;When we look back at the actual peak load, their reserve margins have been running closer to 30%.&nbsp;In short, ratepayers are spending literally billions of dollars to buy far more capacity than we need&mdash;even in a worst case scenario.</p>

<p>In response to this illusionary &ldquo;demand&rdquo; for capacity, generators had an incentive to increase supply.&nbsp;Over-procurement supports overbuilding of fossil resources.&nbsp;Now, as clean and renewable energy <a href=""https://www.lazard.com/perspective/lcoe2020"">keeps getting cheaper</a>, fossil fuel owners and investors are faced with an increasingly competitive energy market and are desperate to keep these guaranteed payments coming in to pad the bottom line.&nbsp;Or, in the dry language of PJM&rsquo;s filing, the expanded MOPR &ldquo;foments greater revenue reliance by resources on the capacity market, rather than the energy and reserves markets, contrary to the original design of restructured wholesale electricity markets.&rdquo;&nbsp;In other words, the rule created a bubble of unneeded capacity. Like any market bubble lacking fundamental underlying support, this could suddenly collapse if fossil fuel interests don&rsquo;t defend it.</p>

<p>Ignoring the value of clean energy on public health and the environment is central to their plan.&nbsp;In this view, paying for clean generation is a &ldquo;subsidy&rdquo; but being allowed to pollute for free isn&rsquo;t, even if the amount others are paying for the damage is massive.</p>

<p>Another fossil-fuel strategy has been to pretend only fossil fuel power is valuable as a capacity resource.&nbsp;While it&rsquo;s true that a solar facility isn&rsquo;t going to operate at night and will produce less electricity on cloudy days, we&rsquo;ve seen in Texas and during our own polar vortex that fossil fuel plants aren&rsquo;t necessarily available when we need them either.&nbsp;While having variable resources complicates the management of our power grid, this is a well-understood issue <a href=""https://www.pjm.com/planning/resource-adequacy-planning/effective-load-carrying-capability"">that we can account for.</a></p>

<p>The expanded MOPR took this all a step further and effectively pretended that much of the new clean generation wouldn&rsquo;t exist at all. For fossil fuel plants, that means all of those capacity dollars flow to their pockets and not to their competitors.&nbsp;Reforming the MOPR not only threatened them with more competition, it drew attention to the more fundamental issue of overprocuremt.&nbsp;If PJM fixes that problem, the ratepayers will benefit but uneconomical and unnecessary fossil fuel plants will lose their safety net.&nbsp;That has them, and their friends in the legislature, in a panic.&nbsp;</p>

<p>For polluters and their friends, forcing higher bills on ratepayers is a small price to pay when profits are on the line.</p>

Climate Goals Remain Elusive and Will Require Bold Action,9/23/2021,"<p>It is fitting that Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Department of Environmental Protection on Wednesday released an updated version of its <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/citizens/climate/Pages/PA-Climate-Action-Plan.aspx?eType=EmailBlastContent&amp;eId=44444444-4444-4444-4444-444444444444"">Climate Action Plan</a> (CAP), which provides insight into the progress being made on Gov. Tom Wolf&rsquo;s climate goals. This is <a href=""https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/its-climate-week-again-but-the-calendar-is-running-out"">Climate Week</a>, after all, a time when activists across the world hold marches and rallies to bring attention to the most pressing issue of our time: the climate crisis.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As the <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2020/08/06/pennsylvania-climate-change-greenhouse-gases-republican-legislature/"">fourth largest emitter</a> of greenhouse gas emissions in the nation, Pennsylvania has an obligation to do its part to combat the climate crisis. To that end, Pennsylvania is well on its way toward achieving a 2025 goal, laid out in Governor Wolf&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/executive-order-2019-01-commonwealth-leadership-in-addressing-climate-change-and-promoting-energy-conservation-and-sustainable-governance/"">Executive Order 2019-01</a>, to reduce emissions 26 percent below 2005 levels. But more&nbsp;significant action will be necessary to achieve a long-term goal of reducing emissions by 80 percent by 2050.</p>

<p>As difficult as the 2050 target may seem, waiting until mid-century to slash emissions will bring even greater hardship. The fifth iteration in a series of reports outlining the commonwealth&rsquo;s progress in addressing climate change, the CAP highlights how Pennsylvania&rsquo;s average temperature has already risen nearly 2 degrees Fahrenheit since 1900. We&rsquo;re now on course for another 6 degrees of warming by mid-century.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While progress has been made, it will be hard for Pennsylvania to meet its climate goals as long as the fracked gas and other fossil fuel industries continue receiving preferential treatment from our elected officials.</p>

<p>Earlier this year, the General Assembly continued to throw good money after bad in offering <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-A-New-Coalition-for-a-Better-Future"">massive handouts to incentivize</a> the construction of more petrochemical facilities here. That&rsquo;s not to mention the more than 50 other ways our state and local governments <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PF_FossilFuel_Report_final_2.12.21.pdf"">subsidize fracked gas and other fossil fuel industries</a> across the Commonwealth.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We cannot expect to meet these bold emissions reductions goals while still relying on dirty energy for economic growth. Unfortunately, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s electric power sector <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/state/?sid=PA"">heavily relies on fracked gas</a>. Now, Pennsylvanians need to accept the hard truth that we must transition -&nbsp;as soon as possible -&nbsp;from&nbsp;fossil fuels, including fracked gas, as the way forward to achieve carbon neutrality. Bold action must be taken to avert the most disastrous consequences of the climate crisis. Continued support for the fracking industry undermines the governor&rsquo;s climate change ambitions.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While the power generation sector has to be an integral focus of emissions reductions, the Climate Action Plan highlighted a new sector that is set to overtake the electricity sector and soon become Pennsylvania&rsquo;s largest contributor of emissions: industry.</p>

<p>In 2005, the industrial sector released only half as many emissions as electricity generation. By 2030, industrial sources will be responsible for more emissions than all the state&rsquo;s power plants and agriculture &mdash; combined. This unfortunate trend is driven by a forecasted growth in petrochemical plants as well as continued pollution from steel plants, cement manufacturers, and other industrial producers. The CAP predicts industrial emissions to grow 14 percent by 2030.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Still, the governor&rsquo;s 2050 goals are not out of reach. Several of the clean energy policies recommended in the CAP are, in fact, well underway. Further policy changes could very reasonably put us on track to achieve the goal of reducing emissions by 80 percent.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Earlier this month, for instance, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Independent Regulatory Review Commission (IRRC) <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-So-What-Comes-Next-for-Pennsylvania's-Efforts-to-Join-the-Regional-Greenhouse-Gas-Initiative"">voted to approve DEP&rsquo;s proposed CO2 Budget Trading Rule</a>. The development means Pennsylvania could become a participant in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI), likely by early next year.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Joining RGGI would help to level the playing field for renewable energy producers. The CAP forecasts a modest growth of renewable energy production in the years ahead, leveling off at 10 percent. This sober estimate pales in comparison to the optimistic forecast produced this month by the U.S. Department of Energy. The <a href=""https://www.energy.gov/articles/doe-releases-solar-futures-study-providing-blueprint-zero-carbon-grid"">Solar Future Study</a> laid out a vision for solar energy &mdash; all on its own &mdash; fulfilling 40 percent of the country&rsquo;s energy supplies.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The contrast is less about differences in report authors&rsquo; energy policy philosophies, and more of a reflection of how Pennsylvania&rsquo;s renewable energy incentives are increasingly antiquated. After all, the state&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.puc.pa.gov/filing-resources/issues-laws-regulations/aeps-act/"">Alternative Energy Portfolio Standard Act</a>&nbsp;was signed into law 17 years ago. Energy markets have since evolved, yet our energy policies remain relatively unchanged.</p>

<p>Finally, the transportation sector will also have to cut emissions significantly to reach the 2050 goal, accounting for 21 percent of targeted emission reductions.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s transit agencies and other public and private fleet operators are increasingly switching to battery-electric vehicles, <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/sep/16/battery-electric-freight-train-wabtec-rail-transport-emissions"">like Pittsburgh-based Wabtec</a>, which recently unveiled the world&rsquo;s first battery-electric freight train. Growing prevalence of charging infrastructure and declining costs of electric vehicles will likely accelerate the transition. Plus, greater electrification further underscores the importance of switching to a cleaner electric grid.</p>

<p>CAP is further evidence that ambitious climate action is not only necessary for protecting Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment but also beneficial for our economy. DEP suggests that implementing the 18 clean-energy policy changes outlined in the report would generate an average of 42,000 new jobs every year.</p>

<p>Lawmakers should take notice. Further delay on serious climate action not only risks further exacerbating heat waves, flooding, and other climate-induced threats. By delaying the transition to a clean energy economy, our state leaders are choosing to protect the fracked gas industry and hold back Pennsylvania&rsquo;s full economic potential.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
Pennsylvania as a Hydrogen Hub,9/16/2021,"<p>It was recently announced that fossil fuel industry leader Perry Babb <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2021/08/15/A-laboratory-at-scale-a-hydrogen-carbon-storage-shale-drilling-and-urea-project-has-hit-the-industry-zeitgeist-at-just-the-right-time/stories/202108080048%E2%80%8B"">will launch a $410 million project</a> called KeyState to Zero in Clinton County, north-central Pennsylvania. This effort is part of a larger push by a mixture of government and private entities to pursue hydrogen as an alleged means to achieve net zero carbon emissions. Hydrogen, generally, is seen as an alternative to traditional fossil fuels <a href=""https://ohiorivervalleyinstitute.org/hydrogen-101/"">for heavy industries that cannot be electrified</a> as easily, such as marine transportation, cement and steel production, and long-haul freight. Hydrogen by itself has no carbon and thus emits none when burned or reacted in fuel cells. However, Babb and others fail to make the explicit distinction between the different types of hydrogen power that exist. Not all hydrogen is created equal, and Babb&rsquo;s hydrogen plant merely keeps the fossil fuel industry alive while polluting just as much as, and in some cases more than, current dirty sources.</p>

<p>One form of hydrogen power which can be truly clean and net-zero is achieved through electrolysis. This form of hydrogen power, also known as &ldquo;green&rdquo; hydrogen, uses renewable energy to power the splitting of water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen.&nbsp; However, PennFuture recognizes that <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/thebarkedition17"">even this form of hydrogen power</a> is still inefficient and costly in most cases, and we must invest resources, time, and research in other forms of sustainable energy such as solar and wind.</p>

<p>One of the other forms of hydrogen power involves the capturing and sequestering of carbon dioxide (CO2), commonly known as &ldquo;blue&rdquo; hydrogen. Blue hydrogen proponents see potential in Pennsylvania becoming a &ldquo;Blue Hydrogen Hub.&rdquo; This is due to the vast amounts of natural gas located in the state, as methane (a large component of natural gas) releases massive amounts of CO2 which can be captured and stored into producing blue hydrogen. Proponents also believe that legacy fossil fuel pipelines can be retrofitted to transport blue hydrogen, which itself can also be blended with traditional fossil fuels and used as energy. This effectively allows the fossil fuel industry an extended lifeline&mdash;where it can continue to extract and pollute, while capturing some CO2 and producing hydrogen power.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Babb called blue hydrogen <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2021/08/15/A-laboratory-at-scale-a-hydrogen-carbon-storage-shale-drilling-and-urea-project-has-hit-the-industry-zeitgeist-at-just-the-right-time/stories/202108080048%E2%80%8B"">a stepping stone to green hydrogen</a> and net zero emissions, as it is too expensive to mass produce green hydrogen at this time. However, while hydrogen on its own produces no carbon emissions, the process required to create blue hydrogen itself is just as CO2-intensive as traditional methane-based natural gas production and even more potentially harmful to the environment. Hydrogen is a smaller molecule than natural gas and more easily leaks out of steel pipelines. It can also cause steel to become weak and brittle, and thus is easier to combust and can create a flame unseen by the human eye. And the truth remains that the more money and time spent on promoting blue hydrogen, the less focus there will be on developing cleaner, green hydrogen. Green hydrogen only comprises <a href=""https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/04/green-hydrogen-is-gaining-traction-but-it-must-overcome-big-hurdles.html"">about .1 percent of all global hydrogen production</a>. It is clear that the fracked gas industry is not looking for a stepping stone, but for an endpoint with blue hydrogen.&nbsp;</p>

<p>On a nationwide lens, it was recently reported that President Biden&rsquo;s current bipartisan infrastructure legislation <a href=""https://thehill.com/changing-america/sustainability/energy/567726-new-study-says-biden-approved-blue-hydrogen-may"">would allocate $8 billion of the total $1 trillion</a> to development and research on CO2 capture and storage-based energy, blue hydrogen. According to the Guardian, <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2021/aug/12/clean-fuel-blue-hydrogen-coal-study"">blue hydrogen creates 20 percent more greenhouse gases</a> than coal during its production. According to the Energy Science &amp; Engineering journal, <a href=""https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/ese3.956"">blue hydrogen is 60 percent more polluting</a> than burning diesel when being burned for heat.</p>

<p>There are green hydrogen projects underway that are at least worth examining further. One is by New York-based <a href=""https://www.ir.plugpower.com/Press-Releases/Press-Release-Details/2021/Plug-Power-and-Brookfield-Renewable-Move-Forward-with-Green-Hydrogen-Plant-in-South-Central-Pennsylvania/default.aspx"">company Plug Power</a>, who is partnering with Holtwood Dam operator Brookfield Renewable Partners to build Pennsylvania&rsquo;s first green hydrogen plant in southern Lancaster County. The new plant will use power from the hydroelectric facility and water from the Susquehanna River to produce 15 metric tons of liquid hydrogen per day, which the company says is enough to power 1,500 heavy-duty trucks. The plant is expected to be online by the end of 2022 and create 25 permanent jobs. As stated earlier, however, state and federal funds allocated to hydrogen should be invested in researching and developing cheaper and sustainable methods to utilize green hydrogen in the future.</p>

<p>For those well aware of the need for our nation to get serious about mitigating climate change, Pennsylvania becoming a &ldquo;Blue Hydrogen Hub&rdquo; would simply be continuing us down the same ruinous path. It has long been the position of PennFuture that we, as both a Commonwealth and a nation, must work towards zero carbon emissions through economic, research, and development investments into alternative, green energy sources which would also produce good paying jobs for our citizens.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy,"John Ukenye, Policy Analyst"
"PennFuture, Partners Appeal Air Permit Extension for Proposed Liquefied Natural Gas Plant in Wyalusing Township",9/15/2021,"<p>The Department of Environmental Protection (&ldquo;DEP&rdquo;) recently issued a second extension of the air pollution permit for a proposed Bradford County Real Estate Partners (&ldquo;BCREP&rdquo;) Liquified Natural Gas (&ldquo;LNG&rdquo;) facility near the Susquehanna River in Wyalusing Township, Bradford County, in Northeastern Pennsylvania.&nbsp;PennFuture, and our partners Clean Air Council and Sierra Club, appealed this extension to the Environmental Hearing Board.</p>

<p>The facility would process fracked natural gas into LNG for shipment by truck or train to a proposed LNG export facility in Gibbstown, New Jersey for transport overseas.&nbsp;The Wyalusing facility would include a six-million-gallon LNG storage tank and truck loadout system.&nbsp;If completed, the Wyalusing facility would be permitted to emit over a million tons of greenhouse gases and hundreds of tons of other harmful air pollutants annually.&nbsp;An LNG facility like this one would not only contribute to climate change and threaten public health and the environment through its direct emissions, but it would also lead to increased fracking in Pennsylvania and further entrenchment of the fossil fuel industry.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We object to the permit extension on a number of grounds.&nbsp;DEP erred in granting the extension because BCREP has not commenced construction at the Wyalusing facility, as required by the regulations.&nbsp;Further, the second extension relies on an outdated and flawed &ldquo;Best Available Technology&rdquo; determination.&nbsp;The DEP also relied on flawed analysis resulting in insufficient and erroneous air emission limits.&nbsp;We also object to the permit extension on the basis of a number of other significant deficiencies, as detailed in our Notice of Appeal.&nbsp;For more information, our full Notice of Appeal <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/2021-8-26-Notice-of-Appeal-without-exhibits.pdf"">may be read here.</a></p>

<p>Moreover, the Wyalusing facility is part of a logistically and financially connected LNG export scheme, which plans to truck or train highly explosive LNG through Pennsylvania communities, to be exported for overseas markets from the proposed facility in Gibbstown, NJ on the banks of the Delaware River.&nbsp;To learn more about LNG, its dangers, and the Wyalusing facility, please check out our LNG Blog Series: <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-Series-1-What-is-Liquefied-Natural-Gas"">LNG Blog #1</a>, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-2-Bomb-Trains-Through-Pennsylvania"">LNG Blog #2</a>, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-3-Protect-Northern-PA"">LNG Blog #3</a>, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-4-Liquified-Natural-Gas-Should-Not-Become-the-New-Bomb-Trains-to-Threaten-Our-Communities"">LNG Blog #4</a>, and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-5-Public-opposition-grows-to-proposed-LNG-shipping-terminals"">LNG Blog #5</a>.</p>

<p>PennFuture has been engaged with local community members and organizations in tracking and opposing this facility and the transport of LNG across the state.&nbsp;PennFuture and Sierra Club <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-Intervenes-to-Support-FERC-Jurisdiction-over-Wyalusing-LNG-Facility"">have previously objected</a> to a filing with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (&ldquo;FERC&rdquo;) regarding FERC&rsquo;s jurisdiction over the proposed Wyalusing facility, thereby removing requirements to analyze the environmental impacts of the proposed scheme, including cumulative impacts under the National Environmental Policy Act.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our appeal of this extension is another step in our efforts to ensure full oversight of the Wyalusing facility and the LNG industry in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;This LNG terminal is nothing more than one more dangerous speculation by a company trying to find new outlets for dirty fracked gas.&nbsp;And once again, our communities will suffer the harmful impacts of this scheme without any benefit of the end product.&nbsp;PennFuture stands committed to opposing new fracked gas facilities, instead supporting a true, sustainable clean energy future for Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture works hard to protect our waters, our air, and our communities from the dangers of the petrochemical buildout across Pennsylvania.&nbsp;By challenging DEP&rsquo;s extension of the Wyalusing facility&rsquo;s air pollution permit, PennFuture continues that work and our fight for a clean energy future.&nbsp;If you are interested in supporting our fight, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">please become a member today!&nbsp;</a></p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Angela Kilbert, Staff Attorney"
So What Comes Next for Pennsylvania's Efforts to Join the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative?,9/14/2021,"<p>On September 1st, 2021, a majority of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Independent Regulatory Review Commission (IRRC) voted to approve the proposed CO2 Budget Trading Rule under which Pennsylvania will participate in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI). IRRC not only found that finalizing the rule is in the public interest, they also concluded that the Environmental Quality Board (EQB) acted within its statutory authority and intent of the General Assembly when it approved the rule.</p>

<p>IRRC didn&rsquo;t take this step lightly. The board&nbsp;not only reviewed the text of the rule itself, but a massive 871-page packet that, in addition to the regulatory text at DEP&rsquo;s analysis of the regulation, included the DEP&rsquo;s responses to the 14,038 written comments they received and issues raised during 32 hours of testimony provided by 449 people during a series of public hearings this past December.&nbsp;In addition to that, IRRC received 280 comment submissions directly from the public along with 68 submissions from members of the legislature.&nbsp;Finally, IRRC took several hours of in-person testimony on the day of the hearing itself.</p>

<p>While this was a resounding vindication for the program, polluters and their friends in the legislature haven&rsquo;t given up their fight, and further delaying tactics are expected.</p>

<p>Shortly after IRRC&rsquo;s approval, the House Environmental Resources and Energy (ERE) Committee&mdash;led by the <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/opinion/editorials/2021/08/05/Cleaner-air-must-be-the-goal-carbon-cap-and-trade-is-the-way-forward/stories/202107200018"">bombastic climate change denier Daryl Metcalfe</a>&mdash;quickly met to vote out a &ldquo;joint resolution of disapproval&rdquo; to kill the program.&nbsp;While there are enough anti-environmental votes in the House and Senate to pass such a resolution, it&rsquo;s unlikely that there are enough votes to override Governor Wolf&rsquo;s veto.</p>

<p>If this sounds familiar, it is.&nbsp;Last session the House and Senate passed HB 2025 which would have required any program to cut carbon pollution be submitted to the legislature for their approval.&nbsp; Governor Wolf quickly vetoed this bill and it didn&rsquo;t go any further&mdash;a good sign that the votes to override the veto just weren&rsquo;t there.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>After already failing once, the Senate tried again this spring with a new version of the bill under the number SB 119.&nbsp;While this easily passed the Senate, it&rsquo;s been sitting in&nbsp;Metcalf&rsquo;s ERE committee without action since then. There is little doubt that this new bill would pass the House if it ever comes up for a vote, but that isn&rsquo;t good enough.&nbsp;Failing to pass with a veto-proof majority would be yet another loss for Metcalfe&nbsp;and his cronies.</p>

<p>While they may not be able to stop the rule, they can cause delays.&nbsp;With the resolution of disapproval voted out of committee, the House and Senate each have 30 calendar days or 10 session days (whichever is longer) to pass the resolution&mdash;which would stop the rule from going forward until at least mid-October.&nbsp;After the Governor vetoes the resolution, the House and Senate would get another 30 calendar days or 10 session days to override that veto.&nbsp;Depending on the precise timing, it could be December or January before that hurdle is cleared.</p>
