<p>Once the clock expires without a veto override, the process isn&rsquo;t quite over yet.&nbsp;The Attorney General must review all regulatory packages for legality and form.&nbsp;This step isn&rsquo;t expected to be a problem, but a thorough review will take some additional time. And, once that is done, the package will go to the Legislative Reference Bureau (LRB) to arrange for it to be printed in the Pennsylvania Bulletin and officially go into effect. It typically takes several more weeks for the LRB to complete this process.</p>

<p>Actual implementation of the rule may be unlikely before the end of the year, but DEP foresaw that possibility. If not in effect by January 1, the rule will start at the beginning of the next calendar quarter following finalization.</p>

<p>Of course, those extra weeks of delay give polluters that much more time to dump their waste into our air for free.&nbsp;That may explain a lot about why their friends in the Legislature are fighting so hard.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
Climate Denial and Pennsylvania Politics: The Ultimate Alternative Universe,9/9/2021,"<p>Last week, on September 1, 2021, individuals on &ldquo;both sides&rdquo; of the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) traveled to and from Harrisburg and through Hurricane Ida for an important meeting, that of the Independent Regulatory Review Commission, also known as IRRC.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>On this day, IRRC was voting whether to advance a regulation that would have Pennsylvania join RGGI, so that the Commonwealth can pursue its climate pollution reduction goals.&nbsp;Be they on the pro-RGGI side of the 23-month long debate, or the anti-RGGI side, to a person, the witnesses mentioned their rough car ride and passages through the deluge that the tropical storm was dumping across our state.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As part of an organization whose mission it is to hasten the state&rsquo;s transition to clean energy, and for which Pennsylvania joining RGGI has been our top priority for reducing greenhouse gases here in the state, the journey to make it to this day had been rocky, but well-worth it because the commission ultimately voted in favor of Pennsylvania linking with RGGI, a big deal to be sure.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>That day, many local and industry folks testified against RGGI, and that was to be expected.&nbsp;There were statements that perpetuated mistruths spread by industry about the program and the Governor&rsquo;s authority, which we dismiss without a second thought.&nbsp;There was angry testimony from folks who rejected everything about the program and its possibilities, who were never going to give RGGI a chance from the start.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>And there was testimony that, for someone like me growing up in the anthracite coal mining region of northeastern Pennsylvania, experiencing the death of that industry and now living in the same region still struggling through economic and social upheaval decades after coal&rsquo;s demise&hellip;well, these testimonies hit a little closer to home.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Closer to home in that the world will be changing for communities still dependent on coal jobs as most energy produced by coal goes away.&nbsp;But this time around, RGGI will be providing a glidepath with funding to underwrite any number of investments that can make a difficult transition less hard.&nbsp;For communities that take advantage of this opportunity, the future can hold promise, and not be defined by a bitter political fight where regular folks are exploited by industry players who will eventually abandon them, and their children, to an inevitable end.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As the day went on, and people made their way home from the Harrisburg hearing, climate-supercharged storm Ida turned its horror on Pennsylvania and the Northeast, killing dozens of people and laughing in the face of our man-made environment.&nbsp;Homes, businesses, transmission lines, drainage and transportation systems that have been able to endure for generations, failing. Our infrastructure cannot withstand climate impacts, and our earth&rsquo;s protective natural systems have deteriorated and are collapsing into floods, fire, and worse.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the face of a changed climate, where impacts are being felt in every part of our world, country and state, we have empathy for coal workers and their families.&nbsp;However, with climate action - the issue by which this era will be defined - and inaction of so many of our elected officials, we are holding accountable the anti-environmental politicians, the fossil fuel industry, and their lobby and public relations firms who in the face of an unleashed climate emergency:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Put profit, pipelines, petrochemicals and plastics before Pennsylvanians;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Embrace climate denial and dismiss climate reality;</li>
	<li>Abuse the power bestowed on them by the electorate who expect representation of the greater good, and instead represent special interests in breach;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Remain laser focused on&nbsp; policies and subsidies that serve coal, fracked gas and hydrogen, while neighboring states invest in climate saving renewable energy and efficiency;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>and champion corporate entitlement before environmental rights.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>This is what defines the majority of our state legislature in the alternate universe of Pennsylvania.&nbsp;We need climate leadership here.&nbsp;We need to urgently decarbonize.&nbsp;Yes, there are abundant fossil fuels here, but it&rsquo;s time to&nbsp; leave them in the ground. We need to help our workers, and re-focus our unions. And we need voters to end this lunacy.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
Philadelphia Has an Urban Planning Problem,8/25/2021,"<p>Philadelphia has an urban planning problem.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the wake of <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-IPCC-Sounds-Code-Red-Alarm-on-Climate-Crisis"">the clarion call to action</a> from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, we can no longer delay in securing a city that is clean, green, and carbon neutral. Philadelphia public officials and residents must recognize that the insatiable hunger for more pavement and impervious surface will only further exacerbate the impact of climate change that is already being felt in neighborhoods across the city.</p>

<p>I was recently afforded the opportunity to publish <a href=""https://twitter.com/amnagel1/status/1427277271132409861/photo/1"">a letter in The Philadelphia Inquirer</a> on the importance of prioritizing green space and green infrastructure in civic space related <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/real-estate/inga-saffron/south-street-district-headhouse-plaza-design-philadelphia-20210811.html"">to Inga Saffron&rsquo;s column</a> on the new Headhouse Plaza. Many have written about the obvious flaws in the design and construction of the new plaza. The space does not provide any protection from the sun or rain. It is visually unappealing and offers no physical comfort to anyone who may need it. Headhouse Plaza lacks basic amenities and offers little in the way of the forward-thinking approach necessary to urban planning as we continue to deal with a changing climate. What it lacks in vision, it is clear that the space is exactly what some neighbors lobbied for throughout the design process.</p>

<p>The architect on the project <a href=""https://www.audacy.com/kywnewsradio/news/local/new-headhouse-plaza-brings-diverging-opinions"">said this</a>: &ldquo;It started out with some more greenery, but that was sort of scaled back because of some of the near neighbors. They had concerns about greenery. <em>People didn&rsquo;t want a place where all the dogs were going to go.&rdquo;</em> (emphasis added)</p>

<p>One neighbor neatly summed up the major issue: &ldquo;We love it, it&rsquo;s a great improvement. The parking is nice. <em>We were afraid they were going to take away the parking.&rdquo;</em> (emphasis added)</p>

<p>Previously, the square contained 40 parking spaces. The new design cut the number of spaces to 30. Reducing parking was a hot topic of conversation throughout the design and construction of the new plaza. When the Art Commission <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/art-commission-approves-public-space-expansion-at-headhouse-square/"">ultimately approved the design</a>, commissioners &ldquo;&hellip;wondered if such an act would provoke controversy, as parking is the third rail of both Philadelphia city politics and urban design.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Philadelphia made significant strides <a href=""http://www.amlegal.com/pdffiles/Philadelphia/120431.pdf"">to reduce parking minimums in 2012</a>. Despite this and the efforts of other cities across the country to eliminate parking minimums entirely, we have seen attempts to reverse the progress made in Philadelphia <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/proposal-to-increase-parking-minimums-finds-no-support-from-planning-commission/"">time</a> and <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/city-council-moves-to-require-more-parking-in-philly-neighborhoods/"">time</a> again. Most recently, the Philadelphia City Planning Commission <a href=""https://www.phila2035.org/germantownnorth?fbclid=IwAR3GMLhQLwS6KioeuljtZ9lWL0N4KvVVsNNzwub65QLoHrKr2xf6jJAtiUM"">announced efforts to update zoning rules</a> in northern Germantown that would effectively mandate increased parking minimums in that area by requiring that new buildings with ten or more apartments or condos have a parking lot or garage. The city has framed this effort as part of its Philadelphia2035 comprehensive plan to manage growth and development in Philadelphia, but significantly increasing pavement and impervious surface does nothing to address the climate emergency we face in 2021 let alone the increasing heat and precipitation we must be prepared for in 2035.</p>

<p>More pavement and impervious surface will only make Philadelphia more vulnerable to warmer, wetter weather. There is <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/racism-left-hunting-park-overheated-neighbors-are-making-a-cooler-future/"">growing evidence and understanding</a> that urban spaces <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/a-coloring-book-to-inspire-solutions-for-cooling-phillys-hotter-neighborhoods/"">consistently suffer from more extreme temperatures</a> due to an absence of green space. We also know that <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/science/climate/philadelphia-trees-canopy-urban-heat-island-race-20210811.html"">racist practices like redlining</a> have disproportionately impacted communities of color as they grapple with hotter temperatures than predominantly white neighborhoods. Impervious surface also directly leads to increased polluted runoff in our water and increased flooding in our streets due to <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Its-Time-to-Reimagine-Americas-Infrastructure"">aging infrastructure that cannot properly handle a 21st century climate.</a></p>

<p>There is such a strong temptation to continue feeding the need for parking because of the powerful forces behind the parking industry and the vocal community members who do not want green space because it attracts too many dogs. Philadelphia may have been a parking diet since 2012, but it is time to quit the feeding frenzy for good. We must <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/real-estate/parking-laws-spaces-philadelphia-20210706.html"">rethink community spaces</a> and engage in processes that inform and educate about the imminent danger of climate change and the need to build more nature into our built world.</p>

<p>There are neighborhoods across Philadelphia that are suffering from urban heat island effect, and some people live in constant fear that their homes will flood every time it rains. Investments in green space and green infrastructure will help neighborhoods combat these dual threats.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Eastwick is one area <a href=""https://www.phillytrib.com/news/local_news/how-can-i-pay-for-this-eastwick-residents-struggle-to-fix-isaias-damage-without-federal/article_d1e4a326-9094-5bb9-b137-532e7ff7b608.html"">that needs help now to protect itself</a> from increased flooding and build a neighborhood that is more resilient to the effects of climate change. Neighbors are actively engaged and have been fighting for decades for investment in their community to address <a href=""https://nextcity.org/features/view/philadelphia-eastwick-neighborhood-urban-renewal-failure"">a legacy of broken promises and deliberate disinvestment.</a> Urban planning and development could serve as a model for the entire city with the proper approach and understanding of climate challenges to come.</p>

<p>Luckily, <a href=""https://issuu.com/interfacestudio/docs/lepls_final_031319"">there is already a plan</a> that broadly outlines what could be possible on city-owned land in Eastwick. While Philadelphia City Councilmember Kenyatta Johnson has taken the prudent approach to halt city development in the area, the Lower Eastwick Public Land Strategy does contain promising suggestions for additional green space and green infrastructure that should be the primary focus of any development in Eastwick.</p>

<p>PennFuture <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/councilmember-calls-for-500-million-for-to-resolve-eastwick-flooding/"">strongly supports Councilmember Johnson&rsquo;s call</a> for $500 million in federal infrastructure funding to be allocated to Philadelphia for flood mitigation efforts in Eastwick. This funding would help clear the way for natural solutions to the area&rsquo;s climate problems. Though there are certain aspects of the Lower Eastwick Public Land Strategy that <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/business/philadelphia-refinery-hilco-redevelopment-plan-soil-contamination-20200723.html"">should be discarded</a> due to other development projects in the area and their negative impact on climate readiness, the strategy points to multiple parcels that will provide open space, preserve existing wetlands, and implement green infrastructure to combat flooding.</p>

<p>Humanity has directly confronted nature with a built world for the past century &ndash; often at the expense of its most vulnerable communities. Now, we are faced with natural problems that will not be solved by <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/u-s-army-corps-and-city-water-department-say-study-on-eastwick-flooding-solutions-should-be-complete-in-october/"">levees</a>, <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/what-it-would-take-build-earthen-berm-flood-control-section-cobbs-creek-eastwick/"">earthen berms</a>, or more pavement. In the face of <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/science/tropical-storm-fred-urban-heat-island-tornado-flood-20210822.html"">growing evidence that our built world</a> is exacerbating the heat and flooding that we experience, it is time to set aside the strategies of the 19th century and adopt natural solutions for the 21st century.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This critical work will require a concerted effort from all levels of city government. It will require public officials to engage with residents, educate their constituents on the climate challenges we face, and be willing to ignore concerns about reduced parking and dogs that like trees and grass. Philadelphia <a href=""https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2021/08/19/early-1990s-heat-waves-battered-philadelphias-most-vulnerable-communities-lessons-learned-are-helping-today/?tid=ss_tw"">remains a leader in helping residents</a> deal with climate change. It is time to build on that foundation and lead the charge for green space and green infrastructure in urban planning and development.</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,"Adam Nagel, Campaign Manager"
Civilian Conservation Corps: Then and Now,8/23/2021,"<p>Earlier this month, Promised Land State Park celebrated its annual Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) Day in which the public was invited to the Masker Museum filled with live music, cake, CCC artifacts, and an honorary guest speaker, Cornelius McHugh, a former CCC worker who had just recently turned 100.</p>

<p>We learned that the Civilian Conservation Corps played a critical role healing our environment and putting Americans back to work. It was established in 1933 amidst the Dust Bowl wherein forests had been clear cut and burned, resulting in erosion and sedimentation of local streams and waterways as well as the Great Depression, in which 13 million people were suddenly unemployed due to an unregulated stock market crash.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This unique federal program established by President Franklin D. Roosevelt put 3 million single men between the ages of 18-25 to work, remedying the damage done by the poor land practices of the earlier centuries. While enrolled, some learned to read, many obtained their high school diploma and all learned a trade. Purposeful work restored a sense of values, taught essential skills and developed a work ethic among these recruits.The CCC boys fought fires, planted trees, built trails, campgrounds and roads, and helped create the beautiful Promised Land State Park in the Poconos area that so many visit today.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The CCC provided opportunities during a time without any social programs in place. Cornelius had mentioned he started his work for the CCC just five days after graduating high school. He had earned $30 a month, in which he had sent $25 back home to his family and kept $5 for himself--which he stated was efficient, especially because there were no other opportunities. In addition, the $5 he spent on cigarettes, candy, beer, and dates with local girls helped contribute to the local economy.</p>

<p>Many of the CCC boys went on to fight in WWII, and when they returned, they came home to a country that was prosperous and had conserved its natural treasures and a nationwide system of parks accessible to everyone.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Civilian Conservation Corps had been a proven success, building 800 state parks in eight years, while keeping local businesses going and families fed. The success of the CCC in rebuilding our nation has taught us that we do not turn our backs on our fellow Americans in need and that we conserve our lands and waters for future generations.&nbsp;</p>

<p>And it&rsquo;s time to bring it back, but with a modernized spin to it.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As communities in Pennsylvania and across the country continue to face devastating economic conditions as well as the effects of the climate crisis, a revitalized Civilian Conservation Corps would enable us to invest in our workforce, our environment, and the next generation of conservationists.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Earlier this year, Senator Bob Casey proposed a new bill, S.B. 2414, for a revitalized CCC that will create federal conservation jobs, support agricultural conservation and ensure we are prioritizing environmental justice communities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This bill comes after months of close collaboration with regional advocates like PennFuture and the ReImagine Appalachia coalition, to ensure that this legislation will help communities most impacted by the combined impacts of the downturn of the fossil fuel industry, the pandemic, and an ongoing opioid epidemic that has devastated families.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This CCC proposal prioritizes Black and Indigenous people, working people with low incomes, rural workers and returning citizens. Seventy million Americans&mdash;one in three adults&mdash;have a criminal record. By prioritizing these marginalized groups, a revitalized CCC could reverse the consequences of mass incarceration, by lifting barriers to the formerly incarcerated, those battling with opioid addiction, and their families.</p>

<p>Not only does this CCC proposal have a strong restorative justice component, but it will assist with carbon absorption by restoring wetlands, planting millions of diverse, native plants and trees, and removing invasive trees and shrubs. A new CCC can help farmers implement regenerative practices to restore the land by the new extractive industry practices over the last decades, potentially absorbing over 20% of all carbon emissions from the Appalachian region alone.</p>

<p>According to <a href=""https://reimagineappalachia.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/ReImagine-Appalachia_PeriBrief_PA_Jan2021.pdf"">a recent study from the Political Economy Research Institute (PERI)</a> and ReImagine Appalachia, relaunching the CCC could create 57,000 jobs in Pennsylvania. How could we pass that up?</p>

<p>This modernized Civilian Conservation Corps combines sound environmental policy with family-sustaining jobs and training. Similar to the lesson learned from the original CCC, we do not turn our backs on fellow Americans in need and must work to conserve our lands and water for future generations to come.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Annie Regan, Senior Program Manager"
IPCC Sounds ‘Code Red’ Alarm on Climate Crisis,8/13/2021,"<p>The days of climate change uncertainty are behind us. In the latest set of reports from the world&rsquo;s leading climate researchers, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change <a href=""https://www.ipcc.ch/2021/08/09/ar6-wg1-20210809-pr/"">announced that the scientific evidence</a> of human influence on widespread and rapid warming is now &ldquo;unequivocal.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>All that remains uncertain is how much of the damage is irreversible, and whether we can muster the collective political courage to slow climate change before it&rsquo;s too late. Failure to reduce emissions will create, in the words of one climate researcher, <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2021/aug/10/code-red-for-humanity-what-the-papers-say-about-the-ipcc-report-on-the-climate-crisis"">&ldquo;hell on earth.&rdquo;</a><br />
&nbsp;<br />
Climate policies such as <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fallacy-Fiction-and-Falsehoods-Debunking-RGGI-Myths-Part-1"">the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative</a> are crucially important because we still have a window of opportunity to slow the pace of warming. Failure to reduce emissions in the next few years will force upon future generations an environment that is very&nbsp;hot, wet and dangerous, barely resembling the world as we know it today.</p>

<p>The &ldquo;Physical Science Basis&rdquo; is the first release in a series of landmark summary findings to be rolled out in the next year. To develop the international body&rsquo;s Sixth Assessment Report, hundreds of climate researchers reviewed all the relevant scientific literature published since 2013.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The IPCC assessment reached the following conclusions:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Humans are responsible for warming global surface temperatures by an estimated average of 1.07 degrees Celsius (1.9 degrees Fahrenheit) above preindustrial levels.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Global climate change is due to a buildup of greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere, now reaching annual averages of 410 parts per million (ppm) for carbon dioxide (CO2), 1,866 parts per billion (ppb) for methane (CH4), and 332 ppb for nitrous oxide (N2O).</li>
	<li>Concentrations of atmospheric pollution have reached historic highs. CO2 levels are higher than at any time in at least 2 million years, while methane and N2O are higher than at any time in at least 800,000 years.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>As a result, each of the last four decades has been successively warmer than any decade that preceded it, dating back to temperatures recorded in 1850.</li>
	<li>Climate change is very likely compounding our risks of extreme events such as heatwaves, droughts, fire, and heavy floods, as well as intensifying global trends of sea level rise, ocean acidification, and glacial retreat.</li>
</ul>

<p>Although the severity of climate change will be experienced unevenly around the world, no region will be totally unaffected. In the eastern half of North America, the assessment <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Updated-Climate-Change-Assessment-Reveals-Future-Pennsylvania-Water-Troubles"">concludes that significant increases in heavy precipitation</a> and flooding are both very likely, especially if current levels of emissions continue.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Essentially, the clock is ticking. We can release less than 500 additional gigatons of carbon dioxide &mdash; roughly equal to 10 years of current global emissions &mdash; if we want a decent chance of limiting warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit). So far, we&rsquo;re on pace to pass the 1.5-degree mark by the early 2030s.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
In Pennsylvania, joining RGGI would cost-effectively mandate limits on carbon emissions by allowing electricity generation producers to cooperate with counterparts across the Northeast. To put RGGI into motion, the CO2 Budget Trading Program has been proposed by the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP). But the program is still awaiting Independent Regulatory Review Commission (IRRC) approval, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-What-Comes-Next-in-Pennsylvanias-Efforts-to-Join-RGG"">the current step in a 19-month (and counting) regulatory process.</a></p>

<p>While progress on joining RGGI is a welcomed development, the latest IPCC report makes clear that delay comes with serious consequences. Regulatory hurdles help polluting industries continue to profit while devastating climate change awaits.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
On the federal level, <a href=""https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/3684"">the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act</a> offers a once-in-a-generation opportunity to combat climate change. The current version of the recently passed Senate bill would, if passed by the House of Representatives, upgrade our power infrastructure to better accommodate renewable energy, develop a national network of electric vehicle chargers, and support school districts with buying electric buses and building out the necessary charging infrastructure.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Still, more is needed. The FY 2022 <a href=""https://www.democrats.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/MEMORANDUM%20for%20Democratic%20Senators%20-%20FY2022%20Budget%20Resolution.pdf"">Budget Resolution Agreement</a> being discussed in Congress has included proposals for a Clean Electricity Payment Program. If passed through reconciliation, the legislation would incentivize electric utilities to transition to 80-percent clean energy by 2030.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
This kind of bold leadership is needed at every level of government and throughout the private sector. By now, each and every municipality, school district, business, and property owner in Pennsylvania needs to wake up to the realities of our climate crisis. Rather than wait and deal with the consequences, it is time to embrace readily available energy efficiency, clean electricity and low-carbon transportation options.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Transitioning to a clean energy future is necessary if we want to avert the worst outcomes of a warming climate. We simply do not have time to waste.</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
Chasing Bitcoin is a Bad Investment for Pennsylvania,8/12/2021,"<p>On August 9th, 2021, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) <a href=""https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/#SPM"">released its Sixth Assessment report</a>, clearly linking human-caused climate change to the extreme heatwaves and severe weather events we see all around the world.&nbsp;While it&rsquo;s not too late to avoid the most severe effects, the situation is projected to get even worse without immediate action to cut carbon pollution.</p>

<p>Against that backdrop, it is shocking that our state government is continuing to force Pennsylvanians to not only suffer the consequences of climate change but to pay polluters massive subsidies that will result in even more emissions. Invariably these unsustainable businesses are boom-and-bust.&nbsp;They take the higher profits while they can, before leaving PA taxpayers to pay to clean up their mess.</p>

<p>PennFuture has written extensively on how this subsidy-then-bust process is propping up fracking and petrochemical businesses in Pennsylvania. This pattern can also be found in the incredibly dirty waste coal industry, but now with an unlikely partner&mdash;Bitcoin. One recent example is Stronghold Digital Mining&mdash;a new firm that repurposes dirty waste-coal burning power plants to mine the cryptocurrency known as bitcoin.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In late July 2021, <a href=""https://sec.report/Document/0001564590-21-038087/#BUSINESS"">Stronghold filed a form S-1</a> with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosing information about the business and its finances.&nbsp;They report that they currently own and operate the Scrubgrass waste coal plant in Venango County, have a definitive agreement for the Panther Creek plant in Carbon County, and a letter of intent to purchase a third plant&mdash;all for the purpose of bitcoin mining.&nbsp; Unlike the fracking and petrochemical industry, Stronghold is at least open about the fact that their business model requires significant taxpayer subsidies for it to be viable.</p>

<p><u>Bitcoin is an energy intensive process and a growing carbon polluter</u></p>

<p>The Bitcoin Network as a whole consumes a tremendous amount of energy to run millions of special-purpose computers&mdash;known as application-specific integrated circuits or ASICs&mdash;that attempt to &ldquo;mine&rdquo; new blocks in the bitcoin blockchain. To create a new block these computers race to find a special number that, combined with the financial transactions and other data recorded in the block, gives a result that meets specific criteria.&nbsp;This is a trial-and-error process that is akin to picking the winning lottery number, but much more difficult, often taking trillions of attempts to find a working number.&nbsp;At the time of this writing, finding the special number might earn the winning miner nearly $300,000 worth of bitcoins. But, if someone else finds the number first, losing&nbsp;miners get nothing and must start the process from scratch.&nbsp;To be competitive, miners build vast data centers containing potentially thousands of ASIC miners, each testing many trillion of these hashes every second.</p>

<p>According to data from the <a href=""https://cbeci.org/"">Cambridge Bitcoin Energy Consumption Index</a>, the network currently takes over 9 gigawatts (GW) of power to operate and could be as high as 35GW.&nbsp; Even at the low end of that range, that is enough electricity for over seven million houses.&nbsp; Stronghold, for its part, reports that they currently operate 1,840 miners that can cumulatively test around 85 thousand-trillion hashes per second (85 PH/S) and draw about 4.1 Megawatts (MW) of power&mdash;enough to supply over 3,000 average houses.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Bottom line: it takes an obscene amount of energy to mine bitcoin and now companies are looking to power that mining by buying up cheap, dirty, outdated power plants just to run the computers to do the mining. In the case of Stronghold, this power is coming from the Scrubgrass waste-coal power plant and, based on their 2019 emissions data, the existing mining is likely resulting in over 6 tons of CO2 being emitted every hour.&nbsp;That&rsquo;s more than 6,700 vehicle-miles worth of pollution.&nbsp;</p>

<p>That is bad enough, but Stronghold reports it has a definitive agreement to buy the Panther Creek waste-coal plant and has signed a letter of intent to purchase a third plant.&nbsp;In all, they are forecasting acquiring 57,000 miners by the end of 2022 and consuming 193 MW of electricity.&nbsp;The exact pollution rate depends on how these miners are split among the three plants, but it may be in the range of 278 tons per hour of CO2.&nbsp;Also, because this is new demand on the grid, other generators may end up increasing their output&mdash;and their pollution&mdash;to meet the demand that these plants will no longer serve.&nbsp;That could easily add another 25 tons of CO2 per hour&mdash;more than 30,000 vehicle-miles worth of emissions&mdash;and possibly much higher .</p>

<p><u>Stronghold Digital Mining&rsquo;s business model is an environmental nightmare</u></p>

<p>Stronghold is selling its business model to investors as environmental progress&mdash;it&rsquo;s purchasing waste coal plants to power its cryptocurrency mining while removing culm piles that scar Pennsylvania&rsquo;s landscapes and communities. Unfortunately, this is a classic case of greenwashing.</p>

<p>Coal-fired power plants are all notoriously dirty, but waste coal facilities are even worse.&nbsp;In addition to CO2, the Scrubgrass plant&rsquo;s most recent emissions report shows hundreds of tons of sulfur dioxide, oxides of nitrogen, hydrochloric acid, carbon monoxide, and more than a dozen other air pollutants including neurotoxins, carcinogens, and smog-forming compounds.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In addition, the Trump administration <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Trump-Administration-Rolls-Back-Air-Protections-from-Fossil-Fuel-Plants"">rolled back critical air quality protections for waste-coal plants</a> (although PennFuture and others have challenged this).&nbsp;While Stronghold claims that their operation is &ldquo;environmentally beneficial&rdquo; because it burns waste coal from piles that are currently polluting the land, they barely mention the very real public health and financial damages caused by increased air pollution and don&rsquo;t consider any alternatives to digging them up and burning them.&nbsp;Even if one believes that some waste piles are so dangerous that the damage and pollution from burning them could be justified, there is no guarantee these are the ones that will be used.</p>

<p>Waste coal is always dirty, but the bitcoin industry has an additional waste stream we should be concerned about&mdash;tons of electronics waste from thousands of obsolete ASICs.&nbsp;Because of the competitive nature of Bitcoin mining, the hardware has a very limited useful life&mdash;in some cases as short as 18 months&mdash;before new hardware renders it obsolete. We see this in Stronghold&rsquo;s own filing with many of their miners requiring 1,300 watts to calculate 13 trillion hashes per second (TH/s) where newer devices work three times as fast for the same power.&nbsp;As highly optimized &ldquo;application specific&rdquo; devices, there is little chance that any obsolete devices will be reused.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Pennsylvanians are, once again, being forced to subsidize pollution without any say</u></p>

<p>Another obvious problem with burning waste coal is the expense.&nbsp;The reason why coal plants are closing across the country is because they can&rsquo;t compete with cheaper gas-fired power plants and even cheaper clean renewable energy.&nbsp;A recent study on <a href=""https://www.lazard.com/perspective/lcoe2020"">the levelized cost of energy</a> (LCOE) shows coal costing more than $65 per megawatt-hour (MWh).&nbsp;Gas might be as low as $44/MWh and renewable energy can be as low as $26/MWh.&nbsp;Compared to a traditional coal plant like Homer City&mdash;which itself has faced bankruptcy&mdash;Scrubgrass needs to burn more than three times as much fuel for the same generation.&nbsp;Even with low-quality fuel that costs roughly half as much, it&rsquo;s clear that waste coal is never going to be the cheapest source of energy.</p>

<p>Stronghold claims that fuel costs, operational and maintenance costs, and administrative expenses to operate Scrubgrass will result in power costing $43/MWh.&nbsp;That seems very optimistic since the company reported $17,629,051 in total 2019 operating expenses in the S-1 filing and 239,191 MWh of generation reported to the Energy Information Administration.&nbsp;That&nbsp;suggests actual costs over $73/MWh. The S-1 lists income from energy sales for the period of just over $29/MWh, which is slightly higher than the PJM grid average of $25/MWh, but it also shows a $6 million operating loss on $7 million in energy sales, so real costs operating the facilities are likely much higher than their sales suggest.</p>

<p>Even if the company can bring the operating costs down to 43/MWh, it&rsquo;s still a big leap to go to the $18/MWh Stronghold claims they expect to pay for power going forward.&nbsp;To get to that number requires significant state subsidies.</p>

<p><em>Subsidy #1:&nbsp; PJM Capacity Over-procurement</em></p>

<p>First, Stronghold expects to receive $6/MWh from the PJM capacity market.&nbsp;This is a separate payment, in addition to the purchase of energy, that our electric grid operator makes to ensure sufficient generation capacity will be available in the future. Companies get these payments if they bid low enough to clear the capacity auction and are available to be dispatched in the delivery year.&nbsp;Over-procurement of capacity has historically acted as a subsidy for fossil fuels, but for 2022/23 <a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/experts/tom-rutigliano/how-save-four-billion-without-really-trying"">PJM procured much less capacity</a> resulting in a market clearing price of&nbsp; $50/MW-day, or about $1.7 million dollars a year for a plant like Scrubgrass.&nbsp;With payments that low, the only way they will receive $6.00/MWh is if the facility only ran at 35% capacity.&nbsp;There would be no reason to purchase two additional waste coal plants if Scrubgrass had that much spare capacity, so the company must be counting on capacity prices in the future well over $100/MW-day.&nbsp;That may have been common in the past, but there is no guarantee payments will return to that level. If true though, this implies billions of dollars in additional payments will come from the pockets of ratepayers.</p>

<p><em>Subsidy #2:&nbsp; Tier II Alternative Energy Credits</em></p>

<p>While most states have &ldquo;Renewable&rdquo; portfolio standards, Pennsylvania has an Alternative Energy Portfolio Standard (AEPS) program that subsidizes polluting resources like waste coal under what is called Tier II.&nbsp;In 2019, Tier II credits were not particularly valuable averaging only $0.31/MWh of generation statewide. Scrubgrass did better than average reporting $105,532 from this source or $0.41/MWh, but going forward, their prospectus estimates a huge jump to&nbsp; $15/MWh for these credits.</p>

<p>In 2020, our legislature changed the rules to the AEPS program restricting where Tier II credits could be generated.&nbsp;Instead of coming from a qualifying facility anywhere in the PJM grid&mdash;an area covering all or part of 13 states and the District of Columbia, those credits will largely need to be generated within Pennsylvania.&nbsp;Prices are expected to spike as a result and, in fact, 2020 credits already shot up to $1.92 before this change was finalized costing ratepayers over $21 million.</p>

<p>We don&rsquo;t have a clear indication how high these prices will actually go, but this doesn&rsquo;t appear to have been a significant concern for the Legislature, and it certainly didn&rsquo;t stop them. If prices actually go up to $15 per credit, it would cost Pennsylvania ratepayers an additional $168 million. That is not only far more that we pay for cleaner wind and solar credits, it is more than the entire AEPS program cost in 2020.</p>

<p><em>Subsidy #3:&nbsp; Coal Refuse Reclamation tax credit</em></p>

<p>The next handout Pennsylvanian&rsquo;s are providing these plants comes in the form of the Coal Refuse Reclamation (CRR) tax credit.&nbsp;This is a transferable credit of $4 for each ton of waste coal these facilities burn. Perversely, this means a plant&nbsp; burning dirtier and lower quality fuel gets a bigger handout per megawatt hour. While the original tax credit was capped at $10 million, our legislature again dug into the pockets of ratepayers in late 2020 doubling the cap to $20 million.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>While currently the $4/MWh Stronghold expects to receive from this subsidy is reasonable for a facility like Scrubgrass, the $20 million cap may already be fully utilized.&nbsp;That means that if the company expands to three facilities and runs at higher capacity like they claim, there will be proportionally fewer credits available per megawatt hour in the future.&nbsp;That makes their claims in the prospectus suspect, but there has already been talk in our legislature about raising the cap on this handout yet again&mdash;that would mean higher profits for these polluters.&nbsp;</p>

<p><em>Subsidy #4:&nbsp; RGGI Allowance Set-asides</em></p>

<p>At the same time we are giving significant handouts to buy more pollution, Governor Wolf has directed the Department of Environmental protection to move forward with programs to begin to address the climate crisis.&nbsp;One of these is the CO2 Budget Trading Rule through which Pennsylvania will participate with the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI).&nbsp;This program sets a cap for allowable carbon pollution from electric generation and requires that facilities purchase an allowance for each ton of CO2 they emit.</p>

<p>Facing significant pressure from the legislature, this program included&mdash;and then expanded&mdash;yet another handout for waste coal generation.&nbsp;The program sets aside 12.8 million allowances that, if needed, will be given to waste coal generation for free.&nbsp;As a result, waste coal facilities can nearly double their 2019 generation and dump all the resulting pollution in the air without paying the fees other polluters must pay.&nbsp;Of course, the citizens of Pennsylvania will still pay the price for increased pollution and we will all suffer the worsening effects of climate change if we don&rsquo;t focus on cutting harmful emissions.</p>

<p><u>Chasing bitcoin is a bad investment for Pennsylvania</u></p>

<p>After totaling up all the subsidies, Stronghold claims it will only be paying $18 per megawatt-hour of electricity&mdash;or $11/MWh less than average on our power grid.&nbsp;That is an amazingly low rate, if true, but it&rsquo;s far from a sure thing.&nbsp;Their projections are based on about $16 in direct handouts for each ton of waste coal they burn, plus free carbon allowances that may be worth in the neighborhood of $8 per ton.</p>

<p>Even if the company receives all of those handouts, it still may not be able to operate as cheaply as they claim.&nbsp;In addition to these highly optimistic predictions, they are relying on indirect subsidies in the form of weak regulation&mdash;specifically that the EPA will not correct the abuses of the Trump administration, which weakened the Mercury and Air Toxics Standards, among other rules.</p>

<p>Those cheap operating costs also have a big price.&nbsp;They neglect the very real costs of public health and environmental damage caused by the excess air pollution&mdash;particularly in the vulnerable communities near these plants.&nbsp;The negative externalities these plants cause but don&rsquo;t pay for, when reduced to dollar values, the citizens of Pennsylvania paying for all these damages could end up being the single largest subsidy the facility receives.</p>

<p>Even if we pay the high prices and accept all the harms, this isn&rsquo;t a sustainable long-term business model.&nbsp;By design, the number of bitcoins one receives for mining a new block decreases over time and, if the value of each coin rises, the competition only gets more intense.&nbsp;This creates a highly-competitive industry with miners flocking to wherever electricity is cheap.&nbsp;Even if sites like Scrubgrass make sense today, things can change quickly if we don&rsquo;t keep ramping up the handouts.</p>

<p>There is a better way.&nbsp;According to <a href=""https://arippa.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/ARIPPA-Report-FINAL-June-2019.pd"">the waste coal industry&rsquo;s own numbers</a>, proper disposal of the waste piles would only cost $33 per ton and other options, such as stabilizing the piles by planting beach grass, could be far cheaper.&nbsp;Instead of forcing Pennsylvanians to hand over their hard-earned money to an industry that turns one form of pollution into another, we should be putting people to work actually solving the problem of coal waste.</p>

<p>If Stronghold wants to truly be a sustainable and environmentally beneficial company, it should ditch dirty coal and source its energy from cheaper, scalable, and rapidly growing renewable energy.&nbsp;If not, it&rsquo;s no better than the other major polluters in Pennsylvania or the failed coal companies that left these mountains of waste coal behind in the first place.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
"PennFuture, Partners Challenge DEP's Approval of Renovo Energy Center",8/10/2021,"<p>If we are truly committed to moving to a renewable energy economy, rather than a fossil-fuel based economy, the first step is to stop building new fossil fuel infrastructure.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Unfortunately, Pennsylvania is struggling with that first step.&nbsp; The Department of Environmental Protection recently approved the application for the construction of the <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/About/Regional/North-central-Regional-Office/Community-Information/Pages/Renovo-Energy-Center-.aspx"">Renovo Energy Center</a>, a proposed 1240-megawatt gas-fired power plant in Clinton County PA. If completed, this facility will be one of ten largest emitters of carbon pollution fossil-fuel power plants in Pennsylvania and could emit more than two million tons of carbon pollution every year. Any new polluting industry in PA poses a threat, but with the ever-worsening climate crisis the time for completing a clean energy transition is running out.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As a result, PennFuture and our partners, Clean Air Council and the Center for Biological Diversity, <a href=""https://ehb.courtapps.com/efile/documentViewer.php?documentID=52766"">are challenging the DEP&rsquo;s issuance of this approval</a> to the Renovo Energy Center. We believe that some of DEP&rsquo;s own policies were violated in approving this plant. Among other issues, we contend that DEP failed to follow its own Environmental Justice Participation Policy and misapplied analyses regarding best available control technology (BACT) as well as required cost-benefit analyses. We also allege that DEP violated Article I, Section 27, of the PA Constitution, also known as the Environmental Rights Amendment.</p>

<p>First, we contend in our challenge that DEP failed to properly take into account that this plant is slated to be in an environmental justice (EJ). These communities, <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/PublicParticipation/OfficeofEnvironmentalJustice/Pages/PA-Environmental-Justice-Areas.aspx"">defined in Pennsylvania</a> as &ldquo;any census tract where 20 percent or more individuals live at or below the federal poverty line, and/or 30 percent or more of the population identifies as a non-white minority,&rdquo; have long been subjected to environmental racism. Industrial facilities are usually built among poor or minority communities, leaving them at higher risk of water and air pollution from the facilities.</p>

<p>Furthermore, across the globe, these communities are often the ones being hid the hardest by the climate crisis. The Renovo plant not only will create industrial pollution in this community but will also further contribute to climate change, which is already harming vulnerable populations the most. The Department&rsquo;s own <a href=""http://www.depgreenport.state.pa.us/elibrary/GetDocument?docId=7918&amp;DocName=ENVIRONMENTAL%20JUSTICE%20PUBLIC%20PARTICIPATION%20POLICY.PDF%20"">environmental justice public participation policy</a> was implemented to increase engagement in these communities and ensure they have a say in the developments that occur in their neighborhoods. This policy includes meetings with local community stakeholders, distribution of information about proposed projects in a manner accessible to members of the local community, and formal and informal public meetings where community members can seek answers and voice their concerns. Unfortunately, these steps do not seem to have been taken here, and the DEP has authorized the Renovo plant to be built without following its own policy to consult with the local community.</p>

<p>Second, we contend that DEP did not properly conduct the required BACT analysis to determine the &ldquo;best available control technology.&rdquo; The analysis requires proposals to consider whether there are any other options that are cleaner and more efficient that will adequately meet the needs of the facility. However, for this facility, the only analysis that was conducted was to compare turbines from three different manufacturers and choose the one with the lowest overall emissions. However, this approach lumps together different categories of emissions, and emissions of different chemicals are not all the same. We contend that this was against the requirements of BACT.</p>

<p>Third, cost benefit analyses are an important step in the permitting process and have long been required under state and federal law. However, in the permitting for the Renovo plant, these analyses failed to consider the public harms of plant. One prime example is the social cost of carbon and other greenhouse gases. The &ldquo;social cost&rdquo; is a way of estimating the harm that something will do and the eventual expense of remediating it. The Biden administration <a href=""https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/cost-of-carbon-pollution-pegged-at-51-a-ton/"">has set the social cost of carbon at $51 a ton</a>, methane at $1500 a ton and nitrous oxide at $18000 a ton. Numbers such as these must be considered when estimating the &ldquo;costs&rdquo; of the plant in order to have an accurate cost benefit analysis, yet this part of the process was sorely lacking.</p>

<p>Lastly, we assert that the construction of this new plant is a violation of Pennsylvania citizens&rsquo; rights under Article I, Section 27 of the state constitution, <a href=""https://blogs.law.widener.edu/envirolawcenter/files/2010/03/PA_Citizens_Guide_to_Art_I_Sect_27.pdf"">known as the Environmental Rights Amendment (ERA)</a>. Under the ERA, &ldquo;The people have a right to clean air, pure water, and to the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic and esthetic values of the environment. Pennsylvania&#39;s public natural resources are the common property of all the people, including generations yet to come. As trustee of these resources, the Commonwealth shall conserve and maintain them for the benefit of all the people.&rdquo; This means that only do Pennsylvania citizens have a guaranteed right to clean air, but so do the future residents and citizens of Pennsylvania who have not even been born yet. Air pollution from this plant and the ever-present threat of climate change poses a serious threat of these guaranteed rights. As an agent of the commonwealth, DEP has a responsibility to protect and maintain these rights, not permit them to be trampled by industrial pollution.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This proposed plant is important because not only will it contribute pollution directly into the environment of Renovo and Clinton County, but it also perpetuates use of fracked gas and the corresponding carbon emissions.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania, in fact, <a href=""https://www.puc.pa.gov/General/publications_reports/pdf/EPO_2019.pdf"">already exports a quarter of the power generated here</a>, so any energy generated by this facility will not benefit the people of the Commonwealth who will be most harmed by the project. Pennsylvania could be a leader of the green energy economy and move away from dirty gas plants such as this.&nbsp; It is critical we do not waste that chance by continuing to support dangerous fracked gas plants. By challenging DEP&rsquo;s approval of the Renovo Energy Center, PennFuture continues the fight for a greener, cleaner environment for all.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Daniela Rakhlina-Powsner, Legal Intern"
What You Won't Hear During the Aug. 17 Public Hearing on Pipelines in Pennsylvania,8/9/2021,"<p>The Pennsylvania House of Representatives&rsquo; Environmental Resources &amp; Energy Committee has announced a <a href=""https://paenvironmentdaily.blogspot.com/2021/08/house-environmental-committee-sets-aug.html"">&ldquo;Public Hearing on Environmental and Economic Benefits of Pipelines&rdquo;</a> scheduled for August 17, 2021. However, even the quickest of research would show that Pennsylvania&rsquo;s pipelines have not been environmentally friendly, economically sustainable, safe, or at all &ldquo;beneficial&rdquo; to the average&nbsp;citizen.</p>

<p>Nearly two years ago to the day of this writing, PennFuture&rsquo;s blog highlighted <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-The-Problem-with-Pipelines"">&ldquo;The Problem with Pipelines,&rdquo;</a> which listed what amounted to nearly 100 violations placed by the PA Department of Environmental Protection and over $13 million in fines on the Mariner East II pipeline. This aforementioned pipeline was constructed by Texas-based Energy Transfer, the group behind the infamous Dakota Access Pipeline. Since the writing of that blog post, <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/hearing-on-mariner-east-2-reroute-shows-public-rifts-persist-over-pipeline-project/"">the violations have now reached 121</a> and exceeded $15 million in total fines due to its continued leaks of drilling mud, disturbance to local water wells, pollution of water bodies, and the creation of sinkholes.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Mariner East II represents a fraction of <a href=""http://pasenategop.com/consumer/wp-content/uploads/sites/34/2018/03/Chairman-Brown-Testimony.pdf"">the 81,213 miles of pipelines in Pennsylvania</a>, which includes gas distribution mains (48,139 miles), natural gas distribution services (28,933 miles), natural gas gathering lines (799 miles), natural gas transmission lines (1,275 miles) and hazardous liquids (2,067 miles). This does not include the <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2015/08/04/unmapped-unregulated-maze-of-rural-pipelines-poses-hidden-risks/"">tens of thousands of miles of unmapped natural gas gathering lines</a> vulnerable to being hit by construction equipment.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Environmentally Unfriendly</u></p>

<p>Pipeline leaks and explosions are common in Pennsylvania, leading to harmful effects on the environment.</p>

<p>Between March 16 (the start of the first COVID-19 lockdown in PA) and September 2020, the Mariner East II pipeline alone <a href=""https://www.fractracker.org/2020/09/mariner-east-2-causes-dozens-of-spills-since-lockdown-300-in-total/"">was responsible for 36 spills</a>, releasing over 10,000 gallons of drilling fluid&mdash;most of which poured into Marsh Creek Lake in Marsh Creek State Park. This adds to the total 344,590 &ndash; 405,990 known gallons spilled into the environment since the beginning of the pipeline&rsquo;s construction in 2017.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2016, a natural gas pipeline in Westmoreland County <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/local/westmoreland/2016/04/29/Emergency-crews-respond-to-gas-well-explosion-in-Westmoreland-County-pennsylvania/stories/201604290161"">exploded and injured one person</a> while destroying 40 acres of farmland and causing property damage.</p>

<p>In 2018, the then-brand new Revolution&nbsp;pipeline <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2021/03/02/revolution-pipeline-part-of-which-exploded-in-2018-is-back-in-service/"">exploded in Beaver County</a>, causing property and natural resource damage, and has so far resulted in fines and penalties of over $30 million by DEP.</p>

<p>Last year,&nbsp;Attorney General Josh Shapiro <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/science/pennsylvania-fracking-hydraulic-fracturing-attorney-general-josh-shapiro-20200625.html"">released a grand jury report on the entire fracked gas industry</a> in Pennsylvania. This report showed the harmful effects of the toxic waste produced by the industry, including the harmful effects of the drilling process which resulted in physical illnesses on nearby residents and water contamination in the form of black sludge clogging well-water pumps that cost homeowners thousands of dollars to fix.</p>

<p>Recently, the Agronomic Crops Network at Ohio State University <a href=""https://agcrops.osu.edu/newsletter/corn-newsletter/24-2021/does-pipeline-installation-have-lasting-effect-crop-yields"">released a study</a> showing that nearby crop yields decreased once pipelines were installed. Specifically, &ldquo;corn grain yields decreased an average of 23.8%, silage corn decreased an average of 28.8%, and soybean yield decreased an average of 7.4% over the pipeline compared with adjacent areas.&rdquo; Pennsylvania State University <a href=""https://extension.psu.edu/calculating-crop-damage-payments-in-natural-gas-pipeline-negotiations"">released a similar report in 2015.</a></p>

<p>And this is just a sample of some of the most destructive catastrophes caused by pipeline construction and operation; it doesn&rsquo;t include the thousands of stream crossings, miles of forest clearcutting, and smaller but no less harmful spills across the Commonwealth.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Economically Unsustainable</u></p>

<p>Pipeline mileage in Pennsylvania <a href=""https://files.dep.state.pa.us/ProgramIntegration/PITF/Meetings/9-23-15/Pipeline%20Development%20-%20Strategies%20and%20Tools%20to%20Minimize%20Landscape%20Impacts.pdf"">is set to quadruple between 2015 and 2030</a>, despite the known continued harmful effects on people and the environment and <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=47076"">signs of a slowing down</a> and possible decrease in consumption through 2050.</p>

<p>Greener, more environmentally friendly energy alternatives are already proving to not only be both <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2020/01/21/renewable-energy-prices-hit-record-lows-how-can-utilities-benefit-from-unstoppable-solar-and-wind/?sh=5128549c2c84"">cost effective for producers and consumers</a>, but also offer <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimmagill/2020/10/26/oil-gas-vs-clean-energy-which-will-have-best-jobs-in-the-future/?sh=51d9704c5738"">higher-paying wages</a> for those in the green energy job sector.</p>

<p>More on the former point, <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=42495"">U.S. Energy Information Administration&rsquo;s (EIA) data</a> predicted solar and wind energy would dominate America&rsquo;s new energy generation in 2020. EIA also projected natural gas generation <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=42497"">to only grow 1.3% in 2020</a> &ndash; the slowest rate since 2017 &ndash; while non-hydropower renewable energy generation will grow 15% in 2020, the fastest rate in four years. Early, actual 2020 reports <a href=""https://www.irena.org/newsroom/pressreleases/2021/Apr/World-Adds-Record-New-Renewable-Energy-Capacity-in-2020"">are beginning to show that solar, wind, and other renewable energy sources</a> &ldquo;beat earlier estimates and all previous records despite the economic slowdown that resulted from the COVID-19 pandemic...exceeding expansion in 2019 by close to 50 percent.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Over the last decade, wind energy prices have fallen 70% and solar photovoltaics have fallen 89% on average, <a href=""https://www.lazard.com/perspective/lcoe2019"">according to a 2019 report</a>. Utility-scale renewable energy prices are now <a href=""https://energyinnovation.org/2018/01/22/renewable-energy-levelized-cost-of-energy-already-cheaper-than-fossil-fuels-and-prices-keep-plunging/"">significantly below those for coal and gas generation</a>. Experts and analysts <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2020/06/09/plunging-renewable-energy-prices-mean-us-can-hit-90-clean-electricity-by-2035at-no-extra-cost/?sh=54f12a7d2f9b"">have claimed that</a>, with wind, solar, and storage prices <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2020/01/21/renewable-energy-prices-hit-record-lows-how-can-utilities-benefit-from-unstoppable-solar-and-wind/#7cbce6f2c84e"">falling at such a fast rate</a>, the United States can reach 90% clean electricity by 2035&nbsp;without raising customer costs at all from today&rsquo;s levels, and actually decreasing wholesale power costs 10%. In other words, renewable energy sources <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2019/03/26/the-coal-cost-crossover-74-of-us-coal-plants-now-more-expensive-than-new-renewables-86-by-2025/#7f5abb5322d9"">are now cheaper than the average cost to operate coal</a>, the average cost <a href=""https://rmi.org/the-climate-opportunity-of-clean-energy-portfolios/"">to build new natural gas sites</a>, and can be great for the consumer&rsquo;s bottom line.</p>

<p>On the latter point, compared with jobs in the coal, natural gas and petroleum industries, jobs in solar and wind <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimmagill/2020/10/26/oil-gas-vs-clean-energy-which-will-have-best-jobs-in-the-future/?sh=51d9704c5738"">pay about 50 cents more</a>, and this industry is only at the beginning of its ascendancy. Specifically, wind and solar electricians -- HVAC technicians, mechanics, welders and assemblers -- <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimmagill/2020/10/26/oil-gas-vs-clean-energy-which-will-have-best-jobs-in-the-future/?sh=51d9704c5738"">get paid $2.50 more than their counterparts</a> in the coal and gas industry. Clean energy jobs are more likely to be union jobs than jobs across the economy as a whole &ndash; <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimmagill/2020/10/26/oil-gas-vs-clean-energy-which-will-have-best-jobs-in-the-future/?sh=51d9704c5738"">9 percent versus 6 percent</a> &ndash; which correlates to higher pay and better benefits.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As America faces an economy post-COVID 19, the green energy sector presents an avenue to create jobs on a massive, interstate scale <a href=""https://www.brookings.edu/blog/the-avenue/2020/09/10/how-clean-energy-jobs-can-power-an-equitable-covid-19-recovery/"">that includes a diverse workforce of people</a> with varying levels of education and skillset. Such a new economy cannot be realized without proper investment, and Pennsylvania, facing the brunt of the dying fossil fuel industry, is the perfect place to rise to the moment and invest.</p>

<p><u>Unbeneficial to the Public&nbsp;</u></p>

<p>In addition to being bad for the environment and being economically unsustainable, these pipelines are not beneficial to the general public.</p>

<p>One analysis showed that <a href=""https://www.spotlightpa.org/news/2020/10/pa-mariner-east-pipeline-accident-emergency-plans-investigation/"">as many as 345,000 people live close enough</a> to the Mariner East pipeline system alone to be affected by a leak or serious explosion. Pipelines are consistently built and expanded <a href=""https://www.bayjournal.com/news/energy/pipeline-projects-draw-criticism-for-environmental-racism/article_99af061e-a98e-11ea-bcdf-33bf50122f39.html"">in areas where poorer individuals live</a>, including poorer whites, but especially Black, and other minority communities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Instead of celebrating pipelines and pretending that they do not lead to catastrophic harm to people and the environment, we should be examining how to phase them out and phase Pennsylvania into the newer, greener economy emerging nationally&nbsp;and worldwide. At the very least, we must be discussing ways to secure populations living near these pipelines a level of compensation for when disaster strikes due to these pipelines.</p>

<p>Unlike what is necessary to own a home or a vehicle, operators of pipelines carrying gasoline, natural gas, natural gas liquids and other hazardous and explosive substances <a href=""https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vzM4MwrRlTBlCq3-XnOdeCdrt4UxbtHuSNeyRbvAK5Y/edit"">are not required by law to have insurance</a> or <a href=""https://ohiorivervalleyinstitute.org/railroaded-by-the-gas-industry/"">a financial assurance plan</a>. One policy analysis postures that pipeline insurance would 1) ensure that financial resources exist to compensate injured parties; and 2) grant injured third parties access to remuneration without having to resort to costly litigation. Such insurance is not unusual, as similar environmental programs require insurance-type coverage for <a href=""http://www.pacodeandbulletin.gov/Display/pacode?file=/secure/pacode/data/025/chapter86/s86.168.html&amp;d=reduce"">surface coal mine operators</a>, <a href=""http://www.pacodeandbulletin.gov/Display/pacode?file=/secure/pacode/data/025/chapter90/chap90toc.html&amp;d="">coal refuse disposal areas</a>, and <a href=""http://www.depgreenport.state.pa.us/elibrary/GetDocument?docId=3480118&amp;DocName=PROCESSING%20AND%20BENEFICIAL%20USE%20OF%20OIL%20AND%20GAS%20LIQUID%20WASTE.PDF%20%20%3Cspan%20style%3D%22color%3Agreen%3B%22%3E%3C%2Fspan%3E%20%3Cspan%20style%3D%22color%3Ablue%3B%22%3E(NEW)%3C%2Fspan%3E"">oil and gas well drilling wastewater treatment facilities</a>, just to name a few. This coverage is especially important as Mariner East II and other pipelines have a long and constantly growing track record of explosions and leaks.</p>

<p>The perceived, fabricated, economic &ldquo;benefits&rdquo; of pipelines cannot be mentioned without also highlighting pipelines&rsquo; proclivity to wreak havoc and destruction on our communities, as well as our shared environment and natural resources. It is clear that pipelines are unfriendly to the lands of Pennsylvania we call home, unsustainable economically as the world chases greener alternatives -- a new economy that Pennsylvania could take the lead in with proper investment, and harmful to the citizens of the Commonwealth in a multifaceted amount of ways. Simply highlighting these false &ldquo;benefits&rdquo; is disingenuous and clearly in the pursuit of a self-serving agenda.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"John Ukenye, Policy Analyst"
"Stakeholders Making Progress on Chesapeake Bay Goals, but Legislature Still Lagging",8/2/2021,"<p>On July 28th, <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/Business/Water/Pennsylvania%E2%80%99s%20Chesapeake%20Bay%20Program%20Office/WIP3/Pages/Public-Meetings.aspx"">the Chesapeake Bay State Team</a>, led by the Secretaries of the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP), the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR), and the Department of Agriculture (PDA), met to hear updates on the progress on the implementation of the Watershed Implementation Plan (WIP) and what&rsquo;s coming next.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In short, a lot of work is being done by the DEP and other state agencies, as well as the County Action Teams, to get&nbsp; Pennsylvania on track to meet its goals set by the Chesapeake Bay Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL). After years of lackluster planning and implementation, Pennsylvania and the other Bay states should celebrate the huge strides that are underway over the last two years since the completion of the Phase 3 WIP.&nbsp;</p>

<p>However, there is one critical area with few successes to report: the legislature&rsquo;s progress to provide adequate funding to meet our clean water goals.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Areas of Progress</u></p>

<ul>
	<li>Countywide Action Plans</li>
</ul>

<p>The Phase 3 WIP breaks up watershed restoration into county planning and implementation efforts, <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/Business/Water/Pennsylvania%E2%80%99s%20Chesapeake%20Bay%20Program%20Office/WIP3/GetInvolved/Pages/Countywide-Action-Plans.aspx"">called County Action Plans</a>. The 43 counties in the watershed were divided into two phases, depending on how much nitrogen and phosphorus they contribute to our streams. The eight Phase 1 counties are already implementing their plans and reporting progress back to DEP. The remaining Phase 2 counties are grouped into 10 clusters with plans due to DEP by the end of September. The local county-level efforts will help to catalyze and report action on the ground and provide DEP with input on what is needed to be successful.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>The Rapid Delisting Strategy</li>
</ul>

<p>The Lancaster Clean Water Partners, working with the Chesapeake Conservancy, put together a data-driven rapid delisting strategy for impaired, or polluted, waters to help prioritize the work being done in Lancaster County, which accounts for 21% of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s nitrogen reduction goals and 23% for phosphorus. This prioritization strategy is based on how healthy an impaired stream is, existing work within a watershed, and is focused on large landowners. Out of 5,100 farms in the county, the Lancaster CAP prioritizes 1,200 farms which helps technical service providers and other conservation organizations to know where focused efforts could make the biggest impact on local stream health. The delisting strategy could be used in other counties to speed up improvements to local stream health.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Center for Water Quality Excellence</li>
</ul>

<p>The Phase 3 WIP proposed the creation of a pilot <a href=""https://www.cwqe.org/"">Center for Water Quality Excellence</a>, led by PENNVEST, where municipalities, farmers, and other interested parties could go to learn more about best management practices and funding opportunities. The pilot Center is now open to serve Lancaster and York Counties. If this model proves to be successful, PENNVEST could open other locations to serve additional counties. In addition to providing one-on-one consulting opportunities, the Center will be offering workshops.&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Phase 3 WIP Amendment and Milestone Reporting&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>At EPA&rsquo;s request, DEP will submit an amendment to the Phase 3 WIP by the end of the year. The original Phase 3 WIP fell short on its plan to achieve the nitrogen reduction goal. The amendment is expected to include the 34 County Action Plans and the implementation and adjustments that have happened over the past 2 years. DEP pointed out challenges will be included in the document, including the COVID pandemic stalling progress due to the lost of construction season and increased construction costs. In addition, as part of the accountability framework of the Chesapeake Bay TMDL, DEP provides milestone reports to EPA for progress and on 2-year commitments. We eagerly await the Phase 3 Amendment and milestone reporting to assess progress toward Pennsylvania&rsquo;s goals and to see if the state has a complete plan to meet 100% of the nitrogen goal.&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Where progress is still lacking&nbsp;</u></p>

<p>Despite all the work being done by the state agencies and partners on the ground, this meeting reaffirmed funding from the legislature remains the main hurdle to overcome.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>We call on the legislature to take swift action on the following policies when they return to Harrisburg in late September.</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>The Agricultural Conservation Assistance Program&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>SB 465 would create a new statewide agricultural cost share program providing farmers and landowners with assistance to install conservation practices which benefit clean water and farms. The program would be administered by the State Conservation Commission and local decisions would be made through County Conservation Districts. These investments would prioritize counties where agriculture has a greater impact on stream health.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Growing Greener III&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>SB 525 would invest $500 million of the federal American Rescue Plan to reinvigorate the state&rsquo;s Growing Greener Program that was passed with bipartisan support over 20 years ago. This program supports community-driven work conservation and clean water projects across the state.&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>The Clean Streams Fund</li>
</ul>

<p>A cosponsor memo by Senator Yaw calls for $250 million of federal American Rescue Plan money to be directed to a water quality improvement dedicated fund. This funding could help improve stream health that is impacted by nonpoint source runoff, such as agriculture, acid mine drainage, and stormwater runoff.&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>The Lawn Fertilizer Bill</li>
</ul>

<p>SB 251 would significantly improve the water quality impacted by nutrient pollution in Pennsylvania by reducing application rates of lawn fertilizer, creating a professional certification program, and standardizing label requirements for lawns, golf courses, and athletic fields. Over 2,600 miles of the Commonwealth&rsquo;s streams are impaired due to excess nutrients, which is the fifth leading cause of water pollution.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The countdown to December 31, 2025 grows shorter everyday. The state agencies and counties are doing their part to build the systems and programs to get the job done. It&rsquo;s far past time for the legislature to step up to the plate. And right now, with&nbsp; $7 billion in federal funding from the American Rescue Plan, there are no longer any excuses remaining to hold off on investing in our state&rsquo;s clean water resources, which benefit the economy, create and sustain jobs, and improve quality of life and public health. Swift action on the legislation mentioned here would be a good start in the right direction.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,"Renee Reber, Campaign Manager, Watershed Advocacy"
It's Time to Reimagine America's Infrastructure,7/29/2021,"<p>As Congress continues to push towards a potential infrastructure package, residents of the Queen Village neighborhood in Philadelphia were reminded just how desperately we need to reinvest in &ndash; and reinvent &ndash; <a href=""https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2021/07/25/queen-village-30-inch-water-main-break-flooding/"">our nation&rsquo;s crumbling infrastructure.</a> A 30-inch water main broke after midnight Sunday and flooded nearby streets, businesses, and homes, resulting in untold damages for residents in the area.</p>

<p>The City of Philadelphia confirmed that the broken cast iron pipe was originally installed in 1891. The Philadelphia Water Department <a href=""https://www.audacy.com/kywnewsradio/news/local/overnight-water-main-break-floods-homes-leaves-giant-hole"">said this</a>: &quot;It&#39;s one of our oldest in our system. We try to get as much life out of them as long as we can, obviously this one reached the end of its life and we&rsquo;re trying to deal with the situation right now.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>You&rsquo;d be forgiven for thinking that this is an isolated incident involving an ancient pipe from the Gilded Age and moving on with your life. But, 15 percent of the city water mains <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/like-an-asteroid-struck-bella-vista-residents-survey-damage-after-massive-water-main-break/?utm_campaign=sproutsocial&amp;utm_content=1627321324&amp;utm_medium=post&amp;utm_source=twitter"">were installed before 1900</a>. It has been reported that Philadelphia has approximately 3,200 miles of pipe, which means that 480 miles of pipe were built at a time when horses were still the primary mode of transportation.</p>

<p>There is so much to admire about the built world that we were able to create through advances in technology and the sheer audacity of the human spirit. I am sure that there was a time when cast iron water main pipes were revolutionary. Now, towns and cities across America are squeezing the last life out of creaking and groaning infrastructure that cannot possibly be expected to deal with the challenges presented by climate change.</p>

<p>We are seeing the troubling signs of climate change across the globe: <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/26/world/asia/china-climate-change.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage"">flooding in China</a>, heat and monsoons <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/26/world/asia/india-landslides-floods.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage"">in India</a>, a tropical storm <a href=""https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/philippines-evacuates-thousands-monsoon-rains-flood-cities-provinces-2021-07-24/"">in the Philippines</a>, and heavy rainfall <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/15/world/europe/flooding-germany-belgium-switzerland-netherlands.html"">in Western Europe</a>. We are experiencing similar phenomena in America, too, as temperatures continue to rise and heavy rains continue to fall. We are also experiencing the damage done to our homes and businesses as our aged infrastructure struggles to keep pace with a harsher climate.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This weekend&rsquo;s water main break is only the latest indication that we risk far more by doing nothing than what we risk with a novel approach to rebuild our nation&rsquo;s infrastructure. Queen Village residents have called the scene &ldquo;apocalyptic&rdquo; and likened the latest sinkhole to an asteroid strike. This comes only months after <a href=""https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2021/02/16/cars-stranded-flooded-street-after-water-main-break-in-north-philadelphia/"">a 48-inch water main break in North Philadelphia</a> forced emergency responders to rescue nearly a dozen people by boat. Another water main break formed <a href=""https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2021/02/08/sinkhole-swallows-suv-after-12-inch-water-main-break-in-philadelphias-logan-neighborhood/"">a sinkhole that swallowed an SUV.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>The current push to rebuild our nation&rsquo;s infrastructure also presents us with our best opportunity to reimagine our nation&rsquo;s infrastructure. If we are truly willing to invest trillions of dollars into building back better, then let&rsquo;s make sure we do just that. Philadelphia&rsquo;s water mains are bursting at the seams due to wear and tear, but it would be a mistake to focus on upgrading pipes that were built before Theodore Roosevelt became President. The best way to build back better is to chart a new course that does not rely on pipes and pavement.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The City of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Water Department have been working to address its aging infrastructure for nearly ten years. Beginning in 2011, the city sought a new way to rebuild its stormwater infrastructure to better combat polluted runoff and the impact of heavy floods through green stormwater infrastructure (GSI). The Green City, Clean Waters program <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Report-highlights-success-of-Philadelphias-Green-City-Clean-Waters-Program"">is a proven model for success</a> that represents truly fundamental change in the way we think of infrastructure in America. Prioritizing nature-based solutions that promote people over pavement allows municipalities to simultaneously increase preparedness for the impact of climate change and begin to address the harm caused to communities of color through decades of deliberate exclusion and disinvestment. GSI projects that incorporate green space like tree trenches and rain gardens provide relief to urban communities through reducing air temperatures and helping to <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/isaias-emergency-eastwick-residents-call-for-city-state-aid-after-devastating-flooding/"">decrease the risk of flooding.&nbsp;</a></p>
