<p>Cities across the world <a href=""https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/26/europe/london-flooding-infrastructure-climate-intl-cmd/index.html?utm_term=link&amp;utm_source=twCNN&amp;utm_content=2021-07-26T21%3A00%3A12&amp;utm_medium=social"">are grappling with the grim reality</a> that they are not prepared for the impact of climate change. There are those in America who will tell us that we cannot afford to reimagine our nation&rsquo;s infrastructure. They will argue that American ingenuity cannot account for the weather. Senators will <a href=""https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-26/infrastructure-talks-near-finish-as-senators-face-time-pressure"">balk at increased spending</a> to deal with the myriad issues plaguing our nation&rsquo;s water systems. We can choose to squeeze the very last drop of life out of pipes better left to a bygone age. We know what the consequences will be: swift-water rescues to save people from drowning in city streets, sinkholes swallowing SUVs, and millions in damages.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But American ingenuity did not die in 1981, 1891, or 1776. We only must choose to face this next great challenge with the same audacity and creativity that led us to create the built world that surrounds us. There are models like Philadelphia&rsquo;s Green City, Clean Waters program across the country. Municipalities and residents have been forced to go it alone for far too long. This moment demands federal action that prioritizes infrastructure that is cost-effective, sustainable, clean, and green.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Adam Nagel, Campaign Manager"
Pennsylvania Supreme Court Rules that Drilling Revenues from State Forests Must be Used for Conservation,7/28/2021,"<p>Last week, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court <a href=""https://www.pacourts.us/assets/opinions/Supreme/out/J-78-2020mo - 104840407140939594.pdf?cb=1"">ruled that it is unconstitutional under the Environmental Rights Amendment (ERA)</a> for the General Assembly to transfer oil and gas lease funds designated for environmental conservation to the general fund for non-conservation purposes. This decision, appropriately dubbed &ldquo;PEDF IV,&rdquo; concludes a six-year legal battle between the Pennsylvania Environmental Defense Foundation (PEDF) and the Commonwealth.</p>

<p>The General Assembly established a lease fund in 1955 under the Lease Fund Act to receive &ldquo;all rents and royalties from oil and gas leases&rdquo; on Commonwealth land, and exclusively dedicated to environmental conservation purposes. The Department of Conservation and Natural Resource (DCNR) is charged with overseeing all oil and gas leases and contracts on these publicly owned lands, and all moneys in the fund are to be appropriated to the DCNR for carrying out the purpose of the fund.</p>

<p>From 1955 to 2008, the leases generated a total of $165 million. Then in 2009, the DCNR leased approximately 74,000 acres for Marcellus Shale drilling which generated close to $600 million. These revenues were made up of upfront bonus payments, annual rental fees, royalties for the marketable gas extracted, and interest penalties for late payments. Inspired by the large influx of revenue, the General Assembly added four new provisions to the Fiscal Code which essentially worked to restrict the allocation of lease fund monies to DCNR and redirect them to the general fund to help balance the state budget. This marked the start of the PEDF litigation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2017, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court established in PEDF II that the ERA, Article I, Section 27 of the Pennsylvania Constitution, creates an express public trust subject to Pennsylvania private trust law with the purpose of conserving and maintaining the state&rsquo;s public natural resources &ldquo;for the benefit of all the people.&rdquo; The ERA designates the Commonwealth as trustee, the people as the named beneficiaries, and Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources as the corpus (or body) of the trust.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PEDF II critically and clearly accepted the Pennsylvania Supreme Court&rsquo;s 2016 plurality&rsquo;s holding in Robinson Township v. Commonwealth, that this public trust imposes trustee obligations on the Commonwealth to (1) prohibit the degradation, diminution, and depletion of our public natural resources, whether these harms might result from direct state action or from the actions of private parties, and (2) the Commonwealth must act affirmatively via legislative action to protect the environment. It also rejected the previous three-part ERA test set forth in <em>Payne v. Kassab.</em></p>

<p>The PEDF II Court also ruled that two of the Fiscal Code provisions relating to oil and gas royalties (1602-E and 1603-E) were facially unconstitutional because they directed the royalties away from the trust corpus. Remember, the corpus under the ERA is Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources, and PEDF II had to figure out what to do if those natural resources are sold.&nbsp; According to Pennsylvania private trust law, revenue from the sale of trust assets constitute trust principle, and trust principle must remain part of the corpus of the trust. Royalties from the sale of oil and gas represent the sale of trust assets, and are therefore trust principle.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Court then remanded the case back to the Commonwealth court to determine whether the other two provisions transferring money from the lease fund to the general fund (1604-E and 1605-E) were also unconstitutional. This required a determination of how the other revenues (the bonus payments, annual rental fees, and interest penalties) should be categorized under private trust law principles.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Taking a step back, typically in an oil and gas lease, the company pays several different payments for the lease/right to extract. The bonus payment is a one-time payment made by the company to secure the lease during a formal bidding process. The company then pays an annual rental fee to maintain its right to explore the area for oil and gas. Interest penalties are penalties related to late rental payments. Finally, the company pays royalties to the commonwealth based on the amount of marketable gas it extracts.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Under Pennsylvania private trust law, rental payments generated from trust assets are classified as trust income and can be distributed to trust beneficiaries. On remand in 2019, the Pennsylvania Commonwealth Court in PEDF III determined that the rents, bonuses, and interest penalties constitute income, and interpreted the ERA to recognize two distinct classes of beneficiaries: the current living citizens of Pennsylvania as life tenants and all future citizens as remaindermen. The court determined that since the ERA didn&rsquo;t specify how the proceeds should be allocated between successive beneficiaries (the life tenants and remaindermen) the trust laws from when the ERA was adopted (the 1947 Principle Income Act) would govern, thereby directing the income to go to the life tenants. This led the court to conclude that the transfer of revenue to the general fund was constitutional as it represented income distributed to the trust&rsquo;s life tenants. PEDF then appealed to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Last week&rsquo;s decision reversed PEDF III on the grounds that the ERA does not in fact establish successive trust beneficiaries, and therefore the 1947 trust laws concerning apportionment among successive beneficiaries do not apply. The Commonwealth Court in PEDF III interpreted the phrase &ldquo;for the benefit of all the people&rdquo; in the ERA in isolation to mean that allocating the trust income to the general budget would benefit all the people, and would therefore be permissible.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In discussing the ERA, the Court explained that &ldquo;[t]he text does not distinguish between &lsquo;current Pennsylvanians&rsquo; and future generations. Instead, generations yet to come are included within the broadly defined beneficiary: &lsquo;all the people.&rsquo;&rdquo; And as the Court in PEDF II explained, &ldquo;The Commonwealth&rsquo;s fiduciary duty to &ldquo;conserve and maintain&rdquo; our public natural resources is a duty owed to the beneficiaries of the public trust, namely &ldquo;the people, including generations yet to come,&rdquo; as set forth in the second sentence of Section 27.&rdquo; This essentially means that the Commonwealth, as the trustee, cannot distinguish or prioritize the needs of current Pennsylvanians and future Pennsylvanians by spending trust income on general budgetary matters because &ldquo;the ERA created simultaneous beneficiaries with equal interests in the trust&rsquo;s management.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Public trusts for natural resources are not a novel concept, and they exist in every state through either constitutional provisions, statutes, or common law (i.e., court decisions) to protect an area&rsquo;s natural resources for the benefit of the present and future public. However, current public trust law for natural resources is vary sparse and lawyers and the courts will often draw on private trust law to help answer questions that arise that are not answered by public trust law &ndash; as was done in the PEDF line of cases.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While there are no binding rules on the type of trust law that should be used to fill these gaps, some legal professionals <a href=""https://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2516&amp;context=mjlr"">have strong opinions on how to apply private trust principles</a> to public trusts so as to uphold the intent and purpose of the public trust. Professor John Dernbach, for example, stresses that the income maximization aspects of private trust law should not be used to define the duties and limits of a public trustee as they are incompatible with the purpose of public trusts for natural resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We have also seen recently how these principals can be perverted into an argument in favor of depleting Pennsylvania&rsquo;s natural resources. Pennsylvania State Senators Gene Yaw and Lisa Baker (joined by the Pennsylvania Republican Caucus and several municipalities) <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-Environmental-Groups-Law-Center-File-Friend-of-Court-Brief-in-Opposition-to-Challenge-to-Delaware-River-Basin-Commission-Fracking-Ban"">attempted to challenge a ban on fracking</a> within the Delaware River Basin passed by the Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC) by essentially arguing that they have public trust duties under section 27 of the ERA as individual legislators to exploit the State&rsquo;s natural resources for economic gain. They argued that the fracking ban harms the Commonwealth and its citizens by &ldquo;interfering with the reasonable investment-backed expectations of landowners,&rdquo; and diminishing the property value of land in the Basin.&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Federal-Court-Dismissed-Lawsuit-Challenging-DRBCs-Ban-on-Fracking"">In an unsurprising victory</a>, the District Court <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Opinion-on-Dismissing-Yaw-Suit.pdf"">rejected these arguments</a> on the basis that the two senators are not ERA trustees and have no standing to bring the complaint. Arguments like the one brought by Senators Yaw and Baker which grossly misinterpret the ERA are why it is so important to remain diligent in ensuring that the ERA is used to its fullest and most correct purpose to <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/legis/LI/consCheck.cfm?txtType=HTM&amp;ttl=00&amp;div=0&amp;chpt=1&amp;sctn=27&amp;subsctn=0"">&ldquo;protect our rights to clean air, water, and the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic and esthetic values of the environment.&rdquo;&nbsp;</a></p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Emily Rollins, Legal Intern"
Maine’s Innovative Response to Plastics Pollution and What the Rest of Us Can Learn From it,7/27/2021,"<p>China remains the world&rsquo;s largest producer of plastic, but&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/us-worlds-number-one-source-plastic-waste-180976214/"">research has shown that the United States</a> was the world&rsquo;s number one source of plastic waste as of 2016, pushing 42 million metric tons into the environment. Americans also use more plastic per capita than any other country on the planet at roughly 286 pounds per person.</p>

<p>Because the U.S. lacks the waste management infrastructure to recycle all its plastic waste, the country transports about half of its recyclable materials to other countries. However, this has been complicated by <a href=""https://www.dw.com/en/amid-plastic-deluge-southeast-asia-refuses-western-waste/a-49467769"">China&rsquo;s 2018 announcement to stop the importation</a> of plastic waste, followed by announcements by other Southeast Asian states such as Thailand in 2021, Vietnam by 2025, India, and even Turkey. Clearly, something must be done to tackle our plastic waste problem in the U.S., and states like Maine might be leading the way and teaching us all a thing or two about finally solving this issue.</p>

<p>According to a 2018 study cited by the Environmental Protection Agency, containers and packaging (namely &ldquo;bags, sacks and wraps; other packaging; polyethylene terephthalate (PET) bottles and jars; high-density polyethylene (HDPE) natural bottles; and other containers&rdquo;) <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/facts-and-figures-about-materials-waste-and-recycling/plastics-material-specific-data"">rank&nbsp;as the most used plastic in the U.S.</a> at over 14.5 million tons.</p>

<p>For the past thirty years, U.S. states have begun to pass individual statewide legislation to curb the usage of plastic bags. In 1991, <a href=""https://www.ncsl.org/research/environment-and-natural-resources/plastic-bag-legislation.aspx"">Maine became the first state to enact legislation</a> requiring recycling efforts at retail stores. The law prevents retailers from supplying plastic bags unless they provide a convenient storefront receptacle to ensure used bags are collected and recycled. Since then at least four other states&mdash;California, Delaware, New York and Rhode Island&mdash;and the District of Columbia have followed their lead.</p>

<p>However, as we have previously noted <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Recycling-is-exacerbating-the-plastic-waste-crisis"">in our PennFuture Blog</a>, plastic recycling by the consumer alone will not solve the plastics pollution crisis our global environment is facing, <a href=""https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/article/plastic-produced-recycling-waste-ocean-trash-debris-environment"">as just 9 percent of global plastic waste</a> is recycled. PennFuture has previously argued that the world must transition away from plastic packaging altogether. As of this writing, eight states&mdash;California, Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Maine, New York, Oregon and Vermont&mdash;<a href=""https://www.ncsl.org/research/environment-and-natural-resources/plastic-bag-legislation.aspx"">have banned single-use plastic bags.</a></p>

<p>Arguably, a major step towards the total elimination of plastic packaging can be seen in Maine&rsquo;s new extended producer responsibility (EPR) policy for packaging which makes it all the more costly for companies to use plastic packaging, among other types as well.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Maine&rsquo;s new EPR law begins to shift the burden on recycling from the consumer to the producer by requiring producers <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/21/climate/maine-recycling-law-EPR.html"">to cover 100 percent of its municipalities&rsquo; recycling costs.</a> Maine&rsquo;s Department of Environmental Protection&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.fastcompany.com/90655072/maine-companies-will-now-have-to-pay-to-help-fix-the-broken-recycling-system?utm_source=postup&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_campaign=world-changing-ideas&amp;position=9&amp;partner=newsletter&amp;campaign_date=07172021"">will set fees for different types of packaging</a>. Companies will be charged on the amount of packaging waste they create in the state, with higher fees charged for materials that are more difficult to recycle. The fees will drop when companies redesign and replace old packaging for more recyclable ones, or increase the amount of recycled content in their packaging. This eco-modulation system &quot;incentivizes less packaging and better packaging&rdquo; <a href=""https://www.wastedive.com/news/extended-producer-responsibility-packaging-maine-oregon/602479/"">according to State Rep. Nicole Grohoski</a>, one of the bill&rsquo;s primary sponsors.</p>

<p>Maine&rsquo;s DEP will partner with a &ldquo;packing stewardship&rdquo; organization that will run the program and will offer companies assistance in designing packaging that better fits the system. The organization will need to report data such as tonnage of packaging collected and provide funding for infrastructure and education improvements.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While 33 states currently have EPR laws, <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/21/climate/maine-recycling-law-EPR.html"">they are far more narrow</a>; typically focusing on specific products like used mattresses and tubs of paint. Even in this narrow application, Connecticut&rsquo;s mattress, paint, electronic and thermostat EPR programs have diverted more than 26 million pounds of waste since 2008, <a href=""https://www.productstewardship.us/news/328753/Extended-Producer-Responsibility-Programs-Proven-Successful-in-Connecticut.htm"">according to one study.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>Packaging-centric EPR policies have achieved success worldwide as well. <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/21/climate/maine-recycling-law-EPR.html"">In Quebec, Canada</a>, a similar program <a href=""https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/kruger-packaging-invests-250-million-in-the-trois-rivieres-mill-527461141.html"">results in $250 million sent back to communities</a> for recycling purposes each year. Around 63% of packaging <a href=""https://www.clf.org/blog/recycling-reform-producer-responsibility-maine-pollution/"">is recycled in Quebec</a>, versus an average of 25% in the U.S. A study by the Oregon Department of Environmental Quality of Canadian EPR programs found that consumer product prices had increased <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/27/arts/design/recycling-packaging-new-york.html"">by only $0.0056 per item.</a></p>

<p>Plastic pollution is undoubtedly an issue in Pennsylvania. Studies have estimated that by 2050 there will be more plastic in our oceans than fish. On average, in a single year, <a href=""https://environmentamerica.org/reports/pac/microplastics-pennsylvania"">the Philadelphia Water Department removes 44 tons</a> of trash from a 32 mile stretch of the Schuylkill and Delaware rivers, 56% of which was plastic waste, according to a PennEnvironment report. In Pennsylvania, plastic is the most common form of visible litter. In fact, the Department of Transportation spends over $13 million every year cleaning up just roadside litter. The problem is so widespread that nine of the largest cities in Pennsylvania spend over $68.5 million every year on litter and illegal dumping, with $46.7 million of that going toward litter abatement.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania&#39;s very low cost in sending trash to landfills and incinerators <a href=""https://www.casey.senate.gov/news/releases/casey-introduces-legislation-to-restrict-flow-of-trash-into-pa-from-other-states"">places Pennsylvania as among the largest importers</a> of out-of-state waste in the nation. At the same time, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Department of Environmental Protection, facing cuts in their funding by the legislature, <a href=""https://wjactv.com/news/local/dep-cancels-statewide-recycling-implementation-grants-for-first-time-in-33-years"">has cut grant funding</a> for the state&rsquo;s recycling program in 2021.</p>

<p>With the plastics pollution issue increasing in Pennsylvania in the face of cuts to traditional recycling programs, it is time to change course. Maine has shown us that legislators can stand up to the plastics manufacturers and larger petrochemical industry and force them to take responsibility for the plastic pollution they are putting into the marketplace, and by extension, the environment at virtually no cost to the consumer.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"John Ukenye, Policy Analyst"
The Problem with Carbon Capture and Sequestration,7/26/2021,"<p>Leaders around the world, including PA Governor, Tom Wolf have been pushing for investments in Carbon Capture and Sequestration (CCS) technology. CCS is a technology that pulls carbon out of the air, usually when it is released at facilities like power plants, and buries it underground to keep it from reaching the atmosphere. Some have claimed that this is a miracle technology that will save us from climate change. Yet, there is little support for this staggering claim.</p>

<p>Captured carbon is most often used to directly further the production of fossil fuels from oil and gas fields while providing an overall excuse that our continued reliance on fossil fuels is ok, because CCS will be here to save us. We cannot allow the promise of future carbon reduction to continue to prolong our reliance on technologies that are already causing <a href=""https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/climate-change-is-central-to-californias-wildfires/"">devastating consequences to our environment.</a>&nbsp;</p>

<p>As mentioned before, CCS is a technology that takes already-released carbon out of the air and transports it to a location where it can be sequestered and kept out of the atmosphere. According to <a href=""https://www.globalccsinstitute.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/GCC_GLOBAL_STATUS_REPORT_2019.pdf"">the Global CCS Institute</a>, as of 2019, global CCS capacity is at around 40 million metric tons of CO2 per year. This is only a drop in the bucket when put in the context <a href=""https://ourworldindata.org/co2-emissions"">of the over 36 billion tons a year</a> that is currently being emitted. CCS promises big results in cutting emissions. One facility in Texas for example, <a href=""https://www.nrg.com/case-studies/petra-nova.html"">claims that over a 3-year period</a> between 2016 and 2019 it successfully sequestered 99.08% of carbon emissions, equal to 3,831,818 short tons of CO2. However, in this facility, as in many others, captured carbon is often used to promote more fossil fuel production elsewhere. In reality this means that emissions will be higher as a result of the carbon that was captured.&nbsp;<br />
<br />
<u>Background on CCS</u></p>

<p>There are <a href=""https://www.rff.org/publications/explainers/carbon-capture-and-storage-101/"">three types of carbon capture technologies</a> that are used to capture the carbon at its source. The most common, particularly in existing power plants, is post combustion carbon capture, where the CO2 is separated from the exhaust that results from the combustion process. Then there is pre-combustion carbon capture which is used in industrial processes but is still in the very early stages for power plants and it is cost prohibitive to try to retrofit an existing powerplant with the technology. In pre-combustion carbon capture, fuel is gasified allowing the CO2 to be separated. Lastly there is oxy-fuel combustion where the fuel is burned in an (almost) pure oxygen environment allowing the CO2 emissions to become more concentrated and thus easier to capture. After the CO2 is captured, it is compressed into a fluid, transported to a storage site, and then eventually injected underground where it can be kept long term to keep from reaching the atmosphere.</p>

<p>Early versions of Carbon capture technology <a href=""https://ieaghg.org/docs/General_Docs/Publications/Information_Sheets_for_CCS_2.pdf"">actually date back to the 1920s</a>, when it was used for separating CO2 that was found in natural gas reservoirs from the saleable methane. Since the 1970s, captured CO2 has been piped to oil fields to boost oil recovery in a process known as <a href=""http://www.netl.doe.gov/oil-gas/oil-recovery"">Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR)</a>, leading to millions of tons of CO2 being piped into oil fields every year. Injecting CO2 for EOR can lead to 20-40% higher oil production in an oil field. Although the CO2 can be left there permanently to sequester it, the production of increased oil still leads to this method creating increased carbon emissions. CCS for the sake of keeping carbon out of the atmosphere to try to halt climate change <a href=""https://www.carbonbrief.org/beccs-the-story-of-climate-changes-saviour-technology"">gained prominence only in the first years</a> of the new century.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>The Problem with CCS</u></p>

<p>The promise of CCS is dramatically overstated. CCS is not cost efficient. It is extremely expensive and thus cost prohibitive to apply to existing sources of pollution, so the&nbsp;only use case is to construct CCS facilities on new fossil fuel plants. We must stop constructing new fossil fuel plants. Not only are they dangerous, <a href=""https://www.lazard.com/perspective/levelized-cost-of-energy-and-levelized-cost-of-storage-2020/"">but it is not cost effective</a>. It would be cheaper to construct new wind or solar than to invest in CCS.</p>

<p>Despite showing some early promise, <a href=""https://www.iea.org/fuels-and-technologies/carbon-capture-utilisation-and-storage"">according to the IEA</a>, as of 2020, there were only 21 CCS facilities operating globally, with another 44 in various stages of development. While CCS may sound promising in concept, it very much remains to be seen whether it will be possible to develop the technology to a scale where it could actually make a significant difference in the climate crisis. It will certainly be extremely expensive, and will draw funds away from renewable energy technology. This could not only delay the construction of renewable energy that is already available but could also delay innovation into new, more advanced forms of clean, renewable energy. This means that we are investing in an unnecessary technology that could never come to fruition instead of trying to reduce our reliance on fossil fuels now with technology that is already ready to be deployed.</p>

<p><u>CCS in Pennsylvania</u></p>

<p>This has been demonstrated be true for Pennsylvania as well. Governor Wolf has announced that PA is joining other states to create a coalition to develop regional CCS infrastructure. Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Secretary of the Department of Community and Economic Development, Dennis Davin, has declared that &ldquo;Carbon capture technologies provide a critical component to addressing our climate challenge.&rdquo; In the <a href=""https://carboncaptureready.betterenergy.org/"">announcement mentioned above</a>, the administration shared literature that declares that &ldquo;states are ready for Carbon Capture.&rdquo; However, Governor Wolf&rsquo;s own administration <a href=""https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/pennsylvania-joins-6-states-in-commitment-to-plan-for-co2-transport-infrastructure/"">clearly seems to disagree.</a></p>

<p>As part of the permitting process for the proposed Renovo Energy Center, a gas fired power plant in Clinton County, the Department of Environmental Protection concluded that currently CCS is not commercially feasible and dismissed it as a way to reduce the emissions of the facility. Standing alone, this might be a plausible conclusion. However, if CCS is really as critical and available as the administration believes, why is the DEP dismissing it as unfeasible for one of the few plants that may have been able to invest in it in PA?&nbsp; CCS is being presented as a pathway to continue moving along an environmentally destructive and carbon-heavy trajectory, while industrial operations are not actually being required to utilize the technology at all.&nbsp; All of this further evidences, as discussed above, that, in reality, CCS is infeasible for any number of new or existing facilities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It is a serious cause for concern that CCS is being held up as a justification to continue to burn fossil fuels indefinitely (while seemingly avoiding the environmental catastrophe the data clearly show is coming) while in practice, CCS <a href=""https://www.utilitydive.com/news/coal-fired-carbon-capture-projects-are-a-waste-of-tax-dollars/602209/"">appears to be a costly</a> (<a href=""https://theclimateconnection.org/carbon-capture-storage-how-cost-effective-is-it/"">and cost ineffective</a>) project with little hope of actually succeeding at the levels needed and <a href=""https://theclimateconnection.org/carbon-capture-should-public-companies-continue-to-fund-it/"">a history of overpromising and underdelivering.</a> The risks <a href=""https://theclimateconnection.org/carbon-capture-and-storage-pros-cons/"">associated with prioritizing CCS</a> include unfair competition for funding and subsidies that could be used for sustainable energy generation like wind or solar and <a href=""https://www.utilitydive.com/news/coal-fired-carbon-capture-projects-are-a-waste-of-tax-dollars/602209/"">also prolonging the life of aging coal and gas plants</a> without actually achieving their goals of large scale carbon capture. So far CCS facilities continuously fallen short of their lofty claims, while the political powers that be are free to rest on their laurels after proclaiming that CCS is about to fix the climate crisis (and continue to throw good money after this inefficient, costly technology).&nbsp;</p>

<p>Instead of averting climate disaster, CCS appears to be another step down our current path of climate destruction under a thin veil of progress. It remains to be seen if CCS will ever manage to create an effective band aid in the fight against climate change, but it is clear that as long as it prolongs our reliance on fossil fuels it will continue to be bring about harm.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Daniela Rakhlina-Powsner, Legal Intern"
What comes next for plastic bags in Pennsylvania?,7/23/2021,"<p>July began with the expiration of a statewide restriction on banning the use of plastic bags. The development is welcomed news for municipalities across the Commonwealth implementing or considering bans on the ubiquitous plastic that too often finds its way into local waterways as litter or becomes a costly contaminant in recycling systems.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Credit likely goes to the <a href=""https://apnews.com/article/health-lawsuits-coronavirus-pandemic-philadelphia-environment-76b04dcd3e8c2b21d5a467e0f2e56cc8"">legal challenge led by Philadelphia and other Southeastern Pennsylvania municipalities</a> and joined by Pittsburgh. Their lawsuit likely discouraged the General Assembly&rsquo;s Republican leadership from renewing the bag-ban moratorium.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Originally passed in 2019, the amendment to Act 23 prohibited enacting or enforcing any tax that would discourage the use or sale of single-use plastic. After the General Assembly extended the one-year restriction in 2020, this year the July 1 extension deadline came and went as quietly as a plastic bag drifting in the wind.&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://www.pennlive.com/news/2021/06/philadelphia-and-pittsburgh-move-ahead-with-plastic-bag-bans-as-pas-preemption-nears-its-end.html"">Media reports suggest &ldquo;pending litigation&rdquo;</a> that revealed the moratorium&rsquo;s unconstitutional approach may have played a role in legislators&rsquo; decision not to extend the ban &mdash; for now, at least.</p>

<p><u>Are the days of plastic bags coming to an end?</u>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This fall, the General Assembly could still take action to limit bag bans. Philadelphia&rsquo;s lawsuit mostly centers on the moratorium&rsquo;s procedural tactics.&nbsp;</p>

<p>With local plastics manufacturers and lobbyists representing the grocery industry still opposed to local bans, supporters in the General Assembly could potentially attempt to overcome their mistakes and find new ways to prevent limits on single-use plastic.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The fact that this is up for debate shows how backward-minded our state&rsquo;s plastics approach has become. Nationwide, <a href=""https://www.ncsl.org/research/environment-and-natural-resources/plastic-bag-legislation.aspx"">a dozen states ban single-use plastic</a> at the state or county levels. Virginia state law specifically allows municipalities to issue fees on single-use plastic if local leaders so choose.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Cities move forward&nbsp;</u></p>

<p>In the meantime, local action to transition away from single-use plastics is gaining momentum.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>The same day that the statewide moratorium expired, Philadelphia announced implementation of the city&rsquo;s single-use plastic bags ordinance would begin, <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/2020-12-30-updated-timeline-for-implementation-of-plastic-bag-ban"">with enforcement starting April 1.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>Philadelphia&rsquo;s legislation prohibits retailers from using carryout or delivery plastic bags less than 2.25 mils thick. The city will also prevent use of paper bags that contain less than 40 percent recycled content.</p>

<p>Pittsburgh appears next in line. City Council <a href=""https://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/single-use-plastics-ban-cleared-for-pa-cities-as-pittsburgh-moves-to-eliminate-plastic-bags/Content?oid=19763862"">passed a resolution in May</a> saying that the city intends to pass a ban on single-use plastic bags in the near future.</p>

<p>With Pennsylvania&rsquo;s two largest cities taking action to eliminate plastic waste, other towns and cities are likely to follow their lead.</p>

<p><u>Environmental and financial benefits</u></p>

<p>Let&rsquo;s take a moment to remember why getting rid of single-use plastics is a move in the right direction. Recent studies <a href=""https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0095069618305291"">found plastic bag bans in other states</a> and cities resulted in significant reduction in plastic bag consumption &mdash; in some cases, a decrease of more than 70 percent.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Benefits of switching from single-use plastic bags to reusable bags include:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Less Litter: Plastic bags don&rsquo;t like to stay in one place. Wind-blown bags escape from trash bins, dump trucks and landfills to pollute our streets, parks, streams and rivers.&nbsp;Currently, the equivalent of <a href=""https://www.ellenmacarthurfoundation.org/publications/the-new-plastics-economy-rethinking-the-future-of-plastics"">one dump truck of plastic litter enters our oceans</a> every day. Microplastics can hang in the air, <a href=""https://www.motherjones.com/environment/2019/04/a-shocking-discovery-shows-just-how-far-wind-can-carry-microplastics/"">perhaps traveling 100 miles or more downwind</a>. That&rsquo;s why even our most pristine places are getting covered in plastic trash.</li>
	<li>Cost Savings for Local Governments: In recent years, the value of recycled waste has declined, leaving municipalities with narrow operating margins when processing local waste. Single-use plastic offers no post-consumer value, making it even harder to be profitable when recycling. In fact, plastic bags can jam equipment at material recovery facilities, at times causing the entire recycling facility to shut down. Such work shortages <a href=""https://azdailysun.com/news/local/phoenix-recycling-officials-plastic-bags-contribute-to-lost-time-worth/article_7ec39600-c28f-5e4c-bb12-b3bb726e7ac9.html"">have cost cities millions of dollars.</a></li>
	<li>Reduction in Pollution: Plastics are manufactured <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/frackingandpetrochemicals"">using resource-intensive petrochemical processes</a> that require burning significant amounts of fossil fuel, contaminating local air and contributing to the climate crisis.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Affordable Convenience: Consumers adopt new behaviors when their options change. To help with this transition, reusable or recyclable alternatives are widely available, affordable and practical. Free tote bags should continue to be handed out at public events. Local leaders can also allocate funds to programs that help to ensure fees on single-use plastic are not punitive on marginalized members of society. In cities like Washington, D.C., proceeds are spent on environmental remediation and education efforts that directly benefit members of the community.&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>To ensure Pennsylvania does our part to address the growing challenge of plastic waste, PennFuture will continue to monitor the General Assembly and advocate for commonsense policies. Phasing out single-use plastics makes sense both environmentally and economically.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But if those arguments fail, perhaps those who celebrate liberty should embrace the right for cities and towns to make their own decisions, including the choice of how they manage their own waste.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jessica O'Neill, Senior Attorney"
Economic Impact Report Commissioned by Shell Doesn’t Tell the Whole Story. Far From It.,7/22/2021,"<p>A report released by researchers at Robert Morris University last week grabbed headlines across western Pennsylvania: once up and running next year, Royal Dutch Shell&rsquo;s massive plastics factory on the banks of the Ohio River in Beaver County will generate nearly $3.7 billion in economic activity annually in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Unfortunately, these types of industry-funded sales pitches presented as &ldquo;studies&#39;&#39; are an effective tactic used by the fossil fuel industry <a href=""https://archive.triblive.com/business/local-stories/pennsylvania-tax-incentive-plan-played-major-role-in-luring-shell-cracker-plant/"">to gain taxpayer subsidies</a> and a license to pollute in exchange for promised economic development that may never materialize.</p>

<p>To that end, a high-ranking Shell official didn&rsquo;t miss the chance to spin this report to fit the company narrative: the fossil fuel giant is &ldquo;proud of the positive impact we are having on the local, regional and state economies,&rdquo; <a href=""https://www.rmu.edu/about/news/rmu-study-shell-ethane-cracker-will-add-nearly-4-billion-each-year-pennsylvania-economy"">Senior Vice President Hillary Mercer said</a>, &ldquo;and we look forward to remaining a valued neighbor and employer of choice in the region for decades to come.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Mercer mentioned the importance of being a &ldquo;valued neighbor&rdquo; in the community, but what does that mean? The RMU report contained nearly 10,000 words typed across 32 pages: the word &ldquo;jobs&rdquo; appeared 40 times, while &ldquo;billion&rdquo; appeared a total of 43 times. &ldquo;Pollution,&rdquo; &ldquo;climate change,&rdquo; &ldquo;cancer,&rdquo; and &ldquo;health impacts&rdquo; appeared zero times.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Keep in mind that this industrial behemoth, which hopes to turn ethane into resins used to manufacture single-use plastics, could emit upward of 2.2 million tons of carbon pollution annually along with air toxics and other chemicals. Once operational, it will skyrocket near the top of the list of worst polluters in all of western Pennsylvania, but RMU report didn&rsquo;t assess, cite, or factor in the public health impacts of facilities like this, which history has shown have severe effects&mdash;one only needs to look at petrochemical hubs in Louisiana and Texas for present day proof. Not considering the very real costs that Pennsylvanians will suffer from the environmental and public health damages is a huge omission, but it&rsquo;s not the only problem with the report.</p>

<p>Perhaps the most glaring problem is the underlying assumption that this plant will actually be successful. The financial press <a href=""https://www.wsj.com/articles/firms-like-dow-bet-billions-on-plastics-now-theres-a-glut-11602754200"">is already covering the glut in the industry</a> as production outstrips demand and long-time industry leaders like Dow and Chevron are scaling back investments. <a href=""https://ieefa.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Financial-Risks_Weak-Outlook_Shell-PA-Petrochemical-Complex_June-2020.pdf"">As was reported last year</a>, Shell &ldquo;will enter the market amidst a plastics price war among formidable corporations with existing client bases that are reducing prices to maintain their position in a constricted market.&rdquo; In this environment, success is far from a sure thing.</p>

<p>The RMU report, for its part, cites &ldquo;Suttles, 2020&rdquo; and &ldquo;Esposito, 2018&rdquo; for the assumption that the plant will employ 600 full-time positions. Readers could be forgiven for assuming those are references to academic papers or some sort of independent analysis of the industry, but that is not the case: both are journalists quoting Shell&rsquo;s own estimations of employment. It&rsquo;s unclear if any of the claims regarding the future performance of this facility come from sources other than Shell or Shell-funded reports.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In fact, when the authors list their final assumption&mdash;that there will be a market for the products of the proposed plant&mdash;there is no footnote at all giving a source.</p>

<p>To be fair, Shell does have one thing going for it that competitors like Dow, Chevron, and ExxonMobile don&rsquo;t&mdash;Pennsylvania is providing them the largest tax subsidy in the state&rsquo;s history, worth as much as $1.65 billion. This expenditure, along with the very real costs of the additional pollution including direct medical expenses, lost work, and environmental damage, don&rsquo;t appear on the other side of the ledger when Shell makes its lofty claims.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The problem for Shell&mdash;and the rest of us&mdash;is that these negative externalities are very real, and very costly. Negative externalities are industry-created costs that are incurred by society rather than the industry at fault, things such as air and water pollution, increased sickness and public health burdens, and contributing to a climate crisis that is already at a tipping point worldwide.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Beaver County residents don&rsquo;t have to look far for <a href=""https://www.wesa.fm/environment-energy/2021-07-18/puc-seeks-comment-on-1-million-fine-for-beaver-county-blast"">a blatant example of a negative externality</a>: in September 2018, the Revolution Pipeline exploded in Center Township, leveling one home, killing several animals, and destroying six high-voltage electricity transmission towers, among other damages. Another negative externality is <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2021/03/17/Falcon-Shell-ethane-pipeline-Pennsylvania-federal-investigation-whistleblowers/stories/202103160171"">the taxpayer money being spent by state and federal officials</a> on an investigation into Shell&rsquo;s Falcon pipeline, which will carry up to 107,000 barrels of ethane to the cracker plant daily.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In a report issued earlier this year <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PF_FossilFuel_Report_final_2.12.21.pdf"">regarding fossil fuel subsidies</a>, PennFuture predicted at least $400 million in negative externalities in air pollution associated with Shell&rsquo;s plant alone, a number that did not factor in plastics pollution in nearby rivers and waterbodies. Considering the Shell plant will produce up to 1.6 million tons of plastic per year, the real cost of these negative externalities is likely much higher.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s one thing for a company to commission a study about itself, and then use the results of that study in its massive public relations efforts. It&rsquo;s another thing entirely for any entity &mdash;be it academic, media, industry or otherwise&mdash;to study or publicize economic impacts without factoring in every negative externality that comes with a warming planet and changing climate. Any results of such a study should be rendered null and void.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Instead, media outlets ran with the story, with some of them failing to mention that Shell paid for the study, let alone that the study did not factor in these negative externalities.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>These kinds of studies serve one purpose, and one purpose only: to shift the narrative away from pollution, sickness and taxpayer subsidies, to one of economic impact, jobs and revitalization. It&rsquo;s an integral part of the industry&#39;s public relations machine that seeks to convince the public that America needs fossil fuels and extractive industry for prosperity.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s time we call this what it is: propaganda.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
New Report Details the Use of “Forever Chemicals” in Fracking Operations Despite Serious Concerns to Public Health,7/20/2021,"<p>The Physicians for Social Responsibility recently released a report titled <a href=""https://www.psr.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/fracking-with-forever-chemicals.pdf"">&ldquo;Fracking with Forever Chemicals&rdquo;</a> which discusses the current findings and evidence of the use of PFAS in hydraulic fracturing, also known as fracking, for oil and gas.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Put simply, these chemicals are very dangerous because they do not break down in the environment, accumulate in the body, and cause significant human health impacts that can result in severe illness and death. PFAS are found in soil and ground- and drinking-waters in multiple communities throughout the United States, including Pennsylvania, from any number of sources, and the inclusion of these forever toxic chemicals in fracking poses even more risk to our communities.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>What are PFAS and why are they harmful?</u></p>

<p>The per- and polyfluorinated substances, <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/pfas/basic-information-pfas"">known as PFAS</a>, are chemicals used to make coatings and products that resist heat, oil, stains, grease, and water. These coatings are used in products such as clothing, adhesives, furniture, food packaging, heat-resistant non-stick cooking surfaces, and the insulation of electrical wire. PFAS are also used in fire-fighting foams.&nbsp; The most studied PFAS chemicals are perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS) and perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA).&nbsp;</p>

<p>PFAS are known as &ldquo;forever chemicals&rdquo; because they do not break down in the environment. They can move through a broad range of substances (solid, liquid, gas) and contaminate soils, surface and groundwater, and drinking water sources. Small doses of these chemicals build up in the human body and cause threatening chronic and toxic effects such as liver damage, thyroid disease, decreased fertility, hormone suppression, and cancer, especially in children. For more health effects, <a href=""https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/pfas/health-effects/index.html"">see the fact sheet here.</a></p>

<p>Not only do small amounts of these highly toxic forever chemicals threaten our health, but the ubiquitous nature of these chemicals increases the threat exponentially. CDC scientists found groups of PFAS in all people tested for it, showing a widespread effect of these chemicals in the US population. <a href=""https://www.cdc.gov/exposurereport/"">See the study here</a>. Furthermore, PFAS have been found in drinking water supplies, rivers, lakes, soils, and fish and other wildlife and livestock.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But shockingly, at this time, PFAS is not a regulated contaminant either by EPA or Pennsylvania. EPA is currently in the process of listing PFOA and PFOS as hazardous substances under the federal Safe Water Drinking Act (and hopefully other federal environmental statutes) and setting a &ldquo;maximum contaminant level&rdquo; (MCL), but its current health advisory guidelines are just that &ndash; guidelines. PA&rsquo;s process for setting an MCL is dragging along as well, leaving our communities without little to no protections from the toxic forever chemicals.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>PFAS in fracking &ndash; Worse than we thought</u></p>

<p>We know that, despite ongoing evidence of contamination and impacts to local residents and livestock, the fracking industry has long opposed any attempts to require the disclosure of the toxic mix of chemicals used in their operations, citing proprietary business information claims.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This report demonstrates that fracking operations (including well drilling) include the injection of these dangerous forever chemicals through the ground and drinking water and that PFAS can also make it into wastewater produced by fracking. The report discusses that oil and gas companies, including many big companies that have fracked in PA, have used PFAS or substances that can degrade into PFAS in hydraulic fracturing for oil and gas in more than 1,200 wells in six U.S. states between 2012 and 2020.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As mentioned, these companies refused to identify chemicals they were using for fracking and instead treat these chemicals as &ldquo;trade secrets&rdquo; and &ldquo;proprietary information.&rdquo; And this is extremely concerning as the report points out: &ldquo;The lack of full disclosure of chemicals used in oil and gas operations raises the potential that PFAS could have been used even more extensively than records indicate, both geographically and in other stages of the oil and gas extraction process, such as drilling, that precede the underground injections known as fracking.&rdquo; Refusal by fracking companies to disclose the myriad toxic and harmful chemicals they use also makes these chemicals almost impossible to study and to find the right medical treatments for those affected by it.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The impacts to our communities from fracking is no secret (although the chemicals they use remain so), but the inclusion of PFAS in the mix is even worse than we thought.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
<u>Fracking with PFAS in Pennsylvania</u></p>

<p>Fracking has been occurring in Pennsylvania since the technology exploded in 2008. The Marcellus Shale covers much of Pennsylvania and is regulated primarily by the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection. Pennsylvania is currently in the number two spot among gas-producing states in the US, thereby leading many Pennsylvanians to be exposed to fracking operations and these toxic forever chemicals.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2020, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Attorney General issued a report based on a criminal grand jury investigation of oil and gas drilling pollution showing that those living in close proximity to a well pad became chronically and unexplainably ill, especially children that are susceptible to these effects. Also, pets died and farm animals started miscarrying or giving birth to deformed animals. It is suggested that the use of PFAS in fracking is heavily related to this and if these chemicals were found in those six states mentioned in the report, it is highly likely PFAS are used by the fracking companies in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>There are many communities that are significantly impacted by fracking in PA, particularly in Washington and Westmoreland County which contain the most fracking wells that resulted in multiple health problems, from nosebleeds to cancer. There are towns in Pennsylvania that have been ruined by fracking. Take for example Dimock, where it was found that heavy concentrations of methane contaminated the drinking water of several dozen families as a result of Cabot Oil and Gas&rsquo; drilling practices.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It is important to note that the use of PFAS is not only dangerous for those living by the well pads, where they are injected into the ground, but is also likely to contaminate our environment and poison our communities through the treatment and disposal of fracking wastewater.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We hope this knowledge will be enough to help move the needle on the regulation of not only fracking water and wastewater, but also of PFAS themselves.</p>

<p>One example of where this will likely come up sooner than later is with the Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC). The DRBC <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fracking-Banned-in-Delaware-River-Basin"">recently banned fracking within the watershed</a>, and in September, the Commission will consider whether to allow the treatment of fracking wastewater in the basin. Previously, the DRBC withdrew its proposed regulations on transport, storage, treatment, and disposal of fracking wastewater within the Basin, along with its proposed regulations on allowing Delaware River Basin water to be exported outside of the basin to be used in fracking operations, arguably because they were not protective of the basin&rsquo;s water quality.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This report further shows that DRBC should also ban the treatment of wastewater within the watershed given the high threat of PFAS and other toxic contamination. The wastewater produced by fracking contains the chemicals used in drilling and fracking fluids. It is almost certain that PFAS substances may be in the wastewater produced by fracked wells. PennFuture will continue to push DRBC &ndash; and others &ndash; to fully protect our waters, lands, and communities from the dangers of fracking in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Finally, there is currently legislation being drafted and proposed in response to the Pennsylvania Attorney Generals Grand Jury report on fracking. Bills have been introduced already that aim to increase setback requirements and give our Attorney General more enforcement power. We anticipate that such legislation will also include a chemical disclosure requirement, as recommended by the Grand Jury, and we hope that the General Assembly will also consider banning fracking companies from using these toxic forever chemicals in the fracking process.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Please see the following, <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/legis/bi/BillIndx.cfm?sYear=2021&amp;sIndex=0&amp;bod=S"">Senate Bills 650-657 for further information.</a></p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Austin Grace, Legal Intern"
Supreme Court Ruled Natural Gas Companies Can Condemn State-Owned Land,7/15/2021,"<p>The U.S. Supreme Court recently dealt a severe blow <a href=""https://www.mycentraljersey.com/story/news/local/land-environment/2021/07/04/penneast-pipeline-supreme-court-decision-opponents/7819506002/"">in an ongoing fight to prevent PennEast</a>, a private natural gas company, from building a 116 mile natural gas pipeline from the Marcellus Shale region in Pennsylvania into New Jersey.</p>

<p>The proposed pipeline is planned to start in Luzerne County, Pennsylvania, and end in Mercer County, New Jersey. In a divided 5-4 opinion, the Court overturned the 3rd Circuit&rsquo;s decision <a href=""https://ballotpedia.org/PennEast_Pipeline_Co._v._New_Jersey"">and held that PennEast has the authority</a> to condemn land owned by the State of New Jersey for the purposes of building the pipeline under the Natural Gas Act.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The authority derives from a certificate issued by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) to PennEast essentially certifying that the construction of the pipeline is a public convenience and necessity. Section 717f(h) of the Natural Gas Act <a href=""https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/15/717f"">authorizes holders of this FERC certificate to exercise the power</a> of federal eminent domain to condemn any private or State owned right-of-way required to build the &ldquo;necessary&rdquo; pipelines if they cannot secure the right-of-way through contract and negotiated compensation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The issues argued in the 3rd Circuit and the Supreme Court turned on complicated constitutional questions of state sovereign immunity. According to the Supreme Court, condemnation proceedings by PennEast against New Jersey do not violate state sovereign immunity because the states consented to federal eminent domain power (including condemnation proceedings) when they ratified the Constitution, and long established precedent allows the Federal Government to delegate this power to private parties. In reaching this decision, Chief Justice Roberts references the &ldquo;humble beginnings&rdquo; of the Nation&rsquo;s interstate pipeline system in central Indiana, and its development into a system spanning hundreds of thousands of miles thanks to Section 717f(h) of the Natural Gas Act.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennEast seeks to condemn 131 properties in New Jersey. The state of New Jersey has an ownership interest in forty-two of these properties, including many which are preserved for open space, conservation, or farmland. Additionally, the pipeline is planned to cross <a href=""https://www.njspotlight.com/2021/06/us-supreme-court-ruling-controversial-penneast-pipeline-state-of-nj-environmentalists-disappointed/"">at least 31 streams designated as &ldquo;Category One&rdquo;</a> by the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection that meet drinking water needs and provide critical habitat to wildlife.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Habitat and clean drinking water degradation aside, the $1 billion dollar investment is a step backwards in achieving the country&rsquo;s goal <a href=""https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/04/22/fact-sheet-president-biden-sets-2030-greenhouse-gas-pollution-reduction-target-aimed-at-creating-good-paying-union-jobs-and-securing-u-s-leadership-on-clean-energy-technologies/"">of reaching net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050</a>. Stranger still, a financial supporter of the PennEast pipeline, South Jersey Industries (SJI), <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/opinion/commentary/penneast-pipeline-south-jersey-industries-emissions-20210519.html"">has recently announced that it plans</a> to be carbon neutral by 2040. Realistically speaking, the global consensus on the threat of climate change and the strengthened focus on renewable, clean energy is influencing future energy markets and demand. No amount of job creation or greenwashing by its financial backers will change the fact that the PennEast pipeline will be competing in a market faced with a decreasing demand for natural gas.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In an effort to continue to move forward at all costs, PennEast decided to <a href=""https://penneastpipeline.com/penneast-files-new-phased-approach-with-federal-regulators-to-meet-growing-customer-demand/"">break the pipeline project into two phases</a> after regulatory and legal delays so that it could begin building in the areas where it has already gained approval, despite the fact that a number of permits and approvals are still outstanding. Phase 1 would be 68 miles and begin from the Marcellus Shale region in Pennsylvania into Bethlehem Township. Phase 2 would continue through Bucks County and across the Delaware River ending in Mercer County, New Jersey. PennFuture <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PennEast-Chs.-102---105-Comments-Jan.-2021-.pdf"">has previously argued</a> that PennEast, especially in this new phased approach, is a pipeline to nowhere, and that allowing for the construction of the pipeline at this time would result in permanent and unnecessary degradation of our lands and waters.</p>

<p>However, the fight is not over yet. Resistance against the pipeline&rsquo;s construction has been on-going for seven years and there is still pending litigation. There are challenges related to FERC&rsquo;s issuance of the certificate of public necessity that were stayed while the Supreme Court evaluated the case, and they will resume now. PennEast also needs to obtain several permits from the Army Corps of Engineers, the Delaware River Basin Commission, and both the Pennsylvania and New Jersey DEPs to go forward with the project. The Pennsylvania DEP <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/Business/ProgramIntegration/Pennsylvania-Pipeline-Portal/Pages/PennEast.aspx"">provides information on the pipeline status</a> in Pennsylvania, including all of the application and permit materials and information on past and upcoming public hearings.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The DEP has not yet approved the required Chapter 102 (Erosion and Sediment Control) and Chapter 105 (Dam Safety and Waterway Management) permits for the Phase 1 portion of the proposed pipeline, and we continue to oppose this destructive and unnecessary pipeline in PA. Take action against this harmful project by <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/penneastpubliccomments/index.html?eType=EmailBlastContent&amp;eId=857ba55b-70fe-4aac-b6ba-c2a3d556da99"">urging the DEP to deny these permits</a> for the PennEast Pipeline. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">Become a PennFuture member today</a> to stay updated and informed on all the important PennEast pipeline news and opportunities for public engagement!</p>

<p>More information on the PennEast pipeline:</p>

	<li><a href=""https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/20pdf/19-1039_8n5a.pdf"">Read the SCOTUS decision on the PennEast pipeline</a></li>
	<li><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Environmental-Impacts-and-the-PennEast-Pipeline"">2017 press conference about the environmental impacts of the pipeline construction.</a><br />
