",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Will Pennsylvania’s Environment Ever Be A Priority for the Legislature?,6/29/2021,"<p>Probably no profession requires taking the long view as does that of the environmental advocate. That&rsquo;s probably why I&rsquo;m so fond of the proverb, &ldquo;Hope springs eternal.&rdquo; It reminds me of the aspect of human nature that will always seek out cause for optimism, and I hold onto it because of that possibility.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Holding onto optimism feels a little challenging these days. Last week, the state budget that PennFuture so optimistically saw as a chance for lawmakers and the Governor to invest in a greener future, fell far short of making those investments, and the support for clean water we were hoping to see never materialized. Yes, the budget came through in important ways. The Governor and the legislature agreed to their funding priorities, none of them environmental. And perhaps, no surprise, fossil fuels made it to their list.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This budget cycle again boosted fracking, and petrochemicals like fertilizer and plastics. We&rsquo;ve bellyached a lot in this blog about the largesse the legislature has shown the petrochemical industry through subsidies and other tax giveaways, and PennFuture has documented this serious problem most recently in <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PF_FossilFuel_Report_final_2.12.21.pdf"">the third edition of our Fossil Fuel subsidy report.</a> When it passed <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-responds-to-passage-of-House-Bill-732"">House Bill 732 (Act 66) last summer</a>, state government set up $6.67 million in annual tax credits for up to four facilities that will use dry gas to produce petrochemicals or fertilizers.</p>

<p>Less than one year later, using the tax code legislation that accompanied last week&rsquo;s approved state budget, the legislature reduced the number of facilities (from four facilities, to up to two facilities) that can qualify for the tax credits, but left the aggregate cap in place guaranteeing there will be unallocated credits. The legislation also stipulated&nbsp;that the Department of Revenue must give those unallocated credits to only one of the qualifying facilities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Like so much else about Pennsylvania&rsquo;s opaque budget process, there was no transparency or forewarning that this move was afoot.&nbsp; It was presumably negotiated by the main budget players &ndash; Governor Wolf, Senate Majority Leader Kim Ward, Senate President Pro Tempore Jake Corman, House Majority Leader Kerry Benninghoff, and Speaker of the House Bryan Cutler &ndash; and the closed-door process forces us to make these kinds of presumptions.&nbsp;What is verifiable is that the state budget and its accompanying tax and fiscal codes received a majority of votes and the Governor has signed the legislation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We are also left to conjecture why the tax subsidy was re-structured so that a much larger piece of the subsidy pie will go to just one&nbsp;petrochemical manufacturer.&nbsp;We are concluding that there is indeed a petrochemical interest waiting in the wings, looking to set up shop here in Pennsylvania, but they sought a much sweeter pie.&nbsp;Hence the legislature and Governor have structured a revised subsidy that&#39;s grown from over $6.6 million to at least $20 million each&nbsp;year for the next 24 years&nbsp;for some lucky grand prize winner.&nbsp;The beneficiaries of these giveaways will in turn buy fracked gas, employ workers, and transform some lucky part&nbsp;of our magnificent state into a petrochemical industrial nightmare.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Some really great things could have been done with the budget this time around because state legislators and the Governor weren&rsquo;t constrained by revenue availability. They have in hand $7 billion in federal money to address Covid impacts including economic recovery and stimulus. Politicians didn&rsquo;t need to once again pick winners, and losers. But they did, and so lead in drinking water will go unaddressed, as will the thousands of miles of dead streams impacted by legacy pollution from coal, and they&rsquo;ve also forgotten the agricultural producers under scrutiny to put more best management practices on their lands and along waterways to improve the health of the Susquehanna River. Instead, politicians decided to bank more than half of the funds, rather than investing in assets like cleaner water, or making Pennsylvania more competitive in the green economy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture works very hard for good outcomes, often playing defense. But the anti-environmental and anti-democracy members of the state legislature are running the show. We are grateful for the times the Governor has used his veto to stop the most egregious measures the legislature comes up with.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture is taking some respite in an alternative pathway to meet our mission advocating for clean air and water, a healthy climate and green economy. It&rsquo;s a path that runs through Washington, not through Harrisburg. President Joe Biden is artfully trying to broker a bi-partisan infrastructure package. It seems separately, he&rsquo;s also attempting a complicated maneuver that may eventually get to investments that make us more climate resilient. But forgive me for being haunted by the ghost of 2013, when a sweeping cap and trade climate bill became a casualty of the Affordable Care Act.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Another interesting proverb I&rsquo;ve pondered along the way is, &ldquo;Politics is the art of the possible.&rdquo; Making a lot of people happy is a rarity in politics, so count me as an unhappy Pennsylvania environmental advocate for the moment. But to think that the half-baked budget this state just approved pushed the limits of what is politically possible is not something I can accept.</p>

<p>The lack of work done by our legislators in the budget process feels lazy at best, blatantly irresponsible at worst, lacking vision and optimism. Nor will I be able to accept any federal infrastructure package that comes to fruition, if it is devoid of green infrastructure that can help us finally deal with the climate crisis. But there is still time to work hard for, and possibly achieve, a hopeful outcome.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
"The Chesapeake Bay is Improving, but Still a Long Road to 2025",6/25/2021,"<p>This week, the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science (UMCES) gave the Chesapeake Bay a C <a href=""https://ecoreportcard.org/site/assets/files/2452/2020-chesapeake-bay-watershed-report-card.pdf"">in their latest report card</a>. This is an improvement from last year&rsquo;s grade of C-.</p>

<p>UMCES assigns grades to numerous regions across the estuary and watershed. The Upper Bay, where Pennsylvania contributes 90 percent of the freshwater, received a grade of C, showing a health trend that is significantly improving. In Pennsylvania, the West Branch of the Susquehanna scored an A-, the Lower Susquehanna and Juniata watersheds received a B-, and the Middle Susquehanna a C+.&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>This year&rsquo;s report card has new social and economic indicators of watershed health, including stewardship, protected lands, walkability, and heat vulnerability. As the President for UMCES, Dr. Peter Goodwin, pointed out, &ldquo;Improvements in our environment go hand-in-hand with improvements in our communities, particularly those that are traditionally disadvantaged.&rdquo;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The indicators showed varying results. The scores for dissolved oxygen and total nitrogen improved. However, chlorophyll a&mdash;a measure of algae&mdash;and total phosphorus scores declined, with a slight decrease in water clarity, benthic community (aquatic life living at the bottom and an important food source for the ecosystem) and aquatic grass scores.</p>

<p>The UMCES says that the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on the health of Chesapeake Bay are not yet known, except for a reduction in atmospheric nitrogen from reduced travel and commuting. Between March and May 2020m, routine water monitoring did not take place.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The good news is that long-term trends of the indicators are showing improvement,thus demonstrating that the efforts taken to improve the health of the stream that drains to the Chesapeake Bay are working.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania is required to reduce its load of pollution into the Susquehanna and Potomac Rivers by 34 million pounds of nitrogen and 756,000 pounds of phosphorus by 2025.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania has long remained behind in meeting clean water goals to address the health of the Chesapeake Bay. That&rsquo;s why this April, PennFuture released a report that provides a legislative roadmap to fully meet our funding and policy needs.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Titled<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Final-Chesapeake-report.pdf""> &ldquo;Underfunded and Polluted: Solutions to Fund Clean Water in Pennsylvania and the Chesapeake Bay Watershed,&rdquo;</a> our report puts forth a legislative agenda that, if acted upon, would provide the technical assistance, agency support, and public investments needed to put Pennsylvania on the path toward meeting the Environmental Protection Agency&rsquo;s Chesapeake Bay Total Maximum Daily Load, or the so-called &ldquo;pollution diet&rdquo; goals, by its 2025 end date.</p>

<p>Efforts to improve the Bay will benefit our local waterways here in Pennsylvania. The Susquehanna River watershed&mdash;including a portion in New York&mdash; contains over 49,000 miles of streams. There are more than 15,000 miles of polluted streams within Pennsylvania&rsquo;s portions of the Susquehanna and Potomac River Basins alone.</p>

<p><u><strong>What We&#39;re Watching in the General Assembly</strong></u></p>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s annual state budget must be passed by June 30th. PennFuture and our partners advocate for increases in funding for critical clean water programs at the Department of Environmental Protection, the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, and the Department of Agriculture.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Right now, Pennsylvania is faced with a unique opportunity. The recent passage of the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 provides the Commonwealth with $7 billion in federal funds. We believe that <a href=""https://www.pennlive.com/opinion/2021/06/pennsylvania-should-invest-federal-covid-relief-funds-in-clean-water-projects-opinion.html"">a portion of the funding should be invested</a> to improve and protect our rivers and streams. The state is also facing a potential $3 billion projected budget surplus.</p>

<p>We are working to secure dedicated funding for clean water through programs such as the creation of a Clean Streams Fund as well as a reinvigorated Growing Greener III program. We&rsquo;re advocating that a portion of this money&mdash;at least $500 million&mdash;be invested in our water resources which in turn supports jobs, a vibrant recreation economy, and supplies our drinking water.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The <a href=""https://www.trcp.org/2018/12/10/outdoor-recreation-ranks-pennsylvanias-economy/"">Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Partnership</a> found that outdoor recreation in Pennsylvania contributes to over 390,000 jobs with a total value of $26.9 billion, including over $7 billion in federal, state, and local tax revenue.</p>

<p>Another bill we are tracking is the Agricultural Conservation Assistance Program, or ACAP, that is proposed to help farmers install conservation practices that improve and protect our rivers and streams. Senate Bill 465 would significantly improve the water quality impacted by nutrient pollution in Pennsylvania. Senate Bill 465:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Expands upon the Conservation Excellence Grant Program, a program from the PA Farm Bill;</li>
	<li>Provides flexibility and places decision-making power at the local level where counties and farmers can make decisions based on local need and benefit;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Can provide up to 100 percent of a project&rsquo;s cost, which can leverage other private and state and federal funding sources; and,</li>
	<li>Allows County Conservation Districts, the State Conservation Commission, and Penn State or similar institutions to keep a small percentage of allocated funds for technical assistance and administrative costs.&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>Another clean water bill we are tracking is SB 251. This is a lawn fertilizer bill that would reduce the excess nutrients that are impacting the health of our waterways. Over 2,600 miles of the Commonwealth&rsquo;s streams are impaired due to excess nutrients, which is the 5th leading cause. One source of excess nutrients comes from applying excess fertilizer. Passage of SB 251 will:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Create a level playing field across the state and protect local waters. This bill will move towards one standard across the region, providing regional companies with similar market requirements to those in neighboring states</li>
	<li>Limit how much nitrogen and phosphorus are applied to turf (grass) protecting our waterways from excess nutrients running off into our streams.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Establish a professional fertilizer applicator certification program, similar to pesticide applicators, to ensure that professionals apply fertilizers at the proper rates.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Develop an Agricultural and Homeowner Education Program to educate nonprofessional applicators on the proper rate of applying fertilizers.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Protect consumers through standardization of fertilizer composition and labels.</li>
</ul>

<p>The University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science&rsquo;s recent report card is proof that investments in our waterways can make an impact. It&rsquo;s encouraging to see the health of the Bay improve and Pennsylvania&rsquo;s passing grades. The Commonwealth has the resources available and pending legislation to make significant investments in the health of our rivers and streams.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our legislators have a choice to make&mdash;invest in our constitutional right to clean water or continue to see slow improvements to Pennsylvania&rsquo;s 25,000 miles of impaired streams.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/waterbudget"">Do your part today and click here to contact your elected officials.</a> Tell them to advocate for increased funding for clean water initiatives and programs, and to support efforts to improve the health of waterways across Pennsylvania. When legislators invest in our waterways, we all benefit. Clean water is essential for healthy communities, healthy residents, and healthy economies.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Renee Reber, Campaign Manager, Watershed Advocacy"
Federal Court Dismissed Lawsuit Challenging DRBC’s Ban on Fracking,6/24/2021,"<p>We continue to bring you good news on the fracking front in the Delaware River Basin. In February 2021, the Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC) took the <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fracking-Banned-in-Delaware-River-Basin"">monumental step in passing regulations</a> that ban the use of high volume hydraulic fracturing technology (&ldquo;fracking&rdquo;) to extract shale gas within the Delaware River Basin.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As predicted, a legal challenge was quickly filed challenging the DRBC&rsquo;s authority to ban fracking, spearheaded by PA State Senators Gene Yaw and Lisa Baker, the PA Senate Republican Caucus, and several municipalities. PennFuture, joined by partners, responded by submitting a <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-Environmental-Groups-Law-Center-File-Friend-of-Court-Brief-in-Opposition-to-Challenge-to-Delaware-River-Basin-Commission-Fracking-Ban"">&ldquo;friend of the court&rdquo; brief</a> which focused on the erroneous Environmental Rights Amendment claims made by the plaintiffs. (Article I, Section 27 of the Pennsylvania Constitution recognizes a fundamental public right to clean air, pure water, and to the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic and esthetic values of the environment and to have the Commonwealth conserve and maintain public natural resources for the benefit of present and future generations.) Our brief supported the arguments of the DRBC and intervenors that the plaintiffs lacked standing to bring this lawsuit.</p>

<p>On June 11, 2021, the District Court for the Eastern District of PA <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Opinion-on-Dismissing-Yaw-Suit.pdf"">agreed and dismissed the case</a> holding that the plaintiffs lacked standing to file this case. Standing is the legal concept that ensures that a party has a &ldquo;dog in the fight&rdquo; &ndash; basically have they suffered the right kind of redressable injury to bring the lawsuit and &ldquo;stand&rdquo; before the court. Ultimately, Judge Paul S. Diamond concluded that this dispute &ldquo;is primarily partisan and is best resolved through the political process.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In particular, Judge Diamond disagreed with the Senators&rsquo; claims that state law vests them with sufficient interest to confer standing as does their claimed status as &ldquo;trustees&rdquo; under the Environmental Rights Amendment, calling these theories &ldquo;meritless.&rdquo; The plaintiffs failed to show that the DRBC&rsquo;s actions harmed them: &ldquo;Although all plaintiffs argue vigorously that they have standing, they do not.&rdquo; However, while foreclosed to the Senate plaintiffs, the court left open the possibility for the municipal plaintiffs to refile with strengthened allegations. The plaintiffs have 30 days to appeal this decision if they so choose.</p>

<p>The fact that DRBC&rsquo;s ban on fracking survived its first legal challenge is definitely cause for celebration! We have been waiting <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Moratorium-on-Fracking-in-the-Delaware-River-Basin-is-Critical-to-Protect-Our-Water"">for over a decade for the DRBC&rsquo;s ban</a> to become permanent and we believe the final ban will withstand any challenges.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But challenges to DRBC&rsquo;s authority over fracking still remain. Not only could the municipal plaintiffs refile this case and the parties can also appeal the decision, but there is an outstanding 2016 lawsuit against DRBC filed by the Wayne Land and Mineral Group. That case challenges DRBC&rsquo;s authority under the Delaware River Basin Compact to regulate shale gas development in the Basin as a &ldquo;project.&rdquo; The impact of both the finalization of the DRBC&rsquo;s fracking ban regulations and the recent decision in Yaw v. DRBC is still being considered.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Additionally, the DRBC withdrew its proposed regulations on transport, storage, treatment, and disposal of fracking wastewater within the Basin and its proposed regulations on allowing Delaware River Basin water to be exported outside of the basin to be used in fracking operations. PennFuture took issue with their <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Public-Comment-Closes-on-DRBC-Fracking-Regulations"">first draft regulations</a> asking for them to be withdrawn because they were not protective of basin waters. The DRBC has until September 2021 to release new regulations on these matters.</p>

<p>PennFuture remains committed to protecting the Delaware River watershed from the harmful impacts of fracking and we will continue to engage on these matters. Please <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">become a member today</a> to support our efforts!</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Introduction: An Intersectional Approach to Fighting the Petrochemical Buildout in Pennsylvania,6/23/2021,"<p>Modern-day Pennsylvania was molded by the rapid technological advancements of the Industrial Revolution. The result of such advancements on human health, however, was devastating: these facilities required fossil fuels (which&nbsp;involve&nbsp;an environmentally destructive process to extract in the first place) which directly led to poor air quality, poisoned water, and destroyed soil in the decades to follow. Pennsylvania&#39;s&nbsp;residents are still feeling the effects of this today.</p>

<p>Science and technology have long been on a path of creating better machines which are much more environmentally friendly. However, especially in western Pennsylvania where I am now based, petrochemical companies are stubbornly refusing to acknowledge the world changing around them. Petrochemical companies hold over the heads of their workers the threat of losing their livelihood if the companies are further pushed by &ldquo;environmentalists.&rdquo;</p>

<p>This is why I joined the fight. I believe in the dignity of the human being, and thus, the dignity of the worker. Every citizen deserves not only a job, but a job that respects the air they breathe, water they drink, and land they live on. I aim to look at our work through this intersectional lens, as environmental issues (specifically the petrochemical and plastics issues) are directly correlated with every person&rsquo;s socioeconomic status, general health and wellbeing, and race, just to name a few.</p>

<p>My name is John Ukenye, and I am originally from South Florida, but am now based in Pittsburgh. Both sides of my family&rsquo;s story are immigrant ones, with my father&rsquo;s story in the United States beginning in Pittsburgh itself. After relocating to South Florida to continue his collegiate studies, he&nbsp;brought me to western Pennsylvania throughout my childhood and I fell in love with its natural beauty and the friendly people that live here. I knew early in my life that I was called to this state and to lend whatever talents I cultivated to help. The environmental realm is one that reaches all Pennsylvanians, and sits at the center of all other issues every person in the state faces.</p>

<p>My first direct experience in the environmental space was during my time as a law clerk with the U.S. House of Representatives&#39;&nbsp;Committee on Oversight and Reform, Subcommittee on Environment in Spring 2020, right before&nbsp;COVID-19&nbsp;reached &ldquo;pandemic&rdquo; designation. One of the last issues I was working on was preparing for a series of hearings on plastic pollution and the over-extraction of water from regional aquifers. I did research on how plastic water bottle manufacturers capitalized on the corroded lead pipe situation in Flint, Michigan by selling and donating what was essentially their own local tap water back to the affected people in the region, now additionally wrapped in toxic plastic single-use packaging. This situation perfectly highlighted the intersection between the environment, the plastics industry, race, and class.&nbsp;</p>

<p>My goal, from the moment I knew I wanted to go to law school, was to promote equity and justice no matter where I ended up. I fought my way through my undergraduate education, finished in three years with two degrees, honors, and Phi Beta Kappa and was admitted to Washington University School of Law where I graduated roughly a year ago. I graduated into a world that was facing a pandemic and a civil rights and social justice reckoning simultaneously, where race and class issues became dinner table conversations across the country and the globe. Average, everyday people&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/intersectionality"">began to see the intersectionality</a> among EVERY issue, and these discussions continue on to this day. This is a perfect time as ever to view our work from a similar equity, justice, and intersectional perspective.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our membership is no doubt plugged in to the environmental issues plaguing our world, country, state, and Appalachian region. While important to keep our supporters engaged, we must continue to actively reach out to those less informed about our area of work. It is those individuals who stand to be harmed the most by continued inaction on the environmental front.&nbsp;</p>

<p>These individuals include both rural western Pennsylvanians (as well as the rest of Appalachia), especially those who work in the dying fracked gas industry, and Black and brown families that live near petrochemical plants due to historic redlining and environmental racism. Both groups stand to gain from uniting against the fracked gas, petrochemical, and plastics industries. Both groups are in generally in the same socioeconomic class, and both generally face the same issues of dirty air, water, and land caused by the petrochemical industry and plastic pollution. It is this disproportionate burden of <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/PublicParticipation/OfficeofEnvironmentalJustice/pages/default.aspx"">harmful environmental and human health impacts</a> that environmental justice seeks to overcome.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Both groups include hardworking people trying to feed their families, and do not deserve to have their ability to provide for their families threatened by petrochemical companies that are simultaneously destroying their land, water, and air.</p>

<p>We must explicitly recognize this intersectionality in the work we do, highlight both their struggles and triumphs from local leaders in the environmental space, and work to do our part to encourage the creation of better-paying green jobs that respect workers&#39; rights&nbsp;to breath, drink, and live freely.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"John Ukenye, Policy Analyst"
Biden Administration Working to Repeal Trump's 'Dirty Water Rule',6/17/2021,"<p>We bring to you another update in the decades-long saga of protecting &ldquo;waters of the United States&rdquo; (WOTUS) under the federal Clean Water Act, but this time it is a positive step toward renewing federal jurisdiction over some of our most critical streams and wetlands that were stripped of protection by the Trump Administration in 2020.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Since the United States Supreme Court&rsquo;s 2006 split decision in Rapanos v. United States, there has been uncertainty and litigation over what waterbodies classify as WOTUS and therefore will fall within the Clean Water Act&rsquo;s protections. PennFuture joined <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-Opposes-Any-Repeal-of-the-Clean-Water-Rule"">over 50,000 Pennsylvanians in supporting the 2015 Clean Water Rule</a> that attempted to bring clarity to the definition of WOTUS. And we vigorously opposed <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-Opposes-Any-Repeal-of-the-Clean-Water-Rule"">the Trump Administration&rsquo;s repeal</a> and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-Submits-Comments-Opposing-the-Dirty-Water-Rule-Engages-More-Than-1400-Citizens-to-Do-the-Same"">replacement of the Clean Water Rule</a> with the 2020 Navigable Waters Protection Rule, more correctly known as the &ldquo;Dirty Water Rule.&rdquo; Despite numerous legal challenges across the nation which lead to a patchwork of rules, as of March 2021, the Dirty Water Rule is in effect in all 50 states.&nbsp;</p>

<p>On June 9, 2021, however, the Biden administration <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/wotus/intention-revise-definition-waters-united-states"">formally began the process to repeal and replace</a> the Dirty Water Rule, which reduced the number of water bodies that would be protected by the Clean Water Act <a href=""https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/biden-moves-to-restore-clean-water-safeguards-ended-by-trump/ar-AAKSsNZ?ocid=BingNewsSearch"">by twenty-five percent</a> and was determined to have led to significant environmental degradation, with thousands of streams and hundreds of permits at jeopardy. Across the country, thousands of wetlands and waterways that maintain water quality and drinking water sources and protect nearby communities from flooding <a href=""https://www.southernenvironment.org/news-and-press/news-feed/biden-administration-announcement-leaves-crucial-waters-in-jeopardy"">have already been destroyed</a> as a result of the Dirty Water Rule.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Dirty Water Rule excludes ephemeral waters (temporary water bodies that only occur after precipitation) and wetlands that are not physically connected to a navigable water body by a visible surface connection. The rule is not based on science and greatly benefited the oil and gas industry and developers by allowing them to fill in wetlands and streams without a permit. The reality is that wetlands are extremely important natural filters that protect waterbodies, whether they are visibly connected by a continuous surface connection or not. Ephemeral waters <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2015-03/documents/ephemeral_streams_report_final_508-kepner.pdf"">play crucial ecological and hydrological roles</a> in maintaining water quality and watershed function and health, and are particularly important in the southwestern states. The EPA&rsquo;s own data shows that ephemeral waters provide drinking water to 117 million Americans.</p>

<p>The new rule will aim to restore protections and establish a durable definition of protected waters. EPA&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/epa-army-announce-intent-revise-definition-wotus"">news release explained</a> that the new rule will be informed by Supreme Court precedent, lessons learned from current and previous regulations, and stakeholder engagement. Additionally, it will be guided by considerations to protect water resources and communities, science and the effects of climate change to national waters, and efforts for practical implementation in states and Tribal communities. The Dirty Water Rule, by contrast, <a href=""https://yosemite.epa.gov/sab/sabproduct.nsf/ea5d9a9b55cc319285256cbd005a472e/5939af1252ddadfb852584e10053d472/$FILE/WOTUS SAB Draft Commentary_10_16_19_.pdf"">was admonished by EPA&rsquo;s own science advisors</a> as being in conflict with established science and the objectives of the Clean Water Act.</p>

<p>And some of the impacts from the Dirty Water Rule are already being felt locally by threatening restoration efforts of the Chesapeake Bay Watershed because excluded waters feed into the Chesapeake Bay. The Choose Clean Water Coalition, a coalition of organizations that advocate for clean rivers and streams in the Chesapeake Bay region of which PennFuture is the PA State Lead, <a href=""https://www.choosecleanwater.org/news/2021/6/10/plans-to-repeal-dirty-water-rule-a-big-win-for-chesapeake-bay"">released a statement supporting the EPA&rsquo;s decision</a> to revise the current rule and also urge them to replace it with one that restores protections to waterways and wetlands.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Stakeholders are encouraged to share their input during the rulemaking process. <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/wotus/public-outreach-and-stakeholder-engagement-activities-forthcoming"">Information on opportunities for public engagement</a> are forthcoming and PennFuture intends to engage in this process to ensure full protections of our critical headwaters and wetlands. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">Become a PennFuture member today</a> to stay informed and get engaged!</p>

<p>More information on the Dirty Water Rule:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-New-Definition-of-Waters-of-the-United-States-Threatens-Clean-Water-Act-Protections"">PennFuture&rsquo;s blog post on the Dirty Water Rule</a></li>
	<li><a href=""https://www.facebook.com/watch/live/?v=356380261631140&amp;ref=watch_permalink"">Video presentation on the Dirty Water Rule</a></li>
</ul>
",Climate; Community; Environment,"Emily Rollins, Legal Intern"
The Plastics Problem: More False Strategies: Statewide Preemption,6/15/2021,"<p>Regular readers of this blog will be familiar with the Pennsylvania Legislature&rsquo;s attempts to <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Regulatory-Reforms-Would-Roll-Back-Environmental-and-Health-Protections"">stymie advances in environmental protection</a> and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Legislators-Continue-to-Stand-in-the-Way-of-Climate-Action"">efforts to deny the realities of climate change.</a>&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Our Legislature has been employing a new strategy when it comes to promoting plastics and petrochemicals, and it is just as problematic. That problematic strategy is known as &ldquo;preemption.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Preemption is the legal concept that a higher-level governmental body can prevent or overrule the actions of lower-level governmental bodies. For example, the federal government can pass laws or regulations that stop a state from passing different laws on a specific issue , or that override laws previously passed by a state on an issue. Similarly, a state legislature can pass laws that stop or override municipalities in that state from enacting laws&nbsp; or override laws that the municipality has previously passed.</p>

<p>Preemption is not, in the abstract,&nbsp; necessarily a bad thing. There are reasons why a state might want to have a whole-of-state approach to a certain issue, rather than having piecemeal regulation by different municipalities across the state.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>For example, the state may want to have - and indeed does have! - uniform rules on how drivers&rsquo; licenses are issued because there is a reasonable interest in having statewide uniformity in requirements for testing and licensing procedures, rather than having each town or city design its own rules for allowing drivers on the roads.</p>

<p>Here, however, the Legislature is not trying to make uniform rules across the Commonwealth for safety reasons, or to lessen the burden on municipalities, or to benefit a statewide goal.&nbsp; Here, the legislature is trying to stop municipalities from taking environmentally-beneficial actions in order to protect the fossil fuel and petrochemical industries.</p>

<p>The first example is the Legislature&rsquo;s action to prevent municipalities from banning single-use plastic bags.</p>

<p>In June of 2019, the Pennsylvania Legislature passed a fiscal code amendment (SB712) that included, as an add-on provision unconnected to the rest of the fiscal code, a prohibition which states: the &ldquo;General Assembly or a local governmental body or agency may not enact a law, rule, regulation or ordinance imposing a tax on or relating to the use, disposition, sale, prohibition or restriction of single-use plastics, reusable plastics, auxiliary containers, wrappings, or polystyrene containers&rdquo; until a report on the economic and environmental impact of plastics on the Commonwealth was submitted.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This report was submitted in June 2020.&nbsp; Around that same time, in the middle of the Covid-19 pandemic, the Legislature again used the fiscal code to effectively delay implementation of any current plastic bag bans at least until July 1, 2021, or six months after the COVID-19 state of emergency is lifted.</p>

<p>Why would the Legislature do this?&nbsp;In order to promote uniform plastics laws across the Commonwealth?&nbsp;This cannot be the case, because there are no other statewide plastics laws in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;In fact, the Legislature here is not acting to promote positive statewide regulation at all, but instead to promote the petrochemical industry.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The state&rsquo;s own report on &ldquo;The Economic Impacts of Regulation of Single Use Plastics&rdquo; is very clear:&nbsp; &ldquo;The regulation of single-use plastics could also have indirect implications for the prospective clustering of petrochemical manufacturing facilities in the state. Pennsylvania is the second-largest producer of natural gas in the U.S. and the state&rsquo;s capacity for natural gas production and proximity to major markets make it an attractive location for new petrochemical facilities...Industry representatives noted that single-use plastics regulation could make the state a less viable option for prospective petrochemical and plastics manufacturers:&rdquo;&nbsp;<a href=""http://www.ifo.state.pa.us/download.cfm?file=Resources/Documents/Single-Use%20Plastics%20Report-2020_06.pdf"">Economic Impact Report at page 33, 35.</a></p>

<p>Municipalities, of course, <a href=""https://www.penncapital-star.com/energy-environment/plastic-bag-preemption-suit-takes-aim-at-long-time-harrisburg-dealmaking-mechanism/"">have taken a different view.</a>&nbsp;Municipalities across the state have considered banning or otherwise regulating single-use plastics.&nbsp;The City of Philadelphia, Narbeth, and West Chester have passed ordinances doing so. Other municipalities, such as Ferguson Township in Centre County, the City of Bethlehem, and the City of Pittsburgh have actively considered doing so.&nbsp; These local government entities have pointed to <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/science/climate/philadelphia-single-use-plastic-bag-ban-mark-squilla-20190620.html"">plastic bag litter in their borders and clogging their waterways</a> as reasons to pass these ordinances.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The second example is the Legislature&rsquo;s ongoing attempt to prevent municipalities from restricting the types of energy used in buildings.&nbsp;Again, why would the legislature do this?&nbsp;To promote a uniform energy policy across the state?&nbsp;No, it is clear that the Legislature wants to promote the use of fracked gas.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The legislature previously tried, through Act 13 in 2013, to specifically eliminate the ability of municipalities to regulate the development of oil and gas resources. The PA State Supreme Court <a href=""http://www.pacourts.us/assets/opinions/Supreme/out/J-127A-D-2012oajc.pdf"">struck down this provision</a> as a violation of the Environmental Rights Amendment of the Pennsylvania Constitution.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Legislature <a href=""https://www.penncapital-star.com/government-politics/an-energy-choice-bill-has-some-lawmakers-worried-local-government-could-lose-power/"">is currently trying to enact very similar legislation</a> targeted at utility services rather than gas development companies, but the effect would be the same, and by focusing only on utility services the proposed legislation <a href=""https://local-government.pasenategop.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/62/2021/05/Additional-Testimony-PENNFUTURE-Letter-to-PA-Senate-on-SB-275-May-7-2021.pdf"">would give preferential treatment</a> to the polluting gas industry.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the City of Philadelphia, the Office of Sustainability <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/opinion/editorials/philadelphia-gas-works-pgw-public-utility-climate-change-lng-20210607.html"">is conducting a study</a> about how the gas utility, Philadelphia Gas Works, can transition away from being an entirely gas-driven utility, in line with Mayor Jim Kenney&#39;s commitment that Philadelphia will achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 in alignment with the Paris Agreement.&nbsp;The Legislature&rsquo;s preemption attempt here would stop this work in Philadelphia in its tracks.</p>

<p>To be fair, the Pennsylvania Legislature is not alone in attempting to stop the municipalities in its state from making positive environmental changes.&nbsp; This is a strategy that national anti-regulatory groups are pushing to state legislatures nationwide to prevent local governments from taking the initiative to solve their own problems.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The real problem with this sort of preemption is that it doesn&rsquo;t solve any problems - it just puts up roadblocks to creating meaningful policy change.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Legislature is not pushing solutions or enacting statewide policies; instead, it is just telling municipalities that they are prevented from the sort of creative problem solving that the American system of federalism is supposed to promote. When it comes to the problem of plastics, we need real solutions, not roadblocks.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jessica O'Neill, Senior Attorney"
"Coal-Fired Power Plant to Close Because of Market Conditions, Not Environmental Regulations",6/11/2021,"<p>On June 9, the owner of the Cheswick coal-fired power plant in Allegheny County, Houston-based GenOn Holdings LLC, announced that the plant <a href=""https://www.genon.com/genon-news/genon-holdings-llc-announces-retirement-of-three-coal-fired-power-plants"">would cease operations effective on&nbsp;Sept. 15, 2021.</a></p>

<p>This was no surprise to industry-watchers and, despite the claims from polluters and their friends, this had little to do with environmental regulations. To be sure, Cheswick&mdash;one of the top emitters of toxic air pollutants in Allegheny County&mdash;is facing lawsuits for releasing hot water into the Allegheny River and for inappropriately turning off pollution control equipment, but even without these lawsuits, Cheswick was struggling.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Most of the energy we use in Pennsylvania is purchased at auctions run by our grid operator, PJM Interconnection. Generators that bid low enough to clear these auctions get called up to run and provide us power&mdash;in return they receive whatever the market-clearing price is for the energy that PJM needs to meet demand.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>As I write this on June 10, the spot market was clearing around $25 per megawatt-hour.&nbsp; A plant like Cheswick could, at least theoretically, earn over $300,000 a day in conditions like this and much more if prices spike higher. But, to earn anything at all, it needs to be among the least-expensive resources available to meet demand. This is a problem for Cheswick, as it is a relatively small plant with a single generating unit that uses an older and less-efficient process&mdash;while these were once common in Pennsylvania, it is the last of its kind.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Even when coal plants were competitive, they wouldn&rsquo;t always be able to run at full capacity for long periods of time as required maintenance and market factors would drive down capacity factors. Seeing these facilities averaging around 60% capacity over the course of a year wasn&rsquo;t unusual.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Increasingly, though, coal plants that are able to run are too expensive to clear the PJM auction and sit idle. According to data from the Energy Information Administration, Cheswick averaged only 15% of its rated capacity in 2019 and not even 10% of its rated capacity in 2020.&nbsp; That&rsquo;s terrible for any business&mdash;no one would expect a restaurant to stay open if 90% of its tables remained empty.</p>

<p>Cheswick was likely only hanging on because of some additional revenue from other sources.&nbsp; Alongside the energy market, PJM also runs a capacity market designed to ensure we have sufficient generation available to meet our needs in the future. This is also an auction system where PJM predicts the amount of generation it will need years in advance and generators submit bids committing to be available, if needed, for a price. Back in 2018, PJM ran an auction for the 2021/22 delivery year that cleared at $140 per megawatt-day for most of the region.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Over-procuring capacity is a serious problem in these auctions. Every extra megawatt of capacity PJM buys drives up the clearing price, forcing consumers to spend billions of dollars more than necessary and, in many cases, those billions subsidize inefficient, old, and dirty fossil fuel plants running that would otherwise retire. Cheswick is a prime example, a plant that size could see almost $30 million in revenue this year from the capacity market, even if they are rarely called upon to actually generate energy.</p>

<p>The capacity auction for next year (the 2022/23 delivery year) would have taken place in 2019, but market adjustments required by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) delayed the auction until this year. A number of factors, including not needing to predict demand three years in advance, meant PJM didn&rsquo;t find it necessary to procure nearly as much additional capacity. That led to much lower capacity prices.</p>

<p>Where this year, capacity resources are getting $140 per megawatt-day, next year those payments will drop to&nbsp; $50 per megawatt-day.&nbsp;This drop in the clearing price <a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/experts/tom-rutigliano/how-save-four-billion-without-really-trying"">will save consumers about $4.2 billion dollars</a> in total or about $100 on the average electricity bill over the year.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Not buying billions worth of unnecessary capacity is a huge win for consumers, but it&rsquo;s very bad news for coal. This year we saw 8,175 fewer megawatts worth of coal capacity cleared the market than did in the previous auction. One of the casualties of this was the Cheswick plant.&nbsp; About a week after the PJM auction results were released, the plant&#39;s owner, GenOn, announced that the plant would cease operation effective June 1, 2022&mdash;the first day of PJM&rsquo;s 2022/23 delivery year.</p>

<p>Any time a fossil fuel plant retires, polluters and their backers almost always blame environmental rules. This is no exception and opponents of Pennsylvania joining the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) have already made repeated claims that the extra expense from RGGI (which hasn&rsquo;t gone into effect yet) was the reason Cheswick failed to clear the PJM capacity auction. This makes no sense as capacity resources are just making a commitment to be available if called, not necessarily to run. Operating costs, such as RGGI&rsquo;s emissions fees, should be reflected in the company&rsquo;s energy market bids, not the capacity market.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
RGGI opponents who make these claims are also saying that if we keep the status quo, where plants like this get to pollute for free, these plants will stay open for ten years or more. The part they don&rsquo;t say out loud is that if polluters don&rsquo;t pay for the cost of their pollution, the rest of us do.&nbsp; Increased pollution means more suffering and premature deaths, higher healthcare and insurance costs for everyone, and lost productivity that increases the costs of everything we buy.&nbsp; On top of that, the added carbon pollution in particular contributes to the trillions of dollars in damages from climate change.</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s hard to believe that, even accepting the risks and the consequences of dirty power, a coal plant that operates at less than ten percent capacity could stay open very long. Even if Cheswick cleared the capacity market this year, they would still lose almost $20 million in revenue because of the lower capacity prices next year.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We just tried four years of polluter-friendly policies during the Trump administration and the results are clear.&nbsp; Coal generation in Pennsylvania fell by a greater percentage over the past four years than it did during President Obama&rsquo;s entire 8-year term.&nbsp; Pennsylvania now has only three conventional steam coal plants left that have yet to announce plans to retire or stop burning coal, and those are all close to retirement-age. Rather than lie to workers and communities telling them that opposing RGGI and other environmental programs will save coal jobs, we should be actively managing the transition in our energy sector that is clearly already happening.</p>

<p>Joining RGGI gives us a pathway to be proactive in addressing this issue. Both the DEP and legislators such as Senators Comitta and Representative Herrin have proposed plans to invest a large part of the proceeds from participating in RGGI in areas most impacted by fossil fuels. This includes investments in Environmental Justice communities that have long faced the consequences of disproportionately high levels of pollution&mdash;much of which comes from fossil fuel power plants.&nbsp;This also includes the workers and communities that are impacted by the failure of these plants.</p>

<p>There is still room for policymakers to step up and have a good faith debate over how to best manage the changes in our energy economy and how best to address the climate crisis. Unfortunately, too many policymakers are quick to oppose proposals like RGGI without offering real alternatives that will lead to a sustainable future.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
"The Plastics Problem:  Identifying False Solutions, Part 1",5/26/2021,"<p>The scope of our plastic pollution problem is well known. Plastic escapes into the environment <a href=""https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0160412020320225"">at all stages of its life cycle</a>. Once in the environment, most plastic finds its way into waterways and <a href=""https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/microplastics.html"">breaks down into microplastics</a>. Those microplastics can be consumed by fish, birds, and other wildlife, and they are finding their way into <a href=""https://orbmedia.org/stories/Invisibles_final_report"">drinking water</a>, <a href=""https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/13/world/atmospheric-plastics-study-intl-hnk-scli-scn/index.html#:~:text=The%20research%20team%20collected%20atmospheric,across%20the%20US%20each%20year.&amp;text=Once%20they%20enter%20the%20atmosphere,days%2C%20according%20to%20the%20study."">air</a>, and even people&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/from-fish-to-humans-a-microplastic-invasion-may-be-taking-a-toll/"">bodies</a> and <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/dec/22/microplastics-revealed-in-placentas-unborn-babies"">placentas</a>.</p>

<p>A recent <a href=""https://pennenvironment.org/reports/pac/microplastics-pennsylvania"">report by PennEnvironment</a> found that 100% of the Pennsylvania waterways&nbsp;sampled contained microplastics. Additionally, plastics contain a host of <a href=""https://www.consumerreports.org/toxic-chemicals-substances/most-plastic-products-contain-potentially-toxic-chemicals/"">potentially toxic chemicals</a> like BPA, flame retardants, and phthalates. These toxins can also be found in <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2019/may/23/phthalates-everyday-products-toxics-guide"">the environment, in wildlife, and in our own bodies.</a></p>

<p>What is not fully known are the long term impacts that plastic pollution will have on human and environmental health. A 2019 report from <a href=""https://www.ciel.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Plastic-and-Health-The-Hidden-Costs-of-a-Plastic-Planet-February-2019.pdf"">Center for International Environmental Law</a> reviewed the health impacts of plastic from cradle to grave. They reported that human exposure to plastic has been linked to a wide variety of human health issues including inflammation of several different organ systems, developmental toxicity, and cancer.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The crisis is here and can no longer be ignored. The plastic industry knows this and is forming partnerships across the world to come up with solutions to address plastic pollution. The industry has proposed improved recyclability and recycling infrastructure and new end uses for plastics like chemical recycling and plastics to energy plants (See PennFuture&rsquo;s blog <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Recycling-is-exacerbating-the-plastic-waste-crisis"">Recycling is Exacerbating the Plastic Waste Crisis</a>). However, proposals to reduce plastic production and use are rare. In fact, the industry is <a href=""https://www.slideshare.net/MarcellusDN/acc-shale-gas-and-new-us-chemical-industry-investment-164-billion-and-counting"">actively increasing their infrastructure</a> and the World Economic Forum has estimated that <a href=""http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_The_New_Plastics_Economy.pdf"">production of plastics will quadruple</a> by 2050 in a business as usual scenario.</p>

<p>While improving recycling infrastructure worldwide may play a role in keeping plastic out of the environment, there is good reason to be skeptical of recycling as THE solution to the plastic crisis. Despite the fact that plastic recycling has been <a href=""https://www.plasticsmakeitpossible.com/about-plastics/history-of-plastics/the-history-of-recycling-plastic/#:~:text=1972,began%20operations%20in%20Conshohocken%2C%20Pa."">widely available for decades</a>, only <a href=""https://www.unep.org/interactive/beat-plastic-pollution/"">9% of plastic ever produced has been recycled</a>. In 2018, China closed its borders to contaminated plastic waste, exposing the ugly truth - that the system was and always has been broken. The farce of plastic recycling was further <a href=""https://www.npr.org/2020/09/11/897692090/how-big-oil-misled-the-public-into-believing-plastic-would-be-recycled"">exposed by NPR and PBS Frontline</a> in 2020. The investigation found that the plastic industry had spent millions of dollars supporting recycling programs, despite the fact that they knew the system was doomed to fail, in order to <a href=""https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/822597631/plastic-wars-three-takeaways-from-the-fight-over-the-future-of-plastics"">sell more plastic</a>.</p>

<p>New end uses for plastic like chemical or advanced &ldquo;recycling&rdquo; and plastic to energy plants are being proposed by the plastic industry as solutions to the plastic problem. They go so far as to say this is <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/science/climate/advanced-recycling-pennsylvania-plastics-fossil-fuel-climate-change-20201203.html"">part of a circular economy</a>. However, the products of chemical recycling are most often burned, contributing more greenhouse gases and pollutants to our already overburdened atmosphere.</p>

<p>Communities are bearing the brunt of plastic pollution and <a href=""https://www.keeppabeautiful.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/KPB-Litter-Cost-Study-013120.pdf"">the costs of cleaning it up</a>. The plastic industry should not be relied upon to solve this problem in a way that benefits them. Instead policies that reduce plastic production and use are needed. These policies should:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Eliminate subsidies to fossil fuel companies that contribute to low plastic prices and overabundance of fracked gas;</li>
	<li>Hold companies accountable for the life of their plastic products and their negative impacts to the environment;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Promote <a href=""https://www.sierraclub.org/sites/www.sierraclub.org/files/Sierra%20Club%20Zero%20Waste%20Policy%20December%202019.pdf"">zero waste solutions</a> and <a href=""https://reports.weforum.org/toward-the-circular-economy-accelerating-the-scale-up-across-global-supply-chains/from-linear-to-circular-accelerating-a-proven-concept/"">true circular economies</a> that design waste out of the equation and do not rely on burning as an end use;</li>
	<li>Empower municipalities to address the plastic pollution plaguing them by <a href=""https://www.penncapital-star.com/energy-environment/plastic-bag-preemption-suit-takes-aim-at-long-time-harrisburg-dealmaking-mechanism/"">eliminating pre-emption laws</a>.</li>
</ul>

<p>The <a href=""https://www.pahouse.com/zerowaste"">Zero Waste PA legislative package</a> and federal <a href=""https://www.breakfreefromplastic.org/pollution-act/"">Break Free From Plastic Pollution Act</a> are examples of state and federal policies to address the plastic crisis. California&rsquo;s plastic bag ban is an example of a policy that has been effective in <a href=""https://www.surfrider.org/coastal-blog/entry/why-bag-laws-work-study-shows-californias-statewide-bill-a-success"">dramatically reducing the use of plastic bags</a> and the <a href=""https://www.cawrecycles.org/recycling-news/xtj9dcga9bmh5daxn4sw4kry4zpndg"">bags found in the environment</a>. The solution to the plastic crisis is not simple, but it is clear - reducing plastic production and use is the only way to definitively keep plastic out of the environment and our bodies.</p>

<p>This is Part 1 of The Plastics Problem: Identifying False Solutions series. Stay tuned for Part 2 to learn about Philadelphia&rsquo;s 2019 plastic bag ban and problems with preemption laws.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Sarah Bennett, Campaign Manager for Clean Water Advocacy"
What Comes Next in Pennsylvania's Efforts to Join RGGI?,5/20/2021,"<p>In October of 2019, Governor Wolf issued an executive order to begin the process of joining the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI).&nbsp;Through this program, Pennsylvania will cooperate with other states in the northeast to cap the emissions of carbon pollution from fossil fuel electric generation because, <a href=""https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/governor-wolf-takes-executive-action-to-combat-climate-change-carbon-emissions/#:~:text=%E2%80%9CClimate%20change%20is%20the%20most,emissions%2C%E2%80%9D%20said%20Governor%20Wolf.&amp;text=In%20order%20to%20show%20compliance,ton%20of%20CO2%2C%20they%20emit."">as the Governor said at the time</a>,&nbsp;&ldquo;climate change is the most critical environmental threat confronting the world, and power generation is one of the biggest contributors to greenhouse gas emissions.&rdquo;</p>

<p>While the Governor started the process with an executive order, actually joining RGGI requires passing a new regulation: the CO2 Budget Trading Program.</p>

<p>Even with the Governor&rsquo;s executive order, regulations don&rsquo;t just happen.&nbsp;Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Regulatory Review Act and Commonwealth Documents Law create a detailed program of review, checks, and balances, which often takes 18 to 24 months to complete.&nbsp;With the RGGI rule, the Pennsylvania&nbsp;Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) is 19 months into the process.</p>

<p>The last major milestone was at the end of 2020 when the public was invited to comment on the proposed version of the rule. The DEP took 32 hours of testimony from 449 people and accepted 14,038 written comments. The vast majority of comments supported moving forward, and, as expected, there were also a number of recommendations for updates and clarifications.</p>

<p>The DEP considered all of that input from residents and updated its&nbsp;proposal accordingly.&nbsp;This language&mdash;known as the &ldquo;draft final-form rulemaking&rdquo;&mdash;was just presented to the Air Quality Technical Advisory Committee, the Small Business Compliance Advisory Committee, and the Citizens Advisory Council.&nbsp;All three of these organizations voted to endorse the rule and move forward.</p>

<p>While it&rsquo;s encouraging these organizations endorsed the DEP&rsquo;s plan, these votes were advisory in nature. The vote that really counts&nbsp;is expected to happen this summer when the DEP presents the complete rulemaking package, including responses to all the public comments, to the Environmental Quality Board (EQB) for&nbsp;formal approval.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>EQB approval is a big step, but even that doesn&rsquo;t end the review process.&nbsp;After that vote the entire package must be delivered to the Independent Regulatory Review Commission (IRRC) and the Environmental Resources and Energy committees in both the state Senate and the House of Representatives.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>IRRC is a panel of five members appointed by the Governor and legislative branch who review regulations and advise whether or not&nbsp;the Regulatory Review Act criteria have been met, and if it is in the best interest of Pennsylvania to proceed. The panel&nbsp;will consider the RGGI rulemaking at their next public meeting that is at least 30 days after they receive the package.&nbsp;</p>

<p>If IRRC votes to approve the rule, the process moves to the next step.&nbsp;If IRRC votes to disapprove the rule, the DEP has 40 days to resubmit or withdraw the package.&nbsp;The DEP isn&rsquo;t actually required to change anything in response to IRRC&rsquo;s concerns, but the agency&nbsp;needs to explain its&nbsp;decision not to make changes and IRRC will get another chance to consider the rule.&nbsp; A vote to disapprove will slow the process, but IRRC doesn&rsquo;t have the authority to stop a rulemaking from proceeding. The result of a second vote, no matter what the outcome, is simply reported to the committees.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In most cases, the standing committees take no action on rules one way or another, but we&rsquo;ve already seen multiple attempts to block RGGI by the legislature, and it&rsquo;s hard to imagine either of the current committee chairs, Rep. Darryl Metcalfe and Sen.&nbsp;Gene Yaw, missing an opportunity to stall its implementation.&nbsp;It&rsquo;s practically certain that the committees will report a concurrent resolution disapproving of the rule.&nbsp;That will create a delay of 30 calendar days or ten legislative days (whichever is longer) while the General Assembly considers the resolution.</p>

<p>Given the composition of the Legislature, it&rsquo;s very likely that this resolution will pass.&nbsp;But, the Pennsylvania&nbsp;Supreme Court has made it clear that there is no such thing as a &ldquo;legislative veto&rdquo; in Pennsylvania&mdash;the only way the Legislature can actually block the program is if the Governor agrees to the resolution or the General Assembly has the two-thirds majority needed to override his veto.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The General Assembly has already attempted to kill the program more than once and, so far, hasn&#39;t&nbsp;found the necessary votes.&nbsp;Having failed to obtain a veto-proof majority, and unwilling to accept the Constitutional limits on their power, members of the Senate <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-responds-to-state-Senates-refusal-to-vote-on-PUC-nomination"">even took the unprecedented step</a> of threatening to reject all of Governor Wolf&rsquo;s Publicly Utility Commission nominations unless he agrees to their demands and withdraws the rule.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While it&rsquo;s seemingly destined to fail, moving a resolution of disapproval will delay implementation at least 30 days.&nbsp;Then, once that resolution is vetoed, the General Assembly will have at least 30 days more to try and override the veto.&nbsp;Ultimately, the anti-RGGI forces are unlikely to prevail and sooner or later, the rule will be sent to the Attorney General for a final review as to legality and form before being published in the Pennsylvania Bulletin and going into effect.</p>

<p>Pennsylvanians want action on climate change and we need a plan to provide a sustainable path forward for the workers and communities impacted by the failures of the fossil fuel industry. For all the rhetoric from the opposition, they have failed to suggest an alternative besides sitting on their hands and doing nothing.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In fact, doing nothing for as long as possible seems to be the goal.&nbsp;While the opposition has little chance of stopping the program, if they can string enough delaying tactics together it may be possible to push back the start date of the program by a couple of months.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Delays like this could give polluters more time to dump carbon pollution in our air for free.&nbsp;That is bad for Pennsylvania, but profitable for the polluting industries.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
Regulatory Reforms Would Roll Back Environmental and Health Protections,5/19/2021,"<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s legislators appear eager to overhaul how the Commonwealth reviews and implements state law. Don&rsquo;t be distracted. The winners of their latest proposals would likely be polluters &mdash; at the expense of public health and the environment.</p>

<p>Too often, regulations get a bad rap. Seen as burdensome&nbsp;to some, in truth, regulations are merely administrative tools to achieve the General Assembly&rsquo;s policy goals. Regulations allow us to adapt laws to changing times and to ensure new laws are implemented in ways that are safe, fair and legal.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Permits seem to be in their crosshairs as well. Onerous &ldquo;red tape&rdquo; to some, in fact, permits are designed to ensure state laws are respected and enforced equitably and effectively.&nbsp; Undermining the process to develop new regulations and implement permits puts Pennsylvania&rsquo;s air and water, workers, consumers, health and economy at risk. That&rsquo;s why the latest proposals are so worrisome.</p>

<p>HB 139 (Rothman &ndash; R, Cumberland County) mandates that state agencies contract with third-party &ldquo;professionals&rdquo; to review certain permit applications. In practice, the bill would force the already time and cash-strapped Department of Environmental Protection to create a third-party review program.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Instead of expediting the review process, this would simply undermine it. Outsourcing reviews of federally delegated permits would likely be illegal. And, given the lack of any conflict-of-interest provisions, the legislation would enable polluters to review their own requests to go on polluting.</p>

<p>HB 288 (O&rsquo;Neal &ndash; R, Washington County) would require agencies designate a &ldquo;regulatory compliance officer&rdquo; empowered to establish guidelines for waiving fines or penalties. A polluter would simply need to self report their own violation prior to being penalized.&nbsp;Waiving fines and penalties may be appropriate in some circumstances. But those decisions should be made using a thorough and transparent process by agency officials who are publicly accountable. Otherwise, this proposal risks creating a simple get-out-of-jail-free card for anyone who pollutes.</p>

<p>HB 939 (Klunk &ndash; R, York County) is another regulatory rollback that, last year, PennFuture and other environmental groups across the state helped to defeat. In this year&rsquo;s version, the bill would add another layer of bureaucracy to the General Assembly by creating a new review board, potentially creating tension with the current committee system. Originally, this bill would have also established a nonsense rule that, for every new regulation promulgated by an agency, two existing regulations would need to be repealed. Due to widespread public pushback, the prime sponsor of the bill amended out this dangerous provision to make it more palatable for the House to pass.</p>

<p>Other proposals we&rsquo;re fighting back against include two proposals that we consider unconstitutional attempts to take power from the executive branch. HB 72 (Keefer &ndash; R, York and Cumberland Counties) would require House or Senate approval of final-form regulations, essentially giving each chamber a veto over new regulations if they cost more than $1 million to implement the protection. HB 950 (Metcalfe &ndash; R, Butler County) would weaken permitting and rulemaking abilities by prohibiting state agencies from reissuing regulations.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Too often, leaders in the General Assembly decry the overreach and burden of regulations and permits. But at the same time, budget cuts and wrongheaded legislative proposals limit the abilities for our state agencies to do their job.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Rather than helping to create more efficient and effective government, these latest proposals create extraneous and added layers of bureaucracy, impede the roles of our executive branch agencies, and undermine the protections enforced and implemented by our state government.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture will continue to post updates as these counter-productive proposals make their way through the General Assembly.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
Electric Mobility Legislation Could Supercharge EV Infrastructure,5/5/2021,"<p>Sales of electric vehicles (EVs) may have slowed during the coronavirus pandemic. But market forces clearly signal that the future of transportation will be electric.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In preparation, legislation is making its way through the General Assembly that could supercharge electric mobility across the Commonwealth. The <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billinfo/billinfo.cfm?syear=2021&amp;sind=0&amp;body=S&amp;type=B&amp;bn=435"">Clean Transportation Infrastructure Act</a> will require that the state&rsquo;s electric utilities develop comprehensive strategies to expand accessibility and to improve affordability of vehicle charging infrastructure.</p>

<p>Transportation accounts for a large and growing share of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. The state&rsquo;s 2020 GHG Inventory shows oil- and gas- powered vehicles are responsible for 25 percent of statewide emissions. That&rsquo;s up by about 4 percent from two years prior.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Fortunately, change is coming. Across Pennsylvania, public transit agencies and school districts are investing in battery-electric vehicles. Utilities, delivery companies and other private fleet owners are going electric. More individual owners are plugging in EVs at home or at work.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Technology improvements are driving down vehicle costs, while allowing batteries to retain charges over longer distances. These improvements &mdash; combined with a renewed attention from the federal government on decarbonizing transport &mdash; <a href=""https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electric-mobility-after-the-crisis-why-an-auto-slowdown-wont-hurt-ev-demand"">are fueling growth forecasts</a>. U.S. electric vehicles are expected to reach 3-6 percent of new sales by 2022 and up to 36 percent by 2030.</p>

<p>SB 435, introduced by Sen. Bob Mensch, will require the Public Utilities Commission to set a statewide transportation electrification goal, encouraging a 50-percent increase in battery-electric, hydrogen or fuel cell electric vehicles over current Pennsylvania 2030 forecasts.</p>

<p>Less than 30,000 EVs were registered in Pennsylvania as of November 2020, according to the Department of Environmental Protection&rsquo;s Pennsylvania <a href=""https://files.dep.state.pa.us/Energy/OfficeofPollutionPrevention/StateEnergyProgram/PAElectricVehRoadmapBookletDEP5334.pdf"">Electric Vehicle Roadmap</a>. EV ownership here is about 25 percent of neighboring New Jersey&rsquo;s.</p>

<p>Massive electrification of the transportation sector will require large-scale investment in new electric distribution and widespread installation of new charging infrastructure. To better prepare for this transformation, SB 435 would require the state&rsquo;s largest utilities develop electrification plans for the 18 largest counties across the Commonwealth.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Importantly, SB 435 would also allow utilities to recover costs for building new charging infrastructure or for incentivizing property owners and private developers to install chargers at their homes, offices, bus depots, shopping centers, parking garages and wherever else it&rsquo;s needed. The legislation sets a maximum surcharge of 0.25 percent on annual customer bills.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Benefits of SB 435 would include:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Developing a strategy to overcome the main barrier to EV accessibility &mdash; the availability of charging infrastructure.</li>
	<li>Assisting regions across the state meet Clean Air Act air quality targets.</li>
	<li>Reducing greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to the climate crisis.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Supporting economic development by displacing imported oil with electricity generated from Pennsylvania-based energy resources including renewable energy.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Promoting economic growth and job creation by encouraging private investment in cars, buses and equipment that Pennsylvania businesses are helping to develop.</li>
	<li>Requiring extensive transportation sector coordination and regulatory review of any proposed utility EV infrastructure investments.</li>
	<li>Positioning Pennsylvania for leadership as changes underway across the transportation industry continue to unfold.</li>
</ul>

<p>PennFuture strongly supports SB 435. We are part of a broad and diverse coalition of organizations that believe this legislation provides a thoughtful and well-balanced framework to significantly advance EVs in Pennsylvania.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
Legislators Continue to Stand in the Way of Climate Action,5/4/2021,"<p>Leaders in the General Assembly are offering more unproductive proposals that would undermine Pennsylvania&rsquo;s entry into the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI). Despite past failed attempts, again and again, they expect different results. As the saying goes, their approach to climate policy is truly insane.</p>

<p>This latest attempt comes as an abundance of Pennsylvanians support climate action. The only logical explanation for ignoring the will of the voters is that our state&rsquo;s legislators prefer to do the bidding of the state&rsquo;s fossil fuel industry.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The shameful undermining of climate progress comes in the form of Senate Bill 119 (Pittman - R, Indiana County). The proposal would strip away the Department of Environmental Protection&rsquo;s statutory authority to adopt regulations to reduce carbon pollution from any source, including power plants. This is despite clear precedent that the governor possesses legal authority to implement a cap-and-invest carbon reduction program.</p>

<p>Make no mistake; the intention of the bill&rsquo;s sponsors is clear. If Pennsylvania were to join RGGI, power plants would no longer be allowed to release carbon pollution for free. The power sector would have to start paying a price for air pollution that they cause.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Governor Tom Wolf&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/executive-order-2019-07-commonwealth-leadership-in-addressing-climate-change-through-electric-sector-emissions-reductions/"">Executive Order 2019-07 instructed the DEP to develop</a> a cap-and-invest program that aligns with RGGI. Joining RGGI would encourage innovation and create a revenue stream that Pennsylvania could re-invest in programs that further reduce air pollution. Other states are already reaping the benefits. Ten current RGGI member states <a href=""https://www.analysisgroup.com/globalassets/uploadedfiles/content/insights/publishing/analysis_group_rggi_report_april_2018.pdf"">have experienced $1.4 billion in net economic benefits</a> between 2015 and 2017.</p>

<p>Yet another effort to prevent action on climate change &mdash; a similar bill <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-responds-to-veto-of-House-Bill-2025"">was vetoed last September by Governor Wolf</a> &mdash; SB 119 would preserve the profit margins of fossil fuel executives.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />
SB 119 not only reflects a lack of desire among the Legislature to lead on climate progress. It reflects a failure to listen to voters across the state.</p>

<p>After RGGI was explained in a recent poll, <a href=""https://www.centredaily.com/opinion/opn-columns-blogs/article246260895.html"">more than 70 percent of surveyed Pennsylvanians</a> expressed their support. The public clearly understands that RGGI membership would have beneficial effects on addressing climate change, improving public health and boosting the state&rsquo;s economy.</p>

<p>DEP has been working for months drafting RGGI regulations, listening to thousands of comments from industry, advocacy groups and ordinary Pennsylvanians. Instead of working with the administration to improve the rulemaking process, SB 119 is a waste of state resources and another disappointing attempt to block DEP from combating the climate crisis.</p>

<p>SB 119 could come up for a vote in the state Senate as soon as next week when the Senate returns to session.&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/antirggibills"">Do your part today and contact your elected officials. Tell them you support immediate action to combat the climate crisis, and demand they vote against these anti-RGGI bills.&nbsp;</a></p>
