Pennsylvania vs. the Future,4/30/2021,"<p>In other parts of our nation, it is the spring of 2021.&nbsp;We have a president who understands that climate change is a crisis, who is making the first movements in a long time towards incorporating environmental justice issues into decision-making, and who is bringing a &ldquo;whole of government approach&rdquo; to environmental problems.</p>

<p>In addition to President Biden&rsquo;s early executive orders on climate change and other environmental issues, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-A-Breath-of-Fresh-Air-Two-Steps-and-Hopefully-More-Forward-on-Environmental-Justice-and-Water-Protection"">which we previously covered in this blog</a>, the administration has advanced concrete policy proposals that include climate goals at their core.</p>

<p>The American Jobs Plan provides funding for infrastructure, clean energy, innovation, manufacturing and workplace support, and the caregiving economy. By incorporating support for the renewable electric grid into a key economic plan, the President is <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-The-Time-to-Hesitate-is-Through"">trying to launch a more sustainable American economy</a> while simultaneously combating climate change.&nbsp;Additionally, last week, the President <a href=""https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/04/22/fact-sheet-president-biden-sets-2030-greenhouse-gas-pollution-reduction-target-aimed-at-creating-good-paying-union-jobs-and-securing-u-s-leadership-on-clean-energy-technologies/"">announced a commitment to 50-52 percent reduction</a> from 2005 levels in economy-wide net greenhouse gas pollution in 2030.&nbsp;This is not just a goal - it is the United States&rsquo; &ldquo;nationally determined contribution&rdquo; or &ldquo;NDC,&rdquo; which is a formal submission to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>While the United States&rsquo; goal is certainly not easy or automatic, the administration recognizes that an ambitious goal is necessary and is explicitly connecting policies and plans for job creation and economic development to responding to the climate crisis.</p>

<p>But in the Pennsylvania legislature, things are different.&nbsp;Our legislature seems determined to resist any attempts to move forward and remains firmly stuck in the past.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the past few weeks, both the State House and the State Senate have released a flurry of proposed legislation designed to push Pennsylvania back into the past. Some of these are explicitly designed to prevent action on climate change, and others are less explicit but still clearly motivated by a desire to frustrate problem-solving.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>An example of an explicitly anti-environment bill is Senate Bill 119 (Pittman - R, Indiana County), which would take away DEP&rsquo;s statutory authority to adopt regulations to reduce carbon pollution from any source, including power plants consistent with the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI).&nbsp;This bill was vetoed last September by Governor Wolf.&nbsp; DEP has been working round the clock for months on its proposed RGGI regulations, including listening to thousands of comments from industry, advocacy groups, and ordinary Pennsylvanians.&nbsp;</p>

<p>There is no purpose to this bill other than to waste state resources and attempt to frustrate a meaningful attempt to combat the climate change that threatens our future.</p>

<p>Then there is House Bill 939, which, among other things, would create a process for &quot;sunsetting&quot; existing regulations by capping the number of regulations and requiring the repeal of two existing regulations for every new regulation promulgated.&nbsp;If this sounds familiar, it is because the former presidential administration attempted to do this on a federal level.&nbsp;Looking for models in the abject failures of the last administration is not the way to move into the future.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Fortunately, the legislature is not the entirety of the government in the Commonwealth.&nbsp;Governor Wolf issued an executive order committing the state to purchase at least 40% of its electricity from new solar arrays built here.&nbsp;Municipalities like the City of Philadelphia are taking climate change seriously and committing to ambitious carbon reduction goals to try to get there.&nbsp;It&rsquo;s just the legislature that is stuck.</p>

<p>We deserve better from our elected state representatives.&nbsp;They need to stop standing in the way of our future.&nbsp;</p>

<p>For more information and to learn more about what you can do to tell your legislators to vote no on these antiquated pieces of legislation, visit <a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org"">www.pennfuture.org</a>.</p>

PennFuture Releases New Report to Save Chesapeake Bay,4/8/2021,"<p>We are at an inflection point for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s efforts to save the Chesapeake Bay.</p>

<p>What policymakers in the Keystone State do&mdash;or more importantly, what they do not do&mdash;over the next five years will determine not only the fate of many of the Commonwealth&rsquo;s rivers and streams in the Susquehanna and Potomac River Basins, but also the fate of America&rsquo;s largest estuary and third largest in the world.</p>

<p>There are more than 15,000 miles of polluted streams within Pennsylvania&rsquo;s portion of the Susquehanna and Potomac River basins. The Susquehanna River itself is the source of drinking water for 6.2 million people. This pollution impacts how we use our water&mdash;whether it&rsquo;s fewer opportunities for fishing, unsafe waters for recreation, or high costs for using it for drinking and business.</p>

<p>The river&rsquo;s pollution stretches well beyond our state borders. Half of all the freshwater that comprises the Chesapeake Bay comes from Pennsylvania, which means Pennsylvania plays an important role in ongoing efforts to clean up the polluted bay.</p>

<p>While Pennsylvania isn&rsquo;t the only culprit&mdash;five other states and Washington, D.C. also contribute to the problem&mdash;our contributions are among the highest, especially for nitrogen. The dirty water in the basin is so dire that Pennsylvania has been placed under a so-called &ldquo;pollution diet&rdquo; by the Environmental Protection Agency meant to limit the amount of pollution we send down into the Susquehanna and Chesapeake Bay.</p>

<p>With that sense of urgency in mind, PennFuture today released a policy agenda designed to give Pennsylvania lawmakers a roadmap to fund clean water programs and to get us back on track toward meeting our obligations to clean up the bay.</p>

<p>The report, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Final-Chesapeake-report.pdf"">&ldquo;Underfunded and Polluted: Solutions to Fund Clean Water in Pennsylvania and the Chesapeake Bay Watershed,&rdquo;</a> puts forth a legislative agenda that, if acted upon, would provide the technical assistance, agency support, and public investments needed to put Pennsylvania on the path toward meeting our &ldquo;pollution diet&rdquo; goals by the 2025 deadline.</p>

<p>Specifically, we recommend policy solutions and funding amounts that would result in the reduction of pollution from its major source&mdash;agriculture lands&mdash;as well as stormwater runoff and forestry-related practices. We also recommend that our state agencies are funded properly and operating with sufficient capacity to carry out the programs and assistance needed to accomplish state pollution goals.</p>

<p>The report also identifies funding mechanisms that are available to state legislators to help&nbsp; achieve these policy goals, including a severance tax on natural gas extraction, eliminating the sales tax exemption for bottled water, levying a fee on single-use plastic bags, and establishing a water use fee for large commercial operations in Pennsylvania, among others.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The pathways spelled out in our report complement efforts already underway in the state Capitol, as two bills with bipartisan support could soon come up for a vote in Harrisburg.&nbsp;<br />
The first is SB 251 which seeks to implement new standards and regulations on lawn fertilizer application across Pennsylvania, while SB 465 would create a statewide Agricultural Conservation Assistance Program to help more farmers and landowners implement practices to combat nonpoint source agricultural runoff to our streams, creeks, and rivers. We will be watching these bills closely and doing our part to support them.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Properly funding clean water initiatives isn&rsquo;t just the right thing to do, it&rsquo;s the smart thing to do. Clean water is a critical component of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s thriving recreation economy, which is the 6th largest in the country and produced $13 billion in revenue, according to 2019 figures. It&rsquo;s also a critical investment in our farmers, one of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s top economic sectors accounting for approximately $83.8 billion in direct economic output and over 280,500 jobs.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Now is a critical time for state policy leaders to show its residents that they&rsquo;re upholding their right to clean water and good health as well as strongly support its recreation businesses and farmers.</p>

<p>Now is the time to invest in our waterways.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To read our report, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Final-Chesapeake-report.pdf"">please click here.</a></p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Renee Reber, Campaign Manager, Watershed Advocacy"
The Time to Hesitate is Through,4/1/2021,"<p>President Joe Biden&rsquo;s American Jobs Plan&nbsp;announcement in Pittsburgh elicits great pride in being a Pennsylvanian. It feels like it&rsquo;s been ages since the leader of the United States has put forth a vision of the future that moves us forward&mdash;no matter whether we work in the frack fields or an office building, reside in a rural county or city, or we&rsquo;re beset by pollution or economic hardship. It&rsquo;s a historic initiative, that if enacted fully by Congress, would be a watershed moment for the country and Commonwealth.</p>

<p>Biden&rsquo;s economic plan goes way beyond kick-starting an economy hit hard by the COVID-19 pandemic.&nbsp;At its core, the President&rsquo;s American Jobs Plan would overhaul our antiquated infrastructure, build resiliency to extreme weather and support new carbon reduction technologies that match and excel beyond the efforts of global competitors currently making their mark in this sector.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The plan will launch a more sustainable American economy anchored by cutting-edge business sectors and family-sustaining jobs that don&rsquo;t rely on polluting our communities and children to succeed. The President&rsquo;s plan would finally and proportionally invest in addressing the climate crisis&nbsp;by deploying renewable energy, retrofitting homes and businesses, investing in clean energy innovation, and advancing ways for industry to lower its carbon footprint.&nbsp;The plan will rightly will give our country a fighting start to meet the daily reality of climate change.&nbsp;And it will seed the projects, tools and technologies we need to address the climate crisis, one made more evident every day, and neglected for far too long.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But of all the places he could have made his announcement, why did the President choose Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania?&nbsp; One reason is the abundance of concrete proposals and feasible ideas emanating from the region that are in sync with the President&rsquo;s economic vision, including&nbsp;<a href=""https://reimagineappalachia.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/ReImagineAppalachia_Blueprint_092020.pdf"">Reimagine Appalachia&rsquo;s blueprint</a>, <a href=""https://www.sustainablebusiness.pitt.edu/sites/default/files/marshall_plan_for_middle_america_roadmap_0.pdf"">the Marshall Plan for Middle America</a>, and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Green-Stimulus-FINAL.pdf"">PennFuture&rsquo;s Green Stimulus and Economic Recovery Platform for Pennsylvania</a>. These independently-crafted platforms all share the common goal of lifting up the Commonwealth through shared prosperity and future-oriented, sustainable economic opportunities.</p>

<p>Why do such synergies exist between the region and the President&rsquo;s economic plan? Maybe only an individual like President Biden, whose formative years were spent in the coal fields of upper Appalachia&rsquo;s Anthracite region, can get why perpetuating fossil fuels as the foundation for future economic growth and opportunity is wrong on so many fronts. As someone who, like the President, has kept their ties to the region, its scarred landscapes, and its strong and proud people, I understand firsthand the President&rsquo;s perspective.</p>

<p>Appalachia&rsquo;s coal fields, where the President was born, are a poster-child for what the American Jobs Plan aims to address: boom-and-bust cycles of fossil fuels industries crippling towns, oppression wrought by big companies when workers are unprotected by unions, and the psychological and demoralizing impacts keeping coal communities from pulling themselves up by their bootstraps. Biden experienced and was witness to these declines, and knows they are frightening for communities in the midst of such change, and equally frightening for policymakers to understand and address.</p>

<p>Unless, that is, you are the kind of leader that Biden is, whose experience and empathy has won him much political support from the region and from local influencers who share his vision.&nbsp;President Biden&rsquo;s vision of prosperity is anchored in the future, and not a distant future, but rather one that is within our reach, if we can all stretch just a bit further and take hold.&nbsp;If we can drop our swords, together we can take a run at doing something monumental and meaningful for our people, to set the country up for success in the new economy, and to make things right for the have-nots among us.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The fight for the President&rsquo;s American Jobs Plan will be a political battle, to be sure.&nbsp;The thing that will make the fight so tough is partisan identity. Ideologies, political or otherwise, divide and blind us to what is right before our eyes: opportunity and seeing that the world around us has changed. Internationally, we see the most powerful and influential regions shift to a sustainable future, while America drags its feet because there are those among us who don&rsquo;t want to see others &ldquo;win&rdquo; or because some among us believe we can stop societal or demographic change using a wall, an insurrection, a vote, or the suppression of one.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Back here in Pennsylvania, and at PennFuture, we are all for making up for lost time and lost opportunity.&nbsp;We stand eager and ready to move beyond the societal infighting and work to advance solutions that benefit all of us. We are leaning hard into the prospects for federal action on resilient infrastructure and climate solutions.&nbsp;We believe if passed, the President&rsquo;s American Jobs Plan can yield great things for our state. If nothing else, is any part of Pennsylvania really so prosperous that it and its elected representatives in Congress &ndash; regardless of party &ndash; have the luxury of dismissing these investments in our common future?</p>

<p>Biden&rsquo;s proposals are showing bipartisan support among voters. The time has come for courageous leadership from all corners of the state to come to the table and give the President&rsquo;s proposals a fair hearing and chance.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

Net Metering Works for Pennsylvania,3/31/2021,"<p>In the early days of distributed generation, utilities would sell power to consumers at the retail rate but, if customers were able to sell excess power they generated back to the utility at all, the utilities would only pay the much-lower wholesale rate.&nbsp;This systematically undervalued the benefits of distributed energy resources (DERs) like solar power and provided very little incentive to invest in such systems.&nbsp;Today, most states require some form of &ldquo;net metering&rdquo; to ensure customers are more fairly paid for their generation.&nbsp;Even where it is not required, state regulators must at least consider rules to make&nbsp;net metering available<sup>1</sup>.</p>

<p>A number of different generation technologies can qualify for net metering, but grid-tie solar systems on homes and businesses are probably the most common. They use a device known as an inverter to turn the low-voltage DC the solar panels produce to the higher-voltage AC we use to power lights and appliances.&nbsp;Such systems are designed to draw power from the local electricity distribution grid whenever they need it and send power back when they have excess.&nbsp;This type of system is often much simpler to install and much less expensive than off-the-grid alternatives that require batteries or other backup generation.</p>

<p>Unfortunately, a recent study found that overall, &ldquo;grid-tied utility customers are being grossly undercompensated in most of the U.S. as the value of solar eclipses the net metering rate<sup>2</sup>.&rdquo;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>The value of net metered solar generation</strong></u></p>

<p>Most consumers recognize the value of buying from local businesses, even when big online stores might offer lower prices.&nbsp;Buying local supports the jobs that were created in the community to build and operate that business, and the money consumers spend locally is more likely to stay in that community.&nbsp;Operating a small solar system shares many of these same benefits.</p>

<p>A small solar system installed on a home or business should easily pay for itself&nbsp;in avoided energy costs over the life of the equipment.&nbsp;But, these systems have more value than just the direct energy savings that they provide to their owners&mdash;they provide benefits to all ratepayers throughout the community.</p>

<p>Because most of our electricity is purchased&nbsp; through wholesale market auctions, adding any new behind-the-meter generation<sup>3</sup> results in less demand and, therefore, lowers the market clearing price.&nbsp;This lowers wholesale prices for everyone&mdash;even on days when the solar panels aren&rsquo;t sending any power back to the grid<sup>4</sup>.&nbsp;Solar generation can magnify this effect when more power is produced on the same hot summer days that electricity demand, and wholesale prices, often peak.</p>

<p>Besides moderating wholesale energy prices, having more distributed generation can lead to lower spending on reserve generating capacity and infrastructure. Nationally, we spend over $100 billion a year to maintain and upgrade our grid&mdash;avoiding even a small fraction of those costs can result in significant savings.</p>

<p>In addition to savings on energy, capacity, and infrastructure, newer technologies like smart inverters can also provide a wide range of valuable grid services.&nbsp;These include things like load following, reactive power support, demand response, and other services that consumers never need to think about but are important to grid operators who need to keep the system functioning smoothly and efficiently.</p>

<p>The benefits of additional clean generation go far beyond direct savings for ratepayers and grid operators.&nbsp;Every megawatt of avoided fossil fuel generation means less pollution&mdash;including smog-forming chemicals, cancer-causing air toxics, and the carbon pollution driving climate change.&nbsp;Less pollution means less spending on medical care and increased productivity.</p>

<p>Fairness demands that we pay net-metered solar generators for the full value of the services they provide.</p>

<p><u><strong>Net Metering in Pennsylvania</strong></u></p>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards Act includes a requirement that &ldquo;excess generation from net-metered customer-generators shall receive full retail value for all energy produced on an annual basis<sup>5</sup>.&rdquo; That is a strong standard but, to date, neither our Public Utility Commission (PUC) nor our courts have fact-based determination on what &ldquo;full retail value&rdquo; actually is. Moreover, there is reason to believe that the PUC&rsquo;s current proxies for full retail value may understate actual full retail value.</p>

<p>PUC rules specify that customers get a bill credit for the &ldquo;full retail rate&rdquo; (emphasis added) for net generation month-to-month and, that where a customer has not been compensated for all of its igeneration at the end of the year, the customer should be paid for that net generation the &ldquo;price to compare&rdquo; (i.e. the amount that customers who do not shop on PA Power Switch pay for electricity&nbsp; generation and transmission)<sup>6</sup>.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>There are two problems with this framework. First, retail rates are a very coarse approximation of value.&nbsp;Value depends on factors that rates do not fully take into account.&nbsp;As one study put it, an accurate value of solar requires&nbsp; &ldquo;evaluating economic development costs, the avoided fuel hedge costs, the avoided voltage regulation costs, secondary health and environmental effects such as increased crop yields from PV-reduced pollution, and accurate estimations of the value of avoided GHG liability costs or avoided GHG emissions liability insurance.<sup>7</sup>&rdquo; These are not things typically reflected in retail rates and particularly not in the lower price-to-compare</p>

<p><u><strong>Defending Net Metering</strong></u></p>

<p>When SolarReviews looked at state net metering policies in early 2021, Pennsylvania earned fairly high ratings compared to other states but had some room for improvement<sup>8</sup>. Keeping the gains we&rsquo;ve made hasn&rsquo;t been without its challenges.&nbsp;Utility trade associations like the Edison Electric Institute, and anti-regulatory groups like ALEC have been leading the attacks.</p>

<p>They generally start by ignoring the non-energy values of solar generation and then push the false narrative that paying net metered generators anything more than wholesale prices always represents a cost shift that impacts other ratepayers.&nbsp;When distributed solar levels become high, as they have in California, cost-shifting can become an issue. But critics of net metering routinely make these claims even where distributed solar levels are low, as they are in Pennsylvania, and&nbsp;despite the lack of actual evidence.</p>

<p>Back in 2016, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s own PUC fell victim to these arguments and attempted to create more barriers to net metered generation.&nbsp;PennFuture and other solar advocates were successful in preventing new caps on the size of net-metered systems, arguing that the PUC simply didn&rsquo;t have the authority to substitute their judgment for that of our Legislature. Still, problems remained.</p>

<p>One of the most obvious problems was the Commission&rsquo;s view on virtual meter aggregation.&nbsp;AEPS specifically allows a net metered generation system to be attached to a separate electric meter, provided it&rsquo;s within two miles of the primary meter.&nbsp;This is particularly useful for farms where a nearby field is a more suitable location than the existing house or barn.&nbsp;PUC tried to add the arbitrary restriction that any such remote site needed a pre-existing independent electric load.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Commision said at the time this was necessary to prevent &ldquo;utilities&rdquo; from qualifying for net metering.&nbsp;This never made any sense. Since Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Electricity Generation Customer Choice and Competition Act passed in 1996, utilities have divested of all their generation assets<sup>9</sup> and, as we pointed out at the time, utilities are prevented from qualifying for net metering because the AEPS defines a net-metered customer generator as a &ldquo;non-utility&rdquo;<sup>10</sup>. Moreover, we argued PUC just doesn&rsquo;t have the authority under Pennsylvania law to create new restrictions that go beyond what the Legislature provided.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Even though the Independent Regulatory Review Commission agreed with our position and disapproved the new restrictions, the PUC went forward and promulgated the faulty rules. I wrote back at the time that &ldquo;people may be denied interconnection for their solar systems in situations where the legislation gives them the right to install that generation.&rdquo;&nbsp; Not surprisingly, that is exactly what happened.</p>

<p><u><strong>A Belated Victory</strong></u></p>

<p>On Feb 17, the PA Supreme Court upheld a May 2020 decision by the Commonwealth Court<sup>11</sup> regarding the PUC&rsquo;s attempt to regulate net metering and virtual net metering. That ruling made it clear we were correct on several important points when we made comments to the PUC and IRRC back in 2016.</p>

<p>The court held the PUC&rsquo;s authority related to net metering is exactly what the AEPS statute says&mdash;they may enact &ldquo;technical and net metering interconnection rules,&rdquo; not address broader questions of energy policy. The Legislature set specific limitations regarding the size of net metered systems along with other policy decisions and it&rsquo;s not the PUC&rsquo;s role to second-guess the laws.</p>

<p>The court also made it clear that, while the PUC has broad authority to regulate utilities, that doesn&rsquo;t grant them the power to limit net metered generation because &quot;the AEPS Act applies to &#39;customer-generators,&#39; which by definition are not public utilities.&rdquo;&nbsp; Also, the PUC&rsquo;s attempt to redefine the term utility to include companies that are not public utilities is unenforceable as it &quot;attempts to redefine statutory eligibility standards.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Finally, the independent load requirement for virtual net metering was specifically rejected as it has no basis in the statute and beyond the PUC authority. It took a number of years, but it&rsquo;s encouraging to know our reading of the legislation was correct.</p>

<p><u><strong>What this means going forward</strong></u></p>

<p>While this ruling fixes the glaring problems with the PUCs rules,&nbsp;there are still some parts of the existing legislation that can be improved.</p>

<p>A significant number of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s households and businesses don&rsquo;t have effective solar access. This is particularly true for renters and those living in multi-family households, but there are a number of other issues that can make it difficult for homeowners to generate their own clean energy.</p>

<p>Many states have fixed this problem by enabling community solar.&nbsp;Under these rules, a family or business may buy or lease a share of a larger solar system and receive a credit on their energy bill for the power their share of the system generates.</p>

<p>While this is similar to &ldquo;virtual meter aggregation&rdquo; as defined by AEPS, the existing rules have additional restrictions that will keep community solar from happening.&nbsp;The current rules say that&nbsp;the remote site hosting the solar system be owned or leased by the same entity as the primary electric meter it is to be netted with.&nbsp;In addition, that remote site must be within 2-miles of the primary meter.</p>

<p>There is a fix on the horizon&mdash;Sen. Scavello recently introduced SB 472 in the Pennsylvania Senate and we expect a similar bill to be introduced by Rep. Kauffer in the House that will specifically enable community solar generation.&nbsp;This will allow qualifying systems to share their generation among a number of subscribers.</p>

<p>The one piece that is still outstanding is whether or not customer generators are actually getting the full retail value for the energy they generate and the services they provide.&nbsp; A fair and independent analysis that includes all the energy and ancillary benefits of distributed generation and clean renewable energy would go a long way to filling this gap.&nbsp; Then PUC Vice Chairman Andrew Place was correct when he said &ldquo;consumers are best served by getting the &lsquo;retail value&rsquo; price right<sup>12</sup>.</p>

A Banner Week for the Delaware River Watershed,3/5/2021,"<div>
<p>It was a banner week for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s portion of the Delaware River Watershed, as three events unfolded here that could have enormous ramifications for clean water for decades to come.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The first big event occurred on Feb. 25 when <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/business/fracking-ban-delaware-river-permanent-drbc-20210225.html"">the Delaware River Basin Commission permanently banned fracking</a> within the basin, a truly momentous step for clean water in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The move came after a decade of considerations and studies by the commission, as well as lawsuits by the fracked gas industry and Pennsylvania politicians <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2021/01/18/State-senators-lawsuit-fracking-ban-pennsylvania-Delaware-River-Basin-baker-yaw/stories/202101180072"">who sought to undo a fracking moratorium</a> imposed by the DRBC in 2010.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Despite that, the commission&mdash;composed of the governors of Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey and Delaware, with the federal representative abstaining&mdash;voted last week to permanently ban fracking in the basin.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In explaining his vote, <a href=""https://www.nj.com/news/2021/02/fracking-permanently-banned-in-delaware-river-basin.html"">New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy said that</a> &ldquo;fracking poses significant risks to the water resources of the Delaware River Basin,&rdquo; and he&rsquo;s right. The Delaware River Basin provides drinking water to 13 million people, which is reason enough to protect it at all costs.</p>

<p>In addition, the fracked gas industry in Pennsylvania <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Setting-the-Record-Straight-About-Fracking-in-Pennsylvania"">has a long and infamous history of disrespecting our laws</a>, communities, shared resources and environment, and it cannot be trusted to act in our best interests. This means that the health of local communities in the basin is also protected from the devastating impacts of fracking, impacts that go beyond water contamination.</p>

<p>In casting a vote on behalf of Gov. Tom Wolf, Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection Secretary Patrick McDonnell said the fracking ban will preserve our pristine water resources in the basin <a href=""http://www.paenvironmentdigest.com/newsletter/default.asp?NewsletterArticleID=52380&amp;SubjectID="">&ldquo;for generations to come.&rdquo;</a></p>

<p>To see what PennFuture had to say about this historic vote, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-responds-to-Delaware-River-Basin-Commission-vote-on-fracking-ban"">please click here.</a></p>

<p>Another significant development for clean water in the basin came on March 3 when Philadelphia and several nearby municipalities <a href=""https://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/green/philly-some-suburbs-drag-pa-to-court-over-blocking-plastic-bag-bans/2727375/"">announced litigation against the state</a> concerning the so-called &ldquo;ban on plastic bag bans.&rdquo;</p>

<p>For context, in 2019 and again in 2020, the General Assembly in Harrisburg passed legislation that forbids any municipality in Pennsylvania from banning plastic bags. This absurd legislation takes away the ability for our municipalities to act in their own self interest, and prevents us from taking real and meaningful action to prevent the clogging of our waterways with plastics.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Specifically, Philadelphia&rsquo;s lawsuit&mdash;which PennFuture steadfastly supports&mdash;seeks to have this legislation declared as unconstitutional so that municipalities across Pennsylvania can finally take measures to keep the proliferation of plastics out of our waters.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To see what PennFuture and others had to say about this lawsuit, <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/2021-03-03-philadelphia-and-other-municipalities-file-litigation-to-assert-right-to-restrict-plastic-bags/"">please click here.</a>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Finally, also on March 3, PennFuture banded together with partners to file a petition designed to spur the DRBC to further protect fish and aquatic life by upgrading the regulatory status of the Philadelphia-Camden-Wilmington reach of the Delaware River.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The initiative seeks to ensure that water quality standards governing the river provide full Clean Water Act protections and adequate dissolved oxygen for the survival of fish and other aquatic life.</p>

<p>Both independent studies and DRBC&rsquo;s own reviews confirm that fish already use the identified river reach every year for spawning and nursery habitats, and that upgraded protections are clearly warranted. This action is needed to ensure that endangered Atlantic sturgeon, striped bass, American shad, and all other aquatic life dependent on clean water receive the proper level of protection from pollution now and into the future.</p>

<p>This petition is in addition to our <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-Petitions-DRBC-to-Recognize-Primary-Contact-Recreation-on-the-Mainstem-Delaware-River"">Safe and Healthy Delaware River Petition</a> which we filed with DRBC last year, which calls on the agency to recognize and legally protect the primary contact recreational use (e.g., swimming, jet skiing, paddleboarding, etc.) of the Philadelphia-Camden stretch of the Delaware.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To read what PennFuture had to say about our latest DRBC petition, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PR_DRBC.Petition_3.3.2021.pdf"">please click here.</a></p>

<p>Last year, a national environmental advocacy group called American Rivers named the Delaware as its <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Congratulations-to-the-Delaware-River"">2020 River of the Year</a> because of its clean water resurgence. With the actions taken over the last week, we&rsquo;re confident that the Delaware River Basin is still flowing in the right direction when it comes to clean water protections.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Please consider <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">becoming a member of PennFuture today</a> and help support our fight for cleaner water and against the fracking and petrochemical industry&rsquo;s destructive practices.</p>

",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
$296,3/2/2021,"<p>PennFuture has published the third edition of a Fossil Fuel Subsidy report that first appeared in 2011. The 2021 version is entitled <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PF_FossilFuel_Report_final_2.12.21.pdf"">&ldquo;Buried Out of Sight: Uncovering Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Hidden Fossil Fuel Subsidies.&quot;</a></p>

<p>Our report reveals that Pennsylvania&rsquo;s fossil fuel subsidies total $3.8 billion, with 52 percent of that amount benefitting fracked gas and petrochemicals. At a time of a climate emergency,&nbsp;pandemic, racial reckoning and an economic downturn that somehow is building extravagant wealth for billionaires while others struggle to make rent and buy food, the inequity and cronyism behind these subsidies strikes one as especially appalling.</p>

<p>The report is having an impact.</p>

<p>We&rsquo;ve heard from many throughout the state who are dismayed over the findings, but who are glad the information is seeing the light of day. They are reacting most to the figure that when spread across all residents of Pennsylvania, these subsidies amount to $296 per person living here.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Boosters of fracking, petrochemicals and plastics want to keep this information hidden from the public.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The report has hit a nerve over at Frack Central&mdash;the cabal of trade associations and companies that coordinate their advocacy to protect these subsidies&mdash;whose public relations machine is churning out messages accusing our meticulously researched report as sloppy. They falsely argue that our commonsense recommendations to have polluters pay their fair share to do business in our state is the equivalent of calling for your taxes to be increased.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Organizers of Frack Central, like the Marcellus Shale Coalition, are singularly focused on attacking the report. This includes their lazy messaging that distorts and simplifies our very sophisticated analysis.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our most basic recommendation is that state agencies be charged with transparency and that they make subsidy information publicly available on a regular basis.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>These distortions by industry spin doctors will not be an effective rebuttal of our report&rsquo;s analysis and our <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Subsidy-graph.JPG"">daylighting of the facts and figures</a> that make up the tangled and hidden truth behind these $3.8 million in subsidies. Frack Central&rsquo;s smear campaign has traction, though, when it gets amplified by its friends in the legislature, and elsewhere, and this is happening.</p>

<p>I invite you to review the dense report, with an eye <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Subsidy-chart.JPG"">to the chart on page 4</a>.&nbsp;There, you can see for yourself the long list of offending exemptions from taxes that the rest of us are subject to, and that can produce tax revenues, including for local governments and services.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The fact is the financial largesse of subsidies shown to the fossil fuel industry is hurting our state&rsquo;s bottom line.&nbsp;Let&rsquo;s remember these subsidies are provided with the blessing of many state elected officials, and the Governor, who are often at odds with each other on the topic of how to generate much needed new revenues in our state. So why make the money matter worse through these goodies to the fossil fuel industry?</p>

<p>The fact is that these subsidies are robbing our state of $2 billion annually in foregone revenues. If the majority of subsidies could be abolished, we can level the playing field between frackers and fossils, and pretty much everyone else including taxpayers, small businesses and other less-favored business sectors who have many fewer lobbyists in Harrisburg pleading their case.</p>

<p>The time has come for the fossil fuel industry to pay its fair share and its most egregious subsidies terminated. This includes paying even the most basic taxes from which frackers and crackers are exempted, namely paying property taxes.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Lastly, since PennFuture&rsquo;s report is based on the most recently available information from 2019, it discusses, but does not calculate, the financial impacts and lost revenues associated with two recent subsidies directed toward petrochemical development.&nbsp;</p>

<p>First is the subsidy package totaling $1.6 billion in grants, tax exemptions and other programs offered to Royal Dutch Shell for its ethane cracker in Beaver County. According to Good Jobs First Subsidy Tracker, Shell ranks seventh among the companies that have generated the most public subsidies in the United States, totaling more than $2.04 billion, with other support also coming from places like Louisiana and Texas. The $1.65 billion package Pennsylvania offered Shell is over 15 times the size of the next largest corporate subsidy offered here. The second largest was a&nbsp;$100 million package granted to Volkswagen in the late 1970s for a manufacturing plant in Westmoreland County. The 2.8-million-square foot plant is now closed.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Second are the subsidies recently approved in July 2020 (House Bill 732) for petrochemical facilities. This legislation includes tax credits &ndash; in place for 26 years and adding up to over $693 million in foregone tax revenue &ndash; and is made available for up to four facilities that manufacture only petrochemicals and fertilizers using fracked gas.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In other words, in a couple of years it&rsquo;s very possible Pennsylvania&rsquo;s fossil fuel subsidy package will balloon from $3.7 billion to almost $6 billion. Yet, Pennsylvania legislators argue nearly every spring about Pennsylvania&rsquo;s budget deficit or high taxes&nbsp;when one of the reasons for these perpetual challenges is their own doing.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture hopes that by bringing sunlight to this growing subsidy problem in Pennsylvania, better policy making can happen in the future. The perpetual cycle of subsidies, boom, and bust fossil fuel industries is a detriment to the Commonwealth. Breaking this feedback loop is one of the keys to a better future.</p>

<p>For more, <a href=""https://www.goerie.com/story/opinion/columns/2021/02/26/fossil-fuel-subsidies-dont-pay-off-pennsylvanians/4573779001/"">read this piece by Rob Altenburg</a>, Director of PennFuture&rsquo;s Energy Center, and co-author of the Fossil Fuels Subsidies report.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
A Breath of Fresh Air: How Will the Biden Administration Fight Carbon Pollution?,3/1/2021,"<p>The beginning of 2021 has been busy for clean energy advocates.</p>

<p>On January 14th, the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection wrapped up its public comment period on its proposed CO2 Budget Trading Program, through which Pennsylvania would cooperate with the other Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) states to minimize dangerous emissions across much of the northeast and invest in cleaner alternatives.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In all, DEP heard from 449 citizens over a series of ten virtual public hearings and from over 14,000 citizens who submitted written comments. The response was overwhelmingly positive and shows the vast support across Pennsylvania for cutting carbon pollution and fighting climate change.</p>

<p>Just days after the DEP wrapped up this process, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit vacated and remanded the Trump administration&rsquo;s anti-environmental &ldquo;ACE rule&rdquo;.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Although ACE stands for &ldquo;Affordable Clean Energy&rdquo; that name was always a cynical joke. The Clean Air Act requires power plants to adopt the best system of emissions reduction (BSER) to cut pollution that endangers public health and welfare. With ACE however, Trump&rsquo;s EPA attempted to redefine BSER to exclude the most cost effective approaches&mdash;including programs like the DEP&rsquo;s CO2 Budget Trading Program.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Repealing ACE was sure to be a high priority for the incoming Biden administration, but the cumbersome regulatory process to do so could easily have taken years. Fortunately, the D.C. Circuit&rsquo;s action throwing out the Trump EPA&rsquo;s horrible plan saves the Biden administration the effort of scrapping it. Now, the new leadership at EPA can focus their attention on what the next steps should be.</p>

<p>We won&rsquo;t know exactly what the new plan will look like until EPA releases a proposal, but we can make some educated guesses based on other initiatives of the Biden administration.</p>

<p>While Trump made a public show of withdrawing from the Paris Agreement, actual withdrawal wasn&rsquo;t effective until November 4th, 2020 and one of President Biden&rsquo;s first action after his inauguration was to rejoin the agreement.</p>

<p>At the center of the Paris Agreement are individual long-term goals set by the parties known as <em>nationally determined contributions</em>. Where President Obama submitted a target of reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) pollution 26 to 28% below 2005 levels by 2025, President Biden is expected to establish targets more consistent with his stated goal of achieving a carbon-free power sector by 2035 and net zero emissions economy-wide by 2050.</p>

<p>There are a number of different pathways towards reaching these goals, but the most straightforward method would be for Congress to pass legislation that caps carbon pollution and invests in clean alternatives. One possible model for this type of legislation was the Waxman-Markey Bill that was passed by the House in 2009 but was never brought up for a vote by the Senate. A modernized version of that bill reflecting the most current science and the Biden&rsquo;s administration&rsquo;s priorities could easily drive the sort of reductions we need.</p>

<p>That isn&rsquo;t the only legislative path of course. The Energy Innovation and Carbon Dividend Act, legislation related to the Green New Deal, and other alternatives could all lead to the needed emission reductions. Whether such bills would have enough support to overcome a filibuster in the Senate remains to be seen&mdash;polluting industries still wield considerable political power.</p>

<p>If the legislative pathway is blocked, the administration could use its existing authority under the Clean Air Act to get the needed emissions reductions. This is what the Obama administration did when it finalized its Clean Power Plan (CPP). In that case, existing fossil fuel power plants were required to meet certain standards of performance&mdash;the aforementioned BSER. This could be accomplished by installing new technology at the facilities themselves, but CPP also allowed states and regions to meet the standards in aggregate through programs like RGGI.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>While the eventual federal approach may not necessarily require states to implement a cap-and-invest system like Governor Wolf has proposed or join a multi-state effort such as RGGI, there are some good reasons for considering that pathway, even apart from preventing 188 million tons of carbon pollution, millions of dollars worth of co-benefits from other emissions reductions, and the potential for investment in clean and sustainable technologies that RGGI brings.</p>

<p>First, to the extent that we are required to meet federal emission targets, modeling indicates that multi-state compliance programs such as joining RGGI would likely be the most cost-effective means to do so. This should be obvious: instead of needing to reduce emissions at each individual plant, a trading program allows those reductions to be made wherever they are cheapest. A multi-state trading program provides a bigger pool of options, so finding a less-expensive alternative becomes more likely.</p>

<p>Having a strong federal program also mitigates another concern with RGGI&mdash;emissions leakage. We are very familiar with this concept in Pennsylvania where, as a member of Ozone Transport Region (OTR), facilities in our state sometimes need to meet more stringent rules than similar facilities in non-OTR states like Ohio. This gives some incentive for businesses to locate operations in jurisdictions where regulations and oversight are more lax.</p>

<p>As expected, modeling conducted on the proposed CO2 Cap and Invest program identified some effects of leakage. While CO2 pollution will fall across the board, emissions in Pennsylvania are expected to decline more than emissions in the grid as a whole&mdash;that indicates some limited shifting of generation to out of state companies could happen.&nbsp;</p>

<p>If this were a very large effect, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s program could be adjusted to compensate for the problem. There is a better solution though&mdash;if&nbsp; the federal government requires other states to achieve similar emissions reductions as a result of the Biden administrations new targets, there will be no incentive for leakage.</p>

<p>Even though federal action is likely on the way, Pennsylvania can and should move forward with its own proposed CO2 Cap and Invest program without delay.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Again, not only does this bring all the net benefits DEP identified that much sooner, it also puts Pennsylvania in a better position to influence the coming federal action. The Clean Air Act makes good use of a concept called &ldquo;cooperative federalism.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>This, essentially, lets states innovate and tailor programs to best fit their needs while the federal government provides a strong backstop ensuring critical standards are met&nbsp; If we act now, there is a much greater chance the federal program will accommodate decisions we make in Pennsylvania. If we delay, we may cede some of that flexibility.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
Fracking Banned in Delaware River Basin,2/25/2021,"<p>After a decade of consideration and study, the Delaware River Basin Commission has finally banned hydraulic fracturing in the Delaware River Basin. This is a truly momentous step.</p>

<p>For the past decade, there has been <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Moratorium-on-Fracking-in-the-Delaware-River-Basin-is-Critical-to-Protect-Our-Water"">a de facto&nbsp;moratorium on fracking</a> in the Basin. The DRBC wrote draft regulations banning fracking in 2011 but held off on finalizing them, citing the need for more information on the potential harmful environmental impacts.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the intervening years, New York State prohibited fracking and issued a final environmental impact statement in 2015 detailing the significant risks fracking poses to water resources.&nbsp;In 2016, the US EPA published a report on the significant water and health impacts associated with fracking.&nbsp;In 2017, DRBC finally sent the draft regulations, which banned hydraulic fracturing and included regulations governing fracking-related interbasin water transfers and the treatment and disposal of fracking-related wastewater, out for public comment. More than&nbsp;8,900 comment submissions were received before the comment period closed in 2018.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Then another three years passed before the February 25, 2021 vote. The DRBC voted to approve the portions of the draft regulations banning fracking.&nbsp;It withdrew the draft regulations governing water transfers and wastewater treatment, and instead it plans to issue new draft regulations on these remaining fracking issues by the end of September 2021. This is exactly what <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Public-Comment-Closes-on-DRBC-Fracking-Regulations"">PennFuture called for in our 2018 comments</a> which argued that the regulations were not strong enough to protect the watershed.</p>

<p>In one way, the February 25, 2021 vote does not change the Basin&rsquo;s status, because the de facto moratorium had been in place since 2010, and a variety of legal proceedings since then had not shaken it loose.&nbsp;In other ways, the vote is critically important.&nbsp;</p>

<p>First, it puts in place a permanent legal ban, which is far more secure than a de facto moratorium.&nbsp;Clear legal status benefits all stakeholders: landowners, water users, municipal governments, everyone who enjoys the water resources of the Delaware River Basin.&nbsp;Second, it sends a strong message from the governors of the four states in the compact - PA, NJ, NY, and DE - who all voted for the ban, that water quality really matters and industrial risks to water quality cannot be ignored.&nbsp;(The Biden administration representative abstained from the vote, saying that there had not been time to appropriately coordinate with the new administration and deferring to the votes of the member states.)</p>

<p>Importantly, today&rsquo;s vote does not put an end to all fracking issues in the Delaware River watershed.&nbsp;There will almost certainly be a legal challenge to the ban brought by pro-fracking advocates and industry, and that legal challenge will take time to work its way through the courts.&nbsp;In the meantime, the ban will be in place and the waters of the basin will be protected.&nbsp;Additionally, we will wait to see what the DRBC proposes regarding fracking-related interbasin water transfers and treatment and disposal of fracking wastewater.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As we know, the fracked gas industry in Pennsylvania has a <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Setting-the-Record-Straight-About-Fracking-in-Pennsylvania"">long and infamous history of disrespecting our laws</a>, communities, shared resources and environment.&nbsp; PennFuture will carefully review the new regulations, when they are issued, to evaluate whether they are fully protective of water quality.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We can rejoice in today&rsquo;s vote that protects water resources and public health from the dangers of fracking and know that we will remain vigilant against future threats to the environment and the people of the Delaware River basin.</p>

<p>Please consider <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/donate/index.html"">becoming a member of PennFuture today</a> and help support our fight for cleaner water and against the fracking and petrochemical industry&rsquo;s destructive practices.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jessica O'Neill, Senior Attorney"
A Breath of Fresh Air: Two Steps (and Hopefully More) Forward on Environmental Justice and Water Protection,2/19/2021,"<p><em>The United States has transitioned to the new Biden Administration that offers a stark departure on national environmental policy that could have profound impacts on Pennsylvania. After years of handouts and rollbacks to polluters, the Biden Administration is offering a hopeful opportunity to restore protections for clean air and clean water. The new Administration is also presenting renewed vigor to tackle the biggest environmental challenges of our time: mitigating climate change, addressing inequality and environmental injustices, and advancing a national economy that creates good-paying jobs while not destroying our environment. In this blog series&mdash;A Breath of Fresh Air&mdash;PennFuture experts discuss their hope, opportunities, and uncertainty during this historic shift in national policy.</em></p>

<p>The Trump administration had rolled back over 100 different environmental rules, regulations, or policies &mdash;&nbsp;an exhausting catalog of actions entirely disregarding health and the environment.&nbsp;Simply undoing the rollbacks would be a start at putting us where we were four years ago. This start is just that &mdash;&nbsp;&nbsp;a start.&nbsp;Environmentalists have much higher hopes.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Another entry in this blog series will focus on the issue of energy and the Clean Power Plan.&nbsp;Of course, given the magnitude and intersectional nature of the climate crisis, climate issues should overlay and interact with nearly everything the Biden administration does.&nbsp;So somewhat artificially setting aside federal energy policy and other more directly climate-focused issues, this post focuses on two areas &mdash;&nbsp;using environmental reviews to promote environmental justice and protection of clean water, on which the Biden administration has already started to undo the anti-environmental legacy of the past four years and where further progress is hopefully on its way.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>First, the Trump administration had viewed the National Environmental Policy Act (&ldquo;NEPA&rdquo;), which requires review and consideration of impacts and alternatives for all major federal actions affecting human health and the environment, as nothing more than a roadblock to construction.&nbsp;The Biden administration has a chance to not only reinforce the review and public participation mandates of NEPA, but to use it to enshrine principles of environmental justice into law.&nbsp;Because many of the Trump-era rollbacks were done via executive order, President Biden can and indeed has already undone them in the same manner.&nbsp;</p>

<p>For example, <a href=""https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-protecting-public-health-and-environment-and-restoring-science-to-tackle-climate-crisis/"">President Biden revoked Trump-era executive orders</a> which eliminated federal guidance on review of greenhouse gas emissions and directed federal agencies to rescind the parts of their review processes that allegedly might impede energy production, particularly from oil, natural gas, coal, and nuclear energy resources.&nbsp;He also revoked an order which imposed an unrealistic two-year completion date for all environmental impact statements regardless of the nature or complexity of the project.&nbsp;</p>

<p>President Biden&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/27/executive-order-on-tackling-the-climate-crisis-at-home-and-abroad/"">executive order also directs</a> the Council on Environmental Quality and the Office of Management and Budget to &ldquo;take steps&rdquo; toward ensuring that federal infrastructure investment reduces climate pollution, requiring federal permitting decisions to consider the effects of climate change and greenhouse gas emissions, and accelerating the deployment of clean energy and transmission projects.</p>

<p>NEPA, and its mandate for review and consideration of impacts,&nbsp;provides a legal opportunity to center environmental justice considerations and evaluate the impacts of proposed development on communities &mdash;&nbsp;including communities of color and tribal communities &mdash;&nbsp;that are already disproportionately bearing environmental burdens. President Biden has created within the Council for Environmental Quality, the office responsible for NEPA, the position of senior director for environmental justice <a href=""https://aldianews.com/articles/politics/joe-biden-adds-environmental-trailblazer-cecilia-martinez-his-climate-team/62115"">and has appointed Cecilia Martinez</a>, an environmental justice expert and advocate.&nbsp; Using NEPA and the CEQ is one method; advocates should continue to push the Biden administration to incorporate environmental justice considerations into decision-making throughout government.</p>

<p>Second, one of President Biden&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-protecting-public-health-and-environment-and-restoring-science-to-tackle-climate-crisis/?fbclid=IwAR2RHPxkppcPEFTkwki83rQ0EMKVmWlFxLACGNfNbBnQN4rmbeL4D8iu98c"">first day executive orders covers</a> the Trump Dirty Water Rule (otherwise known as the &ldquo;Navigable Waters Protection Rule&rdquo;).&nbsp;The Dirty Water Rule <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-Submits-Comments-Opposing-the-Dirty-Water-Rule-Engages-More-Than-1400-Citizens-to-Do-the-Same"">was one of the largest rollbacks</a> of Clean Water Act protections in history and removed federal jurisdiction over an enormous amount of waterways and wetlands.&nbsp;The Dirty Water Rule was a rollback of the Waters of the United States rule, which had expanded and clarified federal jurisdiction over many of those same waterways, enacted during President Obama&rsquo;s term.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Dirty Water Rule was finalized by the Environmental Protection Agency and became law in 2020.&nbsp;Principles of administrative law mean that new leadership at the EPA can&rsquo;t simply undo the Dirty Waters Rule without a new rulemaking; instead, President Biden announced that the EPA and the Army Corps of Engineers (both of which have responsibility for administering the regulation) will review the rule, presumably in preparation for enacting an entirely new regulation.</p>

<p>The Dirty Water Rule is also being challenged through litigation; if a court invalidates the rule or sends it back to the EPA for further consideration, then that also provides an opportunity for the Biden EPA to essentially start again.&nbsp;Expanded federal jurisdiction over waters and wetlands is essential to consistent protection of waters as well as consistency for stakeholders regarding what rules apply.&nbsp;It is inevitable that any action by the Biden EPA will be challenged in court, and so this is an issue to which environmentalists must keep paying close attention and continue to speak up for protection of our waters.</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s not enough to take our laws back to where they were before - environmental justice and protection of clean water requires that we take the opportunity to move forward towards a cleaner and healthier environment for all.</p>
",Community; Environment,"Jessica O'Neill, Senior Attorney"
A Breath of Fresh Air: Reason for Optimism for Lake Erie,2/12/2021,"<p>Great Lakes communities have reason for optimism under the new Biden administration. Among the many issues the administration plans to tackle are climate change, racial inequities, and aging infrastructure. Bipartisan interest in infrastructure upgrades across the U.S. is especially encouraging because these investments will not only generate family-sustaining jobs but they can also launch the U.S. into a cleaner and more resilient future.</p>

<p>The Great Lakes are the largest surface freshwater system in the world and Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Erie County runs along the southern border of Lake Erie. Lake Erie has already seen increased harmful algal blooms and decreased ice coverage over the past few decades. Erie was also named as the 8th fastest warming city in the country <a href=""https://www.climatecentral.org/news/report-american-warming-us-heats-up-earth-day"">by Climate Central.</a> Climatic changes in this region will have far reaching effects given the importance of tourism, fishing, and agriculture to the region&rsquo;s economy. These impacts include longer growing seasons but increased frequencies of drought and flood conditions, as well as increased incidences of <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/nutrientpollution/climate-change-and-harmful-algal-blooms"">harmful algal blooms</a> and <a href=""https://www.iucn.org/resources/issues-briefs/invasive-alien-species-and-climate-change"">invasive species</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Biden administration&rsquo;s quick, decisive actions and <a href=""https://www.pri.org/stories/2021-02-10/biden-vows-take-whole-government-approach-climate-change"">&ldquo;whole government approach&rdquo;</a> have the potential to put the United States back on track to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, upgrade infrastructure to make it more energy efficient, and put us on track for a more sustainable future. Efforts toward energy efficiency and renewable energy are likely to continue Pennsylvania&rsquo;s trend, with <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2020/08/20/report-clean-energy-jobs-among-fastest-growing-in-state-from-2017-2019/"">clean energy jobs among the fastest growing</a> in the state. Additionally, efforts to make homes more energy efficient will lower energy bills, which will have increased positive impact on low-income families who <a href=""https://www.energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2019/01/f58/WIP-Energy-Burden_final.pdf"">pay a larger portion of their income toward energy bills</a> than families with higher incomes.</p>

<p>The Biden administration also promises to upgrade America&rsquo;s infrastructure, including everything from roads to drinking water supply. This would be a major boon for Great Lakes regional economies, marginalized communities, and the environment if conducted in an equitable, sustainable manner. Biden&rsquo;s Transportation Secretary, Pete Buttigieg, recognized that &ldquo;misguided policies can reinforce racial inequities&rdquo; as has been demonstrated <a href=""https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trafficandcommuting/defeating-the-legacy-of-highways-rammed-through-poor-neighborhoods/2016/03/28/ffcfb5ae-f2a1-11e5-a61f-e9c95c06edca_story.html"">in highway projects across the country.</a> Having someone in office who understands this is a step in the right direction that will hopefully trickle down into more equitable transportation decision-making.</p>

<p>Among the infrastructure upgrades that we hope to see are more natural and nature-based stormwater projects, also called <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/what-is-green-stormwater-infrastructure"">green stormwater infrastructure.</a> These features are often overlooked when municipalities develop plans to upgrade stormwater and address flooding issues, but they have been shown to be as effective and less expensive than traditional stormwater infrastructure.</p>

<p>They also have added benefits like adding green space, providing habitat for native flora and fauna, filtering water pollutants, slowing runoff, and sequestering carbon dioxide. If implemented on a broad scale, these green stormwater features can help protect and restore water quality across the Great Lakes and make communities more resilient to extreme precipitation events and flooding that are <a href=""https://toolkit.climate.gov/regions/great-lakes"">already increasing due to climate change.</a></p>

<p>The new administration&rsquo;s plans are ambitious, which is exactly what this country needs right now to pull us out of the economic recession and job loss caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. We need strong action to address racial inequities that have always existed but have received renewed attention due to the social unrest that came from the unnecessary deaths of several Black Americans in 2020. We also saw that people of color have experienced disproportionate impacts from the pandemic, further highlighting the need for action. President Biden has already put together <a href=""https://www.npr.org/sections/president-biden-takes-office/2021/02/05/963837953/biden-pledged-historic-cabinet-diversity-heres-how-his-nominees-stack-up"">a diverse cabinet</a> and issued <a href=""https://www.npr.org/2021/01/29/956012329/hope-and-skepticism-as-biden-promises-to-address-environmental-racism"">an executive order to address environmental racism</a>, both of which are promising steps toward more equitable federal policies.</p>

<p>While there is much to be celebrated at the beginning of this new administration, there is much work to be done and a divided nation to heal. No administration can accomplish everything they set out to do but this one is off to a good start. Hopefully, local momentum for better inclusion and more equitable policies will add to the federal initiatives and move the country toward a more prosperous, sustainable, and equitable future for everyone and a vibrant future for the Great Lakes region.</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,"Sarah Bennett, Campaign Manager for Clean Water Advocacy"
A Breath of Fresh Air: Relationship-Building Under a New Administration,2/8/2021,"<p><em>The United States has transitioned to the new Biden Administration that offers a stark departure on national environmental policy that could have profound impacts on Pennsylvania. After years of handouts and rollbacks to polluters, the Biden Administration is offering a hopeful opportunity to restore protections for clean air and clean water. The new Administration is also presenting renewed vigor to tackle the biggest environmental challenges of our time: mitigating climate change, addressing inequality and environmental injustices, and advancing a national economy that creates good-paying jobs while not destroying our environment. In this blog series&mdash;A Breath of Fresh Air&mdash;PennFuture experts discuss their hope, opportunities, and uncertainty during this historic shift in national policy.</em><br />
<br />
The first week of President Biden&rsquo;s administration galvanized conservationists, environmentalists, and environmental justice activists.&nbsp;With the stroke of a pen, the federal government promised to champion science and prioritize climate change.&nbsp;Ultimately, the series of executive orders signed by President Biden that focused on the environment renewed faith in a system that, for four years, seemed bent on careening us towards climate catastrophe.&nbsp;Many of us breathed a sigh of relief.</p>

<p>Organizers and activists are exhausted.&nbsp;Playing defense against an anti-environment juggernaut for four years left us burned out.&nbsp;So, it&rsquo;s only natural for us to take a break and let the new administration take over for a while.&nbsp;And that&rsquo;s what I&rsquo;m afraid of: relinquishing control is not strategy; it is desperation.</p>

<p>Instead, organizers and activists need to expand our reach and deepen relationships throughout our communities. We need to escape our echo chambers.&nbsp;We need to form coalitions and build networks of communication.&nbsp;White-led organizations and coalitions need to share power.&nbsp;We need to develop alliances with the working class.&nbsp;This is not the time for rest.&nbsp;We have work to do.</p>

<p>In order to successfully build coalitions across class lines, we need a message that puts an end to the division between labor and the environment.&nbsp;Mining, drilling, processing, and pipeline jobs won&rsquo;t just disappear into the ether.&nbsp;A parallel economy - the Green Economy - is emerging.&nbsp;As we transition to renewables, opportunities for labor will abound.&nbsp;Yes, the jobs - and the skills necessary to perform them - will be different.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Training will be required.&nbsp;But there will be opportunities for labor.&nbsp;And they will likely be safer and healthier for workers, communities, and the planet.&nbsp;In a state where some legislators consistently ignore science and pit labor against the environment, I believe that a change in the national conversation may very well - dare I say trickle down - to the local level.</p>

<p>We&rsquo;ve been here before with coal, an industry dying before our eyes, still refusing to fade away in favor of cleaner, renewable options.&nbsp;Now, we&rsquo;re forced to witness the end of the fracked gas industry, only a couple of decades after it ripped through our mountains, poisoned our streams, and destroyed our infrastructure.&nbsp;It is time to break the cycle of environmental abuse levied upon this state by the fossil fuel industry in all of its iterations.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We have the opportunity to rise up as a leader in renewable energy and lift up the working class which has kept the lights on for so long by serving in the mines, gas fields, and oil refineries.&nbsp;It is time to give back by providing new jobs, skills, and opportunities.&nbsp;As the new administration says, <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2021/jan/30/joe-biden-climate-change-action?fbclid=IwAR0iPREAzsjbRwQILFKGtHFZgIfQjvsrcLSZiRhPDguxD72josjUozCcA1M"">&ldquo;When I think of climate change I think of jobs.&rdquo;</a>&nbsp; Organizers at the local level need to embrace that slogan.</p>

<p>It is up to us to build the relationships necessary to see each other as partners, not as adversaries. It is up to us to agree that the climate crisis is worthy enough a foe to link arms.&nbsp;It is up to us to fight for the future of our families, communities, country, and planet instead of political points.&nbsp;</p>

<p>If Pennsylvanians could agree that the environment is one of the most salient issues in our commonwealth, consider the injustices we could confront:&nbsp;environmental racism, the death of the fossil fuel industry that left behind workers whose ancestors kept the lights on for generations, the failing health of our nation caused by pollution and environmental degradation.&nbsp;As organizers, it is up to us to lay the groundwork for progress.</p>

<p>The advent of a new administration does not allow for rest; in contrast, it demands a kind of sortie.&nbsp;Environmentalists, conservationists, and EJ activists must now go on the offensive.&nbsp; It is time to battle for the future. We&rsquo;ve got the opportunity to make real, tangible progress if we coalesce and fight. We can&rsquo;t afford to waste it.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Donna Kohut, Policy Manager for Sustainable Economics"
A Welcomed Shift in Philadelphia’s Approach to Infrastructure Financing,2/2/2021,"<p>Last month Governor Wolf <a href=""https://www.media.pa.gov/pages/Pennvest-details.aspx?newsid=61"">announced $178 million in investments</a> for water infrastructure projects in 11 counties with funds from <a href=""https://www.pennvest.pa.gov/Pages/default.aspx"">Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Infrastructure Investment Fund (PENNVEST)</a>. Philadelphia received the largest award of any applicant: $106 million of the investments will contribute to the goals of the <em>Green City, Clean Waters</em> program - the city&rsquo;s combined sewer overflow compliance program. The announcement represents a welcomed shift in the city&rsquo;s approach to infrastructure financing, and one we&rsquo;d like to see the water department utilize more in the future.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PENNVEST is a low-cost financing program that provides assistance to the communities and citizens of Pennsylvania by funding sewer, stormwater and drinking water projects. PENNVEST was established in 1988 through the Pennsylvania Infrastructure Investment Authority Act to administer and finance federal programs known as the Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF), the Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF), and the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA). CWSRF and DWSRF were established as part of the Water Quality Act of 1987. PENNVEST also finances, through the issuance of special obligation revenue bonds, water management, solid waste disposal, sewage treatment and pollution control projects undertaken by or on behalf of private entities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Recently, concerns have arisen from within the water department about the rising cost of Philadelphia&rsquo;s <em>Green City, Clean Waters</em> program, which is financed by&nbsp;a stormwater charge on water rates and taxpayer dollars. PENNVEST provides municipalities with a low interest rate alternative to pursuing financing through the private market. This allows for municipalities to avoid having to make large increases to water rates or taxes to finance their water infrastructure investments.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2019 PennFuture, along with partners at Sustainable Business Network of Greater Philadelphia, Natural Resources Defense Council, Pennsylvania Horticultural Society, and Friends of the Wissahickon, released <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/common-agenda"">A Common Green Stormwater Infrastructure Agenda for Philadelphia</a>.&nbsp;The Common Agenda offered a series of recommended policy solutions for Philadelphia&rsquo;s Mayor and City Council to consider to ensure the long term success of <em>Green City, Clean Waters</em>.</p>

<p>One recommended solution is that the city &ldquo;take full advantage of all available state and federal programs that provide grants and low-cost financing for municipal infrastructure improvement. This includes programs like PENNVEST&rsquo;s Clean Water State Revolving Fund, which are specifically for water infrastructure, as well as programs focused on transportation, community development, or other projects that can be leveraged to include GSI improvements.&rdquo; (The Common Agenda, Pg. 12).&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>PENNVEST funding is offered to a variety of programs, including <a href=""https://www.pennvest.pa.gov/Information/Funding-Programs/Pages/Green-Initiatives.aspx"">green initiatives that promote and encourage environmental responsibility</a> in communities that are creative and innovative with green solutions for water quality management. The Philadelphia Water Department was awarded PENNVEST funding for two projects. Both projects will contribute to cleaner streams and rivers in Philadelphia and maintain an affordable water rate for ratepayers.&nbsp;</p>

<p>A portion of the PENNVEST award <a href=""https://www.einnews.com/pr_news/534811498/tartaglione-announces-6-7-million-in-state-financing-to-reduce-wastewater-overflows-in-lawncrest"">will provide $6.7 million in green investments</a> in the Lawncrest neighborhood of lower Northeast Philadelphia. These green infrastructure projects include tree trenches, bumpouts, and stormwater trees that will reduce the quantity of stormwater pollution entering the streams and rivers surrounding Philadelphia.</p>

<p>The neighborhood of Lawncrest is also considered an Environmental Justice (EJ) Area. The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection defines an EJ Area as &ldquo;any census tract where 20 percent or more individuals live at or below the federal poverty level and/or 30 percent or more of the population identifies as a non-white minority, based on data for the U.S. Census Bureau and the federal guidelines for poverty.&rdquo; In addition to reducing stormwater pollution and greening the neighborhood, this green investment will contribute to cooling the neighborhood and reversing the Urban Heat Island effect.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Philadelphia also received <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/business/pennsylvania-philadelphia-water-department-sewer-loan-upgrade-northeast-plant-20210126.html"">a $100 million loan to construct</a> a preliminary treatment facility. The facility will reroute wastewater from entering the combined sewer system and install new screening and grit removal systems. The project will have the capacity to treat 300 million gallons per day and will reduce the amount of combined sewer overflows entering the Delaware River. Both of these significant infrastructure investments will contribute to the <em>Green City, Clean Waters&rsquo;</em> goal to reduce the amount of polluted stormwater overflows discharging into the creeks, streams, and rivers in and around Philadelphia by 85 percent by 2036.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s refreshing to see the Philadelphia Water Department pursue innovative approaches towards financing and fixing very old issues with the city&rsquo;s aging infrastructure. <em>Green City, Clean Waters</em> was an innovative and unique solution to combined sewer overflow pollution. The program put Philadelphia on the map as a national leader in green infrastructure. And now, as the program reaches its 10 year anniversary amidst a global pandemic, Philadelphia must once again demonstrate innovation and leadership in stormwater infrastructure.&nbsp;</p>
",,Lena Smith
PennFuture joins with the Philadelphia Coalition for Affordable Communities,1/26/2021,"<p>At the start of 2021, PennFuture became an official member of the <a href=""http://phillyaffordablecommunities.org/"">Philadelphia Coalition for Affordable Communities</a>. The coalition, led by the <a href=""https://www.wcrpphila.org/"">Women&rsquo;s Community Revitalization Project</a>,&nbsp;launched in 2005 through the &ldquo;Development without Displacement&rdquo; campaign to ensure that as the city&rsquo;s neighborhoods recover and thrive, individuals and families from all income levels benefit.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Over the years, the coalition has been advocating for better policies, more funding and more land for affordable housing, as well as funding for childcare and resources to address community needs. These campaigns have resulted in notable victories including the creation of the Philadelphia Housing Trust Fund, The Land Bank, and funding for affordable housing. This year the coalition will be launching its Land Justice Campaign.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We are proud to join the coalition in striving for increased land justice and affordable housing.
