Our Philadelphia work is focused on elevating nature-based solutions to stormwater pollution by elevating the importance of green stormwater infrastructure and the preservation and increase of green space with elected officials and communities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Philadelphia&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/water/sustainability/greencitycleanwaters/Pages/default.aspx""><em>Green City, Clean Waters</em> program</a> has put the city on the map for being the first city in the country to implement green stormwater infrastructure (GSI) at a citywide scale to reduce stormwater pollution. To date, Philadelphia has constructed 1,000 greened acres (a good start in reaching their goal of 10,000 greened acres by 2036) that are reducing stormwater pollution and resulting in cleaner water in our local rivers and streams. But even before the city&rsquo;s <em>Green City, Clean Waters</em> program, communities and residents were reducing stormwater pollution by preserving land for community gardens and open space.&nbsp;</p>

<p>When <em>Green City, Clean Waters</em> was first initiated, Philadelphia was still struggling to recover from decades of declining population and urban blight. The program was chosen, in part, because of the co-benefits associated with greening neighborhoods intended to address many of the intersecting crises. It was also the most cost-effective. Philadelphia was facing, and continues to struggle with today, gun violence, blight, the urban heat island effect, poverty, and job loss.&nbsp;</p>

<p><em>Green City, Clean Waters</em> has had many successes over the years. To date, <a href=""https://gsipartners.sbnphiladelphia.org/the-economic-social-and-environmental-case-for-green-city-clean-waters-an-update/"">the program is producing $4 billion in total economic impact for Philadelphia</a>, including an average of 1,160 jobs annually. In 2018 the program reduced crime by nearly nine percent and saved the city $50 million annually in avoided health-related costs attributed to access to open space.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Now, nearly ten years after the initial launch of <em>Green City, Clean Waters</em>, Philadelphia is a different kind of city. Philadelphia is becoming a more desirable place to live. Development has increased in many neighborhoods and property values are rising. But these improvements have also had some negative impacts on our communities. As affordable, accessible homes are becoming out of reach for most Philadelphians, community open spaces and gardens are quickly being lost to profit-driven development. Community gardens and farms have been places where people gather, sources of affordable nutrition, and naturally manage stormwater.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While this development is critical for improving Philadelphia&rsquo;s neighborhoods and the construction of private green stormwater infrastructure projects, for many Philadelphians who have been preserving open space and investing in their communities for years, it means being forced out of their communities. Preserving housing and land affordability in gentrifying neighborhoods will ensure that those who are committed to and invested in Philadelphia&rsquo;s communities can afford to stay.&nbsp;</p>

<p>On Thursday, PennFuture will join the Philadelphia Coalition for Affordable Housing as it launches the Land Justice Campaign, which seeks to address the city&rsquo;s housing and food affordability crises by transfering city owned vacant land to groups that will put the land back to use and ensure permanent affordability and community control.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The campaign intends to expand opportunities to create Community Land Trusts (CLTs) within the city. CLTs are nonprofit, community-based organizations that are committed to permanent stewardship of land and the permanent affordability of housing and other uses upon its lands. They are one way to achieve permanent accessible affordable and community control in neighborhoods facing displacement.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We are proud to stand among the members of the coalition in seeking community-led solutions to Philadelphia&rsquo;s affordability and land justice challenges.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,Lena Smith
A Breath of Fresh Air,1/22/2021,"<p><em>The United States has transitioned to the new Biden Administration that offers a stark departure on national environmental policy that could have profound impacts on Pennsylvania. After years of handouts and rollbacks to polluters, the Biden Administration is offering a hopeful opportunity to restore protections for clean air and clean water. The new Administration is also presenting renewed vigor to tackle the biggest environmental challenges of our time: mitigating climate change, addressing inequality and environmental injustices, and advancing a national economy that creates good-paying jobs while not destroying our environment. In this blog series&mdash;A Breath of Fresh Air&mdash;PennFuture experts discuss their hope, opportunities, and uncertainty during this historic shift in national policy.</em></p>

<p>Rejoining the Paris climate accord. Cancelling permits for the Keystone XL Pipeline. A commitment to reverse or reinstate an astounding number of environmental rollbacks and repeals from the prior administration.&nbsp;</p>

<p>And that was just Day 1.&nbsp;</p>

<p>President Joseph Biden hasn&rsquo;t been shy about his determination to tackle one of the most pressing issues of our time. Speaking from the Oval Office on his first night as president, Biden said his administration will <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/20/climate/biden-paris-climate-agreement.html"">&ldquo;combat climate change in a way we have not before.&rdquo;</a></p>

<p>Though Biden&rsquo;s actions will ultimately speak louder than his words, his first day in office was already a stark departure from the deregulation and polluter-first policies of the Trump administration, which repealed or otherwise rolled back more than 100 environmental rules and regulations.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In case you needed a reminder, <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/climate/trump-environment-rollbacks-list.html"">the numbers are staggering</a>: 30 rule reversals for air pollution, 19 on drilling and extraction, 16 for protecting wildlife and animals, and 9 for water pollution, among others. All told, 112 rules meant to keep us, our environment, and living species safe from pollution and degradation, wiped off the books or watered down over the last four years.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Trump didn&rsquo;t stop at deregulation. The former president, <a href=""https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2016/jun/03/hillary-clinton/yes-donald-trump-did-call-climate-change-chinese-h/"">who claimed the climate crisis was a hoax concocted by China</a> to weaken America&rsquo;s manufacturing sector, rushed during the dying days of his presidency <a href=""https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-drilling-idUSKBN29O2K5"">to auction off drilling rights for the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge</a>, and to weaken <a href=""https://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/535106-biden-freeze-of-trump-rules-could-halt-environmental-rollbacks"">a 100-year-old law that protects migratory birds.</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Put simply, most in the environmental advocacy world believe that <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/nov/21/trump-environmental-protections-rollback-climate-crisis"">&ldquo;no administration has been worse for our environment or our nation&rsquo;s public health than this one,&rdquo;</a> and it&rsquo;s hard to argue to the contrary. On Friday, the New York Times estimated it <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/22/climate/biden-environment.html"">could take years for Biden to reverse the damage done </a>by the previous administration.&nbsp;</p>

<p>At PennFuture, we don&rsquo;t favor one political party over another. We favor science, sound environmental policy, and anything that gets us closer to a clean energy economy and a healthy, stable climate. Anything less from either side of the political spectrum is unacceptable.&nbsp;</p>

<p>With that said, it&rsquo;s hard not to feel optimistic on the dawn of this new administration. Even while running for president, Biden&rsquo;s platform <a href=""https://www.sierraclub.org/sierra/look-biden-s-climate-and-environment-roster"">included the most ambitious climate action plan in history</a>, with a needed and dedicated focus on environmental justice issues.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Since being elected in November, Biden has unveiled a climate-first cabinet <a href=""https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/biden-names-john-kerry-climate-envoy/"">and even created a new position</a> in nominating former Secretary of State John Kerry as a &ldquo;special presidential envoy on climate change.&rdquo; He also tapped Obama-era EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy to start a new White House office on climate policy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>According to the New York Times, Biden is building a veritable &ldquo;nerve center&rdquo; for climate issues and is overseeing <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/19/climate/biden-climate-change.html"">&ldquo;the largest team of climate change experts ever assembled in the White House.&rdquo;</a></p>

<p>So on this, the second full day of a new administration, we are hopeful for a new era, but we are not yet satisfied or content. We are eager to see what comes next, and how PennFuture might engage with or otherwise work alongside this new administration to advance commonsense policies and regulations that bring us closer to a world without a climate crisis.&nbsp;</p>

<p>At minimum, this new administration is a breath of fresh air, but time will tell as to its true impact on the air we breathe, the water we drink, and the climate we all rely on for survival.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
In the Midst of a Democracy Emergency,1/19/2021,"<p>The United States, and by extension Pennsylvania, is in the midst of a democracy emergency.</p>

<p>Our public institutions are weak, the image of a stable American republic is in tatters, and basic tenets of our constitution&mdash;the ability for all citizens to freely vote, for those votes to be fairly counted, and results of the election to lead to a peaceful transition of power&mdash;has been undermined.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While PennFuture remains, first and foremost, a beacon for environmental leadership and protection in Pennsylvania, we would not be true to our mission if we didn&rsquo;t stand up and emphatically oppose efforts to undercut the democracy we require to ensure clean air, clean water, abundant green spaces, and a stable climate. We stand with all of civil society against the violent sedition, conspiracy theories, and fomenting of hate that has gripped our communities and politics.</p>

<p>PennFuture has now <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/insurrectionaction"">weighed in against elected officials</a> who have breached the trust of the people.&nbsp;Elected officials in our state <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/mastrianoalert"">are propagating and participating in the lie</a> that Pennsylvania&rsquo;s November 2020 election was fraudulent. President Donald Trump has taken that lie to the point of inciting riot, mayhem and insurrection against American Democracy on January 6, 2021.&nbsp;</p>

<p>When we crafted <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-statement-regarding-violent-insurrection-at-US-Capitol"">our media statement</a> around the insurrection, we knew the statement would be different, and the focus would be different, because this moment in time is one of the most appalling and dangerous in our history.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>This moment also lays bare the interconnectedness of our frail democracy with the systemic environmental injustices holding back countless communities around the Commonwealth. The gross racial double standard applied by law enforcement was egregiously on display on January 6.&nbsp; So was the evidence of white supremacists among President Trump&rsquo;s supporters, and the overtly racist aspects of Trump&#39;s doctrine of &ldquo;American Carnage.&rdquo;</p>

<p>The trauma felt by people of color in the aftermath of January 6, simply put, cannot be shared by white America.&nbsp;People of color in this country have not lived the same American experience lived by whites because this country&rsquo;s original sin of slavery, inequality and race relations still have not been reckoned with.&nbsp;Now we endeavor to attempt that reckoning, and January 6 is the latest manifestation of how hard this will and needs to be. We must try harder to open and hold fast to a space for people of color to speak in this moment.</p>

<p>Our country is balancing on a razor edge.&nbsp;On one side is unity; on the other side is violence, and deeper division. Since the November election, I have struggled with the question of how PennFuture can do its work in a state so deeply divided.&nbsp;Racism divides us, and we are taking imperfect steps as an organization to deal with this. The partisan divide is fueling so many problems and we are grateful that many lawmakers talk to us and listen to our concerns.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>There is an urban and rural divide.&nbsp;Over the years, I have done a lot of conservation work in more rural communities of our state.&nbsp;I know at one time there were strongly held and shared values around land, air, water and wildlife across the political and geographic spectrum&mdash; will we ever share those values again?&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>There is also a divide between what our state Constitution says and how it is&nbsp;carried out by elected officials, residents, and corporations. Our mission is tethered to the Pennsylvania Constitution, specifically Article 1, Section 27, the Environmental Rights Amendment that states:</p>

<p style=""text-align: center;""><em>The people have a right to clean air, pure water, and to the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic and esthetic values of the environment.&nbsp;Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources are the common property of all the people, including generations yet to come.&nbsp;As trustee of these resources, the Commonwealth shall conserve and maintain them for the benefit of all the people.</em></p>

<p>Bluntly, we have made little progress in ensuring this guarantee is the law of the land.</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s theory of change relies on the state and nation having in place a majority of elected officials who are pro-environment and who share that value with our organization.&nbsp;For those majorities to occur, our values as an organization need to be shared with voters, participating in an intact democracy.</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s Civic Engagement program&mdash;<a href=""https://www.democracyforall-pennfuture.com/"">Democracy for All</a>&mdash;reaches out to those voters or those eligible to vote and endeavors to open our organization to those voices, particularly in communities of color, but the trust gap is real.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The democracy emergency is real; fraught race relations are real; so is the climate emergency, and the public health emergency in our communities unjustly burdened with pollution. As the country transitions from an unapologetically anti-environmental and anti-regulatory administration to the Biden administration, one that blessedly already is taking major steps to affirm the seriousness of global climate change and the need to transition without further delay to a cleaner energy, you can expect PennFuture to continue to speak up about these interconnected emergencies.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>On a personal note, as a lifelong activist, silence from the advocacy organization I came to lead was not an option after January 6.&nbsp;I&rsquo;ve offered my assurance about our mission, and rationale about why we must focus where we are.&nbsp;</p>

<p>At the end of the day, though, it must be said that we act because it is simply the right thing to do.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO; Matthew Stepp, Vice President and Chief of Staff, PennFuture"
The Growing Danger of Pipelines Our Safety Regulations Overlook,1/6/2021,"<p>In a November 2019 presentation, John Gale, Director of Standards and Rulemaking at the U.S. Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA), called gathering lines <a href=""http://pstrust.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Gale-Presentation.pdf"">&ldquo;the next big thing&rdquo; in pipeline safety</a>. This certainly rings true in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>After just one week in operation, Energy Transfer&rsquo;s 24-inch diameter gathering pipeline ruptured and exploded in Beaver County, taking down a nearby house, six transmission towers, and multiple motor vehicles and burning several acres of trees. Residents of 49 households were forced to evacuate in the 2018 explosion.&nbsp;</p>

<p>By June 2020, Attorney General Josh Shapiro had released a scathing report on the state&rsquo;s failure to protect its citizens during the fracking boom. The report had eight recommendations, and the regulation of gathering pipelines was third on the list.</p>

<p>As the report describes, the emergence of fracking dramatically upended the gas industry, swiftly rendering decades of regulations insufficient.&nbsp;The failed regulation of gathering pipelines provides a blistering example.</p>

<p>Gas pipelines are broken into three main categories: gathering lines, which transport extracted gas to be processed and treated; transmission lines, which transport processed gas over long distances; and distribution lines, which deliver processed gas to homes and businesses. The PHMSA sets minimum regulations for pipelines and certifies state agents &ndash; usually the Public Utility Commission &ndash; for enforcement.</p>

<p>While transmission and distribution lines are generally held to higher standards, gathering lines are subject to a patchwork of regulations that leaves an estimated 439,000 miles of pipelines &ndash; which, end to end, would wrap around the Earth 17 times &ndash; essentially unregulated. These pipelines do not have to be built to standard, marked, or regularly inspected, a regulatory scheme that was devised when gathering lines were considered lower risk because of their comparatively smaller diameter and lower pressure.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Yet with a dramatic increase in production and more gas to transport, fracked gas companies now operate much larger gathering pipelines under higher pressures. In many instances, these pipelines are indistinguishable from transmission lines, despite being subject to far fewer safety regulations.</p>

<p>In fact, which regulations apply to gathering lines depend upon both the population density of the surrounding area - a factor which is subject to change over time - and its operating pressure. These confusing standards undervalue the safety of rural residents, preclude community involvement, and complicate enforcement. They also mean that about 95 percent of gathering pipelines in Pennsylvania are not subject to any federal or state safety regulations.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania needs to streamline and extend its pipeline safety standards by regulating all gathering lines just as we would transmission lines. This means that pipeline companies would be held to a common standard for the design, construction, operation, and maintenance of all gathering lines, regardless of their location.</p>

<p>Gathering lines in urban areas (Class 4 locations) are already subject to most of these rules. This change would extend these safety regulations to pipelines in less densely populated areas, affording peri-urban and rural residents the same level of protection from potential pipeline incidents while simplifying enforcement.</p>

<p>Regulating gathering pipelines is not the only action necessary to modernize our outdated pipeline safety regulations, but it&rsquo;s an important first step.&nbsp;</p>

<p>More than 90 percent of voters in Pennsylvania want lawmakers to take the necessary steps to prevent pipeline accidents. We must urge the General Assembly to heed the Attorney General&rsquo;s recommendations and the expressed concerns of voters across the state by regulating all gathering lines exactly as we would transmission lines.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Emily Persico, Policy Analyst"
Recycling is Exacerbating the Plastic Waste Crisis,1/4/2021,"<p>On November 25th, 2020, Pennsylvania became the ninth state in the nation to pass <a href=""https://nextpittsburgh.com/latest-news/the-advanced-recycling-bill-just-passed-by-the-pa-house-would-harm-the-environment-says-new-report-heres-why/"">so-called &ldquo;advanced recycling&rdquo; legislation</a>.</p>

<p>Coined by the American Chemistry Council, the term encompasses processes that transform plastic waste into their component parts using heat and pressure. Because 99 percent of all plastics are made from oil and fracked gas, the resulting product is most often a fossil fuel.</p>

<p>The legislation redefines plastic-to-fuel operations as &ldquo;recycling&rdquo; under state solid waste law, loosening regulations for plastic-burning businesses and potentially paving the way for them to take advantage of future clean energy funding. All this bodes poorly for the residents of Pennsylvania, who can expect more air pollution and an increased reliance on single-use plastic.</p>

<p>The nascent industry is already descending upon our state, using Pennsylvania residents as guinea pigs as they test out new methods and processes. International Recycling Group <a href=""https://www.goerie.com/story/business/2020/08/17/100-million-recycling-plant-planned-for-erie/113341576/"">is planning to sort and process &ldquo;recycled&rdquo; plastics in Erie County</a> for use as a fuel and reactant in the steel-making process. Meanwhile, Agilyx Corporation <a href=""https://www.recyclingtoday.com/article/agilyx-delta-air-monroe-plastic-scrap-fuel/"">has plans to revert &ldquo;recycled&rdquo; plastics into jet fuel</a> for Delta Airlines, expanding a petrochemical hub in an already overburdened community outside of Philadelphia.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;As we advance the number and types of products we can make from waste plastics, this project marks the first truly commercial-scale facility that will advance the new plastics economy,&rdquo;&nbsp; says Agilyx CEO Joe Vaillancourt.</p>

<p>Advanced recycling builds upon a decades-long crusade by the oil and gas industry to undermine the effectiveness of recycling. As public skepticism of plastic started turning into local bans on non-recyclable plastics in the 80s and 90s, the oil and gas industry realized that they had to <a href=""https://www.npr.org/2020/03/31/822597631/plastic-wars-three-takeaways-from-the-fight-over-the-future-of-plastics"">buy the public&rsquo;s trust in recycling</a> to keep plastic in the marketplace.</p>

<p>Yet an effective recycling system would be at odds with the industry, which <a href=""https://www.houstonpublicmedia.org/articles/news/energy-environment/2020/09/13/381750/how-big-oil-misled-the-public-into-believing-plastic-would-be-recycled/"">makes $400 billion each year</a> turning fossil fuels into virgin plastics. So while they spent millions of dollars on ads and public relations campaigns to promote recycling, they also quietly celebrated the fact that low-quality recycled plastics could never compete with virgin plastics made from cheap oil and gas.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Now, the oil and gas industry is taking our trust - our carefully cleaned and sorted plastic recyclables - and burning it.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Advanced recycling businesses will come to rely upon single-use plastics as feedstock, further aiding oil and gas companies in their ultimate goal of <a href=""https://e360.yale.edu/features/the-plastics-pipeline-a-surge-of-new-production-is-on-the-way"">ramping up plastic production by threefold</a> in the next 30 years.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania will bear the brunt of this too. We have an overabundance of fracked gas - so much so that industry executives were <a href=""https://www.bizjournals.com/pittsburgh/news/2020/12/29/pennsylvania-rig-count-2020.html?ana=e_me_prem&amp;j=90544016&amp;t=Morning&amp;mkt_tok=eyJpIjoiT1Raa056WXpOV1k1WVdGaCIsInQiOiJVUFc5RUtUZitaWXFmZ2tJZG9YazM4bkNJV3RTWE9CMlFxTUliMlN2clBveEtHVkNsNDBNaWh4c0dDZU1DOW1QK3RaczF6a2x5Nmt5NWZKeVpvbFh2VEM2SzNGMjR5NjZ3eWpjZlRwaG4xXC9La0dvcUFtRkhKMnJWUUZ1UUN2bDRwQzhyVzVzamFEVFRhOHg0cmZEZ2pnPT0ifQ%3D%3D"">forced to curb production this year</a>. Eager to find a use for their unwanted product, elected officials are doling out billions of taxpayer dollars to attract companies that would convert Pennsylvania fracked gas into petrochemicals like plastics and fertilizers. Shell was the first company <a href=""https://www.goodjobsfirst.org/shell-cracks-pennsylvania%E2%80%99s-tax-code"">to cash in on the prize</a>. They will not necessarily be the last.</p>

<p>More fracking, more plastic production, more plastic burning. Is this the solution to our plastics waste crisis?</p>

<p>Plastic recycling is exactly what it was always meant to be: a pseudo-solution to the plastics crisis that assuages consumer guilt just enough to keep plastic production churning. Decades into this distraction, we are finding plastics in <a href=""https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/youre-literally-eating-microplastics-how-you-can-cut-down-exposure-to-them/2019/10/04/22ebdfb6-e17a-11e9-8dc8-498eabc129a0_story.html"">our food</a>, <a href=""https://news.wsu.edu/2020/03/13/invisible-plastics-water/"">our water</a>, <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/11/climate/airborne-plastic-pollution.html"">our air</a>. We are finding plastics <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/dec/22/microplastics-revealed-in-placentas-unborn-babies#:~:text=Microplastics%20were%20detected%20on%20both,dozen%20plastic%20particles%20were%20found.&amp;text=The%20microplastics%20were%20mostly%2010,be%20carried%20in%20the%20bloodstream."">in the placentas of unborn babies</a>.</p>

<p>We don&rsquo;t need more recycling; we need less plastic. We must let go of our trust in the dysfunctional recycling system and any techno-solutions the plastics industry has to offer, and instead refocus our energy on holding oil and gas companies accountable for their irresponsible production, corporate greenwashing campaigns, and continual attempts to stop meaningful legislation in its tracks.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Transitioning Pennsylvania to a clean energy economy is one of our top priorities, and so-called &ldquo;advanced recycling&rdquo; won&rsquo;t do anything to get us closer to that goal. PennFuture will closely monitor this emerging industry in 2021, as well as projects already being discussed near Philadelphia and Erie.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Emily Persico, Policy Analyst"
Ready for 2021,12/28/2020,"<p>Early on in 2020, even after a very successful mid-March rally against petrochemical subsidies in the state Capitol that was organized by the PennFuture team and supported by many partners, the pandemic and recession gave me serious doubts that PennFuture would be able to carry on our mission, let alone remain an essential force for environmental protection.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As I reflect on the past and difficult year, that feeling couldn&rsquo;t have been further from what actually transpired &ndash; PennFuture distinguished itself as unparalleled in statewide environmental advocacy.</p>

<p>Sure, the fact that the legislature remained in session, and was sufficiently emboldened to attempt many bad things, helped, and cemented PennFuture&rsquo;s essential role in 2020 as a watchdog of the legislature and of polluters.&nbsp; But we also did so much more: defeated over 50 bad pieces of legislation designed to roll back previously hard-won environmental protections; seven legal actions taken; three major policy reports published; a virtual campaign to protect Pocono headwater streams that yielded almost 2 million social media posts and advocate-produced video content; and 800,000 voters or prospective voters civically engaged.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Our communications output was exhaustive: literally hundreds of media placements; the production of 15 issues of our lockdown inspired early-warning publication &quot;The Bark&quot;;&nbsp;and a full on counter-offensive of published content countering&nbsp;the many false narratives the fracked gas, petrochemical&nbsp;and plastics industries spew regularly.</p>

<p>The year wasn&rsquo;t without its extreme difficulties.&nbsp;The ongoing racism so brutally exposed by Black Lives Matters; the health end economic disparities exacted upon communities of color by COVID and its recession; the attempted robbery of the presidential election; and the deep divisions that define us.&nbsp;</p>

<p>So 2021 must be a year to grapple with these realities, while we seek ways to reset society&rsquo;s desire for clean air, water and a healthy climate.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I can&rsquo;t say enough about the extraordinary talent, energy and commitment of our staff team and the long list of great work not mentioned here.&nbsp;We are fortunate to have the encouragement and good counsel provided by our board of volunteer&nbsp;leaders.&nbsp;</p>

<p>With the help of readers, advocates and supporters like all of you, when 2021 arrives, PennFuture will be ready.<br />
&nbsp;</p>
",Community,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
2019-2020 Legislative Wrap-Up & 2021 Preview:  Where Does the PA General Assembly Stand on Our Environment?,12/16/2020,"<p>With the close of the legislative session in Harrisburg at the end of November&nbsp;came significant victories for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environmental protection, as a handful of bills were halted thanks to our work in the Capitol, and thanks to the many citizens who took action by contacting their elected officials.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This would not have been possible without the advocacy and hard work from PennFuture staff, members, supporters, and partners across the environmental and conservation community in Pennsylvania. Through action alert emails that engaged citizens with their elected officials, in-district constituent meetings with members of the General Assembly, calls to offices, sign-on letters with partner organizations and coalitions, and multiple lobby days, our presence and direct opposition to these bills truly had an impact.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While advancing proactive, offensive, good environmental legislation remains a challenge in Harrisburg, PennFuture and partners killed, blocked, and bottled-up a host of anti-environmental and pro-fossil fuel bills and policies in the recent previous legislative session. Below, please find a summary of the good, bad and ugly bills we engaged with over this last legislative session.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Defensive Victories</strong></u>:</p>

<p>In terms of &quot;regulatory reform,&rdquo; which is really just another term for&nbsp;&ldquo;rollbacks,&rdquo; PennFuture and partners killed a number of dangerous bills in the General Assembly, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>HB 430 (Legislative blocking/killing regulations&nbsp;via concurrent resolution)</li>
	<li>HB 414/HB 509/SB 252 (allowing for &lsquo;third-party permit review&rsquo;)</li>
	<li>HB 762/SB 253 (&lsquo;Regulatory Compliance Advisor&rsquo;)</li>
	<li>HB 507/ HB 806/SB 5 (Legislative approval of &lsquo;economically significant&nbsp;regulations&rsquo;)</li>
	<li>HB 827/SB 305 (undermining the Delaware River Basin Commission with&nbsp;eminent domain and requiring &lsquo;just compensation&rsquo;)</li>
	<li>HB 828 (Regulatory&nbsp;rollback for unconventional drilling: siting, boreholes, water)</li>
	<li>HB 1055/SB 251 (Office of the Repealer)</li>
	<li>HB 1105 (Energize Pennsylvania package: &lsquo;consolidated standards permit&rsquo;)</li>
	<li>HB 414/1106 (Energize Pennsylvania package: &lsquo;deemed approval&rsquo; of permits)</li>
	<li>HB 1107 (Energize Pennsylvania package: &lsquo;PA Permitting Commission&rsquo;)</li>
	<li>HB 1874/SB 703 (Amending the Regulatory Review Act for more legislative control of the&nbsp;Independent Regulatory Review Commission)</li>
	<li>HB 2025/SB 950 (Requiring legislative approval of RGGI) - <em>Governor Wolf vetoed&nbsp;</em></li>
	<li>HB 2416/SB 327 (Regulatory tolling during COVID-19 emergency declaration)</li>
	<li>SB 323/887 (pipeline protest bill; &lsquo;critical infrastructure protection act&rsquo;; liability fees paid by protestors)</li>
	<li>SB 619 (attempt to eviscerate PA&rsquo;s Clean Streams Law)</li>
	<li>SB 726/727 (Cutting scope, powers, membership of Environmental Hearing Board)</li>
	<li>SB 790/HB 1635 (rolling back conventional drilling standards to 1984 levels) - <em>Governor Wolf vetoed</em></li>
</ul>

<p>In terms of fossil fuel subsidies and giveaways, PennFuture and partners killed a number of dangerous bills in the General Assembly, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>HB 11/SB 510 (unlimited &amp; open-ended nuclear subsidies with no Tier 1 AEPS increase)</li>
	<li>HB 695 (incentives for waste-to-energy &lsquo;recycling&rsquo;)</li>
	<li>HB 1100 (Energize Pennsylvania package: open-ended subsidy for 30 years at $660B per petrochemical&nbsp;plant) - <em>Governor Wolf vetoed</em></li>
	<li>HB 1102 (Energize Pennsylvania package: KEEZ/Keystone Energy Enhancement Zones for petrochemicals).</li>
	<li>HB 1392/SB 845 (punitive fees on electric vehicle owners)</li>
	<li>SB 716/717 (Natural Gas development on state lands)</li>
</ul>

<p>In terms of raiding environmental protection &amp; conservation in the state&rsquo;s budgets and special funds, PennFuture and partners killed a number of dangerous bills in the General Assembly, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>HB 1822 (Putting a freeze on spending out of several environmental special funds)</li>
	<li>HB 1988 (Placing environmental special funds into the state&rsquo;s General Fund)</li>
	<li>HB 2004 (Gives the General Assembly control to allocate funds from special funds)</li>
	<li>SB 1034 (Amending fiscal code to include &ldquo;grant management&nbsp;oversight&rdquo;)</li>
</ul>

<p><u><strong>Offensive Victories:</strong></u></p>

<p>Unfortunately, Harrisburg has offered up few bright spots in terms of legislative&nbsp;offensive victories that are pro-environment during this last two-year legislative session, but state lawmakers did a few, great things:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Creation of new, innovative &ldquo;Pennsylvania Farm Bill&rdquo; that elevates agricultural conservation work</li>
	<li>Allocated $3M for REAP (Resource Enhancement and Protection Tax Credit)</li>
	<li>Allocated $2M for the Conservation Excellence program at the PA Department of Agriculture</li>
</ul>

<p><u><strong>Challenges:</strong></u></p>

<p>A few terrible pieces of legislation passed through the General Assembly and secured the Governor&rsquo;s signature this year, mostly via nefarious policy riders to the fiscal codes of budget packages&nbsp;that PennFuture and partners will continue to fight back against, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>HB 732 (petrochemical subsidy to the tune of $670M over 26 years to 4 petrochemical plants)</li>
	<li>HB 2536 (waste coal subsidy by &lsquo;closing the borders&rsquo; for Tier II of AEPS)</li>
	<li>2019&rsquo;s fiscal code (waste coal subsidy for $200M)</li>
	<li>HB 1103 (building out state&rsquo;s PIPE program, increased gas infrastructure)</li>
	<li>Repeal of data reporting requirements outlined by Act 54 for mining operations in the recent 2021 state budget package&rsquo;s fiscal code (former SB 763)</li>
	<li>Termination of Joint Legislative Conservation Commission (JLCC) at the end of 2021 in 2019-2020FY budget</li>
	<li>HB 1808 (promotion of plastics/petrochemicals as &lsquo;recycling&rsquo;)</li>
</ul>

<p><u><strong>What Legislation We Expect to See Next Session (2021-22):</strong></u></p>

<p>Several beneficial bills advancing clean energy, environmental protection and conservation have failed to pass this session, but we will continue to advocate for them next year alongside partners. Here&rsquo;s what to look for in the coming months in terms of the work ahead:</p>

<p><em>Advancing Clean &amp; Renewable Energy</em></p>

<ul>
	<li>Moving forward the DEP&rsquo;s &ldquo;Carbon Trading Program&rdquo; through the regulatory process</li>
	<li>Establishing&nbsp;carbon Cap &amp; Invest programs in Pennsylvania (formerly SB 15/ HB 2586)</li>
	<li>Passing Community Solar legislation (formerly HB 531/SB 705)</li>
	<li>Expanding &amp; modernizing the Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards (AEPS, formerly SB 600/ HB 1195)</li>
	<li>Enacting legislation increasing buildout of infrastructure for electric vehicles (formerly SB 596)</li>
</ul>

<p><em>Advancing Environmental Protections &amp; Holding Polluters Accountable</em></p>

<ul>
	<li>Closing loopholes on hydraulic fracturing waste (cosponsor memoranda out now from Sen. Muth &amp; Rep. Innamorato)</li>
	<li>Passing legislation implementing recommendations from Attorney General Shapiro&rsquo;s 2020 report on environmental crimes by polluters in hydraulic fracturing</li>
</ul>

<p><em>Advancing Clean Water Legislation</em></p>

<ul>
	<li>Setting increased training &amp; application requirements for fertilizer (formerly SB 915)</li>
	<li>Passing the &ldquo;Agriculture Conservation Assistance Program&rdquo; (ACAP - formerly SB 1272), which would give much-needed support to farmers to implement best management practices and conservation work to improve water quality</li>
</ul>

<p><em>Advancing Equity and Funding for Green Stimulus &amp; Recovery</em></p>

<ul>
	<li>Advocating that Gov. Wolf is bold in his budget address in early February and advocating for an equitable budget as it moves through the General Assembly this Spring, a continuation of PennFuture&rsquo;s &ldquo;Green Stimulus &amp; Recovery&rdquo; work</li>
	<li>Working with frontline community advocates to pass legislation establishing an &ldquo;Office of Just Transition&rdquo; and legislation giving more teeth to the PA DEP&rsquo;s Office of Environmental Justice coupled with increased interagency coordination and review of justice concerns</li>
</ul>

<p>PennFuture and partners in the environmental and conservation community will again be busy in defensive work. 2021 is setting up to be a year of more hope and opportunity, but many of the same legislative themes will persist. Pennsylvania legislators will likely take yet another crack at &ldquo;Regulatory Reform&rdquo; legislation such as the &ldquo;Office of the Repealer&rdquo; bill, more legislation attempting to eviscerate the Commonwealth&rsquo;s Clean Streams Law, and more fossil fuel subsidies like the&nbsp;recent waste coal giveaways and the behemoth gifts to the petrochemical industry outlined in the Energize Pennsylvania&nbsp;plan.</p>

<p>What&rsquo;s more, we&rsquo;re likely to continue playing defense against austere and draconian budget cuts to our agencies and dedicated funds for environmental protection and conservation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>For now, the Pennsylvania House of Representatives and State Senate will return to Harrisburg on January 5th to swear-in new Members of the General Assembly, but the two legislative bodies will likely not be back in full swing (and voting session) until mid-late January. Very soon thereafter, Governor Wolf will introduce his proposed state budget for the 2021-22 fiscal year and agency budget hearings for the Appropriations Committees will begin their work in earnest.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We will continue to advocate for a clean and responsible state budget, track and advance legislation that protects our environment, act&nbsp;on climate, and we will defend against any attacks on our Commonwealth&rsquo;s crucial clean air, water, and natural resource protections.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
More Challenges Knocking on Dimock’s Door,12/8/2020,"<p>Dimock has long played the unwelcomed role of ground zero in the fracking crisis in Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>Early on during the fracking boom, this quiet, rural township in Susquehanna County became notorious for explosive water wells, toxic tap water, and aquatic dead zones in its wetlands.<br />
Today more challenges are knocking on Dimock&rsquo;s door.</p>

<p>News reports suggest Dimock may serve as the location for Eastern Pennsylvania&rsquo;s first deep injection fracking well. Although a formal injection well application has yet to be submitted to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, residents located within 1,000 feet of the planned well received letters notifying them of project plans.</p>

<p>An EPA spokesperson <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2020/11/25/dimock-residents-worry-about-planned-fracking-waste-well/"">told StateImpact PA</a> that representatives of Kendra II, a fracking logistics firm based just south of Dimock, met with agency officials this fall to discuss plans for the injection well.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Residents are rightfully concerned about the threat to their properties, health, and safety.</p>

<p>Although not directly connected to the potential Kendra II injection well, a history of irresponsible drilling practices has literally poisoned the drinking water wells in Dimock. Attorney General Josh Shapiro recently announced charges against major fracking operator Cabot Oil &amp; Gas for alleged criminal violations of the Clean Streams Law.</p>

<p>Almost 15 years have passed since Cabot started to develop dozens of private gas wells within a nine-square-mile area around Dimock. Since then, poisonous chemicals have been discovered in 27 private wells, and explosive levels of methane have been detected in 17.</p>

<p>A Department of Environmental Protection investigation resulted in a restriction on Cabot gas operations around the town, known as the Dimock box, as well as a plan to restore water supplies. Unfortunately, it took Cabot nearly a decade to begin gas well remediation. Many violations remain unresolved today.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Kendra II injection well would introduce a new set of challenges.</p>

<p>About a dozen deep injection wells are currently permitted in Pennsylvania, but Ohio currently bares most of the brunt. Rising transportation and disposal costs are, however, leading the industry to push for more wells to be located in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Deep injection wells can extend more than a mile underground. The injection process sends a combination of salty brine, hazardous chemicals, radioactive waste, and heavy metals into belowground formations.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This process has proved to be just about as reckless as it sounds. Hazardous wastewater disposed of in injection wells has been known to migrate and contaminate the drinking water of nearby residents. And the impacts do not stop there. Earthquakes associated with injection wells are popping up in Ohio, Oklahoma, and the Dakotas, at times shaking residents hundreds of miles away.</p>

<p>Dimock already knows well the risks posed by the fracking industry. Even the most well-intentioned fracking companies operate with risks that, any day, chemical waste could unintentionally spill or leak. These risks to local drinking water, combined with the possibility that fracking operations could result in earthquakes throughout the Susquehanna Valley, offer plenty of reasons to oppose the Kendra II wastewater injection well.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Dimock has already suffered enough.</p>

<p>PennFuture will be watching this situation closely as it unfolds, and we will be sure to keep the public informed in the months ahead.</p>
",Community; Energy; Environment,"Emily Persico, Policy Analyst"
PennFuture Releases Blueprint to Protect Pennsylvania's Lake Erie Watershed,12/3/2020,"<p>Today, PennFuture&rsquo;s Erie office&nbsp;publicly released <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/ErieCommonAgenda_6.pdf"">Our Water, Our Future: A Common Agenda for Protecting Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Lake Erie Watershed.</a></p>

<p>This comprehensive document describes the major threats to Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Lake Erie watershed and recommends several solutions to those threats. The Erie region relies heavily on its water resources to attract people to live, work, and play in Erie County. However, the use of those resources and development decisions that are made can lead to their eventual degradation. This Agenda recommends many ways that Erie&rsquo;s decision makers can develop in an equitable, sustainable way, while continuing to benefit from its abundant water resources.</p>

<p>This Agenda was developed by convening local and regional environmental, wildlife, and civic organizations. Twelve partner organizations signed on to the Agenda but at least ten more were engaged in the process of developing it. We met several times via Zoom throughout Summer 2020 to identify threats, prioritize them based on their impacts to human health, the natural environment, and the economy, and brainstorm solutions. A technical advisory committee of non-governmental organizations and several regional scientists was engaged to ensure that the document was technically sound and well-informed. We also sought to ensure that the document made a strong call for racial equity and inclusion, made even more important by Erie County&rsquo;s declaration that <a href=""http://public.eriecountypa.gov/councildocs/resolutions/2020-43.pdf"">racism is a public health crisis.</a></p>

<p>Three organizations acted as social justice consultants by reviewing the Agenda and making recommendations for strengthening the message of equity and inclusion in decision making. The result of these collaborative efforts is a forward-thinking agenda calling for local, county, state, and federal policies that protect our vitally important water resources and promote sustainable development that will improve quality of life for all current and future Erie County residents.</p>

<p>The water quality threats that Common Agenda partners identified are surface runoff including stormwater, agricultural runoff, and sewage, climate change, fossil fuels and plastic pollution, invasive species, and legacy pollution. While the solutions to these threats vary, they all require that municipalities and Erie County embrace the responsibility of being communities on the Great Lakes. This will not only lead to better protected water and healthy communities, it can also stoke the flames of a blue economy in the region.</p>

<p>Among the recommendations are calls to improve collaboration and communication throughout decision-making processes. The social unrest that Erie and the nation have experienced calls everyone to develop new ways of doing things that will not perpetuate persistent inequities and injustice. This agenda invites regional residents, businesses, and government leaders to use the issue of water protection to develop county and municipal level committees that increase resident engagement in decision making. For example, it recommends that Erie County Council establish an Environmental Justice Committee that monitors and responds to disproportionate impacts of pollution on historically burdened residents.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Erie region is rich in water resources and its current revitalization efforts have relied heavily upon that premise. However, this revitalization will be short lived if it fails to protect these assets and water quality declines. The region needs sustainable transformational change that can only be achieved through inclusive collaboration, equitable decision making, and policies and practices that protect natural resources. This agenda provides a blueprint for all three of these necessities.</p>

<p>PennFuture and its partners will move this agenda forward by meeting with regional stakeholders and government officials to discuss water protection policies and practices and advocate for more inclusive decision-making processes. These collaborative efforts will bring new and important voices to the table and add value to the region&rsquo;s revitalization efforts.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture and our partner organizations are very proud of this document, and we hope you will take some time to read it <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/ErieCommonAgenda_6.pdf"">by clicking here</a>. You can also <a href=""https://us02web.zoom.us/rec/share/O3mkeaysIt9w6AnuHYr5Xq_Kk-yjQ-fCg74-KOAjbfUBGgiUrscoaBN-lum86kHW.6m-mVMSjwk6eJ-no"">click here to watch a recording</a> of the virtual press conference held on Dec. 3 to unveil the Agenda.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,"Sarah Bennett, Campaign Manager for Clean Water Advocacy"
Building the United States' Green Economy Future through Appalachia,12/2/2020,"<p>When I returned to environmental work in Pennsylvania in 2015, after five years working in Maryland for the Audubon Society, I was struck by how much the fracked gas industry&rsquo;s influence was able to dominate policy and policymakers here in the Commonwealth. The firm grip the coal industry had on the legislature for nearly a hundred years had been supplanted by frackers.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Lobbying became a growth industry. New government relations and PR firms occupy Harrisburg offices and real estate, all to help out with the influence peddling and promotion of friendly legislation the industry would need to optimize gas in the Marcellus and Utica shales, and turn it into profits. Regulation was at best weak&mdash;Act 13 left a lot of loopholes and wiggle room for industry to pollute. And the state budget allocations that our regulatory agencies need as their lifeblood to provide oversight of this polluting and secretive industry were squeezed to a drip&mdash;a circumstance our legislature continues today.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>With few exceptions, this industry and its political machine has maintained a stranglehold on many elected officials. The industry&rsquo;s playbook disburses campaign contributions throughout the state regardless if a legislative district contains gas, because in Harrisburg, sometimes, every vote counts.&nbsp;Just as dangerous, the frackers&rsquo; public relations firms spin out jobs numbers and promises that any legislator or work-hungry labor union ignored at their peril. The industry created a near unsurmountable ring of self-interest.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s just a fact of life for us that PennFuture&rsquo;s energies are spent defending the environmental protections we fought hard to win in the past. We fight legislative attacks on industry regulations session after session, year after year, and sometimes multiple, identical attacks in any given time period. It became evident to me back then&nbsp;that we&rsquo;d be fighting in the legislature for a few more years at best. The majority of our state legislators embrace the status quo.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The people&rsquo;s house in Harrisburg cannot be relied upon for leadership to transition away from fracked gas, a transition that must happen if we are to reckon with our climate, race, economic and public health crises&nbsp;that are all crashing into each other at the moment.</p>

<p>When I became president of PennFuture, I felt strongly that one of the most important proactive things that needed to happen if this state is to ever break away from the grips of fossil fuels, fracking, petrochemical and plastics was the creation of an alternative economic development and job creation strategy for our state. It was incorporated into our strategic plan, but the question remained about the suitability of an environmental policy and advocacy shop like PennFuture to tackle this. We kept talking it up, particularly to our funders, and to potential partners who also occupied the policy space but with more substantial chops in economics.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The looming build-out of the so-called Appalachian Storage Hub in the Upper Ohio River Valley&nbsp;became a catalyst for concerned groups from Pennsylvania, Ohio, West Virginia, and Kentucky to talk about defending our region from it. Eventually that talk turned to offense and the urgent need to develop an alternative economic and jobs strategy. That economic and jobs blueprint is now encompassed by the campaign called <a href=""https://reimagineappalachia.org/"">Reimagine Appalachia</a>, in which PennFuture participates.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Reimagine Appalachia has produced the vision and economic substantiation to turn the region into a nexus for investments that create a regional economy that is sustainable and adapted to the realities of climate change.&nbsp;Characterized by modernizing infrastructure, greening manufacturing, restoring and managing lands decimated by legacy pollution into wide swaths of carbon storing acreage, and by jobs programs that can employ a diversity of people currently finding working difficult due to a variety of factors, this platform will produce 250,000 jobs in Pennsylvania alone.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>This past spring, PennFuture staff, who were veterans of the 2008 recession and well-acquainted with the stimulus investments that were made to get a faltering country back on its feet, issued our <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Green-Stimulus-FINAL.pdf"">Green Stimulus and Economic Recovery Platform for Pennsylvania</a>. We were able to leverage our knowledge about the inherent strengths of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s economy that were not linked to fossil fuels and put forth investment ideas for those sectors. Bolstering the strength of what we refer to as nature-based economic sectors, such as outdoor recreation and agriculture, and the network of small businesses that support these sectors, PennFuture argues for targeted investments to bridge the impacts of the pandemic and diversify the state economy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Like Reimagine Appalachia&rsquo;s platform, we see real opportunities in a green jobs program. We see jobs to restore land and water impacted by not only past pollution, but jobs installing projects that the state is relying on to meet water pollution reduction requirements, and that are in need of funding that stimulus funds can provide. Our Green Stimulus proposals call for investments in bold clean energy projects as well as energy efficiency retrofits for residences and businesses.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In total, through $2.83 billion in annual investments for the duration of the pandemic and the recession it&rsquo;s caused, we estimate the state will preserve or create over 389,000 jobs. Additional economic benefits would come from embracing recommendations on growing and transitioning to a clean energy economy, similar to the aspirations of Reimagine Appalachia.</p>

<p>Another exciting breakthrough came just last week when mayors of eight leading cities in the Ohio River Valley&mdash;the identical geography of Reimagine Appalachia&mdash;including Pittsburgh Mayor Bill Peduto, issued a <a href=""https://www.sustainablebusiness.pitt.edu/sites/default/files/mp4ma_roadmap_-_final_1.pdf"">Marshall Plan for Middle America.</a> The plan deftly proposes to position the region for national and international competitiveness, and at the same time addresses regional economic and other disparities, by transitioning into a center for renewable energy infrastructure, and manufacturing and infrastructure innovations, among other proposals.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>And so this politically influential region has emerged from the weight of 2020 and has articulated through these three documents a similarity of vision, intention, and determination of where this region wants to go, and must go. And while these are intended as roadmaps for a region, and one that too often has been left behind, therein are opportunities and ideas for the nation. But our climate justice and clean energy future must begin here in Appalachia, whose people, land and water have paid a dear price for powering the nation and world for almost two hundred years.</p>

<p>Finally, the alternative vision that can make a difference.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
"PA General Assembly Wraps Up Annual Budget, Punts on Stimulus",11/25/2020,"<p>Last week, the Pennsylvania General Assembly hammered out the final pieces of this year&rsquo;s state budget, which began in late May when the Legislature passed a five-month stopgap budget package. On a bipartisan basis, the Legislature passed the budget bill (SB 1350) and the fiscal code bill (HB 2536) and the Governor signed the legislation into law Monday. For a number of reasons, the package was very problematic and PennFuture urged opposition to both bills during their consideration by the General Assembly.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Not only did the Legislature not act on completing the budget without cutting environmental and conservation funds, it sorely missed the mark on making key investments in recovery and protecting Pennsylvanians during the ongoing pandemic.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Senate Bill 1350 (Browne) - 2020-21FY Supplemental State Budget:</strong></u><br />
House vote: 104Y-97N<br />
Senate vote: 31Y-18N</p>

<p>While most of the environmental protection and conservation budget lines were approved with flat-funded appropriations from the 2019-20FY levels, a number of accounts do take significant hits. We understand that this year&rsquo;s budget is difficult given the roughly $5B structural deficit coupled with the hole caused by the pandemic-induced recession, but flat-funding our agencies is still felt as a &ldquo;cut&rdquo; due to being less than the &ldquo;cost to carry.&rdquo;</p>

<ul>
	<li>For instance, this year&rsquo;s budget approves a 100% ($1,000) cut to the &ldquo;Great Lakes Restoration&rdquo; effort as a part of the PA Department of Conservation &amp; Natural Resources budget.</li>
	<li>Additionally, 38.5% of the account for &ldquo;Forest Management &amp; Processing&rdquo; ($2.5M) and most concerningly, almost 2% of the line for &ldquo;State Parks Operations&rdquo; ($985,000) was cut.</li>
</ul>

<p>Though the need is overwhelming and advocates have been pushing for increased funding for many years, the water and river basin commissions again take big cuts. With this final budget package (FY2020-21) they are funded at:</p>

<ul>
	<li>$127,000 for the Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC)</li>
	<li>$119,000 for the Susquehanna River Basin Commission (SRBC)</li>
	<li>$13,000 for the Interstate Commission on the Potomac River Basin (ICPRB)</li>
	<li>$40,000 for the Ohio River Valley Water Sanitation Commission (ORSANCO) &amp;</li>
	<li>$175,000 for the Chesapeake Bay Commission.</li>
</ul>

<p>Long a legislative interest and sought after place to raid funding to plug other budget holes, the special, dedicated environmental and conservation funds were once again targeted. Though the Recycling Fund was gutted to the tune of $50M (nearly 50% of its total appropriation) and the Agricultural Conservation Easement Purchase Fund was hit, <strong>PennFuture, along with partners in the environmental and conservation community, saved the Environmental Stewardship Fund (Growing Greener) and Keystone Recreations, Parks, and Conservation Fund.&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p><u><strong>A Closer Look at the Agencies&rsquo; Funding Levels via SB 1350:</strong></u></p>

<p><strong>Department of Environmental Protection</strong><br />
General Government Operations: $8,729,000<br />
Environmental Program Mgmt.: $18, 452,000<br />
Chesapeake Bay Agricultural Source Abatement: $1,696,000<br />
Environmental Protection Operations: $54,215,000</p>

<p><strong>Department of Conservation &amp; Natural Resources</strong><br />
General Government Operations: $15,657,000<br />
State Parks Operations: $27,050,000<br />
State Forests Operations: $25,708,000<br />
State Heritage &amp; Other Parks: $2,487,000<br />
Park &amp; Forest Infrastructure Projects: $525,000</p>

<p><strong>What about code bills?&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>In addition to the appropriations bill and special fund shenanigans, the General Assembly often passes associated &ldquo;code bills&rdquo; that implement the budget across different areas. These code bills are often used to move nefarious pieces of legislation that, by themselves, wouldn&rsquo;t make it through the legislature. This fall, the legislature has only passed a fiscal code bill to accompany the budget bill. HB 2536 does hold a few problems and bad policy riders. Because of these, PennFuture urged opposition to the fiscal code.</p>

<p><u><strong>House Bill 2536 (James) - Fiscal Code:</strong></u><br />
House vote: 108Y-92N<br />
Senate vote: 33Y-16N</p>

<p><strong>Closing the Borders of Tier II in Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards (AEPS)</strong></p>

<p>HB 2536 included language similar to the proposed SB1305 (Argall) that would close the &lsquo;borders&rsquo; for Tier II of the Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards (AEPS). This language is identical to legislation from 2017 that would close the &lsquo;borders&rsquo; for solar energy in the Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards to help level the playing field for renewable energy and incentivize growth of the renewable energy industry in Pennsylvania, increasing the solar providers in the state. This provision slipped into the fiscal code bill is a giveaway to polluting waste-coal, which could lead to more burning of the coal refuse, dirtying Pennsylvania&rsquo;s air. It is yet another fossil fuel subsidy that the legislature has a storied history of doing so.</p>

<p><strong>Repeal of Act 54 Report</strong></p>

<p>HB 2536 also includes language that hamstrings the Department of Environmental Protection&rsquo;s ability to spend monies and collect fees and penalties as put forth by reporting requirements in Act 54 of 1966, known as the Bituminous Mine Subsidence and Land Conservation Act. This will allow more companies in the mining industry to go without meeting accountability measures set by environmental legislation in the Commonwealth in the 1960s. We must keep these measures in place so that we do not add harm to the historical degradation and legacy pollution from the coal industry in Pennsylvania. No more orange water, acid mine drainage, dewatered streams, and abandoned mine lands. The industry must pay to clean up their own messes and the PA DEP must be well situated to act as the chief regulator and protector of our natural resources.</p>

<p><strong>Next Steps</strong><br />
For many of the issues impacting Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment, the costs will only continue to increase the longer they go unabated. State budgets are the ultimate reflection of policy making priorities. Our state priorities are far out of order and need to be changed before the problems become intractable and the harm to our citizens grows more severe.</p>

<p>This fall, the state legislature and elected representatives in Washington balked at passing much-needed, further COVID relief to state and local governments. Where stimulus and recovery monies and large-scale efforts would have proved helpful, we now wait to see what the next administration, 117th Congress and new Pennsylvania General Assembly can accomplish in terms of stimulus and recovery.</p>

<p>PennFuture stands ready to urge lawmakers to make significant investments in green stimulus and recovery including making whole our environmental protection and conservation agencies, new money for supporting nature-based jobs, sustainable agriculture and small food producers, revamping our water infrastructure, significant build-outs in energy efficiency and renewable energy, and more. We will also endeavor to make sure Pennsylvania&rsquo;s stimulus and recovery initiatives are equitable and well serve all Pennsylvanians no matter their station.</p>

<p>We&rsquo;ve reached the end of this 2019-2020 legislative session in Harrisburg, but we are excited for the next chapter to begin soon. We&rsquo;ll continue to push forward good environmental and clean energy legislation and fight back against anti-environmental bills that are sure to come our way. We&rsquo;ll also keep fighting for a restored budget for our critical agencies. Be on the lookout for a legislative session wrap-up blog coming soon to break down what bills didn&rsquo;t make it across the finish line, which bad bills we&rsquo;ve vanquished, and what bills (good and bad) we&rsquo;re likely to see again in the new session.</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
Confronting Reality: Pennsylvania Leaders Refuse to Acknowledge State of Petrochemical Industry,11/23/2020,"<p>In the United States&mdash;<o:p></o:p>the biggest fossil fuel producer in the world&mdash;Pennsylvania is second in shale gas production only to Texas. But even Texas is willing to admit something that many Pennsylvania leaders continue to deny: The shale gas and petrochemical industry is dying.</p>

<p>The latest evidence of this came earlier this week when <a href=""https://www.timesleaderonline.com/news/local-news/2020/11/ptt-delays-cracker-investment-decision-again/?fbclid=IwAR0KFIRLK-Oumi8CmONlI7Get-QEUgeCPox-RWpCcJmMZJo7DYiJAOfe4YA"">PTT Global Chemical announced it was indefinitely delaying</a> a final investment decision on a new petrochemical project in southeast Ohio, dealing yet another blow to the <a href=""https://ohiorivervalleyinstitute.org/lies-damned-lies-and-economic-impact-studies/"">so-called Appalachian petrochemical renaissance</a> envisioned by industry leaders and politicians alike. Even the Shell petrochemical plant in Beaver County will face significant hurdles once it begins operation, directly undercutting the economic impact it was originally predicted to have on the local economy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>All this bodes poorly for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s fracked gas industry. Record production has led to an overwhelming oversupply of fracked gas and depressed prices <a href=""https://www.mcall.com/news/pennsylvania/mc-nws-pa-fracking-gas-production-20200916-f36hsugi35a3rgdbijuhdii6ve-story.html"">below the break-even point for much of the past two years.</a> Petrochemical plants, which convert fracked gas to plastics, were meant to gobble up this excess gas and restore prices and profits.</p>

<p>But as plans to deliver on the promised petrochemical buildout come into question, so too has the future of fracked gas in Pennsylvania. Policymakers have tried to patch these unfavorable economics with subsidies and fracked gas-favoring policies, but the billions of taxpayer dollars they&rsquo;ve thrown at the industry has done little to close the gap.</p>

<p>These local examples are mirrored across the world. In a May 2020 article, McKinsey&rsquo;s Houston-based team delivered a sobering analysis to oil and gas proponents, describing the current bust as &ldquo;an unprecedented crisis for the [oil and gas] industry.&rdquo;</p>

<p>The immediate effects are already staggering[...],&rdquo; the authors write. &ldquo;Looking out beyond today&rsquo;s crisis toward the late 2030s, the macro-environment is set to become even more challenging.&rdquo;<br />
In fact, as Pennsylvania continues to ignore the signs of industry collapse, others in Houston are joining McKinsey in a more honest dissection of the harsh economic realities of the failing oil and gas industry. So, in the words of reporters at the Houston Chronicle, in the heartland of oil and gas, I share with you the following:</p>

<p>From a November 18 article by Paul Takahashi titled <a href=""https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/Oil-bankruptcies-rise-in-the-third-quarter-15736171.php?utm_source=newsletter&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_campaign=Chron_FuelFix&amp;utm_term=business&amp;utm_content=briefing&amp;stn=nf&amp;sid=5f11e83b7afa2729ae52e362"">&ldquo;Oil bankruptcies rise in the third quarter:&rdquo;</a></p>

<ul>
	<li>A new wave of bankruptcies is sweeping the oil and gas industry after the coronavirus pandemic crushed global demand for crude and petroleum products such as gasoline and jet fuel. Unlike past downturns, oil and gas companies are under increased financial pressure after many investors pulled out of the sector in 2018 after years of underperformance.</li>
</ul>

<p>From a November 3 article by Casey Wagner titled <a href=""https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/Energy-s-Plunge-Is-Now-Worst-Among-S-P-Sectors-15698613.php#:~:text=Energy%20has%20been%20the%20worst,since%20the%20start%20of%202020."">&ldquo;Energy&rsquo;s plunge is worst among any S&amp;P sector in nearly a century:&rdquo;</a></p>

<ul>
	<li>In the biggest drop of any sector going back to 1928, energy stocks have lost 60% more value than the S&amp;P 500 Index has, data from Sundial Capital Research show.</li>
</ul>

<p>From an October 22 article by Paul Takahashi titled <a href=""https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/Oil-industry-turns-to-consolidation-to-weather-15665836.php#:~:text=But%20this%20new%20wave%20of,jobs%20in%20recent%20oil%20busts."">&ldquo;The oil industry is consolidating. That&rsquo;s bad news for workers in Houston:&rdquo;</a></p>

<ul>
	<li>This new wave of consolidation will leave behind a smaller industry with fewer players employing fewer workers, analysts say.</li>
</ul>

<p>From an October 15 article by Kevin Crowley titled <a href=""https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/U-S-Oil-Production-Has-Already-Passed-Its-Peak-15649557.php"">&ldquo;U.S. oil production already passed its peak, Occidental says:&rdquo;</a></p>

<ul>
	<li>Shale&rsquo;s debt-fueled expansion came to a juddering halt due to lower gasoline demand and oil prices, but also because of Wall Street&rsquo;s increasing reluctance to fund growth at any cost.</li>
</ul>

<p>From an October 14 article by James Osborne and Paul Takahashi titled <a href=""https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/Houston-oil-and-gas-industry-not-out-of-the-woods-15645577.php"">&ldquo;Why Houston&rsquo;s oil and gas industry &lsquo;is not out of the woods yet:&rsquo;&rdquo;</a></p>

<ul>
	<li>The International Energy Agency warned Tuesday that global energy demand will not recover to pre-pandemic levels until at least 2023 and possibly 2025, setting the oil and gas industry on its lowest growth rate since the 1930s.</li>
</ul>

<p>From a September 30 article by Paul Takahashi titled <a href=""https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/Shell-to-Cut-Up-to-9-000-Jobs-as-Virus-Forces-15608330.php#:~:text=The%20Netherlands%2Dbased%20oil%20and,layoffs%20are%20planned%20in%20Houston."">&ldquo;Shell to cut up to 9,000 jobs as virus accelerates overhaul:&rdquo;</a></p>

<ul>
	<li>Oil companies also are reorganizing their businesses and laying off thousands of employees to prepare for a future with fewer fossil fuels. BP plans to lay off 10,000 workers and Chevron plans to lay off 6,000 workers by the end of the year. Exxon, the Irving-based oil giant, said it does not have layoff plans, but has changed its performance review process to be more stringent.</li>
</ul>

<p>From a September 15 article by James Osborne titled <a href=""https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/As-pipeline-projects-cancel-future-falls-into-15567085.php"">&ldquo;As pipeline projects cancel, future falls into question:&rdquo;</a></p>

<ul>
	<li>For years, a small clique of investors has questioned the logic of putting money into oil and gas pipelines that take decades to pay off when climate change policy was pushing the energy sector away from fossil fuels. Banks and other institutions, however, largely continued to finance the multibillion-dollar projects, confident in projections by oil and gas companies that the so-called energy transition would take time and oil and natural gas would be needed for decades to come. But a rash of cancellations and delays of new pipelines, largely brought on by the coronavirus pandemic, raises questions of whether those skeptics&rsquo; warnings are starting to catch on and the cancellations reflect a newfound wariness among banks to back the projects in view of an uncertain future for fossil fuels.</li>
</ul>

<p>From a July 30 article by Paul Takahashi titled <a href=""https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/Oil-and-gas-employment-forecast-to-bottom-out-15446433.php"">&ldquo;Oil and gas production jobs in Texas could hit bottom this fall:&rdquo;</a></p>

<ul>
	<li>The oil and gas industry was contracting well before the coronavirus pandemic broke out in the U.S. and brought the economy to a screeching halt. Employment in oil and gas production, including oil-field services jobs, was recovering from the previous downturn of 2014-16, climbing back to 228,500 jobs in December 2018, the alliance said. But then, Wall Street investment soured on the sector after years of underperformance, and the number of operating rigs and employment fell throughout 2019.</li>
</ul>

<p>As these excerpts show, Texas is confronting a reality that Pennsylvania leaders&mdash;from journalists, to state and local representatives, to the industry itself&mdash;continue to deny. COVID-19 has accelerated a shift that was long underway: the phasing out of the oil and gas industry, as well as associated infrastructure including pipelines, refineries, and petrochemical complexes.</p>

<p>This is not short-term conjecture but a long-term reality based on industry underperformance, insurmountable debt, commodity oversupply, and a souring attitude to fossil fuels from investors and global regulators. Anyone who fails to disclose this reality is not telling you the full truth.</p>

<p>Despite all this, the favoritism we continue to show for shale gas in Pennsylvania is astounding: Billions of dollars in tax credits, exemptions from critical public health and environmental protections, and a deafening silence on the industry&rsquo;s economic failures, let alone it&rsquo;s failures to public health, the environment, and our climate.</p>

<p>A few weeks ago, independent climate journalist Emily Atkin <a href=""https://heated.world/p/climate-news-trump-can-use-corrected"">reported on the failure of national election coverage</a> to include the cost of doing nothing on climate change. When it comes to climate change and to the failing economics of the fossil fuel industry, these silences are not politically neutral, but instead uphold a status quo that is already leading to catastrophic climate impacts.</p>

<p>To report, to regulate, to understand these issues, we must first be able to admit the truth. Only then will we be able to recognize how we are propping up a dangerous and failing industry.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Emily Persico, Policy Analyst"
PennFuture Intervenes to Support FERC Jurisdiction over Wyalusing LNG Facility,11/3/2020,"<p>PennFuture recently joined with the Sierra Club in moving to intervene in and protesting the petition to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (&ldquo;FERC&rdquo;) by the owner/operator of the Wyalusing LNG facility, seeking an order by FERC that the agency does not have jurisdiction to review and regulate the facility&#39;s&nbsp;construction and operation under the federal Natural Gas Act (&ldquo;NGA&rdquo;).</p>

<p>Over the past year, PennFuture has been engaged with local community members and organizations in tracking and opposing this liquified natural gas (&ldquo;LNG&rdquo;) facility on the Susquehanna River and the transport of LNG by rail or truck across our communities to the export facility in Gibbstown, NJ on the banks of the Delaware River.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To be sure, the Wyalusing facility&rsquo;s operations are speculative and untested, and the ramifications of the operations of the project (including the proposed transport in &ldquo;bomb trains&rdquo;) could be devastating to Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment and the health and safety of our communities, including environmental justice communities. The safety of this proposed LNG project is unknown; the environmental impacts of this LNG project are unknown; whether this LNG project is required by public convenience and necessity is unknown.</p>

<p>To learn more about LNG, its dangers, and the Wyalusing facility, please check out our LNG Blog Series: <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-Series-1-What-is-Liquefied-Natural-Gas"">LNG Blog #1</a>, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-2-Bomb-Trains-Through-Pennsylvania"">LNG Blog #2</a>, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-3-Protect-Northern-PA"">LNG Blog #3</a>, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-4-Liquified-Natural-Gas-Should-Not-Become-the-New-Bomb-Trains-to-Threaten-Our-Communities"">LNG Blog #4</a>, and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-5-Public-opposition-grows-to-proposed-LNG-shipping-terminals"">LNG Blog #5</a>.</p>

<p>In our protest to FERC, PennFuture argued that FERC has jurisdiction under both Section 3 and Article 7 of the NGA. First, the Wyalusing LNG facility is a &ldquo;LNG terminal&rdquo; subject to FERC&rsquo;s jurisdiction under Section 3 of the NGA. Second, the facility is transporting gas in interstate commerce as well as exporting gas in foreign commerce and so is subject to FERC&rsquo;s jurisdiction under Section 7 of the NGA. FERC decision precedent does not argue otherwise, and if FERC were not to exercise jurisdiction it would create an unintended regulatory loophole under the NGA. Moreover, the proposed project is contrary to the public interest. Allowing the Wyalusing LNG facility to evade comprehensive FERC review risks the health of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s communities and environment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our full joint protest and motion to intervene <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/SC-and-PennFuture-Protest-and-Intervention-Mot.pdf"">can be read here</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Intervening in this petition is just the first step in ensuring full federal review, oversight, and enforcement of the Wyalusing LNG facility and connected transport and export processes.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture is working hard to protect our waters, our air, and our communities from the dangers of the petrochemical buildout across Pennsylvania. If you&rsquo;re interested in supporting our fight, <a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">please become a member today!</a></p>
",Community; Energy,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
An Election Day Wish,11/2/2020,"<p>For the past two years now, a good many of the blogs I’ve created land on the importance of voting – do we really need another one? There are a great many crucial and upcoming matters on the near-horizon for PennFuture that we can talk about here. Among them, Pennsylvania will begin hearings soon on joining and shaping the very important climate-pollution-reducing program called <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/opinion/Op-Ed/2019/09/25/Rob-Altenburg-Pennsylvania-should-join-the-Regional-Greenhouse-Gas-Initiative-but-for-the-right-reasons/stories/201909250048"">the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative</a> (RGGI). We also have <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/news/state/2020/10/18/Deadline-looms-to-defuse-Pennsylvania-s-budget-time-bomb/stories/202010160144"">tough state budget conversations</a> coming right around the corner in mid-November. </p>

<p>But nothing has captured the focus of most Pennsylvanians like this election season. Election Day, November 3, 2020, is nearly here.</p>
