<p>Since the lead-up to the primary, this election cycle has been characterized by adapting to new pandemic-induced realities and risks around how we cast our votes. Voters and would-be voters have received straightforward and basic information about new voting and registration formats, but from a bewildering array of sources. Many sources say the same thing but in differing ways. Multiple players and sources can be problematic and feed into another more ugly characteristic of this election, and that is the amount of  unreliable sources, intentional disinformation, subtle undermining, and outright lying to try to discredit voting, this imperfect but still best action we have to participate in our democracy.</p>

<p>We have all walked a very long path to this election. There is excitement, fatigue, anticipation, dread, and a sense of just wanting this election to be over as soon as possible. I must, for the time being, live in a frame of hope and trust that the American people will come through for democracy, for our environment and on the sides of justice, equity and prosperity for all. We must all embrace the likelihood that in order for every vote to be counted, it will take some time, and that means patience on all our parts.</p>

<p>While we wait, let’s reflect on the incredible volunteers, organizations and workers driving this election, on all sides. They are doing everything they can to facilitate access to voting participation. </p>

<p>PennFuture’s Democracy for All team has remained energetic, creative and focused, with their gaze toward communities of color. These communities, who in addition to the strength they are bringing to the Black Lives Matter movement, and in addition to the loss they endure – along with brown communities- as heavily impacted by this pandemic, must now navigate new voting “rules” that rightly create suspicion and distrust.</p>

<p>In the end, if the people come to believe that voting doesn’t matter, our democracy will dissolve, and with it, a key paradigm around which a statewide environmental advocacy organization like PennFuture has been built.  </p>

<p>The outcomes of this election hold high stakes for our environment, and for addressing and ending the injustice and inequity that plague so many of our fellow Pennsylvanians.</p>

<p>So given the possibility for disruption after the election, PennFuture will be weighing its options for engagement, should advocacy be needed. We may find our organization heading back to the courts, or engaging with various elected officials if they become involved in post-election interference, and supporting those that need our assistance. </p>

<p>We will keep you informed through <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/democracyedition"">The Bark</a>, <a href=""https://www.democracyforall-pennfuture.com/"">Democracy for All</a>, and the offerings of our partner <a href=""https://www.conservationpa.org/"">Conservation Voters of PA</a>. And we will be asking for your help in the advocacy we may need to pursue. Until then, stay positive, stay healthy and if you haven’t already, vote!</p>
",Community; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
Green and Complete Streets Programs are Good for Communities and the Environment,10/29/2020,"<p>Last week, the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT) and Philadelphia Streets Department announced they will be funding and installing improvements along Cobbs Creek Parkway, and also initiating a process for a more comprehensive design. This welcomed announcement comes after months of pressure from community residents and <a href=""https://medium.com/@councilmemberjg/west-philadelphia-elected-officials-provide-update-on-cobbs-creek-parkway-pedestrian-safety-efforts-5d70151e7876"">elected leaders Jamie Gauthier, Anthony Hardy Williams, and Joanna McClinton.</a> As part of this new initiative, PennFuture is recommending investments in green and complete streets to address decades of neglect including the environmental injustices of the urban heat island effect, unequal access to green space, and stormwater pollution.</p>

<p>Cobbs Creek Parkway is located on the border of West and Southwest Philadelphia and is a main traffic corridor for the city. In August, the intersection of Cobbs Creek and Catherine Street was the site of the tragic and preventable death of 25-year-old Avante Reynolds, who left behind a 2-month old son. Her death has renewed calls for action to address the safety of the busy highway. Investing in a green and complete streets design of Cobbs Creek Parkway can increase safety, improve the environment, and address inequity in Philadelphia’s neighborhoods. </p>

<p>This hit and run along Cobbs Creek Parkway is not an isolated incident, as there have been 155 crashes there between 2012 and 2016. Residents have lobbied the city and state for decades to invest in safety improvements, but in the end only got small changes. One of the reasons, residents acknowledge, for the lack of investment <a href=""https://whyy.org/episodes/how-racism-fueled/"">is structural racism</a>. The 12-mile long Parkway sits between the Cobbs Creek Park - a park where communities play and recreate, and on the edge of one of Philadelphia’s largest Black neighborhoods that was subject to 20th century redlining. Last month <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-How-a-clean-water-program-is-addressing-equity-in-Philadelphia"">I blogged about how redlining in Philadelphia</a> caused environmental injustices, particularly for Black communities, and how PennFuture is working to address some of the harms. </p>

<p>One way we’re working to address some of those harms is through our <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/keep-philly-green"">Keep Philly Green & Water Clean Campaign in Philadelphia</a>, which is aimed at supporting the Green City, Clean Waters program - Philadelphia’s Combined Sewer Overflow Long Term Control Plan Update. The program relies primarily on green stormwater infrastructure to reduce combined sewer overflows. The 25 year plan aims to construct 10,000 greened acres using green stormwater infrastructure tools like rain gardens, tree trenches, and curbed bumpouts. Green stormwater infrastructure refers to a nature-based solution to water quality issues that urban stormwater runoff causes and provides greater benefits than conventional stormwater solutions. The plan aims to reduce stormwater pollution from the combined sewer system by 85 percent.  </p>

<p>But rain gardens, tree trenches, and curbed bumpouts do more than just intercept and filter stormwater. They also increase access to green space for Philadelphians, particularly in neighborhoods that were redlined and experienced decades of divestment from city and state agencies. The same neighborhoods that, during hot summer days, experience up to a 22 degree temperature difference because of a phenomenon known as the Urban Heat Island effect. The social, economic, and environmental benefits of green stormwater infrastructure, when combined with other city resources, can increase investments back into historically neglected neighborhoods. </p>

<p>Streets make up about 40 percent of most cities’ impervious surfaces, and streets are more than just pathways for automobiles. In the case of Cobbs Creek Parkway, along with being a major traffic artery through the city, the road is used by cyclists, walkers and joggers, buses and trolley, and neighbors seeking to play and recreate in the park. The Cobbs Creek Community Environmental Education Center located along the parkway features meadows, forest areas, two creeks and a wetland. Cobbs Creek Park is a community resource of basketball courts, picnic tables, and walking trails. It is the home of Cobbs Creek Recreation Center, ballfields, a skating rink, and swimming pool. </p>

<p>But roads have also been used historically to divide communities and prevent particular segments of populations from accessing resources. In Cobbs Creek’s predominantly Black community, the parkway also divides the community from safely accessing this community amenity and green space. The busy street and limited intersections for safe crossing make the road dangerous for neighbors to cross.</p>

<p>In 2009 Mayor Nutter issued an executive order that ensured the City’s streets would be designed, built, and maintained as <a href=""https://www.philadelphiastreets.com/complete-streets/"">“Complete Streets”</a>. What this means is that the City’s streets would accommodate “all users of the transportation system, be they pedestrians, bicyclists, public transit users, or motor vehicle drivers.” The <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/media/20170914173121/Complete-Streets-Design-Handbook-2017.pdf"">Complete Streets Design Handbook</a> includes traffic and pedestrian accommodating elements as well as urban design tools like green stormwater infrastructure. Green infrastructure used in Complete Streets design can act as a traffic calming measure and community beautification tool that also makes the streets greener and safer for pedestrians and reduces stormwater pollution.</p>

<p>One example of this type of Complete Streets design is a green stormwater infrastructure project at <a href=""http://water.phila.gov/blog/berks-sedgley-ribbon-cutting"">Berks Street and Sedgley Avenue</a> in the neighborhood of Strawberry Mansion. The Water Department recently installed a scope of GSI elements, including a rain garden, subsurface trench, tree trenches and planters. But the construction was also able to include a number of safety improvements to reshape the infrastructure, <a href=""https://whyy.org/articles/rain-garden-in-strawberry-mansion-holds-water-and-makes-students-safer/"">providing a safer, more beautiful route</a> for students who frequent the intersection on their way to school and the nearby park. New pedestrian crosswalks, additional parking, and upgrades to ADA ramps were all part of the system’s construction. The project also included <a href=""http://water.phila.gov/blog/everything-about-water-strawberry-mansion"">community participation and engagement</a> that allows residents to offer feedback. </p>

<p>The Philadelphia Water Department has already <a href=""http://water.phila.gov/blog/2019-in-review-part-3"">contributed meaningful significant investments</a> into Cobbs Creek Park. Parts of the Cobbs Creek itself are serviced by combined sewer overflow systems, meaning that when it rains or when snow melts, the runoff combines with household wastewater and the sewers discharge untreated wastewater into the creek. This is the problem that the water department is working to correct through the Green City, Clean Waters program. The green stormwater management tools capture the stormwater before it enters into the sewer systems, filtering the water and reducing the capacity entering the system, ultimately reducing the amount of untreated discharge into nearby waters. </p>

<p>This Spring the water department completed an installation of more than 25 stormwater management tools that collect runoff along Cobbs Creek Parkway from North of Market Street all the way down to Baltimore Avenue. The improvements keep about 372,000 gallons of stormwater out of local sewers during a 1-inch rainstorm. Features include close to 60 new trees, one basin, four bumpouts, 11 infiltration trenches, seven rain gardens and three tree trenches. These green improvements not only benefit the local waterways, but also benefit the community by providing traffic calming improvements, increasing green space, and beautifying the neighborhood.</p>

<p>However, other parts of the parkway are not within the combined sewer overflow area, but do experience significant flooding and stormwater related pollution. Unfortunately, those parts of the creek are outside the scope of the Green City, Clean Waters program. Without the focus of this program, Philadelphia must do more to ensure that all of the community receives similar benefits. The multiple community, pedestrian, vehicular, and environmental concerns require a comprehensive plan.</p>

<p>The announcement from PennDOT of its work to improve this area and consider a comprehensive design process is welcome progress to address the inequities. But the community’s voice must be included in the process to ensure that the improvements benefit not only traffic and stormwater issues, but community health and safety measures. Throughout the process PennFuture will work with residents, state and local agencies, and elected officials to elevate the importance of green and complete streets and bring environmental investments to long neglected communities.</p>
",Community; Environment,Lena Smith
Setting the Record Straight About Fracking in Pennsylvania,10/26/2020,"<p>The issue of fracking in Pennsylvania has taken center stage this election season, with dozens of television news segments, newspaper articles and political commercials dedicated to the topic.&nbsp;With so much media saturation given to it, it should come as no surprise that some basic facts about fracking have been misrepresented, misconstrued or, in some cases, completely fabricated.&nbsp;</p>

<p>For starters, while fracking has become politically toxic on the state and national level, <a href=""https://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/new-poll-shows-majority-of-pennsylvanians-oppose-fracking/Content?oid=17800496"">a majority of Pennsylvania voters actually oppose it</a>. This, as we will see, is no surprise given the mixed economic impact and severe consequences for social impacts, public health, environmental quality, and climate stability.</p>

<p>Nonetheless, fracking has been marketed to legislators and their constituents as an opportunity to turn around the fracked gas bust and create widespread economic opportunities. Part of the marketing ploy involves a consistent misrepresentation of the facts. The number of fracking jobs <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2020/10/09/trump-pounds-fracking-as-a-wedge-issue-in-pa-but-if-its-not-a-top-concern-for-voters-how-much-can-it-help/"">has been wildly inflated</a>, with industry jockeys citing numbers up to 35 times those provided by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.</p>

<p>So let&rsquo;s get the records straight: The industry employs <a href=""https://www.vox.com/21529260/fracking-biden-trump-2020-presidential-debate-climate-change"">about 24,000 people</a> and contributes <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/opinion/editorials/2020/10/21/An-American-success-story/stories/202009250047"">about $583 million</a> to Pennsylvania&rsquo;s economy annually. To put this number into perspective, there are 10 times as many Pennsylvania jobs <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Publication-A-Green-Stimulus-and-Recovery-Platform-for-Pennsylvania"">in outdoor tourism and recreation</a> with $29.1 billion in economic benefits, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Publication-A-Green-Stimulus-and-Recovery-Platform-for-Pennsylvania"">11 times as many in agriculture</a> with $135.7 billion in economic benefits,&nbsp;and <a href=""https://e2.org/reports/clean-jobs-pennsylvania-2020/"">3 times as many in energy efficiency</a>. To make matters worse, shale gas jobs&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/15/us/for-oil-workers-deadliest-danger-is-driving.html"">are often non-union jobs</a> with modest pay and no health benefits, despite the many occupational hazards that threaten the health and safety of these workers.</p>

<p>What&rsquo;s more, many of the &ldquo;local&rdquo; jobs made available by the fracking industry go either unfilled or are outsourced, with the industry citing <a href=""https://www.energy.gov/articles/appalachian-energy-and-petrochemical-renaissance#:~:text=The%20U.S.%20Department%20of%20Energy,of%20its%20abundant%20energy%20resources."">&ldquo;a persistent misalignment of skills with needs&rdquo;</a>&nbsp;and local youth <a href=""https://www.rural.palegislature.us/documents/reports/Marcellus-Report-8-Economics.pdf"">expressing disinterest</a> in joining the migrant workforce. Perhaps to overcome this local shortage, but more importantly to cut costs at a time when prospects for the industry appear dim in light of climate change mitigation efforts, big oil companies are <a href=""https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/Shell-to-Cut-Up-to-9-000-Jobs-as-Virus-Forces-15608330.php"">restructuring for a leaner workforce</a>. Just last month, Shell announced that it will lay off 10 percent of its employees over the next two years.</p>

<p>With so few direct employment opportunities for Pennsylvania residents, most of the employment gains from shale gas development are attributed to &ldquo;indirect&rdquo; or &ldquo;salary-induced&rdquo; jobs. And herein we find the widely inflated job numbers, <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/opinion/letters/2020/10/13/Fact-checking-the-energy-secretary/stories/202010060118"">cited most recently by Energy Secretary Dan Brouillette</a>, that include everything from downstream plastics manufacturers to convenience and gas station workers, as well as other similarly <a href=""https://www.foodandwaterwatch.org/sites/default/files/fracking_jobs_memo_final.pdf"">far-fetched &ldquo;salary-induced&rdquo; jobs</a>, many of which existed before the shale gas boom.</p>

<p>In essence, the industry creates a negligible percentage of Pennsylvania jobs, many of which are outsourced, while taking credit for a broad swath of jobs in other industries.&nbsp;What, then, is its actual impact on local communities?</p>

<p>The impact, it appears, is a mixed bag. The benefits are, on the whole, non-local, uneven, and short-term. Employment opportunities are limited, meaning that most of the increase in local taxable income has been driven by <a href=""https://www.rural.palegislature.us/documents/reports/Marcellus-Report-8-Economics.pdf"">increased rents and royalties</a> from those that lease their land to drillers. This means that most benefits accrue to the privileged few who own land, <a href=""https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/11/2/025001"">plenty of whom are non-local themselves</a>. And wherever the income comes from, whether from employment or leased land, and wherever it goes, all of it is temporary. After drilling, <a href=""https://www.rural.palegislature.us/documents/reports/Marcellus-Report-8-Economics.pdf"">98 percent of shale gas development jobs dry up</a>, and rents and royalties dry up soon after.</p>

<p>But what about the so-called salary-induced jobs? Business activity has indeed increased in heavily fracked areas. However, the business activity occurs <a href=""https://www.rural.palegislature.us/documents/reports/Marcellus-Report-8-Economics.pdf"">primarily at big box stores</a> owned by non-locals. Meanwhile, locally owned businesses <a href=""https://www.rural.palegislature.us/documents/reports/Marcellus-Report-8-Economics.pdf"">have declined in heavily fracked counties</a>. In either case, the business activity &ndash; mostly driven by transient gas workers staying in hotels and eating out &ndash; can only last as long as the drilling does, at most a few years.</p>

<p>And these benefits do not come without harm. Empirical analyses have found that Pennsylvania&rsquo;s shale gas development has led to in the following:</p>

<ul>
	<li><a href=""https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2814147"">An influx of transient</a>, less educated, young, unmarried male workers with few social ties to the areas in which they temporarily settle</li>
	<li><a href=""https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0167629619308513"">An increase in sex trafficking</a> and prostitution, sexually transmitted diseases, <a href=""https://www.delawareriverkeeper.org/sites/default/files/ECONW-Costs_of_Fracking-May2019.pdf"">drug use, and drunk driving</a></li>
	<li><a href=""https://www.lycoming.edu/political-science/pdfs/marcellus-housing-report-2015.pdf"">More expensive rental housing</a>, degraded quality of housing units, and housing shortages, due to the influx of short-term, transient workers, and a related increase in homelessness</li>
	<li><a href=""https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140988316303590"">A decline in educational attainment</a> (PA was not a part of this study, but the association was found in all three study states &ndash; MO, WV, and ND)</li>
	<li><a href=""https://www.rff.org/publications/reports/the-accident-externality-from-trucking/"">An increase in truck traffic</a>, leading to noise pollution, stress, car accidents, and related fatalities</li>
	<li><a href=""https://www.delawareriverkeeper.org/sites/default/files/ECONW-Costs_of_Fracking-May2019.pdf"">A decrease in housing value</a> for homes reliant on groundwater sources, for fear of water contamination</li>
</ul>

<p>Other studies have found that dependence on natural resources such as shale gas leads to <a href=""https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/08941920.2020.1728000?journalCode=usnr20"">deepening educational disparities</a>, <a href=""https://www.delawareriverkeeper.org/sites/default/files/ECONW-Costs_of_Fracking-May2019.pdf"">less resilient and diverse economies</a>, <a href=""https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0014292106000614"">increased corruption</a>, and <a href=""https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0928765510000485"">anemic economic growth</a>. Meanwhile, Pennsylvania residents living nearest to drilling <a href=""https://www.attorneygeneral.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/FINAL-fracking-report-w.responses-with-page-number-V2.pdf"">have reported frequent nose bleeds</a>; chronic stress; the inability to sleep due to bright lights, noise, and vibrations through the night; intense stomach pains; and feelings of isolation and lack of control as property values drop and prevent homeowners from relocating. To make matters worse, those reaping the benefits of fracking (distant corporate offices, transient workers, and landowners) <a href=""https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/11/2/025001"">are not the same as those most impacted</a> by its harms (low-income renters and fenceline residents).</p>

<p>Nonetheless, legislators have largely bought into the industry&rsquo;s economic development narrative, so much so that they were willing to subsidize its use with $2 billion in tax credits over the next 25 years. And while taxpayer dollars are pouring into the industry, <a href=""https://ieefa.org/ieefa-from-zero-to-fifty-global-financial-corporations-get-cracking-on-major-oil-gas-lending-exits/?utm_source=rss&amp;utm_medium=rss&amp;utm_campaign=ieefa-from-zero-to-fifty-global-financial-corporations-get-cracking-on-major-oil-gas-lending-exits"">financial institutions are pulling out</a> because they recognize the many early signs of the fracking fallout: <a href=""https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/energy/shales-bust-shows-basis-of-boom-debt-debt-and-debt/2020/07/22/0e6ed98c-cc41-11ea-99b0-8426e26d203b_story.html"">depressed prices</a>, <a href=""https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2020-natural-gas-demand-peak/?srnd=green&amp;sref=piRJ9MA3"">peak gas demand</a>, <a href=""https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/energy/shales-bust-shows-basis-of-boom-debt-debt-and-debt/2020/07/22/0e6ed98c-cc41-11ea-99b0-8426e26d203b_story.html"">mounting debt</a>, <a href=""https://www.desmogblog.com/2020/10/15/bankruptcies-oil-gas-multi-billion-cleanup-bill-public?utm_source=DeSmog%20Weekly%20Newsletter"">record bankruptcies</a>, and <a href=""https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/Exxon-Mobil-Flags-Potential-Job-Cuts-in-Email-to-15666749.php"">industry-wide layoffs.</a>&nbsp;</p>

<p>As aptly summarized <a href=""https://img1.wsimg.com/blobby/go/4691da36-2e74-4c4c-99f0-19c3eee5ac9e/downloads/1d31iaaj6_122302.pdf?ver=1558223417346"">in a report by Pennsylvania nonprofit UrbanKind</a>, &ldquo;The benefits of fracking have not translated into widespread, long-term economic improvement.&rdquo; The very nature of fracking operations has ensured that this will continue to be true, and the long-term outlook of the industry only provides further evidence that our deepening reliance is more a liability than an asset.</p>

<p>Despite an abundance of evidence that the shale gas industry has failed our residents, Pennsylvania legislators lack the imagination to envision an economic future based on anything other than fossil fuels. In doing so, they write our state out of the clean energy future which most certainly lies ahead.</p>

<p>The age of fossil fuel dominance is over, and it is now time to listen to Pennsylvania residents demanding the reigning in of the fracking industry. We must redirect our precious state resources to industries that hold long-term economic promise and, beyond that, do not directly undermine public health, environmental protection, and climate stability.</p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Emily Persico, Policy Analyst"
Clean Water Advocacy Forges Ahead Despite Pandemic,10/15/2020,"<p>The COVID-19 pandemic has left its impact on all of us and continues to raise uncertainty at every corner, including in our clean water advocacy. Every year, in the spring, our clean water advocates from across the state travel to Harrisburg to educate elected officials on the importance of clean water.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This spring, when the COVID-19 pandemic hit, we acted quickly with our partners to adapt the day-long event into a new socially distanced way of doing clean water advocacy. We created the first ever <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-partners-to-celebrate-PA-Clean-Water-Week"">PA Clean Water Week</a> and moved our meeting with legislators from the Capitol to the virtual, which now has become the norm.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We also looked to the first week of October to schedule an in-person Harrisburg event. However, six months later the pandemic still ensues. It turned out to be a good thing that we were already planning the first ever Fall Clean Water Education Day, because the General Assembly has to pass a fall supplemental budget. The &ldquo;annual&rdquo; budget passed by the General Assembly in June was for 5 months, allowing time for the state to react to the unfolding pandemic and its economic implications.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania is facing a nearly $5 billion revenue gap from last year and state legislators must pass a budget by the end of November to carry out this year&rsquo;s budget, which ends in June. With such a budget deficit, our clean water funding is in danger of serious cuts.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Last week the Coalition for the Delaware River Watershed, the Choose Clean Water Coalition, and partner organizations from western Pennsylvania met with our state legislators to talk about the importance of keeping funding for clean water in the Fall 2020 Supplemental Budget. In addition, we sent a letter with 38 signatories to Governor Wolf last week asking him to protect our clean water funding this fall.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Two years ago, clean water advocates <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/cleanwaterbriefingbook2019-01.pdf"">agreed on three priorities</a> for clean water funding.</p>

<ol>
	<li>Funding for the state&rsquo;s Natural Resources Agencies, such as DEP and DCNR</li>
	<li>Funding for the Interstate River Basin Commissions, such as DRBC and SRBC</li>
	<li>A Dedicated Source of Funding for Clean Water&nbsp;</li>
</ol>

<p><u>Funding for the state&rsquo;s Natural Resources Agencies</u></p>

<p>The Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) and the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR) are tasked with several important roles related to clean water. Unfortunately, over the past couple decades they have witnessed significant budget cuts that impact their capacity. Since 2002, state funding for the DEP has been cut by nearly 40 percent, leading to a reduction of staff by 30 percent. And, General Fund support for DCNR has been slashed over the last 15 years, declining from $108.8 million in 2002-03 to a low of $14.5 million in 2014-15.</p>

<p>DEP is responsible for permitting activities that protect public health, such as drinking water and wastewater facilities. DEP is also responsible for permitting activities that may cause harm to our waterways, such as stormwater and construction site runoff. DEP also administers state and federal grant programs that put projects that protect our streams, such as the Environmental Stewardship Fund and Section 319 grants. Funding for DEP is essential for public health and clean water.&nbsp;</p>

<p>DCNR oversees hundreds of programs and parks, greenways, open space, and natural areas, all which benefit our rivers and streams. Yet last year, the Pennsylvania Parks and Forests Foundation estimated that DCNR has a $1 billion infrastructure backlog due to a lack of state funding.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Funding for DCNR is critical to the conservation of our waterways. Our public lands provide vast forested landscapes and natural infrastructure that benefit water quality. At its facilities, DCNR operates wastewater treatment systems as well as stormwater infrastructure. DCNR also administers the state&rsquo;s riparian forested buffer program for streamside trees.</p>

<p><u>Funding for the Interstate River Basin Commissions</u></p>

<p>Pennsylvania is part of five Interstate Basin Commissions:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Delaware River Basin Commission&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Susquehanna River Basin Commission</li>
	<li>Interstate Commission for the Potomac River Basin</li>
	<li>Ohio River Valley Sanitation Commission</li>
	<li>Great Lakes Commission</li>
</ul>

<p>River Basin Commissions are agencies formed by interstate compact to serve state and federal government agencies that coordinate interstate waterway planning and management. The authority of each River Basin Commission varies but each may be responsible for overseeing water quality, flood control, wildlife, water flow, water withdrawals, aquatic flora, recreation, navigation, and industrial runoff in their respective basin. The health and prosperity of each river basin and its inhabitants relies on strong participation and supportive funding of member states in each River Basin Commission.</p>

<p><u>A Dedicated Source of Funding for Clean Water</u></p>

<p>The three leading sources of pollution into Pennsylvania&rsquo;s waterways are (in descending order): runoff from agricultural lands, acid mine drainage from legacy coal mining, and stormwater runoff from developed surfaces. Because the National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permitting system, established a mechanism for reducing pollution coming from industry and other types of facilities, much of the pollution that impacts our waterways is coming from nonpoint source pollution. To clean up this type of pollution, we need to put practices in place that keep the runoff from reaching our streams.&nbsp;</p>

<p>A dedicated source of funding established for clean water projects would help farmers, local governments, conservation organizations, and others working across the Commonwealth to clean up our waterways and fund the projects necessary to do the job. Furthermore, the planning, design, construction, and long-term maintenance of clean water projects create and sustain employment opportunities.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
<u>The Agricultural Conservation Assistance Program</u></p>

<p>In September 2020, <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billInfo/billInfo.cfm?sYear=2019&amp;sInd=0&amp;body=S&amp;type=B&amp;bn=1272"">Senator Yaw introduced SB 1272</a>, the Agricultural Conservation Assistance Program, or ACAP for short. This bill would provide funding assistance directly to farmers or landowners to implement conservation practices that protect or improve our waterways. ACAP would be overseen by the State Conservation Commission, however, decisions on funding projects and the application process would be handled at the local level by the County Conservation Districts. The ACAP program would provide funding to farmers statewide and funding to the counties would be proportional to the agricultural footprint of a county. The more farms, the more livestock and cropland, and the more impaired streams from agricultural sources, the more money a county would receive.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The passage of ACAP is critical to improving our rivers and streams because it addresses Pennsylvania&rsquo;s leading source of stream impairment. Currently, ACAP sits in the Senate Agriculture &amp; Rural Affairs Committee and could make it to a vote in the full Senate this fall. SB 1272 proposes to create a program which is local, supported by farmers, and puts funding directly in the hands of farmers.&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://www.choosecleanwater.org/keystone-farmers"">Click here to learn more</a>&nbsp;and watch videos of two Pennsylvanian farmers reflecting on the changing the legacy of farming and how the proposed Agricultural Conservation Assistance Program would help farmers steward the land and water and provide economic benefits.</p>

<p><u>Fertilizer Legislation</u></p>

<p>In addition to advocating for clean water funding in the budget, PennFuture is working to see SB 915 passed this fall. This bill would establish limits on fertilizers applied to grassy areas, such as lawns and turf. Establishing such limits would improve the health of our rivers and streams. The ground can only hold a limited amount of nutrients, or fertilizers. When grass is overfertilized beyond what can be absorbed by the soil, the excess will wash off into waterways or move down into the groundwater. Over 2,600 miles of the Commonwealth&rsquo;s streams are impaired due to excess nutrients.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Excess nutrients fuel plant and algae growth in our streams. When the algae die they can deplete the oxygen available to other life in the waterways, like fish and macroinvertebrates. Excess algae can also cloud the water, reducing the sunlight available to important vegetation that provide food, cover, and habitat for aquatic life.&nbsp;</p>

<p>If passed, SB 915 will:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Create a level playing field for fertilizer companies across the state and protect local waters, moving towards one standard across the region and providing regional companies with similar market requirements to those in neighboring states.</li>
	<li>Limit how much nitrogen and phosphorus are applied to turf (grass).</li>
	<li>Establish a professional fertilizer applicator certification program, similar to pesticide applicators, that will ensure that professionals apply fertilizers at the proper rates, as established in this bill.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Develop an Agricultural and Homeowner Education Program to educate nonprofessional applicators on the proper rate of applying fertilizers.&nbsp;</li>
</ol>

<p>Right now, this bill sits in the House Agriculture &amp; Rural Affairs Committee, which is led by a new chair, Representative Keller, from Perry County. It passed the Senate in late spring. With strong support behind the bill from many stakeholders, we hope to see this bill passed this fall.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As you can see, there is no shortage of clean water advocacy needed this fall. Please stay tuned to our website, emails, and social media for updates on what you can do to help protect our waters.</p>

<p>Right now, <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/915alert"">you can follow this link asking your state Representative</a> to pass SB 915 and improve our waterways from excess nutrient pollution.&nbsp;</p>
",Community; Environment,"Renee Reber, Campaign Manager, Watershed Advocacy"
Toxic Fracking Waste Becomes Mounting Problem for Downstream Communities,10/13/2020,"<p>We know the dangers of fracking operations &ndash; groundwater contamination, air quality issues, devastating health impacts &ndash; but what many might not realize is that the fracking industry is allowed to dispose of its wastes in landfills across Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As a result, dangerous chemicals in fracking waste &ndash; such as radioactive materials &ndash; eventually make their way into Pennsylvania waters, threatening the health and safety of our communities and our streams.</p>

<p>The Marcellus Shale <a href=""http://vjel.vermontlaw.edu/files/2018/02/Geltman_FP-2.pdf"">is estimated to contain 10 to 100 parts per million (ppm) of uranium</a>, up to 33 times the national average. This unique geology means that rocks brought to the surface during Pennsylvania fracking operations likely have high levels of Radium-226. The industry calls this waste &ldquo;technologically enhanced naturally occurring radioactive material&rdquo; (<a href=""https://www.epa.gov/radiation/technologically-enhanced-naturally-occurring-radioactive-materials-tenorm"">TENORM</a>).&nbsp;</p>

<p>Given the <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2016-09/documents/radionuclides.pdf"">long-term implications of exposure to radium</a>, one of the radioactive chemicals found in fracking waste, communities are raising concerns. Clearly, greater scrutiny is needed &mdash; both of fracking operations and of the landfills that accept the industry&rsquo;s waste.</p>

<p>Although Pennsylvania landfills are not permitted to accept liquid waste, some 30 landfills in Pennsylvania and several in neighboring states accept drill cuttings from fracking sites. Pennsylvania landfills are required to screen drill cuttings to ensure they do not exceed maximum radioactivity levels. But what happens after the cuttings are admitted into the landfill?&nbsp;</p>

<p>When fracking waste combines with stormwater, the pool of leached water mixed with chemicals (&ldquo;leachate&rdquo;) may become a dangerously radioactive runoff, flowing into downstream treatment facilities or directly into nearby waterways.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Landfills are required to treat leachate or somehow capture and transport it to other treatment facilities, but there are no requirements that landfills trace the leachate from fracking waste. This means that radioactive leachate may be threatening our waters without us knowing.&nbsp;</p>

<p>StateImpact Pennsylvania has found <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2019/09/11/how-did-fracking-contaminants-end-up-in-the-monongahela-river-a-loophole-in-the-law-might-be-to-blame/"">16 wastewater treatment plants take treated leachate from landfills</a>. Another 12 treatment plants are too small to be screened by DEP and instead, if they are at all taking action to treat or prevent the inflow of fracking leachate, do so voluntarily.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Public Herald <a href=""https://publicherald.org/pennsylvania-regulators-wont-say-where-66-of-landfill-leachate-w-radioactive-material-from-fracking-is-going-its-private/"">has also investigated these scenarios</a>, producing a map that <a href=""https://novarecollective.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=522c1a37d9f6430c8f05d6041b294af6"">shows the location of 30 landfills</a> likely to accept fracking waste and some 20 wastewater treatment plants that may be receiving the contaminated leachate.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection declared <a href=""http://www.depgreenport.state.pa.us/elibrary/GetDocument?docId=5815&amp;DocName=01%20PENNSYLVANIA%20DEPARTMENT%20OF%20ENVIRONMENTAL%20PROTECTION%20TENORM%20STUDY%20REPORT%20REV%201.PDF%20"">in a 2016 report that the public faced</a> &ldquo;little potential for radiation exposure&rdquo; from landfills receiving fracking waste. Defenders of the report later said any treatment plants that accept contaminated leachate <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2015/12/28/report-revives-debate-over-risks-of-radiation-from-drilling-waste/"">remove the radium</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But the Westmoreland Sanitary Landfill, where the fracking industry deposited nearly 160,000 tons of drill cuttings, mud, and other fracking waste in 2018, has proven this was a faulty assumption and that the threat is real.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The landfill has been receiving fracking waste since 2010 and up until May 2019, leachate flowed downhill from the landfill, directly into the sewer, where it eventually made its way to the Belle Vernon Municipal Authority&rsquo;s treatment plant.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The authority reported that the leachate <a href=""http://www.paenvironmentdigest.com/newsletter/default.asp?NewsletterArticleID=49058&amp;SubjectID=83"">was killing bacteria intended to treat the wastewater</a>. Tests of the Monongahela River near the plant showed levels of radium at 8 picocuries per liter. The EPA standard for drinking water is 5.</p>

<p>Because of this highly contaminated leachate, the Authority cancelled its contract to treat the leachate from the landfill due to the fact that the leachate from the landfill had become untreatable and threated the water quality of the Monongahela. Since then, the landfill has been forced to truck its contaminated leachate to an out-of-state treatment facility.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The contaminated leachate also resulted in environmental litigation against the landfill and in February 2020, <a href=""https://www.media.pa.gov/Pages/DEP_details.aspx?newsid=1313"">DEP issued a consent order with Westmoreland Sanitary Landfill,</a> charging the facility a $24,000 civil penalty and requiring actions to minimize leachate generation.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In May, the landfill <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/news/environment/2020/05/23/Westmoreland-County-landfill-seeks-approval-to-evaporate-contaminated-runoff/stories/202005220120"">announced plans to use an &ldquo;ultra-filtration&rdquo; system</a> to remove solids from the radium-rich leachate by evaporating it into the atmosphere &mdash; up to 45,000 gallons of leachate per day.&nbsp; PennFuture joined others in opposing this proposal citing the significant threat to human health and the environment from the resulting radon gases that are likely to be emitted through the evaporation process.</p>

<p>PennFuture argued that no approval should be issued unless and until DEP has sufficiently monitored, reviewed, considered, analyzed, and mitigated, if necessary, this threat.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We&rsquo;re continuing to monitor this matter as well as others to protect Pennsylvanians and our environment from the dangers &ndash; known and unknown &ndash; that the fracking and petrochemical industries pose.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Please consider supporting our efforts by <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">becoming a member today!</a></p>

<p>PennFuture will continue to monitor the fracking industry and to support community groups that advocate for the defense of their local waterways.</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
How a Clean Water Program is Addressing Equity in Philadelphia,10/5/2020,"<div>While testifying in front of <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Smith-Public-Testimony_200336_COVIDRecovery-1-.pdf"">Philadelphia City Council&rsquo;s Joint Committees on Finance and Commerce and Economic Development</a> about COVID-19 recovery strategies last week, I highlighted a strategy that Philadelphia can take to address the many interlocking crises the city is currently facing.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Whether it&rsquo;s the COVID-19 public health crisis, structural racism, economic downturn, or gun violence, one action can offer real solutions to them all: investing in green space. In particular, I sought to highlight how green space is addressing the structural inequality created by a practice known as redlining that black and brown neighborhoods were subject to during the 20th century.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Redlining was a practice that began in the 1930&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.cbsnews.com/news/redlining-what-is-history-mike-bloomberg-comments/"">where many banks in the U.S. denied mortgages to people,</a> mostly people of color in urban areas, preventing them from buying a home in certain neighborhoods or getting a loan to renovate their house. The practice was once backed by the U.S. government and occurred in many of the nation&rsquo;s largest cities with large minority populations.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>While the South had segregation and Jim Crow laws, the North had redlining. As part of the practice, financial firms, real estate agents and other parties demarcated geographic areas that were effectively off limits for issuing loans by literally using red ink to outline parts of the city. These areas were considered high risk of default. Riskier neighborhoods <a href=""https://whyy.org/segments/redlining-segregated-philadelphia/"">were predominantly Black and Latino</a>, but also recently immigrated European groups like Jews and Italians.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Redlining has had a devastating long-term impact on U.S. urban areas and Black people particularly. Redlining allowed for the systematic denial of various services by federal government agencies, local governments, as well as the private sector. It has also had <a href=""https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/past-racist-redlining-practices-increased-climate-burden-on-minority-neighborhoods/"">a lasting environmental impact.</a> Redlined communities were often subject to air quality deterioration from urban highways, industrial plants and landfills. They are also more likely to experience extreme heats than other communities because of a phenomenon known as the Urban Heat Island effect.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The Urban Heat Island effect occurs in urbanized areas that experience higher temperatures than outlying neighborhoods because of a lack of green space and a high density in asphalt pavement and rooftops. The divestment from redlined neighborhoods also resulted in a lack of investment in green spaces from those same communities. In Philadelphia, these neighborhoods experience <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/science/climate/philadelphia-heat-island-climate-change-hunting-park-20190724.html"">up to a 22 degree temperature difference</a> during hotter months of the year. These neighborhoods also have a greater amount of impervious surface that produces a larger amount of stormwater pollution.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>In 2011 when Philadelphia implemented their Green City, Clean Waters plan, they did so recognizing the opportunities to reverse some of the historical divestment from Philadelphia&rsquo;s Black and Brown neighborhoods. Green City, Clean Waters is the City&rsquo;s Combined Sewer Overflow Compliance program. When Philadelphia first constructed its wastewater and stormwater system over 200 years ago, before enactment of the Clean Water Act, they relied on a combined sewer system model.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>While combined sewer systems were the standard wastewater/stormwater management practice during that time, with the increase in impervious surface, growth, and development, the sewer system can no longer withstand the amount of stormwater runoff entering the system. Traditionally, the solution is to invest in the construction of large tunnels, storage tanks, and wastewater treatment plant upgrades. The costs associated with the traditional approach were estimated to cost about $8-10 billion and would rely on large infrastructure companies that typically bring in high skilled labor from outside of the region to construct the infrastructure.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Green City, Clean Waters is a more cost effective alternative that is also bringing investment back to neighborhoods that often need it the most. The program relies on the implementation of green stormwater infrastructure - like rain gardens, tree trenches, and green roofs - to filter stormwater through plants, soil, and stones before it enters the combined sewer system. This water infrastructure investment is also creating green space and addressing the Urban Heat Island Effect.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Green City, Clean Waters <a href=""https://gsipartners.sbnphiladelphia.org/the-economic-social-and-environmental-case-for-green-city-clean-waters-an-update/"">provides approximately 1,000 local jobs annually</a> and creates a $4 million economic impact - creating local jobs and building a robust regional green economy. Research shows that access to green space <a href=""https://phys.org/news/2020-02-reveals-green-space-violent-crime.html"">reduces crime and blight</a>, increases opportunities to play and recreate, and <a href=""https://www.niehs.nih.gov/research/supported/translational/peph/webinars/green_spaces/index.cfm"">improves mental and physical health.</a>&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Green stormwater infrastructure may not be able to solve the entirety of structural racism and its impact on Philadelphians, but investing in this innovative approach to stormwater management is one way the city is seeking to address the harm caused by racist housing policies.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>PennFuture is a proud supporter of Green City, Clean Waters and the efforts the City of Philadelphia is taking to reinvest in historically neglected neighborhoods. Through it we are seeking to do our part in addressing racism and creating a healthier environment.</div>
",Climate; Community; Environment,Lena Smith
An Admission and a Promise,10/1/2020,"<p>Angst and pain have been common themes for many of us in 2020, given the onset of a deadly pandemic interwoven with social unrest and a democracy that appears to be failing on multiple fronts. </p>

<p>To say that 2020 has been a year of tremendous upheaval and volatility is underselling it. This has been a year none of us will soon forget, and for good reason. </p>

<p>While this has been a difficult year for many of us, the fact remains that millions of people across the United States have been living with deep anxiety and frustration for far longer than just this calendar year. </p>

<p>For Black people, 2020 has been nothing more than the status quo, just another continuation of a long and systemic string of racial and environmental injustices perpetrated on entire segments of our population ad infinitum.</p>

<p>These are entire communities in our country that suffer on a daily basis, and have been subjugated for centuries. The racial unrest and tensions we’re seeing today are a direct result of being ignored, trampled upon and disregarded for entire lifetimes.</p>

<p>The United States is finally reckoning with the fact that black, indigenous, and other communities of color have been treated far different, and far worse, for far too long. </p>

<p>That reckoning is also happening at PennFuture, as we reflect internally on the role that we can play in ending racism. Since our inception in 1998, PennFuture has tried to advocate for every person who breathes air and drinks water in Pennsylvania, and that won’t change. </p>

<p>But, like many others, we’ve fallen short in our efforts to help build a truly equitable and just Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>This is both an admission and a promise: an admission that the traditional environmental movement, including PennFuture, has largely remained silent on racial justice issues, and a promise that we will do better moving forward. We must do better moving forward. </p>

<p>The murder of George Floyd at the hands of Minneapolis police in May was the latest reminder that inaction and race-silent policies are no longer acceptable, but it’s not the only reminder. To that end, more than 1,000 people have been killed by police since 2013. Last year alone, <a href=""https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2020-06-03/data-show-deaths-from-police-violence-disproportionately-affect-people-of-color"">54 percent of those who died</a> as a result of police violence were people of color.</p>

<p>So where do we go from here?</p>

<p>For starters, PennFuture created a new internal committee to explore these and other issues, and to outline the best path forward as we take this journey with a staff and board of directors of about 45 people.</p>

<p>Another step forward was to admit we needed help on this journey, so we are seeking expertise and guidance from outside experts and guides who will help shine a light on implicit biases and blind spots to help us transform PennFuture’s culture, and ensure we understand the operational and other practices that will make us a more welcoming and open organization to a greater diversity of individuals. </p>

<p>Finally, we decided to craft a heartfelt and meaningful statement that is meant to show solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement.</p>

<p>This statement has gone through dozens of edits and revisions, and has been vetted by the entirety of PennFuture’s staff and board. We stand behind this statement, and it won’t simply be pasted on PennFuture’s website and forgotten. </p>

<p>Rather, this statement is a jumping-off point to a much larger internal discussion within PennFuture, the start of a long process to permanently transform the organization. That will not be quick or easy. Nor should it be. </p>

<p>If you’re interested in reading our solidarity statement,<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-releases-statement-showing-solidarity-with-Black-Lives-Matter-movement""> please click here</a>, or just continue reading. It is copied below for anyone who wishes to read it. </p>

<p>We plan on being forthright and honest as this process unfolds, and we appreciate your patience as we work through these delicate and imminently important issues. </p>

<p style=""text-align: center;""><span style=""font-size:16px;""><u><strong>PennFuture Solidarity Statement</strong></u></span></p>

<p>George Floyd. Breonna Taylor. Darrell Banks. Tony McDade. Atatiana Jefferson. Nina Adams. Antwon Rose. Tamir Rice. Ricardo Giddings. Brandon Tate Brown: Ten Black lives stolen by police in recent years, among the more than 1,000 people that police have killed since 2013. Last year alone, 54 percent of those who died as a result of police violence were people of color. </p>

<p>These are lives cut short because of systemic racism in American society. The murder of George Floyd at the hands of Minneapolis police is yet another reminder of this seemingly intractable racism, his dying words – “I can’t breathe” – literal and figurative assertions of generation after generation of suffocating injustices.</p>

<p>In the wake of George Floyd’s death, we have seen black communities protesting state-sanctioned police violence only to be met with tear gas, rubber bullets, and a militarized police force. PennFuture stands in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement in the fight to end violence and all other manifestations of systemic racism. We do this in part because we recognize the connections between racism and the protection of clean air, water, and land. </p>

<p>Black, brown, and indigenous communities are disproportionately burdened by polluting refineries, contaminated water, and toxic dumping. This is environmental racism. Black children are twice as likely to have asthma as white children. This is environmental racism. Movements of black people in public parks and open spaces are policed and controlled. This is environmental racism. And environmental racism is systematically causing the premature death of black people and other people of color. </p>

<p>In the face of overwhelming evidence of environmental racism, the traditional environmental movement, including PennFuture, has largely remained silent on racial justice issues. That is, until recently. At PennFuture, we have begun the long process of actively incorporating anti-racist practices. With expert guidance, our team will begin to shine a light on implicit biases and blind spots to transform PennFuture from the inside out.</p>

<p>We grieve for the lives lost, the communities trampled, and the voices silenced by racism in this country. We are committed to uncovering the root causes of this suffering and repairing the harms after decades of silence. In solidarity with Black Lives Matter, we embrace an inclusive and equitable environmentalism that affirms all Pennsylvanians’ rights to a healthy environment. </p>

<p>In peace and solidarity, </p>

<p>PennFuture staff</p>
",Community; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
Creative Civic Engagement During the Pandemic,9/30/2020,"<p>The 2020 election is just about one month away. Many voters are highly engaged as the stakes are so high for the values we each hold personally dear for our families, our communities, state and country.</p>

<p>As an advocacy organization active with state and federal policy, in legislatures and the courts,&nbsp; PennFuture views participation in voting as strategic to the environmental outcomes we work toward. So we moved more intentionally into democracy work to ensure that this aspect of our democracy is optimized.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We want everyone who is eligible to vote to be registered to vote, and we work to be sure that those who are registered to vote are able to do so safely, free of intimidation and in as informed a way as possible.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s Democracy for All program focuses on non-partisan voter registration, voter education, voter engagement and get-out-the vote work. It is aimed at individuals of color, millennials and single women, a group of voters sometimes referred to as the New American Majority or Rising American Electorate.</p>

<p>Last summer, when we were planning our non-partisan voter registration program, we envisioned a tried and true model that would be deploying canvassers into the field, armed with iPads or tablets, and electronically registering eligible individuals in person. COVID-19&nbsp;upended that model as our need to provide for the safety of our staff and contractors became a paramount consideration.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We held out hope until the last possible minute to run an in-person program but the persistence of the pandemic and contagion of the virus made it too difficult.</p>

<p>Our team needed to get creative and pivot our tactics. Despite all of these restrictions and limitations, we are still out in Pennsylvania communities registering people to vote in the most important election in recent memory.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Some highlights:</p>

<ul>
	<li>In July, PennFuture and our partners <a href=""https://www.wfmz.com/news/area/lehighvalley/art-installation-in-allentown-gets-creative-in-promoting-voter-turnout/article_696f552e-c3c1-11ea-a378-37cb219f675f.html"">installed an art piece entitled Inscribete a Votar in&nbsp;Allentown;</a></li>
	<li>Democracy for All <a href=""https://www.dfavote.org/?fbclid=IwAR0gp-L63oW77moYpNk7FS3Ve847s3l_zgVeAZHgRsE26ED8qAyVDpMp6ss"">kicked off National Voter Registration Day on Sept. 22</a> with a Voter Registration Couch Party hosted by Yellopain.&nbsp; The program just wrapped up this week of voter action with a daily suite of highly visual and art-oriented engagement tools with our partner Democracy for All programs throughout the country ; and</li>
	<li>The team <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/IMG_0781.jpg"">recently formed a voter registration caravan</a> that made its way through the Wyoming Valley, the Poconos and Lehigh Valley on a rainy Saturday. Attached to the vehicles were magnetic signs featuring bar codes that a viewer can aim her/his/its smart phone at and be directed to a voter registration website. The caravan <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/IMG_0779.jpg"">ended in Allentown</a> where it drove by a rally and march for Breonna Taylor.</li>
	<li>The team is also deploying texting and calling to promote voter registration. <a href=""https://www.democracyforall-pennfuture.com/register-2-vote"">October 19, 2020 is the last day to register to vote in the November 3, 2020 elections</a>. After that date the Democracy for All program will pivot to get-out-the-vote efforts.&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>Please consider <a href=""https://www.facebook.com/DemocracyForAllPennFuture"">learning more about this important program</a>, and be sure to <a href=""https://www.instagram.com/democracyforallpennfuture/"">follow us on social media!</a></p>

Fossil Fuel Polluters and Friends Ramp Up New Attack on Solar Energy in Pa.,9/29/2020,"<p>Fossil fuel polluters and their enablers in the legislature have been ramping up a new attack on solar energy in Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>Rep. Chris Dush, one of the most notorious climate deniers in the state&nbsp; House of Representatives, led this charge in a recent House Environmental Resources and Energy Committee meeting with a speech <a href=""https://www.facebook.com/repdush/videos/354190742292978/"">that was either intentionally dishonest or profoundly ignorant.</a></p>

<p>He began by claiming that coal is &ldquo;just compost&rdquo; and is &ldquo;natural,&rdquo; whereas solar panels make use of &ldquo;man-made chemical compounds&rdquo; that are toxic.</p>

<p>Right from the start we recognize the &ldquo;appeal to nature&rdquo; fallacy.&nbsp;As much as advertising tries to convince us that anything &ldquo;natural&rdquo; must be safe, that&rsquo;s ridiculous.&nbsp;Everyone knows not to go out and randomly pick mushrooms to eat, we call the plant &ldquo;poison&rdquo; ivy for a reason, and we rush to the hospital if we are bitten by a venomous snake or spider.&nbsp;It should also be no surprise to anyone that coal is one of the things the EPA <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/recycle/composting-home"">specifically recommends not putting on your compost pile.</a></p>

<p>Rep. Dush may call it &ldquo;compost,&rdquo; but coal can contain arsenic, beryllium, cadmium, chromium, cobalt, cyanide, lead, manganese, mercury, molybdenum, nickel, selenium, and a host of other toxic and radioactive chemicals. When burnt, it releases tons of cancer-causing fine particulates, precursors of ozone smog, the sulfur dioxide that leads to acid rain, and carbon pollution that contributes to climate change.&nbsp;Afterwards, we are left with vast amounts of toxic ash that must be disposed of.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In addition to the new pollution coal is responsible for every day, Pennsylvania is still struggling to cope with the result of decades of coal use.&nbsp;We have billions of tons of waste coal piles polluting our land and water and, as Rep. Dush even admits, a huge number of streams that were rendered effectively dead because of acid mine drainage.&nbsp;Of all people, our representatives should know the difference between compost and pollution.</p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-98743cb3-7fff-b064-fc09-d48d133ff018""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""><span style=""border:none;display:inline-block;overflow:hidden;width:485px;height:365px;""><img height=""365"" src=""https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/wZMJl4xdoYSz_FvTx5f0AfrxYH1UMg_-AFMYhyNYbvezcrpRrzY7WhfpE33HAkZrYpkHfjbHI6O3cJMusIS9wbyODg230_UshuYlUzh8c5OxxFJHbD6lyU_D9b0dOnNNmJNvjCmi"" style=""margin-left:0px;margin-top:0px;"" width=""485"" /></span></span></span></p>

<p><em>Above: More than 45 tons of acid along with thousands of pounds of aluminum and manganese drain from the Jeddo Tunnel into the Little Nescopeck and into the Susquehanna River every day.</em></p>

<p>Fracked&nbsp;gas may contain fewer toxics and heavy metals as coal, but it&rsquo;s hardly safe either.&nbsp;We know waste from drilling operations contains toxic and radioactive material, but the scary part is what we don&rsquo;t know.&nbsp;A 2018 report <a href=""https://www.pfpi.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/PASecretFrackingChemicalsReportPFPI9.10.2018.pdf"">on the use of trade secret rules</a> to avoid disclosing the chemicals used in the drilling process noted that secret chemicals were used in more than half of the wells drilled.</p>

<p>In 2019, Trump&rsquo;s Environmental Protection Agency&nbsp;issued its recommendation <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2019-04/documents/management_of_exploration_development_and_production_wastes_4-23-19.pdf"">to exempt oil and gas waste from regulation</a> under the Subtitle C of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA)&mdash;despite explicitly saying that exemption &ldquo;does not mean that these wastes cannot cause harm to human health.&rdquo; The rationale for this exemption included the claims that regulation could create &ldquo;delays for exploration and production operations&rdquo;, and perhaps more tellingly that &ldquo;the large waste volumes generated could severely strain capacity at existing Subtitle C facilities.&rdquo;</p>

<p>How large are these waste volumes?&nbsp;We know data from the PA Department of Environmental Protection indicates that in 2018 alone over 230,000 tons of waste from oil and gas operations was disposed of in Pennsylvania landfills. This included drill cutting, contaminated soil, spent lubricants, and drilling fluid waste along with other chemicals and radioactive materials. Of course, when Rep. Dush testified that he is &ldquo;not too far from a massive landfill&rdquo; and he doesn&rsquo;t want to see &ldquo;negative environmental impacts&rdquo; from disposing of solar panels, he made no mention of the existing waste problem from the natural gas industry.</p>

<p>In order to generate 230,000 tons of waste from solar panels we would need to throw away about seven times the number solar panels installed in Pennsylvania today&mdash;and repeat that again year after year.&nbsp;In reality panels can have an expected life of more than thirty years, so the actual number that are taken out of service in any one year is tiny.&nbsp;To even get close to the volume of waste created by fracking, we would need several hundred times the amount of solar as we have today and decide, for some reason, to recycle none of the panels when they are retired.</p>

<p>No energy source can ever be perfect, but from an environmental perspective solar is pretty good. More than 90 percent by weight of solar panels is glass, plastic, and aluminum, which is already recyclable and not considered hazardous waste.&nbsp;Everyone agrees that the small amount of other compounds like silver, tin, lead, and other trace compounds need to be either disposed of properly or recycled.&nbsp;Fortunately the rare elements also tend to be commercially valuable so there is a lot of <a href=""https://www.nature.com/articles/s41560-020-0645-2.epdf?sharing_token=gTbOszbDSFo3DPHaqB2oKtRgN0jAjWel9jnR3ZoTv0OtL9QEzcgFMYa45OUzo4NruhWqFy6wgWcztDdWim4XS3hCVOCBhp4d3QDIeKJkRd1qE3jMWfn99b10OTnspoqOjZXZdVAs0r5jaR6vhHiEl_Yr8DM9BCYUFb15u73ruAc%3D"">interest and research in developing effective recycling technology.</a></p>

<p>Even with the appropriate technology in place, recycling can&rsquo;t be cost-effective unless there is a sufficient stream of material to process. This is one area where the long life span of solar systems creates a challenge.&nbsp;As the market for solar grows, so will the recycling businesses. But, instead of irresponsibly spreading fear and doubt while shilling for fossil fuels, our legislators could work to advance solar generation and, in doing so, welcome this new supporting industry to the state.</p>
",Climate; Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
"Trump's Energy Secretary Denies Human-Made Climate Change, Promotes Petrochemicals During Beaver County Visit",9/28/2020,"<p>As the election approaches, it seems national politics have converged on Southwestern Pennsylvania, each visiting politician equipped with a different sales pitch for opposing futures.&nbsp;</p>

<p>When U.S. Energy Secretary Dan Brouillette visited earlier this week, his vision was unambiguous. The Shell petrochemical complex in Beaver County, Brouillette said, is the &ldquo;future of the American economy.&rdquo;</p>

<p>What his vision didn&rsquo;t include, however, was even a basic understanding of climate change. In response to questions about the scientific consensus of human-caused climate change, <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2020/09/21/trumps-energy-secretary-questions-mainstream-science-on-human-impacts-of-climate-change/"">he arrogantly responded that &ldquo;no one knows that.&rdquo;</a></p>

<p>The secretary is right about one thing, though: A petrochemical future requires absolute climate denial. This is because the petrochemical industry <a href=""https://www.nationalobserver.com/2020/09/04/opinion/sorry-break-it-you-futures-not-plastics"">intends to double its carbon emisssions</a> just as other industries and sectors get serious about taking climate action.</p>

<p>According to Brouillette, it is unrealistic to even consider serious climate action.</p>

<p>&ldquo;Today in the marketplace, renewable power is almost entirely dependent on fossil fuels and nuclear technology,&rdquo; <a href=""https://www.timesonline.com/story/news/2020/09/21/u-s-secretary-energy-beaver-county/5855131002/"">he told reporters</a>. &ldquo;No one wants to say that out loud because it sounds politically incorrect at times.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Instead, his Department has taken an &ldquo;all of the above&rdquo; approach to energy development that, in practice, means climate denial, understating the potential of renewable technologies, and an all-out endorsement of fossil fuels.</p>

<p>As if having a climate change-denying energy secretary wasn&rsquo;t enough, Brouillette quickly showed that he lacks even a basic understanding of our economy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The petrochemical industry that he touts as &ldquo;the future of the American economy&rdquo; <a href=""https://www.desmogblog.com/2020/04/16/oil-gas-petrochemical-financial-woes-pandemic-ciel-report"">was under extreme financial duress even before the COVID-19 pandemic hit</a>. It&rsquo;s an industry that <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fracked-Gas-and-Petrochemical-Industries-Jockeying-for-Stimulus-Recovery-Funds"">relies on taxpayer handouts merely to stay afloat</a>, an industry dependent upon <a href=""https://oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/Big-Oils-Risky-Plastic-Bet-Could-Lead-To-400-Billion-In-Stranded-Assets.html"">a nearly impossible increase in plastics demand.</a> Faced with pending market oversupply, billions of dollars worth of petrochemical projects <a href=""https://www.bizjournals.com/houston/news/2020/07/13/petrochemical-projects-on-hold.html"">have already been abandoned or put on hold.</a></p>

<p>To obscure the ongoing failures of the fracked gas and petrochemical industry, Brouillette <a href=""https://triblive.com/opinion/dan-brouillette-and-peter-navarro-trumps-manufacturing-energy-revival-supports-pa-workers/"">grossly exaggerates the number of Pennsylvania oil and gas jobs</a>, using an <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2020/09/10/at-western-pa-gas-drilling-site-pence-talks-jobs-repeats-falsehoods-on-bidens-fracking-position/"">oft-repeated and debunked claim</a> that overstates the number by at least 600 percent. He then falsely claims that the petrochemical industry <a href=""https://www.foodandwaterwatch.org/insight/cracked-case-green-jobs-over-petrochemicals-pennsylvania"">would bring up to 100,000 new jobs to Pennsylvania.</a>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In contrast to petrochemicals, the renewable energy sector continues to grow exponentially, far outpacing the growth of <a href=""https://e2.org/reports/clean-jobs-pennsylvania-2019/"">shale gas and oil in job creation</a> and <a href=""https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2020/01/15/renewable-energy-is-growing-fast-in-the-u-s-but-fossil-fuels-still-dominate/#:~:text=Over%20the%20past%20decade%2C%20solar,of%20any%20U.S.%20energy%20source.&amp;text=Still%2C%20solar%20accounted%20for%20only,by%20wind%2C%20wood%20and%20biofuels."">energy generation</a>. With only 4 percent of U.S. energy consumption attributed to solar and wind, there is plentiful opportunity &ndash; some might even say necessity &ndash; for future growth.</p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-ebcfa41e-7fff-6459-7394-8b445e496771""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""><span style=""border:none;display:inline-block;overflow:hidden;width:560px;height:557px;""><img height=""557"" src=""https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/dSiZ4h7ouLMFNUQDdqwLV5nCEe6vKshJVBowAMRnS_N5UM-zxuSwJ0P5Mu8lfI7kY8VmYsduT5PLIQhNCiiGgnfQfjNJguS4RjLmkhc6IDvS2s5me8FZffwMCcjLjgjQL8xOQQK7"" style=""margin-left:0px;margin-top:0px;"" width=""560"" /></span></span></span></p>

<p>Meanwhile, the fact that the fossil fuel industry has been forced into a nationwide stagnation resulting <a href=""https://www.businessinsider.com/how-top-oil-companies-are-responding-to-the-price-shock-2020-3"">in layoffs</a>, <a href=""https://ieefa.org/sp-u-s-oil-and-gas-industry-distressed-debt-now-at-all-time-high/"">debt,</a> and <a href=""https://www.visualcapitalist.com/tracking-the-growing-wave-of-oil-gas-bankruptcies-in-2020/"">bankruptcy</a> has not deterred Brouillette&rsquo;s enthusiasm, even as the so-called &ldquo;energy companies&rdquo; increasingly turn towards non-energy products like plastics, fertilizers, and other chemicals for profit growth.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Yet Brouillette and his Department of Energy continue to promote the development of an Appalachian petrochemical hub, despite or perhaps because of the industry&#39;s continued struggle to get off the ground.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Secretary Brouillette&rsquo;s personalized tour of the Shell Petrochemical Plant last week was in fact preceded <a href=""https://www.energy.gov/articles/appalachian-energy-and-petrochemical-renaissance"">by a June 2020 report</a> on the future of petrochemicals in Appalachia, stressing the necessity of maximizing public support for the industry. The report says that regional petrochemical growth requires the public sector to abandon its &ldquo;business-as-usual&rdquo; approach and embrace the industry with public (i.e. taxpayer) investment, supportive policies, and propaganda about the potential economic opportunity.</p>

<p>In Pennsylvania, this means <a href=""https://www.goodjobsfirst.org/shell-cracks-pennsylvania%E2%80%99s-tax-code#:~:text=The%20legislation%20did%20not%20name,what%20Shell%20plans%20to%20do."">a $1.65 billion tax break for Shell Petrochemicals</a>, a <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2020/07/14/Pennsylvania-petrochemical-tax-credit-fertilizer-dry-natural-gas-Marcellus-Utica-fracking/stories/202007140122"">$667.5 million tax break for qualifying petrochemical plants</a>, and a persistent misinformation campaign about <a href=""https://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/frack-check-trump-inflates-pennsylvania-fracking-job-figures-by-3500-percent/Content?oid=17937555"">the number of fracking jobs in the state.</a></p>

<p>&ldquo;The competitive aspects of [the Shell Petrochemical Plant] is just enormous,&rdquo; he assured reporters last week, as his dystopian vision of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s future materialized before his eyes. &ldquo;I wouldn&rsquo;t be surprised to see competitors to Shell show up in the very near future.&rdquo;</p>

<p>It goes to show that, regardless of the end product, Brouillette&rsquo;s Energy Department is more invested in fossil fuel exploitation than it is in securing a secure and sustainable energy supply for our country.</p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Emily Persico, Policy Analyst"
LNG in PA Blog #5: Public opposition grows to proposed LNG shipping terminals,9/25/2020,"<p>Before New Fortress Energy announced their risky plan to ship millions of gallons of liquified natural gas across the state&rsquo;s rail lines, perhaps they should have consulted with the emergency responders who would have to clean up a spill or one of many other potential catastrophes the project could bring.</p>

<p>With no risk assessment, no public safety analysis and no environmental review of the potential hazards to communities along the possible LNG transport routes, a growing chorus of local officials are denouncing the New Fortress Energy plan and insisting that state regulators stop the scheme in its tracks.</p>

<p>Over the past month, resolutions opposing the local transportation of LNG by rail or truck were approved by <a href=""https://legistarweb-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/attachment/pdf/694747/Resolution-2020_Opposing_Transportation_of_Liquefied_Natural_Gas.pdf"">Scranton City Council</a> and <a href=""https://delawareriverkeeper.org/sites/default/files/copies_four_reso.pdf"">Clarks Summit Borough Council</a> in Lackawanna County, <a href=""https://delawareriverkeeper.org/sites/default/files/copies_four_reso.pdf"">Kutztown Borough Council</a> in Berks County, and the <a href=""https://delawareriverkeeper.org/sites/default/files/copies_four_reso.pdf"">Lehigh County Board of Commissioners</a>. Similar concern is being raised by four at-large members of <a href=""https://delawareriverkeeper.org/sites/default/files/letter from officials in Philly.pdf"">Philadelphia City Council</a> and a member of the Pennsylvania House representing Northeast Philadelphia, citing the overwhelming hazards to residents with no benefits.</p>

<p>In addition to denouncing the inherent risks of LNG ground transport, these resolutions and letters of opposition are requesting the Delaware River Basin Commission deny New Fortress Energy&rsquo;s permit to build an LNG shipping terminal. If approved, the Gibbstown, New Jersey terminal would be the last major hurdle for <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-4-Liquified-Natural-Gas-Should-Not-Become-the-New-Bomb-Trains-to-Threaten-Our-Communities"">so-called &ldquo;bomb trains&rdquo; to carry dangerous LNG</a> through unprepared communities from a proposed facility in Wyalusing, Bradford County.</p>

<p>PennFuture joined with over 120 other organizations in demanding that the DRBC, the multi-state regulatory agency tasked with protecting waters of the Delaware River, reject the permit that would allow LNG to be exported from an expanded Gibbstown facility.&nbsp; The DRBC also received more than 71,000 petition signatures to stop the project.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Clearly, public opposition is having an effect. Earlier this month, three of the state commissioners <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/business/philadelphia-lng-gibbstown-new-fortress-energy-port-drbc-fracking-trains-20200920.html"">voted to delay approval and to stay any further construction</a> until DRBC issues a final permit decision.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture welcomes the decision by the governors of Delaware, New Jersey and New York (Pennsylvania abstained) to take a &ldquo;careful look&rdquo; at the dangers of LNG.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Shipping LNG by rail or by train is dangerous on multiple levels. In addition to the risks of an accident during transport, LNG opens new markets to fracked gas, perpetuating the industry&rsquo;s disastrous environmental footprint throughout Pennsylvania. LNG production and distribution results in greater emissions, hazards and energy use by adding major steps to the supply chain between well heads and consumers.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As the region determines our energy future, neither the Wyalusing production facility or Gibbstown shipping terminal should be part of the path forward. DRBC and local and state leaders should listen to public concern and prevent these wrong-minded projects from moving ahead.</p>
