",Community; Energy; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Stonycreek River Restoration Shows Power of Conservation Efforts,9/16/2020,"<p><em>Editor&rsquo;s note: Melissa Reckner is one of 11 amazing women being honored during PennFuture&rsquo;s 2020 <strong>&ldquo;Women in Conservation&rdquo;</strong> event on Oct. 8. For more information, and for ticket info, <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/wic2020virtual/index.html"">please click this link now!</a>&nbsp;</em></p>

<p>Growing up along the Stonycreek River in northern Somerset County, I experienced a waterway that was orange, slimy, and largely devoid of life.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Thirty years later, I can go back to those riverbanks and overlook a much cleaner Stonycreek<span style=""font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;
mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin"">&mdash;<o:p></o:p></span>one that harbors a growing diversity of fish, attracts whitewater enthusiasts from over a dozen states, and is often heralded as a &ldquo;Cinderella&rdquo; success story.&nbsp;</p>

<p>However, this fairy tale is far from over.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2018, I published the <a href=""https://conemaughvalleyconservancy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/SOW_FINALElectronic.pdf"">State of the Kiski-Conemaugh River Watershed: Community Shift</a>, a document that quantified changes in this 1,888 square-mile watershed, which includes the Stonycreek River. This document shows how water chemistry and fish assemblages have changed in this basin&rsquo;s major rivers and highlights the watershed organizations that work with local, state, and federal agencies to make streams healthier, net alkaline, diverse, and attractive.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Many people have commented how they did not think this could happen in their lifetime and proves that Mother Nature just needs a helping hand, which has come from countless professional and volunteer hours, millions of dollars, and dozens of projects.</p>

<p>While treatment systems have remediated a lot of Abandoned Mine Drainage (AMD)<span style=""font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;
mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin"">&mdash;<o:p></o:p></span>once the number one source of pollution in Western Pennsylvania - these systems require routine maintenance and do have life spans that must be addressed before they fail.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Flushing pipes, removing animal obstructions, replenishing compost and limestone, collecting samples, cutting vegetation, and similar chores are not necessarily fun tasks, but they are necessary in keeping these life-sustaining projects going. Even one day of failure could kill aquatic life, coat streams with iron and aluminum oxides, and ruin decades of work and restoration.</p>

<p>The work of ensuring this does not happen often falls to watershed associations, conservation districts, and similar organizations that don&rsquo;t necessarily have the funds, expertise, or staff to see to these tasks.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Partnerships help alleviate the pressure, but many are in the same boat<span style=""font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;
mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin"">&mdash;<o:p></o:p></span>trying to do a lot with a little and often with an aging volunteer base. And despite years of education and awareness, there is still a disconnect between those communities downstream<span style=""font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;
mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin"">&mdash;<o:p></o:p></span>the ones receiving the benefits of labor completed in headwater streams with some contributors aligning their areas of interests to political, not geographic boundaries or grantors wanting to fund the new, hip project, when basic operations and maintenance are needed.</p>

<p>Watershed groups and similar organizations will continue to see to these tasks, while trying to be innovative, fresh, and creative, but they could use support through the gifting of individuals&rsquo; time, talents, and treasures. We all live in a watershed and there are many ways in which people may get involved.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>People are needed to:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Serve on organizational boards so business may be conducted&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Generate enthusiasm and new ideas</li>
	<li>Assist with research, construction, or service projects</li>
	<li>Use their connections and solicit memberships and donations</li>
	<li>Write and manage grants &ndash; do the paperwork and spreadsheets!</li>
	<li>Maintain the group&rsquo;s social media presence&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Correspond with local and regional media</li>
	<li>Plan and help with events, like litter cleanups or recycling days.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>Everyone has a skill set that can be beneficial to conservation organizations. No doubt, picking up litter, for example, is not the most fun, but working with a great group of people makes it more enjoyable and the feeling of satisfaction afterwards is very rewarding.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s not all work and no play! Celebrations are necessary to pause and promote reflection on hard-fought accomplishments, recognize the story this work is fashioning, strengthen the sense of comradery that comes from working with awesome people, and share the joy in knowing the world is a little better because a watershed group believed it could make a difference. They are also an opportunity to look to the future, theorizing ways our environment and people&rsquo;s connection to it could be stronger. Plus, you need days to reap the rewards of your work and restore your soul; maybe cast a line and do an informal &ldquo;fish survey!&rdquo;</p>

<p>I&rsquo;ve been blessed to work and volunteer with organizations that spearheaded restoration projects and initiatives that have brought life back to my Stonycreek<span style=""font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;
mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin"">&mdash;<o:p></o:p></span>a river that I still call home<span style=""font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;
mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin"">&mdash;<o:p></o:p></span>and many more waterways, and I&rsquo;m driven to see more stream miles restored.&nbsp;</p>

<p>There are a couple significant tributaries to the Stonycreek, for instance, that have seemingly insurmountable pollution problems, but I think fairy tales can come true with hard work, passion, and persistence.</p>
",Community; Environment,"Melissa Reckner - Program Manager for Penguin Court, Brandywine Conservancy"
"Despite roadblocks from Legislature, RGGI rulemaking process advances",9/15/2020,"<p>In February, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fallacy-Fiction-and-Falsehoods-Debunking-RGGI-Myths-Part-1"">PennFuture&nbsp;wrote a blog post</a> debunking a number of myths surrounding Pennsylvania&rsquo;s future participation in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI). In the seven months since that time, we have some more modeling data and new insights into the benefits of RGGI, but the fossil fuel industry and their friends are still spreading many of the same myths, and sometimes outright lies, to kill the program before it starts.</p>

<p>Particularly in the Legislature, the bias is so blatant it would be comical if the issue was not so serious.&nbsp;Representative Daryl Metcalfe has held several hearings in the House Environmental Resources and Energy committee where he only invited notorious climate deniers, fossil fuel industry advocates, and anti-RGGI speakers to attend. Rep. Metcalf also angrily upbraided the committee&rsquo;s minority chair for pointing out the minority wasn&rsquo;t given the customary courtesy of inviting speakers or even making opening remarks.</p>

<p>The Senate followed this pattern by having a hearing that they pretended was about the impacts of RGGI on employment, but didn&rsquo;t invite any of the hundreds of employees from the Beaver Valley nuclear plant whose jobs have already been saved by RGGI.&nbsp;They also ignored the fact that RGGI is expected to result in a net increase of 27,000 Pennsylvania jobs and didn&rsquo;t talk to anyone from the industries that will see the most growth, they only talked to workers in a limited subset of the fossil fuel industry.</p>

<p>The Legislature didn&rsquo;t stop there.&nbsp;They have also pushed bills not just to limit the DEP&rsquo;s authority to adopt a cap-and-invest program, but also to stop practically any action at all to address the growing climate crisis.&nbsp;Fortunately, while these bills passed in the Legislature, they didn&rsquo;t garner the support of two-thirds of the legislature so it is doubtful proponents will garner enough votes to override Governor Wolf&rsquo;s expected veto.</p>

<p>Although the RGGI proposal has already received unprecedented scrutiny before external reviewers, advisory committees, the Legislature, and in the media, we constantly hear the refrain from the opposition that the people need to have their voice heard.&nbsp;As those making such claims should know, the Regulatory Review Act (RRA) has detailed requirements for just such public participation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The fact this was always a disingenuous claim intended to disrupt the process is clear. The Environmental Quality Board (EQB) was asked on September 15, 2020 to formally open a public 60-day public comment period and hold at least five public hearings on the proposed rule (both more than what is required under the RRA) and the opposition opposed doing so.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Fortunately, a majority of the EQB members did see the need to initiate the full public participation process and voted to formally propose the rule. With that vote the DEP can move forward and give everyone the opportunity to submit written comments or testify at one of several public hearings.&nbsp;These comments&mdash;along with responses provided by the DEP&mdash;will all become part of the official record as the package moves forward and will also be made available to the Independent Regulatory Review Commission (IRRC).</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s clear that, as much as the fossil fuel industry and their friends try, they cannot refute the fundamental truth that coal generation is failing in Pennsylvania and nationwide because it can&rsquo;t compete with cheaper alternatives&mdash;primarily natural gas but increasingly wind and solar energy as well. They may lie to workers and pretend that these coal jobs will be around for years to come, but their actions of the industry and those of their financiers speak louder than words. If they believed that coal could be competitive, we would see investments in new plants&mdash;we aren&rsquo;t.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Some may hope new technologies like carbon capture and storage (CCS) will make it possible to burn coal without emitting huge amounts of greenhouse gasses, but for all its potential benefits, CCS isn&rsquo;t going to make coal generation cheaper. Ignoring the facts and wishing things were different won&rsquo;t reverse the decline of coal generation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Fortunately, we have the opportunity to invest in sustainable alternatives, which can happen by implementing a cap-and-invest program compatible with RGGI as the EQB&nbsp;has just proposed. As Senator Santarsiero pointed out at the EQB meeting, polls <a href=""https://paenvironmentdaily.blogspot.com/2020/05/new-pa-poll-72-of-pennsylvania-voters.html"">have repeatedly shown</a> that strong majorities of Pennsylvanian&rsquo;s support strong policies like these to promote clean air and cut carbon pollution.&nbsp;Now is the time for their voices to be heard.</p>

<p>The Legislature could, of course, play a constructive role in reducing carbon emissions, providing sustainable jobs for our workers, and supporting communities impacted by the inevitable closure of coal-fired power plants.&nbsp;Two bills have been introduced that would do just that&mdash;SB15 (Costa) in the Senate and HB 2856 (Comitta) in the House both take just such an approach.</p>

<p>PennFuture looks forward to championing both bills, and the ongoing rulemaking process surrounding the proposed cap-and-invest program in Pennsylvania.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
LNG in PA Blog #4: Liquified Natural Gas Should Not Become the New Bomb Trains to Threaten Our Communities,9/9/2020,"<p>Communities across Eastern Pennsylvania are at the center of a new debate over whether fracked gas and its byproducts, specifically liquified natural gas (LNG), can be safely produced and transported to new markets. As the LNG project in Bradford County moves ahead, the debate will morph into an experiment in freight design and fuel transport. Put simply, those who live along Pennsylvania&rsquo;s rail lines will be at risk.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Following federal approval in July, the first bulk transport of LNG by rail will potentially travel from Wyalusing to an export terminal in Gloucester County, New Jersey, crossing through the Wyoming, Lehigh and Delaware valleys along the way.</p>

<p>On August 18, <a href=""https://www.law.nyu.edu/centers/state-impact/press-publications/press-releases/lng-by-rail-challenge"">Pennsylvania joined 14 state attorney generals</a> to sue the federal government on grounds that shipping LNG by rail is absurdly dangerous. On the same day, <a href=""https://whyy.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/LNG-by-Rail-enviros-petition-for-review.pdf"">a coalition of environmental groups</a> likewise challenged the health and safety of the U.S. Department of Transportation&rsquo;s new LNG-by-rail regulations.</p>

<p>Petitioners argue LNG transport rules, finalized by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA) on July 24, fail to offer sufficient public safety rules and lack evaluation of environmental impacts. Attorney General Josh Shapiro described LNG rail transport as &ldquo;extremely dangerous&rdquo; and potentially &ldquo;explosive.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Transporting LNG would risk creating &ldquo;bomb trains,&rdquo; posing new hazards to communities and habitats along its path. Read PennFuture&rsquo;s previous articles <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-Series-1-What-is-Liquefied-Natural-Gas"">describing the&nbsp;basics of LNG</a> and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-Series-1-What-is-Liquefied-Natural-Gas"">detailing the threats posed by transporting LNG on rail.</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The PHMSA rule <a href=""https://www.regulations.gov/document?D=PHMSA-2018-0025-0480"">allows LNG to travel by rail in tanker cars</a> never before used to transport LNG. DOT-113 cars would need to add enhanced, thicker carbon steel outer tanks. These enhancements would make the cars heavier than almost any other freight. How these enhanced tanker cars would withstand a rail accident remains unknown.</p>

<p>Bomb trains would be subject to a new speed limit of up to 50 mph. Yet the limit would be voluntary. Federal Railroad Administration officials have noted tank cars are unlikely to survive impacts at even 30 mph.</p>

<p><a href=""https://www.regulations.gov/document?D=PHMSA-2018-0025-0078"">The National Transportation Safety Board</a> and <a href=""https://www.regulations.gov/document?D=PHMSA-2018-0025-0096"">the National Association of State Fire Marshals</a> have both objected to the PHMSA rule. PHMSA claims DOT-113 cars have a track record of transporting other cryogenic flammable materials. But these cars have experienced numerous failures while transporting other, less dangerous cargoes.&nbsp;</p>

<p>A study by <a href=""https://www.iaee.org/en/publications/newsletterdl.aspx?id=460"">University of Wyoming professor Charles Mason</a>&mdash;paid for by the Charles Koch Foundation&mdash;acknowledges the danger of rail transport of crude oil. From 2010 to 2016, the study tracked 75 oil spill incidents. Although the spill rate has fallen in recent years, at its peak rail-related spills occurred once for every 1-2 million barrels (about 90 million gallons) shipped.</p>

<p>The Pennsylvania LNG plant developer, New Fortress Energy, plans to ship 3.5 million gallons of LNG per day by either freight or truck. That&rsquo;s equivalent to three rail tank cars per day. Recently, <a href=""http://www.lrwy.net/index.php/latest-news"">Lehigh Railway announced a five-year lease</a> to TranZ, &ldquo;a bulk material handling company serving the needs of the energy industry,&rdquo; to operate a rail-truck transfer station in Wyalusing.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The exact route LNG trains would take is not yet public information, <a href=""https://www.delawareriverkeeper.org/ongoing-issues/lng-gibbstown-interactive-map"">but Delaware Riverkeeper Network maps out</a> two potential routes.</p>

<p>From the Wyalusing plant, Lehigh Railway would carry the bomb trains until the railway interchanges with the Reading &amp; Northern Railroad lines at Mehoopany in Wyoming County. From there, trains would likely travel alongside the Susquehanna River through Lackawanna and Luzerne counties, then south through Carbon, Schuylkill and Berks counties. Once arriving in Reading, cargo would travel along a Norfolk Southern line to Philadelphia or via Trenton. <a href=""https://gis.penndot.gov/BPR_pdf_files/MAPS/Statewide/parail.pdf"">See the Pennsylvania Railroad Map.</a></p>

<p>PennFuture fully supports this litigation aimed at protecting our communities and environment from the threat of bomb trains carrying the highly explosive LNG. We will be sure to update you with any information and will continue to do all we can to limit this threat from LNG in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>
",Community; Energy,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
LNG in PA Blog #3: Protect Northern PA,9/3/2020,"<p><em>Editor&#39;s Note: This is the third installment of the LNG in PA blog series. The first blog answered the question, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-Series-1-What-is-Liquefied-Natural-Gas"">What is Liquefied Natural Gas?</a> and the second blog, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-LNG-in-PA-Blog-2-Bomb-Trains-Through-Pennsylvania"">Bomb Trains Through Pennsylvania</a>, revealed the dangers of transporting LNG by rail.&nbsp;In this blog, guest writer and PennFuture board member Diana Dakey shares her experiences in the ongoing fight against the construction of a dry LNG facility in Bradford County, PA.&nbsp;</em></p>

<p>In the second half of 2019, news slowly trickled out that a Liquified Natural Gas (LNG) plant was permitted by DEP and received the necessary zoning conditions from Wyalusing Township in Bradford County, PA.&nbsp;</p>

<p>People in surrounding counties who learned about the project argued the public was not consulted in the decision-making process to put up an industrial plant that will impact several counties and two states.&nbsp;Concerned people started researching the issue and formed a committee: Protect Northern PA.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As we considered what to call ourselves, we agreed that the concept of protection is key. If a massively dangerous project could (and did) get approved, what else might?&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Protect Northern PA realized that the threat is fracked-gas industrialization.&nbsp;There is a harmful feedback loop at play in Northern PA. Cheap and plentiful fracked gas attracts industrial promoters who want to process that gas.&nbsp;The fracking companies need to find new outlets for their gas. As Pennsylvania allows gas processing plants to be built, demand for fracking increases. The feedback loop is established.&nbsp;</p>

<p>A company called New Fortress Energy LLC, with a local subsidiary called Bradford County Real Estate Partners LLC, is poised to start building an LNG plant in the historic Browntown district of Wyalusing Township, between Route 6 and the Susquehanna River.&nbsp;Valuable historical resources are being lost. Browntown was the site of the Friedenshutten settlement of Moravians and Susquehannocks in the 1700s.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Why this project in this place?&nbsp;</p>

<p>The New Fortress Energy scheme claims to have a plan to make LNG from gas brought from local gathering lines and ship it out by rail and/or truck.&nbsp;One way to understand the impact that fracked gas is having on a region is to look at Act 13 payments.&nbsp;Also known as impact fees, Act 13 payments are distributed in part to communities affected by fracked gas.&nbsp;Act 13 payment reports show that this LNG project&nbsp;is situated among counties where there was high gas production in 2018 and 2019. It is also located near Norfolk Southern rail lines along the Susquehanna River.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As you have been reading, there is an abundance of natural gas, the price is low, so how would gas producers and related industries make money? By exporting it!&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>LNG is the export form of natural gas.&nbsp;By making a liquid out of a gas, the gas can be transported in containers. This is the form in which gas is moved around the globe.&nbsp;The New Fortress Energy scheme plans to move the LNG by tanker truck or rail from Wyalusing Township&nbsp;to a planned export port in Gibbstown, NJ, for export to foreign markets.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The current federal administration is promoting LNG exports, and a presidential executive order directed various federal agencies to expedite LNG export.&nbsp;Promoters of LNG exportation talk about &ldquo;energy independence.&rdquo;&nbsp;The irony is that LNG exporting, by creating more international demand, can actually drive up the price of gas for U.S. consumers and manufacturers.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>But exporters can make money for their investors by locking in contracts overseas.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Marcellus region is being colonized for resource extraction, and Pennsylvanians are exporting greenhouse gasses that exacerbate climate change.&nbsp; A &ldquo;resource curse,&rdquo; occurs where an economy becomes dependent on one industry.</p>

<p>Let&rsquo;s not go there. Instead, let&rsquo;s control what happens to our communities.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Wyalusing plant, according to our calculation of figures New Fortress Energy told Wyalusing Township, will fill 350 tanker trucks per day, or 15 tanker trucks per hour, 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.&nbsp;That is a harmful amount of traffic through Pennsylvania communities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The LNG may move by rail. In December of 2019, a subsidiary of New Fortress Energy, called Energy Transport Solutions, received a special permit to transport LNG in&nbsp;rail cars.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Whether by tanker truck or rail, the overland transport of this LNG will affect numerous counties and two states by the movement of highly flammable material.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But DEP permits did not look at the environmental harms caused by gas transport.&nbsp;One of the things in the recent Attorney General report that resonates with us is harms caused by truck traffic.&nbsp;DEP permitting does not look at truck traffic related to gas processing facilities or conduct area-wide assessments.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Another lasting impact the Bradford County LNG plant would have is the decades-long continuation of fracking that would have to occur to provide that gas feedstock.&nbsp;Fracking isn&rsquo;t just putting a pipe in the ground. The well pad needs to be constructed. Water needs be drawn from area rivers and streams.&nbsp;Sand needs to be brought in. Fracking waste needs to be taken to a disposal site; new disposal sites may be needed.&nbsp;Then, gas needs to be moved through gathering lines and pipelines to the LNG plant. A compressor station might be needed.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>How did this project get permitted?&nbsp;</p>

<p>In Pennsylvania, that&rsquo;s easy. Fracking is a legal activity and there is a lot of gas here, with people angling to profit from its extraction and sale.&nbsp;We have a fragmented system of local government, where zoning is done at the municipality level. (Some counties have more county-wide planning than others.)&nbsp; For the Bradford County LNG plant, all it took was for township supervisors to approve conditional use zoning changes.&nbsp;Under the PA municipalities planning code, there is no requirement that one township consult with other municipalities to do this. And forget about consulting with other counties!</p>

<p>The other problem is that very few people are required to be informed about a project.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Something called an Act 14 notice needs to be filed with the municipality where there will be earthmoving. It is for compliance with the NPDES permit &ndash; National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System. DEP requires only that the Act 14 notice go to the &ldquo;host&rdquo; municipality and the county.&nbsp;Most counties simply file these notices because&nbsp;they have no mandate to advertise.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The New Fortress Energy plant received only two permits: for Air Quality and Site Disturbance. All other activities with the impacts that are ancillary to the LNG plant will be permitted separately to different companies.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Unless your local press is on top of things, the only way to find out what projects are being proposed in your area, is to sign up for DEP&rsquo;s eNOTICES or read the weekly PA Bulletin.&nbsp; Even then, you will not see the relationships of the various parts of the project: such as pipelines, compressor stations, well pads, waste disposal sites, water withdraws, and sand importation.&nbsp;When you go to the DEP eFACTS website, there is no way to connect the dots to one industrial project.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Projects are not only segmented at DEP, they are also segmented among other state agencies. For example, DEP does not coordinate with PennDOT. (Regardless, PennDOT cannot restrict anticipated volumes of traffic or trucks by type.). Pennsylvania has no agency coordinating siting of pipelines. It is all worked out between the pipeline company landmen and landowners. The Susquehanna River Basin Commission approves withdrawals of water for fracking and industrial use.&nbsp;</p>

<p>On the Protect Northern PA website there is information about how you can delve into publicly available sources of information.&nbsp;This lack of area-wide information and input is a major problem that Protect Northern PA wants to address.&nbsp;Public engagement is much needed, especially now that our legislature, wrongly, passed legislation to give tax incentives to petrochemical facilities to use northeastern PA&rsquo;s &ldquo;dry&rdquo; natural gas.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Protect Northern PA doesn&rsquo;t have all the answers, but we encourage the public to engage with us on how communities can build their defenses.&nbsp;Our website launched last month. <a href=""https://protectnorthernpa.org/"">Please check it out.</a>&nbsp;There is a place for individuals to sign up in order to stay in the loop or volunteer with our effort.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p><em>Protect Northern PA is an alliance of community members, environmental groups, civic organizations, and local businesses formed to critically examine potential air, water, public health, safety, and climate threats from the natural gas industry in the Marcellus Shale region of Pennsylvania. We share a concern that a gas-related industrial buildout will negatively and irreversibly change the environment and character of the region.</em></p>
",,"Diana Dakey, PennFuture Board Member"
Pennsylvania's Unions Must Look to the Future,9/2/2020,"<p>My maternal and paternal grandfathers were immigrants from Italy.&nbsp;Both worked in coal breakers in the anthracite region of northeast Pennsylvania, cracking and cleaning the raw coal that fueled America and the world.&nbsp;As members of the United Mineworkers of America (UMW), they faithfully paid their dues, and revered John L Lewis.</p>

<p>Both would have been appalled by what we&rsquo;re&nbsp;seeing today&mdash;Pennsylvania&rsquo;s unions willing to give up their hard-fought rights to a healthy workplace and healthy community for jobs.</p>

<p>My understanding of the diverse forces and players that make up the labor movement is gleaned from family stories told by grandfathers and uncles that were involved in the UMW. One told stories of being exploited by mine owners, but also by the unions themselves, especially around election day. Perhaps his illiteracy made him an easy target. Their history mimics the imperfect state history of labor unions, but even my&nbsp;family&rsquo;s fraught experience couldn&rsquo;t prepare me for the dualities of&nbsp;today&rsquo;s labor movement.</p>

<p>Last week, for the first time in its 14-year history, the Blue Green Alliance&mdash;a collaboration among national environmental and labor interests&mdash;<a href=""https://www.bluegreenalliance.org/the-latest/in-first-ever-presidential-endorsement-bluegreen-alliance-announces-support-for-joe-biden-for-president-and-kamala-harris-for-vice-president/"">endorsed Joe Biden</a> and Kamala Harris for President and Vice President.&nbsp;The alliance cited the campaign&rsquo;s plan to address climate change and create good-paying green jobs to rebuild the economy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Independent of this joint endorsement, national unions made the same endorsement, including the United Steelworkers of America, United Association of Union Plumbers and Pipefitters, International Union of Bricklayers, and the Utility Workers Union of America.</p>

<p>This union worldview is in stark comparison to what happened a month earlier in our state. The Pennsylvania Building Trades and AFL-CIO unions mounted an intense lobbying effort to win more than $670 million in subsidies to build four facilities that will turn fracked gas into fertilizers and other chemicals. The workers that will construct these facilities are guaranteed union-scale wages through a historic prevailing wage provision in the bill.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>But the effort is also supporting the expansion of hardcore chemical manufacturing into more rural parts of Pennsylvania that, to date, have enjoyed relatively toxic-free jobs until fracked gas drilling, pipelines&mdash;and now&mdash;chemical manufacturing was pushed into their backyards. Like the other petrochemical hubs in the United States, these facilities will soak communities and workers in toxics and exacerbate our climate system.</p>

<p>These actions by organized labor&mdash;a few weeks apart&mdash;are not only in competition with each other, but unsustainably opposed.</p>

<p>Despite decades of bitterly fought battles to win workers&rsquo; rights, elements of labor have lost some of its origin story and true north&mdash;that our workforce deserves and can have good paying jobs that don&rsquo;t destroy one&rsquo;s health or pollute their communities.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>On the flip side, other elements of labor embrace the opportunity to be part of building a 21st Century economy&mdash;one that is sustainable, equitable, and inclusive. PennFuture is proud to be part of an emerging collaboration to charter a new economic development future&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.facebook.com/ReImagineAppalachia/posts/153365683049872"">called Reimagine Appalachia.</a> Their platform is bringing together worker rights, environmental, and justice concerns in ways I have not previously experienced in my decades of environmental work. This approach is having good results with a broad base of endorsements in hand. And we hope one day soon to have organized labor at the table to help shape this platform.</p>

<p>The sentiments expressed <a href=""https://www.penncapital-star.com/commentary/we-shouldnt-have-to-choose-between-a-clean-environment-and-more-jobs-we-can-have-both-opinion/"">in a recent editorial by the principals of the Pennsylvania AFL-CIO</a> does little to build bridges or strengthen any semblance of a possible blue green collaboration in this state. Actions speak louder than words and there was nothing inclusive about the &ldquo;bipartisan&rdquo; deal that these actors helped cut behind closed doors to expand petrochemical manufacturing, which the writers conveniently lump into their editorial&rsquo;s&nbsp;energy argument.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The viewpoints therein show a disconnect from the reality of climate change and what truly competitive workforces right now are focusing&nbsp;on: it is not fossil fuels, or an all of the above energy portfolio This is a body that is unprepared to make the really hard choices, but is choosing a climate-sane future really that hard to make?&nbsp;</p>

<p>We can have family-sustaining jobs and a good environment. They&rsquo;re not mutually exclusive. Pennsylvania&rsquo;s unions need to look to the future and not just its dirty past. As it stands now, many&nbsp;stand&nbsp;in direct opposition to what PennFuture and so many of our partners and allies embrace as the needed solutions to meet the climate crisis in a timely way, as guided by science: a break from fossil fuels.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The solutions must include devising an economy in Pennsylvania where labor leaders of the future will pursue work opportunities in sustainable sectors that are actually good for&nbsp;the environment.&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Energy,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
Pennsylvania Continues to Miss Chesapeake Bay Commitments,8/26/2020,"<p>Despite recent planning efforts by the state and a renewed vigor in Chesapeake Bay cleanup efforts, Pennsylvania continues to lag behind in its progress reports.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Recently, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2020-07/documents/pa_2018_2019_2020_2021_final_milestone_evaluation.pdf"">released an evaluation of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s efforts</a> to reduce nitrogen, phosphorous and sediment pollution into the Chesapeake Bay Watershed by 2025. The evaluation found that, once again, Pennsylvania failed to meet its targets for the reporting period.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The evaluation calls out several of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s major shortcomings, including a plan that falls short of nitrogen-reduction milestones by a whopping 9.8 million tons. In addition, 70 percent of developed land across the state continues to be located outside the jurisdiction of municipal stormwater programs.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s clear that Pennsylvania has a long way to go.</p>

<p>One of the biggest hurdles in cleaning up our local waterways is the lack of a comprehensive funding strategy. <a href=""http://files.dep.state.pa.us/Water/ChesapeakeBayOffice/WIPIII/FinalPlan/PA_Phase_3_WIP_Final.pdf"">Pennsylvania&rsquo;s cleanup plan identified</a> that the state has an annual funding gap of nearly $325 million.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s unfortunately not a surprise that Pennsylvania is failing to meet our Chesapeake Bay obligations. The General Assembly continues to attack environmental regulations and funding while failing to provide an adequate funding strategy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While Pennsylvania has successfully reduced pollution from wastewater treatment plants within the Susquehanna and Potomac watersheds, nitrogen from agricultural runoff continues to account for more than 90 percent of the Bay&rsquo;s 9.8 million ton &ldquo;nitrogen gap.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Due in large part to this high concentration of nitrogen pollution, the Bay&rsquo;s overall ecosystem health scored a C- <a href=""https://ecoreportcard.org/report-cards/chesapeake-bay/bay-health/"">in an annual assessment issued in May</a> by the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science.&nbsp;</p>

<p>More than half of Pennsylvania flows into the Chesapeake Bay Watershed. The Susquehanna and Potomac Rivers empty directly into the Bay.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Poor water quality is not a problem uniquely found in the Bay. Upstream, one third of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s streams and rivers suffer from impaired water quality. <a href=""https://www.depgis.state.pa.us/2020_Integrated_Report/"">A draft report on the state&rsquo;s compliance</a> with the federal Clean Water Act finds that the number of impaired stream miles has grown by more than 5,500 miles over the past two years.</p>

<p>We need a new direction.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To lead the way, PennFuture will soon issue a detailed roadmap that outlines policy solutions and funding proposals to help Pennsylvania meet its pollution reduction goals. Our plan offers real and concrete solutions to bridge this funding gap, and offers practical solutions for state policymakers to put Pennsylvania back on track toward meeting our clean water goals.&nbsp;</p>

<p>For Pennsylvania, without adequate funding,&nbsp;the path toward improving water quality in the Chesapeake Bay watershed remains murky, but we are hopeful that our roadmap will illuminate the best way forward. Be sure to stay tuned in the coming weeks when we unveil this new plan for clean water!</p>
",Community; Environment,"Renee Reber, Campaign Manager, Watershed Advocacy"
Exploring Pennsylvania: Visiting All 121 State Parks in 303 Days,8/25/2020,"<p>Trevor Nordquist thinks every part of Pennsylvania offers something special and beautiful, and he should know: the 27-year-old just visited each of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s 121 state parks in a span of 303 days!&nbsp;</p>

<p>From kayaking in <a href=""https://www.dcnr.pa.gov/StateParks/FindAPark/CodorusStatePark/Pages/default.aspx"">Codorus State Park</a> in southwestern York County and <a href=""https://www.dcnr.pa.gov/StateParks/FindAPark/BaldEagleStatePark/Pages/default.aspx"">Bald Eagle State Park</a> in Centre County, to biking in <a href=""https://www.dcnr.pa.gov/StateParks/FindAPark/MoraineStatePark/Pages/default.aspx"">Moraine State Park</a> in Butler County, to hiking in just about every park that offered trails, Nordquist has seen more of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s beauty in the last year than most of us experience in entire lifetimes.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But Nordquist, a graduate student at Slippery Rock University in Butler County, first had to leave Pennsylvania to appreciate its beauty.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;Growing up in Pennsylvania, especially when I graduated high school, I wanted out of here,&rdquo; Nordquist recently told PennFuture. &ldquo;I never had an appreciation for this state like I should have.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Nordquist&rsquo;s journey took him to Colorado as part of the AmeriCorps program, and it was there that he became &ldquo;obsessed with the outdoors.&rdquo; Given ten weeks to explore the state after his service ended, the Pennsylvania native set a goal to hike a &ldquo;Fourteener,&rdquo; or one of the 53&nbsp;mountain peaks in Colorado that exceed 14,000 feet.&nbsp;</p>

<p>After spending the summer of 2019 immersed in training and planning, Nordquist accomplished his goal by climbing Grays Peak in the Rocky Mountains right before coming home to Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The experience, he said, opened his eyes to the natural beauty in Pennsylvania he previously ignored.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;When I returned, I realized that I never gave Pennsylvania any credit for also being beautiful, maybe even more beautiful than a majority of the country,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;So I thought I should explore our state parks.&rdquo;</p>

<p>And that&rsquo;s exactly what he did.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Starting on October 15, 2019 at <a href=""https://www.dcnr.pa.gov/StateParks/FindAPark/OilCreekStatePark/Pages/default.aspx"">Oil Creek State Park</a> in Venango County, Nordquist covered&nbsp;about 15,000 miles over the next year to see everything Pennsylvania has to offer.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;I loved every single park that I visited and I&rsquo;m going to start revisiting some beginning this weekend,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;I thought each park offered something special. The trails are very well maintained and clearly marked. I think Pennsylvania sets a great example for what a state parks system should look like.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Specifically, Nordquist said he was &ldquo;blown away by the beauty&quot; of <a href=""https://pawilds.com/"">the Pennsylvania Wilds</a> area&nbsp;that includes <a href=""https://www.fs.usda.gov/allegheny"">the Allegheny National Forest</a> and <a href=""https://visitpottertioga.com/explore/attractions/pennsylvania-grand-canyon/"">the Pennsylvania Grand Canyon</a>, among others, as well as the &ldquo;colonial feel&rdquo; of southern Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>His favorite park was <a href=""https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salt_Springs_State_Park"">Salt Springs State Park</a> in far northeastern Pennsylvania, a park that is home to hemlock trees that are over 500 years old and are among the largest trees in all of Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Calling it &ldquo;quant with numerous waterfalls and meadows full of wildflowers,&rdquo; Nordquist said it was the highlight of his trip. Not so much for <a href=""https://www.dcnr.pa.gov/StateParks/FindAPark/MarshCreekStatePark/Pages/default.aspx"">Marsh Creek State Park</a> in Chester County, he said, because it was jam-packed with visitors and didn&rsquo;t allow for much in the way of exploration.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Regardless, &ldquo;every part of this state offers us something special, and I hadn&rsquo;t realized that before,&rdquo; he said.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Unfortunately, his journey took a very unexpected turn when the COVID-19 pandemic began unfolding in March. Lockdown orders sent residents outdoors and into state parks in unprecedented numbers, which isn&rsquo;t a bad thing on its face. But then came the enormous amounts of litter.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;I saw way too much trash,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;Once COVID hit, everyone started to do more outside activities which is great, but they were not mindful of the environment. I started taking a bag with me and picked up after people. I think people think that there are people hired to clean up after them, so they aren&rsquo;t as mindful of their trash, but I really urge people to start cleaning up.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Another area of concern for Nordquist came when he was reflecting on his journey. Only once during the entire ordeal did he have to worry about driving in snow, which is typically a frequent occurrence during Pennsylvania winters.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;It&rsquo;s not common that we only experience one minor snowfall in any given year, and it really opened my eyes to the threat our world faces regarding climate change,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;Climate change is a real threat.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Nordquist finished his impressive feat in mid-August with a visit to <a href=""https://www.dcnr.pa.gov/StateParks/FindAPark/SusquehannockStatePark/Pages/default.aspx"">Susquehannock State Park</a> in Lancaster County. Now back home and able to reflect more intently on his journey, Nordquist said he hopes his experience inspires other Pennsylvanians to appreciate their homeland, but also to respect it.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;I hope native Pennsylvanians appreciate where they come from,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;Pennsylvania is a great state. But I hope it also brings more awareness to being respectful to nature. I think we need to clean up after one another more. I would love to reach out to my local representatives and have an open discussion with them regarding the topic of environmental protection and my experience and how we can better the state.&rdquo;</p>

<p>At PennFuture, we chose to tell Trevor&rsquo;s story for two reasons: it&rsquo;s an impressive story that highlights all of the beauty Pennsylvania has to offer, but it&rsquo;s also a cautionary tale about funding for our abundant state parks.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Now more than ever, it&rsquo;s crucial that our lawmakers maintain funding to these vital resources, especially because Pennsylvanians are flocking to our state parks in record numbers.&nbsp;</p>

<p>However, a contingent of lawmakers in Harrisburg have previously tried cutting funding for our parks, a move we could see again as the General Assembly works to bridge a significant budget deficit made even worse by the COVID-19 pandemic.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In addition, a new bill has been introduced in Harrisburg<span style=""font-family:"">&mdash;<o:p></o:p></span><a href=""http://www.paenvironmentdigest.com/newsletter/default.asp?NewsletterArticleID=50782&amp;SubjectID="">House Bill 2806</a><span style=""font-family:"">&mdash;<o:p></o:p></span>that would remove the current ban on charging admission and parking fees at our state parks. PennFuture opposes this bill, and any bill that could restrict access to our parks and natural resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Rest assured, PennFuture will be pushing back against this bill, as well as any attempts to gut funding for our parks and natural resources once budget discussions begin in the fall.&nbsp;</p>
",,
REFUTED: CNX’s Eight Irrefutable Energy Truths Expose Industry Desperation,8/11/2020,"<p>Recently, CNX published a blog post called <a href=""https://www.cnx.com/newsroom/cnx-tra/news-post?ID=5"">&ldquo;Nine Irrefutable Energy Truths and a Critical Call to Action.&rdquo;</a>&nbsp;Reading the post then&mdash;which I highly suggest you do&mdash;my first reaction was to laugh. Was this a gag? It was so obviously absurd, it was hard to take it seriously at first. But, as I compose my response to the version <a href=""https://www.pennlive.com/opinion/2020/08/eight-irrefutable-energy-truths-opinion.html"">adapted for Pennlive&rsquo;s Opinion section</a> just last week, the post no longer feels so funny.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As outlandish as it is, Nick DeIuliis&rsquo; opinion piece is a tiny part of a larger, highly sophisticated disinformation campaign that has infiltrated Pennsylvania&rsquo;s everyday reality. While DeIuliis seems to be grasping at straws, the not so funny truth is that these flaccid arguments are starting to gain traction with a public increasingly mistrustful of science. That&rsquo;s why we&rsquo;re debunking these eight irrefutable energy &ldquo;truths&rdquo; with some truths of our own. The main difference: Our truths reflect reality.</p>

<p><u><strong>Irrefutable Truth #1: The Natural Gas Industry is Floundering</strong></u></p>

<p>As logic would tell you, price stress, oversupply, industry bankruptcy, and cancelled pipelines are indeed a sign of failure, despite CNX&rsquo;s bold claims otherwise. To make this claim, author and CNX Director and Chief Executive Officer Nick DeIuliis tells his readers that the good times are coming, comparing the rough start of the fracked gas industry to the early struggles of the information technology sector. Yet as the oil and gas sector flounders, information technology has continued to be the S&amp;P&rsquo;s best performing sector in the last decade. It shouldn&rsquo;t come as a surprise that <a href=""https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/indices/equity/sp-500-energy-sector/#overview"">S&amp;P Energy</a>&mdash;made up of exclusively oil and gas companies&mdash;<a href=""https://ieefa.org/ieefa-update-oil-and-gas-stocks-place-dead-last-in-2019-again-despite-30-price-rise/"">comes dead last.</a></p>

<p>This is what failure looks like.</p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-88872f48-7fff-a00d-17a5-879b86c37387""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""><span style=""border:none;display:inline-block;overflow:hidden;width:635px;height:317px;""><img height=""317"" src=""https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/BRoACa-dP9vDmL_OXo7vqHcY0JF_RJZgP3cRja9DCx74djJrTpgxbcPWax2vs8WtTtIaYJ1HMeNPZIczTllQp8ClhqIarcNdwICRPy2-yHcu076AbqaG_yAoQjRtCwtEQ8RA6cc"" style=""margin-left:0px;margin-top:0px;"" width=""635"" /></span></span></span></p>

<p><u><strong>Irrefutable Truth #2: The Era of Fossil Fuel Dominance is Ending</strong></u></p>

<p>Our society has run on fossil fuels for centuries, shifting from one technology to the next as we innovate and discover new pathways forward: From coal to oil and gas. Yet while fossil fuels have brought us a long way, their exploitation has come at a cost.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Fracked gas is no exception. <a href=""https://www.ucsusa.org/resources/climate-risks-natural-gas?utm_campaign=tw&amp;utm_medium=tw&amp;utm_source=tw#:~:text=An%20estimated%20one%20to%20nine,replacing%20coal%20with%20natural%20gas."">Projected global warming emissions</a> from natural gas are on par with an energy mix dominated by coal, especially when we consider factors like methane leaks (a greenhouse gas many times more potent than carbon dioxide), increased energy demand over time, and the slow decline of carbon-neutral nuclear power. Worse still, fracked gas and associated petrochemical facilities threaten public health with <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/news/environment/2020/08/02/A-decade-of-water-woes-in-Butler-County/stories/202007310107"">contaminated water</a>, <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/22/climate/gas-flares-premature-babies.html?surface=home-discovery-vi-prg&amp;fellback=false&amp;req_id=749127125&amp;algo=identity&amp;imp_id=983713178&amp;action=click&amp;module=Science%20%20Technology&amp;pgtype=Homepage"">premature births</a>, and <a href=""https://www.wsj.com/articles/after-string-of-rare-cancer-cases-pennsylvania-investigates-potential-link-to-fracking-11576837802"">unexplained cancers</a>. Communities of color and low-income communities are especially impacted.</p>

<p>Luckily, we now have the technology to continue the progress of centuries prior while improving outcomes for public health, the environment, and justice. As we have done in the past, we will continue to innovate and move forward, to embrace life- and earth-preserving energy conservation and generation like solar and wind. Renewable energy is <a href=""https://ieefa.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/US-Coal-Outlook-2020_March-2020.pdf"">already forecasted to surpass coal</a> in electricity generation by this year&rsquo;s end and will continue its path forward over the coming decades.</p>

<p><u><strong>Irrefutable Truth #3: Renewables are Winning</strong></u></p>

<p>One challenge for the renewable energy transition is that our existing policies and infrastructure are built to serve the energy systems of the past. This legacy&mdash;of fossil fuel subsidies, of preference for large-scale over community energy generation, and of fossil fuel influence in politics&mdash;slows down the transition to renewables, but it cannot stop it. <a href=""https://www.c2es.org/content/renewable-energy/#:~:text=Renewable%20energy%20is%20the%20fastest,wind%20power%20(6.6%20percent)."">Renewable energy is growing faster</a> than any other energy source in the U.S. Part of the reason is that it&#39;s cheap: Just check out the Forbes article titled <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamesellsmoor/2019/06/15/renewable-energy-is-now-the-cheapest-option-even-without-subsidies/#1486c0475a6b"">&ldquo;Renewable Energy Is Now The Cheapest Option - Even Without Subsidies.&rdquo;</a></p>

<p>Despite this spectacular growth in the face of seemingly insurmountable opposition in the U.S., however, supportive policy is still needed. The necessity to shift to renewable energy is more than economical&mdash;it is a moral obligation. The subsidies propping up the flailing fossil fuel industry must be eliminated and replaced with subsidies that help us address the climate crisis, improve public health, and support home-grown jobs.</p>

<p>And, if you&rsquo;re curious about the greenhouse gas emissions of renewable energy from mining all the way to operation, <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/conference/2015/pdf/presentations/skone.pdf"">be sure to read this</a>.&nbsp;Here&rsquo;s a preview: Despite Nick DeIuliis&rsquo; claim, many honest analyses have been performed, and renewables outperform natural gas every time.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Irrefutable Truth #4: A Zero-Carbon Future is Coming</strong></u></p>

<p>According to an article from the Financial Times, <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/conference/2015/pdf/presentations/skone.pdf"">&ldquo;a&nbsp;zero-carbon future is both feasible and affordable.&rdquo;</a> While this may be difficult to imagine&mdash;even the production of renewable energy sources emit greenhouse gases from mining and transportation of materials&mdash;this future relies heavily on &ldquo;boosting the role of electricity.&rdquo; In this not so faraway future, mining equipment and vehicles for transportation will run on electricity powered by renewable energy.</p>

<p>One reason that CNX might want to sow doubt about this prospect is that <a href=""https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2019/11/04/how-to-reach-us-net-zero-emissions-by-2050-decarbonizing-industry/#28baf9f27cb4"">reducing industry emissions</a>&mdash;67 percent of which come from natural gas, petroleum, chemicals, and plastics industries&mdash;will be absolutely critical. When Nick DeIuliis says that &ldquo;outrage should be directed at academia,&rdquo; what he really means is that undermining science is one of the few options fossil fuel industries have left.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Irrefutable Truth #5: Petrochemicals are the Final Frontier for Fossil Fuel Survival</strong></u></p>

<p>The oil and gas industry is trying to leverage the pandemic to reaffirm its role in a world eager to move on, claiming over and over that &ldquo;plastic saves lives&rdquo;&mdash;from surgical gloves and face masks to ventilators. But what the industry isn&rsquo;t telling you is that 59 percent of polyethylene (the type of plastic that the Shell Petrochemical Plant in Beaver County would produce) is actually used to create packaging like food and beverage containers. As prices for oil and gas plummet and alternatives like solar and wind become more competitive, fossil fuel executives are staking their bet on petrochemicals. But as the attractiveness of this industry grows, more companies are jumping on the bandwagon and creating a massive plastics oversupply. Their success, then, relies on you thinking that plastics&mdash;and a whole lot more of them&mdash;are essential.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Irrefutable Truth #6: Commitment to Fossil Fuels Threatens Our Geopolitical Power</strong></u></p>

<p>Fossil fuels like natural gas exacerbate climate change and threaten environmental health domestically&mdash;but the impacts don&rsquo;t stop there. Our undying commitment to fossil fuels is embarrassing us on an international scale. When the United States decided to leave the Paris Climate Agreement, we not only relinquished our role as a global leader on climate change, but we undermined our reputation broadly.</p>

<p>If you need further evidence, look no further than the situation in which we currently find ourselves. Science denialism&mdash;which fuels our failed response to the climate crisis&mdash;is now hampering our response to another issue of international importance: coronavirus. Unless we start taking science seriously and responding to these crises with the urgency they demand, our reputation as a global leader will continue to falter.</p>

<p><u><strong>Irrefutable Truth #7: A Diversified Economy Sustains the Middle Class</strong></u></p>

<p>Extractive industries have left Pennsylvanian&rsquo;s stranded without jobs time and time again. They set up monopolistic economies reliant upon their success. When profits dry up, companies abandon ship, leaving communities to clean up the health, environmental, and economic mess left in their wake.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This is no way to structure an economy. We need the long-term, life-sustaining jobs of the future, not the dirty jobs of our past. Increasingly, these jobs can be found in industries like energy efficiency, renewable energy, and nature-based small businesses. In fact, despite the fracked gas boom of the past decade, clean energy jobs actually employ twice as many people as the fossil fuel industry in Pennsylvania. The majority of these jobs are in construction and manufacturing.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Irrefutable Truth #8: We Need Your Voice to Combat Industry Mistruths</strong></u></p>

<p>Nick DeIuliis&rsquo; mistruths reek of an industry desperate to stay afloat. It is clear that fossil fuel interests will stop at nothing to ensure their legacy of extracting profits continues for as long as possible, despite the consequences for public health, global warming, and environmental protection. Much of that fight is political. It takes place in our newspapers, our schools, and our capitol.</p>

<p>Just weeks ago, legislators passed a bill which provides $667 million dollars of tax breaks to the petrochemical and fertilizer industries over the next 25 years. Other legislation being considered includes enabling community solar, changing the definition of recycling to include harmful plastic incineration, and establishing more public health safeguards from fracked gas. These decisions will impact the immediate future, and their ramifications will be felt for generations to come.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Don&rsquo;t let industry mistruths dominate the conversation&mdash;talk to you legislator today.</p>

<p>Regardless, as fracked gas companies flounder in the past, we will continue to innovate and move forward, to embrace life and earth-preserving energy conservation and generation like solar and wind. Our very future depends on it.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Emily Persico, Policy Analyst"
Senate Bill 15: A New Direction for Pennsylvania,7/30/2020,"<p>The energy industry across the nation is in transition, a fact that is particularly obvious in Pennsylvania.&nbsp; People once talked of &ldquo;king coal,&rdquo; but those days are long gone as new technologies make conventional steam coal plants&mdash;once the mainstay of &ldquo;baseload&rdquo; power&mdash;obsolete and far too expensive.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Politicians like President Donald Trump claim that slashing protections for public health and the environment will bring coal back, but those are nothing but empty campaign promises. Despite an unprecedented number of environmental rollbacks and despite millions of taxpayer dollars wasted on his <a href=""https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/us-to-be-long-on-electricity-coal-closures-may-accelerate-8211-doe-official-58511969"">&ldquo;coalFirst&rdquo; initiative</a>, coal generation in Pennsylvania is one third what it was the day the President took office.</p>

<p>Ohio tried a different approach with HB6, a bill which charges ratepayers an extra $50 million per year to subsidize coal generation, guts standards for clean renewable generation, and subsidizes nuclear power. Despite praise from the fossil fuel industry at a recent committee hearing hosted by Pennsylvania state Rep. Daryl Metcalfe, Ohio&rsquo;s plan is proving to be a spectacular failure. On the very day Rep. Metcalf and his guests were lauding Ohio&rsquo;s approach, Ohio&rsquo;s Speaker of the House was arrested by the FBI on racketeering and bribery charges related to the passage of HB6 and a move to repeal the subsidy program is gaining steam.</p>

<p>Far from coal making a comeback, the few remaining large coal plants in Pennsylvania are all near retirement. No one is investing money in new plants to replace them and many of the traditional coal operators <a href=""https://www.eenews.net/stories/1063430425"">are fleeing the business</a>. It&rsquo;s long past the time that politicians face the facts. Rather than telling lies and making empty promises, they should focus on serious policies to assist the workers and communities that will be impacted when these plants inevitably close.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In addition, our state leadership now faces an additional challenge in helping the state recover from the COVID-19 crisis. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Green-Stimulus-FINAL.pdf"">As PennFuture recently detailed in a report on the topic</a>, that needs to be a green recovery that does more than just fund traditional polluting sources and hoping benefits trickle down.</p>

<p><u><strong>There is a real plan to move Pennsylvania Forward</strong></u></p>

<p>Senator Costa and a number of co-sponsors have just introduced &ldquo;The Energy Transition and Recovery Act&rdquo; (SB15) that, if passed, would help guide the Commonwealth through the coming energy transition and support our workers and communities as we cut carbon emissions and other harmful pollution.</p>

<p>Senate Bill 15 recognizes that while Governor Wolf has the authority to create a RGGI program on his own though the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP), the legislature could work with the Governor to make that program more flexible and make a difference for workers and communities.</p>

<p>RGGI is a market-based program that works by creating a cap on carbon pollution from the electric generation industry. Each ton of allowable emissions under that cap is represented by a single allowance. Facilities can take action to lower their emissions, but if they are going to pollute they need to purchase sufficient allowances at auction. The price of those allowances is set by the market and the proceeds come back to Pennsylvania to be invested in various ways.</p>

<p>DEP is currently developing a RGGI program using the authority granted by the Air Pollution Control Act. Once that program becomes operational, the proceeds from the auction will be deposited into the Clean Air Fund and can be used to support the program itself or be invested in ways that reduce air pollution. That alone can do a lot of good, generating over $2 billion over the first decade of the program, but with the assistance of the Legislature the program could be much more flexible in how the proceeds are used.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Particularly, it is important to provide support to workers and communities that will be impacted by the transition away from coal which is already happening regardless of RGGI.&nbsp; The right thing to do is help communities move away from a reliance on the dying coal industry and toward more prosperous economic activities, including&nbsp; modernizing their skill sets to be compatible with our 21st century economy and incentivizing new industries with long-term growth potential.</p>

<p>The DEP would implement the RGGI program in the same way, but investments of the net proceeds under SB15 would be guided by an energy transition plan. A quarter of the proceeds would still go to the Clean Air Fund, but the remainder would go into a newly created Energy Transition Fund and used for certain types of projects in key categories:</p>

<p style=""margin-left: 40px;"">35% &ndash; Programs to support workers and communities<br />
15% &ndash; Bill assistance for low-income customers<br />
20% &ndash; Weatherization assistance programs<br />
30% &ndash; Solar generation, energy efficiency, and energy demand reduction</p>

<p>While the legislation specifies the categories for funding and the broad goals of the program, the details of what projects are funded and where community support would be prioritized would be guided by an Energy Transition Plan. This plan will be developed by the state agencies involved in transition planning after an extensive public participation process that includes hearings in impacted communities and fossil fuel producing regions of the commonwealth.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The plan must also be approved by a board consisting of agency members, legislative appointees, and representatives of environmental justice areas, labor groups, clean energy companies, energy consuming industries, and others.</p>

<p><u><strong>With this bill, Pennsylvania will be an innovator</strong></u></p>

<p>All the existing RGGI states make investments in energy efficiency, and most also invest in renewable energy and energy bill assistance as well. That has proven to be a success.&nbsp; A recent independent report found that in the first 10 years of the program those investments returned over $5.4 billion in net benefits resulting from $3.2 billion in revenue generated by the RGGI program, producing 1.78 times the benefits compared to the monies invested.</p>

<p>While many of the programs deployed by RGGI states contain implicit job-creation benefits, especially in the areas of renewable energy development and weatherization, the SB15 plan builds on this foundation but goes even further by investing in education, outreach, and job training. Other RGGI states spend an average of just 2 percent on those areas, where this bill would devote 26.25 percent of total proceeds to these efforts. This bill also requires that, in making those investment decisions, the state seek meaningful input and consultation from environmental justice communities as well as labor groups.</p>

<p>This recognition that environmental justice is a key issue for any successful plan is part of a growing trend across states. New Jersey, Maryland, and New York have already taken steps in that direction, but Pennsylvania has the opportunity to show real leadership.</p>

<p>The conventional wisdom may be that the politics of the Pennsylvania Legislature and opposition from fossil-fuel interests will keep SB15 from getting any traction. If so, that will be a big loss for our workers and communities. We have an opportunity to innovate and grow a sustainable economy that will not only help our current recovery, it will keep Pennsylvania an energy leader in the future.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
"PennFuture's ""Democracy for All"" Program At Work in Pennsylvania",7/30/2020,"<p>It is a fact that communities of color are disproportionately impacted by climate change and pollution, and that is not accidental.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

",Community; Environment,"Emily Gale, Director of Civic Engagement"
A New Coalition for a Better Future,7/29/2020,"<p>As of July 23, 2020, it&rsquo;s official&mdash;Pennsylvania has a law that will award four lucky petrochemical or fertilizer manufacturing entities each $6.6 million a year in tax credits for 26 years to set up shop here.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Like the $1.65 billion subsidy the state handed Shell for its Beaver County cracker plant, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s fracked gas industry will once again enjoy the largesse of Pennsylvania taxpayers. The fracked gas industry apparently needs $660 million of the public&rsquo;s help to optimize the use of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Marcellus shale gas into something beyond energy.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>This handout will take its product into the climate-killing and health-risking realm of petrochemical, plastics and fertilizer manufacturing. Apparently the fracked gas industry can&rsquo;t succeed on the basis of significant private investments alone.</p>

<p>The legislation that made this all possible&mdash;<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-responds-to-passage-of-House-Bill-732"">HB 732</a>, which was originally crafted to help emergency responders and was amended to include the fracked gas industry tax credit&mdash;was a reworking of <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-Thirty-five-groups-rally-against-House-Bill-1100"">HB 1100</a>, which also provided a petrochemical subsidy, albeit an open-ended one. That legislation passed both chambers but the Governor vetoed it in March.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The petrochemical industry&rsquo;s friends in the state legislature never attempted to overturn that veto because the environmental community and our partners&mdash;with the help of many of you&mdash;mounted a textbook campaign to call attention to the corporate greed and cronyism that defined that bill. And when the Governor vetoed it, our coalition graciously said thank you, and never spiked the ball to celebrate the formidable victory that it was at the time.</p>

<p>In the end, the fight was among special interests in the state, and legislators chose to do the bidding of the building trade unions and the fracking industry, and not the bidding of mainstream interests that our diverse coalition of environmentalists, community, religious and other business leaders represented.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>This law picks winners&mdash;fracked gas, petrochemicals, fertilizers and plastics&mdash;and every other business and industry sector is by omission, a loser, and during a pandemic-induced recession where all sectors need help. As an example, what is the legislature and Governor doing to bolster agriculture and tourism, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s number one and number two industries, respectively?</p>

<p>The deal that became law was struck behind closed doors, by&mdash;dare I say it&mdash;probably mostly white men.&nbsp;I say &ldquo;probably&rdquo; because when environmental leaders like me were asked to be represented at the deal table, we were rejected. Possibly others asked to be part of the conversation and also denied.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I can say with certainty that after the March 9, 2020 rally in the state capitol held by <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fighting-for-Our-Future"">the 35 groups represented in our HB 1100 coalition</a>, a counter rally was held.&nbsp;During that counter-rally, the proponents of taxpayer giveaways for the petrochemical industry reflected predominately white, male demographics.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>For the most part, the legislators, industry, economic development and union faces that gathered this past Friday in northeast Pennsylvania to celebrate the Governor&rsquo;s signing of HB 732, media coverage revealed the same predominate demographics.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>And we should expect that the &ldquo;800&rdquo; temporary and &ldquo;150&rdquo; permanent jobs that each of the four subsidized petrochemical or fertilizer facilities is supposed to employ will also be mostly, and by a large margin, white and male.</p>

<p>Despite a textbook campaign against HB 1100, the interests of many, many Pennsylvanians who desire an economic break from fossil fuels were not represented at the HB 732 deal table. I am concerned that come 2022, when Pennsylvanians go to the polls to elect a new governor&mdash;possibly our last chance to seat a leader who is climate-aware and willing to lead all Pennsylvanians into a healthier, prosperous and climate-sane future&mdash;we&nbsp;may not be presented a diverse array of candidates.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>We fully appreciate that several early names of possible gubernatorial candidates may very well represent mainstream environmental interests, but no names of women or persons of color are in the rumor mill currently.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>My points here and above should not be taken as anti-male, but we simply need more diversity in the legislature and higher offices in our state for things to change.&nbsp; Nor should this redux be taken as sour grapes over the significant loss this was for PennFuture&rsquo;s mission of clean air, water and a healthy climate. It is meant to be a cautionary reminder of how things still work in &ldquo;the People&rsquo;s House.&rdquo;</p>

<p>For things to change, Pennsylvania needs a new coalition, and one powerful enough that legislators will forego the powerful payoff of campaign contributions that drive so much of this dysfunctional power dynamic.&nbsp;If we use Pennsylvania&rsquo;s primary election as a data point, we saw several races where powerful labor forces supported challengers to pro-environment incumbents&mdash;many women&mdash;and those challengers lost badly. The electorate is waking up to the dominant political paradigms here and fighting back, but many policymakers lag behind the wishes of Pennsylvanians.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We must come together to forge a different economic road forward, with family sustaining jobs that protect and improve our environment. We must come together for a sane climate future. We must fight for a future state legislature where four-fifths of its members vote in favor of protecting our communities and the environment rather than in favor of a subsidy for an industry that will do exactly the opposite.&nbsp; We need a governor who is not reliant upon fracked gas and petrochemicals, and a legislature that is obligated to the electorate, not to powerful labor interests and greedy fossil fuel corporations who are wringing the entrepreneurial and competitive life out of the rest of us and our futures.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s Democracy for All program is now fully engaged in non-partisan voter registration, voter engagement and get out the vote work.&nbsp; The people of color and their communities, single women and millennials this program is reaching out to may form the basis of this new coalition and help move Pennsylvania forward along a very different and green path.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
"PennFuture releases ""A Green Stimulus and Recovery Platform for Pennsylvania"" Report",7/28/2020,"<p>A rampant global health pandemic. A deep and rapid decline in Pennsylvania&rsquo;s economy that is nearly double that of the Great Recession of 2008. Rising racial inequality. Nearly 3 million Pennsylvanians seeking unemployment benefits since mid-March. Small businesses shuttered&mdash;some permanently&mdash;as Pennsylvania&rsquo;s economy struggles to reopen.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s abundantly clear that these are unprecedented times, and that our leaders in all levels of government will have to spend the next several years advancing economic and public health solutions that spur our economy towards recovery.&nbsp;</p>

<p>That&rsquo;s why PennFuture <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Green-Stimulus-FINAL.pdf"">released today a strategic roadmap</a> to guide our leaders to implement a green stimulus recovery plan for Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>This 50-page report lays out specific policy recommendations that leverage Pennsylvania&rsquo;s growing nature-based, clean energy, and low-carbon industries to put people back to work and build a more resilient and sustainable economy.</p>

<p>The report has four overarching goals that guide each recommendation made within the document: safely restart Pennsylvania&rsquo;s economy in a way that reduces pollution and is protective of human health, avoid state budget cuts that will harm our businesses and slow recovery, target short-term investments that provide family-sustaining wages, and advance long-term investments to support sustainable infrastructure and industries that contribute to resilient, clean and profitable communities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>All told, PennFuture&rsquo;s policy platform is estimated to amount to $2.8 billion in investments, which would preserve or create as many as 389,000 jobs in the Commonwealth, including nearly 37,200 shovel-ready jobs, while also reducing pollution, promoting our natural resources, and advancing public health.</p>

<p>There is evidence to back up the necessity of our green stimulus and recovery platform.</p>

<p>According to <a href=""https://www.smithschool.ox.ac.uk/publications/wpapers/workingpaper20-02.pdf"">a recent study from Oxford University</a> that analyzed 700 separate stimulus policies from the Great Recession, projects that focus dually on economic recovery and reductions in greenhouse gas emissions deliver higher returns on government spending both in the short and long term.</p>

<p>Our leaders also cannot turn to industry to jumpstart this recovery. Carbon dioxide emissions <a href=""https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2020-green-stimulus-clean-energy-future/"">skyrocketed by 5.1 percent in 2009</a> when America&rsquo;s economy finally started to bounce back from the Great Recession. It is indisputable that Pennsylvania, similar to the rest of the world, is at a critical juncture where we must make concerted and dedicated efforts to drastically cut our carbon footprint immediately.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania is at an inflection point. We either pursue old and tired methods of recovery that rely on slashing budgets and public sector jobs, or we chart a new direction that creates a new and sustainable economy while serving the dual purpose of addressing the climate crisis.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The choice is ours, and the chance to emerge from this historic challenge as better, cleaner, more resilient Pennsylvania is at our fingertips. Here&rsquo;s to hoping our elected officials are listening.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To read our Green Stimulus report, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Green-Stimulus-FINAL.pdf"">please click here</a>, or go to <a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org/greenstimulus"">www.pennfuture.org/greenstimulus</a>. When you do, please feel free to share it widely with friends, family or your elected officials in Harrisburg.&nbsp;</p>
