LNG in PA Blog #2: Bomb Trains Through Pennsylvania,7/21/2020,,Community; Energy; Environment,"Megan Rulli, Legal Intern"
A New Voice in the Fight Against Petrochemicals,7/16/2020,"<p>As the petrochemical industry rears its ugly head in Pennsylvania, PennFuture is building organizational capacity to deliver a counter narrative focused on the environment, health, and economic future of our state. I am joining PennFuture in this stead under the title of Policy Analyst.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I was first drawn into the fight against petrochemicals about three years ago while working in Pittsburgh at the Group Against Smog and Pollution (GASP) as a Communications and Education Specialist. I was doing outreach at an event in Pittsburgh, speaking to community members about Shell&rsquo;s petrochemical project in Beaver County&mdash;colloquially referred to as a &ldquo;cracker plant&rdquo;&mdash;when a community member recalled the sweet smell of cookies that once emanated from the Nabisco Plant in East Liberty.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;It doesn&rsquo;t seem so dangerous,&rdquo; he told me.</p>

<p>As I packed up my tabling materials later that day, his comment haunted me. How many other community members had misinterpreted the word &ldquo;cracker&rdquo;? Did they understand that Shell was hoping to cook up 1.6 million tons of plastic each year, not cookies? That the industry hoped to replicate Louisiana&rsquo;s toxic &ldquo;Cancer Alley&rdquo; right here in Pennsylvania? That each taxpayer had personally subsidized the buildout by an average of $397 worth of tax credits? What seemed like a small, innocent misunderstanding came to exemplify the true forces that we were up against: the industry&rsquo;s overwhelming presence in our political system, and their disquieting silence everywhere else.&nbsp;</p>

<p>These worries continued to plague me during my time with Pennsylvania Resources Council, where I worked as a Zero Waste Specialist to reduce waste through recycling and composting programs. I watched mountains of trash form over the course of just a few hours as I informed yet another resident that, no, their Starbucks cup was not recyclable, nor was their plastic lid or plastic straw. I came to understand that, despite what the petrochemical industry would have you believe, this problem was bigger than any individual, and our well-intentioned attempts at recycling were not going to solve it.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While my heart is in Pittsburgh and my eyes and ears are on Pennsylvania&rsquo;s petrochemical interests, I am currently writing to you from New Haven, Connecticut. I left Pittsburgh two years ago to attend the Yale School of the Environment. While here, I&rsquo;ve layered a deeper understanding of environmental justice on top of my growing expertise in communications, regional air quality issues, and policy analysis.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Environmental justice lies at the core of my value system, and all of my work is filtered through that lens. I bring these concerns&mdash;those of distributional impacts on economy, environment and health; generational impacts on our youth, of which I consider myself included; and procedural impacts resulting from unjust power relations between industry and individuals&mdash;to my role as Policy Analyst.</p>

<p>Meanwhile, I am joining a committed team of staff members&mdash;PennFuture&rsquo;s DEIJ (Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Justice) Committee&mdash;to help further environmental justice within the organization.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I have a Master&rsquo;s of Environmental Management from the Yale School of Forestry and a Bachelor&rsquo;s of Science in Environmental Science from the University of Florida. I also have an almost 3-year old brother, a less adorable 30-year old brother, and a lovely cast of family and friends supporting me in both South Florida and Pittsburgh. I hope to relocate to Pittsburgh as soon as it is safe to do so.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s a strange time to be making big life changes and yet, here I am, in the middle of the pandemic, joining PennFuture in a fight that will determine Pennsylvania&rsquo;s future&mdash;as well as the stability of our global climate and the long-term efficacy of the fossil fuel industry&mdash;for generations to come. There is no place I would rather be. So, to the board, my fellow co-workers, and anyone who supports PennFuture&rsquo;s work and mission: I am so grateful to have joined the team.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Together, let&rsquo;s chart a path for Pennsylvania that includes a clean energy economy and a healthy environment, not petrochemicals, plastics and dirty energy.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

LNG in PA Blog Series #1: What is Liquefied Natural Gas?,7/9/2020,,Climate; Energy; Environment,"Megan Rulli, Legal Intern"
Pipeline's Cancellation Shows Importance of Renewables in Pennsylvania,7/8/2020,"<p>In a major win for the environment, Dominion Energy Inc. and Duke Energy Corp. announced Sunday that they will not be moving forward with their Atlantic Coast fracked gas pipeline. The <a href=""https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/07/05/dominion-duke-cancel-atlantic-coast-pipeline-legal-uncertainty/5380949002/"">companies said increased costs and delays</a> as well as &ldquo;legal uncertainty&rdquo; made the project untenable. The pipeline&rsquo;s demise ends the threat it posed to the water, air, and soil of the communities through which it would have passed.</p>

<p>The pipeline was controversial from its inception in 2014. Environmentalists and local landowners opposed the 600-mile project, which would have crossed the Appalachian Trail and carried fracked gas from West Virginia to North Carolina. In its path was the predominantly African-American community of Union Hill, Virginia.</p>

<p>The Sierra Club, the Virginia State Conference of NAACP Branches, and the Kairos Center for Religions, Rights, and Social Justice, among others, joined a suit brought by the Chesapeake Bay Foundation and Friends of Buckingham to stop the pipeline&rsquo;s construction.</p>

<p>In January, a three-judge panel of the 4th Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously found that Virginia&rsquo;s Department of Environmental Quality <a href=""https://www.courthousenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/pipeline-station.pdf"">had failed to adequately consider</a> the pipeline&rsquo;s potential effects on Union Hill citizens. The 4th Circuit also agreed that Virginia had failed to consider zero-emission turbines as an alternative to the pipeline developers&rsquo; use of gas-fired turbines in a compressor station.</p>

<p>For developers Duke and Dominion, that ruling was only the latest in a string of legal headaches: the pipeline&rsquo;s Endangered Species Act permit, right of way across the Blue Ridge Parkway, and water permit verifications <a href=""https://www.eenews.net/stories/1060119601"">had all already been invalidated</a> by the 4th Circuit in 2018.</p>

<p>But last month, the U.S. Supreme Court, in a 7-2 decision, <a href=""https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/19pdf/18-1584_igdj.pdf"">sided with the energy companies</a> and overturned another 4th Circuit decision that prevented the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service from granting the pipeline a special use permit for a segment of pipeline that crossed the Appalachian National Scenic Trail on federal land.</p>

<p>Fortunately for the environment and the affected communities, the pipeline developers&rsquo; Supreme Court victory wasn&rsquo;t enough to justify moving forward on the project. The pipeline still lacked many other permits, and <a href=""https://www.southernenvironment.org/news-and-press/news-feed/atlantic-coast-pipeline-problems-persist-despite-supreme-court-decision"">evidence suggested that the project</a> would only add unnecessary fossil fuel capacity to the grid. Duke and Dominion <a href=""https://news.duke-energy.com/releases/dominion-energy-and-duke-energy-cancel-the-atlantic-coast-pipeline"">said in a statement</a> that ongoing &ldquo;litigation risk,&rdquo; including recent adverse rulings in other districts, made the project &ldquo;no longer a prudent use of shareholder capital.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Like Virginia, Pennsylvania has witnessed rapid growth in its gas industry over the past decade because of fracking. The industry has long touted itself as both a jobs creator and an environmentally friendly alternative to coal-fired energy generation.</p>

<p>While it&rsquo;s true that fracked gas has lower carbon dioxide emissions than coal, extraction through fracking <a href=""https://www.edf.org/climate/methane-other-important-greenhouse-gas"">also results in the leakage of methane</a>, a greenhouse gas with a <a href=""https://www.edf.org/climate/methane-other-important-greenhouse-gas"">heat-trapping potential 84 times higher</a> than that of carbon dioxide over a 20-year period. And recent research has concluded that methane emissions from oil and gas production have been underestimated <a href=""https://www.upi.com/Science_News/2020/02/19/Scientists-greatly-underestimating-methane-emitted-by-humans/6531582130062/"">by as much as 40 percent</a>. That means that fracked gas is little better than coal when it comes to slowing climate change and in fact, it may be worse.</p>

<p>In addition, fracking can <a href=""https://www.ucsusa.org/resources/environmental-impacts-natural-gas#references"">result in the release of toxic and hazardous air pollutants</a> regulated by the EPA due to their ability to cause cancer, cardiovascular disease, respiratory problems, and other health complications.</p>

<p>Finally, fracking can also <a href=""https://www.greenpeace.org/usa/global-warming/issues/fracking/environmental-impacts-water/"">threaten local water resources</a>, especially in areas where water is already scarce. The toxic chemicals used in fracking fluid are stored in open pits that have been linked to animal deaths and negative health consequences in humans. And fracking liquid, flammable gas, or methane itself <a href=""https://www.propublica.org/article/federal-report-appears-to-undercut-epa-assurances-water-safety-pennsylvania"">often contaminates local water sources</a>.</p>

<p>What&rsquo;s more, in Pennsylvania, the Attorney General has been coming down hard not only on the industry but also the state Department of Environmental Protection for failing to operate safely (<a href=""https://www.attorneygeneral.gov/taking-action/press-releases/ag-shapiro-pa-fracking-company-pleads-to-criminal-conviction-in-43rd-statewide-grand-jury-investigation/"">here</a> and <a href=""https://www.attorneygeneral.gov/taking-action/press-releases/ag-shapiro-and-43rd-statewide-grand-jury-file-criminal-charges-against-nepa-fracking-company/"">here</a>) and for <a href=""https://www.attorneygeneral.gov/taking-action/press-releases/43rd-statewide-grand-jury-finds-pennsylvania-failed-to-protect-citizens-during-fracking-boom/"">failing to protect our communities</a> and our environment from the harmful impacts of fracking.</p>

<p>The other leg upon which the fracking industry stands<span id=""docs-internal-guid-91bed888-7fff-4e7b-ca45-a3c01629191f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>its role as a job creator<span id=""docs-internal-guid-91bed888-7fff-4e7b-ca45-a3c01629191f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>is equally shaky. Food &amp; Water Watch <a href=""https://www.foodandwaterwatch.org/news/fracking-industrys-phony-jobs-numbers"">recently found that the American Petroleum Institute</a>, a leading oil and fracking trade group, &ldquo;promotes extremely misleading claims about the number of Americans working in the fracking industry&rdquo; in &ldquo;a clear attempt to defend the economically struggling industry that is linked to air, water, and climate pollution.&rdquo; API has claimed, for instance, that half a million jobs in Pennsylvania would be at risk if fracking were banned in the state. The Bureau of Labor Statistics, on the other hand, counts only 26,000 fracking jobs in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The industry has contracted significantly in the face of the coronavirus pandemic. Even before the pandemic, North American fracking firms were in a precarious position: their <a href=""https://energypolicy.columbia.edu/sites/default/files/CGEPReserveBaseLendingAndTheOutlookForShaleOilAndGasFinance.pdf"">net debt exploded</a> from $50 billion in 2005 to $200 billion in 2015. After the COVID-19 outbreak began, <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/31/business/energy-environment/pennsylvania-shale-gas-fracking.html"">Chevron suggested it might sell </a>its Appalachian shale assets, the bulk of which are in Pennsylvania. And Chesapeake Energy<span id=""docs-internal-guid-91bed888-7fff-4e7b-ca45-a3c01629191f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>once the second-largest fracked gas producer in the U.S. and a pioneer in the fracking boom<span id=""docs-internal-guid-91bed888-7fff-4e7b-ca45-a3c01629191f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span><a href=""https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/28/business/chesapeake-energy-bankruptcy/index.html"">filed for bankruptcy last month</a>.</p>

<p>The better option for Pennsylvania is to invest in clean, renewable energy. Unlike fracked gas and other fossil fuels, solar and wind power are not subject to the same sorts of supply and production issues that lead to volatile market fluctuations. As a result, <a href=""https://www.ucsusa.org/resources/benefits-renewable-energy-use"">renewable energy prices can remain stable</a> over time. This is good news for consumers, who can then depend upon predictable electricity costs.</p>

<p>In addition, jobs in solar and wind are growing, while jobs in the fossil fuel industry are not. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that over the next decade, <a href=""https://www.bls.gov/ooh/fastest-growing.htm"">the two fastest-growing jobs</a> in the U.S. are solar photovoltaic installer and wind turbine service technician. As far back as 2016, the solar power industry alone employed <a href=""https://spectrum.ieee.org/energywise/energy/renewables/for-us-jobs-creation-renewables-are-a-better-bet-than-coal"">twice as many people</a> as the coal, oil, and gas industries combined did.</p>

<p>And finally, the pure economics of renewables make them the obvious choice for developing new generating capacity. Solar and wind energy generation <a href=""https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2019/06/04/climate-change-coal-now-more-expensive-than-wind-solar-energy/1277637001/"">are already competitive with fracked gas</a> in many parts of the country. This math is the primary reason <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/07/business/energy-environment/coronavirus-oil-wind-solar-energy.html"">why the use of renewables has grown</a> despite the Trump administration&rsquo;s tariffs on solar cells and panels, and its withdrawal of the U.S. from the Paris Climate Agreement.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania needs <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/clean-energy"">more clean energy jobs</a><span id=""docs-internal-guid-91bed888-7fff-4e7b-ca45-a3c01629191f""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>jobs that support Pennsylvania&rsquo;s communities and safeguard its wildlife and natural resources. What&rsquo;s more, the only major impediment to a total transition toward renewables has been largely attenuated by better and more affordable utility-scale storage options.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The COVID-19 epidemic offers us <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-COVID-19-A-Green-Recovery"">an unprecedented opportunity</a> to rethink the way we use and generate energy. Let&rsquo;s make the most of it.</p>
",Community; Energy; Environment,"Richard Marcil, Legal Intern"

When I first left my house following quarantine, I felt like a trout fry emerging from the gravel. I was so eager to follow the sunlight, stretch my fins and find some escape from anxieties of the COVID-19 crisis.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Observers note that by June the condition of many trails appeared as though they already received as much foot traffic as usually experienced by the end of the summer season. As restrictions are lifted, outfitters are experiencing a flood of interest for water-based activities.&nbsp;</p>

This is especially true when considering the role of clean waters to the Poconos Mountain region.&nbsp;</p>

The 2018 campaign collected more than 3,300 petition signatures from across the Poconos community.</p>

PennFuture Secures Two Legal Victories in One Week,7/1/2020,"<p>At PennFuture, we take great pride in being Pennsylvania&rsquo;s watchdog for clean air, pure water and a healthy environment. We approach our work through multiple facets, one of which involves flexing our legal muscle and protecting our environment through litigation in local, state and federal courts.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Over the course of our 22-year history, PennFuture has achieved significant and meaningful legal victories and, just this week, we received word that two cases had been resolved in our favor.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The first victory, <a href=""https://www.bloomberglaw.com/public/desktop/document/AlleghenyDefenseProjectetalvFERCDocketNo1701098DCCirMar232017Cour/5?1593554996"">handed down by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit</a>, involved the use of so-called &ldquo;tolling orders&rdquo; by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC). Tolling orders allow an agency or court to pause or delay the running of time to take action that is set forth in a statute. Put simply, for many years FERC used these tolling orders to indefinitely delay reviewing complaints from property owners who wished to protect their property from fracked gas and pipeline development.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In fact, FERC used tolling orders in 99 percent of the cases between 2009 and 2017 in which property owners, organizations, and other aggrieved parties asked for rehearings of FERC decisions involving pipeline projects. Until the rehearing request was finally decided upon, the parties were prevented from challenging FERC&rsquo;s decision in court.</p>

<p>Most concerningly, even as these parties were blocked from having their day in court, pipeline companies could rely on the decisions to condemn private property and begin construction, resulting in irreparable harm to property and the environment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Thankfully, the D.C. Circuit on Tuesday ruled that FERC cannot indefinitely delay the review of these complaints. This decision gives landowners, environmental groups, and environmental justice communities who are disproportionately burdened by pipeline infrastructure back our right to challenge FERC&rsquo;s decisions before the irreparable harm from pipeline construction can occur.</p>

<p>PennFuture, which was represented by EarthJustice in this case, was just one of several entities that submitted an amici curiae (&ldquo;friend of the court&rdquo;) brief in the case challenging the illegal use of these tolling order , and we are thankful for the court&rsquo;s ruling. To read more about this case, <a href=""http://paenvironmentdaily.blogspot.com/2020/06/federal-appeals-court-stops-fercs.html"">click here</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The second legal victory, <a href=""https://earthjustice.org/sites/default/files/files/01_Enviro_Complaint_04-15-2019.pdf"">handed down by the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California</a>, involved a case where PennFuture and other organizations, again represented by EarthJustice, sued the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for failing to properly regulate coke ovens like those found at U.S. Steel&rsquo;s plant outside of Pittsburgh.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2005, the EPA publicly acknowledged that carcinogenic emissions from coke ovens destroy air quality and cause devastating health complications, yet the agency also admitted it wasn&rsquo;t sure that its regulations were protecting communities located near these coke plants.&nbsp;</p>

<p>No new rules or regulations have come forth from the EPA in the 15 years since that admission, and this lawsuit demanded that EPA finally take action and craft regulations that protect citizens who live near these dangerous plants. In response to our lawsuit, EPA conceded liability and admitted that they had failed to establish three of the necessary standards to protect human health and the environment as alleged in our lawsuit. The court set a 30-month deadline for the EPA to act on these rules, which is a significant victory for public health.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Both of these court decisions are significant victories for citizens across America whose rights to clean air and clean water have been denied for far too long. These decisions are also further evidence that PennFuture will not stand idly by as corporate polluters and our federal government trample on our rights solely in the name of profits.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Please <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">consider joining PennFuture today</a> to support all of the great work we do to protect our environment and hold polluters and our government accountable.</p>
",Community; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
PennFuture’s Legal Internship Program Helps to Train and Inspire the Next Generation of Environmental Lawyers in Pennsylvania,6/30/2020,"<p>Since its inception in 1998, PennFuture has emphasized the importance of using the law to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment and &ldquo;create a just future where nature, communities, and the economy thrive.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Over the past 20 years, we have achieved significant legal and policy victories that reduce pollution and protect the environment. We have provided millions of dollars in pro bono legal services while setting critical precedents and enforcing environmental laws across the Commonwealth.</p>

<p>But as PennFuture looks forward to the next 20 years, we recognized that we need to be more involved with cultivating the legal talent that will continue to support our mission. Our attorneys have a long history of mentoring legal interns, externs, and fellows, and we wanted to create a more formal program to inspire the next generation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This year, with the generous support of the George and Miriam Martin Foundation and the Otto Haus Charitable Trust, PennFuture created a paid legal internship program to inspire and mentor law students interested in making a difference for our environment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Ultimately, the goal of this program is to provide the organization a cadre of young legal minds interested in taking on the myriad challenges impacting the State as well as to further their potential careers in environmental law.</p>

<p>Speaking from personal experience, the ability of law students to have meaningful legal internships at non-profit organizations is often compromised by the need to financially support oneself while attending law school. We hope that over the coming years, our ability to provide a paid legal internship opportunity will allow for a greater diversity of students and flexibility to be a part of PennFuture and the non-profit environmental law community in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This summer, we have a fantastic group of law students for our inaugural internship class, representing a range of backgrounds and experiences. We&rsquo;ve asked our summer legal interns to explain, in their own words, what environmental law and PennFuture&rsquo;s mission means to them:</p>

<p><strong>Megan Rulli, a rising second-year law student at Penn State Dickinson School of Law. Ms. Rulli is working&nbsp;on a variety of legal matters impacting our water resources across the state.</strong></p>

<p>I come to environmental law after a decade in the world of small-scale, sustainable agriculture. I&rsquo;ve switched to a career in law in order to understand and shape environmental policy.&nbsp;PennFuture is an organization that is working on many levels to make the change I believe necessary to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment for future generations.&nbsp;I feel lucky to be part of a group of people that organizes communities at the grass roots level, works with decision makers to implement meaningful environmental policy, and makes strategic legal challenges that protect the earth and result in long term change.</p>

<p>I first became interested in law as an environmental activist in college, where I saw the power of law as a tool for change. While as students we held meetings and dreamed of change, lawyers were able to enter rooms with decision makers and get things done.&nbsp;I hope to do the same in my legal career.&nbsp;This summer I have the pleasure of seeing the legal standards that protect the environment in action and of participating in campaigns that ensure those standards have teeth.&nbsp;Like farming, law is both challenging and rewarding, and I am excited to take my first steps in this field with PennFuture.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Timothy Wolff, a rising third-year law evening student at the University of Maryland, Francis King Carey School of Law. Mr. Wolff is working with Rob Altenburg on energy and climate issues, including PA&rsquo;s Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) plan.&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>I grew up on a rural Columbia County dairy farm.&nbsp; Tucked among the state&#39;s rolling hills and close to natural treasures like Ricketts Glen State Park, I developed a deep appreciation for the area&#39;s scenic beauty.&nbsp;After college, I spent several years working for a renewable energy company in Lebanon County.&nbsp;Our work not only added badly-needed jobs to the region and produced environmental benefits, but strengthened the balance sheets of our customers&#39; farms and rural small businesses.</p>

<p>I care about environmental issues because having a world that can continually provide food, housing, and resources in the quantities necessary to sustain our communities while population continues to climb is huge challenge that affects everyone.&nbsp;Invention and transformation are hallmarks of the American economy, and I feel that there is a great deal of opportunity to both move us towards a sustainable path while promoting economic prosperity.</p>

<p><strong>Richard Marcil, a rising third-year law student at Widener Law School. Mr. Marcil is working with both me and Rob on matters ranging from developing the federal policy initiative for the Reimagine Appalachia collaboration to researching energy and climate issues for our Energy Center.</strong></p>

<p>Everyone has a right to clean air, water, and soil. Environmental law is the toolbox with which we protect these rights. But environmental law does more than just safeguard human health and wellness. It also protects animals, their habitats, and ecosystems. It ensures we can grow healthy food in a sustainable manner. And it helps us secure economic prosperity. At a time when climate change is accelerating and federal regulators are rolling back environmental rules and enforcement efforts, the work PennFuture is doing to fight for these rights and benefits is more vital now than ever.</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s legal team is dedicated to restoring and protecting our environment and communities, to protecting our right to clean air and pure water, and to moving Pennsylvania toward a clean energy future. I thank our amazing staff and legal interns for their great work, and also our members for your continued support. We can&rsquo;t do this without you!&nbsp;</p>

<p>Not a member? Please <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">consider joining PennFuture today</a> to support all of the great work we do to protect our environment and hold polluters and our government accountable.&nbsp;</p>
",Community; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
At the Bottom of a Steep Learning Curve,6/19/2020,"<p>Since the murder of George Floyd at the hands of police in late May, we have witnessed an ignition of individual, communal and global action against racism, injustice and inequality.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>People are mobilized in anger and in peace, hearts and minds are active and anguished, and consciences are toiling. Aligned institutions, organizations and businesses are grappling with responsibility, and endeavoring to respond and support.</p>

<p>And so it is at PennFuture. My thinking about what the diversity work implanted throughout our 2019 strategic plan would look like has been thoroughly upended.</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s overly simplistic to say that I anticipated a great deal of our effort would play out the way it has been described in trainings we&rsquo;ve been exposed to&mdash;fairly prescriptive pathways and a lot of checking of boxes. I had anticipated that organizational culture would need to be explored, and assessed, and eventually transformed.</p>

<p>But I did not grasp, until now, and because of now, the extent to which the work must begin with conversations about racism, bigotry and hatred. These conversations have always been part of the diversity curriculum&nbsp;but now stand at the front of a long line of issues we must work our way through in an aspiration to be an inclusive, diverse, fair and just organization.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I knew a path to diversity would be painful and difficult, but I thought it might be a collective pain and discomfort, and now am figuring out the discomfort will be felt personally and deeply. But it will never be commensurate to the pain and hurt America has laid on communities of color since the birth of this country and right up to today.</p>

<p>Over the last weeks, the PennFuture staff that I work with has responded so admirably, and with so much bravery and leadership. The environmental community wants to be a leader in helping solve racism and prejudice, but do we really have a clue to how that can happen?&nbsp;</p>

<p>I believe we do, and I believe that knowledge at PennFuture resides with our younger and newer staff members who bring diversity and fresh ideas to the table, but also deeply personal experiences that have shaped their worldviews and perspectives.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>These individuals have stood up with a generosity of spirit, with clear words and thoughts and with an insistence that they be heard within the organization. They are pushing our organization forward. They have expectations and desires for the future and realize we are in a moment when the time to assert them is ripe.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>This team wants our organization to be an ally to the marginalized people of our state, to find new partners, to understand from them how we can use our privilege and access and resources and yes, expertise, in service to these impacted communities and the issues they prioritize. Will it always be possible for us to help? Probably not, but we must figure out some mechanisms and programs to contribute.</p>

<p>On Monday, June 1, after the first weekend of justice actions took place throughout the state, PennFuture <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-issues-statement-in-reaction-to-recent-events"">offered a brief statement of solidarity</a> for the justice activists and their calls for change.&nbsp;Since the next day, June 2, was Election Day, we included our hopes that everyone who is eligible to vote is registered to vote, and voting regularly as one pathway to that change. In fact, that is one goal of PennFuture&rsquo;s new Democracy for All program, which reaches out to communities of color and provides civic engagement opportunities.</p>

<p>We grasp that the same dynamics of power that have perpetuated racism also have systematically manipulated the people&rsquo;s ability to engage with, and have faith in, our elections and civic opportunities.&nbsp;But I hope we do not give up on our democracy or the American flag as a symbol of our dreams and vision for the future.</p>

<p>I&rsquo;ve shared some early thoughts here but to say more would immediately put me back in a place where I think I know something I really don&rsquo;t, which is what the road to diversity will look like for PennFuture.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I will have contributions to make to that future, along with many others here. It is within my ability and control to say with certainty the matter will not be relegated to the back burner.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
",Community; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
"Fracked Gas, Petrochemical Industries Continue to Overpromise and Underdeliver for Pennsylvanians",6/18/2020,"<p>A core tenant of our mission at PennFuture is working to secure a better and brighter future for all Pennsylvanians, and a large part of that mission is protecting our basic rights to clean air and pure water.</p>

<p>Unfortunately, a significant threat to those rights has emerged in the form of the fracked gas and petrochemical industries, which are trying to further entrench and intertwine themselves into our political landscape and economy.</p>

<p>The industries attempt to woo our small and mid-sized communities with promises of revitalization and economic prosperity, all while promising to be stringent and responsible protectors of our shared environment and natural resources.</p>

<p>Unfortunately, they&rsquo;re lying. These claims aren&rsquo;t hard to debunk: in the last week alone, four news stories have been published that expose the financial realities of fracked gas and petrochemicals, as well as those industries&rsquo; complete disregard for the health of Pennsylvanians and our environment.</p>

<p>The first story concerns a group of economists, engineers, policy analysts and former policymakers who banded together <a href=""https://www.dispatch.com/news/20200615/cracker-plant-wonrsquot-bring-petrochemical-jobs-boom-to-ohio-experts-warn"">to issue a letter to the governors of Pennsylvania</a>, Ohio, and West Virginia , stressing that a reliance on petrochemicals for prosperity is both dangerous and badly misguided.</p>

<p>The authors&mdash;among them prominent officials like former Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection Secretary John Hanger, Executive Director of West Virginia Center on Budget and Policy Ted Boettner, and Carnegie Mellon University Associate Professor of Economics Nicholas Z. Muller&mdash;told the governors that they &ldquo;risk squandering hundreds of millions of dollars in public funds in pursuit of a vision that will not materialize.&rdquo;</p>

<p>That vision won&rsquo;t materialize largely because it&rsquo;s becoming increasingly unprofitable. Market conditions are extremely unfavorable as the price of plastic is plummeting, combined with an oversaturation of fracked gas and petrochemical plants that are far outpacing demand.</p>

<p>Simply put, the dream of an Appalachian petrochemical hub is dissipating quickly, but some of our elected officials and policymakers are hesitant to let go and pursue more viable strategies and sound economic development policies.</p>

<p>Unfortunately for residents in Beaver County, the decision to cater to the petrochemical industry has already been made, and another report issued last week is showing the folly of that decision.</p>

<p>The <a href=""https://insideclimatenews.org/news/03062020/shell-plastics-plant-pittsburgh-coronavirus"">Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis warns</a> that Shell&rsquo;s massive plastics factory on the banks of the Ohio River won&rsquo;t be nearly as profitable as once thought due to a combination of poor market conditions and the fact that Shell will be making fewer plastics because of global oversupply.</p>

<p>That all spells bad news for a community that was previously decimated by the collapse of the domestic steel industry, and a community that took Shell at its word when the company promised prosperity and economic revitalization.</p>

<p>It goes without saying that a less profitable plastics plant means fewer jobs and far less impact on the local and regional economy. It is also further proof that Pennsylvania&rsquo;s lawmakers in 2012 shouldn&rsquo;t have offered a massive $1.6 billion tax break to lure Shell to Pennsylvania in the first place.</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s bad enough that these industries are not delivering on promises made to Pennsylvanians, but it&rsquo;s even worse that they are also destroying our environment and natural resources in the process.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To that end, Attorney General Josh Shapiro announced on Friday that his office <a href=""https://www.wesa.fm/post/range-resources-pleads-no-contest-environmental-crimes-southwest-pa-well-sites#stream/0"">had secured a criminal conviction against Range Resources</a>, one of the largest fracking companies operating in Pennsylvania, for environmental crimes at two separate sites in Washington County.</p>

<p>Specifically, Range Resources pleaded no contest to several environmental crimes after a two-year investigation found the company so heavily polluted a family&rsquo;s drinking water supply that it was rendered &ldquo;dangerous and unsuitable for consumption.&rdquo; In a separate incident, the company so heavily polluted a field in Washington County that 100 trees and 12,000 square feet of soil had to be removed.</p>

<p>As if those environmental crimes aren&rsquo;t enough, the attorney general proved that the company knowingly covered up issues that ultimately led to the contamination of the drinking water supply.</p>

<p>Finally, the attorney general on Monday <a href=""https://www.attorneygeneral.gov/taking-action/press-releases/ag-shapiro-and-43rd-statewide-grand-jury-file-criminal-charges-against-nepa-fracking-company/"">announced similar environmental crimes</a> against Cabot Oil and Gas after the company contaminated well water in Dimock, Susquehanna County. In one instance, a landowner held a match to a jug that contained water used for drinking and bathing, and the water caught fire.</p>

<p>Water set ablaze. More than 100 trees permanently removed. A family&rsquo;s drinking supply permanently contaminated. These are very real and very serious incidents, but they are far from the only incidents.</p>

<p>Is the promise of jobs worth the environmental degradation and sickness that accompanies them? Should our elected leaders continue to believe these companies when they promise a better and brighter future?</p>

<p>Keep in mind, these industries beg for and often receive enormous subsidies and tax breaks from our elected officials, and still continue to fail financially even as taxpayers foot the bill. They consistently and purposefully overpromise and underdeliver, then pack up and leave our communities in far worse shape after extracting our resources and destroying our environment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Time and again we&rsquo;ve been shown the true nature of these industries, both financially and environmentally. It&rsquo;s time we start listening.</p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
COVID-19: A Green Recovery,6/15/2020,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-21bf8d08-7fff-9b50-5f6b-5162a431595c""></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-345b33da-7fff-3ff3-c549-2be1a63ccc52""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></p>

<p>Amidst the impacts of the COVID-19 public health crisis, we have seen a significant decline in emissions of air pollution both nationally and in Pennsylvania.&nbsp; As our communities begin the journey to recovery, and emissions rise, we have a duty and an opportunity to protect Pennsylvanians&mdash;especially those that are substantially more vulnerable to COVID-19 and other respiratory diseases.</p>

<p>There is no silver bullet to address air pollution. In Pennsylvania, one possible path is a three-pronged approach that includes modernizing and extending our antiquated Alternative Energy Portfolio Standard (AEPS), strengthening our Act 129 energy efficiency law, and joining our neighbors throughout the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) currently being considered in Harrisburg. With these changes, we can finally begin to bring our energy economy into the 21st century.</p>

<p>A report by Massachusetts Institute of Technology researchers <a href=""https://www.yorkdispatch.com/story/news/local/2020/02/13/pa-leads-nation-premature-deaths-due-air-pollution-study-finds/4749624002/"">published in February concluded that Pennsylvania</a> leads the lower 48 in premature death rate per capita from air pollution.&nbsp; We paid for this nefarious designation with 4,800 preventable deaths in 2018.&nbsp;While the study recognized cross-border air pollution impacts, it found that Pennsylvanians are largely doing this to ourselves.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As tragic as this is, this year may be worse&mdash;a Harvard study <a href=""https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/hsph-in-the-news/air-pollution-linked-with-higher-covid-19-death-rates/"">recently found that exposure to air pollution</a>, particularly small particulate matter (2.5) dramatically increased the likelihood that those infected with COVID-19 would die.</p>

<p>The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/"">projects an 11 percent decline</a> in energy-related CO2 emissions this year due to stay-at-home orders across the nation. However, that is not a sustainable reduction and emissions are expected to jump 5 percent once we fully reopen.&nbsp;After the Great Recession in 2009, the benefits gained from temporary emission reductions began to quickly evaporate.&nbsp;Nationally, emissions from the energy sector <a href=""https://rhg.com/research/preliminary-us-emissions-estimates-for-2018/"">declined by 7.2 percent in 2009</a> only to rebound by 3.6 percent the following year.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Those numbers were even larger in Pennsylvania&mdash;we experienced <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/environment/emissions/state/analysis/pdf/table1.pdf"">a massive 9.4 percent reduction</a> but then a 4.9 percent rise in 2010. Our sluggish economy played a role in the 2009 &ndash; 2010 net reduction, yet the dramatic shift towards less-carbon-intensive energy sources was due primarily to the federal American Recovery &amp; Reinvestment Act and the state Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Commonwealth&rsquo;s <a href=""http://www.pennaeps.com/"">Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards Act of 2004</a> requires that by 2021, 8 percent of electricity consumed in Pennsylvania originate from &rdquo;Tier 1&rdquo; renewable sources, with one-half of one percent of that coming from solar power, and 10 percent from &ldquo;Tier 2&rdquo; sources, which sadly includes electric generation from dirty waste coal and other non-renewable sources.&nbsp; Once an aggressive standard 15 years ago, Harrisburg has allowed Pennsylvania to fall woefully behind as our neighbors in Maryland, New Jersey, and New York:<span id=""docs-internal-guid-7ffb90da-7fff-5aed-0fd1-9d99a6c035c5""></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our neighbors have outworked us to become leaders in the clean energy revolution. Significantly, our AEPS requirement plateaus after 2021&mdash;stifling the Commonwealth&rsquo;s momentum of success.&nbsp; Even <a href=""https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-virginia-renewables/virginia-passes-bill-to-achieve-100-carbon-free-power-by-2045-idUSKBN20T2OF"">Virginia recently committed itself in March</a> to be 100 percent carbon free by 2045. All the while we Pennsylvanians have seen other states with less land and less natural potential for renewables zoom past us.</p>

<p>For example, <a href=""https://www.census.gov/geographies/reference-files/2010/geo/state-area.html"">Pennsylvania has 6 times more land</a> and receives <a href=""https://neo.ne.gov/programs/stats/pdf/201_solar_leadership.pdf"">more solar radiance</a> than New Jersey, yet the Garden State <a href=""https://www.seia.org/states-map"">has 3,180 MW of installed solar PV</a> versus 491 MW in Pennsylvania.&nbsp; It is time for the General Assembly to once again spur renewable development and put Pennsylvania on equal footing with our neighbors.</p>

<p>Compounding the issue of our outdated AEPS is the imminent catastrophe heading our way as federal tax credits for renewables will be eliminated, or dramatically reduced, over the next 18 months.&nbsp; The fossil fuel industry <a href=""https://kleinmanenergy.upenn.edu/policy-digests/ending-fossil-fuel-tax-subsidies"">benefits from tax breaks permanently</a> written into the tax code, yet credits for renewables are provided for only a few years, if that long.&nbsp;Two renewable energy sub-sectors are at the top of the expected job growth list over the next decade (keep reading) according to the U.S. Department of Labor.&nbsp; Why should we build roadblocks to progress?&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Regarding energy efficiency measures, the Commonwealth <a href=""http://www.puc.state.pa.us/filing_resources/issues_laws_regulations/act_129_information.aspx"">implemented Act 129 in 2008</a>.&nbsp;This enactment created the Energy Efficiency &amp; Conservation (EE&amp;C) Program that has spurred utility rebates for purchasing energy efficient goods.&nbsp;Since its implementation, Act 129 <a href=""https://www.aceee.org/white-paper/lifting-the-cap-040419"">has generated over $6.4 billion in net consumer benefits</a> through the deployment of efficiency measures throughout Pennsylvania. In fact, the program requires not only that targets be cost-effective, but also makes that determination with a very restrictive test that does not even consider health and environmental benefits.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While this program <a href=""https://www.aceee.org/sites/default/files/pa-jobs-040419.pdf"">achieved a modest 0.8 percent annual decline</a> in energy consumption across the state, just as with the AEPS, Harrisburg has failed to keep pace with our neighbors leading the charge.&nbsp;New Jersey (1.5 percent), New York (2 percent), and Maryland (2 percent) have all realized&nbsp;the benefits their states recognize with more aggressive efficiency standards.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Expanding the EE&amp;C Program is perhaps the lowest hanging fruit in Pennsylvania to reduce emissions.&nbsp;The program <a href=""http://www.puc.pa.gov/pcdocs/1656474.pdf"">could easily be doubled or tripled</a> at no net cost to ratepayers. Unfortunately, the program contains an arbitrary investment cap that is prohibiting the Commonwealth and its ratepayers from capturing the full potential of Act 129.&nbsp;The success stories of our neighboring states demonstrates what we are capable of if we get serious about energy efficiency.</p>

<p>On the horizon is <a href=""https://www.rggi.org/"">the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative</a>, a cooperative effort of 11 Northeastern and Mid-Atlantic states that establishes an annual CO2 emissions limit for most power plants and the cap decreases annually by 2.5 percent.&nbsp; Governor Wolf <a href=""https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/executive-order-2019-07-commonwealth-leadership-in-addressing-climate-change-through-electric-sector-emissions-reductions/"">has issued an Executive Order</a> directing the state Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) to craft draft regulations under the authority granted by the General Assembly in the Air Pollution Control Act (APCA).&nbsp;</p>

<p>The initiative provides a market-based solution allowing for pollution credits to be sold, ensuring that CO2 reductions occur from the most cost-effective sources and providing long-term market certainty to stimulate renewable energy deployment.&nbsp;Because the U.S. Congress has been unable to advance a RGGI-like proposal at the national level, states grew tired of waiting on Washington and instead took action to protect their citizens and modernize their economies and energy infrastructure.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Proceeds from the credits would be reinvested through Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Clean Air Fund to further reduce air pollution by deploying energy efficiency and renewable energy, among other things. These investments have a significant multiplier effect, rippling through the states&rsquo; economies.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2017, <a href=""https://www.rggi.org/sites/default/files/Uploads/Proceeds/RGGI_Proceeds_Report_2017.pdf"">RGGI states invested $315 million</a> from the sale of pollution allowances that abated 8,300,000 tons of CO2 emissions by avoiding a whopping 13.9 billion kilowatt-hours (kWh) of electricity, or the <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/energyexplained/units-and-calculators/"">equivalent of over 187,885,000 gallons</a> of gasoline.&nbsp;CO2 emissions from RGGI states have been reduced by 50 percent since 2005, not to mention the reductions of mercury, nitrogen oxide, sulfur dioxide, and particulate matter.&nbsp;All of this has taken place as the gross domestic product (GDP) of RGGI states continues to grow faster than the national average.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The size of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s generation sector is comparable to those plants that currently fall under the RGGI umbrella, so it is reasonable to conclude that similar benefits are likely.&nbsp;In 2022, the Commonwealth <a href=""http://files.dep.state.pa.us/Air/AirQuality/AQPortalFiles/Advisory%20Committees/Air%20Quality%20Technical%20Advisory%20Committee/2020/5-7-20/AQTAC%20PA%20CO2%20Budget%20Trading%20Program.pdf"">has proposed limiting CO2 emissions</a> to 78 million tons, roughly equal to the 74 million ton adjusted limit for the combined RGGI states this year.&nbsp;In Pennsylvania the program is expected to generate $320 million in 2022 that will be reinvested in the state to promote renewable energy, energy efficiency, greenhouse gas abatement, direct bill assistance, and workforce training among other things.&nbsp;</p>

<p>RGGI&rsquo;s 2017 environmental achievements discussed in the preceding paragraph would likely be similar to the benefits Pennsylvania would realize in 2022.&nbsp;After 2022, CO2 emission limits are decreased by approximately 2.5 million tons annually until 2030 when the limit reaches 58 million tons, or 25 percent below 2005 levels.&nbsp;Innovation and smart policies both clean our air and energize our economy as our country continues to speed away from coal.&nbsp;Virginia commitmented to RGGI this year, and now it is time for Pennsylvania to step up to the plate too.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Many people still think Pennsylvania is powered by coal, but that simply is no longer true. Coal&rsquo;s role has been dramatically reduced because of the transition to natural gas generation.&nbsp; At the beginning of the gas boom, in 2004, <a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/experts/mark-szybist/will-pas-coal-plants-survive-if-pa-rejects-rggi#:~:text=The%20Pennsylvania%20Department%20of%20Environmental,Greenhouse%20Gas%20Initiative%20(RGGI)."">Pennsylvania generated 55 percent of our electricity</a> from coal. Fast-forward 15 years to 2019 and coal accounted for only 17 percent of electric generation.&nbsp; Natural gas during the same period increased from 5 percent to 43 percent of our electric generation portfolio.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2019 Pennsylvania&rsquo;s largest coal plant, the Bruce Mansfield Plant operated by First Energy in Beaver County, <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2019/08/12/states-largest-coal-fired-power-plant-to-shutter-early/#:~:text=Bruce%20Mansfield%20Power%20Plant%2C%20for,people%20work%20at%20the%20plant."">retired&nbsp;two years earlier than expected</a> after losing $90 million in 2017 and projecting a $104 million loss in 2018.&nbsp;Only five large coal plants remain in the Commonwealth, and they are also all nearing retirement.&nbsp;Simply put, coal-fired generation is not cost-competitive.&nbsp;It is on its way out and it is not coming back.&nbsp;We must now look forward, not back, and smooth the natural transition away from coal to cleaner renewable sources with programs like RGGI.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>As we continually fight for cleaner energy, we also must be mindful of those impacted by this inevitable change and assist in the transition.&nbsp;The good news is that green jobs are here.&nbsp;Pennsylvania had <a href=""https://e2.org/reports/clean-jobs-pennsylvania-2019/"">90,000 green energy jobs in 2018</a>, up from 57,000 in 2014, ranking 11th nationally.&nbsp;In fact, the industry in Pennsylvania swelled 5 times faster than overall job growth in the state. The 2019 U.S. Energy and Employment Report (USEER) found that <a href=""https://www.eesi.org/papers/view/fact-sheet-jobs-in-renewable-energy-energy-efficiency-and-resilience-2019"">the energy efficiency sector had the highest job growth</a> in the entire energy industry, posting 5.37 percent.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Bureau of Labor Statistics found that&mdash;across the entire U.S. economy&mdash;solar PV and wind energy jobs <a href=""https://www.bls.gov/ooh/fastest-growing.htm"">are expected to grow at the fastest rate</a> over the next decade.&nbsp;Renewable energy supports 855,000 jobs in our country, and USEER cited a lack of skilled workforce as the central constraint to growth. There is a clearly burgeoning&nbsp; job market starving for trained labor.&nbsp;Let us bridge the gap by joining RGGI and helping to train those affected by our natural shift away from coal instead of just leaving them out in the cold.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Throughout modern history, environmental initiatives have played a prominent role in bringing our economy back and preparing America to march forward, more resilient than before.&nbsp;As part of the New Deal, <a href=""https://www.history.com/topics/great-depression/civilian-conservation-corps"">FDR created the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC)</a> in 1933 during the Great Depression. Also known as &ldquo;Roosevelt&rsquo;s Tree Army,&rdquo; over 3 million Americans worked on environmental projects in the decade that followed.&nbsp;More recently, at the height of The Great Recession in 2009, the <a href=""https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2016/02/25/fact-sheet-recovery-act-made-largest-single-investment-clean-energy"">American Recovery and Reinvestment Act spearheaded</a> the clean energy revolution.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We are once again afforded an opportunity to move Pennsylvania forward while promoting economic revitalization, protecting those with increased susceptibility to COVID-19, reducing our greenhouse gas emissions, smoothing labor&rsquo;s transition away from coal-fired generation, and bringing our energy infrastructure into the 21st century.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The way in which we can achieve this tomorrow is by finally updating the Commonwealth&rsquo;s AEPS and EE&amp;C Program to align with our neighbors, and utilizing the market-based RGGI to reduce CO2 emissions and reinvest the Initiative&rsquo;s proceeds.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>It is once again time to step forward.</p>

",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Timothy Wolff, Legal Intern"
Pennsylvania’s House Environmental Committee Approves Bill Removing DEP’s Authority to Enact Carbon Reduction Program,6/9/2020,"<p>On June 9, the House Environmental Resources &amp; Energy Committee, chaired by Representative Daryl Metcalfe (Butler), met to consider House Bill 2025 (Struzzi). Instead of passing critical climate legislation that would curb Pennsylvania&rsquo;s carbon emission pollution and combat the air quality challenges of our Commonwealth, Metcalfe&rsquo;s committee approved legislation that would usurp authority from the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection to enact a carbon reduction program known as the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI).&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture is adamantly opposed to HB 2025 and frustrated with the legislators who voted to advance the bill to the full House floor for consideration.</p>

<p>Despite being in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic and battling an illness that aggressively attacks the respiratory system, the House Environmental Committee saw it necessary to spend time today in the People&rsquo;s House peddling mistruths and conflating serious environmental policy with a suite of fables about &ldquo;Tinkerbell outfits and unicorns,&rdquo; communism, troubling disdain for &ldquo;Dictator Wolf&rdquo; and the &ldquo;Chinese virus,&rdquo; and vegetable gardening techniques. Following what has become a pattern for this Committee, today&rsquo;s proceedings were absurd, dangerous and far afield of the behavior of credible elected officials.</p>

<p>The truth is that Governor Tom Wolf&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/executive-order-2019-07-commonwealth-leadership-in-addressing-climate-change-through-electric-sector-emissions-reductions/"">Executive Order 2019-07</a> instructed the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) to <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Model-shows-RGGI-would-reduce-pollution-by-180-million-tons"">develop a cap-and-invest program</a> to control carbon pollution from power plants in Pennsylvania that aligns with the RGGI. And that&rsquo;s exactly what the current rule package does. Instead of letting power plants dump carbon pollution into our air for free, they will have to pay a price that is determined through an auction. In addition, millions of dollars in proceeds from Pennsylvania&rsquo;s participation in RGGI could and should be reinvested in our communities via air quality projects.</p>

<p>The truth is that joining RGGI would allow Pennsylvania to make crucial dents in its carbon pollution while simultaneously raising millions of dollars in the process. RGGI states <a href=""https://www.yaleclimateconnections.org/2020/01/power-plant-emissions-down-47-percent-under-the-regional-greenhouse-gas-initiative/"">have reduced their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 47 percent</a>, outpacing the rest of the nation by 90 percent. Scientists and economists <a href=""https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/plugged-in/what-economists-say-about-carbon-pricing/"">both agree that carbon pricing</a> is one of the best ways to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Further, reducing air pollution would save hundreds of lives, tens of thousands of hours of lost work, lead to strong net job creation, and result in an overall total of $5.7 billion dollars in benefits.</p>

<p>Utilizing the &ldquo;polluter-pays&rdquo; principle is a meaningful way of combating this pollution. Rather than subsidizing the cost of pollution for dirty plants, we would monetize the costs of that pollution and let the market make better-informed choices about what power to buy. The ten RGGI states <a href=""https://www.analysisgroup.com/globalassets/uploadedfiles/content/insights/publishing/analysis_group_rggi_report_april_2018.pdf"">have seen $1.4 billion in net economic benefits</a> from 2015 to 2017. By linking Pennsylvania&rsquo;s air quality program with the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, the Commonwealth could bring in as much as $350-500 million annually.</p>

<p>It was made clear today by Chairman Metcalfe&rsquo;s own revelation that attacking RGGI is nothing more than another attempt to undermine Governor Wolf. In his own words, Metcalfe said that &ldquo;impeachment is the only way to stop him.&rdquo; It&rsquo;s increasingly evident that this is a part of a grander scheme, and one that has shown for a long time to be anti-science and anti-reason.These games convey that the House leadership is not interested in Pennsylvania&rsquo;s&rsquo; clean air and financial growth, but instead solely focused on protecting their polluter friends.</p>

<p>Thankfully, environmental champions on the House Environmental Resources &amp; Energy Committee stood up and put facts on record in the committee room, which is shuttered to the public.</p>

<p>Rep. Leanne Krueger (Delaware) rightfully made the case that the &ldquo;power for the Governor to join compacts [for Pennsylvania] is clearly in the Constitution,&rdquo; and argued that, &ldquo;we have a constitutional [duty] to protect clean air and pure water for all Pennsylvanians.&rdquo; Minority Chairman Greg Vitali (Delaware) added that, &ldquo;Pennsylvania clearly has authority to regulate carbon based on the [state&rsquo;s] Air Quality Control Act.&rdquo; Rep. Mary Isaacson (Philadelphia) showed that transitions and reinvestment in our communities is essential and that jobs spurred by Pennsylvania joining RGGI could be a great source of family-sustaining jobs for our workers.</p>

<p>Perhaps most compelling were the arguments put forward passionately by Rep. Danielle Friel Otten (Chester) who said that &ldquo;protecting our environment is truly about protecting the health and safety of Pennsylvanians.&rdquo; She mentioned that the leading cause of congenital heart disease and asthma in children is air pollution. Rep. Otten mentioned that joining RGGI has many benefits and that &ldquo;we can use money from RGGI to reinvest in environmental justice communities and communities of color who are disproportionately impacted by the industry.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We wholly agree, and at the end of the day, as Rep. Otten succinctly and powerfully posited, &ldquo;when we&rsquo;re not protecting our children, seniors, and vulnerable populations, we&rsquo;re not upholding our constitutional duties.&rdquo;</p>

<p>PennFuture will continue to oppose this cavalier legislation and its companion bill in the Senate&mdash;SB 950 (Pittman)&mdash;and will continue to advocate for the advancement of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s RGGI rulemaking package, which will bring about significant reduction to Pennsylvania&rsquo;s carbon pollution along with increased economic benefits.</p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
Looking in the Rearview Mirror,6/8/2020,"<p>In all honesty, by 1994 after six years leading two environmental movements&mdash;the PA Rainforest Action Committee and Central PA Earth Day Committee&mdash;I became disillusioned that the 20th anniversary of Earth Day would reignite&nbsp;action from Washington to address the threat of global warming, as it was referred to then. For the next 10 years my activism took the form of writing, publishing and studying this country&rsquo;s history of environmental irresponsibility.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2004, John Hanger&mdash;the first Executive Director of PennFuture&mdash;asked me to join the Board of Directors of the organization. At the time, their motto was &ldquo;Every environmental victory is an economic success.&rdquo; Bingo! I found my tribe.</p>

<p>PennFuture has always, even from inception, been highly respected within Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environmental community. Where it had tremendous impact was in the halls of the Capitol. Those were &lsquo;good times&rsquo; for the environment.</p>

<p>We had the ear of Governor Ed Rendell, who had faith in Hanger and PennFuture. There was more balance in the legislature. DEP and DCNR were doing good work and our Energy Center was busy paving inroads for alternatives and throughout those years, our funding from Heinz and Pew Foundations remained strong. In sum, the staff of PennFuture were laying the foundation of what would become a distinguished environmental organization in Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>By 2008 we were celebrating our 10th anniversary with Vice President Al Gore in attendance to support us. Mr. Gore describe PennFuture as &ldquo;the only statewide environmental organization in the country with a three-tier focus of policy, legal and energy work.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We were riding high on successes until the chessboard pieces shifted. Hanger moved onto head DEP, Gov. Tom Corbett replaced Rendell, and the Marcellus Shale created new environmental challenges while gaining more influence on policy.</p>

<p>At the same time, PennFuture was going through what seemed like a revolving door of leadership. In hindsight, these were the most challenging years for the board. I give credit to the leadership of Chair David Lane for guiding the organization through several years of executive searches. For both the staff and the board members, it was our commitment to PennFuture&rsquo;s mission as &ldquo;the watchdogs of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment&rdquo; that we refreshed our efforts.&nbsp;</p>

<p>By 2014, I moved into the Chair&rsquo;s shoes and we were again searching for an Executive Director. In 2015 PennFuture was fortunate to hire Larry Schweiger who had recently stepped down from the National Wildlife Federation. To be frank, we felt we hit payday. And it turns out we did.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Larry brought new ideas and opened doors for the organization. It was Larry&rsquo;s leadership that began the conversation to partner with Conservation Voters of Pennsylvania, which has strengthened our policy and advocacy work and expanded PennFuture&rsquo;s influence.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Larry insisted he hire Jacquelyn Bonomo as his chief operating officer. Jacqui came with decades of environmental leadership and discipline, and she brought structure to the organization and always had an ear for my input, which made working with her one of the highlights of my tenure.&nbsp;</p>

<p>When Jacqui became President/CEO in 2017 and hired Matt Stepp as chief operating officer, they began restructuring PennFuture to meet the political, environmental, financial and personnel challenges of the time. This was hard work that required serious communication, organization and action. Throughout, the board was there to guide and support this transition.</p>

<p>During my time with PennFuture, I have witnessed the organization being transformed into a highly organized, focused and impressive instrument for change. Our reach throughout Pennsylvania has expanded beyond anything I could have imagined 16 years ago when I joined the board.</p>

<p>I leave PF confident and grateful. Confident that the executives are clear, dedicated and driven leaders. Grateful that climate change is now a main focus of PennFuture and grateful for my fellow board members who have always taken their position seriously and when needed, rolled up their sleeves, put in the time and got the work done with the understanding they are the caretakers of this important organization.</p>

<p><u><em><strong>Editor&rsquo;s note:</strong></em></u></p>

<p>Though she wouldn&rsquo;t admit it, Char Magaro was working on climate change issues long before anyone else was really aware of it. Her activism on this issue, and others, emanates from her early work advocating for rainforest protection.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Over the years, Char allowed PennFuture to use her restaurants for fundraisers and other events. We always knew that our guests would feel welcomed and really appreciate Char&rsquo;s high standards and hospitality.</p>

<p>Char was key to the success of PennFuture&rsquo;s 10th anniversary gala. She conceived the look and the style of the event so that it rose to fit the stellar line of speakers including Al Gore, Rebecca Rimmel of Pew Charitable Trusts, and Teresa Heinz of The Heinz Endowments. It was elegant, coordinated and it ran smoothly because of Char&rsquo;s attention to detail.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Char was essential in the transition and recruitment of PennFuture&rsquo;s CEOs, often a time consuming process, not once but twice. Hours of meetings and interviews were involved in this process.&nbsp;Char had great influence on the board, many times offering a point of view which was unique and creative. She blended well with all of the different personalities and thought big picture.&nbsp;</p>

<p>For 16 years Char been a significant part of the life of PennFuture, as we have been part of her life.&nbsp; She has supported us financially, offered wise guidance, floated many ideas, led the board ably as chair, and has been an inspiration and friend to many of us.</p>
