Updated Climate Change Assessment Reveals Future Pennsylvania Water Troubles,4/30/2020,"<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Department of Environmental Protection last week released the state&rsquo;s third <a href=""http://files.dep.state.pa.us/Energy/Office of Energy and Technology/OETDPortalFiles/ClimateChange/2020ClimateChangeImpactsAssessmentUpdate.pdf"">Climate Change Impacts Assessment</a>, and the update tells us of a warmer future with more rain, floods and landslides than ever experienced in Pennsylvania history.</p>

<p>Heavier and more frequent storms will cause Pennsylvania rivers and streams to swell more frequently. Downstream, greater volumes of sediment will mix with farmland runoff and the pollution-filled stormwater of surrounding cities and towns, exacerbating water concerns for miles and miles.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The impacts will affect our local streams and be noticed far beyond Pennsylvania&rsquo;s borders. Left unchecked and unprepared, the climate crisis will further heighten the difficulty of cleaning up the Chesapeake Bay.</p>

<p>Challenges will be further intensified if regional agricultural trends continue. The assessment predicts a warmer Pennsylvania climate will attract greater investment in livestock farming across the state. In particular, poultry farming may double by 2050.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Given the unpredictability of severe weather, we must do whatever we can to prepare&nbsp;now. This is no time to back down on long-term <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/what-is-green-stormwater-infrastructure"">investments in green stormwater infrastructure</a> and agricultural best management practices, as well as carbon-reduction policies such as <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fallacy-Fiction-and-Falsehoods-Debunking-RGGI-Myths-Part-1"">the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI)</a>.</p>

<p>The dozens of Pennsylvania municipalities <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/PennFuture_StormwaterManual_web_3.20.17.pdf"">that collect stormwater fees</a> are already better prepared to fund improvements necessary to adapt to climate change and to meet the state&rsquo;s legal obligations under the federal Clean Water Act.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Among those obligations, under <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/chesapeake-bay-tmdl"">the EPA&rsquo;s Chesapeake Bay Program</a>, regional states agree to Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) pollution goals for across the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Pennsylvania is committed to prevent 34 million pounds of nitrogen and 756,000 pounds of phosphorus.</p>

<p>To meet the Chesapeake Bay clean-up goals over the coming decades, the assessment anticipates that Pennsylvania will need to exceed annual nitrogen-reduction targets by another 4 million pounds.</p>

<p>Plus, if projected shifts in livestock production were to come true, think of the impact from all that animal manure. In Lancaster County, for example, nitrogen and phosphorous levels are projected to grow by 38% and 58%, respectively.</p>

<p>Not only do we need to better incentivize agricultural practices that lessen water pollution, such as riparian forested buffers and soil health, we must also react to how climate change will affect these practices. To date, research on how climate change will alter their effectiveness is, according to the assessment, &ldquo;essentially nonexistent for Pennsylvania&rdquo;</p>

<p>The release of this year&rsquo;s assessment update, amid the COVID-19 crisis, understandably may be lost amid the news cycle. Still, the warnings should not be overlooked. Even during a time of crisis, we must not lose vision of the challenges lying ahead if we fail to take climate action.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As David Wallace-Wells <a href=""https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/04/the-coronavirus-is-a-preview-of-our-climate-change-future.html"">writes in New York Magazine</a>, &ldquo;The virus is a terrifying harbinger of future pandemics that will be brought about if climate change continues to so deeply destabilize the natural world: scrambling ecosystems, collapsing habitats, rewiring wildlife, and rewriting the rules that have governed all life on this planet for all of human history.&rdquo;</p>

<p>In Pennsylvania, we need to stay focused.</p>

<p>Recent analysis finds that if the state were to follow Governor Tom Wolf&rsquo;s proposal and join RGGI, such action would allow Pennsylvania to <a href=""http://files.dep.state.pa.us/Air/AirQuality/AQPortalFiles/Advisory Committees/Air Quality Technical Advisory Committee/2020/4-23-20/RGGI IPM Modeling Webinar.pdf"">reduce nearly 10 times the carbon emissions</a> than anticipated under current policies.</p>

<p>Despite that, leaders of the Pennsylvania Senate Republican Caucus are nonetheless <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2020/04/23/dep-projects-pa-could-cut-carbon-emissions-dramatically-as-part-of-cap-and-trade-effort/"">asking Wolf to rescind the order</a>, citing the pandemic as their excuse. In addition, certain factions within the General Assembly are in the process of trying to freeze funding that supports local parks, trails, environmental restoration projects, county conservation districts and other projects.</p>

<p>Today&rsquo;s emergencies do not justify creating more crises for future generations to bear. We must continue to work toward a stable climate. We must continue to prioritize clean water policies, and we must continue to fund programs and projects that protect our natural resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Otherwise, with the release of each impact assessment, we will find ourselves with less time to act and with diminished ability to avoid the worse to come.</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,"Renee Reber, Campaign Manager, Watershed Advocacy"
Fracked Gas and Petrochemical Industries Jockeying for Stimulus Recovery Funds,4/29/2020,"<p>In mid-April, the fracked gas and petrochemical industries&mdash;with the help of a contingent in the U.S. House of Representatives&mdash;<a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2020/04/22/natural-gas-companies-debt-loan-program-Fed-small-businesses-rate/stories/202004230017"">bombarded the U.S. Treasury Department</a> with letters begging the federal government for help paying back its loans.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Specifically, industry and its boosters want to use a program called the Main Street Lending Program&mdash;which is intended to provide a lifeline to small businesses struggling in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic&mdash;to pay back billions in debts accrued well before the current global health crisis unfolded.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As it currently stands, the government is prohibiting businesses from using these special loans to pay off debt, but an intense lobbying effort by the industry could change that.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Why, in the midst of an economic collapse not seen since the Great Depression, would this industry try to repurpose loans that are needed to keep thousands of small businesses afloat?&nbsp;</p>

<p>Because the industry knows it might collapse without them.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The headlines have been eye-popping. One outlet predicted that <a href=""https://www.worldoil.com/news/2020/3/27/experts-see-a-future-for-shale-rocks-don-t-go-bankrupt"">as many as 70 percent</a> of the 6,000 shale drillers in America may go bankrupt in the near future. In late April, the industry <a href=""https://www.cbsnews.com/news/negative-oil-prices-what-does-that-mean/"">hit an unprecedented rock bottom</a> as the price for futures contracts went below zero for the first time ever.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/31/business/energy-environment/pennsylvania-shale-gas-fracking.html"">the New York Times reported</a> in late March, some of the largest fracking companies in Pennsylvania&mdash;among them Range Resources, EQT and Southwestern Energy&mdash;have seen their stocks plummet and debts increase by a combined $7 billion since 2008.</p>

<p>Even Shell, the global behemoth that is building an ethane cracker plant in Beaver County, has seen its share prices drop by nearly half this year and <a href=""https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-lng-shell/shell-drops-out-of-major-u-s-lng-project-energy-transfer-delays-decision-idUSKBN21H2E9"">has stated its intent to pull out</a> of a major Liquified Natural gas project in Louisiana, citing market conditions.</p>

<p>The industry is facing more than $200 billion in corporate debt, and <a href=""https://www.ciel.org/news/pandemic-crisis-systemic-decline-new-report-warns-oil-gas-and-plastic-industries-are-an-unfillable-sinkhole-for-recovery-funds/"">one study published on April 16</a> warns of the dangers of dumping stimulus money into an industry that was already facing &ldquo;profound and pervasive risks&rdquo; before the pandemic.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;Shoveling money at the oil, gas, and petrochemical industries will not change the fundamental weaknesses they faced before this crisis began and will face moving forward,&rdquo; said report co-author Steven Feit.</p>

<p>That report makes clear an uncomfortable truth facing the industry: the ongoing coronavirus pandemic is accelerating its rapid decline, but it is not the sole cause or reason for the decline.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s exceedingly clear that this industry was on shaky financial footing even before the current pandemic upended our economy. Coronavirus isn&rsquo;t the culprit behind poor money management, declining revenues and inherent weaknesses that have plagued the industry. It wasn&rsquo;t a global public health crisis that made the financial sector deeply wary and skeptical of fossil fuels.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Take, for instance, the chief executive officer of a Texas-based oil and gas exploration company <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2020/04/22/natural-gas-companies-debt-loan-program-Fed-small-businesses-rate/stories/202004230017"">who was quoted recently in the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette</a> as saying &ldquo;no one wants to give (the industry) capital because we have all destroyed capital and created economic waste.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Why, then, would the federal government&mdash;or any other government, financial institution, or other entity&mdash;be enticed to offer billions of dollars in bailouts to an industry that has consistently and routinely &ldquo;destroyed capital and created economic waste&rdquo; well before the current pandemic?&nbsp;</p>

<p>Carroll Muffett, the president of CIEL&mdash;the organization <a href=""https://www.ciel.org/news/pandemic-crisis-systemic-decline-new-report-warns-oil-gas-and-plastic-industries-are-an-unfillable-sinkhole-for-recovery-funds/"">that published the study</a> warning against dumping stimulus money into this failing industry&mdash;said it best by adding that there&rsquo;s &ldquo;overwhelming evidence that this sector has reached its end game,&rdquo; and that it did so even before coronavirus.</p>

<p>&ldquo;No amount of government intervention or taxpayer money can save these companies in the long term unless they fundamentally transform their business models. For governments to continue dumping money into these industries is throwing money down a hole at a time when every moment and every dollar needs to be used effectively for the greatest possible public good.&rdquo;</p>

<p>For fossil fuels, the writing was sprawled across the wall well before current events took hold, and the industry should not try to parlay the coronavirus into an undeserved, irresponsible and reckless attempt at a bailout.</p>
",Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
PennFuture taking holistic view of improving water quality around Philadelphia,4/28/2020,"<p>Last week, the Delaware River <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Congratulations-to-the-Delaware-River"">was named the 2020 national &ldquo;River of the Year&rdquo;</a> by American Rivers. This honor recognizes the dramatic improvement of the Delaware River&rsquo;s water quality, which the organization credited to intergovernmental collaboration and effective environmental enforcement, coupled with innovative local water management.</p>

<p>Fish have returned to the urbanized portions of the river and the community is once again thinking of the lower Delaware River as a place of recreation!&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture is happy to be part of that push for better water quality over the past several decades, especially in the Philadelphia region of the Delaware River Watershed, where we&rsquo;ve been advocating for a variety of ways to improve the water.&nbsp;</p>

<p>For example, our <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Category-KeepPhillyGreen"">Keep Philly Green &amp; Water Clean campaign</a> has been focusing on increasing green stormwater infrastructure (GSI) in the city. Philadelphia is increasing the use of GSI &ndash; such as rain gardens, tree trenches, and green roofs &ndash; through its Green City, Clean Waters program, which reduces the amount of polluted stormwater that enters the Delaware River and its tributaries through Philadelphia&rsquo;s combined sewer overflow (CSO) system. GSI has the added benefit of providing local communities with local jobs, cleaner air, more attractive parks, and streets, and an overall healthier community.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2018, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Philadelphias-Green-City-Clean-Waters-Needs-Funding-to-Achieve-Goals"">PennFuture submitted comments</a> in support of Philadelphia&rsquo;s Green City, Clean Waters program in which we detailed the importance of funding and grant incentive programs to achieve Philadelphia&rsquo;s GSI plan. In 2019, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-The-Opportunity-for-Green-Stormwater-Infrastructure-in-Philadelphias-Rebuild-Initiative"">we advocated for Philadelphia to combine</a> its GSI plan with the Rebuild Community Infrastructure (Rebuild) Initiative and petitioned the Philadelphia City Council to prioritize green stormwater infrastructure.</p>

<p>For the past two years in the fall, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Philly-GSI-Bus-tour"">PennFuture organized&nbsp;bus tours</a> with members of City Council aimed at highlighting the social, economic, and environmental benefits of GSI in Philadelphia. Earlier this month, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Philly-Can-Achieve-a-Green-New-Deal-through-Green-Stormwater-Infrastructure"">PennFuture advocated for a Green New Deal</a> for Philadelphia through an emphasis on GSI projects which create jobs, improve our local communities, and increase community resiliency against the impacts of climate change.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture is a proud supporter of Green City, Clean Waters and the work that the Philadelphia Water Department does to increase GSI and address pollution into the Delaware River while improving Philadelphia&rsquo;s communities. A cleaner Delaware River means we can all enjoy its benefits &ndash; drinking, fishing, and recreating!&nbsp;</p>

<p>That&rsquo;s why in March 2020, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-Petitions-DRBC-to-Recognize-Primary-Contact-Recreation-on-the-Mainstem-Delaware-River"">PennFuture and others petitioned the Delaware River Basin Commission</a> to upgrade the designated use of a portion of the lower Delaware River to reflect the community&rsquo;s use of the River for primary contact recreation sports.</p>

<p>And in late April, PennFuture joined with our partner organizations to educate conservation groups and community members about our <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/3.2.2020-Primary-Contact-PR---Petition.pdf"">&ldquo;Petition for a Safe and Healthy Delaware River.&rdquo;</a> This petition asks for the Delaware River Basin Commission to recognize what American Rivers and others have: that the lower Delaware River has improved and that people are using it for swimming, kayaking, paddle boarding, jet skiing, and other water sports that put community members in the river.&nbsp;</p>

<p>But now we need your support of our petition. <a href=""https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeKiNCkEg_QcEEHqSBhUwbhQiJjgzaKQX5UhAramPQO7nE8aA/viewform"">Share your story of how you recreate</a> on the lower Delaware River. Sign on to our petition &ndash; <a href=""https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSccmsyRjHIRemMq24UQVqGwpL7IYz1s4NsfFXnqpz4F9yd1sw/viewform"">whether you&rsquo;re a conservation organization</a> or a <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/supportdelawarepetition"">concerned community member</a>. Your stories matter to the health of the Delaware!&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We know that there are many different ways to protect water quality, and in the Philadelphia region, PennFuture has been utilizing many of our legal and advocacy tools to achieve a holistic vision for improvement of the water quality of the lower Delaware River watershed!&nbsp;</p>

<p>We have fought hard to stop polluters and to find innovative ways to improve water quality of the Delaware River, and now we&rsquo;re advocating to protect the advances we&rsquo;ve made over the years.<br />
Want to support our great work in Philadelphia and the Delaware River Watershed? <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">Become a PennFuture member!</a></p>

",Community; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Model shows participation in RGGI would reduce pollution by 180 million tons,4/27/2020,"<p>On April 24, the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) held a joint web conference to present <a href=""https://www.icf.com"">recent modeling completed by ICF</a> on the potential impact of Governor Wolf&rsquo;s plan to implement a cap-and-invest program in cooperation with the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI).</p>

<p>The results show the plan marks a significant step toward reaching our carbon pollution goals by saving 180 million tons of carbon pollution while maintaining Pennsylvania&#39;s status as a significant energy generator and exporter.</p>

<p>While this is great news on its own, ICF focused its modeling on the impacts of putting a cap on carbon admissions. The RGGI program also has an &ldquo;invest&rdquo; component where we can see even more benefits, but those weren&rsquo;t modeled. When Abt Associates <a href=""https://www.abtassociates.com/insights/publications/report/analysis-of-the-public-health-impacts-of-the-regional-greenhouse-gas"">looked into these broader impacts</a> seen in the other RGGI states they found it saved hundreds of lives, tens of thousands of hours of lost work, led to strong net job creation, and resulted in an overall total of $5.7 billion dollars in benefits.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Of course, no matter the benefits, you can&rsquo;t talk about reducing carbon pollution without generating attacks from polluters and their friends.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>One of their top-line arguments is that RGGI is going to kill coal. As we&rsquo;ve said before, coal generation in Pennsylvania is already on its last legs without RGGI&mdash;it went from 47 percent of our generation in 2010 to just 17 percent last year, and ICF predicts it will continue to drop to just 3 percent of our generation by 2030 even without RGGI.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>This is not surprising since there are few remaining large coal-fired power plants in Pennsylvania, all of them are rapidly approaching retirement, and no one is planning to build new plants. When RGGI is added to the mix, coal retirement speeds up a little bit to just over 1 percent of our generation by 2030. With RGGI making less than a 2 percent difference in overall coal generation, it&rsquo;s clear whatever problems the industry is facing, it is not RGGI that is killing coal.</p>

<p>The next line of attack is asserting that RGGI will raise prices. It&rsquo;s true that ICF&rsquo;s modeling shows a slight increase in energy prices by 1.1 tenths of a cent a kilowatt-hour over business-as-usual.&nbsp; While this works out to less than $1 per month on the average household bill, when adjusted for inflation energy prices are predicted to be lower with RGGI than they are today.</p>

<p>It is also important to remember that there is a big difference between the price of energy and what consumers actually pay. If gas prices go up, people respond by driving less or buying a car with better gas mileage&mdash;the same thing happens with your electric bill. Consumers can invest in energy efficiency and renewable energy to reduce their bills. Better still, the fees generated by the RGGI program can go into programs that make those investments even cheaper, and this wasn&rsquo;t considered in the ICF modeling.</p>

<p>The last big attack comes in a lot of different forms, but it&rsquo;s that&nbsp; RGGI isn&rsquo;t going to fix the climate change crisis on its own, so it&rsquo;s not worth doing at all. Any elementary school student would probably realize that saying &ldquo;other people litter, so why not throw my trash out the window too?&rdquo; is a cop-out.</p>

<p>We all have a responsibility to act but Pennsylvania, as a huge source of the emissions that created the crisis, may have a greater responsibility than others to solve the problem. The investments and actions we take today will have long-lasting impacts well beyond 2030 and play a significant role in meeting our climate goals.</p>

<p>The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change tells us to avoid the worst effects of climate change we need to get to net-zero emissions by 2050. With electric generation being the largest source of carbon pollution in Pennsylvania, it&rsquo;s clear that we are not going to reach that goal, or even the lesser Paris goals, without doing all we can.</p>

<p>Failing to adopt the RGGI program means that we need to find a way to reduce 180 million extra tons of carbon pollution from some other source, and it&rsquo;s very likely that source isn&rsquo;t going to provide over a billion dollars in net benefits as we would see from RGGI.</p>

<p>These are not the last of the attacks we are going to see. Representatives from DEP did a great job at the briefing responding to these attacks, but as we go forward they are going to increase in frequency and intensity.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Be sure that PennFuture will be there every step of the way, pushing back against fallacies and mistruths, and doing what we can to keep you educated, informed and engaged with this long process.</p>
",Energy; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
Earth Day 2070,4/21/2020,"<p>I truly believed this week, Earth Week, could be a magical one, when the world would come together to commemorate the 50th Anniversary of the first Earth Day.</p>

<p>Many months ago, when I began thinking about how we would be marking this momentous anniversary, I envisioned everything that happened in 1970 on behalf of &ldquo;Mother Earth.&rdquo;&nbsp;The decade of the anti-establishment 1960&rsquo;s actually peaked in 1970. Millions of people were in the streets in peaceful and turbulent protest; colleges students mounted teach-ins or occupied administration buildings; multiple generations were caught in the mod fashion of the day but they were also turned onto activism and issues. Earth Day 1970 and the &ldquo;ecology movement&rdquo; lead to a suite of sweeping legislation to protect our environment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Last summer, it seemed reasonable to think that on Earth Day 2020 in the midst of the existential climate crisis, the people of our earth would want to gather with even more urgency and turn out in bigger numbers than 1970 to change the condition of our planet&mdash;a planet besieged by anti-environmental policymakers, dark money billionaires and our own unsustainable lifestyles.&nbsp;Earth Day 2020 could be a catalyst to:&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Energize the myriad of people across the globe who are experiencing climate impacts who care deeply about addressing the climate crisis, who want to do something about it but don&rsquo;t know how;&nbsp; &nbsp;</li>
	<li>Give birth to a new environmental movement&mdash;one that reorients itself to not only climate matters, but to the concerns of so many diverse and underserved communities who are dealing also with impacts from chronic pollution and other forms of environmental degradation;&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Raise up our youth climate strikers, and their courage and persistence; and</li>
	<li>Mobilize caring citizens everywhere into an unstoppable political force to once and for all change the politics, in order to change the fate of our common climate.</li>
</ul>

<p>Can COVID-19 take this dream away? It sure has put a dent into the tactic of turning out great numbers of people, in public, demonstrating against climate inaction, demanding accountability of elected officials and celebrating climate solidarity.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>But COVID-19 has not taken away our common humanity, interconnectedness, and reliance upon planetary health as foundational to our personal safety and well-being. If anything, this pandemic puts a finer point on these attributes. And, grimly, this public health emergency has deepened the disparities between underserved individuals and communities of color, and their ability to survive this deadly pandemic.</p>

<p>My hat is off to the organizations and activists everywhere that have quickly retooled plans for Earth Day 2020, including PennFuture and Conservation Voters of PA&rsquo;s 30-Day Earth Challenge, and the Pittsburgh Earth Week Teach-In and 24-hour Climate Strike.</p>

<p>And while digital platforms are uniting us, I propose three actions&mdash;more surgical in nature&mdash;to ensure this momentous Earth Day does not come and go with only a whimper or sound tone from our smart phone:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Run for Office. Nothing will change our political system faster than a new crop of climate-forward candidates. Once elected, you can effect real change. And the threat of an onslaught of challengers will threaten incumbent elected officials who have grown stagnant, entrenched in a broken system and to the influence of political action money;</li>
	<li>Vote. Make sure you are registered to vote, and that you actually vote. And make sure that everyone you know who is eligible to vote, is registered to vote, and that they actually vote. Here is everything you need to know about voting in Pennsylvania in 2020.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Contact your elected officials and demand they declare a climate emergency for their respective jurisdictions. Request they develop a climate change action and response plan.&nbsp; Contact Governor Wolf and request that funds for this local climate planning&mdash;and implementation of existing climate action plans and projects&mdash;are included in any stimulus or economic recovery package that emerges as a result of the pandemic.&nbsp;</li>
</ol>

<p>Come with me to the date April 22, 2070&mdash;now the 100th anniversary of the first Earth Day.&nbsp;Will our Earth Week 2020 be one in which we found a way to rise up and break out, and break through the walls of our respective isolations, and despite the oppression of the pandemic, to find a way to recommit to the fight to save our planet, and our futures?</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
Congratulations to the Delaware River!,4/20/2020,"<p class=""MsoNormal"">The resurgence of the Delaware River has received well-deserved recognition. Beating out river basins all across the United States, the Delaware was named River of the Year for 2020 by national environmental group American Rivers.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">With much of Eastern Pennsylvania flowing into the Delaware watershed, PennFuture takes seriously our charge as a clean water watchdog for the river. <o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">Our legal team and community organizers defend the Delaware against illegal polluters and from efforts to undermine legal protections. As award-worthy as the Delaware is today, we take nothing for granted, continuously advocating for greater progress.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">The source of drinking water for 13.3&nbsp;million people, the Delaware is now relied upon as a clean water resource. But, 50 years back, the water quality we enjoy today was nearly unimaginable. Polluters recklessly dumped raw sewage and chemicals straight into the river, making it near impossible to sustain even the most basic forms of aquatic life.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">&ldquo;The quality of water in the Delaware has dramatically improved, fish and wildlife have returned in tremendous numbers, and the mainstem of the Delaware remains the longest free-flowing river in the eastern U.S., with the most extensive National Wild and Scenic River protection of any watershed in the country,&rdquo; <a href=""https://www.americanrivers.org/2020/04/river-of-the-year-for-2020-the-delaware-river/"">writes American Rivers</a> VP of Communications Amy Souers Kober. <o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">American Rivers credits the revitalization to intergovernmental collaboration and effective environmental enforcement, coupled with innovative local water management. <o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">PennFuture is proud of the role our volunteers and campaign staff have played in leading these efforts. <o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">For example, PennFuture is a lead convener for groups such as <a href=""https://ourpoconowaters.org/"">Our Pocono Waters</a>, a coalition of businesses and conservationists advocating for protection of the Exceptional Value headwaters of the Delaware. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Publication-PennFuture-and-Brodhead-Watershed-Association-Earn-Legal-Victory-for-Exceptional-Value-Streams-in-the-Poconos"">A recent campaign successfully thwarted</a> well-heeled owners of resorts and other large developments from weakening regional stream protections.</p>

<p class=""MsoNormal""><o:p>PennFuture also holds the state lead seat for the Coalition of the Delaware River Watershed, a four-state coalition made up of over 150 members nongovernmental organizations. This coalition is dedicated to &ldquo;protecting and restoring the Delaware River, its tributaries, and more than 13,500 square miles of forests, wetlands, communities, and other distinctive landscapes in the Watershed, so that clean water and valued resources can be here for generations to come.&rdquo;</o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">Last month, PennFuture attorneys <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-Petitions-DRBC-to-Recognize-Primary-Contact-Recreation-on-the-Mainstem-Delaware-River"">co-led a draft petition to upgrade water quality standards for a portion of the Delaware River</a>. The petition demands regulators ensure the safety of all who engage in direct contact recreation &ndash; such as jet skiing and kayaking, swimming, stand-up paddleboarding and tubing. <o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">In addition to advocacy work across the watershed, PennFuture keeps watch on individual polluters. Earlier this year, PennFuture placed two Philadelphia scrap metal facilities on notice for operating without necessary stormwater pollution controls. <o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">When scrap metal contacts with stormwater, pollutants such as motor oil, grease, lead, chromium, cadmium, copper, mercury and zinc may flow into the Delaware River. Our actions are deterring scrap yards and other industrial facilities who may otherwise operate with inadequate pollution control measures.<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">Let&rsquo;s continue to celebrate and protect the Delaware River. <o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">Throughout the year, we will pair volunteers with their elected officials, educating leaders on the benefits of clean streams. <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/ourpoconowaters/index.html"">Join us</a> to help ensure the steady flow of clean water progress. <o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">River of the Year? We&rsquo;ll drink to that.<o:p></o:p></p>
",Community; Environment,"Emily Rinaldi Baldauff, Campaigns Director"
"PennFuture, partners to celebrate PA Clean Water Week",4/13/2020,"<p>The ongoing coronavirus pandemic has fundamentally changed most aspects of our lives in the last several months, but one thing that&rsquo;s changed for the positive is our connection to nature and the outdoors.</p>

<p>Here at PennFuture, we&rsquo;ve always taken seriously the need to appreciate Pennsylvania&rsquo;s natural resources, which is why we do everything we can to protect and preserve them. Part of that work, however, involves highlighting all of our beautiful streams, rivers and waterways throughout Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>That&rsquo;s why this week, in conjunction with groups like the Coalition for the Delaware River Watershed and the Choose Clean Water Coalition, we are officially celebrating the first ever &ldquo;PA Clean Water Week.&rdquo; During this period, we are celebrating not only the waters of Pennsylvania, but advocating for their preservation and health, and for funding from our state and federal governments for restoration and maintenance projects.</p>

<p>Each day this week, we will feature a different watershed in Pennsylvania and will use social media like Facebook and Twitter to communicate with supporters.&nbsp;</p>

<p>On Monday, April 13, we will celebrate the Delaware River watershed. On Tuesday, we will highlight the Chesapeake Bay watershed, which includes the Susquehanna &amp; Potomac Rivers. Wednesday will include a celebration of the Ohio River watershed, which includes the Allegheny, Monongahela and Ohio rivers. Thursday will include a celebration of the Lake Erie and Genesee River watersheds. Friday will wrap up PA Clean Water Week with a virtual webinar to celebrate all of these wonderful watersheds!</p>

<p>Every day of the week, you can celebrate Pennsylvania&rsquo;s streams and rivers by sharing photos of your local waterways, posting a short video on why clean water matters to you, writing a poem or short story, or posting on social media. Please be sure to tag PennFuture on both Facebook and Twitter or use the hashtag #PaCleanWaterWeek, so we can share your contributions during the celebration webinar on Friday, April 17!</p>

<p>If you&rsquo;d like to register for the live celebration webinar here, <a href=""https://bit.ly/3bPYhXk"">click here</a>.</p>

<p>At PennFuture, and on behalf of our partners and colleagues, we are thrilled to celebrate Pennsylvania&rsquo;s clean rivers, streams and waterways this week! Now, more than ever, we need to cherish and preserve these natural resources for generations to come.</p>

<p>Will you join us? Anyone wishing to learn more about PA Clean Water Week should contact PennFuture Campaigns Director Emily Baldauff, at <a href=""mailto:baldauff@pennfuture.org"">baldauff@pennfuture.org</a>, or Renee Reber, at <a href=""mailto:reber@pennfuture.org"">reber@pennfuture.org</a>.&nbsp;</p>

",Community; Environment,"Renee Reber, Campaign Manager, Watershed Advocacy"
Five Environmental Consequences of the Covid-19 Pandemic for Pennsylvania,4/8/2020,"<div>The environmental, economic, and social impacts of Covid-19 are profound and are reshaping how we work, recreate, and live our daily lives. While the impacts of this crisis will continue to shift and grow with each passing week, a number of critical environmental observations relevant to Pennsylvania are becoming clearer:</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<p><strong>1. The importance of our outdoor and green spaces is vital now more than ever.</strong> Governor Tom Wolf issued a &ldquo;stay-at-home&rdquo; order to compel citizens across the Commonwealth to limit their daily interactions with others to curb the spread of the coronavirus. The order allowed engaging in outdoor activities as long as safe social distancing guidelines were followed. Pennsylvanians have responded by visiting their state parks, state forest lands, and municipal parks <a href=""https://www.fox43.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/pa-dcnr-shares-guidelines-for-those-who-want-to-spend-time-outdoors-during-the-covid-19-outbreak/521-239d4182-88e9-4827-b5f9-4fcaf7393e69"">in record numbers</a>. The opening of trout season <a href=""https://www.media.pa.gov/Pages/fish-and-Boat-Commission-Details.aspx?newsid=316"">was pushed up by a week</a> to provide anglers more access to fish stocked streams. Whether for exercise, taking in the warm weather, getting our children outside, or wholesome recreation, it&rsquo;s clear that connecting&mdash;or for many re-connecting&mdash;with the historic trails, forests, streams, and lakes of Pennsylvania has been an important escape from the pandemic. The health crisis is re-teaching us how important our green spaces&mdash;and by extension the conservation of these special places&mdash;are to our mental and physical wellbeing. While for terrible reasons, new and old generations of hikers, anglers, birders, walkers, boaters, hunters, and runners are experiencing the state&rsquo;s natural beauty, which could have long term positive impact on the use and conservation of our public lands.</p>

<p><strong>2. Covid-19 is exacerbating the equity and justice gap between communities impacted by pollution and those that are not.</strong> Much reporting has been done on how the pandemic is impacting people differently. While blue collar workers are filing for unemployment, poor, <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/07/us/coronavirus-race.html"">immigrant</a>, and <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/07/us/coronavirus-race.html"">black and brown neighborhoods</a> are experiencing <a href=""https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-coronavirus-and-inequality-meet-in-detroit"">higher levels of infection</a> and death than those that are more affluent. The pandemic is not necessarily an equal opportunist as its consequences are being felt more acutely by those without access to healthcare, those who can&rsquo;t work from home, and those with underlying health and morbidity conditions, such as those <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/07/climate/air-pollution-coronavirus-covid.html"">caused by chronic pollution</a>. According to new research from Harvard University, Covid-19 patients in areas with high levels of air pollution had a higher likelihood of death. Chronic air pollution from traffic, factories, and fossil fuel power plants cause more cases of asthma, lung disease, and cardiovascular disease that, when combined with severe lung inflammation caused by Covid-19, is often fatal. It brings into clear view the long-term damage caused by chronic pollution to our environmental justice communities and how reducing pollution should now more than ever be a top public health priority.</p>

<p><strong>3. The Commonwealth&rsquo;s boom-and-bust fossil fuel economy is unsustainable.</strong> Even before the pandemic, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s fossil fuel economy was on its heels. Oil and gas company stock prices are down 60 percent this year irrespective of the pandemic and companies <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/20/business/energy-environment/coronavirus-oil-companies-debt.html"">are now drastically cutting</a> project costs and their workforce. <a href=""https://www.industryweek.com/supply-chain/planning-forecasting/article/21125045/covid19-is-coming-for-the-chemical-industry-in-2020-basf-frets"">Petrochemical companies worry</a> that Covid-19 will result in yet another year of falling profits and production. And any recession caused by the Covid-19 crisis <a href=""https://grist.org/beacon/covid-is-killing-coal/"">could mark the end</a> of already struggling coal plants and coal mines. In other words, the pandemic is laying bare an unfortunate truth many already know&mdash;the Commonwealth&rsquo;s fossil fuel industry has no clothes. The economic hopes hung around fracked gas, petrochemical facilities, and coal plants are a boom-and-bust mirage. It&rsquo;s what makes the state legislature&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Why-Does-Pennsylvania-Insist-on-Offering-Subsidies-to-Fracked-Gas-and-Petrochemicals-The-Industries-Would-Collapse-Without-Them"">attempts to provide billions</a> in taxpayer subsidies to the petrochemical industry even more unsettling. It puts into question why the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) would want to provide waste coal plants <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-DEP-is-Asking-Us-to-Pick-Up-the-Bill-for-Waste-CoalAgain"">yet another subsidy</a>. And it is inconceivable why the state Department of Community and Economic Development (DCED) has made supporting a natural gas and plastics buildout <a href=""https://dced.pa.gov/key-industries/"">its top economic priority</a>. It&rsquo;s clear that Pennsylvania needs a new economic development strategy that doesn&rsquo;t rely on fossil fuels because our reliance on that industry is destroying not only the health of our communities, but their opportunity for long term, sustainable prosperity.</p>

<p><strong>4. The anti-environmental movement continues to advance even during a public health crisis. </strong>While the rest of the country and Commonwealth is focused on their safety and health during the Covid-19 crisis, the anti-environmental movement continues to advance its agenda. The Trump Administration made a stunning announcement <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Publication-PennFuture-urges-DEP-to-continue-enforcement-during-pandemic"">to suspend enforcement</a> of environmental and public health rules during the pandemic. The EPA is <a href=""https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-eases-emissions-rules-make-cars-safer-but-ignores-facts-2020-4"">finalizing a rollback</a> of fuel efficiency standards that the car manufacturers originally helped write and celebrated. The Pennsylvania Senate waited until the health crisis was in full swing <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-reacts-to-House-Bill-1100-being-sent-to-Gov-Wolf"">to send to the Governor House Bill 1100</a>, which would have provided open-ended subsidies for petrochemical plants (he vetoed it). And right now, a group of state legislators <a href=""http://paenvironmentdaily.blogspot.com/2020/04/analysis-conservative-republicans.html"">are pushing legislation</a> to strip funds from environmental programs that conserve public land (see #1) <a href=""http://paenvironmentdaily.blogspot.com/2020/04/republicans-on-house-committee-report.html"">as well as limit environmental protections</a>. These efforts unveil how little regard the anti-environmental movement has for conservation, public health, and sustainable communities.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>5. Post-Covid-19, the Commonwealth has a generational opportunity to reshape the economy toward sustainable economic development.</strong> I&rsquo;m an eternal optimist. Pennsylvania will make it through this health crisis. A new normal will set in, but our policymakers will need to get to work to restart the economy. The federal government already passed a $2.2 trillion stimulus to provide a 2-month bridge for workers and businesses and they already know that isn&rsquo;t enough to make it through the economic recession we&rsquo;re settling into. Federal, state, and municipal governments will need to enact a series of stimulus and economic recovery packages to get us through the economic inactivity caused by the crisis and then get everyone back to work. But it&rsquo;s clear we can&rsquo;t just restart what we were doing pre-pandemic for the reasons described above. The Commonwealth&rsquo;s economy was already on unsettled ground and throwing more money at unsustainable fossil fuel businesses puts our communities back in the same fear of boom-and-bust industries and fear of pollution impacts. Policymakers needs to get this right and invest in sustainable, shovel-ready projects that provide family-sustaining wages as well as invest in industries that create jobs without harming our air, water, land, and climate. This crisis should be a wake-up call to get moving on a stronger, better, more sustainable economy.</p>
",Community; Environment,"Matthew Stepp, Vice President and Chief of Staff, PennFuture"
Philly Can Achieve a Green New Deal through Green Stormwater Infrastructure,4/1/2020,"<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Since the coronavirus pandemic hit Philadelphia, nearly half a million people have filed for unemployment, and that number will continue to rise. Nationwide the number of people who&rsquo;ve filed for unemployment has reached 6.6 million. We&rsquo;re observing a great depression in the making that will extend long after the pandemic crisis is over.</p>

<p>Last month, a group of climate and social experts in academia and civil society <a href=""https://medium.com/@green_stimulus_now"">released a letter laying out</a> a green stimulus proposal and called on the federal government to take action, a more robust policy plan to the Green New Deal resolution introduced by U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D., N.Y.) and U.S. Sen. Ed Markey (D., M.A.).&nbsp;</p>

<p>Philadelphia should develop the institutional infrastructure now to prepare for a Green Stimulus package, while at the same time calling on the federal government to pass a medium-term stimulus package that invests in communities, workforce development, and protecting natural resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Despite an increase in jobs over the past ten years, Philadelphia has offered too few upward mobility pathways for residents in search of family-sustaining jobs. Of all jobs created since 2009, only 26 percent are in sectors paying more than $35,000 per year.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To achieve clean energy, clean water and community resiliency goals, a Green Stimulus promises to unleash millions in infrastructure investments that would produce thousands of dignified, high-wage jobs and stimulate the economy. These include construction and maintenance opportunities that reduce water pollution across the region.</p>

<p>The city&rsquo;s elected leaders are already advancing some of the climate change and economic policies described in the Green Stimulus letter. Among newly inaugurated City Council members, 11 of 17 members support creating a local Green New Deal, per a survey PennFuture conducted with other groups.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Yet Philly&rsquo;s largest green jobs initiative does not receive enough attention. To lay the groundwork for a local Green Stimulus, we need to refocus attention on the Philadelphia Water Department. The Philadelphia Water Department and its related operations employs thousands of Philadelphians. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/about-philadelphia-water-dept-green-city"">The Green City, Clean Waters program</a> is one of those programs, which is creating jobs and taking PWD into the water utility of the future green economy.</p>

<p>Green City, Clean Waters funds public and private projects across the city that filter stormwater through rocks, soil and plants, limiting the release of pollution into regional waterways caused by sewer system overflows. Beyond cleaner water, these green stormwater infrastructure projects create jobs, improve our local economy and prepare our communities for the impacts of climate change.</p>

<p>To maximize the workforce-redevelopment potential of Green City, Clean Waters, Philly leadership needs to renew the city&rsquo;s dedication to the program. By addressing current barriers to green stormwater infrastructure, including obstacles within city-led programs such as Rebuild, we can address our water pollution challenges while producing hundreds of new jobs.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>From Factory Jobs to Stormwater Careers</strong></p>

<p>After losing 263,000 jobs from 1970 to 2010, Philly <a href=""https://www.centercityphila.org/uploads/attachments/ck24wk9av08l08lqdv2nmwekd-19-jobs-report-web-update.pdf"">had recently been adding jobs</a> at a faster rate than the country&rsquo;s 25 largest cities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>That said, as of 2018, the city still offered 23,000 fewer jobs compared to 1990. This is despite a 69,000-person increase in <a href=""https://www.philaworks.org/philadelphias-population/"">&ldquo;prime working age&rdquo;</a> residents over the same period. And the new jobs were mostly for entry-level work&mdash; most have been in sectors that pay on average $35,000 or less.</p>

<p>The rise in predominantly low-wage jobs contrasts with the opportunities available designing, installing or maintaining green stormwater infrastructure. <a href=""https://gsipartners.sbnphiladelphia.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/SBN_FINAL-REPORT.pdf"">A 2016 study estimates</a> Green City, Clean Waters then supported 430 local jobs and $27 million in annual labor income. Over its 20-year period, the program has been forecasted to produce 1,000 jobs per year.</p>

<p>Such work is generally accessible, well-paying and protected, with many employees offered meaningful advancement opportunities.</p>

<p>Green stormwater infrastructure operations and maintenance jobs typically require a high school diploma or less. Workers earning entry-level wages are, in all likelihood, collecting near minimum wage. But once workers are trained and experienced, they often receive higher wages as they transition from entry-level jobs to roles that require more training and certification. <a href=""https://d3n8a8pro7vhmx.cloudfront.net/greenforall/pages/1562/attachments/original/1412187831/Staying-Green-and-Growing-Jobs-April-2013.pdf.pdf?1412187831"">National data suggests</a> work experience, a high school diploma and additional job-related course work can offer wages upward of $20 per hour.</p>

<p>Workers involved in public projects are even more likely to earn living wages and benefits. Unionization rates in green stormwater infrastructure occupations are likely higher than the nationwide rate of 10 percent. Examples of high union representation among green stormwater infrastructure roles include jobs within the plumbing (20 percent), construction (18.5 percent) and landscape maintenance (15 percent) trades.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Unlock More Green Stormwater Infrastructure Work</strong></p>

<p>As Philadelphia City Council&rsquo;s environmental leaders discuss what a Green Stimulus means for the city, their legislative agendas must start by addressing current barriers to implementing Green City Clean Waters, including within other city programs such as the <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/programs/rebuild/project-sites/"">Rebuild Community Infrastructure Initiative.</a>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Through Rebuild, Philly continues to break ground on much-needed renovation of parks, recreation centers and libraries. At PennFuture, <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-The-Opportunity-for-Green-Stormwater-Infrastructure-in-Philadelphias-Rebuild-Initiative"">we have advocated that Philadelphia leaders</a> combine the goals of Green City, Clean Waters and Rebuild. In doing so, Philadelphia can align two major infrastructure investments and multiply the workforce development impact of these important programs.</p>

<p>In 2020, <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/2020-01-17-14-rebuild-projects-to-get-excited-about-in-2020/"">Rebuild is set to break ground</a> at six refurbished playgrounds. Green stormwater infrastructure does not currently appear to be included in any of these projects.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Green jobs attract a diverse workforce. Including more green stormwater infrastructure projects within Philadelphia&rsquo;s capital improvements could be a means to increase minority participation.</p>

<p>Rebuild, once estimated to reach $500 million in spending, pledged to award at least a third of construction contracts and a quarter of professional services contracts to minority- and women-owned firms. So far, <a href=""https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WBSxQ_1OGEXdIA7fPeHA2Mn6wRhxXHX_/view"">less than 28 percent</a> of Rebuild construction contracts and 24 percent of professional services have been allocated toward minority-owned firms.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>A study of <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/2019-06-06-office-of-economic-opportunity-releases-fy18-disparity-study/"">Fiscal Year 2018 contracts</a> found minority-owned firms were included on $1.45 billion of city-issued and quasi-public contracts. About 30 percent of this spending went directly to minority-owned firms, a slight decrease from FY17 and short of the city&rsquo;s 35 percent goal.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Our Message to City Council</strong></p>

<p>Let&rsquo;s not stop at Rebuild. Philly should require consideration of green stormwater infrastructure in every public capital project &mdash; just like developers must now install green stormwater infrastructure in larger new construction projects.</p>

<p>From school playgrounds and recreation center ballfields to streets and sidewalks, we need city leadership to join together and share responsibility for these stormwater initiatives. That includes funding a Clean Water Act Task Force coordinator position within the Managing Director&rsquo;s Office to develop a strategic plan that addresses interagency coordination.</p>

<p>Finally, to invest in jobs and infrastructure to address climate change, city leaders should call on PWD to plan for sustainable funding for GSI maintenance to ensure long-term success of green stormwater infrastructure.</p>

<p>If we take the Green New Deal seriously, green stormwater infrastructure is an opportunity for City Council to rise to the challenge and to transform Philadelphia&rsquo;s economy while creating jobs, protecting clean water and building climate resilience.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment; Keep Philly Green & Water Clean,Lena Smith
DEP is Asking Us to Pick Up the Bill for Waste Coal...Again,3/23/2020,"<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) is <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-First-Glimpse-PennFuture-analyzes-draft-of-DEPs-cap-and-invest-program"">developing a CO2 trading program</a> compatible with the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI). The <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-First-Glimpse-PennFuture-analyzes-draft-of-DEPs-cap-and-invest-program"">first draft of the program</a> would establish a state-wide cap on carbon emissions and require generators of electricity with a rated capacity of at least 25 megawatts (MW) to obtain allowances for each ton of CO2 they emit. Under the RGGI program, most of these allowances will be obtained through an auction, but it also allows a certain number of credits to be <a href=""https://www.rggi.org/sites/default/files/Uploads/Allowance-Tracking/States_Set-Aside_Accounts.pdf"">set aside for special purposes</a>. This provides for policy flexibility, but also opens the door to bad decisions that will limit carbon reductions.</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet=""""><u><strong>The Proposed Waste Coal Set Aside</strong></u></p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">DEP is proposing one set aside&mdash;reserving 7.9 million tons worth of allowances to be given away for free to electric generators that burn low-quality coal that mining companies dumped in huge piles all over the state&rsquo;s mining regions and left communities to deal with its hazards.</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">Pennsylvania has hundreds of millions of tons of waste coal piles and some have been leaching pollution into our streams and rivers for over a hundred years&mdash;in the worst cases, these piles can catch on fire and pollute the air as well. The companies that caused this pollution have often long-since gone out of business so, if the waste is going to be cleaned up, the state will either need to appropriate the funds to pay for it or find some other solution.</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">Digging up this coal and transferring it to appropriately-sited and designed disposal facilities is an expensive proposition. In some cases, it&rsquo;s possible to stabilize the piles in place by planting beach grass or other vegetation; that is much cheaper but it would still require the state to appropriate clean-up funds. Compared to paying for cleanup, it&rsquo;s not surprising our leaders see burning this waste in power plants as an acceptable alternative.</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">While new technology makes it possible to use this fuel in power plants, it&rsquo;s still a low-quality fuel. This means that waste coal plants tend to produce more air pollution than most other types of generation. In fact, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s waste coal plants are up to thirty percent more carbon polluting than some conventional coal plants and more than twice as carbon polluting as natural gas plants. By choosing to burn this waste, we are trading pollution of our land and water for increased emissions of air toxins, greenhouse gases, and other pollutants.</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">Proponents of waste coal argue that the environmental and public health benefits of cleaning up the waste piles more than make up for the added air pollution. Whether or not that is true in any particular case is not only a difficult technical problem, it&rsquo;s also a challenging ethical issue&mdash;for all the benefits on one end, someone else will be paying the price with adverse health impacts.&nbsp; We all support clean water and pristine landscapes, but is it fair for the most vulnerable to be asked to pay the price?&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">By and large, our leaders don&rsquo;t appear to have spent a lot of time worrying about the ethics or the technical details. Leaching waste coal piles are obvious sources of pollution everyone in the community can see, whereas air pollution is often invisible and the health impacts happen miles away and maybe years later, making it easier to ignore.&nbsp;</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">Proponents also argue that waste coal is a good financial deal for the Commonwealth. Unfortunately, that&rsquo;s far from true and their need for consistent taxpayer subsidies, even though waste coal is a mature technology, is proof enough. The fact that this is low-quality fuel means the plants that burn it have difficulty competing with more efficient generation and are constantly on the lookout for subsidies that help them remain profitable. The federal government effectively built this industry through subsidies resulting from the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 (PURPA) which allowed these plants to sell power at above-market rates.&nbsp; Since that time, more subsidies have followed.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards (AEPS) program includes waste coal in its &ldquo;Tier II&rdquo; category under which facilities collectively received over $2.5 million in subsidies in 2018. Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Coal Refuse Energy and Reclamation Tax Credit already provides $10 million in annual subsidies and a new subsidy bill (SB 618) would, if passed, increase that to $45 million.&nbsp; In addition to direct subsidies like these, we also see repeated efforts at the state and federal level to roll back environmental protections to benefit these plants.</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">In addition to all these existing subsidies, 7.9 million tons of free allowances will amount to another gift worth about $40 million. The DEP will effectively be saying that most plants must pay something to offset the damage their carbon pollution is causing, but the rest of us will pick up the tab for waste coal. Worse yet, when dirty energy is subsidized, that makes it that much harder for cleaner and better alternatives to compete in the market.</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet=""""><u><strong>DEP Should Rethink its Waste Coal Policy</strong></u></p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">Pennsylvania policymakers should also take a hard look at the costs vs. benefits from waste coal, including a thorough assessment of the public health and climate damage it is causing. If the state decides to accept the public health risks and continue subsidizing these plants, it must narrowly target those subsidies to prevent paying for more pollution.</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">At a minimum, that means the DEP should insert basic criteria into its CO2 credit trading rule that ensures the citizens of Pennsylvania will see a net benefit. For example, when Maryland gives plants allowances through their Limited Industrial Exemption Set-aside Account (<a href=""http://www.dsd.state.md.us/comar/comarhtml/26/26.09.02.06.htm"">LIESA</a>), they require plants to submit a climate action plan demonstrating that they have employed reasonably available methods to reduce their CO2 emissions. Similarly, the DEP could require waste coal operators receiving additional subsidies to document that:</p>

<ul font-size:="""" style=""padding: 0px 40px; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">
	<li>we are remediating the most damaging waste piles first;</li>
	<li>we are not overlooking cheaper solutions to stabilize particular waste piles;</li>
	<li>plants are operating as cleanly and efficiently as possible;</li>
	<li>plants are in compliance with all environmental regulations;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>And, we are not subsidizing polluting plants more than is absolutely necessary.</li>
</ul>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet=""""><u><strong>Planning for the Retirement of Waste Coal</strong></u></p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">The DEP&rsquo;s should also address a significant issue with how it reduces set aside allowances as power generation reduces over time.&nbsp;When DEP sets the initial carbon cap, it will consider the amount of electricity generation we expect to consume and the carbon intensity of our available generation mix. Multiplied together, that will give us the amount of CO2 allowances needed to satisfy demand. If the cap is too high, the credits will be devalued and won&rsquo;t drive emissions reductions. If the cap is too low, there is a risk that the cost-containment reserve will be triggered and more allowances will be added to the pool.</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">Because <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/electricity/data/emissions/"">waste coal emits</a> about 1.3 tons of CO2 per MWh of generation, the 7.9 million tons of allowances equates to about 5.9 million MWh of generation. Nobody is building new coal or nuclear plants in Pennsylvania, so when that waste coal retires, it&rsquo;s likely to be replaced with some natural gas generation, some clean renewable generation, and efficiency improvements.&nbsp;Natural gas&mdash;the dirtiest of the likely alternatives&mdash;produces about half a ton of CO2 per MWh and the other options produce zero, so the worst-case scenario would be that the lost generation from waste coal can be replaced with just 3.0 million allowances. The other 2.9 million allowances are unneeded, but added to the pool anyway which will depress allowance prices and allow emissions growth.</p>

<p font-size:="""" style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "" trebuchet="""">Reaching net-zero carbon pollution by 2050 will continue to be a challenge and what to do with waste coal is part of that question.&nbsp;While we work to solve that problem, it&rsquo;s vital we don&rsquo;t make the situation worse. Governor Wolf&rsquo;s plan to institute a carbon cap is an important step, but creating loopholes for polluters is a dangerous precedent.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
While We Wait on the Future to Happen,3/20/2020,"<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">I&rsquo;m struck by how, on the one hand, the COVID-19 emergency demands all of our focus and attention. Society&rsquo;s collective response&mdash;and even its survival&mdash;demands us to stand down, stand back and stand away from our workaday lives to protect ourselves and our communities.&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">On the other hand, our government must push on aggressively&mdash;to govern, uplift, and mandate, if necessary, to address this historic health crisis. But to some extent, our government must also continue to do the people&rsquo;s business because the challenges facing us before the novel coronavirus emerged as a threat are still rampant.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">PennFuture was founded on the basic premise of engaging with the policy and legal institutions of the Commonwealth and giving voice to environmental matters. As a result, even under current circumstance, we simply must stay engaged, diligent and watchful of our elected actors who will be advancing important initiatives, including the state&rsquo;s budget, at some point in the coming months.&nbsp;<br style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;"" />
As many of you who follow us know,&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fighting-for-Our-Future"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">PennFuture&rsquo;s absolute priority</a>&nbsp;since the beginning of 2020 has been vehemently fighting House Bill 1100, the Energy and Fertilizer Manufacturing Tax Credit, a piece of legislation that provides an open-ended subsidy for the petrochemical industry to expand here in Pennsylvania.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">If it becomes law, HB 1100 will enable this highly polluting industry to grow and expand with the use of subsidies financed by Pennsylvania&rsquo;s taxpayers for the next 30 years. If not stopped, this legislation will write Pennsylvania&rsquo;s economic future and tie us more deeply than ever to fossil fuels, fracked gas, petrochemicals and plastics.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Along with our many allies across the state, we have mounted a fierce fight. We believe HB 1100 is rooted in corporate greed and preys not only on the largesse of taxpayers, but on the desperation of regions like northeast Pennsylvania, where family-sustaining wages and jobs are dwindling. It&rsquo;s created an environment where any economic salvation, even giveaways to petrochemical manufacturers, are being embraced, despite the impacts this industry will have on our communities, health, land, air and water.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">On March 9, we stood in the State Capitol with our allies in the legislature. We stood with other organizations, including grassroots folk from as far away as western Pennsylvania&rsquo;s frontline communities, who are dealing with chronic pollution and are now standing against any further suffering this industry will bring if allowed to expand. We stood on behalf of over 30 co-sponsoring organizations to &ldquo;Fight for Our Future.&rdquo;</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">And while we stood, representatives from other interests stood over us&mdash;literally watching from the balcony of the rotunda&mdash;where an hour later they were to mount their own media event, in favor of HB 1100. Point, counterpoint.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">What our diverse coalition of 35 groups and legislative allies did not see coming was what happened two days later. In Wilkes-Barre, 100 miles north of Harrisburg, political champions of HB 1100, representatives of specific labor unions, and friends of frackers, rallied in favor of the jobs they are being promised if HB 1100 becomes law. Jobs that will foul our air and water, kill our climate, and soak our communities in toxins, but jobs nonetheless. Our opponents&rsquo; messaging&mdash;&ldquo;we&rsquo;re for jobs&rdquo;&mdash;went unanswered that day by those of us who also stand for jobs&mdash;jobs that also will sustain families&mdash;but jobs that will not pollute our environment and health. Jobs that center on clean manufacturing and renewable energy instead of petrochemicals.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">HB 1100 has captured the imaginations and support of Republican, Independent and Democratic elected officials alike, including those beyond northeast Pennsylvania. But it&rsquo;s the northeast delegation who are carrying the lion&rsquo;s share of industry&rsquo;s water on this fight. How is it that those same imaginations are not able to dream of a different future for Pennsylvania, one that makes major investments in renewable energy and clean manufacturing rather than relying on us fracking and cracking our way into a paycheck?&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">On Sunday, March 15, PennFuture and our ally Conservation Voters of Pennsylvania placed full page ads in principal newspapers in Luzerne and Lackawanna counties that urged constituents to ask exactly that question of State Senator John Yudichak (I-14th), State Representative Gerald Mullery (D-119th) and State Representative Aaron Kaufer (R-120th). Part of that ad can be seen above. These elected officials must be held accountable for this taxpayer giveaway, and whatever harm this greedy industry causes to our future.&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">HB 1100 has passed both houses of the legislature and has been delivered to Gov. Tom Wolf, who is expected to veto. Next, very possibly, could be a vote to overturn the veto. Who will support the Governor&rsquo;s veto to kill HB 1100&rsquo;s petrochemical subsidy, and who will not?&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Most concerning is this: Will Republican leadership in the legislature attempt to manipulate the casting of an override vote on HB 1100&mdash;one of the most consequential pieces of legislation in years&mdash;while COVID-19 keeps the people and our voices shuttered out from the People&rsquo;s House?&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">We must not let our guard down during this crisis, and we ask for your help&nbsp;<a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/upholdveto-hb1100_copy1"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">by contacting your state legislator</a>&nbsp;and asking them to strike down HB 1100 once and for all.</p>
",Community; Energy; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
Fighting for Our Future,3/20/2020,"<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">There is power in unity and there is power in numbers. When we all come together and speak in a unified voice, decision makers have no choice but to listen.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">That was the primary takeaway from a rally on March 9 when 35 environmental, faith and civic groups from across Pennsylvania banded together on the steps of the Capitol rotunda in Harrisburg. We came from all corners of the Commonwealth for one common cause: to speak out against House Bill 1100, a dangerous piece of legislation that could radically alter Pennsylvania for decades to come.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">The bill, passed by the General Assembly on Feb. 4, offers billions of dollars in taxpayer subsidies to the fracked gas and petrochemical industries. If this legislation becomes law, it means Pennsylvanians everywhere will be paying for and subsidizing massive amounts of pollution, environmental degradation and sickness that come along with fracked gas and petrochemical expansion.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">For PennFuture and dozens of other organizations, this is an unacceptable vision for our future.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Our world is at a crossroads when we need to be moving away from fossil fuels, not using taxpayer money to fund their expansion. This bill completely disregards the need for immediate action on the climate crisis, and it asks Pennsylvanians to trade their health for the promise of jobs.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">As soon as the final vote on House Bill 1100 came through on Feb. 4, we at PennFuture knew there had to be a strong and strategic response. Over the next four weeks, PennFuture staff worked diligently<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>some of them working solely on this event<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>to make sure this rally unfolded in a professional and powerful way.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">It was obvious from the start that PennFuture couldn&rsquo;t pursue this endeavor alone. If there was truly to be a powerful and impactful response to House Bill 1100, it would have to be a coordinated effort amongst partners to not only spread the word, but to pack the steps of the rotunda in a show of force. We needed to show that it wasn&rsquo;t just industry and labor that has a voice in this process.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">The response from other organizations<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>and even regular citizens<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>was immediate and forceful.
