It didn&rsquo;t take long before we compiled a list of 34 other co-sponsors that lent their skills, time and passion to the cause of rallying against House Bill 1100.&nbsp;We enlisted the help of a number of legislators in Harrisburg, and two<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>state Rep. Sara Innamorato and Sen. Katie Muth<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>were able to speak at the rally.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">The final list of sponsors was as diverse as it was long: statewide groups like PennEnvironment, Sierra Club, Natural Resources Defense Council, One Pennsylvania and others joined with us, as did regional groups like the Center for Coalfield Justice, The Climate Reality Project &ndash; Pittsburgh and Philadelphia chapters, Capital Region Stands Up, and the Delaware Riverkeeper Network. There were faith groups, civic groups, and political groups of all shapes and sizes.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">A tremendous amount of work occurred behind the scenes, too.&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">PennFuture staff worked on renting charter buses from Pittsburgh and Philadelphia and coordinated the effort to fill those buses with supporters. PennFuture staff created and printed signs to be used at the rally, while other staff worked on securing enough food to feed more than 100 people at the rally. Finally, our development team worked hard to secure donations to make this event<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>and everything that went along with it<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>possible from a financial perspective.&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">To say that this event was a team effort isn&rsquo;t strong enough, and not just from PennFuture staff. This was a coordinated, strategic effort from hundreds of people representing dozens of organizations across Pennsylvania.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Even on the morning of the rally<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>when it became clear that half the people who registered for seats on our buses weren&rsquo;t going to show up because of coronavirus fears<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>we knew there was no way this rally could fail.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Even though so many people stayed away, we still packed the steps of the rotunda with friends, supporters and colleagues who all banded together to speak in a unified voice. Conservative estimates put the number of attendees at more than 120 people.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">It&rsquo;s safe to say that people listened. Those on the other side of the issue<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>labor unions and industry<span id=""docs-internal-guid-13222f9a-7fff-2b31-ea00-dce866682bed"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">&mdash;</span></span>put together their own, much smaller rally as a response to ours, a rally that took place directly after ours in the Capitol. Media coverage was swift and included a mix of newspapers, radio stations, television stations and blogs. The entire intent of the rally was to make a statement, and that&rsquo;s exactly what happened.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Our rally was a resounding success, but the purpose of this blog isn&rsquo;t to pat PennFuture on the back.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">To the contrary, this was the very definition of teamwork, of many different groups with many different priorities coming together for the common good to defeat a very bad, very dangerous bill.<br style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;"" />
None of this is to say that the fight is won. It&rsquo;s not, because the fight isn&rsquo;t over. The Legislature on Wednesday sent House Bill 1100 to Gov. Tom Wolf, who has vowed to veto it. Even if the governor does the right thing and vetoes House Bill 1100, a certain faction within the General Assembly has promised to try to override that veto.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">So, the fight remains. Will you do your part to help beat back this horrible legislation? Will you&nbsp;<a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/vetohb1100/index.html?fbclid=IwAR1CUKlXOqDmzhFFIr9LuYFfPMOfLBy5Tt4mjTHRxGijC2CZR4G9kv95Gjc"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">contact your legislator</a>, write a Letter to the Editor, or get in touch with PennFuture to see how else you might help?</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Even with these uncertain times amidst a global pandemic, threats to our environment and to the health of our people will not stop. PennFuture, and indeed dozens of our partner organizations, will remain vigilant on this and other issues of great importance to Pennsylvanians everywhere.</p>

<p style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Will you join us?</p>
",Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
"After Stormy Decade, Philly Needs Green Stormwater Solutions to Prepare for Climate Change",3/20/2020,"<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Philadelphia just experienced the wettest decade ever. Average annual rainfall measured at Philadelphia International Airport exceeded 48 inches&mdash; a 10 percent jump over the previous decade.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">In fact, Philadelphia now ranks third on an unenvious list of U.S. cities experiencing the largest increase in heavy downpours. The city has seen a dramatic&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.climatecentral.org/news/across-us-heaviest-downpours-on-the-rise-18989"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">360% rise in storm events since 1950</a>.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">To prepare for these more-intense storms, Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.phila.gov/media/20200106104156/CITY-OF-PHILADELPHIA-MAYOR-SECOND-TERM-REPORT.pdf"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">announced this month</a>&nbsp;his administration will hire a Chief Resiliency Officer. The new position will work to integrate climate adaptation planning across all city operations, while creating citywide climate adaptation guidelines that direct private development toward climate resiliency.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">PennFuture is working to raise awareness of how the climate crisis affects our cities&rsquo; aging infrastructure. With every storm, Philadelphia and other municipalities with combined sewer overflows are dumping raw sewage directly into our rivers and streams. This has been dubbed the &ldquo;<a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/science/climate/delaware-schuylkill-river-combined-sewer-stormwater-sewage-climate-change-20190913.html"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">secret scourge of climate change.&rdquo;</a>&nbsp;We are advocating for a renewed commitment from city elected leaders to&nbsp;<span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;"">&nbsp;</span><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/keep-philly-green"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">green stormwater infrastructure</a><o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);""><b style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;"">A Hot, Wet Philadelphia Climate<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></b></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Hotter global temperatures cause more water to evaporate from the oceans, filling clouds with greater moisture. The result is more storms, wreaking havoc on the roads, costly flooding within our communities, pollution in our waterways, and an unpredictable number of injuries and fatalities. Poor cities like Philadelphia are particularly vulnerable.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Layering onto the impacts of increased storms is Philadelphia&rsquo;s combined sewer system. Constructed over 200 years ago &ndash; city wastewater mixes together with stormwater in pipes across most of the city. When it rains, rather than flowing to the wastewater treatment facilities, the sewage mixture is dumped directly into the surrounding rivers like the Schuylkill and the Delaware River.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">To address this issue, Philadelphia has become a national green stormwater infrastructure leader. The city&rsquo;s 25-year&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/about-philadelphia-water-dept-green-city"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;""><i style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;"">Green City, Clean Waters</i>&nbsp;plan</a>, approved in 2011, dedicates 70% of its $2.4 billion budget toward solutions such as rain gardens, tree trenches and green roofs, with the rest going towards upgrading wastewater treatment plants.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">These green solutions prevent runoff pollution from entering the Delaware River by redirecting stormwater to filter through soil, stones, and plants before entering the main sewer system. Philadelphia Water Department also frames such investments as climate strategies.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">&ldquo;If we need more infrastructure to handle increased frequency or intensity of storms, for example, then green stormwater infrastructure is the way to do that,&rdquo;&nbsp;<a href=""https://ehp.niehs.nih.gov/doi/10.1289/ehp.119-a514"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">a PWD spokesperson said during the plan&rsquo;s early days</a>. &ldquo;Every dollar we&rsquo;re spending there is a dollar spent toward climate change adaptation.&rdquo;<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);""><b style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;"">Philly Can&rsquo;t Afford to Back Down<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></b></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Philadelphia is staying the course on&nbsp;<i style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;"">Green City, Clean&nbsp;</i>Waters. But in recent years, PennFuture has seen a shift to alternative approaches such as large underground pipes.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">While large infrastructure solutions may equally address water quality concerns, the larger projects are often more costly and fail to provide meaningful climate change adaptation benefits within communities needing it most.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">If PWD were to meet its clean-water obligations instead through &ldquo;gray infrastructure,&rdquo;&nbsp;<a href=""https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/gwire/2009/12/24/24greenwire-citys-all-green-stormwater-plan-raises-eyebrow-45258.html"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">costs would balloon to $8-10 billion.</a><o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Mayor Kenney&rsquo;s decision to hire a Chief Resiliency Officer is a welcomed sign that climate adaptation may play a more prominent role in deciding how the city tackles its capital improvements.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Green infrastructure can help manage localized flooding when rainfall overwhelms storm drain capacity. According to EPA estimates, installing green infrastructure solutions across an entire watershed yields significant financial savings. Nationwide, the annual reduction in flood events would amount to&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2016-05/documents/flood-avoidance-green-infrastructure-12-14-2015.pdf"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">$63- $136 million in savings every yea</a><span class=""MsoHyperlink"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;"">r</span>.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);""><b style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;"">Real Life Consequences of Climate Change<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></b></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">The consequences from how we address the climate crisis cannot be measured in simply financial terms.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">In 2011, Philadelphia experienced its&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/philly/blogs/dncrime/Woman-drowned-in-car-is-Phillys-first-flooding-fatality.html"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">first flooding fatality</a>. Over the decade, heavy rains continued to take lives. Of the five people found dead in Pennypack Creek, at least&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/philly/news/pennypack-park-drowning-search-philadelphia-20180603.html"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">one fatality was directly caused by a storm event.</a><o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">As the country&rsquo;s poorest large city, climate change will complicate efforts to overcome Philly&rsquo;s deep poverty. It is well documented that disasters pose&nbsp;<a href=""https://ncdp.columbia.edu/research/vulnerable-populations/"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">disproportionate risk to vulnerable communities</a>. Philadelphia needs to take seriously how we address our stormwater problems.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Looking toward the future, we see green stormwater infrastructure as crucial to building a better Philadelphia. Keep an eye out for future posts on how these green solutions create opportunities to improve some of our most neglected communities while creating accessible, family-supporting jobs.</p>
",Climate; Community; Environment,Lena Smith
PennFuture Petitions DRBC to Recognize Primary Contact Recreation on the Mainstem Delaware River,3/20/2020,"<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Fifty years ago, the lower stem of the Delaware River was a flowing wasteland. Around Philadelphia, Camden and Wilmington, the river was a dump for the region’s wastewater treatment plants, chemical facilities and slaughterhouses.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Fortunately for all of us, the Clean Water Act of 1972 has resulted in significant progress restoring the river to its natural state. Aquatic life is thriving, with species such as shad and striped bass <a href=""https://www.nj.gov/dep/fgw/artdelstudy19.htm"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">on the rise</a>. People are looking towards the lower Delaware River once again as a place to recreate in and on.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">To continue this progress, PennFuture and a coalition of organizations <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/3.2.2020-Primary-Contact-PR---Petition.pdf"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">submitted a petition</a> on Monday to the Delaware River Basin Commission to upgrade the regulatory status of a portion of the lower Delaware River, initiating a process for commissioners to fulfill their legal obligation to protect human health and to advance the water quality standards of the Delaware River.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Upgrading the regulatory status of the urbanized, lower Delaware River — specifically, from River Mile 108, where Pompeston Creek flows from Palmyra, New Jersey, to River Mile 81.8 near the Commodore Barry Bridge in Chester, Pennsylvania — would help ensure the health and safety of all who spend recreational time on the river.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">For years we’ve known community members use this section of the Delaware River for direct contact recreation – such as jet skiing and kayaking, swimming, stand-up paddleboarding and tubing, to name a few. This “primary contact” water sports are likely to result in the ingestion of or immersion in the water (even if accidental).<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">But this section is currently being protected by the DRBC for “secondary contact” which means current regulations only require water quality to be good enough for activities like fishing from the shoreline, where immersion is not likely.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">To be sure, because this section of the Delaware is actually being used for primary contact water recreation, the DRBC and surrounding states are legally required to recognize this and to protect it under the Clean Water Act.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Our DRBC petition is an effort to update regulations to reflect the 21<span style=""box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 12px; line-height: 0; position: relative; vertical-align: baseline; top: -0.5em;"">st</span> century realities of the Delaware River and to ensure water quality is protective of our health. Several examples of “primary contact,” where recreational users are in direct contact with the river and may potentially ingest water, are mentioned in the petition. Examples include:<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<ul style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1rem; position: relative; padding-left: 3em; overflow: hidden; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; font-size: 16px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">
	<li class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: inherit;"">Every day in the summer, campers ages 6-12 ride kayaks on the Delaware River through activities run by <a href=""https://www.phillyseaport.org/"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">Independence Seaport Museum</a> and <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/departments/philadelphia-parks-recreation/"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">Philadelphia Parks and Recreation</a>. Altogether, Independence Seaport Museum leads more than 20,000 people of all ages on river-based activities throughout the year.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></li>
	<li class=""MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: inherit; text-indent: -0.25in;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-stretch: normal; line-height: normal;""><font face=""Symbol"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""> </font></span><span new="""" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;"" times="""">        </span><a href=""http://urbanpromiseusa.org/"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">UrbanPromise</a>, in partnership with <a href=""https://www.camdenshipyardmuseum.org/"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">Camden Shipyard and Maritime Museum</a>, offers programming for Camden middle and high school students that teaches them how to build their own wooden boats. Every school year, more than 70 students build and test their paddleboats, canoes and kayaks on the tidal Cooper River and Delaware River backchannel.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></li>
	<li class=""MsoListParagraphCxSpLast"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-size: inherit; text-indent: -0.25in;""><span style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-stretch: normal; line-height: normal;""><font face=""Symbol"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""> </font></span><span new="""" style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;"" times="""">        </span>At Penn’s Landing Marina, wellness organization <a href=""https://aquavida.com/"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">Aqua Vida</a> has partnered with the <a href=""https://www.delawareriverwaterfront.com/"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">Delaware River Waterfront Corporation</a> to host stand-up paddleboard tours, floating paddleboard yoga and other floating fitness and meditation classes on the river. The classes attract as many as 400 participants each summer.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></li>
</ul>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Recognizing that the water quality of the lower Delaware has significantly improved over recent decades, PennFuture and our partners are looking at the river through a new lens. In order to ensure that we can enjoy the river safely, it is imperative for the DRBC to protect it fully as required by the Clean Water Act.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 1rem; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Over the coming days and weeks, we’ll be reaching out to our members and the public asking you to let the DRBC know that you support this upgrade of the lower Delaware River. We hope that you will be part of this effort to protect our health as we enjoy the Delaware River to its fullest.<o:p style=""box-sizing: border-box; position: relative;""></o:p></p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; position: relative; line-height: inherit; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(58, 58, 58); font-family: Hind, sans-serif; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Please also consider becoming a <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; background-color: transparent; color: rgb(240, 109, 84); text-decoration-line: none; position: relative; transition: color 0.2s ease 0s, background-color 0.2s ease 0s;"">member of PennFuture</a> to support us as we fight to protect the health of our communities and our environment.</p>
",Community; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Why Does Pennsylvania Insist on Offering Subsidies to Fracked Gas and Petrochemicals? The Industries Would Collapse Without Them,2/19/2020,"<p>Harrisburg policymakers are, again, debating whether to give more taxpayer-funded handouts to the fracking and petrochemical industries. It continues a quiet truth about Pennsylvania&rsquo;s so-called fracking miracle&mdash;without taxpayers padding industry profits, its presence in the Commonwealth would collapse. It&rsquo;s high time we tell our elected officials to stop propping up the fracking and petrochemical industry in Pennsylvania and instead build a diverse, long-term sustainable economy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Earlier this month, state legislators approved House Bill 1100 which, if signed by the governor, would provide billions of dollars in taxpayer handouts over the next 30 years to a suite of petrochemical, plastics, and cracker plant facilities.</p>

<p>This isn&rsquo;t a new idea. It is modeled after a $1.6 billion tax handout generously given to Royal Dutch Shell in 2012, which is underpinning the construction of a massive factory along the Ohio River in Beaver County that will turn fracked gas into plastics feedstock. Industry boosters argue the handout will support 600 permanent jobs on the site, meaning each job carries with it <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/opinion/Op-Ed/2020/02/13/Sara-Innamorato-Socialized-risk-privatized-profits-House-Bill-1100-petrochemical-Pennsylvania/stories/202002130024"">a $2.75 million subsidy paid for by all of us</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>That&rsquo;s an astronomical price to pay for an amount of jobs that represents less than one percent of Beaver County&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.workstats.dli.pa.gov/Documents/County%20Profiles/Beaver%20County.pdf"">total workforce of 81,000 people</a>. It&rsquo;s also an astronomical price to pay for an economically and environmentally unsustainable industry.</p>

<p><u>Natural Gas Industry Teetering on a Financial Cliff</u></p>

<p>It&rsquo;s not hard to attain a clear picture of the financial woes facing the fracked gas and petrochemical industries and why they need a taxpayer bailout.</p>

<p><a href=""https://www.eenews.net/stories/1061136849"">According to E&amp;E News</a>, the fracked gas industry is headed for a financial cliff because the initial generation of fracked wells are falling in productivity. In order for companies to grow and provide shareholders profits, they need to drill more wells in less ideal locations, increasing their costs for declining benefit.</p>

<p>This is having devastating impacts on fracking companies. According to a study <a href=""http://ieefa.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Q4-2018_More-Red-Flags-on-Fracking_March-2019.pdf"">by the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis</a>, a group of 29 large shale gas companies in 2018 had their spending outpace reported income by $6.7 billion. From 2010 to 2018, those companies recorded a cash flow totaling negative $181 billion.</p>

<p>Since 2015, there have been 172 gas <a href=""https://www.desmogblog.com/2019/06/23/former-shale-gas-ceo-says-shale-revolution-has-been-disaster-drillers-investors"">&ldquo;exploration and production&rdquo; company bankruptcies</a> involving nearly a hundred billion dollars of debt, including 42 &ldquo;E&amp;P&rdquo; <a href=""https://ieefa.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Bankruptcies-in-Fracking-Sector-Mount-in-2019_January-2020.pdf"">bankruptcies in 2019</a>. Given the massive wave of debt facing the industry, more bankruptcies <a href=""https://ieefa.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Bankruptcies-in-Fracking-Sector-Mount-in-2019_January-2020.pdf"">are all but certain</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania natural gas players are at the center of this financial cliff. In the largest write-down by an energy producer in years, <a href=""https://www.wsj.com/articles/chevron-facing-fossil-fuels-glut-takes-10-billion-charge-11576012579"">Chevron reported recently</a> it is cutting the value of several properties, notably its shale holdings in Appalachia, by more than $10 billion. According to the Wall Street Journal, this move represents a &ldquo;concession that...some of its holdings won&rsquo;t be profitable anytime soon.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>More proof can be found in CNX Resources, a <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2020/01/31/Marcellus-shale-gas-reserves-CNX-EQT-Chevron-pennsylvania/stories/202001300154"">Washington County-based shale gas company</a> that is writing down $446 million in assets in central Pennsylvania. The move means that oil and gas reserves in that area are no longer considered economic and will not be developed in the near future.</p>

<p>Perhaps most important is Pittsburgh-based EQT Corp., the largest fracked gas producer in the country. <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2020/01/31/Marcellus-shale-gas-reserves-CNX-EQT-Chevron-pennsylvania/stories/202001300154"">The company recently announced</a> it will write down between $1.4 billion and $1.8 billion in assets. In total, EQT, Range Resources, and CNX <a href=""https://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/pittsburghs-fracking-industry-cut-more-than-400-jobs-in-2019-with-more-cuts-likely-on-the-way/Content?oid=16477996"">have cut a combined total</a> of more than 400 jobs since January 2019.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Former EQT CEO Steve Schlotterbeck <a href=""https://www.desmogblog.com/2019/06/23/former-shale-gas-ceo-says-shale-revolution-has-been-disaster-drillers-investors"">put it succinctly in June 2019</a> to a crowd of petrochemical industrialists that, &ldquo;The shale gas revolution has frankly been an unmitigated disaster for any buy-and-hold investor in the shale gas industry with very few limited exceptions.&rdquo; Schlotterbeck ended, &ldquo;The industry is self-destructive.&rdquo;</p>

<p><u>Fossil Fuel Industries Require Taxpayer Handouts to Stay Afloat</u></p>

<p>It shouldn&rsquo;t be a surprise then that fossil fuel companies like fracking and petrochemical companies require taxpayer handouts to be successful. And during the modern day history of these industries, federal and state governments on behalf of taxpayers have fronted that bill.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our federal government provides both direct and indirect subsidies to the fossil fuel industry at an alarming rate. <a href=""https://www.eesi.org/files/FactSheet_Fossil_Fuel_Subsidies_0719.pdf"">According to a report</a> from the Environmental and Energy Study Institute, conservative estimates put direct U.S. subsidies to the fossil fuel industry at about $20 billion per year, with about 80 percent of that allocated to the fracked gas and crude oil segments.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The situation is similar in Pennsylvania. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/News/FossilFuelSubsidyReport_PennFuture.pdf"">According to a PennFuture report</a>, taxpayers provided more than $3.2 billion in fossil fuel subsidies during fiscal year 2012-2013, which equals $794 per Pennsylvania taxpayer. Approximately 92 percent ($3 billion) of these subsidies came in the form of tax breaks.</p>

<p>Adding billions more in state taxpayer largesse through House Bill 1100 would be more of the same for both the industry and Pennsylvania. In fact, groups like <a href=""https://www.theintelligencer.net/news/top-headlines/2018/06/shale-crescent-usa-wants-to-rebrand-region/"">Shale Crescent USA</a> and the <a href=""https://www.pachamber.org/media/2516/Forge_the_Future_Phase_2_Report_101118/"">PA Chamber of Business and Industry</a> are pitching the so-called Appalachian Storage Hub&mdash;a sprawling, multi-state complex of petrochemical cracker plants, plastics manufacturing, compressor stations, pipelines, and underground storage facilities&mdash;as a sort of savior to the failing fracking industry.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The so-called economic miracle of fracking is now being replaced by the promise of plastics, except the petrochemical industry requires the same subsidies and deregulation that the fracking industry did to stay afloat. We&rsquo;re simply replacing one failing industry with another, both leaders in polluting our air, water, and climate.</p>

<p><u>Regions that Tie Their Economic Future to Subsidized Industries are in Trouble</u></p>

<p>Those pushing billions in subsidies to the industry frame them as necessary for economic expansion and prosperity in areas that desperately need both. Family-sustaining jobs are promised as our leaders shell out tax breaks and subsidies at an alarming rate to executives and shareholders.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The problem with that thinking is that geographic areas that have linked their economic futures to fracked gas and petrochemicals are still experiencing population losses. For instance, from the period of 2010 to 2018, the Pittsburgh metropolitan area - which includes all of southwestern Pennsylvania, experienced a population loss of -1.4 percent.</p>

<p>In comparison, <a href=""https://www.coalfieldjustice.org/blog/2020/2/14/fracking-and-petrochemicals-good-for-our-economic-future"">metropolitan areas that don&rsquo;t link</a> their economies to fracking and petrochemicals have done much better: Columbus, Ohio had its population increase by 13.1 percent, Lexington, Kentucky saw a 9.4 percent increase, and Indianapolis experienced a 5.7 percent increase.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s clear the industry relies on government intervention to stay afloat, even in the face of statistics that show population and jobs losses in the areas where the industry is most prominent.&nbsp;One last example hammers home that point: like Pennsylvania, Louisiana offers generous taxpayer handouts to the fracked gas and petrochemical industries, <a href=""https://twitter.com/RyanDeto/status/1228007439695581184?s=20"">but the state has lost</a> 40,000 manufacturing jobs in the last 20 years.&nbsp;</p>

<p>All of this information begs a question: if the industry is performing this poorly here and nationally despite taxpayer subsidies, where would it be without government intervention? And why are our leaders in Pennsylvania relying on such an unstable and uneconomic industry?</p>

<p><u>Pennsylvania Should Reject Fossil Fuel Subsidies Once and For All</u></p>

<p>This ongoing push for a bailout should put industry priorities in clear view: they&rsquo;re trying to squeeze as much profit out of the state as they can before packing up and leaving Pennsylvania. Like the coal and oil barons before them, the fracking and petrochemical industries&nbsp;will leave taxpayers with&nbsp;debt, orphaned wells, brownfields, environmental clean-up, and an unstable economy.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania should reject the taxpayer bailout charade of House Bill 1100 and instead plan and invest in a more strategic, long-term sustainable, and environmentally positive economy that won&rsquo;t put taxpayers and communities in harm&#39;s way.</p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
What is the Transportation and Climate Initiative?,2/11/2020,"<p>Gov. Tom Wolf&rsquo;s administration has released an initial proposal for how Pennsylvania might cap carbon emissions from the state&rsquo;s electricity sector, the first step in <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-First-Glimpse-PennFuture-analyzes-draft-of-DEPs-cap-and-invest-program"">potentially joining a regional emission trading system</a>.</p>

<p>At PennFuture, we have long called for Pennsylvania to join the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative. But we know the electricity sector only accounts for a third of U.S. carbon emissions. That&rsquo;s why Pennsylvania and other Northeast and Mid Atlantic states exploring another &ldquo;cap-and-invest&rdquo; approach&mdash;to address transportation-related carbon pollution&mdash;is equally important.</p>

<p>Transportation accounts for <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=41093"">37 percent of energy consumed</a> in the United States and about an equal share of the greenhouse gas emissions from the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic regions.</p>

<p>State leaders recognize that more aggressive action is needed to halt the rise in transportation-related pollution and to empower a cleaner future. Pennsylvania is among 12 states and Washington, D.C. now considering a proposed approach to raise up to $68 billion over 10 years to modernize our public transportation systems, expand electric vehicle charging networks and transition fleets of heavy-duty vehicles to run on cleaner fuels.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The program is called&nbsp;the <a href=""http://www.transportationandclimate.org/"">T</a><a href=""https://www.transportationandclimate.org/"">ransportation and Climate Initiative (TCI)</a>, a coalition of state regulators who recently proposed a cap-and-invest framework for the transportation sector. The proposal sets a goal to reduce carbon emissions 20&ndash;25 percent below 2005 levels by 2032. As a cap-and-invest policy, regulated entities would be provided annual carbon pollution &ldquo;allowances.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Unlike the power, industrial, or building sectors, the transportation sector is <a href=""https://www.wri.org/blog/2019/10/everything-you-need-know-about-fastest-growing-source-global-emissions-transport"">far more distributed and complex</a>. Across the region, more than 52 million tailpipes&mdash;from cars, light duty trucks, and other vehicles&mdash;spew gasoline and diesel-based exhaust and contribute to climate change. That said, like the other sectors of the economy, technology solutions are emerging and getting cheaper every year, including electric vehicle technologies, new charging infrastructure, and new vehicle efficiency technologies and materials, among others.</p>

<p>To catalyze these investments, state regulators have considered a range of policy approaches. Options include tightening vehicle fuel efficiency standards, placing a carbon tax on fuel consumption, or enacting carbon regulations on the country&rsquo;s 1,400 crude oil producers.</p>

<p>The TCI coalition is looking seriously at the latter of these options. The&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.transportationandclimate.org/main-menu/tcis-regional-policy-design-process-2019"">draft framework would limit pollution</a> from entities who supply fuel directly to the TCI members. Fuel distributors would need to stay within an overall pollution limit beginning at 254 million metric tons per year in 2022. Distributors would purchase allowances proportional to their contributions to regional transport emissions. Allowances would decrease over time, drawing down total emissions.</p>

<p>There are 14 large oil refineries located in the TCI states. These and other regional suppliers would potentially be regulated by the framework. Owners of terminals and pipelines may also be included under future rules.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pollution allowances would be auctioned by the states and the&nbsp; proceeds would be invested into cleaner, more resilient, more equitable low-carbon transportation systems that not only reduce pollution but also mitigate the costs to consumers. Initial estimates forecast that allowance prices of about $22 per ton would be necessary by 2022 in order to reach the 25 percent emission-reduction target. If prices reached such levels, the framework would raise about $5.6 billion per year.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Within this &ldquo;pay to pollute&rdquo; model, TCI is considering an alternative for distributors who may not wish to buy allowances. A potentially more affordable option would be to purchase carbon offsets. These projects would have to demonstrate verifiable, voluntary carbon reductions from investments in various sustainable forestry, agriculture or clean energy activities.</p>

<p>TCI states have yet to adopt their rules or to announce their proposed emission limits. Until then, the cost of the program is unclear, with ranges that depend on the aggressiveness of allowance caps. Initial studies predict gasoline consumers may be charged 7&ndash;29 cents more per gallon over 12 years, but consumers can control costs through the use of more efficient vehicles,&nbsp; public transportation, reducing unnecessary trips through telecommuting, or other cleaner transportation policies. Potential investments made in infrastructure projects and more efficient technologies would offset these costs and give consumers even more choices.</p>

<p>In fact, if spread across the transportation economy, the framework&rsquo;s benefits far outweigh potential program costs. <a href=""https://www.georgetownclimate.org/files/report/GCC-Reducing_GHG_Emissions_from_Transportation-11.24.15.pdf"">A TCI analysis estimates</a> net economic savings of $28.7&ndash;$54.5 billion for businesses and $3.6&ndash;$18 billion for consumers over a 15-year period. A cleaner, more efficient transportation system would also help avoid more than 1,000 premature deaths, prevent 1,300 asthma attacks and dodge 1,700 traffic injuries&mdash;resulting in up to $10 billion in public health benefits per year.</p>

<p>Recent polls suggest strong support among both urban and rural commuters. A <a href=""https://www.nature.org/content/dam/tnc/nature/en/documents/TNC_TCI_Survey_2019_Public.pdf"">November 2019 survey found</a> 63 percent of Pennsylvania respondents would be willing to pay up to $20 per month to fund cleaner transportation choices across the state.</p>

<p>It is critical for Pennsylvania to consider the transportation sector when determining how we can best address climate change. PennFuture will continue to closely follow the Transportation Climate Initiative and fight for ambitious and equitable policies to transition our carbon-based economy. Stay tuned for more updates as proposed regulations take shape.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
"Fallacy, Fiction, and Falsehoods: Debunking RGGI Myths Part 1",2/4/2020,"<p>On January 31st, 2020 the Department of Environmental Protection <a href=""http://On January 31st, 2020 the Department of Environmental Protection released its proposal to advance a cap-and-invest program to reduce carbon emissions in Pennsylvania that is compatible with the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI). Facing the prospect of actually having to pay for their pollution rather than being allowed to dump it in the air for free, polluters and their friends are mobilizing to oppose the proposal with fallacies and mistruths.  Check out PennFuture’s primer on the RGGI process and its role in cutting the Commonwealth’s carbon emissions as well as an assessment of why efforts by the legislature to limit the Governor’s climate authority are misguided  Below are three of the most inaccurate statements made so far by polluter-friendly elected officials in Pennsylvania, along with responses debunking these dubious and misleading claims.   1. Legislative approval is required to execute a carbon cap-and-trade program. On Jan. 16., state Rep. Daryl Metcalfe sent a letter to the executive committee of RGGI, asking them not to move forward with Pennsylvania’s proposed entry into RGGI. In his letter, Metcalfe claimed Pennsylvania has a “rogue governor” and that “Pennsylvania law requires that in order for the governor to execute a carbon cap-and-trade program such as RGGI, explicit approval is required from our Commonwealth’s legislative branch.”  Response:  Legislative approval is not required. Pennsylvania’s Air Pollution Control Act gives the DEP, through approval of the Environmental Quality Board (EQB), very clear authority to set limits on pollution and, where necessary, cooperate with other states to do so. The DEP’s proposed rule couldn’t be more clear that interstate compact is required. It says “The Department will determine whether to participate in multistate CO2 allowance auctions in coordination with other participating states or to conduct Pennsylvania-run auctions…”—the proposal also contains specific provisions for a Pennsylvania-run program and says that we will only participate in a multi-state auction if the DEP determines there is one that is compatible with our program and the benefits of doing so outweigh the costs.  Article I § 27 of Pennsylvania’s Constitution says that our “public natural resources are the common property of all the people” and that the Commonwealth acts as trustee to “conserve and maintain” those resources. Instead of questioning the governor’s authority to act, Rep. Metcalfe should ask himself why he thinks it’s acceptable for polluting industries to dump their waste products into our air for free. How is that consistent with his oath of office?  2. Pennsylvania is already a leader in cutting carbon emissions, so joining RGGI is not needed. In an Oct. 16 edition of the Pennsylvania Business Report, Pennsylvania Senate Majority Leader Jake Corman argued that “Pennsylvania is out ahead of many states when it comes to reducing carbon emissions through the RGGI compact...But joining a compact where you give up state independence, in an area where we are already making improvements, seems shortsighted and leaves us open to the possibility of being stuck with the poor decisions and outcomes for others in the agreement.”  Similarly, in a news release issued on Oct. 3, the House Republican Caucus argued that “Pennsylvania’s energy sector is currently reducing greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 30 percent in recent years, according to some estimates, and the industry is doing this without burdensome regulations.”  Response: Of course Senator Corman and the House Republican Caucus know they are comparing apples and oranges—they just hope you don’t notice. For all its “progress,” Pennsylvania is the fourth-highest emitter of carbon pollution in the nation behind California, Texas, and Florida. New natural gas plants have driven most of our coal generation out of business reducing our emissions, but we started with about one and a half times the coal generation as all of the other RGGI states combined. This is a case of being so far behind, the Senator thinks we are in first place. The real issue though is not what we did, but how we move forward.  We don’t have enough coal left for the trends of the past to continue and neither the Senator nor the Republican Caucus have a plan to solve our emissions problem. Rather than reducing emissions, they are working on a package of bills to further subsidize fossil fuel generation. Gas has likely already become a bigger source of carbon pollution than coal in the state and replacing additional lost generation with gas will result in net increases in pollution—we can’t drill our way to a clean and healthy environment.    Instead of more fossil fuel subsidies, we need to implement a program like RGGI to cap carbon pollution and invest in carbon-free alternatives like clean renewable energy and energy efficiency. A recent report by The Analysis Group shows CO2 emissions in the RGGI states have dropped from over 180 million tons per year to under 80 million tons per year while providing over $1.4 billion in net economic benefits. That is the kind of progress we need. 3. Joining RGGI will increase electricity prices and result in job losses. In a June 24 article published by the Commonwealth Foundation, the author implies that RGGI will result in a 64 percent increase in the price of electricity, while it will also result in a loss of between 7,000 to 11,000 jobs per year.  Response:  To come by those shocking numbers, the Commonwealth Foundation relies on a “working paper” by David Stephenson of the Caesar Rodney Institute. Both organizations are part of a Koch-funded umbrella organization called the State Policy Network that actively opposes climate change regulations, so it shouldn’t surprise anyone that they are cherry-picking data to try and make their point. What is surprising is that the Commonwealth Foundation found it necessary to cherry-pick data from a report that already cherry-picked data. The underlying report actually says prices in RGGI increased less than the average in the US, they just increased more than “comparison states.” If you skip their alternative facts altogether and go directly to the Energy Information Administration's (EIA) report on average state prices (the authority they cite) you get a much different picture. Average price per megawatt hour (MWh) across all sectors in RGGI did rise 7% from 2007 through 2016, but the prices in Pennsylvania and the U.S. as a whole rose more than 12% over that same time period. If you update the data to 2018 (the most current available) RGGI is even better with a 6.6% increase from 2007 compared to an 11.2% increase in Pennsylvania and 15.3% for the U.S. as a whole. The other critical factor groups like this purposely ignore is that the cost per MWh is only one part of your bill. If a family or business installs solar generation or invests in energy efficiency, their monthly electric bills can drop substantially even if the retail price of power goes up. The RGGI states take advantage of this by investing in efficiency and renewable—far more than Pennsylvania. To make their claims on job losses, the Commonwealth Foundation resorts to another report from a State Policy Network affiliate, this time from Rhode Island. The really surprising thing about this report is that it doesn’t pretend to be about RGGI at all—this is a report about renewable energy portfolio standards that tries to claim investing in clean renewable generation though programs like Pennsylvania's Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards (AEPS) causes job losses. What we know for a fact is that the remaining large coal plants in Pennsylvania are all nearing retirement age and no plans are on the table to build more. These plants will eventually close with or without RGGI—we need to plan for what is next. Adding more natural gas is a climate killer so we need better choices. Right now, far from being sources of job losses, the largest job growth sectors in the U.S. are solar installers and wind technicians. Pennsylvania in particular has over 68,000 energy efficiency jobs and over 9,000 renewable energy jobs. Clean and renewable energy has more potential job growth than dirty fossil fuels. Next steps The title of this blog says it’s “Part 1” of a series debunking lies, myths, and misconceptions about RGGI and carbon pricing. While it would be nice if a “Part 2” was not required, the people who are making these claims are not likely to stop. Back in 1710, Jonathan Swift wrote that “if a lie be believ’d only for an hour, it has done its work, and there is no farther occasion for it.”  Unfortunately, that is just as true today.  Stay plugged into PennFuture and our blogs as we follow the rule-making process that could end with Pennsylvania joining RGGI."">released its proposal</a> to advance a cap-and-invest program to reduce carbon emissions in Pennsylvania that is compatible with the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI). Facing the prospect of actually having to pay for their pollution rather than being allowed to dump it in the air for free, polluters and their friends are mobilizing to oppose the proposal with fallacies and mistruths.</p>

<p>Check out PennFuture&rsquo;s <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-So-Pennsylvania-Might-Join-RGGI-What-Comes-Next"">primer on the RGGI process</a> and its role in cutting the Commonwealth&rsquo;s carbon emissions as well as <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Legislators-say-Gov-Wolf-lacks-the-authority-to-have-Pennsylvania-join-RGGI-This-is-why-theyre-wrong"">an assessment of why efforts</a> by the legislature to limit the Governor&rsquo;s climate authority are misguided</p>

<p>Below are three of the most inaccurate statements made so far by polluter-friendly elected officials in Pennsylvania, along with responses debunking these dubious and misleading claims.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Myth:</strong>&nbsp;<strong>Legislative approval is required to execute a carbon cap-and-trade program</strong>. On Jan. 16., state Rep. Daryl Metcalfe <a href=""http://paenvironmentdaily.blogspot.com/2020/01/rep-metcalfe-warns-top-regional.html"">sent a letter to the executive committee of RGGI</a>, asking them not to move forward with Pennsylvania&rsquo;s proposed entry into RGGI. In his letter, Metcalfe claimed Pennsylvania has a &ldquo;rogue governor&rdquo; and that &ldquo;Pennsylvania law requires that in order for the governor to execute a carbon cap-and-trade program such as RGGI, explicit approval is required from our Commonwealth&rsquo;s legislative branch.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Response</strong>:&nbsp;Legislative approval is not required. Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Air Pollution Control Act gives the DEP, through approval of the Environmental Quality Board (EQB), very clear authority to set limits on pollution and, where necessary, cooperate with other states to do so. The DEP&rsquo;s proposed rule couldn&rsquo;t be more clear that interstate compact is required. It says &ldquo;The Department will determine whether to participate in multistate CO2 allowance auctions in coordination with other participating states or to conduct Pennsylvania-run auctions&hellip;&rdquo;&mdash;the proposal also contains specific provisions for a Pennsylvania-run program and says that we will only participate in a multi-state auction if the DEP determines there is one that is compatible with our program and the benefits of doing so outweigh the costs.</p>

<p>Article I &sect; 27 of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Constitution says that our &ldquo;public natural resources are the common property of all the people&rdquo; and that the Commonwealth acts as trustee to &ldquo;conserve and maintain&rdquo; those resources. Instead of questioning the governor&rsquo;s authority to act, Rep. Metcalfe should ask himself why he thinks it&rsquo;s acceptable for polluting industries to dump their waste products into our air for free. How is that consistent with his oath of office?</p>

<p><b>Myth:</b>&nbsp;<strong>Pennsylvania is already a leader in cutting carbon emissions, so joining RGGI is not needed</strong>. In an Oct. 16 <a href=""https://pennbizreport.com/news/14450-pa-senate-majority-leader-warns-policies-on-charter-schools-energy-could-hold-commonwealth-back/"">edition of the Pennsylvania Business Report</a>, Pennsylvania Senate Majority Leader Jake Corman argued that &ldquo;Pennsylvania is out ahead of many states when it comes to reducing carbon emissions through the RGGI compact...But joining a compact where you give up state independence, in an area where we are already making improvements, seems shortsighted and leaves us open to the possibility of being stuck with the poor decisions and outcomes for others in the agreement.&rdquo;&nbsp;Similarly, <a href=""https://twitter.com/justin_sweitzer/status/1179764000449536001?s=20"">in a news release issued on Oct. 3</a>, the House Republican Caucus argued that &ldquo;Pennsylvania&rsquo;s energy sector is currently reducing greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 30 percent in recent years, according to some estimates, and the industry is doing this without burdensome regulations.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Response</strong>: Of course Senator Corman and the House Republican Caucus know they are comparing apples and oranges&mdash;they just hope you don&rsquo;t notice. For all its &ldquo;progress,&rdquo; Pennsylvania is the <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/environment/emissions/state/analysis/"">fourth-highest emitter of carbon pollution</a> in the nation behind California, Texas, and Florida. New natural gas plants have driven most of our coal generation out of business reducing our emissions, but we started with about one and a half times the coal generation as all of the other RGGI states combined. This is a case of being so far behind, the Senator thinks we are in first place. The real issue though is not what we did, but how we move forward.</p>

<p>We don&rsquo;t have enough coal left for the trends of the past to continue and neither the Senator nor the Republican Caucus have a plan to solve our emissions problem. Rather than reducing emissions, they are working on a package of bills to further subsidize fossil fuel generation. Gas has likely already become a bigger source of carbon pollution than coal in the state and replacing additional lost generation with gas will result in net increases in pollution&mdash;we can&rsquo;t drill our way to a clean and healthy environment.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;<img height=""286"" src=""https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/-BDUE-ZOPTZVpp98rCAzGWeJHqXiQrpiSIJXVix8hpjhxcN24c6oE8_Sk6yXCTwgQYNRCMCiN7Etd_SddDD-og__yDeWbyc9nB0oQ1Oae5F6FNkDVtlih-hXso2l9BURghK-mVKx"" style=""margin-left: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"" width=""385"" /></p>

<p>Instead of more fossil fuel subsidies, we need to implement a program like RGGI to cap carbon pollution and invest in carbon-free alternatives like clean renewable energy and energy efficiency. A recent <a href=""https://www.analysisgroup.com/globalassets/uploadedfiles/content/insights/publishing/analysis_group_rggi_report_april_2018.pdf"">report by The Analysis Group</a> shows CO2 emissions in the RGGI states have dropped from over 180 million tons per year to under 80 million tons per year while providing over $1.4 billion in net economic benefits. That is the kind of progress we need.</p>

<p><b>Myth:</b>&nbsp;<strong>Joining RGGI will increase electricity prices and result in job losses</strong>. In a June 24 article <a href=""https://www.commonwealthfoundation.org/policyblog/detail/the-rggi-offers-nothing-to-pennsylvania#.XZU1tYuKHNA.twitter"">published by the Commonwealth Foundation</a>, the author implies that RGGI will result in a 64 percent increase in the price of electricity, while it will also result in a loss of between 7,000 to 11,000 jobs per year.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Response</strong>:&nbsp;To come by those shocking numbers, the Commonwealth Foundation relies on a &ldquo;working paper&rdquo; by David Stephenson of the Caesar Rodney Institute. Both organizations are part of a Koch-funded umbrella organization called the State Policy Network <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/14/facebook-microsoft-rightwing-lobby-network-spn"">that actively opposes climate change regulations</a>, so it shouldn&rsquo;t surprise anyone that they are cherry-picking data to try and make their point.</p>

<p>What is surprising is that the Commonwealth Foundation found it necessary to cherry-pick data from a report that already cherry-picked data. The underlying report actually says prices in RGGI increased less than the average in the US, they just increased more than &ldquo;comparison states.&rdquo; If you skip their alternative facts altogether and go directly to the Energy Information Administration&#39;s (EIA) <a href=""https://www.eia.gov/electricity/data/state/avgprice_annual.xlsx"">report on average state prices</a> (the authority they cite) you get a much different picture.</p>

<p>Average price per megawatt hour (MWh) across all sectors in RGGI did rise 7% from 2007 through 2016, but the prices in Pennsylvania and the U.S. as a whole rose more than 12% over that same time period. If you update the data to 2018 (the most current available) RGGI is even better with a 6.6% increase from 2007 compared to an 11.2% increase in Pennsylvania and 15.3% for the U.S. as a whole.</p>

<p>The other critical factor groups like this purposely ignore is that the cost per MWh is only one part of your bill. If a family or business installs solar generation or invests in energy efficiency, their monthly electric bills can drop substantially even if the retail price of power goes up. The RGGI states take advantage of this by investing in efficiency and renewable&mdash;far more than Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>To make their claims on job losses, the Commonwealth Foundation resorts to another report from a State Policy Network affiliate, this time from Rhode Island. The really surprising thing about this report is that it doesn&rsquo;t pretend to be about RGGI at all&mdash;this is a report about renewable energy portfolio standards that tries to claim investing in clean renewable generation though programs like Pennsylvania&#39;s Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards (AEPS) causes job losses.</p>

<p>What we know for a fact is that the remaining large coal plants in Pennsylvania are all nearing retirement age and no plans are on the table to build more. These plants will eventually close with or without RGGI&mdash;we need to plan for what is next. Adding more natural gas is a climate killer so we need better choices. Right now, far from being sources of job losses, the largest job growth sectors in the U.S. are solar installers and wind technicians. Pennsylvania in particular has over 68,000 energy efficiency jobs and over 9,000 renewable energy jobs. Clean and renewable energy has more potential job growth than dirty fossil fuels.</p>

<p><strong>Next steps</strong></p>

<p>The title of this blog says it&rsquo;s &ldquo;Part 1&rdquo; of a series debunking lies, myths, and misconceptions about RGGI and carbon pricing. While it would be nice if a &ldquo;Part 2&rdquo; was not required, the people who are making these claims are not likely to stop. Back in 1710, Jonathan Swift wrote that &ldquo;if a lie be believ&rsquo;d only for an hour, it has done its work, and there is no farther occasion for it.&rdquo;&nbsp; Unfortunately, that is just as true today.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Stay plugged into PennFuture and our blogs as we follow the rule-making process that could end with Pennsylvania joining RGGI.&nbsp;</p>
