",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
First Glimpse: PennFuture analyzes draft of DEP's cap-and-invest program,2/4/2020,"<p>On February 13th, the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) <a href=""http://files.dep.state.pa.us/Air/AirQuality/AQPortalFiles/Advisory%20Committees/Air%20Quality%20Technical%20Advisory%20Committee/2020/2-13-20/AQTAC%20PA%20CO2%20Budget%20Trading%20Program_February%202020.pdf"">will be presenting the first draft</a> of the regulatory language for a <a href=""http://files.dep.state.pa.us/Air/AirQuality/AQPortalFiles/Advisory%20Committees/Air%20Quality%20Technical%20Advisory%20Committee/2020/2-13-20/Draft%20PRN%20CO2%20Budget%20Trading%20Annex%20A%201-30-20.pdf"">&ldquo;CO2 Budget Trading Program&rdquo;</a> to the Air Quality Technical Advisory Committee (AQTAC), a <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-So-Pennsylvania-Might-Join-RGGI-What-Comes-Next"">positive next step</a> in a long 18 to 24 month regulatory process. The draft provides some key details&mdash;and questions&mdash;on the Governor&rsquo;s intention to create a state cap-and-trade program to cut electricity sector carbon emission.</p>

<p><strong>How does Cap-and-Invest Work?</strong></p>

<p>Cap-and-invest is a longstanding carbon reduction tool with a very straightforward concept: the state sets a carbon limit for an industry that declines over time and provides annual &ldquo;allowances&rdquo; to carbon polluters.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the case of Pennsylvania, the Governor intends to enact a cap-and-invest program for power plants with a capacity over 25 megawatts (MW). Power plant owners must obtain allowances for each ton of pollution they emit in any given year. As the carbon cap decreases, the cost of allowances will increase and polluters will be incentivized to invest in lower-carbon technologies. For those generators that continue to emit, the costs of pollution will be better reflected in the wholesale price of the energy they sell.</p>

<p>Economically, this is the &ldquo;polluter pays&rdquo; principle in action&mdash;rather than subsidizing the cost of pollution for dirty plants, we will monetize the costs of that pollution and let the market make better-informed choices about what power to buy.&nbsp; The proceeds from power plant owners buying allowances would be invested back into efforts to reduce air and carbon pollution.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>When this rule goes into effect in Pennsylvania, the DEP will issue a specific number of allowances, each one representing one ton of CO2 emissions. To emit carbon pollution, power plants will need to obtain sufficient allowances. For example, a reasonably modern natural gas plant will require about one allowance for every two and a half megawatt hours (MWh) of generation. Coal plants, which produce significantly more carbon pollution, will need around twice as many allowances per MWh. Of course, carbon free generation like nuclear, wind, and solar won&rsquo;t need any allowances at all.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>What Choices will Polluters Have?</strong></p>

<p>Given a choice, carbon polluters would want to keep the status quo where they get to dump pollution in the air for free. While this proposal closes that particular candy store, companies still have a number of options to make compliance easier and less costly.</p>

<p><u><em>Pollution Prevention</em></u>: Investing in efficiency improvements or changing their operations so they emit less pollution. When pollution is no longer free such changes will be more cost-effective.</p>

<p><u><em>Permit Conditions</em></u>: Power plant units supplying electricity to industrial facilities that don&rsquo;t send a significant amount of power to the grid or other facilities may be able to make minor changes to their operating permits and be exempt from the program entirely.</p>

<p><em><u>Offsets</u></em>: Power plant units may also be able to reduce their need for allowances by offsetting their pollution with verifiable reductions from other projects. This could be capturing landfill methane, sequestering carbon through reforestation, avoiding methane through better agricultural practices, or&mdash;and this is particularly important in Pennsylvania&mdash;plugging abandoned oil and gas wells.</p>

<p><strong>Where do Companies get Allowances?</strong></p>

<p>Ultimately, many electricity generators are going to need to obtain at least some allowances and, for that, the proposed rule sets up an auction program.</p>

<p>An auction program could be developed in several different ways, but the draft doesn&rsquo;t specify which would be prefered. Pennsylvania could provide a&nbsp; &ldquo;clearing price&rdquo; auction where participants submit sealed bids for the number of allowances they want and the price they will pay, and everyone pays the price in the lowest winning bid. It could also create a &ldquo;pay-as-bid&rdquo; auction where all the winners pay what they bid. Or, it could be a multi-round auction where participants can adjust their bidding strategy between rounds. The mechanics may differ, but the goal is to discover what the market thinks is a fair price for allowances rather than a &ldquo;command and control&rdquo; system where the DEP sets the price entirely on its own.</p>

<p>While DEP can run the auction entirely on its own, it also has the option of joining a multi-state market&mdash;like RGGI&mdash;if it determines that there is an appropriate market to join and the benefits outweigh the costs. It is expected they will. Economies of scale with a bigger market will reduce our share of the administrative and support costs, a multi-state market can lessen concerns about cross-border effects, and large markets can even lower the cost of compliance for participants. This is where RGGI comes into play. If we do join a multistate market, RGGI is the logical choice.</p>

<p><strong>Features of DEP&rsquo;s Proposal</strong></p>

<p><u><em>Guardrails Around Allowance Prices</em></u>:&nbsp;Preventing price shocks for consumers is always an important concern and spikes in fossil generation caused by severe weather could cause problems. Like all of the RGGI states, DEP proposes to mitigate this concern with a cost containment reserve (CCR). The CCR will make additional allowances available to keep costs down if the auction price is higher than a specified trigger price. On the other hand, unexpected retirements of polluting plants could make demand for allowances drop sharply. While lowering emissions is a good thing, a sharp fall in prices may make the program less effective at incentivising further emissions reductions. For that reason, DEP is proposing an emissions containment reserve (ECR). Similar to the CCR, the ECR would withhold allowances if the cost of reductions is much lower than expected.</p>

<p><u><em>Free Allowances for Waste Coal</em></u>:&nbsp;The proposal also uses free allowances as a policy tool. The draft program proposes to give away free allowances to further subsidize waste coal generators&rsquo; continued pollution. Waste coal proponents claim that they are providing an environmental service by cleaning up abandoned waste coal piles that are polluting our land and water. While burning these coal piles is one way of removing them, this proposal doesn&rsquo;t require the DEP to first determine that burning the coal is the best option available, it doesn&rsquo;t attempt to prioritize removal of the most problematic waste piles first, and it doesn&rsquo;t require any analysis to ensure the benefits these plants provide to justify the value of all the subsidies they are getting. This is a detail of the draft proposal that needs further attention by DEP moving forward.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Improvements DEP Should Consider</strong></p>

<p><u><em>Planning for retirement of waste coal generation</em></u>:&nbsp;If subsidies for waste coal remain part of the plan, more work should be done to plan for their eventual retirement. Currently, the proposed rule says that when sufficient waste coal retires for the set-aside to be reduced or eliminated, the allowances return to the auction pool. Because waste coal produces significantly more carbon pollution per megawatt-hour than the likely alternatives, this will add unneeded allowances to the market, depressing allowance prices, and making our carbon targets harder to reach. A better choice would be to retire these allowances from the auction pool entirely. If any allowances are returned to the auction pool, they should be discounted to reflect the fact replacement generation will likely be much cleaner.</p>

<p><u><em>Protecting Voluntary Purchases of Renewable Energy</em></u>:&nbsp;One set-aside DEP should consider adding to the draft rule is for voluntary purchases of renewable energy. Having a cap on carbon emissions is vital, but unless we are careful, a cap can also backfire and act as a carbon floor.&nbsp; If households or businesses choose to purchase clean renewable generation to fight air pollution and climate change, they want to ensure that they are getting real emissions reductions. As the rule is written, however, a voluntary purchase of clean generation leaves more room under the cap for others to buy more dirty power. DEP could fix this problem by keeping a pool of credits out of the auction and retire them for each ton of emissions avoided when individuals or businesses choose to buy clean renewable generation. Without this addition, the only way an individual could ensure they were making a difference is to not only buy clean energy but also buying the allowances. Making clean-energy consumers pay twice is the exact opposite of the polluter pays principle.</p>

<p><strong>What Happens Next?</strong></p>

<p>This is one of the most important regulatory actions we have seen during the current administration, and DEP&rsquo;s proposal is a good start, but there are still opportunities to make it better. For the next few months DEP will present their ideas and get input from various advisory committees before formally proposing the rule this summer. After that, the public will have the opportunity to send in written comments and testify at hearings.</p>

<p>PennFuture will be following this closely throughout the rulemaking process, so be sure to stay tuned into our blogs for the most recent updates.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
National Gas Industry Plans to Spend Big to Advertise Mistruths in Western Pennsylvania,1/29/2020,"<p>Western Pennsylvania is about to be center stage in a new million-dollar public relations campaign spearheaded by the fracked gas industry&rsquo;s largest national lobbying group. But, as has been the case previously, the industry isn&rsquo;t telling the whole truth about its environmental impact and contributions to climate change.</p>

<p>The American Petroleum Institute <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/news/politics-nation/2020/01/08/Oil-gas-industry-fracking-shale-drilling-Pittsburgh-messaging-campaign-pennsylvania/stories/202001080044"">recently announced that western Pennsylvania</a> will be one of several locations it will highlight as having benefited significantly from the extraction of fracked gas. The lobbying group will spend in excess of one million dollars on print and social media advertisements.</p>

<p>Specifically, the campaign is expected to hammer home a blatant mistruth consistently put forth by the industry: fracked gas is enhancing our environment, and the industry is doing its part to help combat the climate crisis.</p>

<p>Nothing could be further from the truth.</p>

<p>In a recent interview with the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, API President and CEO Mike Sommers called fracking &ldquo;one of the most important environmental achievements in this country.&rdquo; He added that the fracked gas industry is &ldquo;stepping up to the plate to address the issue of climate change.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Only days later, <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2020/01/13/Range-Resources-DEP-order-methane-gas-leaking-Marcellus-well-Lewis-Lycoming/stories/202001130117"">another story appeared</a> in headlines that directly contradicts that assertion: a gas well drilled by Range Resources has been leaking gas into groundwater in central Pennsylvania for the last eight years. That&rsquo;s nearly 3,000 consecutive days of leakage.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Department of Environmental Protection has alleged that this single well &ldquo;caused methane gas to seep into 11 drinking water supplies, nearby streams and a farm field pocked with spots of dead grass.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Over the last eight years, DEP regulators have been met with &ldquo;sporadic cooperation&rdquo; from Range Resources, which has refused to accept responsibility and is instead claiming that the methane is naturally occurring.</p>

<p>The DEP earlier this month finally ordered the company to fix the leaking well, noting that inaction from Range Resources will &ldquo;no longer be tolerated.&rdquo;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s not as if this is an isolated incident. <a href=""https://www.fractracker.org/2020/01/fracking-in-pennsylvania-in-2019/"">According to a recent report</a>, during the most recent 12-month period for which data are available, the industry was cited for 13,833 violations in Pennsylvania. The most common violation involved failure in properly storing, transporting or disposing of residual waste, while the second most common violation concerned jeopardizing clean water.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Does that sound like an industry that is enhancing our environment? If you need more proof, <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/16/climate/methane-leak-satellite.html"">look to another example</a> that came in February 2018, when a blowout at a single gas well in Ohio&mdash;about 70 miles southwest of Pittsburgh&mdash;resulted in more than 60 kilotons of methane escaping into the atmosphere over a 20-day period.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To put it into perspective, this single incident resulted in more methane leaking into the atmosphere <a href=""https://www.cnn.com/2019/12/17/us/ohio-exxon-mobil-methane-leak-satellite-climate-change/index.html"">than most countries release in an entire year</a>, all while the gas industry has worked with the Trump administration <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/29/climate/epa-methane-greenhouse-gas.html"">to roll back modest federal rules</a> that limit methane leaks in gas infrastructure. This doesn&rsquo;t sound like something an industry &ldquo;stepping up to the plate&rdquo; would do.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Still not convinced? This recent investigative report by Rolling Stone notes that <a href=""https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-features/oil-gas-fracking-radioactive-investigation-937389/?fbclid=IwAR3dBg9Wz1bD2S_aGlPdI4R64hmuqUtkCzBym57_RY5YxeqWtI30AMKcsys"">oil and gas wells produce nearly a trillion gallons</a> of toxic waste per year. The author conducted hundreds of exhaustive interviews with scientists, regulators, industry workers and environmentalists, and he uncovered a &ldquo;sweeping arc of contamination&rdquo; to our environment, the public, and the industry&rsquo;s own employees.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In trying to spin and change the narrative surrounding fracked gas, the industry touts the fact that its product is a cleaner alternative to coal, which is true. But that is a far cry from saying that fracked gas on its own is a solution to climate change. To the contrary, the buildout of natural gas infrastructure <a href=""https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-14/emissions-set-to-jump-on-gas-fueled-industrial-boom-study-says"">could add as much as a half billion metric tons</a> per year of carbon emissions into our atmosphere.&nbsp;</p>

<p>There are dozens of other instances of <a href=""https://newsinteractive.post-gazette.com/fracking-and-health-2/"">claims of tainted water supplies</a>, of <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y-OMydfBGvk&amp;feature=youtu.be"">families who allege sickness</a> stemming from nearby fracked gas operations, and of <a href=""https://www.timesonline.com/news/20190829/revolution-owners-fined-319000-for-pipeline-violations"">environmental damage to streams</a> and wetlands from drilling and pipeline operations.</p>

<p>In the coming months, you might see slick advertisements on television or expensive billboards along the highway. You might hear the upbeat radio ads or see glossy ads online.</p>

<p>Don&rsquo;t be fooled.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The American Petroleum Institute is about to spend seven figures to try to convince Pennsylvanians that it is environmentally friendly and is addressing climate change. Nothing could be further from the truth.</p>

"The Dangers of Senate Bill 790, Part II",1/14/2020,"<p>In December, PennFuture Director of Policy Ezra Thrush&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-The-Dangers-of-Senate-Bill-790"">wrote a blog detailing the dangers</a> of a new piece of legislation called Senate Bill 790. Legislators left Harrisburg for the holidays without voting on the bill but, in the coming days, the Pennsylvania House of Representatives is poised to vote on it, albeit in an amended form.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Though it was recently amended in the House, Senate Bill 790 still represents&nbsp;a substantial rollback of environmental protections governing the conventional oil and gas industry in Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>This bill, promoted by some legislators as a lifeline to the struggling conventional oil and gas industry, rolls back public health protections, allows for significant oil and gas spills to go unreported, and opens the door to more drilling operations across Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>Other controversial provisions of the bill were amended earlier this week by the House Environmental Resources &amp; Energy Committee, in an effort to garner more support from moderate Republicans and Democrats. A provision that would have allowed for drilling wastewater to be used as a road brine was eliminated, while thresholds for spill reporting were reduced.</p>

<p>The amended version of Senate Bill 790 is being touted in Harrisburg as an environmentally-sound compromise, but that&rsquo;s far from the truth. This remains a dangerous bill that would weaken environmental regulations on the oil and gas industry at a time when we need exactly the opposite.</p>

<p>This bill could receive second consideration in the House of Representatives this week, and could receive final consideration votes early next week. Gov. Tom Wolf has said he intends to veto the legislation if it reaches his desk, but PennFuture is working tirelessly to ensure this terrible legislation never makes it there.</p>

<p>You can do your part too, by contacting your local state representative and urging them to vote no on Senate Bill 790. Tell your elected leader that now is not the time to weaken regulations on the oil and gas industry.&nbsp;</p>

",Community; Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
New rule attempts to tackle pollution from oil and gas wells,12/20/2019,"<p>On Jan. 19, 2016 Governor Tom Wolf <a href=""https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/governor-wolf-announces-new-methane-rules-to-improve-air-quality-reduce-industry-loss/"">announced a new strategy</a> to reduce the emissions of methane&mdash;a dangerous greenhouse gas&mdash;from the oil and natural gas industry.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2018, Governor Wolf and the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) updated permits for new oil and natural gas operations to control for methane leakage. Unfortunately, between the Governor&rsquo;s announcement and the time these new permits were put in place, over 4,200 additional fracked gas wells were permitted. To control these wells and the tens of thousands of older existing sources, Governor Wolf announced the DEP would also &ldquo;expeditiously pursue the adoption of a regulation for existing sources.&rdquo; It might have taken nearly three years, but on Dec. 17, 2019, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Environmental Quality Board (EQB) voted to <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/Business/Air/Pages/Methane-Reduction-Strategy.aspx#.Vp6a0vkrJhE"">advance this proposed rulemaking.</a></p>

<p>While an important step, the proposed rulemaking still has some hurdles in the regulatory process before becoming law, but the rule also has some significant shortfalls. The DEP has presented the Environmental Quality Board with the regulatory language the agency would like to adopt along with supporting documentation and recommendations from various advisory committees, and the EQB has agreed to let the process move forward. While the rule&rsquo;s development process has been mostly internal within the DEP, we will see a notice in <a href=""http://www.pacodeandbulletin.gov/"">the Pennsylvania Bulletin</a> early in 2020 which formally opens a public comment period. This will give the public the opportunity to weigh in with written comments and at public hearings.</p>

<p><u>Wait, the Rule Regulates VOC&rsquo;s and Not Methane?</u></p>

<p>As written, the rule specifically controls ozone-forming volatile organic compounds (VOCs) by requiring thousands of existing facilities to adopt what is known as &ldquo;reasonably available control technology&rdquo; (RACT). In this case, RACT includes new standards for storage tanks and gas processing equipment along with requirements for leak detection and repair programs. While these are all specifically VOC controls, and methane is not a VOC under the <a href=""https://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?SID=b77fd17146a534c225c8557b5ed4a469&amp;node=40:2.0.1.1.2.3.8.1&amp;rgn=div8"">Environmental Protection Agency&rsquo;s definitions</a>, the DEP predicts more than 75,000 tons of methane emissions will be avoided as a co-benefit of the program.&nbsp; Using VOC regulation as a surrogate to control methane may not be ideal, but it allowed the DEP to leverage work done at the federal level to establish Control Techniques Guidelines (CTGs) for these sources.</p>

<p><u>OK, So What Will the Environmental Impact of this Rule Be?</u></p>

<p>This rule will make the oil and gas production process a little cleaner, but it doesn&rsquo;t make the gas and petrochemical industry clean. Reducing 75,000 tons of methane a year won&rsquo;t fix the climate crisis alone, nor does it address all of the methane oil and gas operations are polluting into our atmosphere. In fact, the rule is only a small but necessary piece of what we need to do to cut greenhouse gas emissions and address climate change. At the rate our natural gas generation is expanding, even very conservative estimates suggest the industry will put all of that carbon pollution and more back in our air in a few short years. When we add even more pollution from sources like ethane cracker plants and other facilities, the window to see real reductions in carbon pollution from this rule gets even smaller. Pretending that we can drill our way to clean air and a healthy climate isn&rsquo;t the path forward.</p>

<p><u>How Can the Wolf Administration Make This Rule Stronger?</u></p>

<p>While the proposed rule is a positive step, more can be done to limit methane emissions.&nbsp; For example, the rule controls fugitive emissions by requiring qualifying wells to be inspected monthly by sight, sound, and smell and also quarterly using an instrument-based leak detection and repair (LDAR) systems such as infrared cameras and gas detectors that can identify and locate smaller leaks.&nbsp; Regularly checking for leaks isn&rsquo;t very difficult, but of the more than 71,000 conventional wells, the DEP estimates that all but 303 will be exempt from even this basic measure. Removing this exemption for low producing wells make sense&mdash;just because a well doesn&rsquo;t produce a lot of gas doesn&rsquo;t mean it won&rsquo;t have significant leaks.</p>

<p>The rule also weakens the LDAR provision by letting operators test less frequently if the initial testing does not find sufficient leaks.&nbsp; If a part wears out or breaks and a new leak develops, that could mean months of additional uncontrolled emissions before the problem is caught.&nbsp;The Department should correct this and require all sources conduct regular inspections for leaks.</p>

<p><u>It&rsquo;s Time to Act on Climate</u></p>

<p>Making this rule as strong as possible and finalizing it without delay is a step in the right direction, but we should expect opposition. Anti-environmental forces will work to weaken, delay, and de-fund these rules at the same time they are <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/News/PennFuture-Policy-Memo---EnergizePA---6-7-19DRAFT.pdf"">promoting increased subsidies for the oil and gas industry.</a> We believe the people of Pennsylvania want action on climate change and strong common-sense emission controls on polluting industries, but some people in Harrisburg clearly haven&rsquo;t heard that message.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the new year, we&rsquo;ll be asking our members and friends to help fix that problem by sending in comments in support of a stronger rule and opposing attempts to increase pollution. But we also need to be realistic that making the oil and gas industry modestly cleaner, like the rule as currently written would do, won&rsquo;t solve the climate crisis. Much more needs to be done. Our elected officials have a constitutional obligation to take meaningful action in the fight against climate change and they need to hear from the public that we expect nothing less.</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
The Dangers of Senate Bill 790,12/19/2019,"<p>As soon as the Chamber returns to legislative session in January, the Pennsylvania House of Representatives is poised to take up Senate Bill 790, an unprecedented rollback of environmental protections across the state. Our elected leaders must stand against this potentially devastating bill by voting against the bill.</p>

<p>The oil and gas industry in Pennsylvania, including conventional drillers, is prominent and extremely lucrative. The revenues, however, come at the cost of damaging our environment and health, and exacerbates our climate change concerns. According to Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Department of Health, there have been approximately 350,000 conventional oil and gas wells and roughly 10,000 unconventional oil and gas wells drilled across the Commonwealth.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Despite the overwhelmingly large gap between the two types of drilling, conventional oil and gas drilling has declined recently due to large investments and the production of much larger operations in unconventional drilling. SB 790, put forth by Senator Joe Scarnati, aims to revive the conventional industry, but at the expense of undoing years of regulations by reenacting the Oil and&nbsp;Gas Act of 1984. Conventional drilling advocates argue that their industry is different than those employing hydraulic fracturing methods in Pennsylvania, but there is no difference in spills and dirty water, whether&nbsp;caused by conventional or unconventional drilling industries.</p>

<p><u>Loosening Requirements for Industry While Putting Water at Risk</u></p>

<p>SB 790 capitulates to the oil and gas industry to help &ldquo;optimize&rdquo; Pennsylvania&rsquo;s natural resources for the industry&rsquo;s economic benefit. The bill encourages and promotes dirty energy usage in Pennsylvania and puts our water quality at risk. Though this threatens the future, the immediate effects on the environment and human health are far more troubling and outweigh the monetary and economic benefits it might bring. Generally, SB 790 loosens restrictions and facilitates a lack of accountability for the oil and natural gas industry.</p>

<p>For example, the bill allows up to 5 barrels of oil and up to 15 barrels of oil and gas water to be spilled and go unreported. This affects downstream users who are unaware that the spill even occurred.&nbsp;Moreover, SB 790 prohibits communities from creating more protective regulations to keep leaks and spills away from homes, schools, and other&nbsp;buildings, which is simply irresponsible.</p>

<p>One of the most concerning issues is with replacement water due to an unexpected spill, leak, or emergency.&nbsp;The tainted water must be replaced, but that water does not have to comply with the Safe Drinking Water Act standards.&nbsp;This is a dangerous precedent as it allows for entities to pollute our state&rsquo;s precious water resources with unfiltered, dirty wastewater that is not safe for drinking or even swimming.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Toxicity Potential &amp; Health Impacts of Drilling Wastewater</u></p>

<p>This bill also allows for brine, or untreated wastewater, to be used as a dust suppressant on roads throughout Pennsylvania, which directly violates the Solid Waste Management Act, in which potentially toxic wastewater isn&rsquo;t allowed on roads. Excess brine runoff can easily make its way into waterways and systems for drinking water and recreational activities.&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://extension.psu.edu/potential-health-impacts-of-oil-and-gas-wastewater-on-roads"">In a recent study</a>&nbsp;on the health impacts of oil and&nbsp;gas wastewater on roads, researchers at Penn State University found that there is a large potential to aquatic and human toxicity caused by the application of wastewater brine on roads.The study claimed that, &ldquo;Through a variety of experiments simulating (oil and gas)&nbsp;wastewater application to roads, followed by simulated rain events, the majority of contaminants were found not to be retained in the road. The high salt concentrations are likely the major potential threat to aquatic toxicity, requiring up to 1,600 times dilution to reach drinking water quality standards.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Penn State researchers also disturbingly found that radium, a carcinogen from oil and&nbsp;gas wastewater, was found to leave the roads, impacting local watersheds. This wastewater is exempt from reporting, meaning the chemicals in the water do not have to be identified and can be kept confidential even when&nbsp;improperly disposed&nbsp;onto Pennsylvania land and water.&nbsp;SB 790 goes beyond that to specify that brine will no longer be defined as &ldquo;waste.&rdquo;&nbsp; Pennsylvania roads are already bombarded with enough salt to combat ice, and there is no need for Pennsylvania citizens to be exposed to more dangerous and toxic chemicals on our streets and in our water.</p>

<p><u>Stop Senate Bill 790</u></p>

<p>Currently, SB 790 is in the House Environmental Resources and Energy Committee, which is led by Republican Chairman Daryl Metcalfe. It is imperative that House members oppose Senate Bill 790. The conventional oil and&nbsp;gas industry should not have weaker rules for clean water protection, and rolling back regulations 35 years is obscene. We, as a state, have come too far and are too close to a brighter, cleaner future to roll back and roll over now.</p>

<p>Tell your State Representative to protect our water quality and <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/staterep_voteno_sb790"">OPPOSE Senate Bill 790 today.</a></p>

<p><em>Editor&#39;s note: PennFuture intern Ethan Silverstein co-authored this blog post.</em></p>
",Community; Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
Facing the Frack: Gas is Not Enhancing our Environment,12/19/2019,"<p>The fracked gas industry and its proponents excel at spinning false narratives about the health and safety of its operations, and often don&rsquo;t tell the whole story when faced with facts.</p>

<p>Take, for instance, <a href=""https://www.cmu.edu/tepper/news/stories/2019/december/nicholas-muller-research-shale-gas.html"">a groundbreaking study</a>&nbsp;published&nbsp;by Carnegie Mellon University on Dec.&nbsp;8&nbsp;that found that for every three jobs created by the shale gas industry, someone&rsquo;s life in the region is&nbsp;cut short by a year because of associated pollution.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>While not addressing the study specifically, industry trade group Marcellus Shale Coalition <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/news/health/2019/12/08/shale-development-natural-gas-drilling-fracking-costs-health-study-pennsylvania-cmu/stories/201912060038"">emailed a statement</a> to the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, saying that &ldquo;we believe firmly&hellip;that natural gas is unquestionably enhancing our environment and air quality.&rdquo;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s not, and there is recent and ample evidence to prove so. Look at a headline that broke earlier this week to find the fallacy within that statement: in February 2018, a blowout at a single gas well in Ohio&mdash;about 70 miles southwest of Pittsburgh&mdash;resulted in more than 60 kilotons of methane escaping into the atmosphere over a 20 day period.</p>

<p>Methane, the colorless and odorless main component of fracked gas, is an incredibly potent greenhouse gas that can <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/16/climate/methane-leak-satellite.html"">warm the planet more than 80 times as much</a> as the same amount of carbon dioxide over a 20-year period.&nbsp;It was a total disaster for the climate.</p>

<p>The massive leak in Ohio released about 120 metric tons of methane into the atmosphere per hour. The incident also forced about 100 residents to evacuate the area, residents who had previously complained about throat irritation, dizziness and other breathing problems.</p>

<p>To put it into perspective, this single incident resulted in more methane leaking into the atmosphere <a href=""https://www.cnn.com/2019/12/17/us/ohio-exxon-mobil-methane-leak-satellite-climate-change/index.html"">than most countries release in an entire year.</a></p>

<p>The methane leak and its consequences are frightening enough, but what about the fact that it took nearly two years to uncover the scope of the incident? According to <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/16/climate/methane-leak-satellite.html"">the New York Times</a>, the scale only became known after an analysis was undertaken by a satellite specifically designed to monitor the planet for methane leaks.</p>

<p>And that&rsquo;s just one well. According to the Energy Information Administration, <a href=""https://www.cnn.com/2019/12/17/us/ohio-exxon-mobil-methane-leak-satellite-climate-change/index.html"">there are 991,000 oil and natural gas wells</a> in the United States, in addition to an <a href=""https://triblive.com/news/pennsylvania/proposed-methane-emissions-rule-passes-pennsylvania-environmental-quality-board/"">estimated 80,000 conventional oil and gas wells </a>and about 10,651 active unconventional gas wells in Pennsylvania, according to the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection.</p>

<p>Groups like the Marcellus Shale Coalition can make statements about fracked gas enhancing our environment because, compared to coal, fracked gas is a cleaner option. It&#39;s true fracked gas burns much cleaner than coal and produces <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/16/climate/methane-leak-satellite.html"">only about half the carbon dioxide</a> than coal does.</p>

<p>That one fact, however, doesn&rsquo;t give the industry license to peddle its product as safe or clean. Carbon dioxide isn&rsquo;t the only greenhouse gas destroying our climate, and burning fossil fuels for electricity isn&rsquo;t the only way for greenhouse gases to enter the atmosphere.&nbsp;</p>

<p>What about the tons and tons of methane that escape&nbsp;undetected from the hundreds of thousands of oil and gas wells across the country? What about the health effects of living next to natural gas infrastructure that pollutes our air and water?</p>

<p><a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2019/12/17/Pennsylvania-DEP-methane-VOC-rule-existing-oil-and-gas-wells-Marcellus-shale/stories/201912170126"">New rules and regulations are advancing</a> in Pennsylvania&mdash;the country&rsquo;s second-largest natural gas producer&mdash;to reduce emissions of volatile organic compounds from oil and gas operations statewide. It&rsquo;s been estimated the regulations could help cut methane emissions by about 75,000 tons a year.</p>

<p>If this rule is enacted, it could make the gas and petrochemical industries marginally cleaner, but it most certainly will not make them clean. &ldquo;Cleaner than coal&rdquo; does not mean natural gas is clean or sustainable. It is neither,&nbsp;and propagating that narrative is intentional misdirection that fails to tell the entire story.</p>

<p>In the past two weeks, we&rsquo;ve been presented with evidence that lifespans in western Pennsylvania are being cut short because of the fracked gas industry, while we were also presented with evidence that 60 kilotons of methane leaked into the atmosphere as part of a single incident.</p>

<p>Does that sound like an industry that is enhancing our environment and improving our air quality?</p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"

<p>The holidays are for giving.<br />

This global day of giving has become the biggest giving day of the year.<br />

PennFuture&#39;s work goes on all year long because environmental watchdogs never sleep! "Reflections on 2019, and Looking Ahead to 2020",12/13/2019,"<p>It&rsquo;s the end of another year, and what a momentous year it was. The holiday season often offers time for reflection, and I&#39;ve compiled some thoughts below:</p>

<ul>
	<li>2019 was the Year of our Climate Youth, and we are grateful every day for their bold activism and ambition.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>2019 was the year that the stakes in the fight to stop Pennsylvania&rsquo;s blind embrace of gas for energy and petrochemicals rose to new heights. Words were spoken, sides were taken, industry plans were exposed, and the public noticed.</li>
	<li>2019 is nearly over and that brings us closer&ndash;finally&ndash;to 2020.&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>I am so proud of PennFuture. Our work continues to be essential and at a crucial time. In order to address threats to clean air, pure water, a healthy climate and sane energy policy, PennFuture must work in partnership, collaboration and coalition with many other groups, and we do. But I will boast on a few highlights in 2019 where our organizational signature of excellence is shining through.</p>

<p>On October 19, Governor Tom Wolf issued an important climate-related executive order, beginning a 24-month regulatory process that will lead to a cap on carbon pollution in Pennsylvania and our participation in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) market.&nbsp;PennFuture&rsquo;s Energy Center Director Rob Altenburg <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/opinion/Op-Ed/2019/09/25/Rob-Altenburg-Pennsylvania-should-join-the-Regional-Greenhouse-Gas-Initiative-but-for-the-right-reasons/stories/201909250048"">has been front and center</a> in keeping the public informed on what RGGI is about and how it can help address climate pollution.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the last several weeks, Rob faced fire in Rep. Daryl Metcalfe&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.penncapital-star.com/energy-environment/the-stakes-are-too-high-climate-skeptics-meet-their-own-critics-at-state-house-committee-hearing/"">Energy and Environment Committee</a> and on talk radio. To demonstrate what we are up against, read this piece about Speaker Mike Turzai&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.energyandpolicy.org/pennsylvania-house-speaker-says-he-will-rely-on-help-from-oil-gas-lawyers-in-lawsuits-to-oppose-joining-rggi/"">audacious alignment with the gas industry</a> to demolish RGGI.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The gas industry&rsquo;s response to Pittsburgh Mayor Bill Peduto&rsquo;s remarks opposing a petrochemical buildout has been loud, monied and consistent. PennFuture&rsquo;s Media Relations Director Jared Stonesifer has launched a rapid response blog to bust myths propagated by the industry and its spokespeople. You can <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fallacy-Fiction-and-Falsehoods"">have a look here</a>.</p>

<p>Through a unique partnership with students at Vermont Law School&rsquo;s Environmental Advocacy Clinic, PennFuture is suing industrial polluters who are violating clean water laws along the Delaware River. Our focus on protecting the exceptional value headwaters of the river continues as we watchdog energy and transportation projects that stand to adversely impact the best water quality in our state. In addition, we are in litigation against the Environmental Protection Agency for failure to set coal oven standards in a timely manner. This exceptional work advances under the leadership of our senior attorneys Alice Baker and Abby Jones.</p>

<p>Following the lineage of our successful high profile advertising campaigns Toxic Neighbor (targeting perpetual air quality violations at U.S. Steel&rsquo;s Clairton Coke Works) and Our Pocono Waters (targeting misguided development that will impact Pocono headwaters), we launched our Keep Philly Green &amp; Water Clean campaign, drawing attention to green stormwater management and the open space, public health, recreational and habitat benefits it provides, and we are encouraging the city of Philadelphia to remain a national leader with these programs.</p>

<p>Our Clean Energy Pittsburgh campaign is endeavoring to bring clean energy to Wilkinsburg, Swissvale and Braddock. These campaigns all take place under the leadership of staff including Jay Andrews, Lena Smith, Emily Baldauff, Annie Regan and Kelsey Krepps.</p>

<p>This year of 2019 produced a new strategic plan for the organization, under the leadership of our Vice President and Chief of Staff Matt Stepp. PennFuture has a different voice and will unapologetically champion a better future for Pennsylvania, one where the rights guaranteed by our environmental rights amendment prevail over the pollution of our people and natural resources. There is much work to do.</p>

<p>Here&rsquo;s what I am looking forward to in 2020:</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s Civic Engagement program will be front and center in counties all over the state as we organize volunteers, work on non-partisan voter registration and get out the vote efforts.&nbsp;Staff including Josh McNeil and Mike Mehrazar will be very, very busy.&nbsp;PennFuture&rsquo;s reach will extend into new places including Erie, Lehigh and Bucks counties.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

On the positive side of possibilities, there is renewed interest in electric vehicle support infrastructure and community energy proposals that have a decent chance of success.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We earnestly hope the 50th anniversary of the first Earth Day will reset and re-invigorate the environmental movement and the day will turn out diverse and intergenerational peoples bringing a clarion call to elected officials: the peoples of the earth deserve a future,&nbsp;the time has come to act boldly on climate.</p>

<p>Finally, on November 3, 2020 the United States will elect its next president.
