"Fallacy, Fiction and Falsehoods: Debunking the Petrochemical Industry Part 2",12/5/2019,"<p><em>This is the second in an ongoing series of blogs taking a deeper look at the comments, misinformation, hyperbole, and criticisms from the natural gas and petrochemical industry as well as their allies in their attempt to sell Pennsylvanians on the virtues of its climate-killing sector. As we&rsquo;ve seen in other states, the industry often uses misinformation tactics to sow doubt, build political support, and put a wedge in public debate. These blogs will provide an easily digestible point/counterpoint to some of the most prominent statements, quotes, and attacks. The first blog in the series <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fallacy-Fiction-and-Falsehoods"">can be found here</a></em>.</p>

<p><u><strong>Introduction and Context</strong></u></p>

<p>Pittsburgh Mayor Bill Peduto <a href=""https://www.nextpittsburgh.com/features/i-oppose-any-additional-petrochemical-companies-heres-what-mayor-peduto-said-at-the-climate-action-summit/"">ignited a firestorm</a> in late October when he voiced opposition to further expansion of the petrochemical industry in western Pennsylvania. The mayor&rsquo;s stance kicked off <a href=""https://www.bizjournals.com/pittsburgh/news/2019/11/27/the-plastics-debate-heats-up-both-sides-are.html?ana=wpxi"">a heated debate</a> that has unfolded between local and state politicians, business leaders and citizens about the future not just of western Pennsylvania but the entire state.</p>

<p>The debate reached <a href=""https://www.penncapital-star.com/energy-environment/in-radio-interview-wolf-breaks-with-pittsburghs-peduto-on-nat-gas-enraging-environmentalists/"">as far as Gov. Tom Wolf</a>, who sided with Allegheny County Executive Rich Fitzgerald in supporting the industry and its expansion. A letter <a href=""https://www.ellwoodcityledger.com/news/20191120/county-leaders-petrochemical-industry-welcome-in-western-pennsylvania"">signed by 20 regional elected officials</a> circulated in support of the industry, while one state representative <a href=""https://www.pahouse.com/Burns/InTheNews/NewsRelease/?id=111632"">petitioned ExxonMobil to scout</a> his district for a potential ethane cracker plant.</p>

<p>These letters, press releases and public statements continue to make assertions that are misleading and serve only as industry talking points to further the goal of turning Pennsylvania into the next petrochemical hub.</p>

<p><strong>Myth: The petrochemical industry is Pennsylvania&rsquo;s &ldquo;lifeline to the future.&rdquo;</strong> In a letter signed by <a href=""https://www.ellwoodcityledger.com/news/20191120/county-leaders-petrochemical-industry-welcome-in-western-pennsylvania"">more than 20 regional elected officials</a>&mdash;including Allegheny County Executive Rich Fitzgerald and 16 county commissioners from western Pennsylvania&mdash;it was stated that the fracked gas industry has &ldquo;breathed life back into our communities&rdquo; and that the petrochemical industry is our &ldquo;lifeline to the future.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Fact: The petrochemical industry, even if built to capacity, will have a negligible impact on regional employment.</strong> Shell&rsquo;s cracker plant in Beaver County is expected to employ <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2019/06/20/petrochemical-Appalachian-Shell-cracker-promoter-Washington-jobs-DOE-Ohio/stories/201906200133"">roughly 500 people</a> once the plant is operational, meaning jobs at the cracker plant will represent less than 1 percent of the county&rsquo;s workforce of <a href=""https://www.workstats.dli.pa.gov/Documents/County%20Profiles/Beaver%20County.pdf"">more than 81,000 people.</a></p>

<p>By comparison, <a href=""https://www.bls.gov/regions/mid-atlantic/pennsylvania.htm#eag"">more than 6.2 million people</a> are employed in Pennsylvania, meaning that full employment at the cracker plant represents less than&nbsp;0.01 percent of the state&rsquo;s employed workforce.</p>

<p><strong>Myth: The future success of western Pennsylvania&rsquo;s economy relies on petrochemicals</strong>. In a recent interview <a href=""https://www.bizjournals.com/pittsburgh/news/2019/11/27/the-plastics-debate-heats-up-both-sides-are.html?ana=wpxi"">with the Pittsburgh Business Times</a>, Allegheny County Executive Rich Fitzgerald said elected officials &ldquo;need to be reasonable and realistic in where the future lies.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Fact: Employment in the clean energy sector is already driving Pennsylvania&rsquo;s economy without the help of state taxpayer subsidies</strong>. There are more than 90,000 people employed in the clean energy sector in Pennsylvania, <a href=""https://www.e2.org/reports/clean-jobs-pennsylvania-2019/"">according to a 2019 economic analysis</a>, and the sector is adding jobs five times faster than the overall state employment growth rate. Since 2014, the clean energy industry has increased employment in Pennsylvania by nearly 60 percent, putting the state nearly into the top 10 nationally in total employment in clean energy.</p>

<p>Despite that, state lawmakers <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2019/08/13/Shell-cracker-Trump-protesters-plastics-ethane-oil-gas-Beaver-EPA-regulations-pennsylvania/stories/201908130059"">handed out $1.6 billion in tax</a><a href=""http://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2019/08/13/Shell-cracker-Trump-protesters-plastics-ethane-oil-gas-Beaver-EPA-regulations-pennsylvania/stories/201908130059"">&nbsp;breaks</a>&nbsp;for Shell to build a petrochemical facility in Beaver County. That&rsquo;s equivalent to more than $3&nbsp;million for each of the 500 permanent jobs at the plant&mdash;an enormous giveaway to one of the biggest and more profitable corporations on the planet. Compare this further to the state of New York, where leaders in 2018 committed $1.5 billion <a href=""https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2018/03/new-york-to-invest-1-5-billion-in-renewable-energy-projects"">to create 40,000 renewable energy jobs</a> in the state, about $37,500 per job.</p>

<p><strong>Myth: If Pennsylvania becomes the next petrochemical hub, ordinary residents will benefit</strong>. In early December, <a href=""https://www.pahouse.com/Burns/InTheNews/NewsRelease/?id=111632"">State Rep. Frank Burns (D-Cambria County) sent a letter</a> to the chairman and chief executive officer of ExxonMobil, asking the company to scout Cambria County as a location for a new cracker plant. In his letter, Burns said he wants to &ldquo;make a deal that benefits both ExxonMobil and the hardworking residents of our region.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Fact: Industry will be the only winner if Pennsylvania becomes the next petrochemical hub.</strong> Ask the residents of Port Neches, Texas about the benefits of the petrochemical industry. A chemical plant there <a href=""https://www.cbsnews.com/news/texas-chemical-plant-blasts-50000-people-allowed-back-home-2019-11-30/"">exploded before Thanksgiving</a>, displacing 50,000 residents after a four-mile evacuation radius was implemented. That incident was only the latest in a series of mishaps and accidents in the region of the Gulf Coast <a href=""https://www.cbsnews.com/news/cancer-alley-reserve-louisiana-denka-plant-health-risk-higher-national-average-2019-07-24/"">known as &ldquo;Cancer Alley.&rdquo;</a></p>

<p>The health impacts of the Shell cracker plant alone are enough to warrant deep concerns: the plant will emit 2.2 million tons of carbon dioxide per year, which is equivalent to putting nearly a half million more cars on local roads annually. It will also emit three times as much pollution as the Clairton Coke Works, which is Allegheny County&rsquo;s largest source of pollution. Allegheny County already has <a href=""https://www.lung.org/our-initiatives/healthy-air/sota/city-rankings/msas/pittsburgh-new-castle-weirton-pa-oh-wv.html#pm24"">some of the worst air quality in the country</a>, and has previously ranked <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/oct/11/plastics-appalachia-next-cancer-alley-fracking-public-health-ethane"">in the top 2 percent for cancer risks</a> from air pollution. Shell&rsquo;s plant alone will erase 30 years of improved air quality.</p>

<p>If Rep. Burns wants Pennsylvania to be the next petrochemical cluster, he should look at the health impacts of Cancer Alley, a place where <a href=""https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-features/louisiana-cancer-alley-getting-more-toxic-905534/"">7 of the 10 census tracts with the highest cancer risks</a> in the country are located. In addition, Louisiana residents <a href=""https://law.tulane.edu/sites/law.tulane.edu/files/files/Cancer%20Fact%20Sheet%202019%20FINAL.pdf"">have a 15 percent higher cancer death rate</a> compared to the rest of the country.</p>

<p>Communities in Burns&rsquo; district are still reeling from the environmental degradation wrought by the coal and steel industries. It would be an insult to injury to allow their health and communities to be further defiled by petrochemicals.&nbsp;</p>
",Climate; Community; Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
Legislators say Gov. Wolf lacks the authority to have Pennsylvania join RGGI. This is why they’re wrong.,11/22/2019,"<p>Earlier this week, a group of state legislators held a press conference in Harrisburg to unveil new legislation that challenges Gov. Tom Wolf&rsquo;s authority to enter into a partnership like the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI).&nbsp;</p>

<p>These bills&mdash;Senate Bill 950 and House Bill 2025&mdash;make the outlandish claim that &ldquo;no statutory or constitutional authority currently exists that authorizes a State agency to regulate or impose a tax on carbon dioxide emissions.&rdquo; This is simply wrong and misleading.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Constitution is clear saying that our &ldquo;public natural resources are the common property of all the people&rdquo; and that the Commonwealth act as trustee to &ldquo;conserve and maintain&rdquo; those resources. The real constitutional question is not whether the Commonwealth may act, but how any legislator could justify that allowing polluting industries to dump their waste products into our air for free is in keeping with their duty to conserve natural resources for our benefit.</p>

<p>There is also explicit statutory authority to regulate carbon pollution. The Air Pollution Control Act (APCA) gives the Environmental Quality Board&mdash;the organization that promulgates environmental regulations in Pennsylvania&mdash;the power and the duty to &ldquo;[e]stablish and publish maximum quantities of air contaminants that may be permitted under various conditions at the point of use from any air contaminant source in various areas of the Commonwealth so as to control air pollution.&rdquo; That is, essentially, what Governor Wolf&rsquo;s Executive order requires. The fact that the rule will have a market-based component allows more flexibility for the regulated community, lowers compliance costs, and can generate revenue that can be invested in complementary programs, but the core of the program is a cap on carbon emissions.</p>

<p>Attempts to characterize compliance costs as a tax versus a fee is a strawman argument when, in reality, Governor Wolf&rsquo;s Executive Order doesn&rsquo;t expressly require either. The executive order only says that the proposed regulation will &ldquo;provide for the annual or more frequent auction of carbon dioxide emissions allowances through a market-based mechanism&rdquo; and that such allowances &ldquo;may be traded with holders of allowances from other states.&rdquo; The legislature could pass bills allowing for more options in how any auction revenue is expended, but even without legislation the DEP has the ability to collect emission fees and use them for certain purposes.</p>

<p>These bills are equally outlandish when they say &ldquo;no statute...authorizes the [administration] to adopt regulations, implement a policy or take any other action to authorize the Commonwealth to join or participate in a State or regional greenhouse gas cap-and-trade program.&rdquo;&nbsp; In fact, APCA clearly states that the Department of Environmental Protection may &ldquo;[c]ooperate with the appropriate agencies of the United States or of other states or any interstate agencies with respect to the control, prevention, abatement and reduction of air pollution,&rdquo; and this would be the latest of several cap-and-trade systems the DEP has implemented.</p>

<p>The Department of Environmental Protection has used market-based programs to control emissions a number of times, and we expect that experience will be reflected in their proposed regulation. &#8203;The Legislature attempting to delay the process with this legislation serves no purpose but to increase pollution.</p>
",,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
A Trip to the Supreme Court,11/13/2019,"<p>Until last week, I had never been to the Supreme Court of the United States. But an issue that I have been interested in for years had wound its way through the lower courts and was being heard in the highest court in our land, and I wanted to hear it. So, the evening before the argument, I took a train from our Philadelphia offices to Washington, D.C., had an enjoyable evening with family, and went to bed with my alarm clock set for 5:15 a.m.</p>

<p>I got up in the morning, put on my suit, and headed to the Supreme Court arriving by 5:45 a.m. Even then, I was 80th in line! As it gradually got lighter and the morning joggers ran past, the line grew longer and longer. A little before 9 a.m., the first fifty people in line were let into the building and the rest of us remained waiting outside. If no one else was leaving, I wasn&rsquo;t either. At 9:45 a.m., a few more people were allowed in, and ten minutes later a few more. I was now close to the head of the line&mdash;two, maybe three people in front of me.</p>

<p>Then, we were told there were no more seats. The disappointment was frustrating, but we were told if we still wanted to go inside, we could enter for three minutes. After waiting for over four hours, I was going into the court, even if just for three minutes. We passed through security, locked our coats and bags in a locker, went through more security and waited outside the doors to the Supreme Court.</p>

<p>Then, one of the marshals said: &ldquo;We have some extra seats, do you want to stay for the whole argument?&rdquo; Of course I did! And just like that, I was in.</p>

<p>The case I heard was <a href=""https://www.supremecourt.gov/search.aspx?filename=/docket/docketfiles/html/public/18-260.html""><em>County of Maui v. Hawaii Wildlife Fund</em></a>, in which the Court seeks to answer the question of whether the Clean Water Act requires a permit when pollutants originate from a point source but are conveyed to navigable waters by a nonpoint source, such as groundwater. Generally, the Clean Water Act requires a permit for the addition to the nation&rsquo;s waters of any pollutant that comes &ldquo;from any point source.&rdquo; The statute defines a point source broadly including &ldquo;any discernible, confined and discrete conveyance.&rdquo; &nbsp;Over the years, what constitutes a pollutant, a point source, and navigable waters have been the subjects of substantial litigation. This was a case I&rsquo;d been waiting for since it was first filed seven years ago.</p>

<p>In this case, the County of Maui injects its treated wastewater from its sewage treatment plant underground into wells, which flows into the groundwater under the facility. The wastewater then travels through the groundwater to the Pacific Ocean a half-mile away. The County of Maui has never had a Clean Water Act permit for its discharges, although it has always known that pollutants from its wells reach the ocean. It has understood that it was subject to the Clean Water Act&rsquo;s nonpoint source management program, which is largely left to the states to implement.</p>

<p>Several environmental groups alleged in a citizen suit that the County&rsquo;s unpermitted discharges of pollutants violated the Clean Water Act&rsquo;s prohibition of polluting without a permit. The U.S District Court for the District of Hawaii agreed. Interestingly, the court found that both the wells that &ldquo;indirectly discharge a pollutant into the ocean through a groundwater conduit&rdquo; as well as the groundwater itself were point sources.</p>

<p>The U.S. Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit affirmed the lower court&rsquo;s decision, holding that a permit was required because the &ldquo;pollutants are fairly traceable from the point source to a navigable water such that the discharge is the functional equivalent of a discharge into the navigable water&rdquo; and &ldquo;the pollutant levels reaching navigable water are more than&nbsp;de minimis.&rdquo;</p>

<p>When this case was argued in front of the Supreme Court last week, everyone seemed to realize just how much was on the line. Both sides warned of the extreme consequences should the Supreme Court rule against them. The County of Maui argued&nbsp;that a ruling that its discharges require a permit may subject millions of pollutant sources across the country (potentially even small individual households) to the Clean Water Act&rsquo;s permitting requirement for the first time.</p>

<p>Conversely, the environmental groups argued that finding that intervening groundwater eliminates Clean Water Act point source liability would allow polluters to construct a &ldquo;work around&rdquo; to Clean Water Act permitting by directing their pipes into groundwater or cutting off the pipes just a few feet inland of a navigable water. The Supreme Court Justices really seemed to understand both the facts of the case and the potential real-life implications of their decision. They sought, as Justice Breyer said, &ldquo;a standard that will prevent evasion . . . and at the same time doesn&rsquo;t . . . undercut the groundwater program.&rdquo;</p>

<p>With all this, I am glad to live in a state that requires permits for discharges of pollutants regardless of whether it is to surface water or groundwater. Under the Pennsylvania Clean Streams Law, &ldquo;waters of the Commonwealth&rdquo; covers both surface and groundwaters, such that polluters don&rsquo;t have the option to evade permitting by discharging to groundwater or cutting a pipe short of discharging to waters of the Commonwealth. Ensuring these permits protect our natural resources and are enforced is what we do at PennFuture.</p>

<p>Please support PennFuture&rsquo;s fight to protect the over 80,000 miles of streams in PA. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">Become a member today</a>.</p>
",Community; Environment,"Alice R. Baker, Senior Staff Attorney"
Making Sense of Pennsylvania’s Growing Debate Around Petrochemicals,11/12/2019,"<p>When Pittsburgh Mayor Bill Peduto <a href=""https://www.publicsource.org/peduto-speaks-out-publicly-for-the-first-time-against-a-petrochemical-expansion-in-western-pennsylvania/"">announced his opposition</a> late last month to any more petrochemical companies in western Pennsylvania at the Climate Action Summit, I might have been the second person in the audience to rise up and out of my chair to applaud in appreciation and agreement. Advocates and constituents alike have been yearning for an elected leader to call attention to a growing problem: Pennsylvania&rsquo;s proposed petrochemical buildout is bad for the environment, bad for the economy, and bad for our communities.</p>

<p>Mayor Peduto followed his statement of opposition with powerful food for thought: Who was at the table&mdash;and who was not&mdash;when decisions were being made to lay the groundwork for the Royal Dutch Shell cracker plant in Beaver County? Who&rsquo;s at the table on <a href=""https://www.wesa.fm/post/report-exxonmobil-scouting-property-2nd-cracker-plant-beaver-county#stream/0"">where Exxon will build</a> a second plant? Where the industry wants to build a plant in northeast Pennsylvania? Mayor Peduto makes an important suggestion: the region (and in our opinion the state) should reopen its planning for a massive buildout of a three-state Appalachian Petrochemical Storage Hub, and that those plans be the subject to a much more inclusive regional, state, and public dialogue. Otherwise, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s politicians and business leaders are taking the state down a troubling economic and environmental path with little to no discussion.</p>

<p><u>Questioning Pennsylvania&#39;s&nbsp;Petrochemical Buildout is Leadership Against Doublespeak</u></p>

<p>Mayor Peduto&rsquo;s comments show significant leadership. Consider alone the transit of air, water, <a href=""https://www.wtae.com/article/investigation-cracker-plant-will-bring-jobs-pollution/27424034"">and climate pollution</a> that will emanate from the cracker plant. The suggestion becomes even more relevant in light of increasing expressions of concern <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2016/12/12/On-the-fenceline-and-on-the-fence-about-Shell-cracker-plant-pennsylvania-beaver-county/stories/201612120024"">from the frontline communities</a> and families that have been impacted by failing pipeline construction and property value impacts. Rural and urban residents alike simply want a future and livelihood that doesn&rsquo;t come with an unhealthy and fouled environmental price.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Plenty of voters support Mayor Peduto&rsquo;s stance, but his statements were met with outrage and opposition from politicians and industry cheerleaders who lack the courage to buck the will and dominance of the so-called fracked gas and petrochemical industries. There is a disturbing refusal among many elected officials and captains of industry to embrace the changes needed to address climate change and the sustainable industries, jobs, and profits that will grow out of it. Fracked gas and petrochemicals will not be major economic players of a climate-stabilizing future, yet the region and state stubbornly lean into climate-killing industries in a way that is not only intellectually dishonest, but also funnels billions in taxpayer subsidies to help the shareholders and CEO&rsquo;s of petrochemical companies make a profit.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>There is a pervasive problem in Pennsylvania: our elected leaders talk out of both sides of their mouths. Self-identified, climate-aware leaders like Allegheny County Executive Rich Fitzgerald and Governor Tom Wolf repeatedly say that Pennsylvania&rsquo;s fracked gas can be extracted and exploited&nbsp;safely. On Nov. 12, <a href=""https://kdkaradio.radio.com/media/audio-channel/future-energy-and-shell-cracker-plantnew-voting-laws-governor-pennsylvania-tom"">Wolf gave an interview</a> in which he publicly disagreed with Peduto&rsquo;s stance and said Shell&rsquo;s cracker plant is part of an &ldquo;energy efficient future.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Wolf and others follow these statements with a belief that Pennsylvania can also be part of the climate solution. There is a mountain of science, models, and experts that say otherwise. It&rsquo;s the work of organizations like PennFuture to expose the duality of these views and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Fallacy-Fiction-and-Falsehoods"">get the facts out about the fallacies</a> behind them, and help the public unravel these confusing statements.</p>

<p><u>The Petrochemical Buildout is a Statewide Problem</u></p>

<p>Heading up a statewide environmental advocacy organization requires that I keep an eye on the whole of our state. As such, I feel it is important to note&nbsp;that the attempt to elevate Pennsylvania as a world petrochemical power is not just confined to western Pennsylvania. It&rsquo;s intricately connected to pipelines in the southern tier counties, petrochemical projects in northeast Pennsylvania, existing plastics manufacturers in Erie, and along the Susquehanna River, among other existing infrastructure.</p>

<p>Unfortunately, this large scale buildout has flown under the radar. So much of the fracked gas and petrochemical industry&rsquo;s success depends on cultivating elected officials with campaign contributions and other goodies. The industry relies on its access to elected officials to get preferential treatment without the complication of public debate. The industries rely on public relations machines to hammer opposing viewpoints, like that of Mayor Peduto, at a moment&rsquo;s notice. This machine churns out messaging packaged for ease of use by the petrochemical industry&#39;s surrogates in government and powerful economic development circles.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>I fear the spread of petrochemicals in Pennsylvania is becoming unstoppable. Projects are pervasive. Along the Susquehanna River, New Fortress Energy is <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/About/Regional/North-central-Regional-Office/Community-Information/Pages/New-Fortress-Energy.aspx"">constructing a Liquefied Natural Gas facility</a> in Wyalusing, Bradford County.&nbsp;Caithness Energy cut ribbon on its gas fired power plant in Salem Township&mdash;the Moxie Freedom Generating Plant&mdash;along the river in Luzerne County. Elsewhere, the only compressor station along the PennEast Pipeline is moving ahead in Kidder Township, Carbon County, in close proximity the Pocono&rsquo;s Hickory Run State Park and tributaries to the Lehigh River.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>With the help of elected officials, the gas industry is loosening the ground for another possible fracked gas and petrochemical hub in Northeast Pennsylvania. Reminiscent of the exclusionary conversations suggested by Mayor Peduto, <a href=""http://www.thinkaboutbriefing.com/"">a closed door meeting</a> of business leaders (Cabot Oil &amp; Gas, CAN DO, Greater Hazleton Chamber of Commerce, Northeast Pennsylvania Manufacturers and Employers Association, UGI Energy Services) and elected officials (Sen. John Yudichak, Speaker Mike Turzai, Rep. Aaron Kaufer, and Rep. Tara Toohil) recently held in Luzerne County mulling over a wish list of site specifications, subsidies, and regulatory rollbacks that would be needed for Northeast Pennsylvania to become home to another cracker plant like Royal Dutch Shell&rsquo;s 900-acre industrial behemoth in Beaver County.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Shortly after the meeting, Sen. Yudichak <a href=""https://www.lehighvalleylive.com/opinion/2019/11/to-help-working-class-democrats-must-recognize-value-of-low-cost-energy-opinion.html"">published an </a><a href=""http://www.lehighvalleylive.com/opinion/2019/11/to-help-working-class-democrats-must-recognize-value-of-low-cost-energy-opinion.html"">op-ed</a>&nbsp;aimed at sowing confusion, arguing that building out more fracked gas and petrochemical infrastructure is the right thing to do for the environment and electricity reliability. While carbon pollution from the electric generation sector has reduced slightly because gas has replaced coal, that trend will not continue. As the few large coal-fired power plants left in Pennsylvania rapidly approach retirement, we are now seeing most of the pollution come from gas plants. That is bad today, but in a few short years we could see more than 70 percent of our generation coming from gas. That not only means much more pollution, but putting all our eggs in one basket is terrible for reliability. Worse yet, gas plants are dependent on the relatively fragile infrastructure of our pipeline system and, when disruptions inevitably happen, municipal gas systems will have a higher priority to receive fuel.</p>

<p><u>Pennsylvania Needs Leadership, Not Lackeys</u></p>

<p>Elected officials and business leaders have the right to their opinions, but as they govern and lead, they owe the people a level playing field, and they owe others with differing viewpoints respect. They do not have the right to negotiate an unsustainable future behind closed doors, spread misinformation and toe industry lines, or be close-minded to alternative and diversified economic development like that being embraced in our neighboring states. They also don&rsquo;t have the right to misdirect, misinform, and confuse what little direction they&rsquo;re providing their constituents at a crucial moment in Pennsylvania&rsquo;s economic history. The decisions made in the ensuing years will dictate the next 50 years of environmental outcomes. Our leaders shouldn&rsquo;t take that so lightly and without deference to facts, science, and community impacts.</p>
",Climate; Energy; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
"Fallacy, Fiction and Falsehoods: Debunking the Petrochemical Industry Part 1",11/4/2019,"<p><em>Note: This is the first in an ongoing series of blogs taking a deeper look at the comments, misinformation, hyperbole, and criticisms from the natural gas and petrochemical industry as well as their allies in their attempt to sell Pennsylvanians on the virtues of its climate-killing sector. As we&rsquo;ve seen in other states, the industry often uses misinformation tactics to sow doubt, build political support, and put a wedge in public debate. These blogs will provide an easily digestible point/counterpoint to some of the most prominent statements, quotes, and attacks.</em></p>

<p><strong><u>Introduction and Context</u></strong></p>

<p>Speaking at the Climate Action Summit in downtown Pittsburgh on Oct. 30, 2019, <a href=""https://www.nextpittsburgh.com/features/i-oppose-any-additional-petrochemical-companies-heres-what-mayor-peduto-said-at-the-climate-action-summit/"">Pittsburgh Mayor Bill Peduto announced</a> he would not support any further petrochemical development in western Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>The mayor&rsquo;s comments surprised environmentalists and industry supporters alike, albeit for different reasons. In the hours that followed his remarks, Peduto was subjected to harsh criticisms and attacks from those who have a very different vision for the future of western Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s no surprise that emotions are running so high. What&rsquo;s at stake is no less than the very future of millions of people. Pennsylvania is already home to one ethane cracker plant and could soon be home to another, as it was announced earlier this month that <a href=""https://www.wesa.fm/post/report-exxonmobil-scouting-property-2nd-cracker-plant-beaver-county#stream/0"">ExxonMobil is scouting for land in the area.</a> The next few months and years will shape the landscape &ndash; both economic and geographic &ndash; for decades to come.</p>

<p>Some of the statements issued last week in opposition to the mayor&#39;s remarks&nbsp;are at best ignorant and, at worst, intentionally false.</p>

<p><strong>Point: Building out natural gas and petrochemicals provides Pennsylvania both economic growth and a clean environment.</strong> David Spigelmyer, the president of the Marcellus Shale Coalition, stated that &ldquo;clean and abundant American natural gas is enabling economic growth or environmental progress for every single Pennsylvanian.&rdquo; He went on to say that some politicians &ldquo;push extreme or fringe bans on responsible energy development.&rdquo;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Counterpoint: Neither gas or petrochemicals is clean, rather both are and can make profound impacts on our environment.</strong> Pointing out their impacts is neither extreme or fringe. It is disingenuous to suggest there is anything &ldquo;clean&rdquo; about natural gas. Nothing about the extraction process&mdash;fracking, spills and leaks&mdash;is <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/opinion/commentary/natural-gas-carbon-pollution-climate-change-20190708.html"">clean or sustainable for our communities or our environment</a>, and the methane that leaks during natural gas development and processing is <a href=""https://blogs.princeton.edu/research/2014/03/26/a-more-potent-greenhouse-gas-than-co2-methane-emissions-will-leap-as-earth-warms-nature/"">30 times more potent as a greenhouse gas</a> than carbon dioxide. Methane is <a href=""https://unfccc.int/news/new-methane-signs-underline-urgency-to-reverse-emissions"">one of the major contributors</a> to climate change.</p>

<p>A final point on Spigelmyer&rsquo;s statement: there is nothing &ldquo;extreme&rdquo; or &ldquo;fringe&rdquo; about standing up and fighting for clean air and clean water. Pennsylvanians have a constitutional right to both and western Pennsylvania has a long history of environmental damage borne from industry. The mayor&rsquo;s comments reflect on this history and the public health and environmental damage caused by the coal and steel industry. It&rsquo;s fair to question allowing another well known polluting industry access to the region, particularly after <a href=""http://cleanair.org/wp-content/uploads/HIA-Final.pdf"">decades of progress in cleaning up our air</a> and water.</p>

<p><strong>Point: Anyone who opposes the petrochemical buildout also opposes economic growth and new jobs for the region.</strong> Rep. Mike Turzai, who represents a portion of Allegheny County and serves as the speaker of the House of Representatives, said in a statement posted online Wednesday that Peduto&rsquo;s comments represent an &ldquo;anti-growth mindset that is both irresponsible and dangerous.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Counterpoint: Opposing petrochemicals is not an &quot;anti-growth mindset.&quot; It is a pro-public health mindset that puts the health of an entire region ahead of profits for global companies like Shell.</strong> In one sentence, Turzai calls the mayor&rsquo;s comments irresponsible and dangerous, but then turns around and supports turning western Pennsylvania <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/oct/11/plastics-appalachia-next-cancer-alley-fracking-public-health-ethane"">into the next Cancer Alley.</a> Again, there is nothing irresponsible about supporting clean air and clean water.</p>

<p><strong>Point: The region doesn&#39;t have to choose between good jobs and clean air and water.</strong> Darrin Kelly, the president of the Allegheny/Fayette Central Labor Council, issued a statement saying &ldquo;it just isn&rsquo;t true that we have to choose between good jobs and clean air and water.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Counterpoint: It&rsquo;s a false narrative that the petrochemical industry provides both good jobs and clean air and water</strong>. While there are many ways to advance <a href=""https://pittsburghgreenstory.com/pennsylvania-clean-jobs-report-details-states-growing-clean-energy-sector/"">both economic development and environmental progress</a>, the petrochemical has no history of doing so. The Shell cracker plant <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/12/business/energy-environment/plastics-shell-pennsylvania-plant.html"">will emit 2.2 million tons of carbon dioxide per year</a>, the equivalent of about 480,000 extra cars on our roads. It will also release <a href=""https://breatheproject.org/patrolling-our-air/"">more than 30 tons per year of hazardous air pollutants</a> like benzene, which is linked to cancer and childhood leukemia, and particulate matter linked to lung and bladder cancers.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Western Pennsylvania already has <a href=""https://www.lung.org/our-initiatives/healthy-air/sota/city-rankings/states/pennsylvania/"">some of the worst air quality in the entire country.</a> If someone staunchly and unapologetically supports Shell&rsquo;s petrochemical plant, and is also hopeful for more cracker plants to come, then that person is making a tradeoff that includes sacrificing public health for jobs. It&rsquo;s that cut and dried.</p>

<p>Peduto, unlike his critics, seems not to have forgotten <a href=""https://conserveland.org/blog/article-i-section-27-of-the-pennsylvania-constitution/"">Article 1, Section 27 of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s constitution</a>:</p>

<p style=""margin-left: 40px;""><em>&ldquo;The people have a right to clean air, pure water, and to the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic and esthetic values of the environment. Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources are the common property of all the people, including generations yet to come. As trustee of these resources, the Commonwealth shall conserve and maintain them for the benefit of all the people.&rdquo;</em></p>

<p>Pennsylvanians have a right to clean air and clean water.&nbsp;The petrochemical industry doesn&rsquo;t have permission to infringe on those rights,&nbsp;unless we grant it&nbsp;that permission.</p>
",Energy; Environment,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
PennFuture organizes tour of Philadelphia green stormwater infrastructure sites,10/30/2019,"<p>Often times, showing is better than telling. That&rsquo;s why PennFuture last month organized a bus tour in an effort to highlight the social, economic and environmental benefits of green stormwater infrastructure in Philadelphia. &nbsp;</p>

<p>In addition to presenting an opportunity to discuss the many benefits of green stormwater infrastructure, the bus tour also allowed for a discussion about the challenges that come with aligning and integrating various city programs and initiatives.</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s bus tour attracted prominent officials and business leaders from the city, including Philadelphia city Councilwoman Maria Qui&ntilde;ones-S&aacute;nchez, a staff member from her office, as well as experts and&nbsp;partners at Meliora Designs, Roofmeadow, Rodriguez Consulting LLC., and the Sustainable Business Network of Greater Philadelphia.</p>

<p>Our first stop was to visit the <a href=""http://www.americanstimprovementproject.com/"" target=""_blank"">American Street Improvement Project</a> starting at Jefferson Street. American Street was once an industrial corridor, spurred by the Reading and Philadelphia Railroads that were routed through the area. The commercial strip was filled with factories, repair shops, and freight yards. Beginning in the late 1800s, this corridor produced tens of thousands of jobs for the region. But for the last several decades, the post-industrial corridor has been significantly blighted. &nbsp;</p>

<p>The two-mile long corridor is currently being reconstructed to integrate the city&rsquo;s &ldquo;Complete Streets&rdquo; vision&mdash;which ensures that city streets accommodate all users of transportation whether pedestrians, bicyclists, public transit users, or motor vehicles&mdash;with the Philadelphia Water Department&rsquo;s Green City, Clean Waters initiative that is constructing green stormwater infrastructure to manage stormwater runoff.</p>

<p>The final design incorporates 42 green stormwater infrastructure systems including rain gardens, bioswales, subsurface stormwater trenches, and tree pits. Each time it rains, GSI systems will collect more than 1.4 million gallons of stormwater runoff from the right-of-way, which will equate to more than 50 greened acres towards PWD&rsquo;s program for waterway pollutant reduction.</p>

<p>Funding for the project was made possible through partnerships with the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation, Federal Highway Administration, United States Department of Transportation Investment Generating Economic Recovery Discretionary Grants Program, and Philadelphia Water Department green stormwater infrastructure funds.</p>

<p>The American Street Improvement project is a unique approach to green stormwater infrastructure design and construction. The project design required extensive community outreach and engagement to ensure that the corridor was accessible to all stakeholders. Councilwoman Qui&ntilde;ones-S&aacute;nchez&rsquo;s office has been a leader in ensuring all stakeholder priorities are incorporated into the project design. During the tour she acknowledged that at the end of the day, no one stakeholder received everything they asked for.</p>

<p>Our second stop was the Shissler Recreation Center, a portion of Kensington&rsquo;s <a href=""http://www.sustainable19125and19134.org/about-us/big-green-block"" target=""_blank"">Big Green Block</a>. The block was a collaboration of public, private and non-profit partners to turn a 20-acre blighted piece of vacant land strewn with trash and cinders into new green space. Councilwoman Qui&ntilde;ones-S&aacute;nchez is a strong supporter of the Shissler Recreation Center and lauded the success of the park. We were joined by Andrew Goodman from the New Kensington Community Development Corporation who shared with us the story of the Big Green Block and what it took to make the project possible. NKCDC continues to maintain the green stormwater infrastructure through the Soak it up! Adoption program.</p>

<p>The block includes the Shissler Recreation center, the Kensington High School for the Creative and Performing Arts, a spray park, Palmer Doggie Depot dog park, and Stan &ldquo;The Cutman&rdquo; Field for kids. Rain gardens, percolating astroturf, embedded planters, and a basketball court with underground stormwater runoff collection chambers are incorporated into this green space to capture 95 percent&nbsp;of the blocks&rsquo; stormwater run-off on site. The Big Green Block project began in 2008 and was made possible through partnerships with local residents, the New Kensington Community Development Corporation, the Philadelphia Water Department, the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society, the Mayor&rsquo;s Office of Sustainability, the Mural Arts Program, Philadelphia Parks &amp; Recreation, and the Philadelphia School District.&nbsp;</p>

<p>During the return drive to our ending destination, the partners had an opportunity to discuss with Councilwoman Qui&ntilde;ones-S&aacute;nchez the challenges they are facing with incorporating green stormwater infrastructure into designs for the <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-The-Opportunity-for-Green-Stormwater-Infrastructure-in-Philadelphias-Rebuild-Initiative"" target=""_blank"">Rebuild Initiative&rsquo;s</a> investments in the city&rsquo;s parks, recreation centers, playgrounds, and libraries. The <a href=""https://worldlandscapearchitect.com/waterloo-rebosante-philadelphia-usa-roofmeadow/#.XbnaVuhKhPZ"" target=""_blank"">Waterloo Recreation Center</a> is one of those sites receiving investments from the Rebuild Initiative, that is also slated to receive green stormwater infrastructure investments. Initially planned to be completed in late 2017, the project has run into delays in moving forward at the city level.</p>

<p>As part of PennFuture&rsquo;s work to elevate the importance of green stormwater infrastructure in Philadelphia with elected leaders and community residents, we are developing city council champions to advocate for a strong program. Philly green stormwater infrastructure bus tours are one way we are engaging with city council members around this important issue for the people of Philadelphia.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
",Community; Environment; Keep Philly Green & Water Clean,Lena Smith
PennFuture delivers Toxic Neighbor petition to U.S. Steel,10/28/2019,"<p>The steel industry has long played an important role in western Pennsylvania&rsquo;s economy, but it is impossible to ignore its equally long and harmful history of pollution. In Pennsylvania&rsquo;s 21st century innovation economy, there are no excuses for giving job-creating industries like steel a free pass for polluting our air and water. Pennsylvanians can and should have steel jobs and clean air, but it takes investment, good public policy, and corporate responsibility.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2017, PennFuture launched its first &ldquo;Toxic Neighbor&rdquo; campaign with a firm belief that profits shouldn&rsquo;t take priority over people&rsquo;s health and their rights to clean air and clean water, as laid out in Article I, Section 27 of the Pennsylvania Constitution. The campaign was especially important because PennFuture&rsquo;s legal team had documented more than 6,700 air emission violations at U.S. Steel&rsquo;s Clairton Coke Works from January 2012 and May 2015. On average, this is more than five air quality emission violations each day.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Initially, our Toxic Neighbor campaign asked residents to send letters to Allegheny County Executive Rich Fitzgerald, demanding he take action to protect our region&rsquo;s air quality. More than 300 people sent letters to Fitzgerald, increasing the public pressure on the Allegheny County Health Department to ensure that it held U.S. Steel accountable.</p>

<p>The second iteration of our Toxic Neighbor campaign began earlier this year after a fire ripped through U.S. Steel&rsquo;s Clairton Coke Works, knocking out the pollution control systems that remove sulfur dioxide from emissions for almost four months, exposing surrounding neighborhoods to harmful chemicals.</p>

<p>At the heart of the campaign was our petition to U.S. Steel, demanding the company do the following:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Retire Clairton Coke Works&rsquo; oldest, dirtiest and most problematic coke batteries - batteries 1, 2 and 3;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Modernize Clairton Coke Works by investing in technologically advanced upgrades to ensure cleaner air and Mon Valley jobs, now and in the future; and&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Commit to the community and regulators that it will be more transparent about plant operations, especially in times of emergency.</li>
</ul>

<p>Today, PennFuture is proud to announce the petition was delivered to U.S. Steel President and Chief Executive Officer David Burritt. We made it clear in a letter to Burritt that this petition represents the collective voices of more than 5,300 people who demand clean air, healthy communities, and a commitment to public safety by U.S. Steel.</p>

<p>PennFuture started this petition to amplify voices across western Pennsylvania that were demanding cleaner air and healthier communities. Residents in Clairton and across the region are tired of pollution, accidents and lack of transparency from U.S. Steel. These are the voices of people who live and work here. They can no longer be ignored by U.S. Steel.</p>

<p>It is our hope that Burritt will take residents&rsquo; concerns seriously as he leads U.S. Steel into a new decade, and that under his leadership, U.S. Steel and its employees can prosper without harming residents&rsquo; health and the environment.</p>

<p>PennFuture wants to sincerely thank everyone who took the time to sign this petition, and for everyone who continues to advocate for clean air in the Mon Valley and Greater Pittsburgh region. If we speak loud enough, those in power will have no choice but to hear our demands.</p>

<p>Though this phase of Toxic Neighbor has ended, it will not be the end of our efforts to hold U.S. Steel and other polluters accountable. Stay tuned to see what&rsquo;s next as PennFuture continues the fight for clean air, clean water, and a healthy environment.</p>

<p>Now, more than ever, your voice is needed to fight back against major polluters. Please <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/subscribe/index.html"">subscribe to our newsletter</a> or <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">donate to PennFuture</a> to do your part in our ongoing fight.</p>
",Community; Energy; Environment,"Kelsey Krepps, Western PA Outreach Coordinator"
So Pennsylvania Might Join RGGI. What Comes Next?,10/10/2019,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-83f5811c-7fff-ea54-19a0-1e2393e3ccc6""></span></p>

<p>On Oct. 3rd, Governor Tom Wolf signed <a href=""https://www.oa.pa.gov/Policies/eo/Documents/2019-07.pdf"">Executive Order 2019-07</a> instructing the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) &ldquo;to begin the process of developing a carbon budget and trading program that aligns with that of the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI).&rdquo; So what exactly does that mean?</p>

<p>It involves creating a cap-and-trade program where to emit one ton of carbon dioxide, a generator will need to hold an &ldquo;allowance.&rdquo; These allowances are created by the state and together they make the emissions cap. Generators who emit CO2 will need to buy the allowances they need at an auction, letting the market set the price. Revenue from that auction can be invested in different ways&mdash;ideally in things like more clean renewable energy and energy efficiency, but the state could fund other priorities or programs.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>What Kind of RGGI Program Can DEP Propose?</strong></u></p>

<p>The executive order requires the DEP proposal to be &ldquo;sufficiently consistent with the <a href=""https://www.rggi.org/sites/default/files/Uploads/Design-Archive/Model-Rule/2017-Program-Review-Update/2017_Model_Rule_revised.pdf"">RGGI Model Rule</a> such that allowances may be traded with holders of allowances from other states.&rdquo; That suggests that the affected sources will be defined the same way (i.e. electric generators with a nameplate capacity over 25 megawatts), the pool of available allowances will be sized so as not to disrupt the functioning of the market, and that the various compliance periods and accounting procedures will align. Beyond that basic structure, the DEP will have a lot of flexibility.</p>

<p>One issue where we expect debate is related to the allocation of allowances. Every source of fossil fuel generation will likely try and make the case why they are a special case deserving of free or low-cost allowances. The waste coal industry in particular has had some success making these kinds of arguments in the past, so that is a particular industry to watch. Other states also choose to hold some allowances in reserve for special purposes. For instance, Massacusets holds some allowances aside to retire when people voluntarily purchase clean energy.</p>

<p>Early projections suggest there could be $300 to $400 million per year in revenue&mdash;who gets to spend the money and what it gets spent on will be another significant issue. DEP can use money from air emissions fees to support the operation of the air program itself, and the Governor&rsquo;s remarks indicate they are at least considering other spending priorities. It&rsquo;s also clear that the Legislature will have significant input into how the money is spent.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>While the Executive Order is an important and historic step toward reducing Pennsylvania&rsquo;s carbon pollution, it is just the beginning of a potentially long pathway that, even if all goes smoothly, could take 18 to 24 months to finalize.&nbsp; So, what comes next? The answer to that question requires some explanation.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>So What Comes Next?</strong></u></p>

<p>The Regulatory Review Act (RRA) specifies a <a href=""http://www.irrc.state.pa.us/resources/docs/Regulatory_Review_Process_Manual.pdf"">detailed process</a> the DEP needs to follow to promulgate a regulation, but the actual work usually begins several months before this formal process starts, and working towards RGGI is no different.</p>

<p>Before any RGGI language is drafted, the technical and legal staff at DEP will spend a good bit of time researching issues like the ones we mentioned above and will form ideas on how they might move forward. While there are very few requirements at this early stage, DEP tends to start by developing a powerpoint presentation covering the concepts&nbsp;in the regulation, and presenting that to the various relevant advisory committees.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In this case, we expect presentations will be given, at a minimum, to the Air Quality Technical Advisory Committee, the Climate Change Advisory Committee, and the Citizens Advisory Council, but there may also be additional presentations to other committees or groups. The DEP will also likely meet with members of the regulated community, such as power plant owners, and other interested parties to discuss RGGI concepts before the drafting process begins. And, in some cases, the DEP might also hold &ldquo;listening sessions&rdquo; or other events to get even more public input.</p>

<p><u><em>The Proposal&nbsp;Stage</em></u></p>

<p>Once the DEP feels they have the necessary information and analysis, they will write a preamble to the regulation, the regulatory language itself (called &ldquo;Annex A&rdquo;), and prepare a Regulatory Analysis Form, all of which will be presented at a meeting of the Environmental Quality Board (EQB). The EQB, if they vote to do so, will formally propose to adopt the rulemaking. We expect this will take place around July.</p>

<p>Next, the DEP will prepare a package on the proposed rulemaking and have it delivered to the Legislative Reference Bureau (LRB) for publication in the <a href=""https://www.pabulletin.com"">Pennsylvania Bulletin</a>. At the same time the package goes to the LRB, it will also be delivered to the Independent Regulatory Review Commission (IRRC) and to the relevant standing committees in the House and Senate. Normally DEP regulations are sent to the House and Senate Environmental Resources and Energy Committees.</p>

<p>About 10 days after the package is delivered to the LRB, it will appear in the Bulletin. This notice will mark the start of the formal public comment period (which must be at least 30 days) and it will also have information about any public hearings that are scheduled. Anyone interested in the regulation can file written comments and/or testify at a public hearing, and all of their comments will become part of the official record. The DEP will likely also schedule presentations for the relevant advisory committees and give them an opportunity to weigh in on the proposal. After the public comment period closes, IRRC will have 30 more days to submit their comments and the legislative committees may file comments at any time prior to the delivery of a final form regulation.</p>

<p>After the close of the comment period, there will appear to be a lull in the process, but a lot of work will be going on behind the scenes. DEP staff will review each and every comment they receive&nbsp;and make any changes they think are necessary to the draft rule. They will also prepare a &ldquo;Comment Response Document&rdquo; that explains how they handled every comment. Changes at this point are usually either clarifications or relatively minor fixes to the language, but occasionally big changes are necessary that will require DEP to reopen the comment period.</p>

<p><u><em>Final-form Rulemaking</em></u></p>

<p>Once DEP is ready with a final rule, it will be presented once again to the EQB and, assuming it is approved, it will once again be delivered to IRRC and the standing committees in the Legislature along with all of the comments that DEP received. This delivery needs to happen within two years of the date the rule was proposed, estimated to be July 2022. If it is not, the rulemaking ends and DEP needs to start again from the beginning.</p>

<p>Once the rule is delivered, IRRC will schedule it to be considered at their next meeting that is at least 30 days away. The public can submit comments directly to IRRC up to 48 hours before the meeting, and the standing committees can also respond at any time up to 24 hours before the meeting.</p>

<p>If IRRC approves of the rule, the Attorney General gets to review it for legality and form. If all goes well, the rule will be published as final in the Pennsylvania Bulletin.&nbsp;</p>

<p>If IRRC disapproves of the rule, the DEP has 40 days to deliver a report back to IRRC.&nbsp;The DEP can make changes to the rule in response to IRRCs comments, but they are not required to do so. The IRRC will consider the rule again at another meeting and the standing committees will have more time to act, but IRRC cannot stop a rule from continuing toward finalization.</p>

<p><u><strong>What Role does the Legislature Play?</strong></u></p>

<p>The legislative veto is unconstitutional in Pennsylvania so, if the standing committees want to stop a rulemaking, the House and Senate must adopt a concurrent resolution disapproving of the rule and either have that signed by the Governor or override the Governor&rsquo;s veto by a two-thirds majority. Unless that happens, the rule may be delayed, but the process will continue toward finalization.</p>

<p>That&rsquo;s not to say the Legislature doesn&rsquo;t have other methods to halt or delay the process. When Pennsylvania was drafting regulations required to fulfill the Clean Power Plan under President Obama, the legislature passed a bill that added significant delay to the above process. <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/Legis/CSM/showMemoPublic.cfm?chamber=H&amp;SPick=20190&amp;cosponId=30314"">Similar legislation</a> is already proposed in the state House to delay consideration of the RGGI rulemaking. There are also indications that the legislature may try and add additional rules to limit how Pennsylvania can create a RGGI-like program, including requiring that other RGGI states cannot ban the use of natural gas. We expect other new attempts to slow this process down as well.</p>

<p><u><strong>Legal Challenges</strong></u></p>

<p>Outside of the regulatory review process, there is also the possibility that any rulemaking will be challenged in the courts. Although the Governor expressed hope that this process wouldn&rsquo;t become political, the Pennsylvania House Republican caucus quickly <a href=""http://www.pahousegop.com/News/15153/Latest-News/House-Republicans-Urge-Wolf-Not-to-Go-it-Alone---Leadership-responds-to-push-to-join-RGGI-"">issued a statement</a> saying that they &ldquo;believe the executive branch cannot bind the state into multi-state agreements without the approval of the General Assembly.&rdquo; That might signal a pending legal challenge.</p>

<p>While it wouldn&rsquo;t be surprising to see a lawsuit filed in fairly short order, courts tend not to weigh in until the administration makes a final action. Since any actual law is likely 18 to 24 months from going into effect, it is much more difficult&mdash;but not impossible&mdash;for potential challengers to show they will suffer harm by allowing the administrative process to continue.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The other more important hurdle a lawsuit would face is that our state&rsquo;s Air Pollution Control Act (APCA) gives the executive branch fairly broad powers to set emission limits and reduce pollution. Programs with interstate trading components are one of many tools the DEP has used to achieve that goal in the past. This includes the Acid Rain Program (1995), the NOx Budget Trading Program (2003), the Clean Air Interstate Rule (2005), and the Cross-State Air Pollution Rule (2011). It&rsquo;s not clear how opponents will justify that regulating carbon pollution triggers an exception or is any different than previous efforts to reduce air pollution.</p>

<p>Beyond the Air Pollution Control Act, we also have the Environmental Rights Amendment in Article 1 &sect; 27 of our state Constitution, which states that, &ldquo;The people have a right to clean air, pure water, and to the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic and esthetic values of the environment.&rdquo;&nbsp;Even if the authority in the APCA wasn&rsquo;t specific, it would be hard to justify how ignoring carbon pollution was in keeping with the Commonwealth&rsquo;s trust responsibility to conserve and maintain our natural resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Conclusion</strong></u></p>

<p>Pennsylvania has an ethical responsibility to be a leader in fighting the climate crisis. We are the fourth-highest carbon polluter in the nation and are still heavily subsidizing fossil fuels. Governor Wolf&rsquo;s executive order is a good and necessary first step to address this imbalance, but no single action is going to solve the problem.</p>

<p>In addition to implementing a cap on carbon pollution, we need to invest in cleaner alternatives to coal and gas instead of creating new subsidies for dirty fossil fuels. We need to extend and expand our Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards, increase investment in energy efficiency, and enable new business models like community solar. We also need to ensure the Department of Environmental Protection has the tools it needs to do its job.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Joining RGGI is a great first step, but it cannot be the only step Pennsylvania takes to address the climate crisis. Regardless, PennFuture will keep you posted as the process unfolds over the next 18 to 24 months.</p>
