"Exploring Erie, and an Emerging Presence",10/7/2019,"<p>I just returned from an annual field trip we take with PennFuture&rsquo;s board of directors, as well as a terrific group of folks we call our President&rsquo;s Leadership Council. We try to visit special places in Pennsylvania&mdash;there are so many&mdash;and if these places have resonance with our mission, our program or the threats we are addressing, all the better.</p>

<p>This year we visited Erie County.</p>

<p>Erie County has been a part of my worldview from my days working to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s ecological treasures. The county&rsquo;s 77-mile Lake Erie shoreline and ribbon lake watershed contains spectacular biodiversity, natural features, great water-based recreation and rich agriculture. The rest of Erie County&mdash;by my rough estimation 80 percent&mdash;lies in the French Creek watershed, which empties into the Allegheny River and is one of the most ecologically significant tributaries to the Ohio basin, mainly because of aquatic life, freshwater mussels in particular.</p>

<p>My work now lies in defending these waters, lands and communities, and we at PennFuture see threats on the horizon.</p>

<p>One threat to the area is the lack of appreciation the rest of the state has for our northwest corner, Lake Erie and the fact that we are part of the Great Lakes ecosystem and region. The distance between Erie and Harrisburg creates another barrier&mdash;physically, psychologically and politically&mdash;and we know that dynamic can lead to this being an underserved region.</p>

<p>Our portion of Lake Erie has been relatively lucky in avoiding harmful algal blooms. These blooms have the potential to adversely impact our drinking water, and much diligence is required to maintain and improve water quality in light of changing climate and other conditions. Erie remains home to some of the most polluting industries and all have the potential to harm air, water and public health.</p>

<p>PennFuture aspires to play more of a role defending Lake Erie and the region&rsquo;s water, and we are driven to this work by legacy threats such as industrial discharges and leaking septic systems, and other emerging threats. A major concern is Erie&rsquo;s proximity to Pennsylvania&rsquo;s frack fields, its concentration of plastics manufacturing, and the massive petrochemical buildout that can occur there if the community is not attentive to this threat.</p>

<p>Related is the threat of the increasing infiltration of plastics everywhere, including into our freshwater resources, and how we can defend against a gas industry that is intent on exploiting frack gas to exponentially increase production of plastics. PennFuture aspires to shorten the distance between Erie and Harrisburg, and build capacity for the Erie community to have a stronger voice in the halls of the Capitol and be a more integrated part of our statewide water campaigns.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>So we made a field trip to Erie to increase awareness among PennFuture&rsquo;s leaders of the beauty of the area. But more important were our meetings with members of the community who are dealing with environmental threats from invasive species to pollution from Erie Coke. These community leaders, elected officials and resource managers are on the ground every day fighting for their rights to clean air and clean water.</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s brand of advocacy will add value to these efforts and we look forward to close partnerships in the Erie area in the near future.</p>
",Community; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
A Sunnier Vision for Pennsylvania: An Alternative to Giving Tax Breaks to Fossil Fuels,9/27/2019,"<p>On Sept. 19th, the Pennsylvania House of Representatives voted to give yet another gift to the already <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/News-Fossil-Fuel-Subsidy-Report"">heavily subsidized natural gas</a> and petrochemical industry: a 20 percent tax break to companies that build petrochemical facilities that turn natural gas to plastics and other products. This archaic vision of economic development in Pennsylvania is a threat to our communities, ecology, and climate. Instead of giving fossil fuels even more subsidy, state policymakers could get more jobs, grid resiliency, and pollution reduction by providing a similar tax credit for utility scale solar instead.</p>

<p><strong>HB 1100: A Windfall for Polluting Petrochemical Projects</strong></p>

<p>HB 1100 is part of the so-called &ldquo;Energize PA&rdquo; package of policies aimed at giving the economic keys of the Commonwealth to the petrochemical industry. It would be more accurate to call the package <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/News/PennFuture-Policy-Memo---EnergizePA---6-7-19DRAFT.pdf"">&ldquo;Fossilize PA&rdquo;</a>, and it says a lot about what is wrong with Pennsylvania politics. Our legislators are still acting like they can ignore climate change and chase the hope of short-term economic rewards through fossil fuel subsidies, at the cost of long-term economic growth and environmental degradation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While scientists tell us we need to get to net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, this bill gives climate-killing companies a 30-year tax break. The young Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg may as well have been talking directly to them when she said at the <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/video/climate/100000006732168/greta-thunberg-united-nations.html?action=click&amp;gtype=vhs&amp;version=vhs-heading&amp;module=vhs&amp;region=title-area&amp;cview=true&amp;t=53"">United Nations</a>, &ldquo;all you can talk about is money and fairytales of eternal economic growth.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>HB 1100 is, essentially, an extension of the $1.6 billion tax break the legislature gave Shell to build the ethane cracker plant in Beaver County. Offered to any company that invests $1 billion to construct facilities that utilize Pennsylvania fracked gas, the Department of Revenue estimates that the credit is worth an average of <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us/WU01/LI/BI/FN/2019/0/HB1100P1593.pdf"">$26.5 million annually per facility</a> through 2050.</p>

<p>This means the taxpayer subsidy could total $795 million dollars per facility, meaning taxpayers could guarantee developers almost 80 percent of their initial investment in tax breaks&mdash;a major windfall for these projects. And, if they don&rsquo;t have enough tax liability on their own, they are allowed to sell the tax credits to someone else. Since this money doesn&rsquo;t show up as an appropriation in the budget, it&rsquo;s also much less likely that the legislature will revisit the subsidy in the future.</p>

<p><strong>Creating a &ldquo;Solarize PA&rdquo; Tax Credit to support Utility-Scale Solar Projects</strong></p>

<p>What would happen if our Legislature took Thunberg seriously and actually tried to develop new, clean energy sources like utility scale solar?</p>

<p>We have <a href=""http://www.depgreenport.state.pa.us/elibrary/GetDocument?docId=1413595&amp;DocName=PENNSYLVANIA%26%2339%3bS%20SOLAR%20FUTURE%20PLAN.PDF%20%20%3cspan%20style%3D%22color:blue%3b%22%3e%28NEW%29%3c/span%3e"">vast potential for developing projects</a> here in Pennsylvania, and we are seeing some growth, but our weak Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards (0.5% solar by 2021) have made it far more attractive for companies to build projects in other states. That&rsquo;s why New York, New Jersey, Maryland, Massachusetts, and Connecticut all have <a href=""https://seia.org/states-map"">much more solar generation</a> than we do.&nbsp;</p>

<p>When Brent Alderfer, CEO of Community Energy, <a href=""https://consumer.pasenategop.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/51/2019/05/alderfer-slides.pdf"">testified before the Pennsylvania Senate </a>in May, he said that utility-scale solar was already below one dollar per watt and the prices are expected to continue to fall. Based on a calculator <a href=""https://pvwatts.nrel.gov/pvwatts.php"">provided by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory</a>, each $1 billion investment at today&rsquo;s prices could build about a gigawatt of solar and generate more than 1.3 million MWh of clean energy per year. That is enough energy to power more than 130,000 Pennsylvania homes.</p>

<p>HB1100 could be redesigned to give the same magnitude of transferable tax credit to solar companies that it currently gives polluters, but without the negative climate and environmental impact. A $26.5 million dollar transferable tax credit per billion dollars of private investment in utility scale solar would equate to almost $20 per megawatt-hour. That would, in effect, be similar to raising the Solar Alternative Energy Credit (also called SREC) price around $20 without directly impacting consumers&rsquo; electric bills. This would encourage a boom of new private investment dollars into the state and significant growth in solar jobs.</p>

<p>The impact on Pennsylvania&rsquo;s climate goals would also be significant. If that new clean energy generation replaces natural gas generation, we would save over half a million tons of carbon pollution per year. Assuming a social cost of carbon of <a href=""https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5321009/"">$31.2 per ton of CO2 emissions</a>, the carbon reductions alone would have an annual value of more than $31 million dollars&mdash;more than the direct cost of the tax break itself.</p>

<p>A transferable tax credit for utility scale solar would also produce more homegrown jobs. Penn State University <a href=""https://www.lightsourcebp.com/us/penn-state-solar-project/"">recently signed a contract</a>&nbsp;with Lightsource BP to build a 70MW facility. That is, to date, the largest single project in Pennsylvania and it is designed to generate half of Penn State&rsquo;s annual energy demand. That project is projected to result in an additional 250 local jobs. Using that same job-creation rate, a gigawatt of solar projects would create over 3,500 jobs&mdash;three and a half times what HB1100 requires to qualify for the subsidy.</p>

<p>Furthermore, building more solar generation would provide much needed diversity in Pennsylvania&rsquo;s energy grid. Right now most of our generation comes from a mix of nuclear, gas, and coal, but the nuclear and coal plants are rapidly approaching retirement. If we continue to subsidize the gas industry, we will get what we pay for and gas will dominate our electric grid. Having all of our eggs in that basket is a recipe for volatile prices and even blackouts.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Choice Between Two Futures</strong></p>

<p>What has been stunning about HB 1100 is how little the legislature has debated its efficacy, given how significant a decision it is. Pennsylvania is at a fork in the road&mdash;we can invest in the industries, like solar, that are rapidly growing, future proof, and protective of our environment or we can invest in the industries of yesteryear, with an uncertain future, and harsh polluting realities. There is a better vision for Pennsylvania&mdash;let&rsquo;s turn the 20 percent tax break for polluters into an investment in an industry of the future like utility scale solar. Let&rsquo;s&nbsp; &ldquo;Solarize&rdquo; Pennsylvania instead of &ldquo;Fossilizing&rdquo; it.</p>
",Climate; Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
Fracking Across Property Lines: Briggs v. Southwestern Energy Production Company,9/13/2019,"<p>Multiyear litigation over unconventional oil and gas development&mdash;specifically, hydraulic fracturing or &ldquo;fracking&rdquo;&mdash;has caused a stir in Pennsylvania courts regarding the interpretation of a long-standing property law rule.</p>

<p>Established in the late 1800s, the &ldquo;rule of capture&rdquo; considers subsurface oil and gas owned only when it is &ldquo;captured&rdquo; or produced from a well. The rule was originally born out of necessity due to the fugitive nature of oil and gas and the complex relationship between neighboring landowners regarding the ownership of shared subsurface oil and gas deposits.</p>

<p>Traditionally, the rule of capture protected the right of property owners to use their land for oil and gas exploration. However, fracking companies have abused the rule, essentially assuming it allowed them to drill a well on its leased property, tap subsurface oil and gas from adjoining properties, and be absolved from legal liability. This legal exploit is exactly how Texas-based Southwestern Energy Company (SWN) extracted natural gas from the Briggs family property in northeast Pennsylvania, and the family argues that this practice constitutes an illegal trespass onto their property.</p>

<p>Stemming from the family&#39;s 2015 complaint, the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania must now decide whether the rule of capture extends to fracking. In 2017, the trial court extended the meaning of the rule to encompass fracking practices. The trial court&rsquo;s decision effectively halted the Briggses&rsquo; trespass action. On appeal in 2018, the Superior Court reversed the lower court&rsquo;s decision, stating that SWN could be held liable for damages in trespass. The Superior Court refused to recognize the rule of capture as a defense to trespass related to fracking because of the intrusive nature of fracking. SWN appealed the Superior Court&rsquo;s decision, and the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania granted its petition on November 20, 2018.</p>

<p>On Sept. 12, lawyers from both sides argued the following issue in front of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania:</p>

<p>&ldquo;Does the rule of capture apply to oil and gas produced from wells that were completed using hydraulic fracturing and preclude trespass liability for allegedly draining oil or gas from under nearby property, where the well is drilled solely on and beneath the driller&rsquo;s own property and the hydraulic fracturing fluids are injected solely on or beneath the driller&rsquo;s own property?&rdquo;</p>

<p>Attorney Robert L. Byer pleaded SWN&rsquo;s case first in front of the Court, and his argument relied heavily on long standing precedent recognizing the rule of capture as precluding trespass liability. When questioned why the injection of fracking proppants (the solid material used to keep fractures open) on to a neighbor&rsquo;s property should not be considered a trespass, Byer deferred to the uncertainty involved in the fracking process.</p>

<p>He stated that the technology does not exist to sufficiently prove that SWN&rsquo;s proppants crossed the property line, entering the Briggs&#39; land. Furthermore, when asked to distinguish this practice from slant drilling, which the rule of capture does not absolve trespass liability, Byer stated that slant drilling violates the rule of capture because the driller physically and consciously crossed on to the neighbor&rsquo;s property. Byer concluded that the state Legislature is more fit to solve this issue rather than a &ldquo;retroactive&rdquo; judicial decision.<span baskerville="""" bell="""" class=""qowt-font2-TimesNewRoman"" font-size:="""" id=""E330"" is=""qowt-word-run"" new="""" old="""" qowt-eid=""E330"" serif="""" style=""display: inline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: "" times=""""></span></p>

<p>Conversely, Laurence M. Kelly, the Briggs&#39; attorney, advocated that the rule of capture does not preclude trespass related to fracking activities. Kelly compared the invasive nature of injecting proppants into a neighboring subsurface to the drill bit used in illegal slant drilling practices. He asserted that SWN consciously and physically injected proppants into the Briggs&rsquo; subsurface property, continuously leaching fuel from their land without consent.</p>

<p>We think this is an important case to watch because if the Court decides in SWN&rsquo;s favor, there could be negative implications for Pennsylvania landowners with subsurface gas and oil at their property&rsquo;s boundary. Oil companies like SWN could shop around, establish a lease with one landowner at the cheapest price, tap the communal oil, and owe no royalties to the neighbor. Contrary to SWN&rsquo;s argument, this will create negative economic impacts as neighboring landowners could be forced into a race to the bottom to establish a lease in order to capitalize on oil beneath their land.</p>

<p>Furthermore, such an interpretation of the rule will necessarily strip the non-leasing landowner of any legal recourse. As the fracking boom continues in many areas of Pennsylvania, the Court&rsquo;s upcoming decision may help to clarify the interplay between the rule of capture and fracking across property lines.<span baskerville="""" bell="""" class=""qowt-font2-TimesNewRoman"" font-size:="""" is=""qowt-word-run"" new="""" old="""" qowt-eid=""E330"" serif="""" style=""display: inline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: "" times=""""></span></p>
",Energy,"Kody Hines, Legal Intern"
Philadelphia Energy Solutions' Failures,9/10/2019,"<p>In late August, I traveled to South Philadelphia to testify before Philadelphia&#39;s <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/programs/refinery-advisory-group/"">Refinery Advisory Group</a>, which was formed by Mayor Jim Kenney to consider how the closure of the Philadelphia Energy Solutions refinery will affect the city&rsquo;s economy, environment, public health and safety.</p>

<p>My message was simple: dumping money into the petrochemical industry is a dead end for Pennsylvania and we need a better and more sustainable pathway for our future.</p>

<p>Originally owned and operated by Sunoco, the refinery by 2012 was in financial trouble and needed more capital to continue operations. The Carlyle Group put up $175 million and ended up with a two-thirds share of the new company&mdash;PES&mdash;as well as operational control of the 1,300 acre facility. Sunoco, in a separate deal, merged with Energy Transfer Partners around the same time and that company retained the remaining one-third stake. In spite of this deal, and with another $25 million in grants from Pennsylvania taxpayers along with tax benefits and concessions from environmental regulators, PES remained financially troubled.</p>

<p>Phil Rinaldi, the former chief executive officer of PES, often blames the company&rsquo;s financial difficulties on environmental regulations and, particularly, the ethanol mandate that requires refiners to blend in a certain amount of ethanol or purchase credits, known as RINs. Despite the fact that other refineries are able to meet the standard, PES hasn&rsquo;t actually been buying all the RINs it needs for the past few years and they now owe the Environmental Protection Agency more than $350 million worth of credits.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Apparently it&rsquo;s easier to blame the EPA than admit their failure is largely self-inflicted. In 2013, for example, when crude oil prices were more than $90 a barrel, Rinaldi blew through $186 million on a terminal to transport crude by rail, otherwise known as the <a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/stories/protecting-your-community-crude-oil-bomb-trains"">oil bomb trains</a>. When oil prices collapsed in 2015, that plan quickly became unprofitable.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In spite of the failures, Carlyle and the other owners made sure to secure tidy profits for themselves, <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/philly/business/energy/philadelphia-energy-solutions-files-bankruptcy-plan-20180122.html"">taking more than $400 million in dividends</a> from PES, more than half of which was financed through <a href=""https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biofuels-pes-bankruptcy-insight/refiner-goes-belly-up-after-big-payouts-to-carlyle-group-idUSKCN1G40I1"">debt against the refinery.</a> As a result, even after emerging from bankruptcy reorganization in August 2018, it seemed likely that PES was again <a href=""https://kleinmanenergy.upenn.edu/paper/beyond-bankruptcy"">heading for bankruptcy</a>. When a massive explosion shook the refinery on June 21, that became a reality sooner than expected as PES decided to cease operations and once-again <a href=""https://www.reuters.com/article/us-pes-bankruptcy/philadelphia-energy-solutions-files-for-bankruptcy-after-refinery-fire-idUSKCN1UH0O9"">filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection</a>.</p>

<p>PES is now attempting to restructure its debt and reorganize, and Phil Rinaldi is back in the picture once again attempting to get another bailout for the facility. Aside from restarting the facility, this time he also proposes to build a digester to create methane gas from the city&rsquo;s food waste, but that greenwashing is not only too little and too late to cover up the failures of the past, it doesn&rsquo;t begin to offset the continued pollution from the plant. The petrochemical industry isn&rsquo;t the economic savior it&rsquo;s made out to be, but that is apparently a hard lesson to learn.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>We Must Act on Climate</strong></p>

<p>Last October, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change released <a href=""https://www.ipcc.ch/2018/10/08/summary-for-policymakers-of-ipcc-special-report-on-global-warming-of-1-5c-approved-by-governments/"">a special report</a> finding that to have a reasonable chance at keeping global warming below 1.5 &deg;C we will need to reduce emissions by 45 percent from 2010 to 2030 and reach net-zero emissions by 2050.</p>

<p>That recommendation is significantly more aggressive than the one put forth under the Paris Agreement, which calls for a 26 to 28 percent reduction in emissions from 2005 to 2030. It is also bolder than the path put forth by Pennsylvania Governor Tom Wolf, who proposed meeting the Paris Agreement goal and then reaching an 80 percent reduction by 2050.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Philadelphia has responded with its <a href=""https://www.phila.gov/documents/powering-our-future-a-clean-energy-vision-for-philadelphia/"">Clean Energy Vision</a> and is attempting to shift electricity consumption to 100 percent renewable generation by 2050. City leaders are also taking other positive steps such as planning to convert the city&rsquo;s street lights to more efficient LEDs. But, pollution from our electric grid is just one piece of a larger problem. We need to come to terms with our overreliance on dirty fossil fuels.</p>

<p>The gas industry often claims that carbon pollution has declined as natural gas generation has replaced coal on our power grid, but these claims overlook the fact that those reductions are not sustainable. As recently as 2004, Pennsylvania had 90 percent of its generation coming from either nuclear or coal and 5 percent coming from gas. By 2017, Pennsylvania had 34 percent of our generation coming from gas. With 27 percent of our nuclear capacity scheduled to go offline in the next two years, coupled with sharply declining coal generation, gas could easily become 70 percent or more of our generation. That scenario would be a climate killer, and it doesn&rsquo;t even consider the gas used outside of generation in facilities like the Philadelphia Energy Solutions facility.</p>

<p><strong>Attempting to Restart Operations is a Dangerous and Unsustainable Pathway</strong></p>

<p>When we dump money into the petrochemical industry we are buying additional problems that will need to be fixed&mdash;possibly at great expense to taxpayers&mdash;in a few short years. Often, as in the case of PES, this goes beyond carbon pollution. The refinery was the <a href=""https://iaspub.epa.gov/triexplorer/tri_release.facility"">largest source of toxic air emissions</a> in southeast Pennsylvania and has also been a significant emitter of ozone-forming volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and oxides of nitrogen (NOx) as well as particulate emissions.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>As is common with petrochemical plants, even with the facility closed the environmental problems don&rsquo;t go away. There are 1,300 acres of heavily contaminated soil and groundwater that must be remediated, but also ongoing air pollution. PES will likely be able to register the reductions in VOC, NOx, PM-10, and PM-2.5 emissions from its closure as Emission Reduction Credits (ERCs) with the Pennsylvania DEP. These credits have a 10-year shelf life and can then be purchased by other entities who want to increase emissions. Delaying closure of this plant could mean more pollution for years.</p>

<p>Moreover, the remediation of PES should not be delayed. The site is already at a heightened risk for flooding during severe weather events and, at the rates of sea-level rise predicted by the IPCC, areas of the site could be underwater before 2050 and most of the site could be flooded before 2100. The more we wait, the more we risk of additional catastrophic events that will result in much higher remediation costs.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>We Need To Focus on Building Sustainable Industries and Jobs</strong></p>

<p>If we are going to reach our climate goals, and if we are going to address the chronic air pollution impacting the residents of the region, the city needs to transition away from fossil fuels to more sustainable industries. In the near term, we need skilled workers to assist with the closure and remediation of the site, but we also need a long term plan. We see this vividly in the coal and nuclear industries where plants are reaching the end of their useful life and no new plants are being built to replace them. Those jobs are going away and, for the most part, there has been little thought given to the transition of the workforce.</p>

<p>While relatively low fuel prices and considerable subsidies makes gas and other petrochemicals inexpensive, the industry suffers from the same fundamental problem. Fossil fuel prices have always been volatile and prices are likely to rise. Clean renewable alternatives, on the other hand,&nbsp; are already cost-competitive in many areas and prices continue to fall. Subsidizing fundamentally unsustainable industries like petrochemicals isn&rsquo;t the path to long-term job growth, it actually creates more at-risk workers.</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s not surprising that when the Bureau of Labor Statistics projected the <a href=""https://www.bls.gov/ooh/home.htm"">top 20 fastest growing job sectors from 2016 to 2026</a>, solar installers and wind turbine service technicians topped the list with 105 percent and 96 percent growth respectively while no petrochemical jobs made that list. We see similar results in Pennsylvania where a recent report from the National Association of State Energy Officials showed that solar alone already accounts for well over 4,000 jobs in Pennsylvania with much less than one percent of our generation.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>While the future is in green jobs, a number of fossil fuel jobs will continue to be necessary, particularly for the safe closure and remediation of retiring facilities. Unfortunately PES recently announced layoffs of almost almost 400 union workers, including maintenance workers and operators. This raises significant concerns that there will be a lack of qualified staff to safely wind down operations.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>A Pathway Forward</strong></p>

<p>Recently, more than 300 stakeholders came together with the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection on a project called &ldquo;<a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/PASolarFuture/plan"">Finding Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Solar Future</a>&rdquo; to identify 15 key strategies and 52 separate action items that could significantly enhance clean renewable energy deployment in the Commonwealth.</p>

<p>One key ask of the stakeholders was to support the creation and adoption of uniform policies to streamline siting and land-use issues while encouraging conservation.&nbsp; In certain cases, co-locating solar resources with agricultural operations may be beneficial, but often we are seeking to preserve prime agricultural and forest land and encourage solar on less valuable property, including former industrial sites. We&rsquo;ve seen this used across the border in New Jersey where PSE&amp;G reported that landfill and brownfield solar sites were about 40 percent less expensive than typical residential installations.</p>

<p>While direct policy intervention to encourage renewable development on brownfields is a possibility, programs could also indirectly encourage development on brownfields by easing access to capital. Some programs, like expanding our Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards or Enabling community solar in Pennsylvania, will take state action, but Philadelphia could take action on its own in a number of different forms such as:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Expanding the availability of solar lending products through a green bank.</li>
	<li>Lowering interest rates through loan loss reserves.</li>
	<li>Easing third-party financing decisions by entering into long-term contracts for solar energy from new facilities on brownfields.</li>
</ul>

<p>These are just a few of the action items identified, but even if it is not an exhaustive list, the stakeholder project has clearly shown that there is considerable interest in these policies and a significant amount of expertise in the region ready to assist in their further development. With the closure of PES, the city has an opportunity to leverage this work to rapidly expand its sustainable development. We encourage the city to do so.</p>
",Climate; Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"

This is a time of year when everyone talks about the swift passage of time as our short summers begin to transition to autumn. I fully appreciate the imminent arrival of the holiday season and, with it, the turning of our calendars to 2020.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Between now and then, our state legislators will reconvene for a final six-week push before this legislative session ends. This will be another chance for our state&rsquo;s elected officials to do the business of the people&nbsp;and to do what is needed for our environment and climate.</p>

<p>With the arrival of a new season comes new priorities. PennFuture will be working to shape important proposals to preserve our nuclear fleet as a hedge against climate pollution, and there has been talk about fees on carbon pollution that we are keenly interested in. Will our legislature find a path forward to help pay for the myriad of voluntary measures encompassed in the Phase 3 Watershed Implementation Plan for the Chesapeake Bay, which can result in dramatic improvements in our local streams and rivers?&nbsp; This can only happen if our legislators grasp the dire need for dedicated funding for clean water and find a revenue source for it.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We typically see a flurry of legislation at the end of the session. The need for action in Harrisburg this fall and this session feels particularly important. I&rsquo;m concerned that once we cross into 2020, all attention will turn to the national election. Activists, advocates, politicians, donors, voters&nbsp; &ndash; appropriately &ndash; will be laser focused on the outcomes in early primary states, the nominating conventions, campaigns and the election for the next president.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>When PennFuture formed its strategic alliance with Conservation Voters of Pennsylvania, it created capacity for PennFuture to launch a civic engagement program. This program is marked by our on-the-ground community organizing; growing our ACE (Advocates for Conservation and Education) teams that&nbsp;play a role in educating their elected officials on important issues; and elevating non-partisan campaign conversations about environmental issues among all candidates for public office. You might recall hearing about our Common Agenda for Conservation during the last gubernatorial campaign.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As a 501 (c) (3) organization, PennFuture is strictly prohibited from engaging in political activity, endorsements and elections. However, the IRS does grant latitude in the role we can play in reaching a segment of the population known as the New American Majority, also referred to as the Rising American Electorate. This segment is defined by individuals of color, single women and millennials. The IRS allows us to do non-partisan voter registration in places where these demographics are prevalent, but where there are substantial gaps in their voting registrations.&nbsp;PennFuture hopes to begin voter registration work in early 2020. We also hope to do &ldquo;Get Out the Vote&rdquo; work closer to the 2020 general election.</p>

<p>Many of the national environmental groups are focusing on Pennsylvania in 2020, and it&rsquo;s no surprise that others of all stripes will be politically engaged here.</p>

<p>The other momentous event upcoming in 2020 is the 50th anniversary of Earth Day on April 22. Commemorations of Earth Day 1970 cannot be nostalgic events. We must show up, speak up and unequivocally and unapologetically acknowledge the vicious attacks on our environment, communities and public health that have taken place in recent years, and use this Earth Day to create change.&nbsp;</p>

<p>On Earth Day, we must make welcome all and elevate the energy of our climate youth, their families and the front line communities confronted still with the realities of pollution and a dystopian climate future if we do not act and create change in 2020. PennFuture hopes to provide many opportunities for you to join us for Earth Day 2020 action in the coming months.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Regardless, work remains to close out 2019, and we&rsquo;ll be sure to keep fighting for our shared environment in Harrisburg and all across Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>
",Community; Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
Tohickon Creek Is Saved...For Now,8/28/2019,"<p>The lower Tohickon Creek, located immediately downstream of the dam at Lake Nockamixon, was designated&nbsp;as part of the Lower Delaware National Wild and Scenic River in 2000. Located in Bucks County, the Tohickon flows through protected lands like&nbsp;Ralph Stover State Park and provides some of the best recreational opportunities in the area, especially for seasonal whitewater enthusiasts.</p>

<p>Almost 25 years ago, the Tinicum Conservancy petitioned to have the lower Tohickon Creek redesignated to an &ldquo;Exceptional Value&rdquo;&nbsp;stream to recognize and protect its outstanding water quality. The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection is the agency tasked with reviewing the petition. Unfortunately, DEP&rsquo;s initial recommendation was to downgrade the lower Tohickon&rsquo;s designated use in 1997. In response and since that time, Tinicum Conservancy, Delaware Riverkeeper Network&nbsp;and others have repeatedly given DEP numerous data, reports, and information supporting the petition for EV designation. Despite these efforts, earlier this year, DEP issued&nbsp;<a href=""http://files.dep.state.pa.us/Water/Drinking Water and Facility Regulation/WaterQualityPortalFiles/Stream_Packages/Tunkhannock_Creek/Tohickon Creek Draft Report.pdf"">another draft redesignation recommendation</a> which again proposed to downgrade the protections for the creek.</p>

<p>A quick primer on stream designations: In Pennsylvania,&nbsp;surface water is given a &ldquo;designated use&rdquo; which is established based on the ecological and human health uses of a particular waterbody. A designated use is the water quality goal set by the state, whether or not that use is actually being attained. In the case of the lower Tohickon, it is currently designated as a &ldquo;Cold Water Fishes&rdquo; waterbody.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s <a href=""https://www.pacode.com/secure/data/025/chapter93/chap93toc.html"">Water Quality Standards require</a> that the designated uses of each waterbody be protected. Any person can petition the state to change the designated use of a waterbody, based on biological, chemical, or physical characteristics of the water. The 1995 redesignation petition sought for the lower Tohickon&rsquo;s designated use to be changed to Exceptional Value, the most protective of the designated uses. The DEP, however, proposed to change the lower Tohickon to &ldquo;Trout Stocking Fishery,&rdquo; which requires less stringent protections than a &ldquo;Cold Water Fishes&rdquo; designation. For more on the redesignation process, please view&nbsp;<a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Files/News/PennFutureStreamHndbk09.pdf"">PennFuture&rsquo;s Stream Redesignation Handbook</a>.</p>

<p>PennFuture &ndash; along with over 60 of our members and supporters &ndash; stood up for the lower Tohickon and told DEP not to downgrade or remove critical protections for the creek. As PennFuture <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-PennFuture-strongly-opposes-any-attempts-to-downgrade-status-of-the-Tohickon-Creek"">pointed out in our letter</a>, a downgrade of the lower Tohickon is not supported by the data and is an inappropriate action for the DEP to take.</p>

<p>The good news: In response to this public outcry, DEP stated that it has agreed to undertake further analysis of the Lake Nockamixon Dam to see how operational or infrastructural changes could affect its analysis.</p>

<p>We are very pleased that DEP has pulled back from its faulty analysis and has stated its commitment to a thorough analysis of the lower Tohickon Creek. But&nbsp;if history is any indication, we know that the battle over the lower Tohickon may not be over yet. PennFuture will continue to monitor DEP&rsquo;s analysis and ensure the appropriate protections are in place for Tohickon Creek.</p>

<p>We have to be vigilant to protect the lower Tohickon Creek &ndash; and all the waters of the Commonwealth &ndash; not only from pollution, but from regulatory rollbacks that threaten to remove protections and degrade our waters.</p>

<p><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/donate"">Become a PennFuture member today</a> and support our work on protecting our constitutional right to clean water.</p>
",Community; Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Pennsylvania still not doing its part to restore the Chesapeake Bay,8/26/2019,"<p>When the Environmental Protection Agency developed a Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) for the Chesapeake Bay in 2010, it marked a historic cleanup effort to restore one of our nation&rsquo;s most precious treasures.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Bay TMDL identifies the total amount of certain pollutants (nitrogen, phosphorus, and sediment) that the entire Chesapeake Bay Watershed &mdash; including portions of Pennsylvania &mdash; can contribute, but still be able to restore water quality in the Bay to a level that will support protected water uses, like swimming and fishing. To ensure pollutant reductions are achieved, the Bay TMDL establishes deadlines for the states to develop and implement plans within the watershed to reduce these pollutants.</p>

<p>Each State&rsquo;s proposal to accomplish these reductions must be articulated in their respective plans, called Watershed Implementation Plans (WIPs), in order to provide &ldquo;reasonable assurance&rdquo; that the required reductions in pollution will be achieved, EPA is responsible for evaluating whether the plans are sufficient.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s contributions to the Chesapeake Bay cleanup is incredibly important. Approximately half of the land area of Pennsylvania drains to the Chesapeake Bay, and Pennsylvania comprises 35 percent of the entire Chesapeake Bay Watershed. The Susquehanna River is by far the largest tributary to the Bay, providing 90 percent of the freshwater flow to the upper Bay and half of the total freshwater that enters the Bay. Without Pennsylvania getting its act together, the Chesapeake Bay Watershed has little hope of being restored.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Since even before the Bay TMDL&rsquo;s implementation, PennFuture has worked to support efforts to reduce pollution to the Susquehanna River. When agricultural interests initially challenged the Bay TMDL in federal court, PennFuture intervened to support EPA. We have lobbied in Harrisburg for funding for pollution reduction programs and pressed for robust water quality protections in permits and agency programs.</p>

<p>PennFuture serves as the Pennsylvania state lead for the Choose Clean Water Coalition, which harnesses the collective power of more than 230 groups to advocate for clean rivers and streams in the Chesapeake Bay region. Most recently our President &amp; CEO, Jacqui Bonomo, served on the Forestry Workgroup of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s third WIP Steering Committee, which provided feedback and input on industry best management practices.</p>

<p>However, even with all of these efforts, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s waters and the Chesapeake Bay remain polluted. Over the years of implementing the Bay TMDL, Pennsylvania has consistently fallen short. During EPA&rsquo;s midpoint assessment, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s agriculture and urban/suburban sectors were at the &ldquo;backstop action level,&rdquo; meaning that EPA identified substantial concerns with the strategy to implement the TMDL goals and had taken necessary federal actions to get Pennsylvania back on track. Unfortunately, these efforts seem to have been to little avail as Pennsylvania&rsquo;s third WIP remains woefully insufficient.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s third WIP provides little assurance that the state will achieve the required pollution reduction goals. It doesn&rsquo;t even set forth a plan that, if fully implemented, would achieve the goals. There is little accountability built into the plan, and Pennsylvania faces a huge gap in necessary funding to be able to even implement this deficient plan, let alone the measures necessary to actually reduce pollution.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>As Pennsylvania submits its deficient WIP3 to EPA for its review and approval, it faces threats of liability. Since the Plan clearly does not provide the necessary &ldquo;reasonable assurances&rdquo; that reduction targets will be approved, EPA can not legitimately approve the plan. Other states are also displeased with Pennsylvania&rsquo;s lack of progress. Maryland&rsquo;s Governor Larry Hogan <a href=""https://governor.maryland.gov/2019/05/29/governor-hogan-voices-concerns-over-pennsylvania-clean-water-progress/"">even sent a letter to Governor Wolf</a> expressing his deep concern that Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Plan falls short of its critical commitment. And a recent editorial suggested that a lawsuit could be the way to put Pennsylvania back on track. Each of these threats would cost Pennsylvania. The Pennsylvania legislature should fund programs that reduce pollution to our rivers and streams to ensure that it doesn&rsquo;t incur even more expenses by failing to do what is necessary.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/20190607-PF-WIP3-comments.pdf"">recently submitted public comments</a> on Pennsylvania&rsquo;s draft WIP3 commending the Department of Environmental Protection on the stakeholder engagement deployed in the development of the WIP, but critiquing the Plan&rsquo;s significant shortfalls such as its failure to design to meet the minimum necessary reductions of nitrogen, articulate an accountability structure, or ensure the funding necessary to meet even its marginal reductions.&nbsp;For these reasons, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s WIP3 does not provide the necessary &ldquo;reasonable assurance&rdquo; that the required reductions in pollution will be achieved. Even with the modifications the Department has made since the public comment period ended, we do not believe Pennsylvania&rsquo;s WIP3 satisfies the required standard to be approved by the EPA.</p>

<p>However, as Pennsylvania continues to lag behind the other states, it is important that some progress begins to be made. In light of this, we hope a path can be created that directs Pennsylvania to immediately implement critical elements in its WIP3 while the Department works on addressing the significant deficiencies and shortfalls in its Plan.</p>

<p>We will continue to work with Pennsylvania state agencies to implement pollution reduction measures, advocate to the legislature to support funding to implement important practices, and monitor those that contribute pollution for compliance with the law and opportunities to go further.</p>

<p>If you like our efforts to support a robust Chesapeake Bay cleanup in Pennsylvania, please consider <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/donate"">donating to PennFuture</a>!</p>
",Environment,"Taylor Nezat, Campaign Manager for Watershed Advocacy, PennFuture"
Running for a Reason,8/21/2019,"<p>How far are you willing to go to prove a point?&nbsp;</p>

<p>For Sam Bencheghib, it&rsquo;s about 3,100 miles, or roughly the distance between New York and Los Angeles. All on foot, in the span of 160 days, running on shoes made from recycled plastics.&nbsp;</p>

<p>That last part is important, because it underscores the purpose of every step of his journey. Sam Bencheghib is running across America to raise awareness about the massive amounts of plastic currently polluting our oceans and waterways.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Sam, who recently met with PennFuture employees in Pittsburgh and Harrisburg, doesn&rsquo;t mince words when explaining the importance of his run. By 2050, there will be more plastic in our oceans than fish. There are already more microplastics in our oceans and on our beaches than stars in our galaxy, he said.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The problems posed by plastic pollution are massive, yet the issue isn&rsquo;t being addressed on a global scale by governments and corporations. That doesn&rsquo;t deter Sam from his journey, though. In fact, it only makes him more motivated to raise awareness.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;Sometimes you have to do something crazy to get people&#39;s&nbsp;attention,&rdquo; he said.&nbsp;</p>

<p>His journey started on July 26 in New York City, and it didn&rsquo;t take long to pass over into New Jersey and Pennsylvania. From there, his path will take him through West Virginia, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Missouri, Kansas, Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Nevada and California. He hopes to arrive near Los Angeles on Dec. 20.</p>

<p>To put it into perspective, Sam will be running the equivalent of about 115 marathons in a span of about 160 days, with a goal of running between 20 to 30 miles per day. He will stop to rest only on the weekends and usually only in bigger cities, where he intends on meeting with and speaking to college students, environmental organizations and local politicians about the need to address the plastics pollution epidemic.&nbsp;</p>

<p>That&rsquo;s exactly what he did in Pennsylvania, meeting with local politicians and community activists. Sam said his goal is to get people on board with his message, but it&rsquo;s been a challenge in Pennsylvania because of a <a href=""https://www.pennlive.com/news/2019/06/pa-blocks-plastic-bag-bans-for-at-least-a-year.html"">recently passed moratorium</a> on plastic bag bans.&nbsp;</p>

<p>That so-called &ldquo;ban on bans&rdquo; was enacted as part of budget discussions in Harrisburg in June, and bars local municipalities and cities from banning plastic bags for at least a year.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;In Pennsylvania, it&rsquo;s been a lot harder than I thought it would be,&rdquo; Sam said about creating awareness and momentum for his movement.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The difficulties found within Pennsylvania won&rsquo;t derail his message, Sam said. After all, fighting against plastic pollution has been a passion of his since he was a young boy on the Indonesian island of Bali.&nbsp;</p>

<p>During his childhood, Sam and his older brother would clean up beaches in Bali, completely removing any traces of plastic. It wouldn&rsquo;t even take 24 hours before the beaches would be full of plastic again, a product of local streams and rivers carrying the pollution into the ocean and onto the beaches.</p>

<p>&ldquo;I felt we were making a difference but, realistically, were we really making a difference?&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;That&rsquo;s when we decided to focus on rivers and streams and educating local government and businesses.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>From that experience came a new organization founded by Sam and his brother called &ldquo;<a href=""https://makeachange.world/"">Make a Change World</a>.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Sam, who is 22 years old, brought his message and ambition to America when he enrolled at Lehigh University in eastern Pennsylvania. Recently graduated, Sam knew there would be no better time to spread a message that desperately needs to be heard.&nbsp;</p>

<p>During the cross-country run, he will be accompanied by friend Josh Madre, who follows behind Sam in an RV and documents the journey with a video camera. The entire journey can be tracked on the organization&rsquo;s website at <a href=""https://makeachange.world/"">https://makeachange.world</a>.</p>

<p>For his part, Sam understands the daunting task ahead of him, both in running across the vast expanse of America, and in trying to combat a problem in plastics pollution that is already at a crisis level. But he isn&rsquo;t deterred, either in body or spirit, because he knows he will bring about change.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;I wouldn&rsquo;t be doing this if I didn&rsquo;t think it would make a difference,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;Every step I take across this country is one step closer to a world without plastic pollution.&quot;</p>
",,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
"Before You Leap, Learn About Your Water Quality",8/19/2019,"<p>During the dog days of summer, a bend in a river might provide the perfect reprieve from the heat.</p>

<p>But with recent articles about <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/12/us/blue-green-algae-dogs.html"">dangerous algal blooms</a>&nbsp;and the complicated answer to the <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/science/climate/delaware-schuylkill-river-swim-philadelphia-pollution-20190815.html"">safety of swimming in the Delaware or Schuylkill rivers</a> near Philadelphia, it is important to know about the quality of the water you&#39;re about to dive&nbsp;into. Is there a sewage treatment plant upstream that regularly violates its discharge permit? Are legacy pollutants, like Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) from industry that has long ago moved on, still present?&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>A good place to learn about the water quality in your local stream, river, or lake is the <a href=""https://www.depgis.state.pa.us/2018_integrated_report/index.html"">Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection&#39;s Integrated Water Quality Report</a>. This report, which the&nbsp;federal Clean Water Act requires the state to prepare every other year, provides information about the water quality of every waterbody in the state. The report also lists what uses&nbsp;<span style=""font-family:"">&mdash; such as recreation or drinking water&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-family:"">&mdash;</span>&nbsp;it has been assessed for, whether or not each use is impaired, and&nbsp;if so, the state&rsquo;s prioritization of creating a restoration plan.</p>

<p>PennFuture <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/News/20190603-PF-2018-Integrated-Report-comments.pdf"">recently submitted comments</a>&nbsp;on this report, taking a deep dive into the policy decisions of how certain waters are listed that will impact the waters&rsquo; uses moving forward. But the report, which has been revamped to present important information in map form, can provide helpful insights about your local water&nbsp;hole too.</p>

<p>As you head out for a swim to cool off this summer, take a minute to learn about the water you are jumping into.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Community; Environment,"Alice R. Baker, Senior Staff Attorney"
The Problem with Pipelines,8/5/2019,"<p>The burgeoning petrochemical movement is in its infancy in western Pennsylvania, but we&rsquo;ve already experienced significant detriments to both the environment and private property because of fracking and pipeline accidents.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Take a look at the recent track record of Texas-based Energy Transfer Partners. Maybe you&rsquo;ve never heard of the company, but you&rsquo;ve almost certainly heard about its pipeline projects.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Dakota Access Pipeline, which was so controversial that <a href=""https://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/dakota-pipeline-protests/north-dakota-governor-orders-pipeline-protesters-leave-citing-winter-weather-n689366"">thousands of people staged a sit-in protest</a> over environmental concerns. The Mariner East 2 pipeline &mdash; constructed by Sunoco, which is a subsidiary of Energy Transfer &mdash; which was beset by so many spills, sinkholes, and shutdowns that Attorney General Josh Shapiro <a href=""https://www.pennlive.com/news/2019/03/pa-attorney-general-launches-investigation-into-mariner-east-ii-pipeline.html"">opened a criminal investigation</a> into the project. The Revolution Pipeline in western Pennsylvania, which exploded last September, <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2018/09/10/natural-gas-pipeline-blast-in-beaver-county-prompts-evacuation/"">destroying one house and damaging another</a> while literally shaking an entire community.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Those are just the glaring examples of incompetence. There are others, like the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) assessing a $355,000 penalty against Energy Transfer Partners for <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2018/05/03/dep-hits-sunoco-with-another-fine-for-mariner-east-2-pipeline-construction/"">polluting streams and wetlands</a> across nine Pennsylvania counties. Or another fine from the DEP &mdash; <a href=""https://www.timesonline.com/news/20180827/texas-company-fined-for-damages-to-raccoon-creek-during-pipeline-construction"">to the tune of $150,000</a> &mdash; after polluting a portion of Raccoon Creek in Beaver County last summer.</p>

<p>All told, Energy Transfer <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/Business/ProgramIntegration/Pennsylvania-Pipeline-Portal/Pages/Mariner-East-II.aspx#Compliance"">has been hit with nearly 100 violations</a> &mdash; the most recent coming on July 26 &mdash;&nbsp;from the Mariner East project alone, and fines that surpass $13 million.</p>

<p>The list goes on. The situation became so untenable in Pennsylvania that the DEP <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2019/02/08/DEP-halts-permit-review-gas-pipeline-Energy-Transfer-Sunoco-Revolution-Mariner-East-Pennsylvania/stories/201902080125"">suspended all permit reviews</a> for all of Energy Transfer Partners&rsquo; ongoing projects. This, only after the company <a href=""https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2019/05/14/DEP-Energy-Transfer-fix-damage-streams-wetlands-revolution-pipeline-Beaver-permit/stories/201905140158"">failed to abide by a DEP order</a> to resolve issues at the Beaver County explosion site.</p>

<p>As if a criminal investigation from one state agency and permit suspensions from another weren&rsquo;t enough, Gov. Tom Wolf <a href=""https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/governor-wolf-issues-statement-dep-pipeline-permit-bar/"">entered the fray</a> with a damning statement.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;There has been a failure by Energy Transfer and its subsidiaries to respect our laws and our communities,&rdquo; Wolf said in a news release. &ldquo;This is not how we strive to do business in Pennsylvania, and it will not be tolerated.&rdquo;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s a step in the right direction that Gov. Wolf acknowledged the repeated failures of the pipeline industry in Pennsylvania, but is it enough? Evidence suggests otherwise.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Even after the debacles of the Mariner East and Revolution pipelines, the DEP in December <a href=""https://archive.triblive.com/news/state-dep-action-clears-way-for-construction-of-shell-falcon-ethane-pipeline-in-3-counties/"">approved&nbsp;construction of an ethane pipeline</a> that will feed up to 107,000 barrels per day to Royal Dutch Shell&rsquo;s cracker plant in Beaver County.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Based on past experiences, can you guess what&rsquo;s already happened? During construction, Shell&rsquo;s pipeline <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/Business/ProgramIntegration/Pennsylvania-Pipeline-Portal/Pages/Shell.aspx"">incurred four violations from the DEP</a> between April and July alone. The most recent violation on July 22&nbsp;involved the spilling of 500 gallons of drilling fluid, 30 gallons of which impacted&nbsp;Raccoon Creek, the same waterway previously impacted by Energy Transfer Partners.&nbsp;</p>

<p>If you don&rsquo;t want this to be your future, action is required. The fracked gas, pipeline, and plastics manufacturing companies have millions of dollars to throw at public relations, and too often put profits over people.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As Energy Transfer Partners polluted and destroyed Pennsylvania, they experienced <a href=""https://ir.energytransfer.com/news-releases/news-release-details/energy-transfer-reports-fourth-quarter-2018-results-record"">&ldquo;record performance and continued growth&rdquo;</a> in the fourth quarter of 2018. The company hasn&rsquo;t missed a beat and isn&rsquo;t slowed down in the slightest. The pollution it created in Pennsylvania and fines it was assessed are simply a part of&nbsp;doing business. It&rsquo;s a machine that will churn on as long as we let it.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Last month, Energy Transfer <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cs26xnjBXkk"">began running television advertisements</a> across Pennsylvania, showing pristine farmland and rolling hillsides. The narrator of the commercial insists that America&#39;s oil and gas moves through 2.4 million miles of underground pipelines &ldquo;safely.&rdquo; Ask Beaver County residents &mdash;&nbsp;those who <a href=""https://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2018/09/10/center-township-gas-line-explosion-fire/"">saw the fireball</a>, those who were <a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2018/09/10/natural-gas-pipeline-blast-in-beaver-county-prompts-evacuation/"">forced to evacuate</a>, those who could <a href=""https://www.timesonline.com/news/20190111/pipeline-company-buys-properties-near-explosion-site-in-center-twp"">never return home</a> &mdash;&nbsp;how safe pipelines really are.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Does that sound like a company that is remorseful about its actions in Pennsylvania? Does that sound like a company that has any intention of acknowledging the role it plays in destroying our environment? No, it sounds like a company that is bent on throwing money at a public relations disaster until it goes away, only until another pops up. Rinse and repeat.</p>

<p>Don&rsquo;t let this be our future.</p>

<p>PennFuture will continue to fight for a cleaner, healthier, more sustainable future. <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/donate"">Become a PennFuture member today</a> and help us win this battle.</p>
",Community; Energy,"Jared Stonesifer, Director of Media Relations"
PennFuture's Rob Altenburg appointed to DEP committee,7/26/2019,"<p>One of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s foremost experts in air quality issues just got another accolade to add to an already-impressive resume.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Rob Altenburg, the director of the PennFuture Energy Center, has previously been invited to testify before the state legislature, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, and the White House. Now, he&rsquo;s taking his talents back to the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection, the same agency where Rob started his career nearly three decades ago.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Effective July 1st, DEP Secretary Patrick McDonnell appointed Rob to a two-year term on the agency&rsquo;s Air Quality Technical Advisory Committee. In that role, Rob will provide input on regulatory packages and other key proposals from the department&rsquo;s Bureau of Air Quality.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This won&rsquo;t be his first interaction with the DEP. Rob&rsquo;s first environmental job was with the Bureau of Air Quality, working on new rules to implement the 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act.&nbsp;</p>

<p>He focused on calculating and predicting emissions from factories, vehicles, and off-road equipment and was soon working on computer models to predict concentrations of air pollutants. For years, Rob was the primary forecaster for the south central and Lehigh Valley regions of Pennsylvania, deciding if certain days met the parameters for air quality action days.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Rob attended law school in the evenings while working full time and, after graduation, became an executive policy specialist in DEP&rsquo;s policy office. In that role he advised the governor&rsquo;s office and executive staff on a variety of environmental and public health issues and worked to improve public participation in the department&rsquo;s decision-making.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In response to his appointment, Rob said he was happy and proud to be given the chance to give back to the agency that gave him a start in the environmental world.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;I was very happy to hear from Secretary McDonnell that I&rsquo;ve been appointed to serve on the Air Quality Technical Advisory Committee,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;My first environmental job was with the DEP 27 years ago, so I&rsquo;m proud to be able to give something back.&rdquo;</p>

<p>We here at PennFuture applaud Rob, and we can&rsquo;t wait to see his great work continue with the DEP.</p>
