How Climate Change is Affecting Baseball Games Across the Country,7/30/2018,"<p>Recently, the Harrisburg Senators had to cancel its game against the Bowie Baysox in anticipation of the Susquehanna River flooding out City Island. Like many others, I was disappointed because I was looking forward to an evening of cheering on the home team. I was also disappointed because the Senators had planned to host their first ever &ldquo;Go Green&rdquo; night to benefit and promote a number of local environmental organizations, including PennFuture. The Senators are to be applauded for organizing this promotion and I greatly look forward to participating in it next season&mdash;as long as City Island isn&rsquo;t flooded again.</p>

<p>Rainouts have always been a part of baseball, but are we seeing something different? Thanks to climate change, abnormal weather conditions are becoming the new normal. This year&rsquo;s baseball season opened with a record 28 major league games being postponed in April because of weather conditions. Having a ballpark on an island certainly makes the minor league Senators more vulnerable to inclement weather, but what we are experiencing this summer is extreme.</p>

<p>Dr. Michael Mann, Distinguished Professor of Atmospheric Science at Penn State and PennFuture Board Member says, &ldquo;The extreme weather we are seeing this summer around the Northern Hemisphere (i.e. extreme heatwaves, floods, droughts, and wildfires), including the extreme rainfall seen recently here in Pennsylvania, is related to an unusually stationary, highly meandering perturbation in the jet stream. Our work (i.e. this article last year: <a href=""https://www.nature.com/articles/srep45242"">https://www.nature.com/articles/srep45242</a>) shows that this sort of pattern, which has been associated with many of the most extreme, persistent weather events in recent years including the 2003 European heat wave, 2010 Moscow wildfires, 2011 Texas &amp; Oklahoma drought, 2016 Alberta wildfires etc., is becoming more common because of human-caused climate change (and in particular, because of amplified Arctic warming).&rdquo;</p>

<p>Rainouts and flooding are not the only threats to America&rsquo;s oldest pastime. <a href=""http://blog.nwf.org/2018/07/how-will-climate-change-affect-the-future-of-baseball/"">According to a recent report from the National Wildlife Federation</a> the high humidity that much of the country is experiencing is making the balls heavier with moisture, and it is easier to hit a home-run with a heavier ball&mdash;and not just in the Colorado Rockies ballpark where they&rsquo;ve been storing their baseballs in humidors since 2002. For 2018, the MLB has mandated that all teams store their balls in an &ldquo;air conditioned and enclosed room&rdquo; with a sensor to help determine if every team should be required to use humidors.</p>

<p>Another issue affecting baseball, according to NWF, relates not to the balls, but the bats. The invasive Emerald ash borer beetle has killed millions of ash trees since 2002. And ash happens to be one of the most popular woods for making baseball bats. Unfortunately, like games in April and infield hits, the ash bat may become a thing of the past for baseball fans because of climate change.</p>

<p><a href=""https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2018/03/29/poll-most-pennsylvania-voters-say-climate-change-causing-problems-now/"">According to a Franklin &amp; Marshall College/StateImpact Pennsylvania poll this spring</a>, the majority of us in PA believe that climate change is causing problems right now and that the state should be doing more to address it.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Confronting a problem of this magnitude can seem overwhelming. Individually, we all have a voice &ndash; collectively, we have impact. PennFuture amplifies this voice. Recently, we worked with a coalition of 25 unified environmental groups across the state to create the first-ever Pennsylvania Common Conservation Agenda. The Common Agenda is a comprehensive blueprint the next governor can use to address our environmental challenges. It provides the candidates with common sense solutions for the state to move towards a clean energy economy and increase environmental protection for our most vulnerable communities, and just maybe our baseball parks too. <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Updated-Final-Version-of-the-PA-Common-Conservation-Agenda-5.1.18.pdf"">You can read the Common Agenda here&nbsp;while waiting for the rain delay to end.</a></p>
",Climate,"M. Travis DiNicola, Director of Development"
What You Can Do For Your Watershed,7/30/2018,"<p>On Wednesday, July 18, I met with a dedicated group of citizen scientists&nbsp;who gathered to learn more about how to get involved with policy in their watershed. Hosted at the Visitor Center of the Pennypack Ecological Restoration Trust in the Pennypack Preserve, 15 volunteers from watershed organizations throughout the greater Philadelphia area participated, including representatives from the Wissahickon Valley Watershed Association, the Tookany-Tacony/Frankford Watershed Partnership, Pennypack Ecological Restoration Trust, and Friends of Poquessing Watershed.</p>

<p>Citizen scientists play an important role in protecting our waterways. Watershed organizations have recruited and trained volunteers to sample water quality and look for signs of pollution that traditional surveys may have missed. Citizen scientists are trained to identify the most visible signs of pollution, such as debris, water discoloration, odors, surface films and sheens, fish kills, and algal blooms. Volunteers also sample water and test for nutrients, such as phosphorus and chlorine. A volunteer scientist can sometimes be the first line of defense against pollution in our waterways&mdash;seeing the warning signs firsthand and alerting coordinators, emergency responders, and the PA Department of Environmental Protection (PA DEP).</p>

<p><strong>The purpose of the gathering was to explore ways that citizen scientists can transform their data and water testing experiences into policy action and change.&nbsp;</strong>We partnered with Gayle Killam, Deputy Director of Science and Policy at River Network, Lindsay Blanton, Water Programs Coordinator for Wissahickon Valley Watershed Association, and Kevin Roth, Stewardship Assistant for Pennypack Ecological Restoration Trust, to discuss how data and personal stories can make a difference for our waterways through participating at regulatory hearings, commenting on permits, and advocating for stronger legislative protections.</p>

<p><strong>There are many avenues you can take to protect our waterways, too. For instance, when you find pollution in your creek, you can take immediate action by calling the PA DEP &ldquo;Emergencies and Spills Hotline&rdquo; (1-800-541-2050). </strong>When pollution causes a fish kill, for example, your advocacy and knowledge can help raise awareness about it and resolve the problem through stronger regulations and more effective policies.&nbsp;</p>

<p>If you are interested in learning how you can take action in your watershed, contact me at cupo@pennfuture.org if you would like to know more!&nbsp;<br />
For additional resources, including our <a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/FINAL-BE-A-WATERSHED-WATCHDOG-PDF.PDF"" target=""_blank"">&ldquo;Be a Watershed Watchdog Guide,&quot;</a> <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/news-list"">click here.</a></p>
",Environment,"Alexander Cupo, PennFuture Southeast PA Outreach Coordinator"
Saving Energy on a Budget,7/30/2018,"<p><em><strong>By Veronica Manning, PennFuture Intern</strong></em></p>

<p>It&rsquo;s easy to save energy on a budget with a few practical, simple steps. Here are some easy, cost-effective ways to decrease your home&rsquo;s carbon footprint.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Switch to Clean Energy for Your Electricity</strong></p>

<p>Switching to a clean energy provider for your electricity is a simple alternative that allows you to rely less on fossil fuels. Pennsylvania is one of 17 states with a retail electric program, which lets customers choose where they buy their electricity.&nbsp;Using renewable energy doesn&rsquo;t require changing your utility company. In Pennsylvania,&nbsp;electricity utility companies own the distribution networks in a local area, or the wires that connect your house to the rest of the grid. The utility companies buy energy from a mix of sources, and that energy is then sent to their customers. Customers who have not chosen an electricity generator receive default electricity service, or energy that comes from multiple generators.&nbsp;Choosing your generation provider means that your same utility company will now send energy from your specified source instead of providing default electricity service to your home. Depending on what source you choose, this clean energy also may also be cheaper than what you currently pay for default electricity.</p>

<p>Switching to a clean energy provider can be done online in a few minutes. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/TakethePowerBack_Steps-to-Take-for-Parents.pdf""><strong>Follow our step-by-step guide here to get started.&nbsp;</strong></a></p>

<p><strong>Reduce Your Standby Power Consumption</strong></p>

<p>Standby power is a term for the energy used by devices that appear to be off. Electronics like TVs, phone and laptop chargers, streaming devices, and gaming consuls all consume a small amount of power while in sleep mode. The Department of Energy estimates that standby power accounts for up to 10 percent&nbsp;of the total residential energy use in the U.S.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>While standby power is necessary for the functioning of many appliances in your home, you can still reduce your standby power consumption by turning off nonessential devices when not in use.&nbsp;Your electronics can either be unplugged individually or grouped on a shared power strip. Some smart power strips also have an option to set a timer, automatically turning off your devices for you.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>If you&rsquo;re willing to spend more, you can also consider replacing your appliances with more efficient models. Older appliances consume more standby power than their newer counterparts.&nbsp; When shopping, look for models with an <a href=""https://www.energystar.gov/"">ENERGY STAR</a> certification. These products meet EPA guidelines for appliances that are both energy efficient and cost-effective in the long term. You also have the option of switching to a programmable thermostat.&nbsp; The EPA found that replacing a manual thermostat can cut heating or cooling costs by 20 percent or more.</p>

<p>For more information on standby power, <a href=""https://standby.lbl.gov/faq/#what"">check out this fact sheet from the Berkley Lab.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p><strong>Use LED Lightbulbs</strong></p>

<p>If you are still using incandescent lightbulbs, consider switching to LEDs. Incandescent lightbulbs lose about 90 percent of the energy they consume as heat. Because so much energy is wasted, an incandescent bulb requires more energy to produce the same amount of light as an LED.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Light-emitting diodes, or LED bulbs, lose about 10 percent of the energy they consume as heat, making them much more efficient than their incandescent counterparts. They are more expensive than traditional lightbulbs, but last about 10 years. LEDs are also easy to dispose of once they have reached the end of their lifespan.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While compact fluorescent light bulbs, or CFLs, are sometimes also listed as another energy-efficient alternative to incandescent bulbs, they are much less efficient than LEDs. CFLS lose about 80 percent of the energy they consume as heat. CFLs also contain mercury and need to be specially recycled to prevent contamination. If you have CFL bulbs in your home, you should replace them with LEDs once they burn out or break. Your local waste collection service and some stores may offer cheap or free CFL recycling. Check online to see what&rsquo;s available in your area. The EPA has also released guidelines for cleanup and disposal of broken CFL bulbs, <a href=""https://www.epa.gov/cfl"">which can be found here.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p><strong>Line Dry Your Laundry</strong></p>

<p>Electric tumble dryers are one of the biggest consumers of energy in many households. In 2014, the <a href=""https://www.nrdc.org/sites/default/files/efficient-clothes-dryers-IB.pdf"">National Resource Defense Council</a> found that the typical electric dryer had seen only marginal improvements in energy efficiency since&nbsp; 1981. As of 2015, ENERGY STAR certified dryers are available, but these machines still consume large amounts of energy compared to other energy-efficient appliances.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Line drying your laundry is a great way to reduce the energy consumed by drying clothes in an electric tumble drier. Sheets, blouses, dress shirts, and other items made of medium to lightweight fabric can be dried outdoors on a line. If line drying is not an option in your area, consider investing in an indoor drying rack for items like sweaters.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Use Window Coverings to Keep Your Home at a Comfortable Temperature</strong><br />
&nbsp;<br />
Using window coverings will reduce energy loss and save money on your heating and cooling bills. Heating energy can escape through your windows and decrease your home&rsquo;s energy efficiency.&nbsp; Uncovered windows also allow heat from sunlight to enter your home, making it harder to stay cool in the warmer months.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>If you already have coverings on your windows, use them strategically to improve your energy efficiency. Window coverings should be opened on sunny winter mornings to allow heat from sunlight to enter your home throughout the day. Coverings should be closed on summer days to reduce heat from direct sunlight. Windows that do not receive direct sunlight can be left uncovered to take advantage of natural light.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>If you do not&nbsp; already have coverings on all of your windows, <a href=""https://www.energy.gov/energysaver/energy-efficient-window-attachments"">use this guide from the Department of Energy</a> to find which type would work best for you.&nbsp;</p>
",Energy,
Engaging on Environmental Concerns and Listening across the State: Meet the CEO Happy Hours,7/27/2018,"<p>This spring, PennFuture kicked off a series of Meet the CEO Happy Hour events around the state, as we wanted to create opportunities for me to meet more of our supporters, activists and partners spread all around this very large Commonwealth.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>More importantly, we wanted to create a chance for all of you, as our eyes and ears on the ground, to talk with me, share your concerns and meet other members of our talented PennFuture staff. I&rsquo;ve enjoyed this time a lot, and now I feel much more plugged into a community of people who care deeply about our environment, and who are doing remarkable work to protect it.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>After the 2016 elections, PennFuture made a conscious decision to be more active in Pennsylvania&rsquo;s mid-sized towns and communities. Our happy hours are a part of that endeavor, and now have taken us to Erie, Ambler, State College, Mount Pocono, and of course Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, where I tend to spend a lot of time already.&nbsp; I&rsquo;ve learned quite a bit more about the concerns of folks living in these places and I wanted to share some of what I have heard with all of you.</p>

<p><strong>One of our best attended events was held in Erie, where I reconnected with several activists who shared their concerns about Erie Coke Works.</strong>&nbsp;While we are not ready to make specific pronouncements about pollution from the facility, the community may be dealing with significant pollution problems, based on the odors and visible emissions coming from the works.&nbsp; There were conversations about the Lake Erie and French Creek and about renewable energy opportunities, and threats from pipelines and plastics.&nbsp; We had a chance to meet a large group of senior academics and administrators from Gannon University, who were not there for the happy hour, but with whom a lot of synergy is now evident.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>In Pittsburgh, there was a lot of talk about air quality, fracking and the petrochemical build-out underway and led by Shell Global in nearby Beaver County.</strong>&nbsp;I connected with some old friends from the nine years I spent living and working in Pittsburgh.&nbsp; For as much time spent talking over the challenges, there was good talk about renewable energy over microbrews. PennFuture has had a presence in Pittsburgh since its beginning, and so many of you who came out have had long relationships with our organization.</p>

<p><strong>Up in the Poconos, we had a fantastic turnout and we saw friends from close partners like Brodhead Watershed Association and Trout Unlimited.</strong>&nbsp;PennFuture&rsquo;s office in Mount Pocono is focused on protecting those high quality headwater streams of the Delaware River Basin, and so there was a lot of talk about Exceptional Value streams, and how they must continue to be protected, while at the same time allowing for economic development to flourish. We had a group from the Wind Gap area come to talk to us about sludge disposal and their work to protect their community.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>In Ambler, I had a chance to meet Mayor Jeanne Sorg, and talk about Ambler&rsquo;s commitment to sustainability, including clean energy.</strong>&nbsp;My conversation with Mayor Sorg gave me some food for thought as PennFuture looks to expand its Clean Energy Communities project beyond Pittsburgh.&nbsp; Mayor Sorg reminded me that as clean water and clean energy are intrinsic to healthy, thriving communities, the bottom line for elected officials is managing a budget and how important it will be that green solutions and practices are positively impacting those bottom lines.&nbsp; Wissahickon Valley Watershed Association staff showed up in numbers for some socializing, and several important local activists came out to support the event.</p>

<p><strong>Renowned Penn State climate scientist and PennFuture board member Michael Mann joined us in State College, and there was a lot of talk about climate and politics and how we can tackle the lack of leadership among most elected officials on our issues.</strong>&nbsp;I had a chance to reconnect with a woman who shares my name, almost 30 years after we found out the other existed on a bus trip to Washington, D.C. for a rally after the Three Mile Island disaster.&nbsp; She&rsquo;s not of blood relation, but she and others who came out for the happy hour share the same DNA for environmental advocacy.</p>

<p><strong>We also had a crowd at the new Yards Brewery in Philadelphia, a business we love because of their commitment to renewable energy.</strong>&nbsp;<strong>By far, the biggest question we heard over and over was, &ldquo;What can I do to help?&rdquo;</strong> There&rsquo;s so much you can do.&nbsp;As I&rsquo;ve mentioned in past blogs, <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/greenin18"" target=""_blank"">our Green in &rsquo;18 campaign is seeking volunteers through the fall.</a>&nbsp;Our <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/join-the-ace-program"" target=""_blank"">Advocates for Conservation and the Environment (ACE) program</a> is training volunteers to do education on issues and meetings with legislators in district offices. That program is slowly expanding and we&rsquo;d welcome your help. <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/newsletter-sign-up"" target=""_blank"">We also ask that you subscribe to our email list</a>, as your engagement and rapid response to action alerts will allow you to contact your legislators and push them on specific actions when in session, and we will always keep you up to date on the latest environmental legislation moving in Harrisburg.</p>

<p>Thanks to everyone who attended, just to say hello, or to bring important issues to our attention.&nbsp;While PennFuture does not have the capacity to work on every environmental issue in the state, we have&nbsp;concerns after several of these conversations and will be looking into next steps.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>We need you to be our eyes and ears on the ground because our state is large and we cannot be everywhere &ndash; as much as we would like to be.&nbsp;In the meantime, we count on you.&nbsp;I want to thank all of the PennFuture board members and President&rsquo;s Leadership Council members, and ACE volunteers who have joined us thus far. Thanks to the staff who came out, and brought&nbsp;their family members, and significant others with them. I hope to see more of you at future happy hours that are on our calendar for the rest of the summer into spring.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Community,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
Why You Should Join Tom Wolf & Scott Wagner on the Campaign Trail,7/27/2018,"<div>The threats to Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment have never been more urgent. We have the third worst air quality in the country, and as a result, in some Pennsylvania cities, one in three children suffers from asthma. Pennsylvania drinking water ranks as one the nation&#39;s riskiest for lead-contamination, and 19,000 miles of our streams and rivers are unsafe for drinking, recreation, aquatic life, or agricultural use. The race to exploit the abundance of natural gas beneath the surface has turned Pennsylvania into one of the largest producers of methane, a major health and climate hazard, and has produced large quantities of wastewater and solid waste, which has exposed Pennsylvanians to harmful substances that cause a variety of serious illnesses.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>In response, a coalition of 26 environmental organizations across the state, led by PennFuture, developed the <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/CCA_2nd-Edition_Web-Version-6.1.18.pdf"" target=""_blank""><strong>Pennsylvania Common Conservation Agenda</strong></a>, a comprehensive series of fiscally responsible solutions to the problems above. Another advantage of the agenda: the recommended solutions can be enacted by the incoming governor using the executive authority granted in the state constitution. With a pivotal gubernatorial election taking place on November 6, this would seem like an opportune time to distribute the agenda. But so far, we&#39;ve heard little about either candidate&rsquo;s environmental and conservation agendas.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Why are the candidates focusing so little attention on the environment? After all, aren&rsquo;t more and more people convinced that the environmental problems facing Pennsylvania must be addressed before it&rsquo;s too late? The answer to the latter question is a resounding &ldquo;yes.&rdquo; The <a href=""https://www.fandm.edu/uploads/files/708725106986767486-f-m-poll-release-march-2018.pdf"" target=""_blank"">March 2018 Franklin and Marshall College Poll</a> survey of 423 Pennsylvania registered voters found that 62% think climate change is causing problems now, and 67% think the state should do more to address the problems associated with climate change, including 47% who say the state should definitely do more. What&rsquo;s more, 55% of the respondents believe the potential environmental risks of natural gas drilling outweigh the potential economic benefits, a turnaround of the findings in a Franklin &amp; Marshall survey four years earlier.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Yet despite these findings, only 2% of the participants in the March 2018 poll believe that the environment is the most important problem facing the state, a sentiment that is essentially the same as in other recent Franklin &amp; Marshal polls. The top five concerns expressed by Pennsylvania voters in March were:</div>

<ul>
	<li>Government &amp; politicians<span style=""white-space:pre""> </span>16%</li>
	<li>Taxes<span style=""white-space:pre""> </span>15%</li>
	<li>Unemployment &amp; personal finances<span style=""white-space:pre""> </span>12%</li>
	<li>Crime, drugs, violence, and guns<span style=""white-space:pre""> </span>10%</li>
	<li>Education/schools<span style=""white-space:pre""> </span>9%</li>
</ul>

<div>These five problems have been at the top of the list dating back to early 2017, while the environment has ranked no higher than seventh during this time period and has not been mentioned by more than 3% of Franklin &amp; Marshall poll participants. So, although Pennsylvania voters are concerned about the environment and want to see more action taken, they consider other issues even more important. Therefore, it should come as no surprise that the issues overshadowing the environment are the ones being discussed on the campaign trail. I can personally attest to that having attended a Scott Wagner town hall last week.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

The only way this will happen is if the Green in &rsquo;18 campaign can elevate the importance of the environment in voters&rsquo; minds, and motivate them to get out on the campaign trail and ask the candidates questions about their positions on and plans for the environment.&nbsp;</div>

PennFuture Joins Forces with Franklin County Coalition for Progress for Presentation,7/27/2018,"<p>On Saturday, July 14, PennFuture provided a presentation on &quot;Climate, Stewardship, and Environmental Justice&quot; at the Coyle Free Library in Chambersburg, Pa. as dozens of activists came out to discuss and learn more about a variety of environmental issues hindering our Commonwealth.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture was invited to present and participate in the event by Franklin County Coalition for Progress (FCCP), a local advocacy group advancing social justice and equality for all residents in Franklin County. Topics ranged from federal and state policy, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s standing in the Phase III Watershed Implementation Plan (WIP), and environmental justice.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I had the honor of joining my colleagues, Ezra Thrush, Director of Policy, and Roman Acri, Green in 18&rsquo; south-central Pennsylvania campaign organizer, on a variety of conversations with the attendees.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Ezra began the event by highlighting several essential pieces of work he has been a part of. It has been a busy legislative season for our Director of Policy, and the impact of it has been felt across the board by those in the conservation effort and beyond. Highlighting the positive and negative aspects of the House and Senate Farm Bills, as well as increased funding for our environmental agencies, he informed the coalition that much has been accomplished &ndash; yet much more work still needs to be done.&nbsp;</p>

<p>My work primarily revolves around the Susquehanna and Potomac Rivers, specifically the cleanup and restoration of the Chesapeake Bay. On April 10, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environmental advocates and state agencies conducted a meeting where they developed their toolbox for four pilot counties that will be heading up the initial strategy of reducing pollution and runoff, and developing best management practices (BMP&rsquo;s) to help Pennsylvania reach its Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) goals.&nbsp;</p>

<p>With Pennsylvania being so far behind in its pollution reduction goals, I highlighted some of the most important areas of work that are taking place at the state and county levels. Being in Franklin County, which is one of the four pilot counties of the WIP pilot program, Chambersburg plays a critical role in the progress of our pollution reduction goals. With their state-of-the art MS4 program, this small town is making big progress and setting a great example for the south central part of the state.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Roman then closed out the session talking about Environmental Justice in the state. According to the PA Department of Environmental Protection, nearly one-third of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s population lives in an Environmental Justice area. These areas are now defined as a census block group with a 30 percent or greater minority population, or a 20 percent or greater population at or below the poverty level. &ldquo;These are really important issues that are severely harming entire communities &ndash; solely because of where they live,&rdquo; Roman said. &ldquo;We have a responsibility not only as advocates, but as human beings, to look out for each other.&rdquo;</p>

<p>PennFuture would like to thank the Franklin County Coalition for Progress for allowing us to speak at their meeting. Any time environmental advocates are able to come together, enjoy some coffee, and discuss environmental protections is a good day.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>FCCP is leading the way to a renewal of the promise of America; that Franklin County becomes a community of welcome, acceptance, fairness, and opportunity for all people. They hold monthly seminars on the second Saturday of every month from 10am-12pm at the Coyle Free Library in Chambersburg. The next few months will continue the focus of watershed health, specifically examining the Borough of Chambersburg storm water sewer systems. To learn more about FCCP, <a href=""https://www.facebook.com/pg/FCCforProgress/about/?ref=page_internal"" target=""_blank"">be sure to &ldquo;like&rdquo; their Facebook page</a>, to stay up to date with all of their news.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

Cloudy with a 100% Chance of Solar Power Generation,7/17/2018,"<p><img alt="""" src=""/Files/Admin/PennFuture%2D1%2Ejpg"" style=""width: 700px; height: 726px;"" /></p>

<p>Bob and Susan Donnan have always had an appreciation for the environment, and after choosing to go solar at their home in Peters Township, common misconceptions about installing solar panels in Western Pennsylvania were quickly shattered.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;I was surprised by how much energy could be stored on cloudy or partly cloudy days,&rdquo; Susan said. &ldquo;People think it has to be sunny all of the time and that is a misconception.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>The couple attended PennFuture&rsquo;s Annual Pittsburgh Solar Tour in October 2017. Just a couple of weeks later during a trip to Home Depot, Bob spoke to representatives from Solar City, made an appointment for a free estimate, and made the switch to solar energy.&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>The couple&rsquo;s passion for clean energy stems from their shared desire to create a better world for future generations, especially their own family.</p>

<p>&ldquo;My greatest concern is the environment I am leaving for my grandchildren. I worry about the future and I feel many people are concerned with profit and making money. I am concerned for my grandkids,&rdquo; Susan said.</p>

<p>Susan, a volunteer with Face2Face Healing, and Bob, a retired landscaper, live in a home that now has 11 solar panels that are then backed up by a Tesla power wall. The panels are a 3.3 kilowatt system. The Tesla power wall is a rated 14 kilowatt hour lithium ion battery, of which 13.5 kilowatts are useable. The panels supply the house with energy, and any excess power produced by the solar panels is then stored in the power wall. This is helpful because it gives the home energy independence in the event that the grid goes down.</p>

<p>&ldquo;There have been days when we put energy back on the grid, which is a good feeling,&rdquo; Bob said. &ldquo;Today, we were 97% self-powered. Yesterday, we were 100% self-powered and for the week, we have been 86% self-powered. This month, our home has been 72% self-powered.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>The combination of attending PennFuture&rsquo;s Pittsburgh Solar Tour and then bumping into Solar City workers around the same time period spurred their choice to go solar.</strong></p>

<p>&ldquo;While on the tour, I learned more about the orientation of the panels and got a better idea of what the production would do for those families and households,&rdquo; Bob said. &ldquo;We learned about the SRECS and renewable credits. It just gave you a feel for seeing it up close and talking to someone about it, and hearing about their commitment, interest and their knowledge. Everyone was enthusiastic.&rdquo;</p>

<p>They also liked the fact that many of the homes were right in their neighborhood.</p>

<p>&ldquo;It came out to our local area and that made it more interesting to us,&rdquo; Bob said. &ldquo;These were areas I was familiar with and one place I drive past often. There was a nice group of people on the bus and snacks &ndash; you always remember the food.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Bob and Susan encourage those interested to attend PennFuture&rsquo;s Pittsburgh Solar Tour Oct. 6, 2018 to get an idea of the clean energy possibilities for their own families and homes.</strong></p>

<p>&ldquo;They can get a firsthand look for themselves, talk through how it works for them and be pretty specific, getting a close-up look at panels on a roof, learning about a power wall, how it works and what it does,&rdquo; Bob said.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Throughout the process, the couple has discovered the power of going solar and the possibilities it can bring, even if it&rsquo;s a typically dreary Pittsburgh day.</p>

<p>&ldquo;I think if I have learned something, it&rsquo;s that I am kind of surprised to see that the panels still produce even after the sun goes over the house in the late afternoon and into the evening. We still get production. The panels produce energy for a lot longer period every day than I thought they would &ndash; it is surprising even on a grey, cloudy day, you still get production,&rdquo; he said.</p>

<p><em><strong>Already have solar? <a href=""https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSf_b2_Pkh5VyHuJY30K4wGeFPrefNUIGN7mFPMHWQb3oKPjcA/viewform"" target=""_blank"">Become a stop on PennFuture&#39;s Pittsburgh Solar Tour by clicking here to sign up</a> and spread the word! For more information on PennFuture&rsquo;s Pittsburgh Solar Tour, contact regan@pennfuture.org and save the date for this year&#39;s event: Oct. 6, 2018.</strong></em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Energy,"Stephanie Rex, Director of Communications"
RESPECTAgZone Aims to Protect Community from Intrusive Proposed Power Lines Route,6/27/2018,"<div><em><strong>By Susan Cenname, RESPECTAgZone Member and Indiana Township Resident</strong></em></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>For the past year, residents of Indiana Township, adjacent to Hartwood Acres County Park, have been under a threat that would change their way of life, the appearance of their community, the value of their homes, and the safety of their land. The threat has been unnecessary on many levels, and yet it persists.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Residents first learned of the threat from a benign-appearing notice that began, &ldquo;Dear Duquesne Light Customer: As new homes are being built and the demand for energy grows in the area, Duquesne Light Company [DLC] is working to maintain a level of reliability customers have come to expect while increasing the overall resiliency of the grid. Our dedication to improving the way energy is delivered is just one of the many ways we are working to become your next generation energy company.&rdquo;&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>It went on to describe the company&rsquo;s plans to build a new high-voltage transmission line through Indiana Township to service West Deer Municipality. The notices did not contain any maps of the routes being considered by the company.&nbsp; The description of the project failed to vividly reflect the dramatic impact 150-foot high towers would have on our environment, working farms, and landscape.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>This notice initiated a process by which residents educated themselves about DLC, their project, its alternatives, and the approvals needed before it could happen. The notice also spurred community members to organize around the issue into a cohesive voice that would be heard by DLC and other decision-makers.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>The Project:</strong> DLC is proposing to construct a 128 kV high-power transmission line through Indiana Township to serve West Deer Municipality.&nbsp; The question is: how will DLC achieve that goal? DLC initially proposed three routes through Indiana Township. DLC&rsquo;s proposal identified a &ldquo;preferred route,&rdquo; which passed next to Allegheny County&rsquo;s Hartwood Acres Park.&nbsp; All three routes initially proposed would cut through prime agricultural lands.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>The Common Sense Alternative: </strong>Through the work of a Township employee, local citizens identified a fourth alternative that would achieve DLC&rsquo;s goals without the social and environmental impacts of the initial alternatives.&nbsp; This route would hug the Turnpike for much of its path - thereby avoiding much of Indiana Township&rsquo;s prime agricultural lands and Hartwood Acres Park.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>That Turnpike Route, as we term it, has many win-win characteristics.&nbsp;</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>It limits visual and environmental degradation to areas already impacted by the Turnpike itself;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>It can share some of the existing right-of-way belonging to the Turnpike, which reduces costs and impacts associated with right-of-way management;</li>
	<li>It provides greater engineering redundancy and resiliency to the electric grid&mdash;a stated project goal for DLC;</li>
	<li>It is supported by the PA Turnpike Commission; the PA Department of Agriculture, the PA Office Small Business Administration, and the local community; and&nbsp;</li>
	<li>It causes the least environmental and social impact of any of the alternatives being considered.</li>
</ul>

<div><strong>The Process: </strong>As our group dug into this proposed project, we learned that DLC had to follow a specific process in order to obtain approval to implement it. Because DLC is a regulated electric service provider that has the authority to condemn private property, it must apply for approval and obtain the consent of the Public Utility Commission (PUC) before implementing the project. The cost of this project will be borne by DLC&rsquo;s customers, so DLC must first and foremost demonstrate a need for the project. After performing an environmental assessment of the alternatives, DLC must justify its choice of routes before the PUC.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Because the PUC is a government entity, its decision, and by extension DLC&rsquo;s decision, must comply with Article I, Section 27 of the PA Constitution, known as the Environmental Rights Amendment (ERA). The ERA requires government, when faced with equally practicable alternatives, to choose that which does not harm the fundamental constitutional rights granted citizens by Section 27, that is, the right to clean air, pure water, and the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic and esthetic values of the environment.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>If this project is needed, we, the citizens of Indiana Township who have organized as RespectAgZone, urge DLC to choose the most common sense alternative for its proposed high-voltage power line -- along the existing Pennsylvania Turnpike route.&nbsp; Only that route minimizes environmental and social costs while achieving the overall benefits proposed for the project. RespectAgZone is pleased to have the assistance of and be represented in this matter by PennFuture, which we were glad to learn recently won an important land use decision before the PA Supreme Court, and which has substantial experience before the PUC.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>We look forward to the day when DLC removes the constant threat of this proposed project and does the right thing by prioritizing the long-term natural, scenic, historic, and esthetic values of these beautiful lands so accessible to the citizens of the city of Pittsburgh.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><em><strong>For more information, visit&nbsp;<a href=""https://www.respectagzone.org/"" target=""_blank"">https://www.respectagzone.org/</a>.</strong></em></div>
",Environment,
State Budget Headed in the Right Direction for Environment,6/26/2018,"<div>Governor Tom Wolf signed into law a $32.7 billion spending plan for the Fiscal Year 2018-19 Pennsylvania state budget (House Bill 2121). Compared to the long budget stalemates Pennsylvania has dealt with over the last few years, this appropriations bill made its way through the General Assembly on time and with modest increases in investment for environmental protection.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s FY2018-19 Budget &amp; the Environment</strong></div>

<div>It&rsquo;s important to put Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environmental investment budget in context first: our key state resource agencies and commissions are chronically underfunded, understaffed, and work with aging infrastructure. For almost two decades, Pennsylvania Governors and legislators &ndash; both Democrats and Republicans &ndash; cut environmental budgets even while ecological stressors like natural gas drilling and climate change were on the rise.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The FY2018-19 state budget does very little to reverse these decades of dismantling and it will take strong bipartisan leadership in Harrisburg to reverse this costly trend. Nonetheless, the state budget provides modest increases that allow the Commonwealth&rsquo;s resource agencies, such as the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR) and the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) to slightly increase capacity and not have to cut back programming.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>In fact, unlike the last few years, no environmental agency or commission we work hard to advocate for saw spending cuts and some saw increases. It signals some hope that this budget indicates a floor to the cuts and a beginning to the long-road to building strong, well-financed and staffed environmental and conservation agencies that protect and advance public health and a sustainable economy.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>Take a closer look at the FY2018-19 budget allocations (HB 2121):</strong></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>Department of Agriculture&nbsp;</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>$1M increase from FY2017-18 for General Operations</li>
	<li>$3M increase from FY2017-18 for Spotted Lanternfly Control</li>
	<li>Overall, $7.49M increase for PDA from FY2017-18</li>
</ul>

<div><strong>Department of Conservation &amp; Natural Resources</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>$1.74M increase from FY2017-18 for General Operations (from Oil &amp; Gas Lease Fund)</li>
	<li>$5.16M increase from FY2017-18 for State Parks Operations (from Oil &amp; Gas Lease Fund)</li>
	<li>$6.52M increase from FY2017-18&nbsp; for State Forests Operations (from Oil &amp; Gas Lease Fund)</li>
	<li>$2.50M increase from FY2017-18 for Parks &amp; Forests Infrastructure</li>
	<li>Overall, $16.1M increase for DCNR from FY2017-18</li>
</ul>

<div><strong>Department of Environmental Protection&nbsp;</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>$1.07M increase from FY2017-18&nbsp; for General Operations</li>
	<li>$1.52M increase from FY2017-18&nbsp; for Environmental Program Management</li>
	<li>$3.98M increase from FY2017-18&nbsp; for Environmental Protection Operations</li>
	<li>$135K increase from FY2017-18&nbsp; for Chesapeake Bay Agricultural Source Abatement</li>
	<li>No change from FY2017-18&nbsp; for DRBC (Delaware River Basin) - $217K</li>
	<li>No change from FY2017-18&nbsp; for SRBC (Susquehanna River Basin) - $237K</li>
	<li>No change from FY2017-18&nbsp; for ICPRB (Potomac River Basin) - $23K</li>
	<li>No change from FY2017-18&nbsp; for ORSANCO (Ohio River Basin) - $68K</li>
	<li>No change from FY2017-18&nbsp; for Chesapeake Bay Commission - $275K</li>
	<li>No change from FY2017-18&nbsp; for Conservation District Fund - $2.5M</li>
	<li>Overall, $6.84M increase for DEP from FY2017-18</li>
</ul>

<div><strong>Fiscal Code Bill Makes Few Environmental Changes</strong></div>

<div>In addition to the appropriations bill, the legislature often passes associated &ldquo;code bills&rdquo; that implement the budget across different issues areas. These code bills are often used to move nefarious pieces of legislation that by themselves wouldn&rsquo;t make it through the legislature. For this budget, legislators passed a Fiscal Code, which implements the state budget (House Bill 1929) that only included a few environmental and conservation provisions, including:&nbsp;</div>

<ul>
	<li>Transferred $30.4 million dollars from the Volkswagen (VW) settlement to the General Fund. These funds were provided to Pennsylvania from a settlement that found VW defrauded owners of low-emissions vehicles, resulting in more pollution. These dollars are supposed to be used by the state to reduce air pollution, but the legislature is diverting those funds to balance the budget instead;</li>
	<li>Established a state financial fund to help owners of private dams satisfy financial responsibility obligations under the Dam Safety and Encroachments Act, administered by the Department of Community and Economic Development (DCED) in consultation with the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP);</li>
	<li>Allocated $14.5 million in funding through the Commonwealth Financing Authority (CFA) for small water and sewer projects around the Commonwealth;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Mandated that the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR) open and create various ATV trails in northcentral Pennsylvania.</li>
</ul>

<div><strong>Looking Ahead Through 2018</strong></div>

<div>With the state budget wrapped up on time, the legislature will make themselves scarce in Harrisburg between now and the November elections. A number of big issues are still on the table, including threatened closures of uneconomic nuclear power plants, unsafe pipelines under construction impacting local communities, implementing the state&rsquo;s new building codes, passing community solar legislation, and updating the Alternative Energy Portfolio Standard (AEPS). Furthermore, factions within the legislature are still interested in advancing regulatory rollbacks and dismantling state environmental protections. It&rsquo;s possible these issues may crop up through the end of this year and PennFuture will keep an eye out, particularly in a lame duck session after the elections.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Nonetheless, it&rsquo;s been an incredibly busy legislative season and I&rsquo;d be remiss without mentioning how important you and your support have been. <strong>This year, our members and supporters have taken countless actions including making calls to legislators, sending letters to your representatives, and organizing in-district meetings on issues around conservation and the environment. Your presence is felt in Harrisburg and is making a difference as we begin reversing decades of cuts, rollbacks, and degradation.&nbsp;</strong></div>
",Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
Fueling Pennsylvania’s Clean Energy Jobs Engine,6/26/2018,"<div><img alt="""" src=""/Files/Admin/cleanenergyjobspaBILL%2Ejpg"" style=""width: 397px; height: 284px;"" /></div>

<div>Over 86,000 Pennsylvanians work in clean energy jobs, <a href=""https://www.e2.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Clean-Jobs-Pennsylvania-2018.pdf"" target=""_blank""><u><strong>according to a report released June 19</strong></u></a>, by the national nonpartisan business group <a href=""https://www.e2.org/"" target=""_blank"">E2</a> and partner organizations &mdash; Green Building Alliance, Keystone Energy Efficiency Alliance, Sustainable Business Network of Greater Philadelphia, and Sustainable Pittsburgh.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The exact number of jobs is 86,285, and includes jobs in renewable energy (solar and wind), energy efficiency, clean vehicles, battery storage, advanced biofuels, low-impact hydro, and other areas. The surge in clean energy jobs is not confined to one or two regions of the state; there are residents in every county&nbsp;working in these fields.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The report also shows that Pennsylvania ranks 11th among the 50 states and the District of Columbia in the number of clean energy jobs. Sounds pretty good, right? Well, not exactly.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>Pennsylvania is the 5th largest state in terms of population according to the <a href=""https://www.census.gov/data/datasets/2017/demo/popest/state-total.html"">U.S. Census Bureau</a>, yet ranks 11th in clean energy jobs. </strong>In contrast, Massachusetts, which has about half the population of Pennsylvania (15th overall), has the 7th highest total of clean energy jobs. Virginia, which ranks 12th in population, has the 10th most clean energy jobs. (<a href=""https://www.e2.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/Clean-Jobs-America-2018.pdf"" target=""_blank"">Click here to view E2&rsquo;s national report.</a>) <strong>These statistics suggest that Pennsylvania can do better.</strong></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The private sector is the engine of job growth, but there is much state government can and must do to rev up this engine. <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/CCA_2nd-Edition_Web-Version-6.1.18.pdf"" target=""_blank""><u><strong>The PA Common Conservation Agenda, a blueprint for environmental action developed by PennFuture</strong></u></a> and 25 other environmental groups across Pennsylvania &ndash; including three that helped produce the E2 jobs report, Green Building Alliance, Sustainable Business Network of Greater Philadelphia, and Sustainable Pittsburgh &ndash; contains a number practical, fiscally responsible steps that can be enacted by whoever occupies the governor&rsquo;s office after the 2018 election, simply using his executive authority. <strong>Among the recommendations in the agenda pertaining to creating more clean energy jobs:</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>Invest in workforce training programs that provide displaced workers and new workforce entrants with skills in clean technology areas, including energy efficiency, renewable energy, and clean transportation.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Grow the state&rsquo;s green business sector by participating in recruitment trips to the top companies around the country to advocate for expansion or relocation to the Commonwealth.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Instruct the Department of Community and Economic Development&rsquo;s Manufacturing PA initiative to focus on workforce development and job opportunities in clean energy manufacturing.</li>
	<li>Expand the Department of Labor and Industry&rsquo;s Apprenticeship and Training Office to focus on clean energy trades.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Develop an in-depth economic plan in concert with strong clean energy policies that includes opportunities for displaced workers, openings for a diverse workforce, considerations for rural and vulnerable communities, and innovative workforce investments.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Offer active public support and leadership to help pass the Congressional RECLAIM Act, a bipartisan bill, which would allocate funds to reclamation and restoration of land and water resources adversely affected by coal mining, providing Pennsylvania with $67 million annually for five years.</li>
</ul>

<div>Additionally, hundreds of millions of dollars in Pennsylvania Infrastructure Investment Authority funding are available to invest in the Commonwealth&rsquo;s clean water infrastructure. With our water sector facing an aging workforce, leadership from the governor&#39;s office could help attract job-seekers, and support hiring and recruiting the next generation of clean water professionals.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/CCA_2nd-Edition_Web-Version-6.1.18.pdf"" target=""_blank""><u><strong>The PA Common Conservation Agenda </strong></u></a>represents the best thinking of many of the state&rsquo;s top environmental organizations, when it comes to strengthening the Commonwealth&rsquo;s 21st-century workforce through green jobs; safeguarding our water, air, land, and wildlife; and protecting the health and quality of life of our communities. But it takes more than great ideas to generate action; it&rsquo;s going to take a groundswell of support from people across the state. That&rsquo;s why PennFuture is backing <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/greenin18"" target=""_blank""><u><strong>Green in &rsquo;18</strong></u></a>, a grassroots movement of Pennsylvanians speaking out for the environment and demanding action.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/greenin18"" target=""_blank""><strong>Green in &rsquo;18</strong></a> is primarily focused on making sure environmental issues receive the attention they deserve from the candidates vying to be Pennsylvania&rsquo;s next governor. I encourage you to add your voice to this growing movement. Visit www.greenin18.org to learn what you can do to help; then sign up to get involved. Through the concerted efforts of Green in &rsquo;18 supporters, the environment will be front and center on the campaign trail, which will, in turn, lead to the action we are seeking.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>To stay up to date on Green in &rsquo;18, follow us on Facebook at <a href=""https://www.facebook.com/PAGreenin18/."" target=""_blank"">https://www.facebook.com/PAGreenin18/</a><a href=""https://www.facebook.com/PAGreenin18/."" target=""_blank"">.</a></div>
",Energy,"Bill Madway, Press Secretary, Green in '18 Campaign, PennFuture"
Meet Kelsey Krepps: PennFuture's New Western PA Outreach Coordinator,6/25/2018,"<p>Hey there! My name is Kelsey Krepps, and I am so excited to be back in my home state of Pennsylvania <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/kelsey-krepps"" target=""_blank"">working for an organization that cares so deeply for the issues near and dear to my heart.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>When I was a child, I thought being green and helping the environment was all about cleaning it up. My babysitter would take my sister and I on walks to our local ice cream stand just a half mile up the road, and on the way, we&rsquo;d pick up all the trash. I loved seeing my handiwork and knowing that I was responsible for making the world just a little bit better. As junior high and high school passed, I participated in numerous clean ups and tree plantings all over Crawford, Venango, and Erie Counties. I loved that these events were a part of my school curriculum, and I like to think of them as me leaving little green thumbprints everywhere I go.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Later, I went to the University of Pittsburgh at Bradford for my undergraduate degree in Environmental Studies &ndash; shocking, I know. One of the greatest things I learned there, though, was the role that environmental issues play in community development. Being green and helping the environment is not an environmental issue, it&rsquo;s a people issue. We don&rsquo;t get to have healthy, thriving communities when we don&rsquo;t live in a healthy, thriving environment. Our families and our health suffer when the environment suffers. Businesses suffer when the environment suffers. Being green is more than cleaning up, it&rsquo;s about preventing the clean ups from needing to happen in the first place. It&rsquo;s about having an active role in how we influence our homes.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I spent the last three years in Boone, North Carolina for graduate school. There, I studied renewable energies like wind and solar, but I also studied the history, natural resources and culture of the Appalachian Region. In Western PA, we have such diverse histories from coal mines in the Southwest to the industries of Pittsburgh to farming in the Northwest and eco-tourism, well, everywhere. I was raised in a farming community just ten minutes away from Titusville, PA &ndash; the birthplace of the oil industry. We can celebrate Pennsylvania&rsquo;s history in fossil fuels and industry while still choosing to create a cleaner, renewable future.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We can be both the clean up crew and the people who protect the policies in place that defend our health, homes, and families from big polluters. We can be both pro-job and pro-environment, creating just transitions for our fossil fuel imbedded neighborhoods. We can be leaders in renewable, clean energy. We can have cleaner air, water, and land. We can speak up about environmental injustice. We can love the communities we&rsquo;re from, while knowing there&rsquo;s still work to be done.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I look forward to meeting you and working with those of you in Western PA and beyond for a more sustainable Pennsylvania. Please feel free to contact me at krepps@pennfuture.org or call me at 412-224&ndash;4477.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Let&rsquo;s do this together!</p>
",Environment,"Kelsey Krepps, Western PA Outreach Coordinator"
PennFuture Secures Victory for Homeowners in PA Supreme Court Case,6/25/2018,"<p>The PA State Supreme Court announced its long-awaited decision&nbsp;in Gorsline et al. v. Board of Supervisors of Fairfield Township v. Inflection Energy LLC et al., earlier this month, which completes a multi-year journey between PennFuture and its clients, Brian and Dawn Gorsline, and their neighbors, Paul and Michele Batkowski.</p>

<p>PennFuture began representing the Gorslines and Batkowskis in January 2014, when its lawyers appealed a decision by Fairfield Township to issue Inflection Energy a conditional use permit for operation of a shale gas well pad in the residential portion of the municipality&rsquo;s R-A (Residential-Agricultural) zoning district.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>To issue the permit, the Township&rsquo;s ordinance required that it conclude that an industrial shale gas well pad was &ldquo;similar to and compatible with&rdquo; other uses allowed in the R-A district. The appeal focused on the company&rsquo;s failure to meet that standard, and that issuing the permit violated our clients&rsquo; constitutional rights.&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The appeal was heard in the Lycoming Court of Common Pleas by Judge Marc F. Lovecchio, who sided with PennFuture and overturned the Township&rsquo;s decision.&nbsp; Recognizing that there were important constitutional issues at play, Judge Lovecchio concluded that Inflection had failed to put on adequate evidence at the local hearing to justify issuance of the permit.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The Township and Inflection appealed that ruling to the Commonwealth Court.&nbsp;The Commonwealth Court held that the Township was justified in issuing the permit because the ordinance allows &ldquo;public service facilities&rdquo; in all of its zoned districts, and an industrial shale gas well pad was similar to a &ldquo;public service facility.&rdquo; The Court had previously used this rationale in another case to allow a compressor station to be located in a light industrial zoned district.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>This case, then, if allowed to stand, would have constituted an outrageous expansion of this rationale that would have swallowed any need for townships to affirmatively regulate where shale gas development would be allowed.</strong> Instead of fulfilling the township&rsquo;s obligations under Article I, Section 27 in choosing where to locate all of the various impacts associated with this vast industry, townships would have been free to issue ad hoc approvals for well pads, processing plants and compressor stations in any of its zoned districts under the ruse that the land use was similar to a &ldquo;public service facility.&rdquo;</p>

<p>PennFuture appealed and the Commonwealth Court&rsquo;s decision went to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court.&nbsp;In its appeal, PennFuture argued that there were four different ways in which the Commonwealth Court made the wrong decision, including that the decision violated Article I, Section 27 of the Constitution and our clients&#39; substantive due process rights.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>The Supreme Court did not decide the case on the broader constitutional arguments that we made, but did agree with our other three arguments.&nbsp;</strong>The Court held that:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Shale gas development is an industrial land use, and that this industrial land use is not the same as a public service facility;</li>
	<li>Industrial shale gas well pads are not &ldquo;in any material respect&rdquo; similar to and compatible with the other permitted uses in the Township&rsquo;s R-A District;</li>
	<li>The Township could not rely on its earlier decisions to allow shale gas development in its R-A District in order to justify issuance of this permit.&nbsp;</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Even though the Court did not decide the case on constitutional bases, the decision established a number of important points.&nbsp;</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>The Court firmly characterized shale gas development as an industrial land use while rejecting industry&rsquo;s fiction that after construction of the well pads, the facilities have no ongoing impact on public health and the environment.</li>
	<li>The Court rejected the Commonwealth Court&rsquo;s finding that shale gas well pads are similar and compatible with &ldquo;public service&rdquo; facilities. The Court recognized that shale gas is a private enterprise that does not directly provide any public service to area residents. This establishes important precedent that precludes townships from using &ldquo;public service facility&rdquo; provisions in existing zoning ordinances for permitting shale gas well pads.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>The Court stated that shale gas development was not materially similar in any manner to other permitted uses in Fairfield Township&rsquo;s R-A District.&nbsp;This finding was very important, because even though the Court did not expressly decide the case on constitutional grounds, the finding has important constitutional implications.&nbsp;When exercising its zoning powers, local government takes away, to one degree or another, private property owners&rsquo; rights to do with their property whatever they choose, and they do that without paying for the taking of those rights. For government to exercise that power constitutionally, the Supreme Court has said that property owners must also benefit from the existence of zoning districts, and that requires that only similar and compatible uses be allowed in each zoned district.&nbsp;Consequently, when zoning for shale gas development, townships must determine and justify what other land uses are similar and compatible with this particular industrial land use. To the extent shale gas development is not similar and compatible with other uses in a particular zoned district, the municipality cannot constitutionally allow shale gas development to occur in the same zoned district.&nbsp;</li>
	<li><strong>Finally, the Court&rsquo;s ruling effectively requires that townships make conscious decisions, with public participation, about how this industry will be regulated on the local level.&nbsp;</strong>It is not adequate to, as did Fairfield Township, permit industrialization of a zoned township on an ad hoc basis.&nbsp; The township must make reasoned decisions that take into account the expectations of its citizenry about the type of land uses that will be allowed in particular zoned districts, and, in the end, those decisions must comport with the state and federal Constitutions.</li>
</ul>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s success in this case is not just a long-awaited win for our clients, but a win for concerned residents across the Commonwealth.&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"George Jugovic, Jr., Vice President of Legal Affairs"
Opinion: Wolf and Wagner need to be specific in plans to help the environment,6/7/2018,"<p><em><strong>This blog post originally <a href=""http://www.pennlive.com/opinion/2018/05/wolf_and_wagner_need_to_be_spe.html"" target=""_blank"">appeared in PennLive</a> on May 30, 2018.</strong></em></p>

<p><strong><em>By Jan Jarrett</em></strong></p>

<p><em>&quot;The people have a right to clean air, pure water, and to the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic and esthetic values of the environment. Pennsylvania&#39;s public natural resources are the common property of all the people, including generations yet to come. As trustee of these resources, the commonwealth shall conserve and maintain them for the benefit of all the people.&quot;</em></p>

<p>This coming Jan. 15, either Tom Wolf or Scott Wagner will raise his hand and take a binding oath to uphold the Pennsylvania Constitution.</p>

<p>Among the duties the next governor will be obliged to carry out under its provisions is the protection of our air and water and the natural beauty of the Commonwealth as required by the Constitution&#39;s Environmental Rights Amendment.</p>

<p>Between now and Election Day, Nov. 6, both candidates need to tell Pennsylvanians how they intend to fulfill that legal responsibility.</p>

<p>The primary season has not given us much of a preview of either of the candidates&#39; environmental and conservation agendas.</p>

<p>Wagner&#39;s campaign website contains no mention of environmental policy except indirectly - he pledges to roll back &quot;overregulation.&quot;</p>

<p>His trash hauling company, Penn Waste, has incurred fines from at least 30 violations of environmental regulations. He has <a href=""http://www.politifact.com/pennsylvania/statements/2017/mar/31/scott-wagner/pa-gopers-climate-change-theory-debunked-nope-not-/"" target=""_blank"">publicly addressed climate change</a>, attributing it to the earth moving ever closer to the sun and the increasing body heat from a growing population.</p>

<p>Environmental policy took a back seat during Governor Wolf&#39;s first term. There were a few bright spots.</p>

<p>In the politically complex forum of the Delaware River Basin Commission, Wolf voted with the governors of Delaware and New York in favor of a resolution to place a permanent ban on fracking in the Delaware watershed.</p>

<p>He also signed bipartisan legislation that will put the Pennsylvania solar industry on an equal competitive footing with solar businesses in other states, a welcome recognition of the economic development potential of the clean energy sector.</p>

<p>But neither candidate has laid out anything near a vision or plan for how he will protect Pennsylvania&#39;s air and water now; and what he can do to conserve our natural resources for our grandchildren.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Other governors have achieved landmark conservation and environmental protections.</p>

<p>The late Gov. Robert P Casey Sr.&#39;s administration successfully promoted one of the first significant investments in conservation with Key 93, a $100 million conservation bond and a permanent fund, the Keystone Recreation, Park and Conservation Fund, which gets its revenue from a portion of the real estate transfer tax.</p>

<p>Former Gov. Tom Ridge created Growing Greener, funded by a fee on garbage dumped at landfills, that provides grants to local organizations for conservation, watershed restoration and recreation projects</p>

<p>Ex-Gov. Ed Rendell signed the first legislation requiring energy suppliers to obtain 18 percent of their power from renewable and alternative energy supplies.</p>

<p>Rendell successfully campaigned for $625 Growing Greener II bond which was overwhelmingly approved by voters, and issued the $650 million Alternative Energy Investment bond, the largest bond for any purpose in state history.</p>

<p>The next governor faces a daunting list of environmental challenges.</p>

<p>The air in many parts of Pennsylvania is among the worse in the nation. We have thousands of miles of streams and rivers which do not support fish or provide clean drinking water.</p>

<p>The legacy of unregulated historic coal mining has left us with 180,000 acres of unproductive, dangerous and ugly polluted land that holds back economic development in coal communities. And Pennsylvania remains a major global source of the pollution that is disrupting the climate.</p>

<p>Neither Wolf nor Wagner will be able to adequately address these problems without a Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) that is fully staffed, adequately funded and independent of political pressure.</p>

<p>The Environmental Rights Amendment puts the responsibility of safeguarding our air, water and future environmental quality squarely at the doorstep of the Commonwealth.</p>

<p>The Department of Environmental Protection is the state agency charged with carrying out most of those responsibilities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The good news is that solutions to our environmental problems abound. Both candidates can find a comprehensive list of policy options in the <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/CCA_2nd-Edition_Web-Version-6.1.18.pdf"" target=""_blank""><u><strong>Pennsylvania Common Conservation Agenda</strong></u></a> that contains ideas from 25 of the Commonwealth&#39;s environmental and conservation organizations.</p>

<p>Both candidates for governor will be bound by the Environmental Rights Amendment to protect our air and water and leave our grandchildren an environment that is at least as good as we now enjoy.</p>

<p>They owe the voters their plans for how they will carry out that duty.</p>

<p><em><strong>Jan Jarrett, a former head of the environmental group, PennFuture, is the principal of Ad Hoc LLC. She writes from Harrisburg.</strong></em></p>
",,
A New Strategy for Sparking Environmental Leadership in Pennsylvania,5/29/2018,"<div>I&rsquo;m sure many of you, like me, are thinking very hard these days about how to cross the divide between our personal views toward our planet&rsquo;s future, and those held by people with very different views. How can an issue like a safe and healthy environment be viewed as a special interest, when such an issue is in everyone&rsquo;s interest?&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>That&rsquo;s the question PennFuture and 25 of our colleague organizations took up this past winter as we sat down to craft the <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Updated-Final-Version-of-the-PA-Common-Conservation-Agenda-5.1.18.pdf"" target=""_blank"">Pennsylvania Common Conservation Agenda, </a>released this month. </strong>Our goal with the document was to first unite our diverse movement under the banner of the Common Agenda, a document that set forth a nonpartisan, pragmatic and achievable path forward to make real progress &ndash; and in a pretty short time period &ndash; toward clean air, pure water and a healthy climate, so our state can prosper and our economy thrive.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The second question we asked ourselves was, in addition to getting our diverse community to agree on a common agenda, what did the Common Agenda need to look like for the highest elected official in our state &ndash; our governor &ndash; to find his way into parts of it and provide the kind of leadership the people of Pennsylvania are asking for?&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Lastly, to the end of political leadership, we decided the platform for opportunity and influence was the upcoming campaign for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s governor and getting the candidates&rsquo; embrace of the agenda our aim. And so, to support the Common Agenda, <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/greenin18"" target=""_blank""><u><strong>we have launched PennFuture&rsquo;s Green in &rsquo;18 campaign</strong></u></a>. More on that in a moment.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<ol>
	<li>Strengthening the 21st century workforce through green jobs;</li>
	<li>Championing the great waters of Pennsylvania from source to tap;</li>
	<li>Providing the PA Department of Environmental Protection and the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources with sufficient resources to fulfill their missions;</li>
	<li>Improving the Department of Environmental Protection&rsquo;s ability to protect the public from the threats posed by natural gas and petrochemical infrastructure;</li>
	<li>Ensuring environment justice for vulnerable communities;</li>
	<li>Boosting current investments in the Growing Greener program, which protects our forests and farmland, restores watersheds and saves wildlife habitat; and</li>
	<li>Bolstering the state&rsquo;s clean energy sector.</li>
</ol>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The Common Agenda has knitted together the environmental community, and is attracting new endorsers every day as business and other groups sign on to support it.&nbsp; The solutions it presents were crafted to appeal to a broad cross section of our state, regardless of political affiliation, geographic location, urban or rural settings &ndash; and to appeal to the gubernatorial candidates.&nbsp; <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/green18/index.html"" target=""_blank""><strong>Join in to help shine a brighter spotlight on these important environmental solutions today.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></a></div>
",Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"

<p>The rally is calling for increased clean water funding as state budget talks begin to ramp up in the coming weeks in Harrisburg. In Pennsylvania, there is no dedicated fund for clean water, and the PA Department of Environmental Protection has had its budget slashed 40 percent over the last 15 years.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;Ensuring clean, safe drinking water is vital to all Pennsylvanians. Proposed cuts to existing funding streams that support the Susquehanna and its rivers and streams would be detrimental to families across the state,&rdquo; said Mariah Davis, Field Manager for the Choose Clean Water Coalition. &ldquo;Our aim is to empower environmental advocates and citizens through collective action so that their voices are heard, and our natural resources have improved protection.&rdquo;</p>
