"Philadelphia’s Green City, Clean Waters Needs Funding to Achieve Goals",5/29/2018,"<p>Philadelphia is known as a leader when it comes to using rain gardens, tree trenches, and green roofs to reduce stormwater overflows that pollute local waterways.&nbsp;These practices and others, known as <strong>green stormwater infrastructure</strong>, allow water to naturally soak into soil or evaporate into the air without carrying pollutants into our streams and rivers. At the same time, they provide residents with cleaner air, more attractive parks and streets, and a healthier community.</p>

<p><strong>Philadelphia committed itself to accomplishing significant stormwater overflow reductions through a 25-year plan focused on green practices, known as the Green City, Clean Waters.</strong>&nbsp;In the first five years of the program, Philadelphia surpassed the expectations set for the program, creating over 800 &ldquo;greened acres&rdquo; across the city.&nbsp;Some of these projects have taken place on public property, such as the Mill Creek Playground where basketball courts were retrofitted with porous asphalt over an infiltration bed or Liberty Lands Park where a rain garden detention pond was installed to collect runoff from the site and an adjacent street.&nbsp;But from its beginning, Green City, Clean Waters contemplated the necessity of private development and investment in the success of the program.&nbsp;The Philadelphia Water Department has encouraged private investment in green stormwater infrastructure through regulatory changes&mdash;for example all new and/or redevelopment sites disturbing more than 15,000 square feet of earth must to infiltrate, retain, or treat the first inch of stormwater&mdash;as well as through grant incentive programs like the Stormwater Management Incentive Program (SMIP) and Greened Acre Retrofit Program (GARP).&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>These grant programs provide funding to private land owners and developers for the construction of stormwater retrofit projects on private property.&nbsp;This allows the Philadelphia Water Department to take compliance credit for greened acres on private project sites that would otherwise be inaccessible to the agency and at a cheaper price than it would cost the Philadelphia Water Department to build equivalent projects on public property.&nbsp;These programs are so successful that the Philadelphia Water Department is asking the Philadelphia Water, Sewer, and Stormwater Rate Board to increase the Department&rsquo;s budget for these programs.</p>

<p>PennFuture, along with the Natural Resource Defense Council, <a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/20180525-PF---NRDC-comments-on-2018-rate-proceeding.pdf""><u><strong>submitted comments to the Rate Board</strong></u></a> detailing the importance of Green City, Clean Waters, the grant incentive programs, and predictable funding to the Philadelphia Water Department to be able to achieve its goals. We look forward to continuing this work. Please follow our blogs for upcoming updates.</p>
",Environment; Keep Philly Green & Water Clean,"Alice R. Baker, Senior Staff Attorney"
What the Volkswagen Settlement Means for PA,5/18/2018,"<p>Back in 2014, it was discovered that certain diesel Volkswagen vehicles met the required emissions standards during the official Federal Test Procedure, but produced almost 40 times the smog-forming oxides of Nitrogen (NOx), when driven on the road.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Eventually, Volkswagen admitted to installing an illegal &ldquo;defeat device&rdquo; on 11 million vehicles that would deactivate the emissions controls when it sensed the car wasn&rsquo;t being tested.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The ensuing worldwide scandal resulted in a number of criminal charges and civil suits.&nbsp;In the U.S. alone, the company has agreed to pay around $20 billion in penalties and settlements.&nbsp;One part of these settlements is known as the &ldquo;Environmental Mitigation Trust.&rdquo;&nbsp;It&rsquo;s&nbsp; a pool of money intended to mitigate the damages from pollution caused by these vehicles.&nbsp;<a href=""https://pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-Statement-New-State-Program-Will-Advance-Clean-Air-Projects"" target=""_blank""><strong>Out of that pool, Pennsylvania has been allocated a little over $118.5 million.</strong></a></p>

<p>This is not the same as the $30.4 million settlement Pennsylvania Attorney General Josh Shapiro announced in March of 2017.&nbsp;While that was also intended to mitigate environmental damages, the Legislature -- through last year&rsquo;s fiscal code -- required that money be deposited in the General Fund, and it&rsquo;s not clear how that has benefited the environment.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Environmental Mitigation Trust program works a bit differently.&nbsp;Here, the PA Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) is the lead agency and they will review proposed projects, certify if they meet the conditions of the State Trust Agreement, and request funds for specific eligible projects.</p>

<p>The DEP has made its Beneficiary Mitigation Plan available online, but they have not yet announced that the program is open for applications.&nbsp;Still, it&rsquo;s not too early to start thinking about potential projects.&nbsp;<strong>Funding will be available for reducing emissions in the following ten categories:</strong></p>

<ol>
	<li>Class 8 Local Trucks and Port Drayage Trucks</li>
	<li>Class 4-8 School Busses, Shuttle Busses, or Transit Busses</li>
	<li>Railroad Freight Switcher Locomotives</li>
	<li>Ferries/Tugs</li>
	<li>Ocean Going Vessels Shorepower</li>
	<li>Class 4-7 Local Freight Trucks</li>
	<li>Airport Ground Support Equipment</li>
	<li>Forklifts</li>
	<li>Light-Duty Zero Emission Vehicle Supply Equipment</li>
	<li>Matching funds for projects eligible under the Diesel Emission Reduction Act</li>
</ol>

<p>Within these categories, the DEP has said that &ldquo;consideration will be given to distributing project funding statewide, as appropriate, primarily based on the cost-effectiveness and the quantity of NOX emission reductions.&rdquo; While replacing fossil fuel engines with electric alternatives will probably result in the largest overall emissions reductions, this focus primarily on NOx emissions will mean that many of the funded projects could involve replacing or retrofitting diesel engines with natural gas engines.</p>

<p><strong>While there likely are cases where natural gas engines are the best available choice for a given application, PennFuture has encouraged the DEP to look beyond just the dollars per ton of NOx removed.</strong>&nbsp;Instead, we have asked that it puts more emphasis on projects that will build clean energy infrastructure or otherwise speed the market transformation to electric vehicles and other cleaner alternatives.&nbsp;This would be in keeping with the DEP&rsquo;s trust responsibility under Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Environmental Rights Amendment.</p>

<p>Hopefully, DEP will take this advice, but this likely isn&rsquo;t something it can make happen on their own.&nbsp;We need companies and individuals considering electric vehicles, EV infrastructure, or similar projects to apply for funding as soon as it becomes available.&nbsp;We don&rsquo;t know how long this pool of money will last, but when it&rsquo;s gone so is the opportunity.</p>

<p><strong><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/newsletter-sign-up"" target=""_blank"">Stay tuned on this issue by joining PennFuture&#39;s email list</a>, as we will continue to keep the public updated on further developments.</strong></p>
",Environment,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
Protect Your Forests: 2018 Farm Bill Update,5/16/2018,"<p>Sustainable agriculture, forestry, and clean water take center stage this week as the Farm Bill debates begin in the House of Representatives in Washington, D.C.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Farm Bill is the largest federal source of conservation funding on private and public land. Over the past half-century, the Farm Bill has done much to support landowners and farmers in Pennsylvania who want to improve water quality and conserve wildlife habitat on their lands. The current Farm Bill&rsquo;s (Agriculture and Nutrition Act of 2014) authorization expires at the end of September, and the legislation currently under consideration would provide funding through 2023.</p>

<p>The House is poised to push through and vote on the House version of the Farm Bill later this week. In what is typically a bipartisan effort to craft legislation to help our farmers, low-income communities, and conservation work every four years, <strong>this bill is ideological and harmful.</strong> It is problematic due to its cuts in protections and funding for the environment and conservation along with draconian work requirements for recipients of the SNAP program.</p>

<p><strong>The Agriculture and Nutrition Act of 2018 (H.R. 2) is replete with attacks on bedrock environmental laws and America&rsquo;s national forests.</strong> The House Farm Bill includes numerous categorical exemptions from public input and environmental review on forestry projects and incentivizes logging over clean water, recreation, and wildlife. Further, H.R. 2 undermines the National Environmental Policy Act.</p>

<p>The bill goes back on a long-sought-after and hard-won bipartisan fire funding compromise signed into law only a few months ago as a part of the Fiscal Year 2018 Omnibus Appropriations Act. This partisan, one-sided farm bill goes on to attack the Roadless Area Conservation Rule by creating a loophole that allows logging and costly road-building in protected and precious roadless forest areas, such as parts of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Allegheny National Forest in the northwest.&nbsp;</p>

<p>H.R. 2 also attacks the Endangered Species Act by removing a requirement for expert consultation regarding endangered species and critical habitat. We need the Forest Service to consider how water, soil, and wildlife are affected by large-scale projects &ndash; not cut back on protections and reviews to favor the industry. We must keep public lands in public hands. All Americans deserve a say in how these lands are managed, not just those out to make a buck.</p>

<p>As it stands, the House bill&rsquo;s conservation title is a solid start, but it could be stronger. We are pleased with the five million acre increase in the conservation reserve program, the increase in funding for the easement program and the continuation of the Regional Conservation Partnership Program. However, the bill cuts nearly $800 million from the conservation title over a ten-year period&mdash;this funding needs to be restored.</p>

<p><strong>Please ask your Member of Congress and Senators <a href=""https://www.casey.senate.gov/"" target=""_blank"">Bob Casey</a> and <a href=""https://www.toomey.senate.gov/"" target=""_blank"">Pat Toomey</a> to oppose the House Farm Bill (H.R. 2) federal forestry provisions and to speak out publicly against the egregious attacks on American&rsquo;s wild national forests. </strong>We ask that our Representatives and Senators work towards a bipartisan bill with strong forestry and conservation titles that are free from provisions that will put in jeopardy our lands, water, and wildlife.&nbsp;</p>

<p><em><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/newsletter-sign-up"" target=""_blank"">Stay tuned for more on the Farm Bill</a> as we track it closely and will provide updates often over the coming months.</em></p>
",Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
A Recap of the 2018 PA Clean Water Lobby Day,5/14/2018,"<p>PennFuture recently teamed up with our partners from the Chose Clean Water Coalition (CCWC) and the Coalition for the Delaware River Watershed (CDRW) to stand side by side to address an issue critical to us all: clean water.</p>

<p>In total, 26 members from our groups came together April 30 during the PA Clean Water Lobby Day to educate lawmakers in a great series of meetings which highlighted the importance of clean water.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Throughout the day, our discussions with elected officials centered around Pennsylvania&rsquo;s need for a dedicated clean water fund, proper funding for our state resource agencies like the Department of Environmental Protection, the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, and the Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture, and asking that Pennsylvania&nbsp;start doing its fair share of fully funding our state water basin commissions,&nbsp;such as the Susquehanna River Basin Commission, Delaware River Basin Commission, Interstate Commission for the Potomac River Basin, and the Ohio River Sanitary Authority Commission.</p>

<p>The day was a huge success, thanks in large part to&nbsp;the phenomenal advocates and professionals we work alongside. But, this time next year, we want to think bigger and better. Our goal is to have environmental advocates from&nbsp; throughout the Commonwealth unite in the Capitol Main Rotunda with the singular message of protecting life&rsquo;s most precious natural resource: water.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We want to thank the speakers who came out and expressed what clean water means to them, including:&nbsp;Marel King of Chesapeake Bay Commission, Rep. Mike Sturla, 96th District, Member of the Chesapeake Bay Commission, Rep. Leanne Krueger-Braneky, Delaware - 161st Legislative District, PennFuture President and CEO Jacquelyn&nbsp;Bonomo, Mariah Davis, Field Manager &ndash; Choose Clean Water Coalition,&nbsp; Madeline Emde, State Policy Manager &ndash; Coalition for the Delaware River Watershed,&nbsp;Stephanie Wein, Water &amp; Conservation Advocate &ndash; PennEnvironment,&nbsp; and&nbsp;Jackson, Clean Water Supply Associate&nbsp; &ndash; American Rivers. We&rsquo;ll see you next year!</p>

The New Tax Law and Charitable Giving,5/14/2018,"<div><em>Note: The information presented here is for educational and informational purposes only. Please consult your personal financial advisor and/or attorney on all legal, tax, or financial issues related to your charitable giving.&nbsp;</em></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Since the tax law changes in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act passed last year, there has been much discussion about how it will affect charitable giving. Some have even speculated that the changes will greatly hurt nonprofit organizations, such as PennFuture, who rely on your support. This doesn&rsquo;t have to be the case.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The <strong>good news</strong> is that there are key tax code provisions which will continue to <strong>impact charitable giving in favorable ways.</strong> You can still enjoy important tax benefits while meeting your charitable goals.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>How the new tax cuts affect you depends on many factors, including family size, available deductions, and income. And, of course, <strong>you need to talk with your own financial advisors.</strong> But, here is a brief overview of the key provisions of the new tax law and how it affects charitable giving this year.&nbsp;</div>

<ul>
	<li>The standard deduction increases substantially and fewer people will itemize their taxes. The result? <em><strong>Taxpayers can still realize charitable giving goals and some donors will have even more discretionary funds available for planning.</strong></em></li>
	<li>The amount of charitable cash contributions that can be deducted in any particular year has been increased from 50 percent&nbsp;of adjusted gross income to 60 percent&nbsp;of adjusted gross income. <strong>This is particularly helpful for donors making a large, legacy-shaping gift.</strong></li>
	<li><strong>Donor Advised Funds</strong> were not affected by the new law, which means contributions to these funds continue to be deductible when made. Donors can select the timing and amounts of gifts that are made from the fund, just as they have in the past.</li>
	<li>Gifts of retirement assets (including <strong>charitable distributions from an IRA for those age 70&frac12; or over</strong>) remain particularly attractive charitable giving options. The new tax law passed in December 2017 did not change the popular gift option known as the <strong>IRA Charitable Rollover</strong>&mdash;a charitable distribution from your IRA directly to PennFuture. This is good news for IRA owners age 70&frac12; and over who must take a required minimum distribution from their IRA and also want to support our work in 2018. You can use your IRA to make a meaningful gift now and avoid taxes on the IRA distribution. It&rsquo;s easy to do.
	<ul>
		<li>Instruct your IRA custodian to make a distribution directly to PennFuture. The distribution counts toward your required minimum distribution (RMD).</li>
		<li>Although there is no tax deduction, the distribution is excluded from your income for federal tax purposes&mdash;<strong>no tax is due!</strong></li>
		<li>Up to $100,000 of your gift qualifies for this favorable tax treatment.</li>
		<li>Your gift makes an immediate impact<strong>&mdash;<strong>there is no need to wait until the end of the year!</strong></strong></li>
	</ul>
	</li>
	<li>For many of our friends, moving beyond the &ldquo;basic&rdquo; gift planning options makes it possible to experience even greater personal benefits. For example, <strong>there are two reasons why a gift of stock may be more advantageous than a gift of cash.</strong>
	<ul>
		<li>There is no capital gains tax due on the appreciated amount.</li>
		<li>The full amount of the gift qualifies for an itemized tax deduction.</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
</ul>

<div>Please let us know how we might help you and your advisors explore charitable strategies under the new law. You can always call me directly at 717-214-7924, or email me at <a href=""mailto:dinicola@pennfuture.org"">dinicola@pennfuture.org</a>.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>Thank you! Your continued support for PennFuture&rsquo;s mission makes a lasting difference.&nbsp;</strong></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><em>For gifts of stock, IRA rollovers, and planned giving, PennFuture&rsquo;s legal name is &ldquo;Citizen&rsquo;s for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Future.&rdquo; Our EIN# is 31-1607866, and mailing address is 610 N. Third St. Harrisburg, PA 17101.&nbsp;</em></div>
",Environment,"M. Travis DiNicola, Director of Development"
Introducing the Pennsylvania Common Conservation Agenda and the Green In ’18 Campaign,5/1/2018,"<p><img alt="""" src=""/Files/Admin/green%2Din%2D18%2Dweb%2Dlogo%2D%2D4%2Ejpg"" style=""width: 650px; height: 175px;"" /></p>

<p><a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-From-the-CEO-PennFuture-Priorities-in-2018"" target=""_blank"">In a December 2017 blog post about PennFuture&rsquo;s 2018 priorities</a>, President and CEO Jacquelyn Bonomo wrote, &ldquo;As part of our new civic engagement program, PennFuture will launch its Green In &rsquo;18 campaign. The campaign will elevate the public discussion around environmental issues in the upcoming elections.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Since then, PennFuture has been working with 20+ environmental, land, air, and water groups and organizations to identify the biggest environment challenges facing Pennsylvania.</strong> <strong>As a result, this coalition has created and agreed upon the most promising policy solutions to these threats. This process led to the creation of the <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Updated-Final-Version-of-the-PA-Common-Conservation-Agenda-5.1.18.pdf"" target=""_blank""><u>first-ever Pennsylvania Common Conservation Agenda</u></a>, a blueprint for restoring and preserving our life-sustaining natural resources.</strong></p>

<p>Not only do these solutions promote a healthier environment and a stronger economy, they are publicly popular, fiscally responsible, and can be enacted by our next Governor using his or her executive authority.&nbsp;In virtually every instance, increases in state spending will be offset through job growth, revenue growth, energy savings, and/or lower healthcare costs.</p>

<p><strong>The agenda was released today during a press conference in Harrisburg, and it will be shared with all&nbsp;candidates running to be Pennsylvania&rsquo;s next governor.</strong>&nbsp;<a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/Updated-Final-Version-of-the-PA-Common-Conservation-Agenda-5.1.18.pdf"" target=""_blank""><u><strong>Click here to read it</strong></u></a> and to find out how you can <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/greenin18"" target=""_blank""><u><strong>get involved in the Green in &rsquo;18 campaign</strong></u></a>, which is mobilizing citizens to elevate environmental issues and the policy solutions within the agenda for all candidates running for governor.</p>

<p><em><strong>Why the candidates?</strong></em> We believe the upcoming gubernatorial election represents is an ideal time to push for changes in the state&rsquo;s priorities and policies for safeguarding the environment. So, during the election cycle, coalition members will be taking this agenda to the gubernatorial candidates and urging each one to enact our recommendations if they are elected.</p>

<p><em><strong>Easy, right? </strong></em>If only. In reality, it&rsquo;s going to take more than our efforts alone to get the candidates to consider and ultimately implement our agenda. It&rsquo;s also going to require a groundswell of support from Pennsylvania voters, speaking out on several crucial issues. But while the majority of Pennsylvania citizens think the state should do more to safeguard the environment (<a href=""https://www.fandm.edu/uploads/files/708725106986767486-f-m-poll-release-march-2018.pdf"" target=""_blank"">see results of March 2018 Franklin and Marshall College Poll</a>), the environment is one of many issues voters consider important. To make sure the environment is front and center in the minds of&nbsp;citizens and all of the candidates, <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/greenin18"" target=""_blank""><u><strong>we will be backing the agenda with the Green In &rsquo;18 campaign.</strong></u></a></p>

<p><strong>PennFuture&rsquo;s new Green in &lsquo;18 campaign will be reaching out to citizens, community groups, and businesses to let them know about the policy solutions we are advocating as a coalition. </strong>We have a simple message: a healthy environment is best for everyone in Pennsylvania&mdash;children, families, workers, retirees, businesses&mdash;now and those yet to come. And the Common Conservation Agenda is the most feasible way to restore and preserve our state&rsquo;s environment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Through this process, we hope to increase the urgency of environmental issues in citizens&#39; minds, earn their support for the agenda, and motivate them to attend candidates&rsquo; events to ask those candidates where they stand on the environment, what their plans are to safeguard our air, land, and water, and whether they support the agenda. This is the type of pressure that will force the candidates to address our concerns and prioritize clean air, pure water, and a healthy climate.</p>

<p><em><strong>How can you get involved? </strong></em>For our movement to succeed, we need friends of the environment like you to volunteer to help with the Green In &rsquo;18 campaign. <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/green18/index.html"" target=""_blank""><u><strong>You can fill out the form available here to get started.&nbsp;</strong></u></a></p>

<p>This is a pivotal moment for the environment in Pennsylvania. The threats have never been more urgent. But thanks to the election calendar, the surging resistance to the status quo among citizens, and the unprecedented unification among conservation organizations in the state, the prospects for difference-making action have never been more positive. By building an army of volunteers&nbsp;committed to rising up for the environment and the Common Conservation Agenda, we believe our cause will be successful. Please join us.</p>

<p><strong><em>Please visit <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/greenin18"" target=""_blank"">www.GreenIn18.org </a>for more information. You can also <a href=""https://www.facebook.com/PAGreenin18/"" target=""_blank"">like us on Facebook</a> and <a href=""https://twitter.com/PAGreenIn18"" target=""_blank"">follow us on Twitter.</a></em></strong></p>

What Act 40 Means for Solar Energy in PA,4/26/2018,"<p><em><strong>UPDATE:&nbsp;PUC&rsquo;s final implementation order on the solar borders issue was released May 3. <a href=""http://www.puc.pa.gov/pcdocs/1565100.docx"" target=""_blank"">Click here to read more.&nbsp;</a></strong></em></p>

<p><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/News-Pennsylvania-Public-Utility-Commission-Removes-Barriers-to-Solar-Growth"">On Thursday, April 19, the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission (PUC) took an important step forward</a> and removed a long-standing barrier that kept solar projects from being built in Pennsylvania. In a unanimous vote, the PUC implemented the bipartisan Act 40 to require solar-credited projects under the state Alternative Energy Portfolio Standard (AEPS) be built in Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>While Pennsylvania is traditionally a leader on developing and installing new energy sources, we have been lagging behind surrounding states when it comes to deploying solar energy.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania ranked 19th behind Massachusetts, New York, New Jersey, Maryland, and Ohio in the most recent <a href=""https://www.thesolarfoundation.org/national/""><strong>Solar Jobs Report.</strong></a>&nbsp;The Commonwealth is ranked 39th in solar jobs per capita. Massachusetts alone had about three times more solar jobs than Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>There are a number of reasons why Pennsylvania lags behind.&nbsp;One issue is that the solar alternative energy credit program (SAEC*) part of our AEPS has much lower targets than many nearby states. Pennsylvania requires 0.5% solar energy by 2021 compared to 4.1% by 2028 in New Jersey, 2.5% by 2020 in Maryland, and 8.4% by 2030 in New York.&nbsp;Compounding the problem, Pennsylvania was one of the only states in the region with &ldquo;open borders&rdquo; that allowed solar from anywhere on our electric grid -- encompassing 13 surrounding states and the District of Columbia -- to be used for compliance.&nbsp;This lowered the value of SAECs in the state, meaning solar jobs went elsewhere.&nbsp;According to the most recent AEPS report, more than 60% of SAECs in 2017 came from out of state.</p>

<p>Last December, Governor Wolf signed into law Act 40, a bipartisan bill that requires solar-credited projects to be built in Pennsylvania. Unfortunately, the PUC originally proposed to implement the bill in a way that would make it almost completely ineffective and still allow projects to be sourced outside of the state. This changed last week when all five PUC commissioners voted in favor of a joint statement by Chairman Brown and Vice Chairman Place that reversed that decision.</p>

<p>Going forward, new credits must now come from facilities connected to Pennsylvania&rsquo;s distribution system. Specifically, Act 40 changes the following depending on when a solar project was credited under the AEPS:</p>

<p><img alt="""" src=""/Files/Admin/solarblog%2Ejpg"" style=""width: 671px; height: 389px;"" /></p>

<p><strong>What does this mean for the value of my SAECs?</strong></p>

<p>Since Act 40 was signed by the governor, SAEC prices have risen from about $6 to around $11, but it&rsquo;s unclear how much of that is attributable to the change in law.&nbsp; Because a relatively large amount of credits are banked, most in the industry are not expecting to see the full impact of this rule for at least two more years.&nbsp; Still, Act 40 is a good start and will lead to more solar projects in Pennsylvania in the coming years.</p>

<p><strong>Next Steps</strong></p>

<p>Now that we have taken a step in the right direction, Pennsylvania should make the commitment to becoming a solar leader. We have a lot of tools at our disposal to get there; some things to consider include:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Increasing the AEPS solar target to be more in line with surrounding states.</li>
	<li>Enabling Community Solar so families and businesses that can&rsquo;t install their own solar panels have meaningful access to solar.</li>
	<li>Encouraging more and better financing options for solar.</li>
	<li>Making sure solar gets the same state tax benefits that fossil fuel projects enjoy.</li>
	<li>Ensuring energy purchases fully account for public health and environmental costs.</li>
</ul>

<p>PennFuture is working with the PA DEP, US Department of Energy, industry experts, and over 450 stakeholders to evaluate options like these, but even the best ideas are not going to get implemented without strong public support.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><em>*SAECs are commonly called a Solar Renewable Energy Credits or &ldquo;SRECs.&quot;</em></p>
",Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
Public Comment Closes on DRBC Fracking Regulations,4/24/2018,"<p>On March 30, the Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC) closed its four-month public comment period on proposed regulations of fracking and fracking-related activities.&nbsp;The DRBC received 227 oral comments over six&nbsp;public hearings, and over 8,600 written comments, which includes petitions in favor of the proposed ban signed by tens of thousands of individuals.&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/2018-03-30-PennFuture-Comments-on-DRBC-Fracking-Draft-Regulations.pdf"">PennFuture&rsquo;s comments to the DRBC</a> strongly supported the proposed prohibition on fracking within the Basin, and called on the DRBC to strengthen its proposed regulations on both water withdrawals for fracking outside of the Basin and the transport, storage, treatment, and disposal of fracking wastewater within the Basin. If those regulations cannot be strengthened in order to protect the Delaware River water resources, then the DRBC must not allow these activities to occur.&nbsp;Like PennFuture, it appears that a good number of commenters supported the fracking ban, yet called for stronger regulations of those fracking-related activities to protect our waters.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The majority of the public comments received called for a full ban on all fracking-related activities, including water withdrawals and wastewater treatment. However, there was a large contingent of comments that opposed the proposed ban on fracking, lead primarily by gas industry interests.&nbsp;All written comments received by the DRBC are available for review and download <a href=""http://www.nj.gov/drbc/meetings/proposed/notice_hydraulic-fracturing.html"">through the DRBC&rsquo;s website.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>The DRBC has no set deadline by which they must make their final decisions to adopt, modify, or reject the proposed fracking regulations. This final decision, however, is likely to take several months, if not longer.&nbsp;The DRBC must not only review each comment in their decision-making process, but must also draft a written comment response document that responds to each type of comment (not each individual comment) submitted.&nbsp;During its review of the comments, DRBC will likely consult with experts and may even possibly conduct additional research.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>The DRBC&rsquo;s responses and recommendations will then be submitted to the five Commissioners for a vote. Assuming no changes to the proposed regulations, it seems likely that the regulations will be adopted by the Commissioners, who include the governors of the four Basin states and a representative of the U.S. government.&nbsp;The governors of Pennsylvania, Delaware, and New York had previously voted to propose the regulations, and the new governor of New Jersey has expressed his support for the fracking ban, making a 4-1 vote in favor of adopting the proposed regulations the most likely outcome.&nbsp;</p>

<p>What this all seems to foreshadow is that, regardless of what the DRBC&rsquo;s final adopted regulations do, there will be legal challenges. If the DRBC adopts the regulations as proposed, it&rsquo;s likely that they will receive challenges from both sides of the aisle &ndash; environmentalists and anti-fracking supporters arguing the regulations didn&rsquo;t go far enough to protect the Delaware River water resources and industry, and pro-fracking supporters arguing that the regulations go too far.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>During the pendency of any legal challenges to the DRBC&rsquo;s final regulations regarding fracking in the Basin, the &ldquo;<a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Moratorium-on-Fracking-in-the-Delaware-River-Basin-is-Critical-to-Protect-Our-Water"">de facto moratorium</a>&rdquo; on fracking that has been in place since 2010 will most likely continue, thereby protecting the Delaware River Basin while the issue makes its way through the courts.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>In the end, PennFuture is confident that fracking will not be allowed to jeopardize our water, environment, and health within the Delaware River Basin. PennFuture remains committed to protecting the Delaware River Basin and will keep you updated as this matter moves forward. <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/newsletter-sign-up"">Please click here to subscribe to our emails for regular updates on this issue.</a></p>
",Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Building a Community Clean Water Toolbox: How PA Will Meet its Goals,4/23/2018,"<p>On April 10, nearly 200 leaders from county conservation districts, agriculture, municipal governments, environmental groups, water companies, and other entities participated in a workshop focused around the state plan for improving water quality in Pennsylvania&rsquo;s portion of the Chesapeake Bay Watershed.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Participants shared their expertise and aided in the development of the Community Clean Water Toolbox to draft policy and suggestions to help Pennsylvania meet its Total Maximum Pollution Reduction (TMDL) goals by 2025.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>During the conference, the group learned about planning, engagement, resource, tracking, and implementation tools that would be available to counties for developing and implementing action plans to reduce pollution runoff into our waterways. The areas in focus for initial pilot development are Lancaster, York, Adams, and Franklin County. These counties will lead the way in development and create their action plans by October. After the initial toolbox is created and implemented in these counties, it will then be further modified (as needed) for use by the other counties in the Commonwealth.&nbsp;</p>

<p>From this meeting, there are a few points that everyone took home: We need more community engagement, Lancaster County has the most opportunity for pollution reduction in the Commonwealth, and forested riparian buffers are the most cost-effective way of meeting our pollution reduction goals.</p>

<p>In terms of community engagement, it will play a critical role in the state&rsquo;s ability to meet its goals for the plan. The PA Department of Environmental Protection will not be enforcing compliance through regulatory oversight; instead, its aim is to have counties use the numbers presented to them to define pollution reduction goals and identify existing and proposed local initiatives that can be used to help meet them. The end game is having a county-level approach that will lead Pennsylvania in attaining its pollution reduction goals&nbsp;</p>

<p>The second major takeaway from the event centered on the amount of nutrient and sediment runoff in Lancaster County. Due to the lack of trees in the county, and the amount of populated areas coupled with the abundance of farming, Lancaster has earned a reputation as a major load-producing geography that contributes to the condition of the Chesapeake Bay. Because of this, a major focus of the Watershed Implementation Plan Steering Committee is looking at Lancaster and York County as sites for &ldquo;pilot&rdquo; programs that will implement these best management practices (BMP), and then modify them as necessary after the Phase III WIP is set into motion.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Lastly, the Steering Committee showcased a study that indicated riparian buffers to be the most cost-efficient and results-driven form of BMP that can be implemented. Riparian buffers are patches of vegetation and trees surrounding a stream or body of water that helps shade and protect the stream from the impacts of adjacent land uses. Implementing riparian buffers throughout the Commonwealth will aide in the restoration of streams by protecting the fish and inhabitants of the water and provide a natural balance to the ecosystem, because they absorb runoff and cool the temperature of the creeks and streams.</p>

<p>As great as these initiatives are, there is still work that needs to be done. Pennsylvania still remains nearly 60 percent behind schedule for the TMDL, funding sources for implementing clean water projects still seems out of reach, and we are woefully underperforming compared to our neighboring states. However, the leadership shown at this conference is a step in the right direction. Now comes the difficult part &ndash; translating this down to the local level and installing BMP&rsquo;s on time to meet our state goals.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Taylor Nezat, Campaign Manager for Watershed Advocacy, PennFuture"
Meet PennFuture's Director of Development: M. Travis DiNicola,4/16/2018,"<div>When you think back on your favorite memories, how many of them took place outdoors?&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>With most of my memories, I don&rsquo;t recall just the places and people that made a moment special, but the atmosphere. I remember the season&mdash;the rain, the snow, the warmth or coolness of the air. And I remember the light.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>About two years ago when my wife and I decided to move back to Pennsylvania to be closer to our families, she asked me what part of coming home was I most excited about. I told her that all of my best memories of summer took place in Pennsylvania. There is something about the atmosphere here that is very special.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Growing up in Erie, I was fortunate to spend much of my youth exploring Presque Isle: going on hikes with my grandfather, biking the trails, windsurfing on the lake, fishing on the bay, canoeing the inlets, and of course, hanging out with friends on the beaches. Presque Isle was my playground. It was there that I discovered my passion for flying stunt kites&mdash;a passion I continue to enjoy today when I fly my kites off the edge of City Island in the middle of the mighty Susquehanna.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>After studying theatre and dance as an undergrad and then art and museum education as a graduate student at Penn State, my career took me to Indianapolis. For 20 years, I worked in many capacities there as a champion of mission-based organizations, including arts, education, and community-service groups. I emceed a number of events for environmental organizations, and hosted a monthly &ldquo;climate-change quiz-show&rdquo; for a few years at a local theatre.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>I am most proud of the 10 years I spent as the Executive Director of Indy Reads, an adult literacy program. During my tenure, I created Indy Reads Books, a nonprofit bookstore and community arts center in downtown Indianapolis. It was there that I edited and published Indy Writes Books: A Book Lover&rsquo;s Anthology, which features Indiana authors writing about their love of books, bookstores, and reading. While in Indianapolis, I was also fortunate to be the co-host and producer of a weekly arts talk show on the local public radio station.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>I greatly enjoyed my time in the Midwest, but it wasn&rsquo;t home. Pennsylvania and its air, mountains, and water&mdash;this is home. This is where my wife and I got married, in the garden of her family&rsquo;s farm that sits on the Conewago. Since coming back to PA, my wife and I have already been creating wonderful new outdoor memories: fly-fishing on Big Spring, kayaking on the Susquehanna, hiking Ricketts Glen, biking on the Capital Area Greenbelt, and kite flying on City Island.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Our natural resources in Pennsylvania are incredible, they should be treasured, and they deserve to be protected. This is why I am so proud to be the new Director of Development for PennFuture. There are few things more important to me than PennFuture&rsquo;s work in protecting our air, water and land. This is a mission that I proudly champion.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>As the Director of Development, it is my job to make certain that PennFuture has the funds it needs to be able to fulfill that mission, and to ensure our future sustainability. In this role, I have two very important responsibilities:</div>

<ul>
	<li>To represent PennFuture as best as I can to you, our supporters.</li>
	<li>To represent you as best as I can to PennFuture.</li>
</ul>

<div>My approach to fundraising? It is a two-way street. I will communicate accurate and helpful information to you about the great organization that you have chosen to support.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>What can you do? Tell me why PennFuture, and the work we do, is worthy of your support.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The most important thing a Development Director can bring to an organization isn&rsquo;t a big donation, it is your trust.&nbsp; As your representative, it is my pledge to you that I will be transparent and honest in everything I do to further the mission of PennFuture.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>So, let&rsquo;s get to know each other. I would love to hear from you. Please contact me at <a href=""mailto:dinicola@pennfuture.org"">dinicola@pennfuture.org</a> or at 717-214-7924 with any questions, concerns, or thoughts you have regarding your support of PennFuture.&nbsp;</div>

",Environment,"M. Travis DiNicola, Director of Development"
State Level Implications of Pruitt's Vehicle Emissions Rollback,4/12/2018,"<p>Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt&#39;s attempted rollback of vehicle emissions standards is dangerous, misguided, and will mean dirtier cars and a less competitive auto industry. How do we know this? We have been there before.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Prior to 2008, the auto industry built too many huge and high-profit-margin gas guzzling SUVs rather than a diversified fleet of options for consumers. Their shortsightedness left the industry dangerously exposed to rising gas prices. And, in the end, it took tens of billions of dollars in government aid to save the industry from their own poor choices.</p>

<p>For a time, the industry was ready to admit their fault. They came to the table and negotiated improved fuel economy standards in line with goals set by other countries. Unfortunately, the industry saw an opportunity in Scott Pruitt&rsquo;s anti-regulatory mania to return to their old irresponsible ways. Once again, they are claiming that they just can&rsquo;t make and sell cleaner cars. Even though cleaner vehicles will save American consumers over a trillion dollars in fuel costs and billions more in health and environmental benefits, far outweighing the additional $50 it might add to the sticker price, Pruitt is ready to hand his lobbyist pals whatever they ask for.</p>

<p>The EPA has a lot of power in this area. Section 209(a) of the Clean Air Act has a &ldquo;federal preemption&rdquo; provision that says &ldquo;no state...shall adopt or attempt to enforce any standard relating to the control of emissions from new motor vehicles&hellip;&rdquo; Fortunately, however, California was regulating emissions from vehicles long before the EPA, so the Clean Air Act allows them to continue to do so under a 209(b) waiver as long as their program is no less stringent than the federal one. The Act also gives other states the ability to choose between the EPA&rsquo;s program and the California one. Twelve states, including Pennsylvania, have opted into the California program.</p>

<p>No one thinks it&rsquo;s ideal to have two different programs. In fact, one of the purposes of the &ldquo;Tier III&rdquo; emissions controls that are at issue was to harmonize the standards. Now though, instead of continuing with the agreed-upon standards, anti-environmental and anti-regulatory activists are asking Pruitt to revoke the California waiver. If he does, that would leave Pennsylvania with no choice but to accept more pollution from our cars and worse gas mileage.</p>

<p>That&rsquo;s bad enough, but there are additional complications. Pennsylvania made its clean vehicle program part of its &ldquo;State Implementation Plan&rdquo; (SIP) for meeting federal ozone standards. Currently, 17 of our counties are out of compliance and we need to demonstrate we are adopting permanent, quantifiable, and enforceable emissions reductions to clean up their air. This SIP program also contains an &ldquo;anti-backsliding&rdquo; provision, where losing an enforceable strategy, like the clean vehicle program, requires the state to find something else to take its place.</p>

<p>As Pennsylvanians, we have a right to clean air, but we also expect our government to pick the most cost-effective programs to achieve that goal. Even though vehicles are responsible for about a third of the pollution in the state and the clean car program is highly cost effective, federal preemption means we can&rsquo;t regulate them on our own -- we need the California waiver. If Pruitt revokes that, we may need to get additional emissions reductions from businesses in the state -- no matter what the cost.</p>
",Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
