<p>I&rsquo;ve long desired to work in environmental and conservation policy to save the resources I&rsquo;ve fallen in love with over the years. Growing up, I spent countless hours on my family&rsquo;s farm property and became intimately familiar with the forested and mountain landscapes of Penn&rsquo;s Woods. My worldview has been indelibly shaped by memories of learning to swim in the Juniata with my father, fishing in the Conococheague, and&nbsp;today, I continue to enjoy kayaking the Yellow Breeches and backpacking the Appalachian Trail. It&rsquo;s these experiences I believe my six-year-old and two-year-old nephews should also have some day. These experiences should be available for all Pennsylvanians.</p>

<p>But, these waterways and land won&rsquo;t be preserved from degradation without organizations like PennFuture building relationships with and holding accountable state and federal legislators.</p>

<p>It is essential I keep my finger on the pulse of moving issues and that PennFuture regularly weighs in on policy matters in both Harrisburg and Washington.&nbsp;As PennFuture&rsquo;s chief lobbyist, I&rsquo;m on the front lines of a battle being waged to defund our parks, farmlands, trails and water, and a battle against our state agencies&rsquo; power to enforce strong laws and regulations over polluters.</p>

<p>From early on and through my professional work, I&rsquo;ve held an inner conviction to defend the powerless and advance justice wherever I can. As an advocate for our clean air, water, and climate, I&rsquo;m called to speak out. Speaking our truths to those in power helps us imagine and create the world in which we want to live. I want to live in a community where my drinking water is protected, forest land is conserved, animal species are saved, and the ability to breathe without fear of pollution is realized. My work means believing deeply in what we say and fighting for our voices to be heard in every legislative and executive office PennFuture engages. My raison d&rsquo;&ecirc;tre is to increase public participation in government at all levels, to advance government for the common good by increasing stakeholder engagement in all public decisions, and to look out for the people of Pennsylvania during policy debates and budget negotiations. Sometimes these positions aren&rsquo;t popular and might mean taking a risk, but, to me, that&rsquo;s what it means to stand up for something.&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>We face formidable challenges and opportunities on the road ahead. More troubling is that we live in a rapidly changing political landscape that, at times, threatens our basic laws for the stewardship of our environment. It is important, now more than ever, that PennFuture serve as the watchdog in our statehouse, Congress, and municipalities and that we all do our best to preserve and restore our environmental protections. I&rsquo;m happy to be a part of this team and driving the policy work, day to day, for our members and all Pennsylvanians.</p>
",Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
False Choices: Why PA Doesn’t Need to Sell Out Health for Dirty Energy Jobs,2/28/2018,"<p>Since its founding 20 years ago, PennFuture has occupied a unique space in the state, from brokering the most significant policy victories advancing clean energy, to prevailing in legal cases we&rsquo;ve brought on behalf of communities and individuals fighting for their rights to clean air and pure water.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>This element of accountability has been a common thread weaving through PennFuture&rsquo;s lifespan, and it extends to elected officials, state and federal agencies, and corporate interests whose actions stymy our work on behalf of our constituents, and our mission to protect the environment. In our view, the environment is not a special interest, it is everyone&rsquo;s interest.</p>

<p><strong>We have been compelled to extend that accountability to officials in Harrisburg and question why the environment continues to be an almost invisible issue among so many of them.</strong> To be certain, there are a handful of state legislators who lead on environmental issues, but they are outnumbered by those who are anti-environmental and anti-regulatory in their votes, actions and words.&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvanians are concerned about their environment. On Jan. 30, PennFuture, the Breathe Collaborative and leading activists from Allegheny and Beaver counties held a press conference and rally in Pittsburgh to oppose the buildout of the petrochemical industry in western Pennsylvania. Afterwards, our <a href=""http://www.toxicneighbor.org"">Toxic Neighbor petitions</a>, signed by more than 3,000 Pennsylvanians opposed to Shell Appalachia&rsquo;s $6 billion ethane cracker in Beaver County, were delivered to the governor, state, federal and local legislators and Pittsburgh Regional Alliance.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Many of these petition recipients champion the &ldquo;petchem&rdquo; industry and its promise of jobs. While we acknowledge the opportunity that natural gas under our feet represents when it is exploited, what is the cost of that exploitation and those jobs in terms of taxpayer subsidies, risks to public health, decimation of our forests and streams, and insults to our climate?&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>We seek leadership from our policymakers, particularly around creating and supporting opportunities to develop technologies, good paying jobs and our workforce around the clean energy sector.</strong>&nbsp;According to January 2017&rsquo;s U.S. Energy and Employment report, more than 62,000 Pennsylvanians already work in energy efficiency, and more than 7,000 work in solar and wind electric generation.<strong> Imagine the economic growth that would result from state elected officials leveling the playing field and offering similar policy support to clean energy industries that will not pollute the air your children breathe. </strong>This support is currently provided to polluting industries. We need and deserve leaders who will no longer force voters to choose between pure water to drink - or more jobs. In 2018, we can have both, and we must demand it before it is too late. If Shell is given a $1.65 billion tax break to pollute southwest Pennsylvania in exchange for jobs, why is the same investment not going into clean energy industries? Tax payers deserve better than the threat of increased asthma and cancer rates. Pennsylvania must choose to be a part of the clean energy future that many other states are pursuing.</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s impossible for us to conjecture who among our elected officials will step up and lead in the arena of clean air, healthy climate and a new clean energy economy, but it is within our power to use our voices and our votes to say loud and clear that leadership among our elected officials is sorely missing.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Unfortunately, like so much of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s long history, the modern day coal barons of the natural gas industry have captured many of the institutions that drive economic development in the state, and while it appears to be succeeding beyond all expectations, it is nowhere near finished taking advantage of the hospitable welcome it has received in the form of government subsidies, benevolent permitting and friends in government extolling its virtues and enjoying campaign contributions.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture and our allies are championing clean energy as a growth area for economic development and one that will not sentence our people, natural resources and climate to a future that looks poised to replicate the pollution and health impacts we&rsquo;ve experienced as a result of our fossil fueled past.&nbsp; We do not need to repeat history when we have better options for the future.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Energy,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
Public Engagement is Key to Pennsylvania’s Clean Water Goals,2/21/2018,"<p>A year from this month, the final draft of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Phase III Watershed Implementation Plan will be submitted to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for final review, approval, and enactment. Before that happens, though, a lot of work is set to take place in the coming months. As important as this document is, and its next steps for making sure Pennsylvania meets its pollution reduction goals by 2025, none of this can happen without you.</p>

<p>Conversations during January&rsquo;s meeting of the Steering Committee for the Watershed Implementation Plan (WIP) began to lay out the Pennsylvania&nbsp;Department of Environmental Protection&rsquo;s public engagement strategy and communications around the importance of executing the important work of the WIP. To underscore this need, a new report out earlier this year reminded Pennsylvania policymakers that our Commonwealth has almost 20,000 miles of impaired streams, creeks, and rivers. Instead of focusing narrowly on the Chesapeake Bay, Pennsylvania and the WIP should focus on cleaning its local waters, which will, in sum, restore the Chesapeake Bay.</p>

<p>Local governments, planning commissions, county commissioners, township supervisors, and state legislators, will be critical to include in these discussions and buy-in moving forward and Pennsylvania agencies should work closely with nongovernmental and nonprofit organizations working in the field to reach all of the stakeholders.</p>

<p>We recommend DEP and its Steering Committee workgroups engage the public extensively to provide needed input and feedback on the draft local planning process. Along with including public-private partnerships and innovative groups and strategies, DEP and the WIP Steering Committee should identify key stakeholders to develop action steps at the local level.</p>

<p>This year, as DEP puts its pen to paper for the Phase III WIP, it should hold a number of hearings, windows for public comments, and several opportunities for Pennsylvanians to stand up for clean water and make their voice heard for strong targets. As the state government rolls out its public engagement strategy, citizens&rsquo; participation will make all the difference.</p>

<p>You have power and you should be at the table in our states&rsquo; decisions on how to cut back our water pollution. Stay tuned for more actions and upcoming opportunities.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
A New Role & Policy Priorities for 2018,2/21/2018,"<div>Just about a month ago, I moved into a new role at PennFuture as the director of policy. Each day, I come to work excited to continue advocating for the clean air, pure water, and healthy climate&nbsp;of all Pennsylvanians. Though we live in a rapidly changing landscape, at this critical time for state and federal levels of government, it is important we serve as the watchdog over polluters and do our best to preserve and restore our environmental protections. Please allow me to introduce myself and our policy priorities for 2018.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Based in PennFuture&rsquo;s Harrisburg office, I lead and develop the organization&#39;s policy initiatives and serve as&nbsp;its liaison with elected officials in both Harrisburg and Washington D.C. I manage all legislative and executive branch relationships as well as public policy decisions and processes for PennFuture.&nbsp;As a member of the senior leadership team, I serve as PennFuture&rsquo;s chief lobbyist and external voice on policy positions, strategy, and relationships with decision makers at the local, state, and federal levels of government. I also have the pleasure of representing PennFuture on the Steering Committee of the Choose Clean Water Coalition.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Prior to serving as director of policy, I worked as PennFuture&rsquo;s Campaign Manager for Watershed Advocacy and state lead for the Choose Clean Water Coalition, where I led high-impact outreach and communications campaigns around clean water issues affecting Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment and communities in the Susquehanna and Potomac River basins. I focused on the Commonwealth&rsquo;s waters, and provided oversight and support of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Chesapeake Bay plan and the state&rsquo;s Watershed Implementation Plan. I had the chance to work extensively on state and federal issues, including stormwater management, clean water funding, agriculture, forest retention, the Farm Bill, climate change, and water infrastructure, among others. <strong>For more information on my background, <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/ezra-thrush"">click here.</a></strong></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>Our 2018 Policy Priorities</strong></div>

<div>With this background, I look forward to continuing and leading the great work of PennFuture in both the state and federal policy spheres. So much is at stake in 2018 and we&rsquo;ve developed a comprehensive suite of policy priorities for our work in Harrisburg and Washington, D.C. this year.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>For clean water, PennFuture will&hellip;</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>Push for full funding for Water Commissions. Pennsylvania&rsquo;s share of funding for the Delaware River Basin Commission, the Susquehanna River Basin Commission, and the Interstate Commission on the Potomac River Basin Commission have all been cut to dangerously low levels and must be restored to protect these watersheds.</li>
	<li>Push for the creation of a dedicated clean water fund. Pennsylvania&rsquo;s waters are in crisis. This fund is crucial for restoration and stewardship projects for our watersheds and we will push for the General Assembly to enact a water usage fee.</li>
	<li>Advocate for increased clean water funding for our resource agencies. We are advocating for reversing decades of program cuts to clean water programs at the Department of Environmental Protection, Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, and the Department of Agriculture as a part of the 2018-2019 state budget.</li>
	<li>Advocate for the passage of a package of stormwater bills (HBs 913, 914, 915, 916), which allow towns, boroughs, and other municipality types in Pennsylvania the ability to asses stormwater fees. Municipalities can use these monies for implementing critical best management practices to help them meet their clean water requirements and their pollutant reduction plans.</li>
</ul>

<div><strong>For land protection, PennFuture will&hellip;</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>Advocate for the passage of Growing Greener III legislation. The state&rsquo;s Growing Greener program has funded hundreds of local parks and trail projects, conserved more than 80,000 acres of threatened open space, and restored hundreds of miles of streams and waterways. Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Growing Greener program has also protected thousands of acres of farmland and reclamation of abandoned mine land.</li>
	<li>Oppose any attempt to reverse Governor Wolf&rsquo;s moratorium on drilling for oil and gas in our state parks and forest lands.</li>
</ul>

<div><strong>For clean air, PennFuture will&hellip;</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>Push back against and oppose Shell Global&rsquo;s petrochemical build-out in Beaver County through our Toxic Neighbor&nbsp;campaign.</li>
	<li>Push for setting limits on methane pollution. The Governor has made it a priority to implement regulatory controls on methane pollution from oil and gas operations in 2018. We are working to advance the first part of these controls by May 2018 and begin the final process this year.</li>
</ul>

<div><strong>For clean energy, PennFuture will&hellip;</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>Support Commercial PACE as it builds momentum. Commercial PACE (C-PACE), which provides new financing mechanisms for municipalities wanting to support commercial buildings becoming more energy efficient, took steps forward in 2017. The bill is cosponsored by nearly two thirds&nbsp;of the state Senate and is poised for passage in 2018.</li>
	<li>Advocate for the passage of the Climate Mitigation Action Act (SB 15 &ndash; Costa). This legislation instructs DEP to develop a carbon reduction program to cut emissions by 30 percent&nbsp;by 2030. It represents the first legislation in Pennsylvania for capping carbon emissions.</li>
	<li>Work with partners to draft and move legislation for community solar in Pennsylvania. Community solar would allow residents who can&rsquo;t install solar panels because of poor building structure or low-income to buy into a joint solar installation and still gain benefits from renewable energy.</li>
</ul>

<div><strong>For a responsible State Budget and defense of our protections, PennFuture will&hellip;</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>Fight the continued dismantling of DEP. The FY2017-18 state budget cut DEP&rsquo;s budget 7 percent, adding to the 40 percent already cut from DEP&rsquo;s budget during the last ten years. This hollowing out is having tangible impact, as we see fewer inspectors who can ensure water supplies are safe, fewer inspections of oil and gas activity, fewer permit reviewers, and a smaller number of scientists studying new sources of pollution. PennFuture is fighting on the frontlines in Harrisburg to stop and reverse this disturbing trend.</li>
	<li>Oppose all attempts at moving and passing the Regulatory Review bills which are currently in the House State Government Committee (HBs 209, 1237, 1792, 1959, 1960). A suite of bills crafted under the guise of &ldquo;regulatory reform&rdquo; is scheduled for a vote in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives this year that would irreparably harm our environmental agencies ability to protect our health and the environment from pollution. PennFuture is leading a coalition of organizations to defeat these bills.</li>
	<li>Oppose efforts to raid the Environmental Stewardship Fund, Keystone Recreation &amp; Parks Fund, Agriculture Preservation Fund, County Conservation District Fund, and other crucial environmental and energy funds administered by the DEP and DCNR.</li>
</ul>

<div><strong>Regarding federal policy initiatives, PennFuture will&hellip;</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>Advocate for a strong 2018 Farm Bill. The Farm Bill represents the key opportunity to drive federal investment in agriculture, water, and land conservation programs. We are leading a coalition effort to push for increased funding across a number of key water and land programs as well as protect the EPA Chesapeake Bay Program.</li>
	<li>Protect and fund the Delaware River Basin Restoration Program (DRBRP), which was created by the Delaware River Basin Conservation Act of 2015 (DRBCA) and was a key legislative victory for PennFuture and its coalition members.</li>
	<li>Advocate for the federal RECLAIM legislation, which would invest over $50 million in new funding for land and water clean-up from legacy coal mining and acid mine drainage in Pennsylvania&rsquo;s coal country.</li>
	<li>Oppose the repeal and replacement of EPA&rsquo;s Clean Water Rule (Waters of the United States). We&rsquo;ve submitted legal and technical comments to the EPA docket to preserve the Rule which protects the drinking water of millions of Americans. PennFuture also collected hundreds of citizen letters for the EPA to stop the roll-back of this critical protection. We are continuing to fight against this move and any subsequent replacement that weakens our clean water safeguards.</li>
	<li>Be a leader in the Renewable Fuel Standard Campaign: The RFS is a federal mandate to blend renewable fuels into conventional gasoline, which had good environmental intentions initially, but ultimately led to significant carbon and land use issues. We are advancing legislation in Congress to fix the RFS and restore its initial environmental intent.</li>
</ul>

<p>With significant challenges and opportunities ahead of us this year, our team is already fast at work and eager to continue holding polluters accountable and pushing for policies and legislation that will make our environment better for all Pennsylvanians.</p>

Air Quality Expo Educates Citizens on Air Pollution,2/13/2018,"<p>PennFuture and Clean Water Action hosted the Third Annual Air Quality Expo at the Squirrel Hill Carnegie Library this month to educate East End Pittsburgh residents about the steady stream of air pollution from the Mon Valley - pointing out that this pollution travels and impacts their lives.</p>

<p>The event kicked off with <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HPpNlct8Lu0"" target=""_blank"">VICE media&rsquo;s documentary, &ldquo;Steam Valley,&rdquo;</a> in which PennFuture member, Cheryl Hurt, as well as other Clairton residents discuss their day-to-day routines, how they can smell benzene in the air, and how they have learned to master the technique of &ldquo;breathing while running&rdquo; in order to participate in local sports. Residents also discussed dealing with the alarming rates of childhood asthma in the area.</p>

<p>The degradation of air quality that many in the Mon Valley observe is due to one of the biggest polluters in Allegheny County, U.S. Steel&rsquo;s Clairton Coke Works. In fact, Allegheny County ranks in the top two percent nationally for cancer risk from hazardous air pollutants (<a href=""http://www.chec.pitt.edu/documents/PRETA/CHEC%20PRETA%20HAPs%20Report.pdf"" target=""_blank"">Pittsburgh Regional Environmental Threat Analysis Report, 2013</a>).</p>

<p>The eye-opening documentary shows the disconnect between Pittsburghers who are convinced what comes out of the Clairton Coke Works is purely steam, versus what local public health and air quality experts state is actually spewed from the smokestacks, which includes particulate matter (PM 2.5).&nbsp;</p>

<p>But it&rsquo;s not just Clairton residents who are at risk of these harmful plumes.&nbsp;</p>

<p>According to Dr. Albert Presto, an Assistant Research Professor in the Department of Mechanical Engineering and a member of Carnegie Mellon University&rsquo;s Center for Atmospheric Particle Studies, who is tracking the path of Mon Valley pollution, these plumes can be as far-reaching as to travel to East End communities like Squirrel Hill.&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""http://breatheproject.org/learn/breathe-mobile/"" target=""_blank"">Using the &ldquo;Breathemobile,&rdquo;</a> Presto collected pollution data throughout Allegheny County and turned this data into a series of color-coded maps that reveal where pollutants are found throughout the county.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;Industrial facilities such as the Clairton Coke Works that emit large amounts of pollution can affect communities miles away,&rdquo; Presto states. &ldquo;Pittsburgh&rsquo;s river valleys augment the problem because the emissions can get trapped down there.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Dr. Deborah Gentile also presented her recent childhood asthma study that is contingent with Presto&rsquo;s work. She found that among 1,200 elementary school children who live near sources of pollution, such as the Clairton Coke Works, about 35 percent have asthma, and two thirds of them, or 24 percent, actually knew they had asthma.</p>

<p>The national asthma rate is about 8 percent and in Allegheny County, it&rsquo;s 13 percent.</p>

<p>Children are more susceptible to the effects of air pollution because, compared to adults, they have a larger lung surface area in relation to their body weight, and breathe about 50 percent more air per kilogram of body weight.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Gentile states, &ldquo;Near these point sources of pollution, we tend to see more minority families as well as more lower socioeconomic status, and that&rsquo;s what they find in other cities as well. These are the people who can&rsquo;t afford to live elsewhere.&rdquo;</p>

<p>&ldquo;The kids who are exposed to the highest level of particulate matter, as well as the highest level black carbon, are twice as likely to have a diagnosis of asthma than those who are exposed to the lower levels. So, that really has to be a call for public policy change to clean this air up,&rdquo; she said.</p>

<p>While this all may seem a bit daunting and out of your hands, Carnegie Mellon University&rsquo;s CREATE Lab would argue otherwise. With their citizen science tools such as the <a href=""http://smellpgh.org/"" target=""_blank"">&ldquo;Smell Pgh&rdquo; app</a>, where you can submit real-time data on your location and what kind of industrial smell you are encountering directly to the Allegheny County Health Department, any Pittsburgher (including YOU) can help in holding industry and its regulatory agency, in this case the Allegheny County Health Department, accountable.</p>

<p>In addition to monitoring the air in your community by <a href=""http://breatheproject.org/learn/breathe-cam/"" target=""_blank"">watching the Breathe Cam</a> or renting a <a href=""https://www.specksensor.com/"" target=""_blank"">Speck Sensor</a> from your library, we need you to <a href=""http://www.achd.net/board/meetings.html"" target=""_blank"">speak out to the Allegheny County Health Department Board of Health</a> meetings to voice your concerns and why we all have the right to breathe clean air.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Join us as we continue to fight for clean air, and <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/newsletter-sign-up"" target=""_blank"">join our email list to stay updated</a> on the latest actions you can take.</p>
",Environment,"Annie Regan, Senior Program Manager"

Our Clean Energy Future Requires Leadership from All,1/25/2018,"<div><strong>What will it take for Pennsylvania to break away from its dependence on dirty, unhealthy, old fuels like coal and gas, and move enthusiastically and proudly into a clean energy future?&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s economic reliance on fossil fuel runs deeper than the veins of coal we insist on still extracting. In reality, our fossil fuel economy is as tenuous as the bedrock we frack and decimate to release natural gas into our lives. What will it take to leave it in the ground, and move boldly into a new energy, climate-friendly future driven by renewables and efficiency?&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>That &ldquo;future&rdquo; is taking place, right now, in other states that have embraced clean energy jobs.</strong>&nbsp;Neighboring states are making business development investments and creating incentives that attract wind, solar and related-manufacturing jobs, and create a new workforce to support clean energy industries. They are increasing public investment in research and development and innovation. This is happening in places like New Jersey, where new Governor Murphy <a href=""https://www.murphy4nj.com/issue/building-a-clean-energy-economy/"" target=""_blank"">prioritized clean energy during his campaign</a>,&nbsp;and in neighboring New York, where Governor Cuomo <a href=""https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-launches-5-billion-clean-energy-fund-grow-new-york-s-clean-energy-economy"" target=""_blank"">launched a $5 billion fund to grow New York&rsquo;s clean energy economy.</a></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>Other states are reaping the economic benefits of clean energy now, at lower cost to public health, environment and climate than what Pennsylvanians must endure through the dominance of dirty energy.&nbsp;</strong>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s government is simply doing too much to facilitate the success of the fossil fuel industry, including sweetening fossil fuel development with exorbitant subsidies such as the nearly <a href=""http://www.toxicneighbor.org"" target=""_blank"">$1.6 billion that ex-Governor Tom Corbett provided Shell Chemical Appalachia</a> to build an ethane cracker plant in Beaver County so the world can have more plastic. Governor Wolf supports the plant.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>So, what needs to happen to wake Pennsylvania up to the future before the new energy economy passes us by and we&rsquo;re left unable to catch up with clean energy states?&nbsp;</strong></div>

<ol>
	<li><strong>Clean energy leadership and vision at the highest level of state government, namely through our next governor. </strong>Now that we are witnessing the success of the natural gas business, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s future governor must step up and help level the playing field between the fossil fuel industry and the clean energy industry. <a href=""https://www.e2.org/pennsylvania/"">Clean energy jobs are outpacing fossil fuel jobs in Pennsylvania</a> and deserve political support and public investment. The new governor must be prepared to present a package of incentives for clean energy, workforce development and greenhouse gas reduction.</li>
	<li><strong>Clean energy champions in our communities</strong> are needed to step up and run for elected office.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
	<li><strong>Anti-environmental climate deniers in the state legislature must be held accountable</strong> for their unabashed embrace of natural gas and <a href=""http://marcellusmoney.org/"">their acceptance of gas lobby campaign support.</a>&nbsp;And if they will not be held to account, we need to turn them out of office. This will take time, but elections matter and can create long-lasting change.&nbsp;</li>
	<li><strong>Community activists must roll up the red carpet and pave over the yellow brick road being traveled by pipeline companies, the plastics industry and natural gas businesses and their lobbyists. </strong>Communities must begin to work in earnest on a viable clean energy economic development vision for their communities.</li>
	<li><strong>Statewide environmental advocacy organizations must do more to assist on-the-ground activists, through legal and policy assistance. </strong>Through our work in Harrisburg, organizations like PennFuture, PennEnvironment, Sierra Club and others must hold the line to defend existing laws and regulations in a hostile anti-regulatory state legislature. Here at PennFuture, we are planning projects with individual communities that are taking their clean energy and climate future into their own hands.&nbsp;Working in these communities, PennFuture will offer technical and planning assistance, and help with project development to local outcomes of reductions in the cost of energy and greenhouse gas reductions.</li>
	<li><strong>Policies must be adopted that continue to prioritize energy efficiency and clean renewable energy.</strong>&nbsp;This means defending our Act 129 energy efficiency program, strengthening our Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards, and not wasting billions of dollars in tax breaks subsidizing dirty fossil fuels.</li>
	<li><strong>All of us need to play our part:</strong> change out your light bulbs, switch to energy star appliances, act on your ability to choose your electric supplier and choose clean energy by visiting <a href=""http://www.papowerswitch.com"" target=""_blank"">www.papowerswitch.com</a>, choose hybrid and electric vehicles, call an elected official and express your views, support your favorite environmental organization working hard for their missions.</li>
</ol>

2018 Work is Key to Reaching State's Clean Water Goals,1/25/2018,"<p>The Phase III Watershed Implementation Steering Committee meets this week in Harrisburg at a pivotal time for the Chesapeake Bay clean-up. In December, the steering committee met to discuss the mid-point assessment and to gather feedback from stakeholders to the PA Department of Environmental Protection and the Principals&rsquo; Staff Committee of the Chesapeake Bay Program.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As we turn to 2018, we are entering into the critical second half of the period for Pennsylvania to meets is pollution reduction goals by 2025, set by the Total Maximum Daily Load in 2010. For a number of reasons, progress made this year and the actions taken by the Phase III WIP Steering Committee and the state agencies will be crucial in setting the stage for how well Pennsylvania steps up to meet its obligations.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
In December, early information from the EPA Chesapeake Bay Program&rsquo;s model is showing that Pennsylvania&rsquo;s 2025 targets for reducing nutrients may be 7 million pounds less for nitrogen and 270,000 pounds less for phosphorous than originally thought. While this is welcome news, PennFuture and clean water stakeholders plan to continue holding the state agencies, the Environmental Protection Agency, and the WIP Steering Committee to strong commitments for our clean water. Pennsylvania needs a strong Phase III Watershed Implementation Plan in order to meet its goals and restore thousands of miles of streams and creeks.&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Last week, DEP Secretary Patrick McDonnell informed the Citizens Advisory Council on DEP&rsquo;s work with the Chesapeake Bay clean-up and shared that the Chesapeake Bay Program should be releasing its initial nutrient and sediment reduction targets in February, finalizing them in May.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Secretary McDonnell rightly admits that Pennsylvania still faces uphill challenges in reaching the pollution reduction goals. While it remains a key concern for clean water stakeholders in Pennsylvania and the Chesapeake Bay watershed, Secretary McDonnell told the Citizens Advisory Council that the Conowingo Dam issue will be dealt on its own with its separate watershed implementation plan created by the owner of the dam &ndash; Exelon, EPA, Maryland, and the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
2018 is shaping up to be a very important year for Chesapeake Bay and clean water policy in regard to the WIP and state agencies&rsquo; enforcement and work in water quality and restoration. On top of these challenges and movements in the right direction by our key policymakers in Pennsylvania, legislators in Harrisburg threaten the progress of the Chesapeake Bay clean-up and all of its stakeholders by continuing to challenge critical state funding for environmental projects, river basin commissions, and clean water programming at the Departments of Agriculture, Environmental Protection, and Conservation and Natural Resources. State elected officials are also actively seeking the roll-back of essential regulations to keep our water clean and are trying their best to implement a regime of supposed reform.&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
At the federal level, while the constant challenge to reach a deal on permanent appropriations from this Congress and presidential administration appear elusive, we have a few strong bills emerging from watershed legislators to help increase our buffers and funding to farmers as a part of the 2018 Farm Bill, including S.2139 from Senator Van Hollen (D-MD), and HR4420 from Congressman Bobby Scott (D-VA).&nbsp;</p>

<p>At this time, we need a strong state government commitment to restoring and protecting our drinking water in the Chesapeake Bay watershed and in Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture remains an integral part of the WIP development and discussions and state and federal levels of government for clean water.&nbsp;</p>

Replacing the Guardrails,1/24/2018,"<p><em><strong>By Larry J. Schweiger, President Emeritus, PennFuture</strong></em></p>

<p><em>Note: With so many unfathomable, discordant, and unsettling things emanating from the Trump administration, it is important that the numerous environmental threats and terrible actions summarized herein not get lost in the cacophony. We are losing much and we must work together as never before to find new ways to push back.&nbsp;</em>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A number of years ago, my youngest daughter was driving back to college after her winter break and hit a patch of black ice and slid into the guardrails. I spent $500 replacing a single section of guardrail on I-79. I share this because I am watching the Trump administration ripping down critical environmental guardrails. Watching the loss of guardrail after guardrail, the questions I have been wrestling with include: Can the guardrails be repaired or replaced? If so, at what cost? Is there such a thing as being too late?</p>

<p>Until the recent tax bill was signed, many in the media had been suggesting that Trump isn&rsquo;t getting anything done. That was simply not true. While Trump was distracting us with his perverse tweets and endless lies, important regulations have been rolled back and in many cases, ended completely at an astounding rate. The Trump administration has been demonizing government, reminiscent of Ronald Reagan&rsquo;s rhetoric, but its actions go far beyond Reagan&rsquo;s. As Steve Bannon once boasted, the Trump appointees are &ldquo;deconstructing the administrative state&rdquo; at a pace that is hard to follow, and even harder to resist.</p>

<p>At the Environmental Protection Agency under Scott Pruitt, we are witnessing the abandonment of the Clean Water Rules, the retreat from the Paris Accord, moving to end the Clean Power Plan and the endangerment findings, gutting the highly successful auto rules, the national clean air guidelines and on and on I could go. Harvard University has created an environmental rollback tracker that has identified 40 environmental protections. <a href=""http://environment.law.harvard.edu/policy-initiative/regulatory-rollback-tracker/"" target=""_blank"">You can sign up for alerts here.</a></p>

<p>The failure to enforce existing law and the many inadequate settlements of prior enforcement actions, coupled with the stripping of publically funded climate science from their websites is and should be a continuing outrage. Despite the legacy of abandoned mines and polluted waterways in virtually every state where coal has been mined, the administration will not require the mining industry to provide financial assurances demonstrating that they have the capacity to clean up any and all pollution caused by mining. We are witnessing a race to the bottom with dark money and its appointed surrogates in charge of the very agencies that were created to protect our environment.</p>

<p>The tax bill got a lot of attention for the way it further advantaged the super wealthy and further concentrated wealth even more at a time when there is already grave inequities. What got very little if any coverage in the midst of this was the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge giveaway. To buy Senator Lisa Murkowski&rsquo;s vote for a bad tax bill, the Arctic Refuge was put up for oil development as an offset to some of the tax cuts for the wealthy. This is America&rsquo;s last remaining pristine Serengeti. Covering 29,800 square miles of untrammeled wilderness, it will now be exploited by the oil interests who will destroy the core calving area of the Porcupine Caribou herd that has been finding insect relief along the coastal plain for millennia. The coastal plain is a critical mosquito relief habitat considered by the Gwich&rsquo;in people to be sacred for 20,000 years.</p>

<p>Adding insult to this ecological injury, U. S. Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke has put virtually all of the off-shore waters up for oil and gas leasing. While he was forced by their Republican lawmakers to retreat on the waters off the Florida coast for political reasons, the remaining waters are put at risk while Zinke abandoned all the important rules put in place after the disastrous BP oil spill, and he has scaled back the enforcement and monitoring procedures put in place to avoid another massive spill. Lessons learned from the BP spill are soon forgotten.</p>

<p>At the request of Utah&rsquo;s uranium industry and other special interests, Zinke cut the heart out of two important monuments (Bears Ears and Grand Staircase Escalante) so they can be leased for mineral development. He diminished the size of a total of six monuments including the lifting of fishing restrictions in a critical ocean sanctuary established by George W. Bush.</p>

<p>In another disgusting action, Zinke doubled the cost of entering a National Park to seventy dollars and in seventeen parks the fee will be seventy-five dollars. These fees will be prohibitive for many young families, for minorities and especially for the poor struggling to just make ends meet. Even before the doubling of the fees, only seven percent of the visitors to the parks were black according to a survey commissioned by the National Park Service. Do we really want our National Parks to be restricted to a privileged few?</p>

<p>Nine of 12 members of the Congressionally sanctioned National Park System Advisory Board resigned because Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke ignored the board for a year. The committee established in 1935 has been vital to the Park Service. In recent years the committee has advised the Interior Department on how to deal with global warming, emphasized the need to protect American historical sites and advised the service on how to encourage more young people to the parks.</p>

<p>If that was not enough, Zinke announced on Dec.&nbsp;22 that he had come up with a new legal interpretation of the Migratory Bird Treaty Act that strictly prohibits the unregulated killing of birds. Migratory birds landing on toxic waste impoundments often associated with fracking are often killed and have been treated as a violation of the law. The Zinke memorandum reinterprets the Migratory Bird Treaty Act to allow corporations to kill migratory birds outside of carefully established seasons and bag limits contrary to the long-standing interpretation by every administration since 1970.</p>

<p>Trump just put a 30 percent&nbsp;tariff on solar panels imported from China. This pushes the cost of solar higher. He is just one year in and we must expect more damaging environmental policies. Those of us deeply concerned with the environment must come to the realization that we must become much more active politically and begin to work with those seeking fundamental reforms to restore our democracy.</p>

<p>The environment will not be protected until we address the broken democracy. Environmentalists like so many Americans are shell-shocked. It&rsquo;s a much more complicated situation and we are forced to dig deeper into our plight and find pathways to recover our floundering democracy. The Pennsylvania Supreme Court took an important first step this week overthrowing one of the most egregious gerrymandered Congressional districts in the country. Much more must be done.</p>
",Environment,
Supreme Court Decision May Impact Trump Administration’s Attempt to Repeal the Clean Water Rule,1/23/2018,"<p>The Supreme Court issued a <a href=""https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/17pdf/16-299_8nk0.pdf"" target=""_blank"">unanimous decision</a> yesterday that challenges to EPA&rsquo;s Clean Water Rule (CWR) were properly brought before federal District Courts, and not federal appellate courts. The decision is not about the validity of EPA&rsquo;s definition of &ldquo;waters of the United State,&rdquo; but instead involves the procedural issue as to where challenges to EPA&rsquo;s rule must be filed.&nbsp; The decision is important, nonetheless, because it invalidates an appellate court decision that had prevented the CWR from taking affect across the Nation.</p>

<p>The issue before the court was which federal courts could review challenges to the 2015 CWR, which defined &ldquo;waters of the United States&rdquo; under the Clean Water Act.&nbsp; After EPA promulgated the rule, numerous lawsuits were filed challenging the CWR in both federal district courts and federal courts of appeal or so-called circuit courts. In one of those cases, the United States Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit issued a nationwide stay that prevented the CWR from taking effect.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The government argued that the 6th Circuit had jurisdiction to issue its decision.&nbsp; Typically, challenges to EPA rules must be filed with a district court and not an appellate court like the 6th Circuit.&nbsp; However, the Clean Water Act provides seven categories of EPA actions that can be challenged in circuit courts.&nbsp; The government argued that this was one of those types of actions that could, and should, be challenged in circuit courts.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The US Supreme Court rejected all of the government&rsquo;s legal and policy arguments.&nbsp; The Court held that the CWR is &ldquo;a definitional rule that clarifies the scope of the statutory term&rdquo; and while litigating before the district courts may be less efficient and may result in a less uniform regulatory landscape, the plain language of the Clean Water Act shows that Congress made clear that rules like the CWR must be reviewed first by the federal district courts.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Supreme Court&rsquo;s decision will impact the nationwide stay of the CWR imposed by the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals.&nbsp; Once the 6th Circuit dismisses the case, as directed by the Supreme Court, the CWR will be reinstated in all states &ndash; including Pennsylvania &ndash; except in those 13 western states for which the District Court of North Dakota issued a stay on the CWR in 2015.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Under the CWR, EPA defined &ldquo;waters of the United States&rdquo; in a manner that clarified that protections under Clean Water Act covered small intermittent and ephemeral streams and wetlands.&nbsp;These waters are critical not only in their own right, but also for the water quality of the larger bodies of water of which these smaller streams are a part.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This decision will also impact the Trump Administration&rsquo;s 2017 attempts to repeal the CWR.&nbsp; The government sought to preserve the circuit court&rsquo;s jurisdiction over the CWR because they are generally viewed as being less inclined to overturn federal agency rules, which might have made it harder for environmental groups to challenge Trump&rsquo;s effort to repeal and replace the existing CWR.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture is engaged in the battle over the Clean Water Rule.&nbsp; <a href=""/Files/Admin/2017%2D09%2D27%2DPennFuture%2DClean%2DWater%2DRule%2DRepeal%2DPublic%2DComments%2D%28EPA%2DHQ%2DOW%2D2017%2D0203%29%2Epdf"" target=""_blank"">Last year, we submitted comments</a> against the initial proposed repeal&nbsp; of the CWR and a <a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/2017-12-13-PennFuture-Clean-Water-Rule-Applicability-Date-Public-Comments-%28EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0644.%29.pdf"" target=""_blank"">secondary attempt&nbsp;</a> by EPA at gutting the CWR.&nbsp; PennFuture will continue to be engaged over the coming year to help ensure that our waters remain protected.</p>
",Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Using PennFuture’s New Click-To-Call Advocacy Tool,1/16/2018,"<p><strong>What is Click-To-Call?</strong></p>

<p>PennFuture is providing a new advocacy tool for supporters, allowing you to call your representatives directly with the help of easily accessible talking points and a phone connection made with the simple click of a button.</p>

<p>In December, we launched our first ever campaign using a Click-To-Call action to protect the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and we look forward to using it even more in the future during times in which your rapid response to elected officials is needed.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>The process involves three simple steps and only takes about 3 minutes to complete. In that short time, you will have made a major impact in our work to protect the environment!</strong></p>

<p>While sending emails and letters to representatives is always an effective way to share your opinions on issues that matter to you, click-to-call actions allow citizens to create a larger sense of urgency for elected officials when the window for change is smaller than usual. This tool will be crucial in our fight in 2018 for clean air, water, and a healthier future for Pennsylvania.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Here&rsquo;s how it works:</strong></p>

<ol>
	<li>After you receive a PennFuture e-mail requesting you to take action through click-to-call, you&nbsp; will fill out a form with your contact information. After that, you will see the name and phone number for your representatives. Please note that you should not call the number during this step.&nbsp; Our technology takes care of that for you later.</li>
	<li>During the next step, you will be able to see and review the provided talking points for the phone call with your representative.</li>
	<li>At the very bottom of this page, you will find a space to add your phone number. After submitted, you will receive a phone call detailing the issue and preparing you for the conversation. Then, using the talking points, you complete the call!</li>
</ol>

<p>After the call is complete and the staff-person or representative has hung up, you will then receive a &ldquo;thank you&rdquo; call to let you know that your action is done.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Thank you to all of our supporters, and please email me at <a href=""mailto:cupo@pennfuture.org"">cupo@pennfuture.org</a>, if you have any questions about this new and exciting tool.</p>
",Environment,"Alexander Cupo, PennFuture Southeast PA Outreach Coordinator"
How to Effectively Comment on the DRBC’s Draft Fracking Regulations,1/8/2018,"<div>On Nov.&nbsp;30, 2017, the Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC) <a href=""http://www.state.nj.us/drbc/meetings/proposed/notice_hydraulic-fracturing.html"" target=""_blank""><strong>issued draft regulations</strong></a> regarding fracking within the Delaware River Basin.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>In short, the draft regulations do the following:</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>Prohibits high-volume hydraulic fracturing (fracking) in shale and other rock formations within the Basin;</li>
	<li>Regulates Delaware River water use for fracking outside of the Basin (inter-basin water transfer); and</li>
	<li>Regulates the treatment and disposal of produced water/wastewater from fracking from outside of the Basin.</li>
</ul>

<div>As with any proposed regulations, DRBC is accepting public comment on its draft fracking regulations.&nbsp;Submitting written comments on proposed environmental actions is a way to make your voice heard and to influence decisions on the issues you care about.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>Public participation is an essential part of the rulemaking process.&nbsp;In particular, public comments can do the following:</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>Strengthen a regulation;</li>
	<li>Create a comprehensive and accurate record; and</li>
	<li>Support an appropriate and informed decisionmaking process.</li>
</ul>

<div>While PennFuture continues to review and develop its own comments, we strongly encourage each and every one of you to write to DRBC to express your gratitude (banning fracking in the Basin!) and your concerns (allowing other dangerous activities).</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Written public comments can be as short or as detailed as you want them to be, but there are a few tips and techniques that can help make your comments persuasive.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>And so, PennFuture developed a short video on <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MJQbNpEmkTQ&amp;feature=youtu.be"" target=""_blank"">&ldquo;How to Effectively Engage in the Public Commenting Process.</a>&rdquo; These tips include:</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li>Use specific examples and highlight how the regulations could impact you, your family, your community, and the natural resources you love.</li>
	<li>Use persuasive language throughout.</li>
	<li>Present your comments in a clear, concise, and respectful manner.</li>
</ul>

<div><strong>DRBC is accepting public comment on these draft regulations until 5 p.m. on March 30.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Unfortunately, the only way to submit written comments on these draft regulations is through DRBC&rsquo;s online comments webpage at <a href=""http://dockets.drbc.commentinput.com/"" target=""_blank"">http://dockets.drbc.commentinput.com/</a>.&nbsp; DRBC is not accepting emailed, faxed, or hand- or postal-delivered comments. (PennFuture submitted this letter&nbsp; regarding DRBC&rsquo;s flawed public participation process.)</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>Public Hearings</strong></div>

It&rsquo;s not too late to register to attend these hearings and hear others&rsquo; concerns. Although the deadline to register to speak has passed, DRBC has indicated that you may still be able to register to speak if time is available.</div>

"How You Can Get Involved: ""Our Water Campaign""",1/2/2018,"<p>Although very much underplayed by the general public and the media, <a href=""https://www.vox.com/2016/2/3/10904120/lead-exposure-flint-pennsylvania"" target=""_blank"">Pittsburgh is facing a drinking water crisis</a>, with lead levels still high in many homes and water rates increasing by 28 percent in 2018. &nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>The <a href=""https://www.facebook.com/pg/OurH2o/about/?ref=page_internal"" target=""_blank"">&ldquo;Our Water Campaign&rdquo;</a></strong><br />
Comprised of Pittsburgh United, Clean Water Action, Pennsylvania Interfaith Impact Network, Sierra Club, Nine Mile Run Watershed, Hill District Consensus Group, Thomas Merton Center, One Pennsylvania, and PennFuture, the campaign is a coalition that believes safe, clean water is a vital resource for the Pittsburgh region and that the lack of investment and repair of our public water system threatens our economy and public health.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The need for safe and healthy drinking water is too important to be left in the hands of corporations. The profit motive will always come before the needs of residents. We need solutions that treat our public water as a common good and human right for all, where residents&rsquo; health isn&rsquo;t put at risk so corporations can turn a profit. Residents have made it clear that they want more control and accountability over the Pittsburgh Water and Sewer Authority, not less.&nbsp;</p>

<p>So, when Washington, D.C.-based Infrastructure Management Group (IMG), hired by the city to explore options to rebuild PWSA, suggested a public trust to govern the authority, we have to ask if this is the best decision for the residents of Pittsburgh.</p>

<p>If IMG&rsquo;s recommendation was implemented, the public trust would be placed under the jurisdiction of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Public Utility Commission, and would then lease its infrastructure to a private entity and dissolve PWSA&rsquo;s current board.</p>

<p>However, a functional PWSA that keeps the authority completely public is achievable!&nbsp;</p>

<p>PWSA has listened to public input and has passed a plan to replace lead service lines, invest in green infrastructure, and protect low-income residents with a Customer Assistance Program. <a href=""http://apps.pittsburghpa.gov/redtail/images/932_PWSA_Report.pdf"" target=""_blank""><strong>You can read the full plan here.</strong></a></p>

<p>In addition, thanks to the recent passage of a new state law, PWSA may finally have the funding and the authority to replace private lead lines, with permission from homeowners.</p>

<p><strong>What can you do?</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li><a href=""https://www.facebook.com/OurH2o/"" target=""_blank"">&ldquo;Like&rdquo; and follow the &ldquo;Our Water Campaign&rdquo; on Facebook</a> for updates on upcoming meetings, hearings, and volunteer opportunities such as canvassing</li>
	<li>Get a free lead water test kit from PWSA for you and tell your family, friends, neighbors to test their water at <a href=""http://pgh2o.com/lead-testing-kits"">http://pgh2o.com/lead-testing-kits</a></li>
	<li>Spread the word on your social media about keeping Pittsburgh&rsquo;s water public by using our hashtag, <strong>#OurH2O</strong></li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Annie Regan, Senior Program Manager"
From the CEO: PennFuture Priorities in 2018,12/19/2017,"<p>The PennFuture staff has been reflecting on 2017 as the year comes to an end. Many of us and our supporters tend to view the year as one marked by profound threats &ndash; to our climate system and our children&rsquo;s&nbsp;futures, to our democracy, and to the institutions and laws that give us some measure of protection from pollution. Indeed, the year was marked by all of that, but also by counterbalances that can end up being similarly profound.</p>

<p>With the president&rsquo;s <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-Statement-on-Paris-Climate-Agreement-Withdrawal"">withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Climate Accord</a>, we&rsquo;ve seen the Paris to Pittsburgh movement take shape, culminating in former Vice President Al Gore and the Heinz Endowments&rsquo; hosting of the largest ever Climate Reality Project training in Pittsburgh this past October. As a result, we have hundreds of new climate communicators in our state, ready to deploy and bring solid information about the climate crisis and its solutions to the public.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We have seen the PA State Supreme Court issue a second important opinion in <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/News-State-Supreme-Court-Rules-Leasing-Public-Land-for-Fracking-Betrayed-Governments-Constitutional-Duties""><em>PEDF v. Tom Wolf, Governor and Commonwealth of Pennsylvania</em></a>, building favorable case law around the Environmental Rights Amendment to Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Constitution. And the gerrymandering movement has tremendous momentum.</p>

<p>We&rsquo;ve seen environmental issues influence elections in places like Delaware County and Jessup, where voters turned pro-pipeline and pro-gas elected officials out of office and replaced them with clean energy visionaries.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>We are entering 2018 with a wind at our backs. Here is a look at PennFuture&rsquo;s priorities for the coming year:</strong></p>

<p><strong>Clean Energy Cities Initiative</strong><br />
In the wake of the Paris withdrawal, we&rsquo;ve witnessed Pennsylvania communities and elected officials step up by taking pledges and other actions that indicate their seriousness in taking their climate future into their own hands. What comes next for these communities, especially smaller ones that are willing but perhaps lacking the expertise and resources to take the next big step into renewables and energy efficiency? <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/careers-and-internships"">PennFuture is piloting a program in Pittsburgh</a> that we hope to expand to three new communities as support grows. PennFuture will be on the ground&nbsp; in communities, ready to offer technical and planning assistance, help design projects and find resources to move communities aggressively in the new energy space, bypassing the anti-environmental forces and climate deniers trying to hold this unstoppable movement down.</p>

<p><strong>Green in &rsquo;18 Campaign</strong><br />
As part of our new civic engagement program, formed as a result of our January 2017 strategic alliance with Conservation Voters of Pennsylvania, <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/careers-and-internships"">PennFuture will launch its Green in &rsquo;18 campaign.</a> The campaign will elevate the public discussion around environmental issues in the upcoming elections. PennFuture and Conservation Voters of Pennsylvania are working with more than 30 environmental, land, water and recreation groups to design a common agenda of priority issues for our organizations. The Green in &rsquo;18 campaign will focus its attention on these issue priorities and find opportunities for all candidates in key elections to react to and discuss key issues in the water, air, and energy arenas.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Using the Courts</strong><br />
PennFuture&rsquo;s legal team plans to explore ideas to be more creative and aggressive with our litigation activity. We will continue our good work in the enforcement and regulatory arenas, but can we push harder on litigation around the Environmental Rights Amendment and climate issues?&nbsp; PennFuture&rsquo;s legacy of impact around our legal work has been defined by selecting smart cases that have broad implications. We want our work defined by that criteria, but we want to use the courts fully, especially in times like these when the legislature is actively stymying our ability to advance a clean water, clean air, and clean energy agenda.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Restoring the Ohio River Basin</strong><br />
The Ohio River is at a critical juncture, again named America&rsquo;s most polluted river according to the Environmental Protection Agency&rsquo;s Toxics Release Inventory. But in comparison to our other great river systems, the Ohio Basin is underserved, especially when considering the threat of a multi-state petrochemical complex that will further degrade the basin&rsquo;s air, water and public health.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture currently is part of two large, multi-state coalitions working to protect local waters of the Delaware River, and the Susquehanna River, respectively. As part of these coalitions, PennFuture is coordinating a large number of state, regional and local groups active in Pennsylvania and in these two major watersheds. PennFuture and National Wildlife Federation seek to begin a closer examination of threats to the Ohio, and working with other organizations, academics and resource managers, begin to craft pathways to environmental health and economic prosperity.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Your Support Makes it Possible</strong><br />
We hope you find these upcoming undertakings of PennFuture worthwhile and exciting, and worthy of your advocacy support and <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/donate"">financial investment in 2018</a>. This list only reflects a small portion of the excellent and impactful work and campaigns that will continue in 2018.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We will continue to build our presence in mid-size towns and communities throughout our state. We will put forth solutions and alternatives to economic development defined by dirty energy.&nbsp; Thank you for supporting our Toxic Neighbor campaign to protect Pittsburgh&rsquo;s air from polluters like U.S. Steel and Royal Dutch Shell. Thank you for supporting our newest office and staff in Mount Pocono, where we are working to protect the headwater streams of the Delaware River Basin. Thank you for making our ability to represent clients through our legal services a reality.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We have a big year planned, and I hope to see you along the way, perhaps at our Women In Conservation event in the Philadelphia area in April, or at our Fall 2018 Solar Tour in Pittsburgh. Together, we will continue to make a difference.</p>
",Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"

Chesapeake Bay Efforts Headed in Right Direction for 2018,12/18/2017,"<p>As we approach the end of this crucial year for the Chesapeake Bay clean-up and efforts to meet its pollution reduction goals, Pennsylvania has taken a number of actions over the last month to capture the status of the state and provide input to the Environmental Protection Agency for the Total Maximum Daily Load&rsquo;s mid-point assessment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Halfway to 2025, the decisions and efforts Bay watershed states make in 2018 will ensure that they remain (or get on track) to meeting those pollution reduction goals.</p>

<p>In November, the Watershed Implementation Plan (WIP) Steering Committee for Pennsylvania recommended to the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) that local goals for the WIP should be developed at the county scale and the level of effort for the Bay planning targets should be equal for all jurisdictions in the Chesapeake Bay watershed.&nbsp;</p>

<p>These decisions should be applauded, because they are strong, but feasible and realistic policy decisions for implementing changes and best management practices for Pennsylvania. Rich Batiuk at the EPA Chesapeake Bay Program (CBP) office shared that he believes this was the right way for the Commonwealth, but recent discussions with EPA CBP Director Nicholas DiPasquale remind stakeholders that Pennsylvania should not lose sight of keeping a strong focus on York and Lancaster Counties specifically. Intentional and intensive focus must remain on the South Central Pennsylvania counties, which contribute the most load (nutrient pollutants and sediment) to the Susquehanna and Potomac River basins.</p>

<p>Over the last several months, DEP and EPA have collected &ndash; and continue to collect -&nbsp; a significant amount of data and continuously monitor and analyze information to better perform and make public policy decisions. But, it is important to effectively target and prioritize available funding, technical, and human resources. It is becoming more evident that Pennsylvania should leverage relationships with public-private partnerships, involve the private sector to meet goals, and include innovative technology in its path forward, but these strategies and tactics must be proven to work and be equitable.</p>

<p>At last week&rsquo;s December WIP Steering Committee meeting, stakeholders discussed other essential issues that need to be resolved for the Mid-Point Assessment of the Bay Program. Among these are Pennsylvania&rsquo;s take on the effects of climate change on the Bay watershed, sector growth, and the issue of the Conowingo Dam on the Susquehanna River.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While these are large topics that encompass a great deal of uncertainty, changing landscapes and input needs, Pennsylvania must step up and be a strong leader on climate change in the next WIP and its actions moving forward in the Chesapeake Bay clean-up. Though it should be a team effort with New York and Maryland, addressing the overflowing of sedimentation and pollutants at the Conowingo Dam must include Pennsylvania as an equal party to provide support in finding a solution.</p>

<p>In terms of sector growth, it is imperative that the Commonwealth be thoughtful and include its ramifications in all planning processes. Tomorrow, the Principals&rsquo; Staff Committee of the EPA Chesapeake Bay Program meets to take action on the TMDL mid-point assessment, and we urge strong policies be enacted on climate change, the Conowingo Dam, and growth in the Bay watershed.</p>

<p>It is long past time for Pennsylvania to step up and be a leader in the Chesapeake Bay clean-up, but recent actions provide some hope for next steps. As stakeholders and citizen advocates, we must continue to remind our legislators and executive officials that clean water matters in Pennsylvania. To restore and steward our beloved watersheds in the Commonwealth, we must hold fast our engagement and commitment to rigorous planning goals and targets.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Beside all requirements and goals, I long for the day I can share a few hours of crayfishing with my nephews in the currently impaired Conococheague and paddling in the impaired Susquehanna without fear of dirty water.&nbsp;</p>

<p>My New Year&rsquo;s resolution is to continue pushing hard for clean water in Pennsylvania and share my favorite waterways with friends and family more often. What&rsquo;s yours?</p>
",Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
"Proxy Battles, Bad Omens, and Small Victories: A 2017 Policy Retrospective",12/18/2017,"<div>A war against environmental protection is being waged in Pennsylvania and 2017 was about positioning for the next round of legislative attacks.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Proxy battles were waged through negotiations on the state budget and a proposed severance tax on natural gas, signaling larger efforts to come in 2018. And the legislature continued its dismantling of the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP).&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The callous legislative attacks on foundational clean air, water, and public lands policies continue and are unrelenting.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>Nevertheless, it&rsquo;s important to not lose sight of the victories in 2017 that are having tangible impacts and will improve local air quality and boost renewable energy and energy efficiency in the Commonwealth.</strong> Certainly, defending our communities and ecologies from bad legislation is a top priority, but advancing good legislation has been critical to re-engaging the public and policy community to show what good environmental laws can do for people&rsquo;s health, jobs, and living space.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>In retrospect, the headlines below best summarize the state of environmental policy in 2017:</strong></div>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Gutting basic protections against oil and gas industry pollution.</strong> A major proxy battle over oil and gas regulations was (and is still being) fought through the severance tax debate. The Senate and Governor agreed to a deal in the summer that would have levied a small severance tax in exchange for weakening the DEP&rsquo;s ability to enact strong permits for industrial activity. In particular, it would have shifted some of DEP&rsquo;s permitting authority to industry-chosen third-party reviewers, as well as forced DEP to approve all permits within a certain period of time, no matter if they&rsquo;re deficient. This bill died in the House, but momentum for gutting DEP permits still remains.</li>
	<li><strong>Allowing unlimited methane pollution.</strong> The Governor has made it a priority to implement the Commonwealth&rsquo;s first ever limits on methane pollution and the legislature is doing its best to stop that from happening. A provision to give the legislature the ability to veto any methane regulations was passed by the Senate and proposed in the House. DEP is advancing new methane limits on new oil and gas infrastructure as I write this blog, setting up a significant battle in 2018 over its success, as well as efforts to implement methane limits on existing oil and gas operations.</li>
	<li><strong>The continued dismantling of DEP. </strong>The FY2017-18 state budget was similar to the last decade in that DEP&rsquo;s budget was cut another 6 to 7 percent, depending on the line item. This adds to the 40 percent already cut in DEP&rsquo;s budget over the last ten years. This hollowing out is having tangible impact, as we see fewer inspectors who can ensure water supplies are safe, fewer inspections of oil and gas activity, fewer permit reviewers, and a smaller number of scientists studying new sources of pollution. For a state with a long history of environmental degradation, it&rsquo;s a stunning and underreported story with long-term consequences, and these shortages leave everyone at risk.</li>
	<li><strong>New subsidies for nuclear plants put on hold. </strong>Nuclear industry efforts for new subsidies benefitting its five Pennsylvania plants didn&rsquo;t gain traction with the legislature in 2017. Instead, the industry pushed the legislature to provide its toothless support for the Department of Energy&rsquo;s (DOE) request to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) to immediately provide support for aging coal and nuclear plants. Depending on what FERC ultimately does with DOE&rsquo;s request dictates whether the nuclear industry will apply significant pressure to get state subsidies in 2018.</li>
	<li><strong>Solar receives a legislative boost. </strong>Solar energy finally received support from Harrisburg. A provision in the state budget (Administrative Code, House Bill 118) includes language to &ldquo;close Pennsylvania&rsquo;s solar borders.&rdquo; What this means is that utilities must source solar energy projects housed in Pennsylvania to meet the Commonwealth&rsquo;s solar target (0.5 percent by 2020), rather than being able to source outside of the state. Under previous law, utilities were sourcing more than 70 percent of its projects from outside the state, stealing jobs and projects from Pennsylvania&rsquo;s solar industry.</li>
	<li><strong>Commercial PACE builds momentum.</strong> Commercial PACE (C-PACE), which provides new financing mechanisms for municipalities wanting to support commercial buildings becoming more energy efficient, took steps forward in 2017. The bill is cosponsored by nearly 2/3 of the state Senate and is poised for passage in 2018.</li>
	<li><strong>Protecting the Delaware River Basin from fracking. </strong>The Delaware River Basin Commission took its next steps toward officially banning oil and gas drilling in the Delaware River basin. While much of this process will play out through 2018, it was an important step toward protecting the important headwaters of the Delaware and the ecology it supports. As it currently stands, the proposed regulations aren&rsquo;t perfect and would still allow fracking fluid to travel from and through the basin. As such, more work needs to be done on the regulations, but the ban on fracking is a major step toward protecting this important water resource for the state.</li>
</ul>

<div>Many of these issues and battles will continue well into 2018, leaving no rest for the weary. There are bad omens signaling further attacks in the near future, but public engagement, perseverance, good science, and strong advocacy are helping turn the tide and beat back, at least some, bad legislation.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>I personally started 2017 much more cynically toward what was to come. It had been a bruising 2016 and environmental protection was poised for more rollbacks. But I end 2017 on a positive note. <strong>I see a re-energized environmental community and a general public catching on to the bad deals they&rsquo;re being dealt. </strong>Furthermore, I see pathways to advancing new protections and stopping the agents of greed and environmental destruction from succeeding in making Pennsylvania a wild west for industry and pollution.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Onward and upward.</div>
",Environment,"Matthew Stepp, Vice President and Chief of Staff, PennFuture"
The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is Not for Sale,12/14/2017,"<p>The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge spans over 19 million acres, a third of which is designated as pristine Alaskan wilderness and is a habitat for polar bears and dozens of other species. Hundreds of thousands of porcupine caribou, native to Alaska, migrate each year through the Coastal Plain. (1) The Arctic Refuge is an incredible example of America&rsquo;s natural legacy and is a symbol to the world that the United States has historically been one of the great stewards of the wilderness.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>However, that legacy may soon be tarnished by greed and profit.</strong> On Nov. 16, the House of Representatives passed the first version of the tax bill, which did not include anything regarding the Arctic Refuge. A week later, Senator Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) added a provision to the Senate version of the Tax Bill that essentially opens the Arctic Refuge&rsquo;s Coastal Plain to oil and gas drilling through an auction of lease sales.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>The resulting profit would cover only a fraction of the deficit that will result from the deep tax cuts that congressional leaders are proposing. </strong>The Coastal Plain is an ecological center for the wildlife that lives in the Arctic Refuge. Selling off these lands to oil and gas corporations to support tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans makes little economic sense and endangers a national treasure, which will never be able to be replaced once it is gone.</p>

<p>On Dec. 2, the Senate passed its version of the tax bill, which included Senator Murkowski&rsquo;s Arctic Refuge provision. In a process called &ldquo;Reconciliation,&rdquo; representatives from each congressional chamber have been tasked with reconciling differences between the House and Senate versions. Once complete, this compromise bill will return to the House of Representatives for a vote. Unfortunately, reports say that the Arctic Refuge provision will be included in the &ldquo;reconciled&rdquo; bill.</p>

<p>The Arctic Refuge has been imperiled before, but the decision to open the Coastal Plain is a deeply unpopular one. Environmental groups and conservationists across the country are critical of the tax bill, in part because of this provision.</p>

<p>Collin O&rsquo;Mara, President and CEO of the National Wildlife Federation, of which PennFuture is a state affiliate, is one of those leaders who has worked to mobilize action on behalf of preserving this habitat for so many species of animals.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;Drilling in the arctic will forever scar one of the remaining truly wild places on earth with a maze of well pads, roads, and pipelines. Destroying critical habitat for imperiled polar bears, porcupine caribou, and musk oxen, not for national security reasons, but for short-term tax breaks that benefit the few, is simply wrong. Some places are too special to drill. We urge members of Congress to defend the Arctic,&rdquo; O&rsquo;Mara said.</p>

<p>The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is a wildlife refuge first and foremost. It should remain fully protected for the many generations to come.</p>

<p><strong>Use the social media graphic at the top of this page on Facebook or Twitter to tell our representatives that we must continue to defend the Arctic! Use #ProtectTheArctic or #NotADrill and raise your voice.</strong></p>
