",Environment,"Alexander Cupo, PennFuture Southeast PA Outreach Coordinator"
Pittsburgh's Dirty Open Secret: Air Pollution,12/12/2017,"<p><em>Pictured: Greg Cooper and Colleen Sohn outside of their former home in Bellevue.</em></p>

<p><em><strong>By Colleen Sohn, Guest Blogger and Former Pittsburgh Resident</strong></em></p>

<p>Shortly after ringing in 2015, in the wee hours of the morning, I awoke to an acrid burning. In the moment of dread and terror before shaking my husband and hopping from bed, I thought: We&#39;ve only lived here a month and haven&#39;t even unpacked all the boxes.</p>

<p>Lightning quick, we dashed around the house, upstairs and downstairs, finding no flame. My husband unearthed a flashlight, and champion that he is, ran outside, clad only in underpants. There, he realized it was neither the house, nor the garage, but the sky, our neighborhood cloaked in a cloud of toxic air.</p>

<p>We were born and raised in Colorado, and had spent the previous 16 years living in Portland, Oregon. It was not as though pollution was entirely foreign to us. Denver&#39;s brown cloud of our youth was an ugly brute that often kept kids inside and friends and relations from burning fires in winter. We&#39;d caught dreadful whiffs of air from the paper plant located upriver from our home in Portland. Sadly, these were mere kittens to the beast we would experience in Pittsburgh.</p>

<p>My husband and I consider ourselves to be adventurous and easy going. We love to travel, to experience new places. After spending the first half of our lives in the West, we decided it was time to better know the East. From all we read online, it seemed Pittsburgh was the place to do it. Like Portland, it is a river city, fancies itself &quot;green,&quot; and has a burgeoning restaurant scene. There&#39;s great architecture, a gorgeous skyline, and world renowned institutions of learning. It&#39;s also a mere day-long (or less) drive from practically every city and town we hadn&#39;t yet had the opportunity to explore. Perfect on paper.</p>

<p>I arrived in October to buy a house. The skies were clear and bright and the winds were favorable. I never caught so much as a whiff of the air that would come to be my tormentor. I looked at houses in practically every neighborhood, too distracted by the task at hand to notice the chemical plants and factories along the rivers. I settled on a 1908 brick beauty in the borough of Bellevue. We could walk to the library, shops and restaurants, and zoot easily downtown. Again, perfect on paper.</p>

<p>Then, that fateful night, everything changed. At first, we thought it was a fluke. Then, we were taken aback, again and again, out to get groceries, visiting friends, a myriad of awful scents on the breeze. We asked around. &quot;I don&#39;t smell anything,&quot; they said. &quot;It&#39;s pollution from Ohio,&quot; they said. &quot;It&#39;s trains passing,&quot; they said. And then we saw it, Neville Island, and knew.</p>

<p>We learned about black carbon, part and parcel of PM2.5 - known to increase risks of lung cancer, asthma, and heart attacks, Pittsburgh&#39;s dirty open secret. We also came to know what we called the Pittsburgh mantra: &quot;You should have seen it before. It&#39;s better than it was!&quot; We heard the &quot;hell with the lid off&quot; stories, the businessmen who changed their soot stained shirts at lunchtime stories. And so it was better, and yet so awful.</p>

<p>As our interests and circle of friends widened, we further explored the city, secretly hoping we would find that magic spot where the pollution would not find us and perhaps move there. We had fun evenings in Mount Lebanon, saw movies in Regent Square and Lawrenceville, ate burgers on the South Side Flats, perused the murals of dahn-tahn, walked in Frick and Schenley Parks, and were assaulted. We met friends at an outdoor classical music concert on the most gorgeous of summer days in Highland Park, spreading our blankets in the warmth of the sun, only to be assaulted, yet again. We complained amongst ourselves and were on the receiving end of the evil eye from surrounding concert-goers. How dare we speak the truth out loud.</p>

<p>We kept a calendar, rating the air from zero to four. Zero was a lucky day, one where we could walk the neighborhood, dash off to the Phipps or the cookie shop and not feel our nostrils burning. A four had our HEPA filter on full blast. Our calendar showed more one to four days than zeroes, a whole lot more.</p>

<p>And so it went, any time we questioned or saw anyone else question the polluted air, we heard the Pittsburgh mantra, it was blamed on Ohio, or were told, &quot;Hope the door kicks you on the way out.&quot; And so we left, just over a year after moving into our lovely home. We&#39;re back in the West, Colorado Springs. The air is some of the cleanest in the country, and each day we breathe a literal sigh of relief that we were among the lucky ones. We could leave.</p>

<p><em><strong>Colleen Sohn is a bit of a renaissance woman. A former teacher, she is a photographer, writer, gardener, and ace cook. Born and raised in the West, she&#39;s happy to be back in her home state of Colorado. She and her husband lived in Pittsburgh for one year, between 2014 and 2015.</strong></em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,
Your Donation Keeps Eagles Safe in Their Nests,12/12/2017,"<p>PennFuture&#39;s work to protect and sustain the natural habitats of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s wildlife is effective - and sometimes that hard work leads to other environmental benefits &ndash; like a new park!&nbsp;</p>

<p>A 600-acre woodland set high on a hilltop overlooking the Monongahela River in Pittsburgh, known as Hays Woods, has long had an amazing diversity of wildlife that called it home. So, when Hays Woods became a high-profile, proposed location for a strip mine intended to level its hills and fill its stream valleys to pave the way for a race track and casino, PennFuture&rsquo;s Vice President of Legal Affairs, George Jugovic, Jr., led the way to protect it.&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture partnered with neighbors, grassroots organizations, activists, university students, and concerned decision makers to fight to protect the woodlands and streams for local wildlife. The work that began in 2003 culminated in a 2009 major legal victory for Hays Woods and Pittsburgh&rsquo;s environment.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Then in 2013, eagles began nesting in the forested hillsides of the property. Thirty years ago, there were only three nesting pairs of bald eagles in all of Pennsylvania. Today, more than 270 pairs nest in our state. Their recovery in Pennsylvania, and throughout the nation, is one of our great wildlife conservation stories. Habitats like that of Hays Woods are critical for their continued recovery.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>And today, Hays Woods takes another step to being the newest park in Pittsburgh, something that would not be possible if not for the good work of PennFuture&#39;s lawyers, which prevented mountain top mining on the Hays Woods site more than 14 years ago.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our legal work is more critical than ever and <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/2017dec/index.html?eType=EmailBlastContent&amp;eId=fba1a123-4ab3-4243-b044-d50e8ac2c2ab&amp;eType=EmailBlastContent&amp;eId=4173f0bf-87f6-4917-bf94-cd69ec19f3de""><strong>your tax-deductible gift to PennFuture </strong></a>is a powerful investment as we fight on your behalf to protect our parks, wildlife and special habitats for generations to come.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>It makes all of us at PennFuture proud to have been a part of Hays Woods&#39; restoration and transformation to a real park. But we can&rsquo;t (and never could) do it alone. We succeed because <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/2017dec/index.html?eType=EmailBlastContent&amp;eId=fba1a123-4ab3-4243-b044-d50e8ac2c2ab&amp;eType=EmailBlastContent&amp;eId=4173f0bf-87f6-4917-bf94-cd69ec19f3de"">supporters like you</a>&nbsp;know our work is valuable. <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/2017dec/index.html?eType=EmailBlastContent&amp;eId=fba1a123-4ab3-4243-b044-d50e8ac2c2ab&amp;eType=EmailBlastContent&amp;eId=4173f0bf-87f6-4917-bf94-cd69ec19f3de""><strong>Please take a moment to help us keep our voice strong</strong></a> for Pennsylvania&#39;s parks, wildlife and special habitats. I promise we will put your donation to immediate use.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Yours in gratitude,&nbsp;</p>

<p>Jacquelyn Bonomo&nbsp;<br />
President and CEO&nbsp;<br />
PennFuture&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

How Pending Federal Appropriations Might Affect Chesapeake Bay Watershed,12/7/2017,"<p>As our federal government approaches Friday&rsquo;s deadline to avoid a government shutdown, we wanted to check-in on how pending federal appropriations proposals will affect the Susquehanna River Basin and larger Chesapeake Bay watershed in Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>The health of the Susquehanna River basin and the Chesapeake Bay watershed in Pennsylvania is something that PennFuture works hard to protect and fight for every day through policy, litigation, communications, and outreach. For the past several years, PennFuture has led the fight for listing the lower Susquehanna River as impaired after the Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission found signs of sick aquatic life, advocating for increased conservation dollars for farmers, and cutting back on the overuse of fertilizer. Not only does PennFuture lead the Commonwealth&rsquo;s clean water advocacy efforts at the state level, but our constant presence and relationships forged with our federal legislative offices have forced the slow-down of regulatory roll-backs and the draconian gutting of critical funding for the Susquehanna River basin.</p>

<p>Earlier this year, the White House released its 2018 federal budget proposal, which included massive cuts to investment in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Alarmingly, President Trump&rsquo;s proposal slashed the EPA&rsquo;s annual Chesapeake Bay Program budget from $73 million to $0. If the proposed budget had been enacted, it would have been impossible for Pennsylvania to meet its pollution reduction obligations required by the U.S. Clean Water Act to clean up the Chesapeake Bay and restore local streams in the Susquehanna River basin.</p>

<p>Chesapeake Bay Program funding for restoration comprises nearly 55 percent&nbsp;of its total budget. Under President Trump&rsquo;s proposal, Pennsylvania would have lost nearly $12 million in aid through Chesapeake Bay Implementation grants and National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Stewardship grants. If the Bay Program&rsquo;s almost $41 million of on-the-ground grant funding disappeared, the state of Pennsylvania would be left without the resources necessary to guarantee clean water to local communities and businesses. At a time when there is broad-based support to work on pollution reduction compliance goals, this funding is crucial to support a wide range of watershed efforts, including agricultural best management practices for farmers, green infrastructure and stormwater management for municipalities, and protecting riparian buffers along streams.</p>

<p>Despite 63 percent of Americans having a favorable view of the EPA, under President Trump&rsquo;s proposal, the EPA&rsquo;s budget would take the hardest hit of any agency. Its 31 percent budget cut would eliminate more than 3,000 staff and discontinue a number of programs critical to the survival of America&rsquo;s wildlife.</p>

<p>Without full funding, Pennsylvania&rsquo;s waters are put in jeopardy by nutrient pollution, erosion, sediment, and run-off. A healthy and robust Chesapeake Bay Program budget is an integral part of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s effort to ensure clean water for its citizens and the Susquehanna River basin.</p>

<p><u><strong>Fortunately, we can tell a different story.&nbsp;</strong></u></p>

<p>Through the spring, summer, and fall, PennFuture has been actively working with congressional offices across the state and in Washington to reinstall the EPA funding for the Chesapeake and Susquehanna. We learned in October that the House Interior Appropriations bill has approved returning $60 million to EPA&rsquo;s Chesapeake Bay Program, and just before Thanksgiving, we heard that the newly passed Senate Interior Appropriations bill has included $73 million for the Chesapeake Bay Program, with $6 million for each grant program ($12 million in total).</p>

<p>PennFuture extends deep thanks to our champions for Chesapeake funding in the House of Representatives for their work in seeing the Bay Program&rsquo;s budget secured and renewed &ndash; namely, Congressman Glenn Thompson, Congressman Charlie Dent, Congressman Lloyd Smucker, and Congressman Matt Cartwright. PennFuture thanks Senator Bob Casey, as well, for his continued support for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Chesapeake and Susquehanna funding.</p>

<p>Our pollution reduction goals for the Chesapeake Bay watershed cannot be realized without continuing to make these clean water investments in our communities. We are asking our federal legislators and President Trump to support funding for programs that provide aid to Pennsylvania, local governments and communities, and farmers throughout our region. A strong EPA is essential for the restoration and stewardship of the Susquehanna River basin. We ask our members of the Pennsylvania congressional delegation to bring back full, dedicated funding for our clean water in upcoming appropriations legislation.</p>

<p>Anyone who spends time in the outdoors knows that Pennsylvania has abundant water resources. With more than 86,000 miles of streams, we&rsquo;re second only to Alaska. Unfortunately, there is a water crisis in Pennsylvania, and a united voice of citizens is needed to press back and remind our federal legislators that funding for clean water is non-negotiable. Six million Americans rely on the Susquehanna River for their drinking water, but that has been put at risk. Elected officials have failed to protect the water we drink by failing to protect our waters and streams, and as a result, Pennsylvania ranks third in most reported drinking water violations.</p>

<p>We have a constitutional responsibility to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment and that includes protecting and maintaining our rivers and streams.</p>

<p>We must support a responsible budget and EPA&rsquo;s role in protecting the Susquehanna and the Bay. We must remind our Representative and Senators that we oppose President Trump&rsquo;s plan to slash the Chesapeake Bay Program budget and support the recent Senate bill to fully restore the $73 million for the EPA Chesapeake Bay Program.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s clean water depends on it.</p>
",Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
November Snapshot: Chesapeake Bay Clean-Up Efforts,11/28/2017,"<p>It has been a busy autumn in terms of addressing Pennsylvania&rsquo;s water quality challenges.</p>

<p>Since the kick-off of the Steering Committee for the Watershed Implementation Plan&rsquo;s Phase III in early June and the large success of Penn State University&rsquo;s &lsquo;Ag Progress Days&rsquo; in August, stakeholders and voices for clean water across the Commonwealth have provided critical feedback and scores of public comments to the PA Department of Environmental Protection on how and what to address with the Chesapeake Bay clean-up.</p>

<p><strong>In late August, the Wolf administration rolled-out an announcement regarding the first year of the Chesapeake Bay Agricultural Inspections Program and wrote about how the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection, in partnership with Pennsylvania&rsquo;s conservation districts, &ldquo;not only exceeded federal expectations for numbers of acres inspected, but also found that a majority of farms are complying with state planning requirements.&rdquo; </strong>The executive branch agencies working on the current Chesapeake Bay clean-up efforts should be lauded for their 60 percent farm inspection completion rate, but this means about 40 percent of the Keystone State&rsquo;s 60,000 farms have yet to be inspected. This means that more than three million acres of agriculture land has gone the last year without ascertaining whether these properties are compliant with conservation and maintenance requirements. With yet another shaky and delayed state budget this year &ndash; at times agriculture preservation and conservation dollars in jeopardy &ndash; these missed opportunities underscore the importance of increased staffing and funding in our state agencies.</p>

<p><strong>Through September and October, the WIP Steering Committee met regularly to start to answer the larger questions and establish the stage for the development of the Watershed Implementation Plan.</strong> Key workgroups on funding, agriculture, wastewater, stormwater, forestry, and local area goals, priorities, and practices have begun to meet in earnest. As Pennsylvania&rsquo;s WIP Steering Committee has begun to dig deeper to address current water quality challenges, a few members reflected on the experience of Phases I &amp; II. Chief among these reflections were that Pennsylvania policymakers, in Phase III, should break down the larger target numbers of the EPA expectations to a more local, and tangible level. It was also recommended that the third phase, helping Pennsylvania meet its TMDL pollution reduction goals by 2025, should ensure that the current local water cleanup efforts be accurately tracked and the data shared with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Perhaps the clearest proposal to keep in mind moving forward is the need to identify the value (economic, cultural, spiritual, aesthetic, etc.) and stacked benefits of cleaning up our local waters.</strong> In reports this fall presented at the Susquehanna River Symposium at Bucknell University, hosted by the Susquehanna River Heartland Coalition for Environmental Studies, the University of Michigan and Penn State University state that, when we monetize and think in terms of economic value of a natural resource, the Susquehanna River Basin is worth nearly $2 billion annually. Investing in our watershed should not be about the Bay, but instead about restoration and stewardship of our own waters. As an Amish farmer from Lancaster County told me this fall, &ldquo;Our conservation is not about meeting requirements &ndash; it&rsquo;s all about taking care of our home.&rdquo; The cost of inaction far outweighs the abundant benefits of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s renowned outdoor recreation, beverage industry, sustainable agriculture, energy, and forestry, and clean water supply.</p>

<p><strong>What remains to be clear is that Pennsylvania is far behind in meeting its pollution reduction goals for nitrogen, phosphorous, and sedimentation.</strong> Thanks to generous help and leadership provided by the University of Maryland, United States Geological Survey (USGS), the Susquehanna River Basin Commission (SRBC), and the EPA Chesapeake Bay Program, Pennsylvania stakeholders, policymakers, and members of the WIP Steering Committee are starting to understand the way forward better. Large-scale and in-depth efforts are underway to collect and analyze data in order to create local water cleanup plans with the greatest possible impacts and it has become a priority of the groups at play to focus on the top load-producing watersheds.</p>

<p><strong>A newly released report entitled &ldquo;Boots on the Ground&rdquo; from the Chesapeake Bay Commission further points out the severe need for more technical assistance to farmers implementing best management practices in the Bay watershed &ndash; including Pennsylvania &ndash; along with increased need for incentives and funding.</strong> As 2017 begins to draw to a close, EPA Chesapeake Bay Program staff are starting to determine how Pennsylvania is doing and what actions must &ndash; and should &ndash; be taken to get the state on track again for 2025. The TMDL mid-point assessment does not look good for Pennsylvania, and that is before we think about other factors inhibiting progress that are knocking on our door: addressing climate change&rsquo;s effects on the Chesapeake Bay watershed, the Conowingo Dam issue, the potential impairment of the lower Susquehanna, pipeline infrastructure, and development and forest fragmentation taking place at rapid paces.</p>

<p><strong>And this all brings us back to the age-old problem in Penns Woods: funding.</strong> While the state budget dilemma for FY2017-18 has been resolved, albeit four months overdue, state dollars for conservation practices and staffing at our state agencies charged with clean water responsibilities seem to be cut on an annual basis. Members of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s General Assembly have dug in their heels on not investing in and prioritizing Pennsylvania&rsquo;s clean water and next year&rsquo;s budget process is likely to be slow coming, as well.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As this Watershed Implementation Plan process continues to unfold, make sure to take a stand for clean water. Follow our upcoming regular blogs on the WIP, frequent check-ins on the Bay watershed clean-up and upcoming policies we&rsquo;re pushing. Tell your state and federal legislators we need a strong DEP and EPA. This holiday season, #OptOutside - explore your watershed&rsquo;s headwaters and plant your holiday trees. Stay tuned.</p>
",Environment,"Ezra P. Thrush, Senior Director of Government Affairs"
What You Need to Know in Advance of the Issuance of DRBC’s Fracking Regulations,11/27/2017,"<p>The Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC) has directed its staff to issue regulations regarding unconventional natural gas extraction activities, namely, the horizontal, hydraulic fracturing method, also known as fracking,&nbsp;within the Delaware River watershed.&nbsp;Those draft regulations are to be issued no later than this Thursday, Nov.&nbsp;30.</p>

<p><strong>This blog post is intended to provide you with background information and to prepare you for the upcoming public commenting period.&nbsp;We want everyone to be engaged to protect the Delaware River from the environmental and human health risks posed by fracking.</strong></p>

<p><strong>Brief History of DRBC&rsquo;s Regulation of Fracking</strong><br />
<a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Moratorium-on-Fracking-in-the-Delaware-River-Basin-is-Critical-to-Protect-Our-Water"">We recently wrote about how the DRBC&rsquo;s long-standing moratorium on fracking is critical to protecting the Basin&rsquo;s resources.</a>&nbsp;In that blog, we briefly discussed why the DRBC was formed and what it does to protect the Delaware River.&nbsp;We also explained how the&nbsp;7-year &ldquo;de facto&rdquo; moratorium came to pass. We concluded by pointing out that DRBC had identified specific and serious concerns about the risk of harm posed by unconventional natural gas development in the Basin, and has held off on allowing such risky extraction unless and until it can ensure the protection of the water resources of Basin. Considering the precious nature of the Basin&rsquo;s resources, and the possible long-term impact that natural gas development can have on water resources, PennFuture supports a permanent ban on fracking in the Basin.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>What to Expect</strong><br />
The DRBC will draft regulations prohibiting the production of natural gas via fracking within the Basin, but will allow other fracking-related activities to occur within the watershed.&nbsp;In particular, the DRBC will allow both (1) the storage, treatment, disposal, and/or discharge of fracking wastewater within the Basin, and (2) the transfer of Delaware River water outside of the Basin for use in fracking.&nbsp;Both of these activities have the very real possibility of impacting both the water quality and water quantity of the Delaware River, and&nbsp;these are the regulations that PennFuture is most concerned about.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>When the draft regulations come out, we expect an in-depth review of the regulations regarding fracking wastewater and inter-basin water transfers will be needed.&nbsp;Based on our 2010 review&nbsp;of the then-draft DRBC regulations, we anticipate that the regulations will not be strong enough to sufficiently protect the critical headwaters and wetlands of the Delaware River.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>At this point, it is unclear how long the public comment period will be, but PennFuture expects it to be at least several months, since DRBC has indicated its intent to hold several public hearings throughout the Basin.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>What You Can Do</strong><br />
As we review the draft regulations and the public comment process moves forward, PennFuture will be providing you with information and ways to get involved to protect the Delaware River Basin.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In addition, <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/donate"">please consider supporting PennFuture&rsquo;s efforts</a> to protect the sensitive, high-quality headwaters of the Delaware River Basin.&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Making a Difference with Momentum,11/27/2017,"<p>This month has turned out to be an extraordinary time for all of us who care deeply about our environment.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>We are beginning to see important shifts in power, both in the political realm and in the realm of our democracy in action.</strong> These shifts must become more pronounced, and must be sustained if we are to win back the safeguards that ensure cleaner air and water. The attempted theft of these hard-won laws, regulations and rights seems finally to be slowing. It is up to all of us to continue the fight, and hasten the shift back to a sane and balanced Commonwealth, where citizens can determine their clean energy future, assisted by responsible elected officials.</p>

<p>Thanks to the diligent and inspiring leadership of PennFuture&rsquo;s former director of policy, recently named Vice President and Chief of Staff Matt Stepp, along with Joanne Kilgour, director of the Pennsylvania Chapter of Sierra Club, and other groups active on the legislative front, we saw a near-disastrous state budget season turn net-positive.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Not only was the environmental community able to fight off horrendous proposals to fundamentally change the state&rsquo;s approach to environmental permitting, and to stop raids on environmental funding, we had a win. </strong>We secured legislation to &ldquo;close the borders&rdquo; on solar credits. This means that solar energy that gets counted towards Pennsylvania&rsquo;s clean energy goals must be generated within our state, somewhat incentivizing solar production right here at home. These measures were fought and won with the help of a cohesive and core group of pro-environmental legislators, who&nbsp; joined with PennFuture in taking a firm stand against the antis, holding that first line of defense, and perhaps for the first time, hanging tough as a core group to win the day.</p>

<p><strong>This month also saw diverse and pro-environmental candidates winning in the general election. </strong>A former Riverkeeper is now mayor of York. Every one of the candidates endorsed by our partner organization, Conservation Voters of Pennsylvania, prevailed, and my colleague there, CVPA Executive Director Josh McNeil, is ready to bring more environmentally friendly candidates into the critical 2018 elections.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>In Western Pennsylvania, PennFuture&rsquo;s Toxic Neighbor campaign had material impact on holding to account the most egregious air polluter in the region &ndash; U.S. Steel&rsquo;s Clairton Coke Works.</strong>&nbsp;Recently joining me in speaking before the Allegheny County Health Department board and staff were a group of tenacious, smart and strategic community leaders who have been fighting for cleaner air in Pittsburgh for many years. Volunteer leaders with powerful messages are emerging through this campaign, including East End resident Lisa Minetti, <a href=""http://www.post-gazette.com/opinion/Op-Ed/2017/11/12/Reality-check-Pittsburgh-s-air-is-still-highly-toxic/stories/201711120024"">who joined forces with PennFuture to write an op-ed that appeared in the Sunday edition of the Nov. 12th Pittsburgh Post-Gazette.</a> Lisa&rsquo;s voice, our collective work, and this campaign is beginning to make a difference.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Two weeks ago, <a href=""http://www.post-gazette.com/news/environment/2017/11/14/US-Steel-Edgar-Thomson-mill-Pittsburgh-Braddock-on-notice-pollution-equipment-violations-EPA-ACHD/stories/201711140148"">we saw a glimpse of leadership</a> from the Allegheny County Health Department and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency when the agencies issued a notice of violation to U.S. Steel around another abomination in our right to clean air, the Edgar Thomson steel mill. <a href=""http://www.post-gazette.com/opinion/editorials/2017/11/19/Something-in-the-air-Violations-cannot-stand-at-local-U-S-Steel-plant/stories/201711300023"">And on Sunday, Nov. 19, we saw the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette state in an editorial that these continued air quality violations by U.S. Steel &ldquo;cannot stand.&rdquo;</a></p>

<p>Finally, emerging from the COP23 Climate Change Conference is a very important group of Pennsylvania mayors from Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, Allentown, Ambler, Bethlehem, Easton, Ferguson Township, Lancaster, Swarthmore and West York Borough. These mayors have stated their commitment to support local climate action in the absence of federal and state leadership.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Is the tide truly turning?&nbsp; Do we have the collective will and energy to keep this momentum going? Can we beat back the next volley of anti-environmental measures that the legislature will surely try to put in place to protect the interest of the fossil fuel industry? Will more pro-environment leaders emerge in communities, to speak out, or stand for elected office? Will more climate-conscious mayors take their communities&rsquo; clean energy future into their own hands and stand with the Paris Climate Agreement? Will more elected officials join that core of pro-climate and pro-public health legislators and fight alongside PennFuture? The answer must be yes.</p>

<p>As I transition from running PennFuture, as its former Chief Operating Officer, to leading PennFuture as its president,&nbsp; I want you to know that I, and the rest of the staff, are privileged to lead the state&rsquo;s top watchdog for clean air, water and a healthy climate.&nbsp;Every day, we embrace our work, and the trust you have in us, with energy, passion and seriousness. We know you look to us for leadership, and turn to us for good information and assistance.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Know that we look to you, too, for inspiration. </strong>You are making a difference with every vote you cast, every letter you write, every conversation you have with your family, friends or colleagues. With every check you write supporting PennFuture, with every solar panel you install, or light bulb you change out, and with your social media activism, you make a difference. So, keep up the good work, and I assure you that we at PennFuture will do the same.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
Environmental Impacts and the PennEast Pipeline,11/14/2017,"<p><em>PennFuture Staff Attorney Abigail M. Jones is pictured.</em></p>

<p>Last Thursday, a local Carbon County environmental organization hosted a press conference to bring to light concerns surrounding the anticipated approval of the PennEast pipeline.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Save Carbon County Coalition, along with PennFuture and the Lehigh Gap Nature Center, gave testimony on this issue at the Carbon County Courthouse Annex building in Jim Thorpe, PA after the commissioners meeting.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The group is anticipating that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), will give PennEast pipeline the certificate it needs to proceed with the pipeline construction following a meeting scheduled for Dec.&nbsp;21.&nbsp;</p>

<p>With this in mind, Save Carbon County President Linda Christman organized this press conference to highlight the environmental impacts that will follow pipeline construction. The impacts include clear cutting trees in Carbon County, treats to waterways and wildlife, along with eminent domain struggles for landowners. Save Carbon County will be holding frequent meetings with landowners to inform them of their rights at every step of the Eminent Domain process.</p>

<p>Lehigh Gap Nature Center&rsquo;s program specialists Chad Schwartz and Brian Birchak spoke about the clear cutting trees issues and how it will affect farmland, wetlands, and invite invasive species to inhabit the area. Clear cutting trees will create an edge for the regional/ native species that live in the area. This &ldquo;edging&rdquo; will offer space for invasive species, such as the spotted lantern fly and tree of heaven to take over the clear cut areas.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;While PennFuture has many concerns with the increased pipeline infrastructure in Pennsylvania &ndash; including climate change and cumulative environmental impacts &ndash; our focus is on the price that our environment and individual landowners are forced to pay as a result, even before the pipeline route is finalized,&rdquo; said Abigail M. Jones, PennFuture Staff Attorney. &ldquo;In our state, we are seeing an alarming lack of protection for the environment at the hands of the expansion of natural gas pipelines&hellip; it is estimated that Pennsylvania could have upwards of 10,000 miles of Marcellus Shale gas pipelines crisscrossing the state by the end of the year.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Jones also highlighted: &ldquo;Our environmental rights are as fundamental as our right to free speech. Yet DEP&rsquo;s pipeline policy fails to protect our environmental rights from pipeline construction and &lsquo;pre-construction&rsquo; activities.&rdquo;</p>

<p>PennFuture, Save Carbon County, and Lehigh Gap Nature Center came together to educate the public and bring to light major concerns about the clear cutting process during preconstruction of the PennEast pipeline. This not only affects wildlife and nature, but the pipeline and tree clear cutting will affect the natural, scenic, historic, and aesthetic values to the environment throughout Carbon County and the rest of the PennEast pipeline route&nbsp;that brings economically valued tourism and a beautiful place to live in the Lehigh Valley and beyond.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Emily Rinaldi, Northeast PA Outreach Coordinator, PennFuture"

<p><em><a href=""http://goatrodeocheese.com/"">Goat Rodeo Farm and Dairy</a> is a member of <a href=""https://www.respectagzone.org/"">RESPECTAgZone</a>, a committed, passionate group of homeowners, businesses, farms and neighbors in the heart of Allegheny County, Pennsylvania. Members of the group live in the Agricultural Zone of Indiana Township, a decades old community with ordinances that protect the agricultural way of life, and preserve one of the last remaining areas of its kind for all. <strong>PennFuture&#39;s legal team is representing <a href=""https://www.respectagzone.org/"">RESPECTAgZone</a> in an effort to protect the land.</strong></em></p>

<p><em>Superior Motors restaurant in Braddock is hosting an awareness fundraiser dinner featuring Goat Rodeo Farm &amp; Dairy&#39;s cheeses on Nov. 14. <a href=""https://www.superiormotors15104.com/articles/we-love-what-we-do-at-goat-rodeo-farm-and-dairy--raising"">Click here for more details.</a></em></p>

<p>We love what we do at Goat Rodeo Farm and Dairy - raising our 100+ goats and making award-winning cheeses that people across Pennsylvania and the region love.</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s amazing what you can accomplish in a few years. We have a beautiful, 130-acre farm located in a designated Agricultural Zone (AgZone) in Indiana Township, just 10 miles and a short 20-minute ride north of Pittsburgh.</p>

<p><strong>We worked hard to secure this designation. But today, Duquesne Light Company (DLC) is planning new construction of high-power transmission lines and monopoles for its northern region. Our AgZone falls within two routes under consideration.</strong></p>

<p>RESPECTAgZone is a community group of people who work and live in Indiana Township&rsquo;s Agricultural Zone. We&rsquo;re strongly opposed to Duquesne Light&rsquo;s routes that cross the AgZone because it will devastate our businesses, recreation areas and the environment.</p>

<p><strong>There is a viable alternate route that makes use of current rights of way and infrastructure corridors, and we&rsquo;re petitioning DLC to proceed with construction along this eastern route that follows the Pennsylvania Turnpike north to the West Deer area. It is an environmentally conscious route that will save small businesses like ours, recreation areas used by thousands, and 1,000 acres of agricultural land.</strong></p>

<p>The RESPECTAgZone community organization is doing everything possible to persuade DLC of the Pennsylvania Turnpike route. Turnpike engineers have told us they believe it is a viable, good route. And our state legislator and Turnpike officials are also supportive.</p>

<p>We welcome your support, too! Please visit <a href=""https://www.respectagzone.org/"">www.RespectAgZone.org</a> to learn more and sign our online petition to save this treasured farmland, a short 20-minute drive to the city. Also, we invite you to write to State Senator Randy Vulakovich and State Representative Frank Dermody to let them know this issue is important to you and it&rsquo;s the right thing to do. You can also copy Jessica Rock and Zach Merritt of Duquesne Light on your letters.</p>

<p>Thank you,</p>

<p>India and Steve Loevner&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""http://goatrodeocheese.com/"">Goat Rodeo Farm &amp; Dairy</a></p>

Five Years After Superstorm Sandy,11/6/2017,"<p>On Tuesday, Oct.&nbsp;31, PennFuture commemorated the fifth anniversary of Superstorm Sandy by hosting a statewide telepresser exploring the relationship between climate change and the increasing frequency of extreme weather events.</p>

<p>Larry J. Schweiger, President Emeritus, and Rob Altenburg, Director of the PennFuture Energy Center, discussed the climate impacts of governmental inaction as well as the enormous costs that taxpayers bear in the wake of increasingly severe weather events.</p>

<p>During the call, Schweiger addressed the combination of massive and widespread damage from this season&rsquo;s hurricanes, along with the California wildfires that were exacerbated by a warmer climate, and caused FEMA and other governmental emergency response groups to be strained financially and operationally.</p>

<p>Schweiger highlighted that over the past decade, the government has spent $350 billion responding to extreme weather and fire events, made worse by climate change, according to a <a href=""https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/extreme-weather-climate-change-costing-taxpayers-billions-n813431"" target=""_blank"">recent report from the Government Accountability Office</a> (GAO). Additionally, as regulations are rolled back and our climate response is effectively halted, the cost of these storms will only increase.</p>

<p>Altenburg provided his expertise around environmental, climate, and energy policy that are essential to advancing clean energy solutions for Pennsylvania, and highlighted recent work in the state to improve our energy profile and move us towards a renewable future.</p>

<p>Altenburg&nbsp; also gave updates on the state of solar in PA and pointed to the Finding PA&rsquo;s Solar Future project as an ongoing effort by PennFuture to find a pathway to achieving 10 percent of our in-state generation from solar power by 2030.</p>

<p>Thank you to our speakers and to all who attended. You can find the recording for the event below.</p>

What It Means to Live Near Big Polluters,11/1/2017,"<p style=""text-align: center;""><img alt="""" src=""/Files/Admin/Blaine%2Dand%2DLisa%2Ejpg"" style=""width: 562px; height: 750px;"" /></p>

<p>We moved to Pittsburgh for many reasons: a slower pace of life, the kind of friends who will linger after dinner, and the chance to have a backyard garden.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Fifteen months into this Pittsburgh life, we have all of that and more. Unfortunately, there was one surprise that wasn&#39;t so welcome. Two days after landing here last July, we awoke to crisis.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Lisa, my wife, woke up with an asthma attack and a splitting headache. </strong>I woke up to the sound of her slamming the windows shut to our home in the East End. We hadn&#39;t yet unpacked the HEPA filter that we brought from New York. What was that smell? It was a blend of rotten eggs and burning metal. Whatever it was, we knew we had a big problem.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>&ldquo;The smell,&rdquo; as we have come to call it, is most noticeable early in the morning hours, and it is often weakened by noon. Beyond the nuisance of smelly air, this pollution gives Lisa respiratory distress and headaches. Exercising outdoors on a bad air morning is out of the question, and sometimes we have to cancel preplanned activities when bad air comes in.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>Our experiences led us to start investigating just what was producing this polluted air. Our search led us to the <a href=""http://www.achd.net/air/enforcement.html"">Allegheny County Health Department website</a>, which showed that there are four non-compliant industrial facilities in the county.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The smoking gun in our research was PennFuture&#39;s investigation, finding 6,700 Clean Air Act violations by one of these facilities, Clairton Coke Works, in a 3.5 year period. During this period, Clairton Coke Works&#39; violations average to more than five air quality violations per day.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>We know that the Allegheny County Health Department has repeatedly fined Clairton Coke Works for air quality violations. These fines have not stopped the violations or the resulting public health crisis. <strong>When a facility commits 6,700 air quality violations in 3.5 years, that suggests an operating strategy more than a series of accidents.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>PennFuture is a leader in the movement to help make sure our elected and appointed officials represent the environmental interests of the millions of people imperiled by industrial pollution in our community. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/ToxicNeighborPgh""><strong>We first noticed PennFuture&#39;s Toxic Neighbor Campaign</strong></a> as a Facebook ad focused on the Clairton Coke Works. <strong>We were so inspired that the campaign was addressing the two most pressing local air quality issues &ndash; <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/ToxicNeighborPgh"">the long emergency of the Clairton Coke Works</a> and the impending emergency of the <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/toxicneighbor"">Shell Ethane Cracker Plant in Beaver County</a> &ndash; that we immediately sent a donation to help PennFuture amplify this campaign.</strong> PennFuture has been doing great work across the state for decades, and it is great to see them taking on some of our most significant environmental threats in Pittsburgh and Western Pennsylvania.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Of course, the history of the coking and steel industry is one of flagrant local air pollution. <a href=""http://[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1948_Donora_smog"">During the 1948 Donora Smog</a>, 20 people died as a result of U.S. Steel&#39;s Hydrogen Fluoride and Sulfur Dioxide emissions, accumulating during a 4-day weather inversion. The disaster was partly limited by cooperation between local officials and plant managers who agreed that the plants had to be shut down for the duration of the weather inversion. Where is this kind of cooperation today?</p>

<p>Seventy years later, the air is cleaner in Pittsburgh than it was in the 1940&#39;s, but far from acceptable. In the 1940&#39;s, Mayor David Lawrence and banker Richard Mellon worked together to help check a smoke problem that was wildly out of control. Thanks in part to them, that coal door in my basement goes unused, and I don&#39;t have to change my shirt mid-day due to sooty air.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Today, we have the Clean Air Act and a better scientific and medical understanding of the health effects of emissions from coke and steel making. <strong>Unfortunately, we also have a situation in which industrial polluters can continue to pay fines to operate outside of Clean Air Act standards.</strong></p>

<p>The Allegheny County Health Department, ACHD Director Dr. Karen Hacker, and County Executive Rich Fitzgerald must lead us as David Lawrence and Richard Mellon did in the 1940&#39;s.&nbsp;They must act more aggressively to stop the toxic emissions that harm our most vulnerable populations, up to and including revoking emissions permits for non-compliant facilities. Until they do, Pittsburgh and Allegheny County will fall short of its potential to be a great, healthy place to live.&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-Launches-Toxic-Neighbor-Citizen-Engagement-Campaign""><em>For more information on the Toxic Neighbor campaign and how to get involved, click here.</em></a></p>
",Environment,"Blaine Martin, Guest Blogger"
PennFuture's New CEO: Jacquelyn Bonomo,10/30/2017,"<p style=""text-align: center;""><img alt="""" src=""/Files/Admin/Jacquelyn%2DBonomo%2DPhoto%2DCredit%2DBrandon%2DReefer%2D2017%2EJPG"" style=""width: 800px; height: 532px;"" /></p>

<p><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/News-PennFuture-Leadership-Transition-Announced"">Last week, I became president and CEO</a> of PennFuture, a 20-year-old statewide organization fighting for your rights to clean air, pure water, and a healthy climate.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I thought I&rsquo;d use this blog post to briefly introduce myself to you. I also want to personally thank everyone who supports PennFuture through activism or financial support. We will always need more of both, and I will strive to say thank you over and over again along the way, if I am lucky enough to meet you in person, and through these notes.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I hail from northeastern Pennsylvania, the anthracite coal region &ndash; Hazleton to be exact. I grew up surrounded by family &ndash; five of the seven houses on my block were occupied by my grandparents, aunts, uncles and cousins, and at one point, I could count more than 200 family members living in the Hazleton area. The view from our upstairs window was one of coal breakers, abandoned mineland, strip mines and even a steam shovel or two. Several of my uncles were active with the United Mine Workers and worked oiling the buckets at the end of the behemoth shovels&rsquo; arms. One of my uncles died tragically when ground underneath the steam shovel he was operating gave way. I was too young to absorb the breadth of this tragedy, which occurred around the same time that &ldquo;hard coal&rdquo; began to see its demise in the early 1960&rsquo;s.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>I left Hazleton the day after high school graduation to begin college at Penn State&rsquo;s main campus and soon began hiking, and doing a little birdwatching. That was the start of my real love of the outdoors and the wanderlust that has taken me to so many special parts of our state, the country, and beyond. After graduating from Penn State with a degree in English, I lived out west for a spell, working in Arizona and Jackson Hole, Wyoming, where I ski bummed and became a river guide. After returning to my hometown, being outdoors and in nature as much as I could was a part of my essence as a person, and I spent a lot of my time around the Nescopeck Creek. The area&rsquo;s array of wildlife, natural communities and unique flora revealed itself to me in so many special experiences and observations over the many hours I spent there. I fell unabashedly in love with the place and could not believe I grew up so close to it, truly appreciating it all for the first time at the age of 26.</p>

<p><strong>My heart was broken when I learned that the state had plans to flood the valley of the Nescopeck, and condemn those gorgeous bottomland forests, wetlands, and miles upon miles of brook trout habitat to watery oblivion. I said to myself: &ldquo;I&rsquo;m not going to let them do it.&rdquo; And that was the day I became an activist, sometimes warrior, for our environment. I was able to build a large coalition of local, regional and national sportsmen and wildlife groups, supported by a list of state and national natural resource agencies with missions to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s nature and biodiversity, and together, we stopped the dam at what is today Nescopeck State Park.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>In the early days of that fight, I met Larry Schweiger, who I now succeed as PennFuture&rsquo;s president. Larry offered me my first professional position in the environmental field, and I joined him at National Wildlife Federation&rsquo;s Washington D.C. office as he became head of its national field operation. Since then, Larry and I have worked together twice more over my 32 year career. We collaborated when he brought me into Western Pennsylvania Conservancy, and most recently at PennFuture, where I served as executive vice president and chief operating officer prior to my promotion to CEO. I am humbled to be taking the baton from him&nbsp;at this critical time for our planet.</p>

<p>In the coming months and years, I will have much more to share with you about this amazing organization, PennFuture, and the work of my gifted staff and volunteers. For now, let me fast-forward five decades from when I looked out the window of my home.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Today, when I peer out the window of my parents&rsquo; home in Hazleton, the mineland in the foreground of my view just this past year has been reclaimed, and the dangerous pits are filled in, graded, and covered with warm season grasses.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Now, I know that at the base of the next ridge over, Nescopeck Creek flows freely, and the next ridge further west of the Susquehanna River is making its way to Chesapeake Bay.&nbsp;</p>

<p>And while there is so much more work to be done &ndash; another part of the Nescopeck Creek receives the largest mine drainage on the east coast, and the Susquehanna River is being used to cool Talen Energy&rsquo;s Susquehanna Nuclear Power Plant -- let me tell you what lies on the furthest ridge out that I can see.</p>

<p>I see a long line of wind turbines, churning out renewable, clean energy: a symbol of our future, our children&rsquo;s future and Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Future.&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/newsletter-sign-up""><em><strong>Stay connected to our work today by joining our email list.</strong></em></a></p>
",Community,"Jacquelyn Bonomo, PennFuture President and CEO"
Time for Solar,10/27/2017,"<p>On Saturday, Oct. 14, we joined a bus tour hosted by PennFuture and sponsored by Levin Furniture that featured three homes in the Pittsburgh area with solar power.</p>

<p>The first house was a solar passive house that made maximum efficient use of &quot;free&quot; energy from the sun.</p>

<p>The second house had a double array of 40 solar panels in the backyard of a homeowner who is driving an electric car (Nissan Leaf) and also has two electric Tesla&#39;s ordered. He can fill-up at home for &quot;free!&quot;</p>

<p><img alt="""" src=""/Files/Admin/bob1%2Ejpg"" style=""width: 750px; height: 422px;"" /></p>

<p>The third house featured 16 solar roof panels that provided about half their electric needs during most months of the year. Like the previous homeowners, they were very excited about their role in reducing air pollution and dependency on fossil fuels, while adding some energy independence to their own lives.</p>

<p>According to our tour guide, there is still time to save money on solar installations with a 30-percent federal tax credit extending through the end of 2019, while a reduced tax credit extends a year or two beyond that.</p>

<p><img alt="""" src=""/Files/Admin/bob2%2Ejpg"" style=""width: 750px; height: 422px;"" /></p>

<p>Beyond the immediate benefits to the environment, homeowners estimate their investments will reach the financial break even point in 15 years.</p>

<p>Most of the panels have a 30-year guarantee and the average installation cost per roof panel is approximately $1,000 (before the 30% federal tax credit). Ground arrays cost more due the extra cost of posts and supports.</p>

<p>Imagine the beauty of lower electric bills while benefiting the environment, a win-win!</p>

<p><em>Bob began his 35-year landscape contracting career following graduation from the Ornamental Nursery Industry program in Penn State&#39;s College of Agriculture. <a href=""https://bobscaping.com/"">Click here to view his blog.</a></em></p>
",Energy,"Bob Donnan, Guest Blogger"
Meet the Donor: Joseph Morinville – EIS Solar,10/27/2017,"<p>As PennFuture celebrated its 7th Annual Pittsburgh Solar Tour, which was held Oct. 14, I had the opportunity to speak with one of our long-time donors who has supported the event for several years &ndash; Joe Morinville of Energy independent Solutions (EIS Solar).</p>

<p>Joe is originally from Minnesota and came to Pittsburgh when he met and married a local lady! While he originally missed his hometown, he told me, &ldquo;Now you couldn&rsquo;t drag me out of here. I love Pittsburgh.&rdquo;</p>

<p>I asked him why he started his business and what made him interested in renewable energy.&nbsp; Joe said there were two main events that turned him on to all things solar and renewable.&nbsp; The first was when he was a high school student back in Minnesota. His dad was interested in solar and Joe found himself taking a solar training course. He thought it was the coolest technology and really liked how it worked.</p>

<p>But in the early 2000&rsquo;s, the second event happened that really strengthened Joe&rsquo;s resolve.&nbsp; He and his wife were looking for some property to build a home in the Pittsburgh area and thought they had found the perfect place.&nbsp; But Joe noticed that the ponds on the beautiful property looked strange and sadly, he found out that the ponds were heavily contaminated.&nbsp; Doing some more research, Joe learned that the property had been owned by a coal company that had strip mined it and then went bankrupt.&nbsp; The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection had been brought in to do a cleanup not once, but three times.&nbsp; Joe and his wife decided not to build their home there.&nbsp; Even today, Joe told me, the land is still vacant and unusable because of its legacy with chemical waste that remains in the water and surrounding ground.</p>

<p>All of that led Joe to really think about the impact and legacy of coal.&nbsp; It was not cheap, he thought.&nbsp; The cleanup costs and health impacts were enormous.&nbsp;</p>

<p>He then became involved in Oil Free Farms (O.F.F.), a nonprofit, before starting EIS in 2008. He had been in financial services for 11 years but was very interested in farming.&nbsp; He always liked agriculture and that combined with clean energy led him to the idea of farmers growing their own energy!&nbsp; He wanted to help farmers become more energy efficient and he began working with a team of folks on biomass projects.</p>

<p>One evening, he and his team were in a discussion group and a large general contractor came in and asked Joe&rsquo;s group to do an audit of their building.&nbsp; It turned out that the Massaro group wanted solar on their building, but as Joe said, at the time, he was not certified to do that. Rising to the challenge, Joe changed direction.&nbsp; He went from nonprofit to for-profit, got himself certified to do solar work, and EIS Solar was born! He&rsquo;s never looked back.</p>

<p>One of the projects he is very proud of&mdash;he calls it the quintessential project for EIS Solar &ndash; was at Phipps Conservatory.&nbsp; At the time, EIS Solar was small and many believed he and his team didn&rsquo;t have the capacity to complete the job. Joe would go to events and people would come up to him and say &ldquo;If you and your team can finish at Phipps&hellip;&rdquo; and he would always respond, &ldquo;We don&rsquo;t fail.&rdquo;&nbsp; But Joe knew they had to prove themselves, and they did. They have also worked on Phase 2 and Phase 3 at Phipps Conservatory&rsquo;s Living Building.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>EIS Solar has completed work on five Living Building projects. Those types of buildings are harder to do than regular LEED buildings in terms of code compliance because the building has to create all of its own energy and clean its own water.</p>

<p>Joe says what makes his renewable work so gratifying is: &ldquo;our people.&rdquo;&nbsp; EIS Solar has assembled a team of phenomenal individuals &ndash; local to Pittsburgh &ndash; whose quality and workmanship is fantastic.&nbsp; His team, he said with pride, is the secret to their success.</p>

<p>From a clean energy perspective, Joe reminded me, you never accomplish all of your goals, but EIS Solar is where they want to be at this point in time.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>When I asked him about what he hoped for the future of clean energy, Joe said, &ldquo;EIS Solar is always pursuing the cutting edge of things and we make sure we can build the most beautiful functional projects.&rdquo;&nbsp; But he noted Harrisburg is all about policy &ndash; and all the policy and all the technology in the world do not make clean energy &ndash; you have to actually build it!</p>

<p>Joe, thank you and your team for your clean energy leadership and your support!&nbsp; We&rsquo;re glad you are standing with us.</p>
",Energy,"Susanne Whitehead, Director of Donor Relations"
ACE Program Volunteers Engage Legislators on Environmental Issues,10/13/2017,"<p>After the 2017 presidential election, Brian Polilli knew he needed to get involved in the democratic process to make a difference on environmental issues &ndash; he just wasn&rsquo;t sure where to turn.</p>

<p>&ldquo;Post-election, I was pretty aggravated about the direction of the country and since then, we have seen a lot of environmental standards being relaxed. The global warming issue is something we can&rsquo;t continue to drag our feet on,&rdquo; Polilli said. &ldquo;I have always been concerned about these issues and the election motivated me to take a further look at what I could do.&rdquo;</p>

<p>When he found PennFuture&rsquo;s newly created Advocates for Conservation and the Environment (ACE) Program, he discovered an outlet and the guidance needed to take the first steps to meet with his elected officials. This program enables volunteers to voice their concerns about environmental issues directly to their elected representatives in their home district offices.</p>

<p>PennFuture&rsquo;s ACE program organizes teams of volunteers to educate their state and federal legislators about conservation and environmental issues. ACE volunteers provide policy makers with an opportunity to learn from concerned citizens who live in their respective districts about environmental and public health issues that affect their communities.</p>

<p>&ldquo;ACE committees meet with Democrats and Republicans, liberals and conservatives, to advocate policy rather than to advance an ideological agenda,&rdquo; said Jay Andrews, Ph.D, PennFuture&rsquo;s Director of Outreach. &ldquo;Such pragmatism is not just for show; it is an effective way to realize tangible benefits for our members, for the public, and for the environment. ACE is about policy, not partisanship.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Polilli, 39, of Phoenixville, Pa., is a scientist with Johnson &amp; Johnson. As an ACE volunteer, he recently participated in two meetings that engaged State Rep. Becky Corbin&rsquo;s (R-155) office, and State Sen. John Rafferty&rsquo;s (R-44) office.</p>

<p>&ldquo;These meetings are valuable no matter what happens. When you show your elected officials that enough people are concerned, it matters,&rdquo; Polilli said. &ldquo;We are trying to educate them and I learn something more as well in terms of the process. It helps when you participate in conversations and have experience with your elected official, rather than just reading about them in an article.&rdquo;</p>

<p>PennFuture outreach staff worked with Brian and other volunteers prior to the meeting, providing talking points and information about key environmental issues in his district, including education on methane pollution, watershed protection, and policy proposals that advance energy efficiency.</p>

<p>Polilli&rsquo;s biggest takeaway from the program is that the process is not as daunting as others may think. He is also more aware than ever that regular citizens need to voice their concerns about the environment to their elected officials to make sure progress is made.</p>

<p>&ldquo;Don&rsquo;t just assume the right thing is going to get done,&rdquo; Polilli said. &ldquo;That is frequently not the case. If you really believe certain things should be done, complaining about it on Facebook doesn&rsquo;t do anything. This is an opportunity. It is far less intimidating in the moment than you might think. These are professional people who are pleasant to talk to. If you go in to have a conversation, they will listen. If you know a little bit of information and are reasonably engaged on an issue, it&rsquo;s easy enough to talk about it.&rdquo;</p>

<p><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/join-the-ace-programhttps://pennfuture.org/join-the-ace-program"" target=""_blank""><em><strong>For more information on the ACE program, click here.</strong></em></a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Stephanie Rex, Director of Communications"

Join PennFuture's 7th Annual Solar Tour!,10/10/2017,"<p>Ever wonder how solar energy works in a city as cloudy as Pittsburgh? And even if it does work, is it affordable?</p>

<p><strong>All of your solar-related questions can be answered this Saturday, Oct. 14 at <a href=""http://pghsolartour.org/"">PennFuture&rsquo;s Seventh Annual Pittsburgh Solar Tour</a>, sponsored by Levin Furniture.</strong></p>

<p>During this event, you will have the chance to meet home and business owners who went solar for various reasons throughout the Greater Pittsburgh Area. For instance, Fred went solar to help fight climate change, Bryan wanted to save money on his electric bills, and Marybeth wanted a stronger energy approach for her family.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Others on the tour went solar because their neighbor made the switch, which isn&rsquo;t an uncommon reason. In fact, two researchers at Yale and the University of Connecticut found the single most important factor driving people to go solar happened to be peer influence.&nbsp;</p>

<p>With the Pittsburgh Solar Tour&rsquo;s interactive online map, you can take a look to see if someone in your neighborhood went solar and get insight on how it works for their home. The Pittsburgh Solar Tour strives to make sure you have all of the resources available when making the decision to use clean energy from solar panels.</p>

<p>While homeowners will be able to talk about their perspective of what the process was like for them, and perhaps show you some recent energy bills, you will also have the opportunity to speak with various installers from companies including Energy Independent Solutions, Scalo Solar, and SolarCity. They will be able to explain and suggest if a solar loan or power-purchase agreement is a better fit for your needs.</p>

<p>This year&rsquo;s tour features: Phipps Conservatory, Homewood&rsquo;s Oasis Farm &amp; Fishery Bio Shelter, The Aquaponics Project at Repair the World, Levin Furniture&rsquo;s Wexford location, and the Telsa showroom in the North Hills of Pittsburgh.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Pittsburgh Solar Tour doesn&rsquo;t just promote solar energy. As Adam Haas of Phipps Conservatory states in our video, &ldquo;Sustainability isn&rsquo;t a destination, it&rsquo;s a journey. There&rsquo;s always something else to improve.&rdquo; By featuring other sustainable facets such as aquaponics and geothermal energy on the tour, even folks who have already switched to using solar panels can learn about next steps to take in their clean energy journeys.</p>

<p><strong>There are many different venues a person can take to participate in this year&rsquo;s tour. You can:</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Take a free bus ride from noon to 2 p.m. and/or from 2 to 4 p.m. from the Frick Environmental Center, led by solar experts.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Join the guided 2 p.m. East End Bike Tour, led by Solarize Allegheny&rsquo;s Sharon Pillar. The tour will start at solar homeowner Fred Kraybill&rsquo;s house at 7211 Thomas Boulevard in Point Breeze and end at the East End Brewing Company.</li>
	<li>Download our free mobile app or use the online interactive map to do a self-guided tour</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Be sure to secure your spot and register at <a href=""http://pghsolartour.org"">pghsolartour.org</a>.</strong></p>

<p>This tour is&nbsp;timely as Environmental Protection Agency Chief&nbsp;Scott Pruitt recently announced,<a href=""http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/354594-epa-chief-id-do-away-with-wind-solar-tax-credits""> &ldquo;I would do away with these incentives that we give to wind and solar,&rdquo; </a>referring to solar&rsquo;s investment tax credit.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s critical that we create more incentives for people to go solar, including better tax credits, rebates, performance payments, and property/sales tax exemptions as, solar only powers 5 percent of Pennsylvania. By participating in the Pittsburgh Solar Tour, we hope you&rsquo;ll see the enthusiasm these home and business owners possess and how we can continue to solarize Pennsylvania.</p>
",Energy,"Annie Regan, Senior Program Manager"
PennFuture Opposes Any Repeal of the Clean Water Rule,9/27/2017,"<p>Today, <a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/2017-09-27-PennFuture-Clean-Water-Rule-Repeal-Public-Comments-%28EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0203%29.pdf""><strong>PennFuture submitted public comments </strong></a>urging the Trump Administration not to repeal the federal Clean Water Rule.&nbsp;Repealing the Clean Water Rule would threaten Pennsylvania&rsquo;s clean water, outdoor economy, and safe drinking water for millions of citizens.&nbsp;</p>

<p>One of the most important aspects of the Clean Water Rule is its protection of the sensitive, smaller waters critical to safeguarding water quality and wildlife throughout Pennsylvania.&nbsp;Small headwater streams and wetlands provide the greatest connections between land and water, trapping and storing nutrients, providing critical habitat, storing floodwaters, contributing to drinking water supplies, and filtering out pollutants. These streams are essential to protect drinking water; in Pennsylvania 58% of the streams that provide water for surface water intakes that supply public drinking water are intermittent, ephemeral, or headwater streams.&nbsp;But just as importantly, headwater streams have biological, chemical, and hydrologic connections to downstream waters.&nbsp;Scientific studies repeatedly demonstrate that the health of downstream lakes, rivers, and estuaries are directly tied to the health of their smaller headwater streams and wetlands.&nbsp; Leaving these critical headwaters vulnerable to pollution puts the health of all of our rivers and the communities that depend upon them at risk.</p>

<p>Case in point: according to a recent analysis, repealing the Clean Water Rule would result in a loss of Clean Water Act protections to 55% of all stream miles in the Delaware River Watershed.&nbsp;These intermittent, ephemeral, and headwater streams in the Delaware River Watershed provide not only clean drinking water but are also spots for outdoor recreation and esthetic enjoyment of the natural environment. A repeal of the Clean Water Rule would put all of this at risk.</p>

<p>And although Pennsylvania has the Clean Streams Law, which protects the &ldquo;waters of the Commonwealth,&rdquo; this federal Clean Water Act jurisdictional issue can directly impact water quality protections in Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>For example, Section 401 of the Clean Water Act requires that any federally-permitted project that may discharge into a &ldquo;navigable waterway&rdquo; (the definition of which includes &ldquo;waters of the United States&rdquo;) cannot proceed unless the state certifies that the discharge will not violate state water quality standards.&nbsp; Quite simply, should the federal government narrow the definition of &ldquo;waters of the United States,&rdquo; smaller but ecologically important streams and wetlands, which likely suffer greater impacts from these projects than larger waters, will lose this protection under the Clean Water Act.&nbsp; An important aspect of the 401 Water Quality Certification process is that states may deny a certification or impose conditions as part of its certification to ensure that the applicant complies with any applicable state law. These conditions then become a part of the federal permit.&nbsp; If a project avoids the need for state certification because the federal government narrows the definition of &ldquo;waters of the United States,&rdquo; the states lose this ability to protect their waters by either denying the certification and halting the project or imposing federally-enforceable conditions to ensure that the project will not harm state water resources.</p>

<p>Additionally, and as a very practical matter, this loss of clear protection at the federal level for these critical headwaters and wetlands could result in the future weakening of protections in Pennsylvania as well, especially where the state environmental regulatory agency is so underfunded and under-staffed.&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
PennFuture&rsquo;s comments made clear that we will not accept any repeal of the Clean Water Act protections that keep our waters, our economy, and our communities healthy.&nbsp;<br />
Background</p>

<p>Promulgated in 2015, the Clean Water Rule clarified the definition of &ldquo;waters of the United States&rdquo; under the federal Clean Water Act, and notably extended clean water protections for small, intermittent and ephemeral streams and wetlands that had a &ldquo;significant nexus&rdquo; to traditionally navigable waters.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The 2009 United States Supreme Court split decision in Rapanos v. United States, 547 U.S. 715 (2006) (&ldquo;Rapanos&rdquo;) left regulators and the regulated community confused about which waters fell under the Clean Water Act&rsquo;s jurisdiction because a majority of the Supreme Court did not agree on a definition of &ldquo;waters of the United States.&rdquo;&nbsp; The Clean Water Rule sought to clarify this confusion by adopting a definition of &ldquo;waters of the United States&rdquo; that was consistent with Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy&rsquo;s opinion in Rapanos, which protected any waters that had a &ldquo;significant nexus&rdquo; to navigable streams.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In adopting the Clean Water Rule, EPA engaged in an almost 7-month public comment period, met with over 400 stakeholders, and received over one million comments on the proposed rule, with over 87% of them in favor of the agencies&rsquo; proposal.&nbsp; More than 50,000 Pennsylvanians supported the Clean Water Rule, including business owners, local officials, farmers, and health professionals.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>PennFuture strongly supported the Clean Water Rule because it not only protected the larger streams used directly for drinking water by millions of Pennsylvanians -- it also protected sensitive headwater streams and wetlands that makeup thousands of miles of streams in the Commonwealth.</p>
",Environment,"Abigail M. Jones, Vice President of Legal and Policy"
Meet the Donor: Dawn Gorsline,9/26/2017,"<p>When Dawn and Brian Gorsline purchased property in Fairfield Township, they were overjoyed.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 1999, Dawn and Brian were looking for property that would allow them to build a home to raise a family in a healthy and safe environment - a place where they could conserve land, grow Christmas trees and watch generations of their family experience the beauty of nature at its fullest.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Their search led them to an area in Fairfield Township, Lycoming County, zoned Residential-Agriculture. Dawn had grown up in the area and her family still lived there. &ldquo;It was the perfect place with the best people living in it,&quot; she said.</p>

<p>Little did she realize that several years after building her dream home, Dawn&rsquo;s desire to protect her family&rsquo;s way of life would involve her in a constitutional law case that would lead all the way to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2013, a neighbor mentioned to Dawn that a company, Inflection Energy, was looking at locating a shale gas well pad near their homes, and that a township meeting had been scheduled.&nbsp;Dawn recalls the meeting. &ldquo;It was filled with angry people who had a lot of questions&quot; she said.&nbsp;It was at this meeting that she met one of PennFuture&rsquo;s legal team members, who, after studying the township&rsquo;s zoning ordinance, said, &ldquo;We have a case.&rdquo;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Because the township&rsquo;s ordinance did not expressly regulate oil and gas development, in order to allow shale gas development in its R-A district, the township had to find that use of the land for construction and operation of a well pad was &ldquo;similar to and compatible&rdquo; with other land uses expressly allowed in the district.&nbsp;Despite opposition from those most impacted by the well, the township&rsquo;s board of supervisors approved use of the land to construct and operate the well pad. Within 3,000 feet of the pad were 126 drinking wells. The owner of the property on which the well pad would be located lived in another township. PennFuture, representing the Gorslines and their neighbors, the Batkowskis, challenged the township&rsquo;s decision in Common Pleas Court.</p>

<p>Dawn and her neighbors quickly experienced the impacts associated with construction of a gas well pad in a residential neighborhood.&nbsp;Seismic &ldquo;thumper&rdquo; trucks showed up unexpectedly; strangers with chainsaws appeared in backyards without permission; helicopters hovered overhead and dropped cables across those same properties. It generally felt like life had gone from predictable to chaos in a few short months.&nbsp;</p>

<p>When Inflection began constructing a holding pond for the well pad despite the pending appeal, PennFuture&#39;s legal team sprang into action and obtained an injunction to prevent further construction activities until the judge could rule on PennFuture&rsquo;s challenge.&nbsp;After deliberation, Judge Mark Lovvechio issued a decision in favor of the Gorslines and Batkowskis, reversing the township&rsquo;s conditional use application.&nbsp;Judge Lovvechio believed that Inflection had failed to show that the proposed land use was &ldquo;similar to and compatible with&quot; other land uses expressly allowed in the district.</p>

<p>Not to be outdone, Inflection appealed its loss to the Commonwealth Court.&nbsp;After written and oral argument, a three-judge panel of the Court reversed the Common Pleas Court&rsquo;s decision.&nbsp;The opinion was extraordinary in that the Court held that an industrial land use that uses heavy machinery, large diesel engines, and involves the storage of highly flammable material, toxic waste and explosives, and generates waste characterized as industrial by the state of Pennsylvania, was &ldquo;similar to and compatible with&rdquo; other land uses expressly allowed in the R-A district, such as single family homes.&nbsp;The ruling effectively cut an exception in the zoning ordinance so wide that it would result in shale gas development being allowed everywhere, regardless of the nature of the zoning district.&nbsp;It was an outrageous demonstration of judicial overreach.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Not giving up, PennFuture sought allocator permission to have the case reviewed by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court. Only a small percentage of these types of petitions are granted by the Court, but this one of them.&nbsp;The case presents for decision the issues of whether shale gas development constitutes an industrial land use, and whether the government violates the constitutional rights of existing property owners who relied on the township&rsquo;s zoning scheme by allowing incompatible land uses in the zoning district in which the residents reside.&nbsp;The case was argued on March 8, 2017.&nbsp;The case has the potential to establish statewide precedent on a number of important environmental and public health issues facing Pennsylvania.</strong></p>

<p>Dawn feels strongly that clean air and clean water should never be threatened and that we - all of us - need to fight for our basic rights to protect those natural resources and public health and safety. Dawn teaches third grade and environmental science at her primary school and regularly emphasizes to her students that &ldquo;wherever you step, there is life where you walk. You cannot just abuse the land and expect good results.&quot;</p>
",Environment,"Susanne Whitehead, Director of Donor Relations"
