Shifting Away from Coal Toward Renewable Energy,7/31/2017,"<p><em>This opinion piece appeared in the <a href=""http://www.observer-reporter.com/20170729/commentary_we_should_shift_away_from_coal_toward_renewables"">Washington Observer-Reporter </a>on July 29, 2017 in a point / counterpoint feature about the coal industry in Pennsylvania.</em></p>

<p>Any conversation about the future of coal must be candid about a number of realities. Our energy system is changing rapidly toward clean energy and away from fossil fuel. Our political class can either lead toward economic and environmental success or continue to bury its head in the sand and be defeated. Part of the problem is the public debate on coal has been layered with myths, misdirection, and lies that have derailed a forward-looking discussion on how we harness and use energy, as well as how it impacts hardworking Americans.</p>

<p>First, we must discuss the reality of climate change. The facts are clear: we cannot hope to keep the world&rsquo;s temperature at a safe level if we continue to rely on carbon-intensive fossil fuels like coal. The United States has already emitted more carbon pollution than any other country in history, and has a moral and ethical responsibility to do its fair share to mitigate the danger. Instead, our climate policy is rife with weakness, denial, and obstruction, rather than providing an economically beneficial pathway to a cleaner, prosperous energy future.</p>

<p>Second, coal remains dangerous to the communities that surround it. Burning coal releases a wide variety of cancer-causing, lung-damaging pollutants, including mercury, acid gases, and smog-forming pollutants, which result in hospitalizations and deaths. Coal mining itself permanently scars our environment and damages our land and water &ndash; just ask anyone in the old coal towns scattered around Pennsylvania. Coal isn&rsquo;t clean, and we can&rsquo;t forget how it has harmed generations of workers and communities.</p>

<p>Third, there is no such thing as a &ldquo;war on coal.&rdquo; Tree huggers, former presidents, and government regulations aren&rsquo;t killing coal. Rather, simple economics are leading to its demise as cheaper alternatives replace it in the market. Natural gas and renewable energy are winning the day. As a result, coal industry leaders are trying to cut every corner they can find. They&rsquo;re using automation to replace workers. They&rsquo;re spending money they say they don&rsquo;t have to lobby for even more government subsidies. And, in some high-profile cases, they have been caught cutting corners on their safety and environmental responsibilities. Underneath all of the war-on-coal rhetoric is a textbook case of industry trying to skirt its responsibilities to its workers and environment to make a few more dollars. We all pay the price.</p>

<p>Fourth, don&rsquo;t be duped by promises of metallurgic coal. Coal has been the main source of power for our blast furnaces and steel mills, but even so, its future is not assured. Steel manufacturers, such as U.S. Steel, are already publically discussing plans to replace coal and coke used in steel mills with natural gas as a cost-cutting measure, and the rise of international carbon tariffs could limit international markets for steel made in coal-fired mills.</p>

<p>Fifth, political leaders are doing coal workers a disservice. Rather than recognizing that the United States is under a generational shift in energy and providing support for its workers and a path to more prosperous jobs, they&rsquo;re instead providing lip service, myths, and false hope.</p>

<p>Policymakers should be passing legislation to rebuild old coal communities, fund reclamation of abandoned mining operations that are polluting our streams, and provide new job opportunities for coal miners. Coal workers have provided a critical service to society by lighting our homes and providing heating for our families. We should ensure that those workers are treated with respect and provided with good-paying jobs in new industries.</p>

<p>With the industry in a permanent state of decline, there are policy choices to be made. Doing nothing is probably the worst decision. If we take that path, we will face not only the worst effects of climate change, but the workers and the communities that rely on coal will continue to suffer.</p>

<p>Further subsidizing coal is an equally terrible choice. In Ohio, coal plant owners have lobbied to force consumers to pay above-market prices for coal power. Taking a similar path in Pennsylvania might keep coal plants profitable a little while longer, but will raise electricity prices. With many coal plants near the end of their expected lives, that would only be a short-term solution. When the inevitable collapse comes, the fall will be that much harder.</p>

<p>The best alternative is to provide real support to coal workers and provide them a path to work in next-generation energy industries. We must also account for the environmental and public health damage caused by coal and include that in the price &ndash; ending a significant subsidy to coal that it has benefitted from for more than 100 years. Pennsylvania can use that revenue from the cut subsidies to help coal communities rebuild their economies, clean up their coal piles, and provide cleaner, more prosperous jobs for its families.</p>
",Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
Legislators Target a Severance Tax – in Name Only,7/26/2017,"<p>Over the last few weeks, state legislators have <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Harrisburg-Punts-on-Environmental-Protection-in-the-State-Budget-Again"">prioritized raiding conservation funds </a>and cutting environmental protection agencies under the guise of getting serious about balancing the budget.&nbsp;</p>

<p>This was no more evident than when the House of Representatives recently considered a &ldquo;severance tax in name only,&rdquo; in which legislators proposed changing the name of the natural gas &ldquo;Impact Fee&rdquo; to &ldquo;severance tax.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>In other words, the House proposed last minute legislative deception to make it look like it passed new revenue.</strong> It&rsquo;s like saying they balanced the state budget by passing a law that changes the word &ldquo;debt&rdquo; to the word &ldquo;surplus,&rdquo; or rebranding carbon pollution as &ldquo;good for farmers and agriculture&rdquo; and calling it <a href=""http://www.nationalreview.com/article/295098/carbon-emissions-are-good-robert-zubrin"">promising for the planet.</a></p>

<p><strong>The Fake Severance Tax Gambit</strong></p>

<p>On Saturday, July 21, the House was convened to develop, debate, and vote on bills that would raise enough revenue to pay for the budget the legislature passed a few weeks earlier. (i) Of environmental concern, legislators proposed taking money from funds dedicated to land conservation, supporting parks, farmland preservation, and water pollution projects to balance the budget. (ii)</p>

<p>The legislature doesn&rsquo;t have to take a sledgehammer to these programs as it has many other revenue options at its disposal, including some that have significant support among the general public. <strong>One of those ideas is implementing a severance tax on natural gas drilling, which has received support from <a href=""http://www.politicspa.com/rmu-poll-finds-support-of-same-sex-marriage-and-extraction-tax/58349/"">58 percent of the public when polled.&nbsp;</a></strong></p>

<p>As such, the House called an Energy and Environmental Resources Committee hearing on July 22&nbsp;to vote on severance tax proposals &ndash; House Bill 113 (Rep. Harper, R) &ndash; which would levy a 3.5 percent severance tax and use the revenue to pay down the pension liability and help balance the budget.</p>

<p><strong>Rather than take up the bill on its merits, House legislators concocted a plan to replace the bill with language that renames the already existing &ldquo;Impact Fee&rdquo; on gas wells a &ldquo;severance tax.&rdquo;&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p><u><strong>I&rsquo;ll state that again so it sinks in:</strong></u><strong> Instead of debating a real severance tax, the legislature wanted to rename an existing fee, and call it a good day&rsquo;s work.</strong></p>

<p>Ultimately, the House didn&rsquo;t follow through with the fake severance tax gambit because members were sent home after an overall budget agreement couldn&rsquo;t be made. But it&rsquo;s indicative of how many more of our legislators are interested in gutting conservation and environmental protection rather than coming up with an equitable budget solution that doesn&rsquo;t require doing so.</p>

<p><strong>Pennsylvania Doesn&rsquo;t Have a Severance Tax</strong></p>

<p>The fake severance tax gambit highlights the common myths holding back its passage, the most prominent being industry&rsquo;s charge that Pennsylvania already levies a severance tax and instead calls it by a different name &ndash; an &ldquo;Impact Fee.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>While it&rsquo;s true that the Commonwealth charges a fee on gas wells, it&rsquo;s much different than a severance tax, and the distinction means Pennsylvania taxpayers are leaving hundreds of millions of dollars in potential revenue on the table.</p>

<p>Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Impact Fee is an annual charge on gas wells that is tiered to the price of natural gas and declines over time. It&rsquo;s structured to provide more revenue as the number of gas wells increases. Revenue flows back to municipalities to invest in fixing infrastructure degraded or oversubscribed by increased industrial use. It&rsquo;s a popular program and serves an important purpose, supporting local municipalities with small local tax bases to deal with rising infrastructure costs.</p>

<p>On the other hand, a severance tax charges a percentage of the average market price of the gas extracted, plus a flat fee for every thousand cubic feet of gas extracted. It&rsquo;s structured to provide more revenue as the price of gas increases, or as the amount of extracted gas increases.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>It&rsquo;s easy to see why the gas industry doesn&rsquo;t want a severance tax and pushes the argument we already have one.&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>Their top goal is to increase the price of natural gas in Pennsylvania to increase their profits. They&rsquo;re doing so by limiting new drilling, and building new pipeline projects to sell the gas outside of the state and, more importantly, outside of the United States at a higher price.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>As the value of gas increases, a severance tax would become more lucrative, whereas Impact Fee revenue would remain static or decline. Keeping the Impact Fee is more profitable to an already very profitable gas industry.</strong></p>

<p>This act of corporate trickery is having a ripple effect throughout the state budget.&nbsp;</p>

<p><a href=""https://www.pennbpc.org/no-matter-how-you-figure-it-severance-tax-generates-more-revenue-impact-fee-and-clearly-better-deal"">The Pennsylvania Budget and Policy Center estimates </a>that the Commonwealth would raise at least $480 million more revenue per year through a severance tax than the Impact Fee.&nbsp;</p>

<p>In other words, Pennsylvania is leaving a significant amount of budget revenue on the table by not levying a severance tax and are instead cutting core environmental protection programs to try and balance the budget.</p>

<p><strong>Calling a Spade a Spade</strong></p>

<p>To be fair, balancing the budget always includes a mix of budget cuts and new revenue. Both are needed to equitably close a <a href=""http://www.witf.org/state-house-sound-bites/2017/06/breaking-down-the-budget-the-political-path-to-pas-structural-deficit.php"">$3 billion structural deficit</a> that has dragged on too long. Calling a spade a spade, the legislature isn&rsquo;t acting fairly and is eviscerating environmental protection and conservation programs and selling it as needed budget cuts.</p>

<p>For over a decade, the legislature has stripped to the bone the Commonwealth&rsquo;s environmental protection programs and support for our parks and forests. These agencies currently can&rsquo;t complete their most basic functions, like protecting the public&rsquo;s <a href=""http://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2017/02/02/u-s-warns-pennsylvania-over-safe-drinking-water-violations/"">drinking water</a> or cleaning up the <a href=""http://lancasteronline.com/news/local/pennsylvania-lags-on-chesapeake-bay-cleanup/article_2ff5229e-40ba-11e6-98be-df8ac8dc9c42.html"">Susquehanna River basin</a>. Parks and forests are understaffed and are sitting on years of past maintenance backlog <a href=""http://paenvironmentdaily.blogspot.com/2013/02/senate-budget-hearing-dcnr-has-1.html"">exceeding $1 billion.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>Certainly, times are tough for state budgeting, but these fundamental state programs have given <a href=""http://paenvironmentdaily.blogspot.com/2017/06/house-senate-governor-agree-on-31996b.html"">more than enough</a> toward balancing the budget. Rather than dangerously cutting environmental protection programs yet again, as well as taking dedicated money from land conservation and water projects, legislators need to look elsewhere to balance their budget.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>This includes taking a hard look at their rhetoric around a severance tax (and other potential revenue raisers) and asking whether protecting <a href=""https://www.fool.com/investing/2017/07/26/can-the-marcellus-shale-continue-fueling-big-profi.aspx"">soaring</a> gas industry profits is worth harming the Commonwealth&rsquo;s environment and public health.</strong></p>

<p><em>(i)Note that the legislature already slashed environmental investments this year. The FY2017-18 budget cuts water, land, and air protection and conservation programs by 2 percent to 7 percent compared to last year&rsquo;s budget (and up to 33 percent compared to these budgets 15 years ago).<br />
&nbsp;(ii)Specifically, the legislature was targeting: (1) Environmental Stewardship Fund, which supports everything from greenways, trails, and community parks to water cleanup and wildlife habitat protection; (2) Keystone Recreation, Park, and Conservation Fund, which is the chief way Pennsylvania conserves and protects public lands and historic sites as well as invests in libraries, public parks, and new lands for recreation; and (3) Farmland Preservation Fund, which is how state and county governments purchase conservation easements to preserve Pennsylvania farms to slow the selloff of those lands for development.</em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Matt Stepp, Director of Policy"
Meet the Donor: Rodney Gasch,7/25/2017,"<p>Rodney Gasch, a retired freelance writer and current president of the Latin American Children&rsquo;s Fund and president of Historic Harmony, Inc., has been a long-time PennFuture donor. In 2016, Rodney and his wife, Laurie, decided to change things up and become monthly supporters.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As Rodney said, &ldquo;Giving once a year is important, but PennFuture, like most nonprofits, has expenses 12 months a year.&rdquo; It was an easy decision for he and his wife to make the switch.</p>

<p>Rodney grew up in eastern Wisconsin on a small family dairy farm. His father participated in land conservation and farmed carefully to avoid soil erosion, giving Rodney the bird&rsquo;s eye view to learn about the importance of both stewardship of the land, and erosion control.</p>

<p>On their farm, they practiced contour tillage (tilling perpendicular to a slope), strip cropping (alternating long strips of row crops, such as corn, with long strips of dense hay crops) &nbsp;and utilized &nbsp;grass waterways (broad, shallow channels planted in grass that &nbsp;move surface water across slopes without causing soil erosion).</p>

<p>In 1993, Rodney and his wife moved to Pennsylvania as Laurie accepted a position at the University of Pittsburgh. They bought a non-functioning farm with a great barn and nice farmhouse. Most of the land had grown in with trees. &nbsp;While it is beautiful to look at, Rodney says the most successful plants on the farm seem to be poison ivy, multi flora rose, and autumn olive, the latter two growing into dense thickets that can crowd out native species. &nbsp;Rodney worked in marketing communications as a freelance writer, specializing in product literature and direct mail for agricultural and equipment manufacturers.</p>

<p>Rodney and Laurie are the proud parents of William and Noah, whom they adopted from El Salvador and Guatemala, respectively. Their first adoption 27 years ago spurred an interest in the boys&#39; cultures, but Rodney did not get heavily involved in charity work in Central America until 2006.</p>

<p>At the Latin American Children&#39;s fund, Rodney and his team raise money for a rural medical clinic in El Salvador, as well as helping the poor with micro enterprises that build economic stability and self-worth. In Guatemala, a program provides scholarships to help children continue their educations past the sixth grade. Working with local charities that have &ldquo;boots on the ground,&rdquo; they direct their efforts toward issues that are way beyond the reach of rural poor and subsistence farmers.</p>

<p>Historic Harmony, Inc. was founded in 1943, and operates eight properties, including the 1809 Harmony Museum building, which interprets 250 years of rich history in western Pennsylvania. The group provides presentations that include the topics of George Washington&#39;s 1753 mission, the Harmonists, Mennonites, and the Ball Collection of outstanding sporting rifles by 19th century Harmony gunsmith Charles Flowers. Historic Harmony is also home to the oldest Mennonite meetinghouse west of the Allegheny Mountains. It was recently added to the National Register of Historic Places.</p>

<p>Two years ago, Historic Harmony, Inc. asked for PennFuture&rsquo;s help to take on a developer who planned to fill and develop a farm field in a flood plain. While Historic Harmony, Inc. wasn&rsquo;t able to stop the entire process, with PennFuture&rsquo;s help, the organization gained a better understanding of what it could do to prevent the size and scope of the development. Through these efforts, Historic Harmony, Inc. was able to identify and protect several acres of wetlands and prevent the development in the flood way.</p>

<p>Rodney first became interested in supporting PennFuture when Marcellus gas development became a larger statewide topic. Rodney and his wife were some of the first people to sign a Marcellus gas lease in Butler County, long before Marcellus, fracking, and horizontal drilling became household terms. They quickly learned that without strong rules and vigilant oversight, gas companies were prone to cut corners, especially on environmental issues. &nbsp;</p>

<p>&ldquo;Their goals are speed and profits, not land stewardship,&rdquo; notes Rodney. He and his wife felt it was fitting to put some of the money they received from gas development back into a group that would strive to enforce those rules, and be the watchdog over gas drillers and the legislature.</p>

<p>&ldquo;We got to thinking, who&#39;s going to speak for the environment? &nbsp;Businesses speak for their bottom line. &nbsp;Gas folks can influence the legislature. Who speaks for the land and the water and the air?&rdquo; Rodney thought PennFuture was the best group to stand up for those issues.</p>

<p>In terms of gas drilling, Rodney is not opposed to resource development, but feels that development must be done with a keen eye toward long-term environmental impact.</p>

<p>&quot;Initially, the technology of gas extraction was way ahead of the rules. &nbsp;We have made some progress, but if we didn&rsquo;t have an organization like PennFuture pushing back against the gas drillers and pipeline companies, we could easily repeat the environmental mistakes made In Pennsylvania in the 19th and 20th centuries&mdash;mistakes that gave us acid mine drainage, methane leaks, and abandoned strip mines,&rdquo; Rodney said.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
PennFuture thanks Rodney and Laurie for their monthly support.</p>
",Environment,"Susanne Whitehead, Director of Donor Relations"
Oil Trains: What is the Threat?,7/12/2017,"<p>People have lived amongst trains for more than 200 years. Trains are by far one of the oldest and most successful vehicles of world history, delivering goods and people quickly and efficiently across the United States and beyond.&nbsp;</p>

<p>While it is an incredible machine navigating an incredible rail system, I am often struck by a different perspective of the train, the goods they can carry, and what they represent.&nbsp;</p>

<p>I began to wonder and really think about oil trains about two years ago, when I discovered oil trains have been running through my community. Since then, oil trains have become one of my all-time favorite talking points, and learning about them has changed my life.&nbsp;</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s funny to me now that I have been hearing the whistle of these trains in the far away distance at night since I was a kid. I grew up in Southwest Philadelphia, and oil trains have been a part of my life for years even though I didn&rsquo;t know about them.</p>

<p>Now that I recognize oil trains&mdash;which can have more than 100 cars at one time&mdash;they are hard to miss. Just knowing the cars that they carry are filled with volatile crude oil has changed the way I see these trains.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Seeing the black tanker cars feels like a slap in my face, and an annoyance that keeps popping up in the most unexpected places. These black, pill-shaped disasters-just-waiting-to-happen continuously show up in our neighborhoods. I no longer have to search for them; instead it feels like they are looking for me.</p>

<p>The presence of oil trains in my city, and in the other communities is the embodiment of intimidation. My relationship with these black tanker cars has transformed into one that feels strange and slightly personal. In my head, oil trains are the physical representation of the terms, ideas and institutions that shape our reality. When I see oil trains, I hear the tanker cars whisper, &ldquo;capitalism,&rdquo; &rdquo;classism,&rdquo; &ldquo;colonialism,&rdquo; &ldquo;climate change,&rdquo; &ldquo;industry deregulation,&rdquo; and &ldquo;powerlessness.&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>See, in my eyes, fractivism (anti-fracking activism), and activism around the reality of oil trains are spiritual practices. There is a subliminal message that each tanker car delivers to the communities that they travel through, and a destructive aura that each tanker car exudes. When I look at these trains and listen to their sounds, I hear them spew messages like: &ldquo;This is how things are and will continue to be.&rdquo; &ldquo;You are powerless to change our fossil fuel economy.&rdquo; &ldquo;Your health and safety means nothing to the interests of industry and their beneficiaries.&rdquo; &ldquo;You are inferior to the systems that uphold destructive power dynamics.&rdquo;</p>

<p>But the movement and saying, &ldquo;STOP OIL TRAINS!&rdquo; have become a war cry for activists like me for this very reason. Halting the use of oil trains has the potential to end a lot of the negative things that travel with them. It can end community members having to ask questions like: &ldquo;What is in these tanker cars?&rdquo; or &ldquo;Where are these trains coming from?&rdquo;&nbsp;</p>

<p>And ultimately, if we stop oil trains, it can end community members having to ask, &ldquo;What will happen if one of these trains derails?&rdquo;</p>

<p>I am currently attending school in Kutztown, Pa. and I still see oil trains traveling through a nearby town named Topton. I haven&rsquo;t heard anyone in this area speak up against oil trains, which feels similar to my experience living in Southwest Philly, and even how I feel now living in Southeast Delaware County (where I have also seen many oil trains passing through).&nbsp;</p>

<p>One consistent observation that I&rsquo;ve had in all of these communities is that the people most impacted and most vulnerable to an oil trains disaster know little to nothing about the existence of them. And that is by far the most frustrating (and motivating) part of this work.</p>

<p>Whenever I travel or move I find oil trains and community members who don&rsquo;t yet know the danger traveling with those tanker cars.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We must inform the people who don&rsquo;t know about the presence and dangers of oil trains and get them involved in standing up for their communities. If we can take that first step together, and if everyone living in a neighborhood next to these oil train routes can also see the reality of oil trains that I see (as a slap in the face to all communities with a right to a safe environment), then I believe that we can begin to make a bigger push to move away from reckless fracking and fossil fuel transportation.</p>

<p><em><strong>Please join us in Philadelphia this Thursday, July 13 for a special premiere of an oil trains documentary, featuring Jeremy and his work. <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/oiltrains"">Click here for more details.</a></strong></em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Jeremy R. Griffin, Activist and Student at Kutztown University"
Managing Stormwater: A Leading Cause of Pollution,7/7/2017,"<div>Believe it or not: Stormwater is a leading cause of water pollution.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>When it rains or snows, the water flows on the ground, runs off solid (impervious) surfaces collecting pollutants (such as oil, pesticides, sediments, bacteria, and other pollutants) that are on those surfaces, and carries them into our waterways. This &ldquo;runoff&rdquo; can make our waterways an unhealthy place to live, work, and play. Untreated stormwater runoff entering our streams can result in the contamination of our drinking water supplies; prohibitions on swimming, fishing or boating uses; injury or death to aquatic plants and animals; dangers to public health; and increased flooding. &nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>In many places, this stormwater runoff is conveyed through distinct sewer pipes that bypass the wastewater treatment plants and discharge the polluted runoff directly into our streams and lakes. This system is known as a &ldquo;municipal separate storm sewer system&rdquo; or MS4.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>In addition to the damage to water quality from MS4s, local governments spend millions of dollars each year trying to rectify the damage to public and private property caused by uncontrolled stormwater runoff. &nbsp;This damage includes repairs to roads, culverts, water, sewer line washouts, flooded homes and yards, the removal of deposited sediment and debris on properties and roads, and repairs of damage to bridges.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Luckily, there are laws out there that protect our waters from polluted stormwater runoff. For example, stormwater from &ldquo;urbanized (define here what that means) areas&rdquo;, which are densely settled area that have population of at least 50,000 as designated by the U.S. Census Bureau, &nbsp;is controlled through a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit under the federal Clean Water Act. &nbsp;Under the NPDES program, the Environmental Protection Agency began issuing Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System (MS4) permits almost 30 years ago. &nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>In order to obtain coverage under an MS4 permit, permittees, including municipalities, must implement a Stormwater Management Plan (&ldquo;SWMP&rdquo;). &nbsp;These SWMPs must include the development and implementation of &ldquo;six minimum measures&rdquo; that prevent or reduce stormwater pollution to the maximum extent possible. The six minimum control measures are:&nbsp;</div>

<ol>
	<li>Public Education and Outreach on Stormwater Impacts</li>
	<li>Public Involvement/Participation&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Illicit Discharge Detection and Elimination (IDDE)</li>
	<li>Construction Site Stormwater Runoff Control&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Post-Construction Stormwater Management (PCSM)&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Pollution Prevention/Good Housekeeping&nbsp;</li>
</ol>

<div><a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/FINAL-Guidelines-for-Reviewing-and-Commenting-on-Municipal-Separate-Storm-Sewer-System-Minimum-Control-Measures.pdf""><strong>You can learn more about the MS4 program and the six minimum control measures here</strong></a>.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>In Pennsylvania, the Department of Environmental Protection (PADEP) administers the MS4program. &nbsp;PADEP issued its first general permit for MS4s in 2003. &nbsp;Although each permit is only supposed to be effective for five years, the PADEP&rsquo;s second MS4 general permit did not become effective until 2013. &nbsp;Even then, after over 10 years of the program&rsquo;s implementation, this second MS4 permit was woefully insufficient. &nbsp;PennFuture took issue with the inadequacy of the PADEP&rsquo;s MS4 program and filed an appeal of PADEP&rsquo;s approval of coverage under the MS4 general permit for Upper Gwynedd Township. &nbsp;(PA Environmental Hearing Board Docket No. 2013-105-L). You can read more about <a href=""https://pennfuture.org/cases"">PennFuture&rsquo;s claims here</a>.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>After over a year of negotiations, PennFuture and PADEP entered into a settlement which addressed PennFuture&rsquo;s most important objections, including providing an opportunity for public participation and requiring a demonstration that designated pollution reductions would occur. &nbsp;Thanks to PennFuture&rsquo;s diligence, PADEP was required to include these more stringent conditions in its next MS4 general permit proposal. &nbsp;Many of these conditions were incorporated into <a href=""http://www.elibrary.dep.state.pa.us/dsweb/Get/Document-112608/3800-PM-BCW0100d%20Permit%20SAMPLE%20with%20Signature%20(Final).pdf)"">the new five-year MS4 general permit,</a> which became final in June 2016 and goes into effect in March 2018.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Even though the new MS4 general permit does not go into effect until March of 2018, there are things that must be done now. &nbsp;This summer (2017) municipalities must prepare pollution reduction plans (PRPs) and make these plans available for public review and comment. &nbsp;The PRPs assist MS4 municipalities to understand their obligations regarding &ldquo;impaired&rdquo; waters and must include the following:</div>

<ul>
	<li>A detailed map,&nbsp;</li>
	<li>An explanation of the current pollutant loads in local waterways,&nbsp;</li>
	<li>A description of best management practices (BMPs) to be implemented over the five year term of the permit and demonstration that these BMPs will reduce pollutants by specified amounts,&nbsp;</li>
	<li>A description of how the municipality expects to pay for implementation of their plan, and&nbsp;</li>
	<li>A description of the operation and maintenance of proposed BMPs.</li>
</ul>

<p>PennFuture will be reviewing and commenting on some of these MS4 PRPs this summer, but we need engagement from community members to ensure that stormwater doesn&rsquo;t harm our waters. &nbsp;</p>

<div><strong>How you can make a difference:</strong>&nbsp;If you live in an <a href=""http://files.dep.state.pa.us/Water/BPNPSM/StormwaterManagement/MunicipalStormwater/Municipal_MS4_Requirements_Table.pdf"">MS4 municipality</a> &nbsp;and stormwater is polluting your local waters or causing damage to property, infrastructure, or drinking water near you, reviewing and commenting on these plans in your opportunity to encourage your municipality to properly address these problems. &nbsp;DEP has provided&nbsp;instructions on preparing a PRP you can <a href=""http://www.elibrary.dep.state.pa.us/dsweb/Get/Document-116283/3800-PM-BCW0100k%20PRP%20Instructions%20(3-28-17)%20(003).pdf)"">access here</a>. <strong><a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/FINAL-Guidelines-for-Reviewing-and-Commenting-on-Pollutant-Reduction-and-Total-Maximum-Daily-Load-Plans.pdf"">You can learn more about how to review and comment on your municipality&rsquo;s </a></strong><a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org/Files/Admin/FINAL-Guidelines-for-Reviewing-and-Commenting-on-Pollutant-Reduction-and-Total-Maximum-Daily-Load-Plans.pdf""><strong>PRP here</strong></a>.</div>
",Environment,"Alice R. Baker, Senior Staff Attorney"
Oil Trains and the Threat to Our Communities and Environment,7/6/2017,"<p>Oil trains are dangerous. On July 6, 2013 &ndash; exactly four years ago today - a runaway oil train brought tragedy and devastation to a community in in Lac-M&eacute;gantic, Quebec when it derailed and ignited 1.5 million gallons of crude oil, destroying buildings and ending the lives of 47 people.&nbsp;</p>

<p>On this four-year commemoration of that tragic event, trains continue to travel through Lac-M&eacute;gantic and many other communities, serving as a reminder of the risk we face when our reliance on dirty energy trumps the safety of our communities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>More than 700,000 Philadelphia residents (and more statewide) live in proximity to the rail routes that run crude oil near their yards, past their hospitals and childcare centers, and alongside their bike paths and highways. Trains carrying hazardous and highly flammable liquids even run alongside and cross our drinking water sources, even though the consequences of a spill or accident could impact the public health and safety of millions of people. In Pennsylvania, there is poor oversight of railroad bridges, a lack of transparency, and minimal access to rail maintenance records, along with insufficient penalties for regulatory violations.</p>

<p><strong>We cannot wait for another disaster to hit before taking action. </strong>We need stronger safeguards to protect our communities and our environment. As the federal government continues to pursue a regulatory reform agenda to &ldquo;alleviate unnecessary regulatory burdens,&rdquo; (1) we will continue to see threats to our health, safety, and natural resources in the pursuit of dirty energy production. One of the first things we can do to come together to defend our communities is to speak up with them. Jeremy Griffin is one Philadelphia resident who has decided to do just that, and share his story on oil trains and the risks that we face.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Here at PennFuture, we fight the big polluters and hazards that impact every community&rsquo;s access to clean water, clean air, and a safe environment. This is why we&rsquo;re excited to release our new documentary film on oil trains by hosting a special happy hour on Thursday, July 13 from 5:30-6:30 p.m. at our Philadelphia office.&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p><a href=""https://vimeo.com/222534442""><strong>Check out this exclusive sneak peek of the oil trains project</strong></a>&nbsp;and join us at this special premiere to view the film, and to share your own story and concerns with members of our community. <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/oiltrainsdocumentaryfilmpremiere/index.html?eType=EmailBlastContent&amp;eId=3fb71d8a-2467-4178-8536-f9676043d2e2""><strong>Please RSVP no later than 11:59 p.m. on Tuesday, July 11.</strong></a></p>

<p><em>(1)&nbsp;Presidential Executive Order on Enforcing the Regulatory Reform Agenda, Exec. Order No. 13777, 82 Fed. Reg. 92 (May 15, 2017) Federal Register: The Daily Journal of the United States. Web. 6 July 2017.</em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
",Environment,"Zakia M. Elliott, Southeast PA Outreach Coordinator"
Harrisburg Punts on Environmental Protection in the State Budget (Again),6/30/2017,"<div>At the 11th hour, the House, Senate, and Governor&rsquo;s office agreed to a General Appropriations budget for FY2017-18 that continues a funding crisis for environmental protection that started more than a decade ago.&nbsp;</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>The chief environmental protection agencies &ndash; Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) and Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR) - have been systematically underfunded. Under the auspices of tough budget times and belt tightening, key programs have been cut or eliminated. Staffing has been reduced, putting public health at even greater risk. Yet, the environmental challenges impacting Pennsylvania continue to grow.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><a href=""https://pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-A-Primer-on-Pennsylvanias-Water-Crisis-Challenges-Impacting-Every-Community"">For example, the Commonwealth&rsquo;s water pollution challenges are growing in every corner of the state</a>, yet the DEP&rsquo;s Operational Budget, which supports water programs, was cut another 3.85 percent from the previous year. Since 2002-03, DEP&rsquo;s Operations Budget is down nearly 34 percent. Growing Greener investments through the Environmental Stewardship Fund have decreased by 75 percent. And the budget deal cut the critical water commissions, including the Susquehanna River Basin Commission (SRBC) and Delaware River Basin Commission (DRBC), by a whopping 50 percent.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>There is truly only one way to describe the overall budget deal: it&rsquo;s awful for Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment.</strong> It ensures that the biggest challenges facing our public lands, water, air, and climate will not be addressed for at least another year, and probably longer.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div>Specifically, the following are some of the major concerns from the budget deal:</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><u><strong>Department of Environmental Protection</strong></u></div>

<ul>
	<li><strong>The overall General Fund DEP budget ($147.72 million):</strong>

	<ul>
		<li>2.04% cut compared to the FY16-17 budget</li>
		<li>38.93% cut compared to the FY02-03 budget</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
	<li><strong>DEP General Operations budget ($13.394 million):</strong>
	<ul>
		<li>3.85% cut compared to the FY16-17 budget</li>
		<li>33.88% cut compared to the FY02-03 budget</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
	<li><strong>Water Commissions take a devastating budget cut:</strong>
	<ul>
		<li>SRBC, DRBC, Rivermaster for the Delaware River, Interstate Commission for the Potomac River Basin, and Interstate Mining Commission all take a 50% cut compared to the FY16-17 budget</li>
		<li>Chesapeake Bay Commission budget held steady at $275,000</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
</ul>

<p><u><strong>Department of Conservation and Natural Resources</strong></u></p>

<p>The overall DCNR budget:</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>6.29% cut in General Fund appropriations compared to the FY16-17 budget</strong>

	<ul>
		<li>7.8% cut in General Fund appropriations compared to the FY02-03 budget</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
	<li><strong>Budget deal shifts money from Oil and Gas Lease Fund</strong>
	<ul>
		<li>The budget takes $50 million from the oil and gas royalties on state lands and provides it for General Operations</li>
		<li>It provides an additional $11.2 million from royalty revenue to the operations of State Parks and State Forests, which is an 83% reduction compared to the original House and Governor budget proposals</li>
		<li>The continued use of oil and gas royalty revenue for general operations raises questions due to the recent Supreme Court decision on interpreting Article 1, Section 27 of the state constitution.</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
	<li>Additionally, the budget deal does not include, at this time, the bond proposal introduced in the Governor&rsquo;s budget that would have increased DCNR&rsquo;s water program budgets significantly.</li>
</ul>

<div>For many of the issues impacting Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment, the costs will only continue to increase the longer they go unabated. One only has to look at the decades of inaction around coal mining impacts on our waterways and the $15 billion liability to the Pennsylvania taxpayer currently estimated to clean up those culm piles and streams. We&rsquo;re making similar mistakes with Pennsylvania&rsquo;s drinking water, unconventional drilling, climate change, and air pollution challenges.</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><strong>State budgets are the ultimate reflection of policymaking priorities and for over a decade, environmental protection has been cut, and in many instances eviscerated. Our state priorities are out of whack and need to be changed before the problems become intractable and the harm to our citizens grows more severe.</strong></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>
