PA streams: Let's protect the best of the best.,4/29/2015,"Anyone who spends time in the outdoors knows Pennsylvania has abundant water resources. With more than 86,000 miles of streams, we&rsquo;re second only to Alaska in the number of miles of streams. Although many thousands of these stream miles are polluted by a variety of sources, we are fortunate to find other rivers and streams in excellent health, capable of supporting a variety of fish and other aquatic life. The rivers and streams with the most outstanding water quality are afforded the greatest degree of protection, and are designated High Quality (HQ) or Exceptional Value (EV).<br />
<br />
Pennsylvania has a detailed process for protecting the existing use and designated uses of all HQ and EV waters. The public may petition the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) to upgrade a stream to HQ or EV if sufficient data exist to support the request, and partner agencies such as the Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission may do the same. The DEP regional office may also make a recommendation for a stream re-designation. Ultimately, all streams proposed for re-designation must be approved by the Pennsylvania Environmental Quality Board (<a href=""http://www.portal.state.pa.us/portal/server.pt/community/Environmental_Quality_Board/21511"" target=""_blank"">EQB</a>).<br />
<br />
Protecting streams through anti-degradation policies and <strong>ensuring that streams have the appropriate regulatory designation prior to permitting development activities</strong> within the watershed is critical to protecting the high quality of the Commonwealth&rsquo;s water resources, for today and for the future.<br />
<br />
Unfortunately, t<strong>he DEP has not proposed any stream re-designations to the EQB since September 2011.</strong> Since then, hundreds of miles of streams have been petitioned for upgrade with no formal action by the DEP to re-designate these streams and apply regulatory protections, mainly due to very limited staff.<br />
<br />
To remedy this, we recommend that Gov. Tom Wolf ensure that the DEP has adequate staff resources to ensure that streams receive appropriate stream designation under 25 Pa. Code Chapter 93.
<ul>
	<li>The DEP should have adequate staff designated: 1) to review stream re-designation petitions submitted by the public and by partner agencies, and 2) to conduct stream surveys to determine appropriate regulatory designations.</li>
	<li>The DEP should revise and streamline its internal process for reviewing stream re-designation petitions.</li>
	<li>The DEP should respond to petitions for stream re-designations in a timely fashion and propose rulemaking packages to upgrade or downgrade streams to the Environmental Quality Board (EQB) at least three times per year.</li>
</ul>
<br />
This recommendation, along with many others, can be found in a recent PennFuture report that highlights actions Gov. Tom Wolf and his administration can take to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment.<br />
<br />
Jen Quinn is central Pennsylvania outreach coordinator for PennFuture and is based in Harrisburg. She tweets @QuinnJen1.",Environment,Jen Quinn
2017-18 State Legislation Session: Looking Ahead,,"<p>Get ready for a wild ride.</p>

<p>That&rsquo;s the best way to describe what could happen when the Pennsylvania General Assembly begins a new, two-year session this week. It has only been two months since we wrapped up the 2015-16 session, which was marked by historic legislative attacks on environmental protection, but next year already portends to even worse outcomes.</p>

<p>While I don&rsquo;t have a crystal ball and can&rsquo;t tell exactly which bills will advance and which won&rsquo;t, here are some major stories to watch for that could have an outsized impact on environmental protection:</p>

<p>1.&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;High stakes around the Governor&rsquo;s veto: Governor Tom Wolf&rsquo;s veto pen is what stood in the way of the General Assembly gaming the Commonwealth&rsquo;s regulatory process so that legislators could unilaterally hold up new rules on polluters. The threat of a veto held up a number of other potential environmental rollbacks. But the November election has changed the dynamic of the General Assembly, providing for a one-party veto-proof majority in the Senate, and a very achievable 13 votes away from a veto-proof majority in the House. &nbsp;The Governor&rsquo;s decision whether or not to veto legislation now becomes even higher stakes.&nbsp;</p>

<p>2.&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Protecting Act 129: Act 129 is Pennsylvania&rsquo;s central energy efficiency program that is saving ratepayers money and cutting pollution. Yet, at the behest of a handful of large companies, the Senate passed SB 805 in October, which would dramatically cut funding for the program and lower its energy efficiency goals. The House ran out of time to advance the legislation, but the bill will be back in 2017 with more time to succeed.</p>

<p>3.&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Closing Pennsylvania&rsquo;s solar borders: Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Alternative Energy Portfolio Standard (AEPS) has a loophole that allows utilities to take credit for solar projects built in other states. Bipartisan legislation advanced in the House and Senate last session to close this loophole and ensure that solar projects are built in-state. Look for similar legislation to move in the new session.</p>

<p>4.&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;New subsidies for fossil fuels and nuclear plants: Three states have extended new subsidies to nuclear power plants, in part to keep zero-carbon electricity flowing to ratepayers. Pennsylvania&rsquo;s aging nuclear power plants are in a similar situation, and may require new legislation to keep them open. In addition, numerous bills aimed at subsidizing natural gas were proposed last session and may move under the new-look General Assembly.</p>

<p>5.&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Water pollution issues take center stage: Water pollution issues dominated the headlines in Pennsylvania last session with little legislative action. Whether its lead, PFOA&rsquo;s, cancerous fish in the Susquehanna, or cleaning up the Chesapeake Bay watershed, numerous high profile water pollution issues are knocking down the doors of the General Assembly. With a new two-year session to come up with solutions, there is little excuse for inaction.</p>

<p>6.&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Keeping electronics out of landfills: Pennsylvania&rsquo;s covered electronics recycling market is broken. New electronics are smaller and lighter than previous generations, yet the recycling mandate on electronics manufacturers are set by more recent sales. As a result, recycling quotas are being met earlier in the year, leaving many municipalities without a viable electronics recycling option. Without legislative change, more and more old televisions and large electronics will end up on street corners and landfills, potentially causing pollution concerns, in addition to the eyesore. A number of bills were filed last session to fix the issue and more legislative action is expected in 2017.</p>

"Fallacy, Fiction and Falsehoods: Debunking Myths about the Petrochemical Industry",,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-c882a10f-7fff-48ea-9d24-f8a2a16eb6d2""></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-c882a10f-7fff-48ea-9d24-f8a2a16eb6d2""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></p>

<p><em>Note: This is the first in an ongoing series of blogs taking a deeper look at the comments, misinformation, hyperbole, and criticisms from the natural gas and petrochemical industry as well as their allies in their attempt to sell Pennsylvanians on the virtues of its climate-killing sector. As we&rsquo;ve seen in other states, the industry often uses misinformation tactics to seow doubt, build political support, and put a wedge in public debate. These blogs will provide an easily digestible point/counterpoint to some of the most prominent statements, quotes, and attacks.</em></p>

<p><u><strong>Introduction and Context</strong></u><br />
Speaking at the Climate Action Summit in downtown Pittsburgh on Oct. 30, 2019, <a href=""https://www.nextpittsburgh.com/features/i-oppose-any-additional-petrochemical-companies-heres-what-mayor-peduto-said-at-the-climate-action-summit/"">Pittsburgh&nbsp;Mayor Bill Peduto announced</a> he would not support any further petrochemical development in western Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>The mayor&rsquo;s comments surprised&nbsp;environmentalists and industry supporters alike, albeit for different reasons.&nbsp;In the hours that followed his remarks, Peduto was subjected to harsh criticisms and attacks from those who have a very different vision for the future of western Pennsylvania.</p>

<p>It&rsquo;s no surprise that emotions are running so high. What&rsquo;s at stake is no less than the very future of millions of people. Pennsylvania is already home to one ethane cracker plant and could soon be home to another, as it was announced earlier this month that <a href=""https://www.wesa.fm/post/report-exxonmobil-scouting-property-2nd-cracker-plant-beaver-county#stream/0"">ExxonMobil is scouting for land in the area</a>. The next few months and years will shape the landscape &ndash; both economic and geographic &ndash; for decades to come.</p>

<p>Some of the statements and remarks issued against Mayor Peduto on Wednesday are at best ignorant and, at worst, intentionally false.</p>

<p><strong>Point: Building out natural gas and petrochemicals provides Pennsylvania both economic growth and a clean environment.</strong> David Spigelmyer, the president of the Marcellus Shale Coalition, stated that &ldquo;clean and abundant American natural gas is enabling economic growth or environmental progress for every single Pennsylvanian.&rdquo; He went on to say that some politicians &ldquo;push extreme or fringe bans on responsible energy development.&rdquo;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Counterpoint: Neither gas or petrochemicals is clean, rather both are and can make profound impacts on our environment. Pointing out their impacts is neither extreme or fringe.</strong> It is&nbsp;disingenuous to suggest there is anything &ldquo;clean&rdquo; about natural gas. Nothing about the extraction process&mdash;fracking, spills and leaks&mdash;is <a href=""https://www.inquirer.com/opinion/commentary/natural-gas-carbon-pollution-climate-change-20190708.html"">clean or sustainable for our communities or our environment</a>, and the methane that leaks during natural gas development and processing is <a href=""https://blogs.princeton.edu/research/2014/03/26/a-more-potent-greenhouse-gas-than-co2-methane-emissions-will-leap-as-earth-warms-nature/"">30 times more potent as a greenhouse gas</a> than carbon dioxide. Methane is one of the <a href=""https://unfccc.int/news/new-methane-signs-underline-urgency-to-reverse-emissions"">major contributors to climate change</a>.</p>

<p>A final point on Spigelmyer&rsquo;s statement: there is nothing &ldquo;extreme&rdquo; or &ldquo;fringe&rdquo; about standing up and fighting for clean air and clean water. Pennsylvanians have a constitutional right to both and western Pennsylvania has a long history of environmental damage borne from industry. The mayor&rsquo;s comments reflect on this history and the public health and environmental damage caused by the coal and steel industry. It&rsquo;s fair to question allowing another well known polluting industry access to the region, particularly after <a href=""http://cleanair.org/wp-content/uploads/HIA-Final.pdf"">decades of progress in cleaning up</a> our air and water.</p>

<p><strong>Point: Anyone who opposes the petrochemical buildout also opposes economic growth and new jobs for the region.</strong> Rep. Mike Turzai, who represents a portion of Allegheny County and serves as the speaker of the House of Representatives, said in a statement posted online Wednesday that Peduto&rsquo;s comments represent an &ldquo;anti-growth mindset that is both irresponsible and dangerous.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Counterpoint: Opposing petrochemicals is not an &quot;anti-growth mindset.&quot; It is a pro-public health mindset that puts the health of an entire region ahead of profits for global companies like Shell.</strong> In one sentence, Turzai calls the mayor&rsquo;s comments irresponsible and dangerous, but then turns around and supports turning western Pennsylvania <a href=""https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/oct/11/plastics-appalachia-next-cancer-alley-fracking-public-health-ethane"">into the next Cancer Alley.</a> Again, there is nothing irresponsible about supporting&nbsp;clean air and clean water.</p>

<p><strong>Point: The region doesn&#39;t have&nbsp;to choose between good jobs and clean air and water.</strong> Darrin Kelly, the president of the Allegheny/Fayette Central Labor Council, issued a statement saying &ldquo;it just isn&rsquo;t true that we have to choose between good jobs and clean air and water.&rdquo;</p>

<p><strong>Counterpoint: It&rsquo;s a false narrative that the petrochemical industry provides both good jobs and clean air and water</strong>. While there are many ways to advance both economic development and environmental progress, the petrochemical has no history of doing so. The Shell cracker plant <a href=""https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/12/business/energy-environment/plastics-shell-pennsylvania-plant.html"">will emit 2.2 million tons of carbon dioxide per year</a>, the equivalent of about 480,000 extra cars on our roads. It will also release <a href=""https://breatheproject.org/patrolling-our-air/"">more than 30 tons per year of hazardous air pollutants</a>&nbsp;like benzene, which is linked to cancer and childhood leukemia, and particulate matter linked to lung and bladder cancers.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Western Pennsylvania already has some of the <a href=""https://www.lung.org/our-initiatives/healthy-air/sota/city-rankings/states/pennsylvania/"">worst air quality in the entire country.</a> If someone staunchly and unapologetically supports Shell&rsquo;s petrochemical plant, and is also hopeful for more cracker plants to come, then that person&nbsp;is making a tradeoff that includes sacrificing public health for jobs. It&rsquo;s that cut and dried.</p>

<p>Peduto, unlike his critics, seems not to have forgotten <a href=""https://conserveland.org/blog/article-i-section-27-of-the-pennsylvania-constitution/"">Article 1, Section 27 of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s constitution</a>:</p>

<p>&ldquo;The people have a right to clean air, pure water, and to the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic and esthetic values of the environment. Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources are the common property of all the people, including generations yet to come. As trustee of these resources, the Commonwealth shall conserve and maintain them for the benefit of all the people.&rdquo;</p>

<p class=""MsoNormal"">Pennsylvanians have a right to clean air and clean water, and the petrochemical industry doesn&rsquo;t have permission to infringe on those rights &ndash; unless we grant them that permission. <o:p></o:p></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><br />
<span><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span><span id=""docs-internal-guid-c882a10f-7fff-48ea-9d24-f8a2a16eb6d2""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;""></span></span></p>

Introducing PennFuture’s New Legal & Policy Interns!,,"<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Since its inception in 1998, PennFuture has emphasized the importance of using the law to protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s environment and &ldquo;create a just future where nature, communities, and the economy thrive.&rdquo;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Over the past two decades, we have achieved significant legal and policy victories that reduce pollution and protect the environment and our communities. We have provided millions of dollars in pro bono legal services while setting critical precedents and enforcing environmental laws across the Commonwealth.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">But as PennFuture looks forward to the next 20 years, we recognize that we need to be more involved with cultivating the people that will continue to support our mission. Our staff have a long history of mentoring interns, externs, and fellows, and we wanted to create a more formal program to inspire the next generation.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">With the generous support of the George and Miriam Martin Foundation and the Otto Haas Charitable Trust, PennFuture created a paid legal and policy internship program to inspire and mentor students interested in making a difference for our environment.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Ultimately, the goal of this program is to provide the organization a cadre of young legal and policy minds interested in taking on the myriad challenges impacting Pennsylvania as well as to further their potential environmental careers. We also hope that providing for a funded internship will help to bring more diversity and inclusivity into the non-profit environmental advocacy sphere.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">This spring, we have two fantastic students for our internship, representing a range of backgrounds and experiences. We&rsquo;ve asked our new interns to explain, in their own words, what environmental law and PennFuture&rsquo;s mission means to them:</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;background-color:#ffffff;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;padding:0pt 0pt 12pt 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Lisa Dang, Third Year Student at Penn State Dickinson Law</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;background-color:#ffffff;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;padding:0pt 0pt 12pt 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">I have always had a penchant for environmental issues. During my undergraduate studies at William and Mary, I participated in a semester-long study abroad program in Cambodia and Vietnam, exploring environmental and climate change impacts on local communities located along the Mekong River. Immediately after undergrad, I worked at Environment Virginia, coordinating and implementing grassroots activities to advocate for environmental justice and renewable energy. Additionally, I interned at the Pennsylvania Utility Law Project (PULP), serving at-risk communities affected by utility and energy-related matters.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;background-color:#ffffff;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;padding:0pt 0pt 12pt 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">As a 3L at Penn State Dickinson Law, I have continued to pursue environmental policy and law classes, further driving my passion and commitment to help foster a more sustainable future. I spent significant time researching the feasibility of deploying solar technology in K-12 public school systems in Pennsylvania.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;background-color:#ffffff;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;padding:0pt 0pt 12pt 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">I am thrilled to be a part of the PennFuture team, working with passionate, diverse environmental law attorneys to tackle a wide range of environmental issues. I relish the opportunity to learn and help protect Pennsylvania&rsquo;s right to clean air, water, and environment.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;background-color:#ffffff;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;padding:0pt 0pt 12pt 0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Beyond work and school, I enjoy playing competitive ultimate frisbee. Currently, I play for DC Shadow and Scandal based in Washington, DC.</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; text-decoration-line: underline; text-decoration-skip-ink: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Caroline Weiss, graduate student at the University of Iceland in Environment and Natural Resources, with a specialization in environmental policy</span></span></p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">I am currently pursuing my Master&rsquo;s in Environment and Natural Resources at the University of Iceland, where I am specializing in environmental policy and management. Beginning my undergraduate study at the University of Pittsburgh, I had never envisioned myself double majoring in Environmental Studies and Political Science. Yet my introductory Environmental Science course, sustainability-focused extracurriculars, and childhood influence converged as I recognized my passion for environmental issues. <p dir=""ltr"" style=""line-height:1.38;margin-top:12pt;margin-bottom:12pt;""><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">Throughout my studies,I have been drawn to the social sciences and policy as tools to drive environmental change. I am eager to learn from PennFuture&rsquo;s talented team of environmental advocates this spring, especially regarding renewable energy policy issues in our state.</span></span></p>

<p><span id=""docs-internal-guid-58c91e36-7fff-7f12-a378-d5039ac81cad""><span style=""font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;"">PennFuture&rsquo;s legal and policy team is dedicated to restoring and protecting our environment and communities, to protecting our right to clean air and pure water, and to moving Pennsylvania toward a clean energy future. I thank our amazing staff and interns for their great work, and also our members for your continued support. We can&rsquo;t do this without you!&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<h2>Come back later for updates</h2>
",,
Let the Failed DNA Hydrogen Hub Go,,"<p>The Decarbonization Network of Appalachia (DNA) Hydrogen Hub put forward by <a href=""https://teampa.com/"">Team PA</a> failed to secure federal funding and lost two major industry backers, but TeamPA is still attempting to move forward with the Ohio-Pennsylvania-West Virginia dirty hydrogen project.</p>

<p>By building it in the heart of the Marcellus Shale region, the DNA Hub will allow high-polluting fossil fuel industries to survive market changes. Unfortunately, that means the communities of Southwestern Pennsylvania will continue to bear the brunt of terrible air quality, impacts to water and further destruction of Appalachia.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<h3><strong>Background on the Federal Hydrogen Hub Projects</strong></h3>

<p>In September 2022, the Department of Energy (DOE) announced that it was soliciting applicants for its <a href=""https://www.energy.gov/oced/regional-clean-hydrogen-hubs-0"">Regional Clean Hydrogen Hub Program (H2Hubs)</a>, which would direct billions of dollars to large-scale <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-The-Basics-of-Hydrogen"">hydrogen projects</a> across the nation through the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA).&nbsp;</p>

<p>A total of three applications included Pennsylvania:</p>

<ul>
	<li>ARCH2</li>
	<li>MACH2</li>
	<li>DNA H2Hub</li>
</ul>

<p>Each project claimed to leverage Pennsylvania&#39;s existing infrastructure, technology expertise, and skilled labor force. The promoters of the DNA project &ndash; which was not chosen by DOE to receive federal dollars&nbsp; &ndash; are attempting to press on anyway, despite the deep risk of environmental and human harm to Southwestern PA. Why? A peek behind the curtain provides some answers.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The <a href=""https://www.arch2hub.com/"">Appalachia Regional Clean Hydrogen Hub (ARCH2)</a> is a WV-OH-PA-based &ldquo;<a href=""https://rmi.org/clean-energy-101-hydrogen/"">blue</a>&rdquo; hydrogen project and will utilize fracked-gas methane along with carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies to produce hydrogen and mitigate carbon emissions. The <a href=""https://mach-2.com/"">Mid-Atlantic Clean Hydrogen Hub (MACH2) </a>is a PA-NJ-DE-based &ldquo;green&rdquo; hydrogen project and will utilize renewable energy to produce hydrogen. Both the ARCH2 and MACH2 projects advanced to the next round. However, the <a href=""https://www.decarbonizationnetworkofappalachia.org/"">Decarbonization Network of Appalachia (DNA)</a> project, another blue hydrogen hub based in OH-PA-WV, did not move forward. Getting denied billions of dollars in federal funding would be a good reason to scrap the project and move on, especially when another very similar project located in the same geography is moving forward. But Team PA, DNA&#39;s prime applicant, refuses to see the writing on the wall.</p>

<p>The DNA H2Hub promised to <a href=""https://teampa.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/DNAH2HubPublicSummary.pdf"">&quot;unlock affordable, clean hydrogen and decarbonize the supply chains, manufacturing, and power production in America&rsquo;s industrial heartland.&quot;</a>&nbsp; One of the clear goals of this project was to provide methane for polymer manufacturing for plastics production and energy production. This goal would be accomplished by doubling down on the fracked-gas methane production capacity in southwestern Pennsylvania. In essence, the project would seed and ultimately establish an artificial economic life-support system for the failing fracked gas industry, which is struggling to compete with low-cost renewable energy and is suffering from unfavorable market forces.</p>

<p>Southwestern Pennsylvania is home to some of the <a href=""https://www.lung.org/media/press-releases/pittsburgh-sota-2023#:~:text=The%202023%20%E2%80%9CState%20of%20the,year's%20report%20to%20a%20'C'"">most polluted communities</a> in the nation due to the legacy of steel, plastics, and refining operations based in the region. In fact, it is precisely this industrial history that makes it such an attractive place to try to seed hydrogen, a fuel that can be clean but can also just be a clean facade, or greenwashing. Communities here suffer the consequences of decades of hosting extractive, energy-intensive, and high-pollution industries. While there&rsquo;s no shame in the work folks here have done in the past, it&rsquo;s a simple fact that this legacy has left these communities economically dependent on these industries and struggling to emerge from under their smog-filled shadows. Locating the DNA H2Hub project in the heart of the Marcellus Shale region allows these high-polluting industries to continue this cycle of dependence,and the communities of Southwestern Pennsylvania will continue to be the ones holding the bag.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The fenceline communities in southwestern Pennsylvania don&#39;t want more methane fracked from the ground, transported through leaky pipelines, and converted into carbon dioxide and hydrogen. They want a sustainable and healthy economy based on renewable energy, energy storage, sustainable manufacturing, and family-sustaining union jobs.</p>

<h3><strong>Blue Hydrogen Fails Economics 101</strong></h3>

<p>Even the fossil fuel giants recognize that it is time to flip the switch. Both Shell and Equinor pulled out of the DNA project before the Biden administration even announced the winners of the DOE&#39;s program. Now, <a href=""https://theintercept.com/2022/07/30/blue-hydrogen-climate-oil-and-gas/#:~:text=Blue%20hydrogen%20produces%20no%20carbon,the%20most%20potent%20greenhouse%20gas."">Shell is working on green hydrogen projects in Europe, Australia, and India</a>. Meanwhile, Equinor, which is Germany&#39;s primary source for gas, is collaborating with several other energy companies to field test hydrogen technology - <a href=""https://www.renewableenergymagazine.com/hydrogen/abb-joins-hypilot-project-alongside-yara-equinor-20231030"">&quot;ultra-efficient electrolyzers&quot; with the ultimate goal of reducing the cost and &quot;facilitating the widespread adoption of large-scale green hydrogen production.&quot;</a></p>

<p>Why would these energy titans move their focus overseas to develop green hydrogen when the Marcellus Shale region is drowning in methane? Because they are profit-motivated, and the <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Turning-PA-into-a-Hydrogen-Hub-is-not-a-Sustainable-Energy-Solution"">economics for blue hydrogen do not make sense</a>. Equinor, in particular, can attest to the risk involved in developing blue hydrogen at-scale. The international company has a<a href=""https://www.climatechangenews.com/2022/02/15/experts-sound-alarm-oil-sectors-blue-hydrogen-push/""> history of failed attempts at CCS projects</a>. The company had to abort a CCS project because <a href=""https://www.tu.no/artikler/to-av-tre-prestisjeprosjekter-for-co2-lagring-er-mislykket/234802"">the reservoir was at risk of collapsing</a>, and a <a href=""https://www.tu.no/artikler/ma-bruke-to-milliarder-kroner-for-a-redde-snohvit-gassen/235227"">second was halted because the injected CO2 was polluting the methane extracted from the site</a>. What&#39;s more, when Equinor was known as Statoil in 2013, it shutdown its <a href=""https://www.equinor.com/en/news/archive/2013/09/20/20SepMongstad.html"">Mongstad CCS plant</a> after just about a year of operation. Through decades of trial and error, Equinor has experienced the economic and technical challenges of blue hydrogen, and rather than continuing to invest in technology that consistently fails in both arenas, it is moving in a new direction.</p>

<p>Recently, Team PA offered a <a href=""https://files.dep.state.pa.us/PublicParticipation/Citizens%20Advisory%20Council/CACPortalFiles/Meetings/2024_01/Team%20PA%27s%20Hydrogen%20Presentation%20to%20DEP%20CAC%20-%20Thomas%20Murphy.pdf"">presentation</a> about the MACH2, ARCH2, and DNA hub projects to the Department of Environmental Protection&#39;s (DEP) <a href=""https://files.dep.state.pa.us/PublicParticipation/Citizens%20Advisory%20Council/CACPortalFiles/Meetings/2024_01/January%202024%20CAC%20Agenda%20-%20Version%202.pdf"">Citizens Advisory Council (CAC)</a>. During that presentation, Thomas Murphy, the Senior Managing Director of Strategic Energy Initiatives, said that in spite of two of its major partners pulling out and a lack of federal funding, the organization was moving forward with the project and would continue to collaborate with Mitsubishi. <strong><em>In the face of contrary market forces, lack of government investment, unproven technology, and abandonment by industry leaders, maddeningly, Team PA insists on doubling down on methane-derived hydrogen.&nbsp;</em></strong></p>

<p>The bottom line is that blue hydrogen isn&rsquo;t climate friendly. Even when operating at its most efficient, experts argue that the blue hydrogen technology available right now is only 78% effective at capturing its carbon emissions. It takes additional energy input for carbon capture technology to run, which means that<a href=""https://www.climatechangenews.com/2022/02/15/experts-sound-alarm-oil-sectors-blue-hydrogen-push/""> &quot;due to the increased amount of fossil gas needed to power the CCS process, blue hydrogen likely had a 20% higher carbon footprint than burning methane alone.&quot;</a> This should be said again: blue hydrogen, which supposedly takes a high impact fuel and makes it lower-impact, actually has a higher footprint than if it was never created in the first place. This is why groups like PennFuture are calling for <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Chasing-the-Rainbow-Carbon-Capture-is-Magic-Thinking"">investment in renewables first</a>, before throwing good money at bad technologies that perpetuate fracking and all of the negative health outcomes and economic failures that come with it.</p>

<h3><strong>The DNA Hub Will Only Perpetuate the Harms of the Past</strong></h3>

<p>Team PA claimed that the DNA hub would improve the economic conditions for workers by providing good-paying jobs for a &quot;marginalized, underserved, and fossil fuel-dependent region.&quot; In reality, it would maintain the status quo by offering the same hollow promises that the fossil fuel industry has offered for centuries, refusing to acknowledge the real threats that this project poses to the environment and, consequently, to workers and local communities. Simply put, the DNA H2Hub, if completed, will perpetuate the boom-bust economic cycle created by the extraction of both fossil fuel and labor resources with detrimental environmental and health consequences.</p>

<p>It would behoove Team PA, the Commonwealth, fenceline communities, and workers to follow Equinor&#39;s lead. Pennsylvanians - especially the most vulnerable, disaffected, and disenfranchised among us - do not need more empty promises and cycles of a boom-bust economy. We need a stable economy, a stable climate, and a healthy environment. Ironically, fossil fuels seem to be going the way of the dinosaur. And yet Team PA seems unwilling to recognize this fact.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pennsylvania needs Team PA to read the writing on the wall and pivot. They need to focus on serving the residents and workers of the Commonwealth, instead of chasing a scheme designed to keep the fracked gas industry afloat and funneling resources away from real solutions like renewables, battery storage, and building a sustainable economy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Going forward PennFuture will be focusing our efforts on pushing Pennsylvania towards a better economic future. Every day you can find our staff and members testifying before the legislature, holding polluters accountable in our courts and advocating for better environmental policies in our communities.&nbsp; To support this work, please consider<a href=""http://www.pennfuture.org/donate""> becoming a member today</a>!&nbsp;</p>

The Importance of Agriculture to Clean Water,,,,
The Opportunity for Green Stormwater Infrastructure in Philadelphia’s Rebuild Initiative,,"<p>By combining the goals of Green City, Clean Waters and the Rebuild Community Infrastructure (Rebuild) Initiative, Philadelphia can align two major infrastructure investments and multiply its investment in its residents, our neighborhoods, and the environment.</p>

<p>The Rebuild Initiative, made possible by the Philadelphia Beverage Tax, is investing hundreds of millions of dollars in physical improvements to our neighborhood parks, recreation centers, and libraries. From a list of more than 400 eligible sites, the Rebuild office is prioritizing neighborhoods that face high rates of poverty, drug crime, and poor health outcomes. It is selecting facilities where investment will promote community development and stabilization, as well as sites that are in extremely poor condition. It is currently moving forward on revitalizing more than 50 sites.</p>

<p>In addition to making physical improvements to these sites, Rebuild prioritizes engaging community members in the site planning and design process as well as promoting diversity and economic inclusion through small business and workforce development initiatives.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Parks, recreation centers, and libraries offer many social and community benefits. Libraries create opportunities for learning and access to important services. Parks and recreation centers are areas where neighbors gather for play, exercise, social interaction and other leisure activities. They also serve as safe spaces for our city&rsquo;s residents. Studies have shown that having access to parks or green space can reduce stress and contribute to improved general psychological health and well-being for people who live or work nearby.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Rebuild represents a major investment in our city and its people. Another major city investment &ndash; Green City, Clean Waters &ndash; creates very similar tangible benefits for residents while also creating a cleaner and more resilient environment. Green City, Clean Waters is Philadelphia&rsquo;s 25-year stormwater management program initiated in 2011 that invests primarily in green stormwater infrastructure (GSI) to manage combined sewer overflows. As stormwater runs off roads, parking lots, and roofs it picks up oil, dirt, and other pollutants that make their way to storm drains.</p>

<p>Approximately sixty percent of Philadelphia&rsquo;s storm drain system is a combined system that mixes stormwater with household wastewater. Most large storms cause untreated sewage to overflow directly into local rivers and creeks. The Philadelphia Water Department defines GSI as a &ldquo;soil-water-plant system that intercepts stormwater, infiltrates a portion of it into the ground, evaporates a portion of it into the air, and in some cases releases a portion of it slowly back into the sewer system.&rdquo; GSI tools reduce pollution and flooding events by naturally slowing and filtering rainwater before it enters the city&rsquo;s stormwater system.</p>

<p>Green City, Clean Waters&rsquo; cornerstone is the tangible benefits beyond Clean Water Act compliance that other approaches cannot achieve. GSI implementation has the potential to accomplish substantial triple bottom line benefits&mdash; economic, social, and environmental. GSI creates community green space, revitalizes vacant lots, enhances recreational use, and even has the potential to reduce illegal drug use in public spaces. It decreases heat stress and energy use while improving air quality and contributing to climate change resiliency. It also stabilizes property values and reduces poverty through job creation.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Philadelphia Water Department (PWD), the agency tasked with implementing Green City, Clean Waters, exerts minimal direct control over city property. PWD cannot accomplish all necessary public GSI projects without strong partnerships with other city agencies and stakeholder communities. Parks and recreation centers are more than just the physical buildings &ndash; they are situated on impervious surfaces and open spaces, thereby providing ideal opportunities to manage stormwater with GSI.</p>

<p>While the Rebuild Initiative process includes a commitment to sustainability, communities can advocate for GSI projects that provide additional benefits. The Rebuild Initiative is prioritizing community engagement to inform the improvements made to facilities. Public participation in GSI and parks and recreation center design is essential for achieving the positive community benefits they are expected to create.</p>

<p>Residents can advocate for GSI in the Rebuild Initiative by attending Rebuild community engagement events, meeting with park advisory committees, friends groups, and civic associations, requesting GSI be implemented in design plans, meeting with their city council members to discuss Rebuild investment, and writing a letter to the editor in support of GSI investment in their Rebuild site.</p>

<p>Green Stormwater Infrastructure is integral to Philadelphia&rsquo;s economy, environment, and social equity. If you agree, please sign our petition <a href=""https://pennfuture.salsalabs.org/keepphillygreenandwaterclean/index.html"">here</a>, which will be delivered to city council.</p>
",Keep Philly Green & Water Clean,
The People Have A Right: A Brief Overview Of Environmental Rights Amendment Case Law,,"<p>Pennsylvania&#39;s Constitution provides a unique Environmental Rights Amendment that guarantees our right to clean air, pure water, and to the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic and esthetic values of the environment and requires the Commonwealth to conserve and maintain Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources for the benefit of all people. Since the ERA&rsquo;s adoption in 1971, Pennsylvania courts have had the task of determining what it means. PennFuture constructs a brief history of the Environmental Rights Amendment court cases and the decisions that interpret and apply this important law.&nbsp;</p>

<h2>&nbsp;</h2>

<h2>In the Beginning&nbsp;</h2>

<p style=""text-align: center;""><strong>Commonwealth v. National Gettysburg Battlefield Tower, 311 A.2d 588 (Pa. 1973)&nbsp;</strong><br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p>In one of the earliest cases brought under the ERA, the Attorney General sought to prevent a private company from constructing a 307-foot observation tower 700 feet from Gettysburg National Military Park. The Attorney General argued that the tower violated the ERA because it would despoil the natural and historic values of the battlefield. The Pennsylvania Supreme Court held that the ERA did not, by itself, allow the government to stop the actions of private parties in the absence of some other law prohibiting the activity. Since the ERA does not define things like &ldquo;clean air,&rdquo; &ldquo;pure water&rdquo; and &ldquo;historic value,&rdquo; allowing the government to bring suit against private parties for interfering with those values would mean that &ldquo;individuals could be singled out for interference by the awesome power of the state with no advance warning that their conduct would lead to such consequences.&rdquo;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<h2>The Payne Era&nbsp;</h2>

<p style=""text-align: center;""><strong>Payne v. Kassab, 312 A.2d 86 (Pa. Cmwlth. 1973), affirmed by Payne v. Kassab, 361 A.2d 263 (Pa. 1976)&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p style=""text-align: center;"">&nbsp;</p>

<p>The next major ERA decision came in 1976. Residents of Wilkes-Barre claimed that the ERA prevented PennDOT from paving over a portion of a public park to widen a highway because doing so would harm the historic value of the park. The Commonwealth Court rejected &ldquo;such an absolute interpretation&rdquo; of the ERA and instead held that the ERA was intended to allow &ldquo;controlled development of resources rather than no development.&rdquo; The Court concluded that the ERA requires a balancing of environmental concerns and other legitimate government interests. It also devised a three-part test to assess whether the proper balancing had taken place. This test, which came to be known as the <em><strong>Payne test</strong></em>, asks:&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li>Was there compliance with all applicable statutes and regulations relevant to the protection of the Commonwealth&rsquo;s public natural resources?&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Does the record demonstrate a reasonable effort to reduce the environmental incursion to a minimum?&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Does the environmental harm which will result from the challenged decision or action so clearly outweigh the benefits to be derived therefrom that to proceed further would be an abuse of discretion?&nbsp;</li>
</ol>

<p>The Court held that the paving of a portion of the park to widen the highway satisfied this test and was thus permissible under the ERA. On appeal, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court did not explicitly affirm the Commonwealth Court&rsquo;s three-part test but agreed with the lower court that &ldquo;it is manifest that a balancing must take place&rdquo; between&nbsp; the environmental values protected by the ERA and other important societal values.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Commonwealth Court&rsquo;s decision in <strong>Payne v. Kassab</strong> ushered in a nearly forty-year period of failed ERA claims. Because the first prong of the <em>Payne test</em> asks whether the challenged action complies with all applicable statutes and regulations, the question of whether any particular action violated the ERA effectively collapsed into the question of whether the action complied with other environmental laws. Under the <em>Payne test</em>, where no other law was violated, the ERA provided no additional protection for the environment. In addition, the <em>Payne test</em> effectively dictated that no action could violate the ERA unless the environmental harm &ldquo;clearly outweighed&rdquo; any benefit to be gained by the action. In practice, courts rarely found this to be the case.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>Other important decisions also came out of the Payne era, for example:&nbsp;</p>

<p style=""text-align: center;""><strong>Community College of Delaware County v. Fox, 342 A.2d 468 (Pa. Cmwlth. 1975)&nbsp;</strong><br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p>Residents argued that the Department of Environmental Resources (DER) violated the ERA by issuing a permit allowing the Central Delaware County Authority to expand sewer service. The residents argued that the permit would induce additional development in environmentally sensitive areas, leading to potential water pollution effects. The Commonwealth Court rejected this argument because it concluded that the ERA cannot expand the powers of a state agency like DER. Instead, the ERA operates &ldquo;only to limit such powers as have been expressly delegated by proper enabling legislation.&rdquo; The General Assembly had not given DER the authority to consider the effect of future land development when deciding whether to issue permits, so the ERA could not be used to compel DER to consider or make decisions based on such concerns.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Robinson Township&nbsp;</h2>

<p style=""text-align: center;""><strong>Robinson Township v. Commonwealth, 83 A.3d 901 (2013)&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>In 2013, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court reinvigorated the ERA with its decision in <strong>Robinson Township v. Commonwealth</strong>. In this case, several municipalities, environmental advocacy organizations, and other parties challenged amendments to the Pennsylvania Oil and Gas Act, known as Act 13. Among other things, the challengers argued that Act 13 violated the ERA because it forced every municipality in the Commonwealth to allow oil and gas drilling by right in all zoning districts.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>In its decision, the Court opined that the Commonwealth Court&rsquo;s ERA decisions up until that point had weakened the meaning of the ERA by tending to define the ERA&rsquo;s broad constitutional rights in terms of compliance with various other laws. It criticized the Payne test, saying that it was not based on the text of the ERA, improperly narrowed the scope of the ERA, and minimized the constitutional duties of the non-legislative branches of government. A better analytical scheme was needed.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Providing that analytical scheme, the Court explained that the ERA is structured in &ldquo;three mandatory clauses that define rights and obligations.&rdquo; The first clause establishes Pennsylvanians&rsquo; right to clean air, pure water, and to the preservation of the natural, scenic, historic, and esthetic values of the environment. It operates to protect the people from governmental action that unreasonably causes actual or likely deterioration of these features. This clause does not impose an express duty on the government to enact specific affirmative measures to promote clean air, pure water, and the preservation of different values of the environment, but it does impose an obligation to refrain from unduly infringing upon that right by legislative or executive action.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The second and third clauses work together. The second clause guarantees the common ownership of the people, including future generations, of Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources. This applies to a narrower category of &ldquo;public&rdquo; natural resources than is covered by the first clause, but nevertheless implicates relatively broad aspects of the environment, including state-owned lands and other resources that &ldquo;implicate the public interest&rdquo; such as ambient air, surface and ground water, and wild plants and animals.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The third clause establishes a public trust&mdash;a type of legal relationship whereby the Commonwealth as &ldquo;trustee&rdquo; must conserve and maintain Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources (called the &ldquo;corpus&rdquo; of the trust) for the benefit of all Pennsylvanians, present and future, referred to as &ldquo;beneficiaries&rdquo; of the trust. The Court explained that this means that the Commonwealth has a duty to conserve and maintain Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources with prudence, loyalty and impartiality. It also means that the Commonwealth must prevent and remedy degradation, diminution, and depletion of those resources, whether they occur through direct state action or due to the state&rsquo;s failure to restrain the actions of private parties. The Commonwealth&rsquo;s trustee obligations are both negative and affirmative, meaning that the Commonwealth not only has a duty to prevent degradation of public natural resources, but to act affirmatively to protect the environment by passing laws.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Court went on to caution that the ERA does not call for a stagnant landscape, the derailment of economic or social development, or the sacrifice of other fundamental values. It is not intended to stop development. Rather, the ERA means that economic development cannot take place at the expense of unreasonable degradation of the environment.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />
The Court also explained that the ERA imposes obligations and limitations on all branches and levels of government&mdash;including local government&mdash;because the quality of the environment is a task with both local and statewide implications. Because the ERA is a constitutional command, the General Assembly cannot take away local governments&rsquo; responsibilities under it, nor can it remove the necessary and reasonable authority local governments need to carry out their constitutional duties. Therefore, the Court held, the portion of Act 13 that removed local governments&rsquo; authority to decide where oil and gas operations may be located within their boundaries violated the ERA and must be struck down.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Post-Robinson Township&nbsp;</h2>

<p>Only three of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court&rsquo;s seven justices agreed with the reasoning in Robinson Township, although a fourth agreed with the outcome based on a different rationale. This meant that the provisions of Act 13 that forced municipalities to allow oil and gas development in all zoning districts were invalidated, but the Court&rsquo;s analysis of the ERA did not become binding precedent on lower courts. Because a majority of the Supreme Court had not conclusively rejected the Payne test, the Commonwealth Court continued to apply it for several more years, until the Supreme Court definitively rejected it in a case known as PEDF II.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>PEDF II</h2>

<h2>&nbsp;</h2>

<p style=""text-align: center;""><strong>Pa. Envtl. Def. Found. v. Commonwealth, 161 A.3d 911 (Pa. 2017) (PEDF II)&nbsp;</strong><br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p>The next significant ERA decision by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court came in 2017. In this case, the Pennsylvania Environmental Defense Fund (PEDF) challenged the leasing of state-owned land for oil and natural gas development and the budgetary scheme that dispersed the revenue from those leases. This scheme redirected over $330 million that would have been used for conservation purposes under prior law to the General Fund, where it was appropriated for a variety of state government purposes unrelated to maintaining and protecting public natural resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Court began its analysis by decisively rejecting the <em>Payne test</em>, stating that it was unrelated to the text of the ERA and stripped the ERA of its meaning. This time, four Supreme Court justices agreed with this holding, finally spelling the end of the <em>Payne test</em>. The four-justice majority also affirmed Robinson Township&rsquo;s statement of basic ERA principles, thus solidifying those principles into binding precedent. The Court went on to elaborate on the Commonwealth&rsquo;s trustee duties, firmly grounding these in private trust law. These duties include the duty of loyalty, which imposes an obligation to manage the corpus of the trust so as to accomplish the trust&rsquo;s purposes for the benefit of the trust&rsquo;s beneficiaries, and the duty of impartiality to treat all beneficiaries equitably in light of the purposes of the trust. The Commonwealth&rsquo;s discretion as to how to handle Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources is limited by these trustee duties and the purpose of the trust.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Court also held that the proceeds from the sale of public natural resources, including the sale of oil and gas from public lands, are to be considered part of the corpus of the trust and must be dealt with in the same way as other public natural resources. Therefore, the Commonwealth is not entitled to spend that revenue on general budgetary items in any way it sees fit; those funds must be directed toward the purpose of the trust&mdash;conserving and maintaining Pennsylvania&rsquo;s public natural resources. Accordingly, the Court held that the budgetary provisions that took revenue generated from the sale of oil and gas on state lands and placed them in the General Fund without requiring the Commonwealth to put them toward conserving and maintaining public natural resources violated the ERA.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The remainder of the Court&rsquo;s decision, as well as several subsequent decisions, dealt primarily with characterizing the precise nature of the revenue generated by oil and gas leases and the precise scope of the activities that could be funded with that revenue. For example, in a later case, <strong>Pennsylvania Environmental Defense Foundation v. Commonwealth, 279 A.3d 1194 (Pa. 2022)</strong>, the Supreme Court held that a trustee is entitled to incur reasonable costs in administering the trust, and, therefore, oil and gas revenues could be used to fund general operating expenses of the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources such as salaries, wages, and travel expenses for its employees.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Recent Cases&nbsp;</h2>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the years since Robinson Township and the PEDF cases, Courts have tended to focus on language in those two seminal cases stating that the ERA protects only against unreasonable degradation of natural resources and &ldquo;does not call for a stagnant landscape&rdquo; or &ldquo;require a freeze of the existing natural resource stock.&rdquo; Although Payne&rsquo;s explicit balancing test has gone by the wayside, courts have continued to view the Commonwealth&rsquo;s ERA obligations in terms of a balance between the duty to maintain and conserve natural resources for the benefit of all the people and other legitimate government interests. The effect has been that, when specific government actions have been challenged, courts have focused on whether the challenged action represents an appropriate balance between environmental interests and other concerns or is instead an unreasonable degradation of the environment. In nearly all cases, courts have decided that the appropriate balance has been struck and no unreasonable degradation has or will occur. Often, these decisions have resulted from what courts or local decision-making bodies have found to be inadequate evidence of alleged environmental harms.&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>One such case is <strong>Frederick v. Allegheny Twp. Zoning Hearing Bd., 196 A.3d 677 (Pa. Cmwlth. 2018)</strong>. In this case, residents of Allegheny Township challenged a zoning ordinance that permitted fracking by right in all zoning districts, subject to various restrictions. The Commonwealth Court held that the challengers had not produced sufficient evidence that fracking was harmful to the environment or public health and, even if they had, Township had appropriately balanced those concerns against the economic benefits of fracking.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />
Courts have also doubled down on the principle, first articulated in <strong>Community College of Delaware County v. Fox</strong> in 1975, that the ERA does not give executive branch agencies like the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) additional powers or authority beyond what the General Assembly has given them by statute. On multiple occasions, courts have held that DEP and other agencies like it cannot create regulations, make decisions, issue or deny permits, or take any other actions based on ERA concerns if there is no state statute allowing them to do so. For example, the <strong>Commonwealth Court in Marcellus Shale Coalition v. Department of Environmental Protection, 193 A.3d 447 (Pa. Cmwlth. 2018)</strong>, invalidated a regulation that required DEP to consider impacts to species of special concern when issuing permits for oil and gas development because the statute that created the permitting scheme only authorized DEP to consider impacts to endangered and threatened species.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>The same applies to municipalities, who cannot act beyond the powers given to them by the General Assembly. For example, in <strong>Frederick v. Allegheny Township</strong>, the Court held that municipalities lack the power to replicate the environmental oversight that the General Assembly has conferred upon DEP and other state agencies.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Conclusion</h2>

<p>Courts continue to wrestle with the ERA and the implications of Robinson Township and PEDF II. Courts have never directly addressed what preservation of the &ldquo;scenic&rdquo; and &ldquo;esthetic&rdquo; values of the environment means. The scope of what constitutes &ldquo;public natural resources&rdquo; also remains largely unexplored. Questions remain as to the nature of the Commonwealth&rsquo;s duty to act affirmatively to protect the environment by passing laws. Few cases have delved deeply into the question of what &ldquo;prudence, loyalty, and impartiality&rdquo; look like in the context of preserving and maintaining public natural resources. The Pennsylvania Supreme Court has not elaborated on the proper approach to balancing the rights guaranteed by the ERA with other legitimate government interests like promoting economic development, and it is unknown whether it will approve of the two-part test created by the Commonwealth Court in Frederick Township.&nbsp;</p>

<p>As these questions percolate through the courts, PennFuture&rsquo;s legal team is dedicated to protecting and defending our fundamental constitutional right to a healthy environment through litigation and regulatory commenting. To learn more about PennFuture&rsquo;s legal efforts on the ERA, visit [page]</p>
",Environment,"Brigitte Meyer, Staff Attorney"
The State of Solar Development in PA: Solar Energy Benefits Remain Unrealized,,"<p>According to the <a href=""https://www.dep.pa.gov/Citizens/solar/Pages/default.aspx"">Pennsylvania&nbsp;Department of Environmental Protection</a>, solar energy currently contributes less than 1 percent of the state&rsquo;s total electricity generation. Despite overall <a href=""https://www.seia.org/state-solar-policy/pennsylvania-solar"">increases across the state</a>, slow solar growth in PA does not align with the rapidly declining costs of installation,<a href=""https://www.energy.gov/eere/solar/homeowners-guide-federal-tax-credit-solar-photovoltaics""> available tax credits</a>, and myriad health benefits of prioritizing solar over fossil fuels. There are more reasons than ever to act quickly to secure Pennsylvanians&rsquo; economic, environmental, and social wellbeing, all of which would be augmented by increased deployment of solar energy.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To clarify why Pennsylvania decision-makers must take urgent action to invest in, expand access to, and amplify the co-benefits of solar energy, PennFuture recently released a <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Publication-White-Paper-Solar-Energy"">new report on solar energy.</a> This paper sets the record straight on commonly held myths about solar and recommendations to overcome the largest obstacles to solar energy adoption.&nbsp;</p>

<h3><span style=""color:#696969;"">Solar Myths and Misconceptions</span></h3>

<p>Several myths and misconceptions have led to confusion and worry about the construction of both utility-scale and<a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Why-Go-Solar""> residential solar</a>.</p>

<p><strong>A few key points correcting common misinformation include the following:</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Pennsylvania receives ample sunshine to make solar generation effective.</li>
	<li>Solar arrays <a href=""https://www.reuters.com/business/sustainable-business/with-agrivoltaics-we-dont-have-choose-between-solar-power-producing-food-2023-03-20/"">can coexist with working farms</a>, providing farmers with a sustainable source of income and the opportunity to maximize profit through agrivoltaics &mdash; the co-location of solar panels and agriculture. Unlike permanent housing developments, solar development and agricultural land use are not mutually exclusive.</li>
	<li>Well-designed modern solar systems are designed to mitigate concerns about erosion, groundwater contamination, and glare.</li>
	<li>The reuse, recycling and decommissioning of solar panels is feasible and sustainable. Many panels will continue to generate electricity long after a system is decommissioned and can be used in other applications. When it is time to retire the panels, <a href=""https://www.energy.gov/sites/default/files/2022-02/Solar%20Energy%20Supply%20Chain%20Report%20-%20Final.pdf"">90% of their&nbsp; components are recyclable</a> with current technology, which is continually improving.</li>
</ul>

<p>In addition to the threats posed by solar myths, solar development in PA also faces more concrete legislative obstacles. Bills currently awaiting action in the PA legislature could further solidify the state&rsquo;s dependence on fossil fuels, prevent local efforts to incentivize solar, and burden solar development with greater bonding requirements than dirtier industries. Pennsylvania also lacks bills that strengthen solar access; to combat this issue, lawmakers should enable community solar and <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-Misguided-Homeowner-Association-Restrictions-Block-Pennsylvanias-Solar-Potential"">curtail HOA solar restrictions</a>.</p>

<h3><span style=""color:#696969;"">Move Forward from Pennsylvania&rsquo;s Legacy of Dirty Energy and Polluted Air</span></h3>

<p>Solar energy offers a key opportunity to <a href=""https://www.pennfuture.org/Blog-Item-What-We-Learned-from-the-December-2022-Deep-Freeze-Dont-Rely-on-Natural-Gas-When-Its-Fracking-Cold-Part-1."">enhance the security of our energy grid</a>, create <a href=""https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy22osti/82213.pdf"">thousands of jobs</a>, <a href=""https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy07osti/41998.pdf"">improve air quality, and reduce health impacts</a> caused by fossil fuel emissions.</p>

<p><strong>Policy Recommendations:</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Pennsylvania should increase its solar energy goals through higher Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards (AEPS) targets. The previous AEPS solar goal (0.5% of the 8% renewable energy goal) was attained in 2021, and a more ambitious target is needed. PennFuture supports <a href=""https://www.legis.state.pa.us//cfdocs/Legis/CSM/showMemoPublic.cfm?chamber=S&amp;SPick=20230&amp;cosponId=40010"">PA Senate Bill 230</a>, which would increase the renewable energy goal to 30% by 2030 and permit community solar.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Pennsylvania must encourage solar power development on brownfields and through use of agrivoltaics. The state has plenty of space for solar, especially since solar is a more preferable investment for farms than permanent-conversation developments. Additionally, the Eastern Pennsylvania Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation has found that there are more than <a href=""http://epcamr.org/storage/Abandoned_Mine_Land_Pgm_Fact_Sheet.pdf"">200,000 acres of abandoned mine land in PA</a>, which could potentially host solar farms.</li>
	<li>Pennsylvania needs to implement legislation supporting residential solar access, community solar, and more equitable bonding requirements. Rather than perpetuating the dominance of polluting fossil fuels, PA lawmakers must instead focus on pro-solar policies that will yield greater long-term advantages for their constituents.</li>
</ul>

<p>PennFuture continues its work promoting clean energy and a sustainable future for all Pennsylvanians. Solar energy is undoubtedly a crucial climate solution that is more affordable than ever. Continued solar restrictions, limited funding for renewable infrastructure, and subsidies for dirty energy are simply illogical and are doing a disservice to future generations.</p>
",Energy,"Rob Altenburg, Senior Director for Energy and Climate"
